Howard will be a TE1 if healthy Sunday against Atlanta.  If he sits, Cameron Brate is a plug-and-play option at the weak position.
report: O.J. Howard (knee) was a limited participant at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Howard is less than two weeks removed from a sprained MCL but is trending toward playing Sunday against the Falcons. He'll be in an excellent spot against Atlanta's beat-up secondary.
report: O.J. Howard (knee) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Much to the dismay of Cameron Brate owners, O.J. Howard was surprisingly a full participant in practice Friday. If ruled active, expect Howard to play outside the 20-yard line with Brate continuing to soak up a majority of red zone looks. It's a terrific opportunity for both against a Falcons defense missing five key defenders Sunday.
report: O.J. Howard (knee) is questionable for Week 6 against the Falcons.

impact: Howard was initially expected to miss a couple of games after suffering a sprained MCL in Week 4, but he is ready to go coming out of the bye week. He might be limited, but Howard will be tough to sit considering the landscape at tight end. With Howard back, Cameron Brate is more of a desperation option.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports O.J. Howard (knee) is expected to play Week 6 against the Falcons.

impact: This was the expectation after he got in a full practice Friday. It is possible Howard is limited coming off a sprained MCL, but he is a back-end starter at a weak position. Bucs declared OG Alex Cappa, CB Carlton Davis (groin), QB Ryan Griffin, OL Michael Liedtke, DT Rakeem Nunez-Roches, DE Noah Spence, and RB Shaun Wilson inactive for Week 6.
report: O.J. Howard (knee) is active Week 6 against the Falcons.

impact: Howard was not limited at all despite coming back quickly from his sprained MCL. HIs first catch of the game was a 10-yard touchdown in which he out-muscled a linebacker, and but he really took over in the second half, catching three passes for 52 yards. Apparently fully healthy, Howard will be a TE1 next week against the Browns.
report: O.J. Howard hauled in all four of his targets for 62 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Howard's nine targets were the most he's had in a game this season. His best play of the day came on a 24-yard catch over a defender in which he was down at the 2-yard line. Howard now has 20 catches for 351 yards and two scores through six games and will be a lower-TE1 option in Week 8 against a Bengals team that has struggled to defend the tight end position all season.
report: O.J. Howard caught 5-of-9 passes for 67 yards in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: Hyper efficient as usual, Howard's 18-yard score narrowed the deficit to two points late in the fourth quarter, and Chris Godwin tied the game with a two-point conversion one play later.  The Bucs went on to lose in overtime.  Even though Howard is not heavily targeted, he is catching everything in sight and making big plays.  He will be an upside TE1 play in Week 9 at Carolina.
report: O.J. Howard caught 4-of-4 targets for 68 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 8 loss to the Bengals.

impact: Howard's scores, his fourth and fifth of the season, went for three and four yards. The first came on a "counter boot." The second, Howard was sent in motion and created a sufficient amount of space. Today was actually Howard's first healthy game since Week 1 where he failed to clear 60 yards. He will be a top-five tight end for Week 10 against the Redskins.
report: O.J. Howard caught 4-of-6 targets for 53 yards and a pair of touchdowns in the Bucs' Week 9 loss to the Panthers.

impact: Cameron Brate had one catch for 14 yards on three targets as the Redskins blanketed the Bucs' tight end duo.  Howard will get back on track next week as a lock-and-load TE1 on the road against the lowly Giants.
report: O.J. Howard caught his lone target for 15 yards in the Bucs' Week 10 loss to the Redskins.

impact: The Giants have struggled against tight end of the year, so it wasn't shocking to see Howard get back on track. He was being checked on the sideline by trainers for a brief period during the team's final drive, so there was actually room for an even bigger day had he stayed on the field. He'll be a TE1 again next week against the Niners.
report: O.J. Howard caught 5-of-6 targets for 78 yards in the Bucs' Week 11 loss to the Giants.

impact: Initial testing revealed "good news," but the Bucs have ordered up more just to be sure. Howard was injured on the Bucs' final drive against the Giants. We should have a good idea of his status by the time the Bucs release their first Week 12 injury report on Wednesday.
report: O.J. Howard is getting a second opinion on his ankle.

impact: Howard suffered both injuries on the same play late in Sunday's loss to the Giants. It's the second-straight season the No. 19 overall pick of last year's draft will end on injured reserve. Howard was also felled by his ankle as a rookie. Howard was in the midst of a genuine breakout campaign, turning 34 catches into 565 yards (16.6 YPC) and five touchdowns. He cleared 50 yards in 8-of-10 healthy appearances. Still only 24, Howard will be a TE1 pick in next year's drafts. As for 2018, Cameron Brate is now a must add in all formats and will be in the TE1 mix from here on out.
report: Bucs placed TE O.J. Howard on injured reserve with foot and ankle injuries, ending his season.

impact: Unlike last week, it was DeSean Jackson (5-112) who benefited immensely as the Bucs trailed 38-3 after two quarters. Evans' nine targets were still a team-high, with Adam Humphries (6-36) seeing seven. Evans has proved to be a true WR1 with Jameis Winston, who replaced Ryan Fitzpatrick at the half, under center and that should continue once the Bucs return from their Week 5 bye.
report: Mike Evans hauled in 6-of-9 targets for 59 yards in the Bucs' Week 4 loss to the Bears.

impact: It is an extremely disappointing result considering Jameis Winston threw for 395 yards and four touchdowns. That said, Evans did not make any glaring mistakes or play poorly. He just did not really get the opportunities. That should change next week against the Browns.
report: Mike Evans hauled in 4-of-5 targets for 58 yards in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: After two slow weeks with 107 yards combined through the air, Evans led the Bucs across the board in receiving on Sunday. With Denzel Ward following DeSean Jackson, Evans worked mostly on Damarious Randall on the afternoon. After scoring a touchdown in each of the opening three weeks of the season, Evans has failed to reach the end zone over the past three games. Despite that, he remains a high-end WR1 option in Week 8 on the road against the Bengals.
report: Mike Evans caught 7-of-10 targets for 107 yards in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: Evans' highlight-reel play was a 72-yard touchdown bomb delivered by Ryan Fitzpatrick.  The Bengals' zone coverage couldn't account for Evans as he got lost behind the defense and caught Fitzpatrick's throw wide open in stride.   Unfortunately, Evans appeared to tweak his leg or knee late in the fourth quarter.  We thought it might have been a cramp.  Hopefully, the Bucs will shed some light on whether Evans is injured in the near future.
report: Mike Evans caught 6-of-13 targets for 179 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 8 loss to Cincinnati but left late with a leg injury.

impact: Evans suffered the injury late in last week's loss to Cincinnati. He had a monster game before getting hurt, producing a season-high 179 yards on six catches. This is more than just a simple maintenance day, though it's too early to speculate on his status for Sunday's game in Carolina.
report: Mike Evans (knee) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: It puts Evans on track to suit up against the Panthers, though his status can't quite be taken for granted. How Evans rebounds on Friday will be the final hurdle to clear. Having a monster season with Ryan Fitzpatrick at the controls, Evans will be locked and loaded as a WR1 if he suits up against the Panthers.
report: Mike Evans (knee) returned to a limited practice on Thursday.

impact: Evans didn't practice Wednesday and was limited Thursday. Getting taken off the injury report confirms he's fully healthy. After a downswing with Jameis Winston at quarterback, Evans should benefit from the Bucs turning back to Ryan Fitzpatrick.
report: Mike Evans (knee) was removed from the Week 9 injury report.

impact: Evans entered halftime 0-of-6, and things did not get better after the break. Evans was the intended "target" on Ryan Fitzpatrick's first interception. Fitz sailed the ball 10 feet over his receiver's head. Evans had previously balled out with Fitz under center, but the quarterback had little time to throw today. The Bucs get Josh Norman and the Redskins in Week 10.
report: Mike Evans caught just 1-of-10 targets for 16 yards in the Bucs' Week 9 loss to the Panthers.

impact: This appears to be a maintenance day for Evans, who also got a breather last Wednesday before being removed from the injury report entirely on Friday. Coming off his worst game of the season, Evans will look to bounce back Sunday against Washington. Josh Norman's presence limits Evans to low-end WR1 status for Week 10.
report: Mike Evans (knee) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: Coming off a game where he caught just 1-of-10 targets, Evans got a Wednesday breather. He will be safe to fire up as a WR1 against the Redskins.
report: Mike Evans (knee) returned to a limited practice on Thursday.

impact: The Bucs removed him from the injury report after he was upgraded to full participation at Friday's practice. Going against a Redskins secondary that was just torched by Julio Jones, Evans will be a rock-solid WR1 when he takes the field in Week 10.
report: Mike Evans (knee) wasn't listed on the Buccaneers' final injury report for Week 10 against the Redskins.

impact: It's an improvement off of Evans' 1-16 day on 10 targets last week, but Evans looked like he was going to have a bigger day when he had 28 yards on two grabs early in the first half.  The Bucs totaled nearly 500 yards of offense but didn't score a touchdown.  Ryan Fitzpatrick had Evans wide open for a two-yard score in the fourth quarter but spiked it right at his feet then fumbled on the very next play.  Evans will be a WR1 next week against the Giants.
report: Mike Evans caught 3-of-6 targets for 51 yards in the Bucs' Week 10 loss to the Redskins.

impact: Evans was well on his way to another disappointing afternoon before Ryan Fitzpatrick was benched in the second half. Jameis Winston came in and promptly peppered Evans with targets, including a 41-yard touchdown bomb that sailed over the watchful eye of CB Janoris Jenkins. He had caught just 4-of-16 targets for a lowly total of 67 yards in his previous two performances, so this outing was needed for both Evans and his owners. He'll have an extremely tough matchup on paper against the Niners and Richard Sherman in Week 12, but can't possibly be benched whether it's Winston or Fitzpatrick under center throwing to him.
report: Mike Evans hauled in 6-of-7 targets for 120 yards and one touchdown in the Bucs' near-comeback loss to the Giants.

impact: His biggest play was a first-quarter gain that came directly in Richard Sherman's coverage for 42 yards, setting up Cameron Brate's six-yard touchdown.  Evans has now gone over 100 yards in consecutive games.  Week 13 opponent Carolina held Evans to 16 yards on ten targets in the teams' earlier-season meeting.  Evans will look to exact his revenge on James Bradberry in the rematch.
report: Mike Evans caught 6-of-8 targets for 116 yards in the Bucs' Week 12 win over the 49ers.

impact: Evans saw fewer targets than Adam Humphries and didn't have many red-zone looks. It's a disappointing game with DeSean Jackson sidelined. This breaks a two week stretch of at least 100 yards for Evans. Evans should rebound in blowup Week 14 spot against the Saints.
report: Mike Evans caught 4-of-6 targets for 48 yards in the Bucs' Week 13 win over the Panthers.

impact: Henry rushed just 10 times for 26 scoreless yards and played just 20 snaps to Dion Lewis' 47.  Henry also had a 62-yard touchdown wiped off the board due to a Delanie Walker holding call.  Anytime the Titans fall behind, Henry's playing time is going to be a concern because he simply hasn't been a productive pass-game member in his college or pro careers.  Henry needs to be treated as a high-ceiling, low-floor RB2/3 this week against the Texans.
report: Derrick Henry said he is "pissed" about his Week 1 performance against the Dolphins.

impact: It was a tremendous game script for Henry, who will typically be called upon to ice games when the Titans are trying to secure a lead. He out-carried Dion Lewis 18-14, but both struggled mightily for breathing room without starting tackles Jack Conklin and Taylor Lewan available. Henry merely averaged 3.1 YPC, slightly better than Lewis' 3.0 Sunday. With only one target under his belt through two weeks of play, Henry (albeit immensely talented and an able receiver out of Tennessee's backfield) can't be considered anything more than a touchdown-dependent RB4 until further notice.
report: Derrick Henry rushed 18 times for 56 yards in the Titans' Week 2 win over the Texans.

impact: It's a new injury, but the limited practice suggets it's not a Week 3 concern. With Tennessee's offensive line banged up, Henry has a shy-away matchup with Jacksonville.
report: Derrick Henry (back) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: There's been no indication Henry is in danger of missing Sunday's game against the Jaguars. From both an opponent and game-flow standpoint, the matchup could not be more poor. Henry is a fringe RB3 for Week 3.
report: Derrick Henry (back) remained "limited" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Henry was removed from Tennessee's injury report and was a full participant in Friday's practice. Even so, he's been out-snapped, out-targeted, and has received fewer carries than teammate Dion Lewis so far this season. Henry is merely an RB3/RB4 stuck in a terrible matchup in Week 3.
report: Derrick Henry (back) is expected to play in Week 3 against the Jaguars.

impact: He was targeted once and didn't catch it.  Henry did out-touch Dion Lewis 18 to 12, but he remains scoreless on the year and has no passing-game role.  Henry will remain a touchdown-or-bust flex option in Week 4 against the Eagles.
report: Derrick Henry rushed 18 times for 57 yards in the Titans' Week 3 win over the Jaguars.

impact: Henry opened the day on a positive note with a 13-yard catch and a 14-yard run, but that was about it for the struggling running back. He did have a nice eight-yard run in overtime, but he played far fewer snaps than Dion Lewis in a game the Titans were trailing throughout the second half. On the bright side, Marcus Mariota looked healthy in this one, which should open up the running game and create more scoring opportunities. Henry will be an interesting DFS play in a bounce-back spot next week against the Bills.
report: Derrick Henry rushed eight times for 24 yards and caught two passes for seven yards in the Titans' Week 4 win over the Eagles.

impact: Dion Lewis out-touched him 15 to 11.  Henry drew just one target and missed it, and he is averaging one target per game five weeks in.  He is also scoreless on the year.  Henry will be a poor flex option in Week 6 versus Baltimore.
report: Derrick Henry rushed 11 times for 56 yards in the Titans' Week 5 loss to Buffalo.

impact: The only positive to takeaway is that Henry out-carried teammate Dion Lewis 7-5. He still averaged just 3.0 YPC on the day and has seen one target per game this season. As a touchdown-dependent back who hasn't scored a touchdown, he's droppable if a roster spot is needed.
report: Derrick Henry rushed seven times for 21 yards and caught his only target for five yards in the Titans' dreadful Week 6 loss to the Ravens.

impact: This was one of the better games of the season for Henry. He saw fewer touches than Dion Lewis but converted a goal-line carry for his touchdown. Henry added 30 yards on two catches and looked good when the Titans got him in open space. With Marcus Mariota getting closer to full health, Henry's ROS value is slightly trending up.
report: Derrick Henry had 12 carries for 33 yards and a touchdown in Week 7 against the Chargers.

impact: He also caught both of his targets for five yards, his seventh and eighth catches of the season.  The six carries marked a new season-low, as Dion Lewis set a new season-high with his 19 and 23 touches in total.  Lewis has flipped the script the past few weeks and taken over as the No. 1 back by a wide margin.  Henry has scored touchdowns in back-to-back games, but it's clear he's now nothing more than a short-yardage guy.  Henry is a bottom-barrel RB3/4.
report: Derrick Henry rushed six times for 27 yards and one touchdown in the Titans' Week 9 win over the Cowboys.

impact: Scoreless for nearly the entire first half of the season, Henry's TDs are now coming in bunches with four over his last three games.  He hit pay dirt on a goal-line score late in the first half, then danced in from a Wildcat formation in the fourth before icing the game with multiple clock-killing runs.  Henry was still out-touched by Dion Lewis 22 to 11 and has no passing-game role.  Henry will remain a touchdown-or-bust flex option when the Titans visit Indianapolis next.
report: Derrick Henry rushed 11 times for 58 yards and two touchdowns in the Titans' Week 10 rout of the Patriots.

impact: Most of Henry's yardage came in the second half of a non-competitive game. The Titans' offense was completely off the rails today, especially once Marcus Mariota departed with an elbow injury. With only two teams on bye for Week 12, Henry will be a last-gasp FLEX option against the Texans.
report: Derrick Henry rushed nine times for 46 yards in the Titans' Week 11 loss to the Colts.

impact: Henry was the target on Marcus Mariota's lone incompletion on 23 attempts.  He also lost a fumble at the end of a 12-yard catch-and-run on the final Mariota completion in the fourth quarter.  Henry out-produced Dion Lewis, but neither was good in this one.  Henry isn't a glowing fantasy option heading into Week 13 against the Jets, though he's always a candidate for a short score.
report: Derrick Henry rushed eight times for 30 yards and caught 2-of-3 targets for 19 yards in the Titans' Week 12 loss to the Texans.

impact: He caught his two targets for five yards.  This has become the new norm for Henry -- minimal yards and a short touchdown.  He's a boom-bust RB3/FLEX in standard leagues.  The same will be the case next week vs. Jacksonville.
report: Derrick Henry rushed 10 times for 40 yards and one touchdown in the Titans' Week 13 win over the Jets.

impact: Rudolph didn't see his first target until there was about five minutes left in the third quarter.  Both Vikings backup TEs David Morgan and Tyler Conklin caught a pass before Rudolph was targeted, but Rudolph saved his day with the red-zone touchdown.  His lack of targets is still alarming, especially after Rudolph was targeted just once in the preseason despite playing a full game's worth of snaps.  Rudolph will be a TD-or-bust TE1 next week in Green Bay.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught 1-of-2 targets for an 11-yard touchdown in the Vikings' Week 1 win over the 49ers.

impact: It was the quietest 72 yards in history. Rudolph did get loose for 23 yards in the third quarter, but that was his only catch of more than 12. Still, it was a welcome bounceback after Rudolph went for just 11 yards total in Week 1. He will be a back-end TE1 next week against the Bills.
report: Kyle Rudolph hauled in 7-of-8 targets for 72 yards in the Vikings' Week 2 tie with the Packers.

impact: Rudolph was one of the primary beneficiaries from the Vikings' 27-0 first half deficit. His lone score came in garbage time with less than two minutes to play while Minnesota was still getting blanked. Even so, the touchdown alone was enough to vault him into the top-three at his position in Week 3. The Rams have been exploited by tight ends in the middle of the field so far this season, so expect another juicy outing from Rudolph Thursday night.
report: Kyle Rudolph hauled in 5-of-6 targets for 48 yards and one touchdown in the Vikings' Week 3 loss to the Bills.

impact: All five of his catches came before halftime as Rudolph was targeted just once over the final two quarters. The Notre Dame alum has been reasonably effective in the early going, logging five-plus catches in each of his last three games. Playing on the road against the Eagles’ elite defense, Rudolph belongs on the lower end of the TE1 spectrum next week.
report: Kyle Rudolph secured five-of-six targets for 57 yards Thursday in the Vikings’ Week 4 loss to the Rams.

impact: That's as standard issue as a Rudolph game gets. Rudolph has two scores through five games. He's an uninspiring, but consistent and locked in, TE1. The Cardinals are on tap for Week 6.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught 5-of-5 targets for 41 yards in the Vikings' Week 5 win over the Eagles.

impact: It's another standard Rudolph game. Rudolph has just two touchdowns this season and hasn't scored since Week 3. He'll be a back-end TE1 against the Jets in Week 7.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught four passes for 37 yards in Week 6 against the Cardinals.

impact: Rudolph has been held below 50 yards in 5-of-7 games and hasn't scored since Week 3.  However, he remains a TE1 at a weak position going into a potential shootout next week at home against a bad Saints defense.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught just 1-of-4 targets for 16 yards in the Vikings' Week 7 win over the Jets.

impact: Rudolph had a pair of red-zone targets he couldn’t come down with. He was ruled out of bounds on a touchdown that was overturned. Rudolph has been an afterthought in a Vikings pass offense the goes through Adam Thielen and Stefon Diggs. He hasn't scored since Week 3.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught 4-of-7 targets for 39 yards in Week 8 against the Saints.

impact: Rudolph hasn't scored since Week 3 and has been held below 50 yards in 7-of-9 games.  He has zero upside.  Fantasy owners can find more tight ends capable of breakout weeks rather than continuing to use Rudolph.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught both of his targets for 28 yards in the Vikings' Week 9 win over the Lions.

impact: Rudolph continued to be a non-factor in a pass game that goes through Adam Thielen and Stefon Diggs. He has just one game over 70 yards this season. Rudolph hasn't scored since Week 3.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught 2-of-5 targets for 13 yards in Week 11 against Chicago.

impact: Both were season highs. Rudolph still couldn't find the end-zone, but this was a step in the right direction. Rudolph will be a touchdown-dependent TE2 for Week 13 against the Patriots.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught seven passes for 63 yards in Week 12 against the Packers.

impact: Rudolph didn't have a huge impact on the game, though he did contribute one highlight, pulling in a 23-yard catch over Patrick Chung with time winding down in the first half. It's been a frustrating season for the eighth-year tight end, who will take a nine-game touchdown drought into next week's action against Seattle. He's best viewed as a TE2 going forward.
report: Kyle Rudolph nabbed three catches for 38 yards on three targets Sunday in the Vikings’ Week 13 loss to the Patriots.

impact: It will be Crowder's fourth-straight absence. The Thursday rule out does not bode well for Crowder's Week 10 status.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) has been ruled out for Week 9.

impact: Crowder hasn't played or practiced since Week 5. The fourth-year Duke alum is likely headed for a fifth straight absence. Maurice Harris should occupy Crowder's slot role Sunday against Tampa Bay.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) remained sidelined at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Crowder has missed the past four games. This gives him a shot at returning in Week 10, but it should still be considered far from certain. Crowder's return would be well timed, as the Redskins are adjusting to life without Paul Richardson.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) returned to Redskins practice on Thursday, getting in a limited session.

impact: Crowder resumed practicing on Thursday, though it's unclear if he'll be ready for Sunday's game in Tampa Bay. Maurice Harris would become an interesting DFS play if Crowder can't get the green light.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is questionable for Week 10 against the Buccaneers.

impact: Crowder practiced on Thursday but ultimately won't be ready for Sunday's game in Tampa Bay. The Bucs have been exploited by slot receivers this season, putting Maurice Harris firmly in play with Crowder now officially out. Josh Doctson and Michael Floyd will be in three-wide sets with Harris, but neither are viable options on the outside.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is out for Week 10 against the Bucs.

impact: He's been out for well over a month.  "He's not quite 100 percent coming in and out of his cuts," coach Jay Gruden said.  "I don't think he's totally comfortable with it.  Hopefully by Thursday he has a chance."  Filling in for Crowder in Sunday's win over the Bucs, Maurice Harris gained 52 yards on five catches.
report: Jamison Crowder needs another MRI on his long-troublesome ankle.

impact: Crowder is looking at another missed game. He hasn't played since Week 5.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) didn't practice Wednesday.

impact: We'd be stunned if Crowder plays this week. Maurice Harris will continue to fill in at slot receiver.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) remained sidelined at Thursday's practice.

impact: Crowder hasn't seen the field since Week 5. The only surprise is that the Redskins haven't already placed him on injured reserve. This is the last thing Crowder needed in his contract year.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is out for Week 11 against the Texans.

impact: It's progress for Crowder after he was limited in practice all week.  Crowder hasn't played since Week 5 but could return Thursday.  If he does play, it would be bad news for Trey Quinn, who went 4-49 out of the slot last week.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is questionable for Week 12 against the Cowboys.

impact: This will be Crowder's seventh-straight absnece. Also inactive for the Redskins are RB Chris Thompson, RB Samaje Perine, CB Adonis Alexander, LB Pernell MCPhee LB Zach Vigil and DL Caleb Brantley.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is inactive for Week 12 against the Cowboys.

impact: Crowder has a chance to return after missing the last seven weeks. Even if active, he'll likely play limited snaps in his first game back.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) was limited at Friday's practice.

impact: Crowder looks on track return after missing the last seven games. There's high target share potential for Crowder in a checkdown heavy Colt McCoy offense but he'll be hard to trust after an extended layoff. Crowder's presence would relegate Trey Quinn (questionable, ankle) to four-wide sets.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is questionable for Week 13 against the Eagles.

impact: Crowder will be making his first appearance since Week 5.  He should slide right back into slot duties with rookie Trey Quinn (ankle) now inactive.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is active for Week 13 against the Eagles.

impact: Crowder was playing for the first time since Week 5.  He was the top slot man in this one, but Mark Sanchez threw for just 100 yards in relief of Colt McCoy (broken leg, 50 yards).  Crowder has no ceiling and a scary-low floor moving forward with Sanchez under center.  He doesn't need to be owned.
report: Jamison Crowder caught all four of his targets for 36 yards in the Redskins' Week 13 loss to the Eagles.

impact: Lynch may not get in a full practice all year. At age 32, he doesn't need to. Beast Mode will be ready to rock and roll against Cleveland in Week 4. He'll be taking a three-game touchdown streak into that matchup.
report: Marshawn Lynch (shoulder) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: The Raiders have been limiting Marshawn's practice reps all year. He's in no danger of missing Week 4 against Cleveland.
report: Marshawn Lynch (shoulder) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Lynch has been following this pattern most of the season, practicing on a limited basis throughout the week before being removed from the injury report on Friday. Beast Mode will be safe to fire up as an RB2 Sunday against Cleveland.
report: Marshawn Lynch (shoulder) wasn't listed on the Raiders' final injury report for Week 4 against the Browns.

impact: Lynch's highlight came on a pitch play where he got to the perimeter of the Browns' defense and followed an impressive downfield block by Martavis Bryant to gain 59 yards.  Lynch failed to score due to repeated goal-line stuffs, but this was his biggest rushing-yardage performance since 2014 with Seattle.  Lynch now has 20 or more touches in three straight games.  In an improving Raiders offense, he will be a high-end RB2 play in Week 5 at the Chargers.
report: Marshawn Lynch rushed 20 times for 130 yards and caught 3-of-5 targets for 27 yards in the Raiders' Week 4 win over the Browns.

impact: The Raiders have been managing Lynch's practice reps all year.  Lynch is a high-end RB2 for Week 5 at the Chargers.
report: Marshawn Lynch (shoulder) didn't practice Wednesday.

impact: Lynch was just getting a breather on Wednesday. He'll be fine to play his normal snaps Sunday against the Chargers. The 32-year-old has already put up 300 rushing yards this year, which ranks fourth in the league behind only Ezekiel Elliott, Todd Gurley and Matt Breida.
report: Marshawn Lynch (shoulder) returned to practice on Thursday.

impact: Lynch was previously listed with his shoulder. Lynch will be a high-end RB2 for Sunday's matchup with the Chargers.
report: Marshawn Lynch was limited in Thursday's practice with an abdomen issue.

impact: Lynch was limited by an abdominal injury at Thursday's practice, but there was never any doubt about his status for Sunday's game. When asked about the possibility of scaling back Lynch's workload, coach Jon Gruden said, "We’ll just keep feeding him Skittles and keep sending him out there as long as he can." Coming off a 157-yard eruption last week against Cleveland, Beast Mode is a worthy RB2 in all formats.
report: Marshawn Lynch (abdomen) wasn't listed on the Raiders' final injury report for Week 5 against the Chargers.

impact: Lynch's volume goes as the Raiders' game script goes, and the Raiders' game script got completely out of hand in this one. Jalen Richard even got involved late with Oakland in full-on catch-up mode, finishing with six catches on the day. Lynch is still averaging 15.4 carries and has received at least 18 in Oakland's three competitive games this season. With Seattle next up, Lynch should resume the RB2-usage we're accustomed to.
report: Marshawn Lynch rushed nine times for 31 yards, adding two catches for 10 yards in the Raiders' Week 5 romping by the Chargers.

impact: "I talked to the team about it," rep Drew Rosenhaus said. "His issue was unrelated to the tweet or his relationship with the team." We actually take Rosenhaus at face value that Brown does not want to be traded. His tweet was clearly just a frustrated player blowing off steam to a Twitter troll. As for Brown's Monday absence, the team has yet to say it was excused. We are not expecting any long-term consequences, but the sides' relationship is certainly looking a bit frosty right now.
report: Antonio Brown's agent insists his client does not want a trade and says his Monday absence was related to a "personal matter."

impact: This non-story of a "story" should disappear within the week.  Brown's bigger concern is a calf issue he gutted through in the second half in the Week 2 loss.
report: Antonio Brown returned to the team on Wednesday.

impact: "He and I met yesterday for an extended period of time," said Tomlin. "I'll leave the nature of that conversation between us. There was discipline involved for his missed meeting on Monday." It's been an eventful week for Brown, who got into it with OC Randy Fichtner on the sidelines in Sunday's loss to Kansas City, then tweeted "Trade me, let's find out" in response to a Twitter troll. Brown is clearly frustrated and obviously so is Tomlin, though there's been no indication that AB will be benched for Week 3 against Tampa Bay. With Brown upset and Le'Veon Bell still MIA, Pittsburgh's locker room has seen better days.
report: Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said Antonio Brown was disciplined for missing a team meeting on Monday.

impact: "I’m still grateful to put on my uniform, grateful to be part of this organization," Brown said. "I don’t take it for granted. Obviously it was a stupid remark online. I just got to stay away from online and the distractions." From his Twitter moment to his blowing off of Monday's team activities, Brown had an eventful week. It will all be forgotten with a big game against the Bucs on Monday Night Football.
report: Speaking Thursday, Antonio Brown said "obviously I don't want to be traded."

impact: It's a new injury for Lynch. The Raiders like to manage his practice reps, so this isn't a Week 6 concern. Lynch is an RB2 for Sunday's matchup with Seattle.
report: Marshawn Lynch (hip) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: It was a frustrating day for the entire Raiders' offense, which would have gotten shut out if not for a garbage-time field goal to "cut the deficit" to 27-3.  Lynch has been Oakland's best offensive player, but he has been boom or bust in fantasy because the Raiders have too often found themselves in negative game script.  Lynch now draws a Week 7 bye to rest his 32-year-old legs.
report: Marshawn Lynch rushed 13 times for 45 yards and caught 3-of-5 targets for 14 yards in the Raiders' Week 6 loss to Seattle.

impact: Yikes. It sounds like Lynch will be seeing some doctors during the Raiders' Week 7 bye. Ageless Lynch has a been rare bright spot for Jon Gruden's unmitigated disaster of a team so far this season. His loss would be massive on offense. Although Jalen Richard is catching a ton of passes, Doug Martin is the next man up for Lynch's role.
report: Raiders coach Jon Gruden admits the team is concerned about Marshawn Lynch's groin injury, and that it could be a long-term issue.

impact: It's another blow to the Raiders' offense. Lynch has been a bright spot for Oakland this year, averaging a respectable 4.2 yards per carry with three touchdowns through his first six games. Without him, the Raiders will turn to a committee featuring some combination of Doug Martin and Jalen Richard. Perhaps Oakland will scour the free agent market to see what running backs are available.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports Marshawn Lynch will miss at least a month with his groin injury.

impact: Lynch is expected to miss at least a month with his groin injury. He'll rehab for now, but surgery hasn't been ruled out. Going on IR would effectively end Lynch's season. Doug Martin will replace Lynch on early downs, with Jalen Richard and DeAndre Washington playing change-up roles.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports injured reserve is a "strong possibility" for Marshawn Lynch.

impact: Backed by a strong "squeaky wheel" narrative, Brown underwhelmed (by his standards) with merely six catches for 50 yards Monday night. Ben Roethlisberger hit him for a 27-yard touchdown prior to the half, which ultimately salvaged his day. Brown should still be considered fantasy's overall WR1, but the emergence of receiving TE Vance McDonald (4-112-1 Monday night) and JuJu Smith-Schuster's constant peppering of targets (11 against the Bucs) are both slightly concerning. Brown still ranks second in the league with 42 targets and is eventually bound to explode, perhaps even as soon as Week 4 when the Steelers host an injury-riddled Ravens defense.
report: Antonio Brown hauled in 6-of-9 targets for 50 yards and one touchdown in the Steelers' Week 3 win over the Buccaneers.

impact: Brown's touchdown came on a broken play where he made a double move and high-pointed the ball in the end-zone. He was otherwise held in check by Ravens CB Marlon Humphrey. Browns got almost all of his yards in the first half before the Steelers' offense stalled out. It was an underwhelming game for his standards. Brown will be a top-five option for a Week 5 blowup spot against the Falcons.
report: Antonio Brown caught 5-of-11 targets for 62 yards and a touchdown in Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: Ben Roethlisberger was forcing the ball to his No. 1 receiver in the first half, but Brown entered the break just 2-of-8 for 15 yards. The duo finally got in sync in the second half, with the highlight being Brown's 47-yard score down the left sideline. Brown soundly beat Robert Alford and Roethlisberger hit him in stride. It was off to the races after that. The 100-yard game was Brown's first of the season. He will have a shot at getting a hot streak going against the Bengals in Week 6.
report: Antonio Brown caught 6-of-13 targets for 101 yards and two touchdowns in the Steelers' Week 5 win over the Falcons.

impact: Brown was quiet most of the day before going 49 yards on a second-half catch-and-run for his longest play of the season to date.  He then scored from 31 yards out with 10 seconds left and the Steelers trailing by one point.  The six targets were third on the team behind JuJu Smith-Schuster (10) and Vance McDonald (8).  The Steelers are entering their bye week and will host the Browns in Week 8.  Brown went 9-93-1 on 16 targets versus Cleveland in Week 1.
report: Antonio Brown caught 5-of-6 targets for 105 yards and one touchdown in the Steelers' 28-21, Week 6 win over the Bengals.

impact: Brown did all of his damage in the first half, catching a 43-yard touchdown for the Steelers first score of the game on a blown coverage in the second quarter and then catching a 1-yard quick hitting screen pass for a score with eight seconds before halftime. The Steelers took the air out of the ball in the second half as Brown added just one catch 19 yards after the break, but the damage was already done. Brown now has scored a touchdown in five straight games and has eight touchdowns through seven games on the season. The Steelers head to Baltimore in Week 9.
report: Antonio Brown caught 6-of-8 targets for 74 yards and two touchdowns in Sunday's Week 8 game versus the Browns.

impact: Lynch is officially out of commission until Week 16 at soonest, although he has undoubtedly played his final down in Oakland.  The tanking Raiders had no use for Lynch, and will move forward with Doug Martin, Jalen Richard, and DeAndre Washington.  Lynch's tenure in Oakland certainly fell short of his personal hopes, but his on-field performance was quietly excellent.  He was the Raiders' best offensive player from midway through the 2017 season up until his 2018 core muscle injury.  We suspect Lynch will retire for good at age 32.  He is not under contract for 2019.
report: Raiders placed RB Marshawn Lynch (groin/core muscle) on injured reserve.

impact: This wasn't one of Brown's better weeks, which was probably to be expected playing on the road against a stingy Ravens defense. But he still provided his weekly touchdown, punching it in from six yards out on a screen from Ben Roethlisberger with just over seven minutes remaining in the second quarter. AB showed expert elusiveness, making two defenders miss on the play. Brown had his hand/finger stepped on early in the game but the injury didn't seem to affect him. The Steelers stud now has nine touchdowns for the year, the same number he had all of last season. He'll take a six-game touchdown streak into Thursday night's Week 10 showdown with Carolina.
report: Antonio Brown notched five catches for 42 yards and a touchdown on 11 targets Sunday in the Steelers’ Week 9 win over Baltimore.

impact: Most of Brown's damage came on his 53-yard touchdown in the second quarter. Matched up 1-on-1 with second-rounder Donte Jackson down the right sideline, Brown simply overpowered the rookie on his way to the end zone. Jackson wanted an OPI call, but it was just a little hand fighting. Brown is now up to 10 scores on the season after visiting the end zone "just" nine times in all of 2017. He should see a heavy dose of Jalen Ramsey against the Jaguars in Week 11.
report: Antonio Brown caught 6-of-6 targets for 96 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 10 win over the Panthers.

impact: Brown was erased by Jalen Ramsey through nearly three quarters with just one catch, then his entire day changed on one play. On a play in which Ben Roethlisberger extended the play in the pocket, Brown found a hole in zone coverage upfield and raced 78 yards to the end zone. It was the eighth consecutive game in which Brown has caught a touchdown pass, the longest streak since Wes Welker over the 2012-2013 seasons. Brown will look to keep the streak going next week in Denver.
report: Antonio Brown caught 5-of-13 targets for 117 yards and a touchdown in Sunday's Week 11 win over the Jaguars.

impact: There were rumblings back in August that Brown has the sickle-cell trait, but he's going to be out there regardless. Brown played two games in Denver in 2012 without any complications. He should see his normal snaps.
report: The Pittsburgh Tribune Review confirms Antonio Brown will play in Week 12 at Denver.

impact: The Broncos were allowing the Steelers to dink and dunk all game, but unlike JuJu Smith-Schuster, Brown was not able to break off the big play to help boost his catch average. He should have had a long gain near the sideline in the fourth quarter, but he was not able to get both feet down. This game ended Brown's eight-game touchdown streak, but he still came through in a big way in PPR leagues. Even with a tough matchup against the Chargers up next, Brown will remain a solid WR1.
report: Antonio Brown hauled in 9-of-13 targets for 67 yards in the Steelers' Week 12 loss to the Broncos.

impact: Brown had a 46-yard catch on the opening drive but was tackled just short of the end-zone. He later beat double coverage and got wide open for a 28-yard touchdown at the end of the first half. Brown did most of his damage despite being shadowed by Casey Hayward most of the night. It's a nice rebound after Brown was held to 67 scoreless yards last week. Brown will be one of the top receiver plays for Week 14's matchup with the Raiders.
report: Antonio Brown caught 10-of-13 targets for 154 yards and a touchdown in Week 13 against the Chargers.

impact: The Titans opened the game trying to "establish" Derrick Henry -- Henry handled the first eight touches in Tennessee's backfield -- but Lewis eventually took over as the team's clearly-superior option.  Lewis' all-purpose game gives the Titans' offense more diversity than one-dimensional Henry brings to the table.  Elevate Lewis to a borderline RB2 when the Titans host the Texans next.
report: Dion Lewis rushed 16 times for 75 yards and a touchdown and caught 5-of-8 targets for 35 yards in the Titans' Week 1 loss to Miami.

impact: It was a game best-suited for Tennessee to lean on teammate Derrick Henry, which is exactly what the club did. Henry out-touched Lewis 18-15, with all of the former's touches coming via carries. Unfortunately for owners of this backfield, performances like this are bound to occur throughout the year depending on game script. Lewis remains the more coveted of the duo considering his usage in the Titans' passing game.
report: Dion Lewis rushed 14 times for 42 yards and hauled in his only target for one yard in the Titans' Week 2 win over the Texans.

impact: Derrick Henry was Tennessee's main back in this one, out-touching Lewis 18 to 12.  Lewis' touch counts have descended each week, falling from 21 in the opener to 15 in Week 2 and 12 today.  With an inconsistent timeshare role, Lewis will remain a shaky flex option when the Titans host the Eagles in Week 4.
report: Dion Lewis rushed nine times for 26 yards and caught 3-of-3 targets for 14 yards in Tennessee's Week 3 upset win over Jacksonville.

impact: He "added" zero yards on four carries. A struggling running game and a second-half deficit conspired to keep Lewis on the field instead of Derrick Henry, and he responded with a nice PPR outing. He made a couple big plays in the passing game in the second half, but his biggest was a fourth-down conversion in which he made a man miss and went 17 yards up the sideline in overtime. With the offense looking better and Buffalo on deck, Lewis will be an RB3 next week.
report: Dion Lewis hauled in all nine of his targets for 66 yards in the Titans' Week 4 win over the Eagles.

impact: He out-touched Derrick Henry 15 to 11 and has seemingly emerged as the Titans' preferred back, although it remains a fairly even committee.  Still rarely scoring touchdowns and firmly in a timeshare, Lewis will be a low-upside flex option when Tennessee hosts Baltimore in Week 6.
report: Dion Lewis rushed 12 times for 34 yards and caught 3-of-4 targets for 14 yards in the Titans' Week 5 loss to Buffalo.

impact: That's right, 14 yards on seven touches (2.0 yards per touch) for Lewis in Week 6. It was an abysmal outing for anyone donning silver and navy blue as everyone fell victim to Baltimore's 11-sack shutout defensive stand. Derrick Henry out-touched Lewis 8-7 but even he managed just 26 yards and an average 3.25 yards per touch. Lewis will be needed (and should out-touch Henry) in the Titans' Week 7 matchup against the Chargers' explosive offense.
report: Dion Lewis handled five carries for nine yards and caught both of his targets for another five yards in the Titans' Week 6 loss to the Ravens.

impact: Gabbert was predictably bad, but the bigger story is the Titans may have to start him in Week 2 with Marcus Mariota (elbow) ailing.  The Titans host the Texans next.  We'll have a better idea of Mariota's injury on Monday.
report: Blaine Gabbert completed 11-of-22 passes for 117 yards and an interception in the Titans' Week 1 loss to Miami.

impact: Marcus Mariota (elbow) was limited in warm-ups and is still struggling to grip the football. There is no official word from the Titans just yet, but it sounds like Gabbert will be starting behind a makeshift offensive line missing both starting tackles.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports it's "looking more" like Blaine Gabbert will start in Week 2 against the Texans.

impact: Lewis carried the Titans' offense, outrushing Derrick Henry and finishing behind only Tajae Sharpe in receiving. It's a nice rebound after Lewis managed just 14 total yards last week. Lewis has been better than Henry through the first seven games and there's no reason to downgrade his rest-of-season outlook. The Titans have a matchup against Dallas after their Week 9 bye.
report: Dion Lewis rushed 13 times for 93 yards and caught six passes for 64 yards in Week 7 against the Chargers.

impact: The 23 touches marked a new season-high, besting his previous mark of 19 from the Titans' last game, a London loss to the Chargers in Week 7.  The Titans have slowly been moving more and more toward Lewis as their clear No. 1 back after trying to force Derrick Henry earlier in the season.  It's clear Lewis is the best fit for this offense, and he's now totaled 279 yards and a score over his last two outings on 42 touches.  He'll be an RB1/2 next week against his former Patriots teammates, especially with the Titans likely to be playing from behind.
report: Dion Lewis rushed 19 times for 62 yards and caught all four of his targets for 60 yards and one touchdown in the Titans' 28-14, Week 9 win over the Cowboys.

impact: Lewis was a Week 10 fantasy disappointment in a game where Derrick Henry scored twice, but the 22 touches are still highly promising for Lewis' going-forward outlook.  Keep rolling with him as an every-week RB2 when the Titans visit the Colts next.  Indianapolis' run defense has collapsed since early in the year, and they also hemorrhage receiving production to running backs.
report: Dion Lewis managed 57 yards on 20 carries and caught 2-of-2 targets for 11 yards in the Titans' Week 10 win over the Patriots.

impact: Both the touches and yards were Lewis' fewest in over a month. The Titans offense never got in rhythm. Marcus Mariota was discombobulated by the blitz and departed with an elbow injury late in the first half. Blaine Gabbert should not be on an NFL football field. Provided Mariota can get back for next Monday's game against the Texans, Lewis should bounce back to the 15-20 touch range as an RB2.
report: Dion Lewis rushed 10 times for 24 yards in the Titans' Week 11 loss to the Colts, adding an eight-yard reception.

impact: Both Gabbert and Marcus Mariota (elbow) warmed up for the Titans' Week 2 division bout against the Texans, but it was the former who took all reps with the first-string offense. The Titans only have two available quarterbacks, so Mariota could still stay glued to the sidelines despite being active. There has been no official announcement on Tennessee's starter.
report: Blaine Gabbert is warming up with the Titans' first string offense.

impact: Marcus Mariota (elbow) is active but may only be used in an emergency. The Titans will notably be without tackles Jack Conklin, Taylor Lewan, and second-stringer Dennis Kelly against the Texans' daunting pass rush.
report: Blaine Gabbert will start in Week 2 against the Texans.

impact: Gabbert barely cracked the century mark in his spot-start for Marcus Mariota (elbow), tossing for 117 yards and an abysmal 5.8 YPA. Gabbert's fantasy production typically derives (and hinges on) his legs, but he mustered only two scrambles for two yards in Tennessee's Week 2 win. Corey Davis (5-55) still managed to lead all Titans skill players with a team-high seven targets, so consider him the focal point of Tennessee's passing game no matter who is under center moving forward.
report: Blaine Gabbert completed 13-of-20 passes for 117 yards and one touchdown in the Titans' Week 2 win over the Texans.

impact: The Titans are "hoping" Marcus Mariota (elbow) can "grip the football as soon as possible", which is a vague timeline that leaves his return wide open. Blaine Gabbert is expected to make his second consecutive start in the interim. Gabbert completed 13-of-20 passes for 117 yards and one score against the Texans in Week 2 and, if looking for a positive note, will have LT Taylor Lewan (concussion) back protecting his blindside. Although they'll be on the field for nearly every offensive play, WR Corey Davis and TE Jonnu Smith can be promptly downgraded until Mariota returns.
report: Titans QB Blaine Gabbert is expected to start in Week 3 against the Jaguars.

impact: Gabbert took a first-quarter hit so massive that he was noticeably woozy and eventually left the field with trainers.  Marcus Mariota, dealing with a nerve problem in his throwing-arm elbow, has taken over at quarterback against Jacksonville.
report: Blaine Gabbert left Sunday's Week 3 game with a concussion.

impact: Lewis' touches have been down the last two weeks in back-to-back blowout losses.  In this one, he was constantly getting hit behind the line and running into his own blockers, who were getting destroyed up front by the Texans' front seven.  Derrick Henry wasn't any better with 49 scoreless yards and a lost fumble on 10 touches.  Lewis will be an RB2 next week against the Jets.
report: Dion Lewis rushed seven times for eight yards and caught all seven of his targets for 33 yards in the Titans' Week 12 loss to the Texans.

impact: Lewis was a total non-factor in the second half, getting just two carries and an empty target after the break.  Marcus Mariota and Derrick Henry were moving the ball, with Henry scoring a short touchdown and Mariota amassing nearly 250 yards after half while tossing a game-winning score to Corey Davis with 36 seconds left.  Lewis will be an RB2/3 next week against the Jaguars.
report: Dion Lewis rushed six times for 36 yards and caught 2-of-3 targets for -2 yards in the Titans' Week 13 win over the Jets.

impact: Gabbert suffered a concussion in Week 3 and remains in the league's protocol. Marcus Mariota is still working back from a pinched nerve in his throwing elbow but played through the pain last week against the Jags. Mariota should get the nod Sunday when the Titans host Philadelphia.
report: Blaine Gabbert (concussion) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: Gabbert has yet to pass the concussion protocol. Even if he gets cleared, the Titans are starting Marcus Mariota at less than 100 percent this week. Austin Davis will back up Mariota if Gabbert sits.
report: Blaine Gabbert (concussion) is questionable for Week 4 against the Eagles.

impact: With Gabbert down, the Titans will turn to Austin Davis behind Marcus Mariota. Tennessee also declared CB Kenneth Durden, RB David Fluellen (groin), OG Aaron Stinnie, OT Dennis Kelly (illness), DL Darius Kilgo, and DL Matt Dickerson inactive for Week 4.
report: Titans declared QB Blaine Gabbert (concussion) inactive for Week 4 against the Eagles.

impact: Gabbert is one of the least-effective backups in the league.
report: Blaine Gabbert has cleared the concussion protocol.

impact: Gabbert was forced into the game in the dying moments of the first half after Marcus Mariota re-injured his throwing elbow. The Titans were already losing 24-0. Gifted an entire half of garbage time, Gabbert did nothing until the final two minutes, when he found Tajae Sharpe in the end zone. Hilariously, his interception was thrown literally right to LB Darius Leonard. The Titans won't have a prayer if Gabbert is forced to start next Monday night's game against the Texans.
report: Blaine Gabbert completed 11-of-16 passes for 118 yards, one touchdown and an interception in the Titans' 38-10, Week 11 loss to the Colts.

impact: Cook was arguably the only reason Oakland managed to stay competitive. A clear favorite of Derek Carr's, Cook was surprisingly treated as an in-line receiver, even lining up in the slot at times. An early best ball favorite and undervalued TE2 with TE1 upside, Cook need be picked off waivers immediately if he's still available.
report: Raiders TE Jared Cook caught 9-of-12 targets for 180 yards in Monday's Week 1 loss to the Raiders.

impact: After a massive opening week to the season, Cook fell back in line with his career output, but was still tied for second on the team in targets. Catching 13-of-16 targets to open the season, Cook will remain a fringe TE1 entering Week 3 versus the Dolphins.
report: Jared Cook caught 4-of-4 targets for 49 yards in Sunday's Week 2 loss to the Broncos.

impact: Cook appeared to find the end zone for his first touchdown of the season in the third quarter, but replay review revealed he was down at the one. Cook has been the Raiders' only consistent pass catcher, notching at least four receptions every week out. He is proving to be a legitimate TE1 in his age-31 season.
report: Jared Cook caught 5-of-6 targets for 31 yards in the Raiders' Week 3 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: Cook dropped at least two targets, but he atoned with twin seven-yard scores and several chunk gains between the twenties.  Through four games, Cook leads the Raiders in every meaningful receiving category and has easily been the team's most-consistent pass catcher.  Cook has solidified himself as an every-week fantasy TE1 and will remain so in Week 5 against the Chargers.
report: Jared Cook caught 8-of-13 targets for 110 yards and two touchdowns in the Raiders' Week 4 win over Cleveland.

impact: Cooks' six targets on the day were still encouraging despite the results. It was always plausible this day would come given his history in boom-bust performances, too. Having said that, Cook again dropped another potential touchdown inside the 10-yard line. Given the landscape (a.k.a. wasteland) of tight ends in 2018, Cook remains a weekly matchup-proof TE1.
report: Jared Cook caught 4-of-6 targets for 20 yards in the Raiders' Week 5 loss to the Chargers.

impact: We're going to get outcomes like this when Derek Carr has no time to throw and is unwilling to make difficult throws, and both scenarios played out against the Seahawks.  Cook will enter the Raiders' Week 7 bye coming off two slow games.  He remains a huge part of the passing offense as an every-week TE1.
report: Jared Cook caught 2-of-2 targets for 10 yards in the Raiders' Week 6 loss to Seattle.

impact: Cook's touchdown, his third of the year, came on a 25-yard dart from Derek Carr in the second quarter. Carr shook off a defender on a play-fake to Martavis Bryant, leaving Cook one-on-one with linebacker Anthony Walker. Obviously Cook won that encounter. Cook has been Carr's go-to target all season and now that Amari Cooper has left the nest, he should see even more targets going forward. Look for him to keep the train rolling Thursday night in San Francisco.
report: Jared Cook came down with four catches for 74 yards and a touchdown on five targets Sunday in Oakland’s Week 8 loss to Indianapolis.

impact: Cook finished tied for fourth in targets on a night where the Raiders struggled to move the ball with Carr constantly under duress. It was a disappointing performance for Cook, who had higher expectations with Amari Cooper shipped to Dallas, but Carr has been looking Cook's way for most of the season, so the veteran tight end should bounce back in Week 10's matchup against the Chargers. Cook is a low-end TE1.
report: Jared Cook caught both of his two targets for 20 yards in the Raiders' Week 9 loss to the 49ers.

impact: Cook appeared on his way to a quiet day after failing to catch either of his two targets in the first half, one of which was a bad drop on third down, but he bounced back somewhat after halftime. His nine targets and 52 receiving yards led the team, and his 31-yard catch was the biggest play for the offense outside of Johnny Townsend's 42-yard run on a fake punt. Cook should continue to get targets as the No. 1 option in the passing game, but his upside is muted with the Raiders spiraling.
report: Jared Cook hauled in 4-of-9 targets for 52 yards in the Raiders' Week 10 loss to the Chargers.

impact: Cook capped off the Raiders' opening drive with a 23-yard score. He caught a slant-and-go and then put CB Jamar Taylor on skates. Cook was obviously invisible thereafter, which is disappointing considering the Raiders were down to the dregs of the roster at wide receiver. Cook will be a risk/reward TE1 for Week 12 against the Ravens.
report: Jared Cook caught 3-of-6 passes for 31 yards and a touchdown in the Raiders' Week 11 win over the Cardinals.

impact: It was a rollercoaster afternoon for Cook, who committed an ugly first-half drop and also had a long catch negated by offensive pass interference. The Raiders' offense predictably struggled in a tough road game, though Cook salvaged the afternoon for his fantasy owners by hauling in a 16-yard touchdown strike from Derek Carr with around five minutes to go in the third quarter. Cook made a terrific adjustment on an under-thrown ball by Carr, though replay showed he may have been out at the one-yard line. The 31-year-old has already matched a career-high with five touchdowns this season. He'll look for No. 6 when the Raiders host Kansas City in Week 13.
report: Jared Cook pulled in two-of-five targets for 32 yards and a touchdown Sunday in the Raiders’ Week 12 loss to the Ravens.

impact: The Bucs’ backup played sparingly and was ineffective in the few instances when he was called upon, managing a long gain of just three yards. Peyton Barber served as Tampa’s workhorse in the opener, leading the Bucs’ backfield with 19 touches. We’d expect that trend to continue next week against the Eagles.
report: Jacquizz Rodgers rushed twice for only one yard while catching his lone target for a two-yard gain Sunday in the Buccaneeers’ Week 1 win over the Saints.

impact: He carried the ball just one time for no gain.  The eight targets and 102 yards were both team-highs for Rodgers as the third-down and passing back behind Peyton Barber.  Rodgers made a critical mistake in the second half, however, losing a fumble at the Washington 20-yard line that ended up in the end zone and recovered by the Redskins.  This is a fluke line; Rodgers isn't a fantasy option.
report: Jacquizz Rodgers caught all eight of his targets for 102 yards in the Bucs' 16-3, Week 10 loss to the Redskins.

impact: Only one week after leading his team in receiving, Rodgers touched the ball three times and failed to record a single catch against the Giants. Apologize to your league for wasting their time if you spent any amount of FAAB on him.
report: Jacquizz Rodgers rushed three times for 15 yards in the Bucs' Week 11 loss to the Giants.

impact: Smith-Schuster won in the slot often when faced off against Briean Boddy-Calhoun with the highlight of his day being a 67-yard catch and run that set up a Steelers touchdown in the 3rd quarter. Building off an impressive rookie season, Smith-Schuster will be a starting option next week at home versus the Chiefs.
report: Steelers WR JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 5-of-8 targets for 119 yards in Sunday's Week 1 game versus the Browns.

impact: With Antonio Brown gutting out a calf injury, Smith-Schuster set new career highs in both targets and catches. He benefitted from the Steelers spending literally the entire game in comeback mode. Smith-Schuster's touchdown was a two-yarder where he displayed ridiculously strong hands while getting tackled in tight coverage. He drew another end zone target later in the game but could not hook up with Ben Roethlisberger. The Steelers' No. 2 wideout is now sitting at 18/240/1 through two games. He's flirting with every-week WR1 value.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 13-of-19 targets for 121 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 2 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: It was just another 100-plus yard evening for Smith-Schuster, who's up to 27-356-1 on 38 targets this season. He also helped notched the game on the Steelers' final drive, separating from his defender and getting loose over the middle to bring down Ben Roethlisberger's across-the-body heave and secure Pittsburgh's 30-27 win. JuJu has now scored a touchdown and/or eclipsed the 100-yard mark in seven consecutive games. He's an every-week matchup-proof WR2.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 9-of-11 targets for 116 yards in the Steelers' Week 3 win over the Buccaneers.

impact: It's possible, if not likely, that Smith-Schuster is just getting a breather following Monday night's win over Tampa Bay. After leading all rookies in receiving yards last season, JuJu has been even better this year, topping 100 yards in each of his three contests. Assuming this is only a minor setback for Smith-Schuster, the former USC Trojan will be a borderline WR1 Sunday night when the Steelers host Baltimore.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster (abdomen) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: Smith-Schuster got the day off on Wednesday coming off the Monday night game. His participation on Thursday, albeit in a limited capacity, suggests he'll be fine for Sunday night's tilt with Baltimore. One of only two players in the league (the other being Minnesota's Adam Thielen) to top 100 yards receiving in each of his first three games, JuJu will be in the WR1 mix for that one.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster (abdomen) returned to a limited practice on Thursday.

impact: Smith-Schuster was upgraded to full participation at Friday's practice after sitting out Wednesday and getting in a limited session on Thursday. There was never much doubt about his availability for Sunday night's rivalry game with Baltimore. Through three weeks of action, JuJu ranks third in the league in receiving yards per game behind only Michael Thomas and Mike Evans. The 21-year-old has quickly ascended to weekly WR1 status in fantasy.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster (abdomen) wasn't listed on the Steelers' final injury report for Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: It was the first time Smith-Schuster has been held under 100 yards all season. He tied for a team high with 11 targets, but the Steelers offense couldn't get anything going downfield and were shut out in the second half. Smith-Schuster missed time with a core injury going into Sunday night, but looked fully healthy. He'll remain a WR1 for Week 5's Falcons matchup.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 4-of-11 targets for 60 yards in Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: With Ben Roethlisberger (successfully) fixated on getting Antonio Brown going, Smith-Schuster had his quietest game of the season. Thankfully for fantasy owners, it included a touchdown. With just eight catches over his past two games, Smith-Schuster will look to get cooking again in Week 6 against the Bengals.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 4-of-4 targets for 34 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 5 win over the Falcons.

impact: His 10 targets led the team.  JuJu made an incredible catch over the top of CB Darqueze Dennard at the goal line and was ruled down at the one, setting up a second one-yard touchdown for James Conner.  This was Smith-Schuster's fourth 100-yard game of the season as the Steelers head into their bye before hosting the Browns in Week 8.  JuJu went 5-119 in Week 1 vs. Cleveland.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 7-of-10 targets for 111 yards in the Steelers' Week 6 win over the Bengals.

impact: The 33 yards were a season-low for Smith-Schuster. He only received one target in the second half as the Steelers put the game away as he now has games of 34 and 33 yards in two of his past three games in Pittsburgh blowout wins. Despite the down day, Smith-Schuster will be a WR2 option in Week 9 on the road against the Ravens.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 4-of-6 targets for 33 yards in Sunday's Week 8 win over the Browns.

impact: On a day where the Ravens sold out to stop Antonio Brown, JuJu made a number of clutch catches. His highlights included a second-quarter, fourth-down conversion and a timely seven-yard catch that kept the clock running late in the fourth quarter. Smith-Schuster did have one bad drop, taking his eye off the ball before he had possession. JuJu was checked for a concussion in the third quarter after taking a big hit from safety Eric Weddle but only missed a couple plays. The second-year USC product owns an impressive 53-672-2 receiving line at the season's halfway mark. JuJu and the surging Steelers will take a four-game winning streak into Thursday night's battle with Carolina.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster tallied seven catches for 78 yards on nine targets Sunday in the Steelers’ Week 9 win over Baltimore.

impact: Smith-Schuster scored a 75-yard touchdown on the Steelers' first play from scrimmage. James Bradberry got confused in coverage and Smith-Schuster exploded down the left sideline. He didn't do much thereafter as Ben Roethlisberger spread the ball around on a night where he posted a perfect quarterback rating, but the damage was already done. The sledding will be tougher in Week 11 against the Jaguars.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 3-of-5 targets for 90 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 10 win over the Panthers, adding a 13-yard reception.

impact: Like the entire Steeler offense, Smith-Schuster was limited in the first half, catching just two passes for 16 yards before the break. His biggest play of the game was a 35-yard catch over A.J. Bouye with 1:39 left to get the Steelers into position for the game-winning touchdown. Smith-Schuster finally turns just 22-years old this Thursday, having amassed the most receptions (122) and receiving yards (1,783) before turning 22-years old in NFL history. The Steelers head to Denver in Week 12.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 8-of-10 targets for 104 yards in Sunday's Week 11 win over the Jaguars.

impact: Smith-Schuster found his inner Jarvis Landry early in this one. He recorded eight catches on nine targets in the first half, but he managed just 39 yards on those grabs. All of that changed in a flash in the third quarter. With the Steelers backed up against their own goal line, Smith-Schuster got loose down the sideline, Ben Roethlisberger was able to find him despite taking a hit, and the receiver out-ran everyone for a 97-yard touchdown. Amazingly, it is the second 97-yard catch of Smith-Schuster’s career, both the longest passing plays in Steelers’ history, and he also scored a 96-yard kickoff return last season. Smith-Schuster did not pack it in after that grab. With the game on the line late in the fourth, Smith-Schuster caught two 19-yard passes to help get the Steelers in position for the win -- a Roethlisberger interception ended the comeback. Smith-Schuster faces a tough matchup next week against the Chargers, but he will remain a high-end WR2.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster hauled in 13-of-17 targets for 189 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 12 loss to the Broncos.

impact: Smith-Schuster had the better matchup with Antonio Brown facing Casey Hayward, but this was a step back after blowing up last week. It breaks a steak of five straight games with at least 70 yards or a touchdown. Ben Roethlisberger locked on to Brown for over half of his yards, so there wasn't much room for Smith-Schuster. With a matchup against the Raiders, Smith-Schuster should get back on track in Week 14.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 6-of-9 targets for 49 yards in Week 14 against the Chargers.

impact: That means a bigger role for rookie James Washington after Hunter played 51-of-84 snaps against the Browns in Week 1. Washington was on the field for just 11 plays. That will change against the Chiefs in what could be an extremely high-scoring game. If you're already in the deepest of binds, there's a case for Washington as a blindfold, dart throw WR5.
report: Steelers WR Justin Hunter is a healthy scratch for Week 2 against the Chiefs.

impact: Washington played just 11 snaps in Week 1 but was far more involved today with Justin Hunter a healthy scratch. Washington was targeted on the Steelers' first play from scrimmage and drew four looks in the first quarter, one of which was nullified by a Steelers penalty. The Steelers went away from the strategy as Washington's looks proved fruitless, though he did score a 14-yard touchdown late in the second quarter where a scrambling Ben Roethlisberger was almost entirely across the line of scrimmage. Washington is going to bust some big plays, but he's not currently re-draft relevant.
report: James Washington caught 1-of-5 targets for 14 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 2 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: Washington was stuck behind Justin Hunter in the season opener, but Hunter was a healthy scratch in Week 2. That allowed Washington to play a massive role in a game Ben Roethlisberger attempted 60 passes. He was inefficient with his work, catching just one of his five targets for 14 yards and a score, but the usage is promising.
report: James Washington played 66-of-82 (80 percent) snaps Week 2 against the Chiefs.

impact: Washington's four targets were behind Antonio Brown, JuJu Smith-Schuster, and Ryan Switzer. His usage has been down since his big Week 2, but the Steelers should look to get him more involved as the season progresses. Washington would be a plug-and-play WR2 if Brown or Smith-Schuster gets injured.
report: James Washington caught 2-of-4 passes for 10 yards in Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: The second-round pick was active for all six of the games prior to the Steelers' Week 7 bye, but was hardly involved in the offense, catching just 5-of-14 passes for 49 yards and a touchdown. With Washington not dressing, the Steelers will lean on Justin Hunter, Ryan Switzer and Darrius Heyward-Bey to chip in behind their stellar duo of Antonio Brown and JuJu Smith-Schuster.
report: Steelers declared WR James Washington, QB Mason Rudolph, S Marcus Allen, CB Brian Allen, T Zach Banner, T Marcus Gilbert, and DE L.T. Walton inactive for Sunday's Week 8 versus the Browns.

impact: Washington was a healthy scratch in Week 8. He's back ahead of Justin Hunter after his surprise demotion. Washington should return to his role in three-wide sets but doesn't have much target share behind Antonio Brown, JuJu Smith-Schuster and Vance McDonald.
report: James Washington is active for Week 9 against Baltimore.

impact: He's a healthy scratch. Also inactive for Pittsburgh are QB Mason Rudolph, WR James Washington, CB Cameron Sutton, S Morgan Burnett, OT Zach Banner, OT Marcus Gilbert, and DE L.T. Walton.
report: James Washington is inactive for Week 13 against the Chargers.

impact: It's the sixth straight game Thielen has went over 100 yards. The Vikings pass offense went through Thielen, who caught Kirk Cousins' only touchdown on a red-zone pass in the middle of the end-zone. He also had a highlight diving sideline catch in third quarter. Thielen has been the highest floor receiver in the league this year. He'll remain a locked-in WR1 for Week 7 against the Jets.
report: Adam Thielen caught 11-of-15 targets for 123 yards and a touchdown in the Vikings' Week 6 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Thielen got the scoring started with a 34-yard touchdown on the opening drive, beating backup-turned-starter CB Darryl Roberts as he was falling away in the end zone.  With his seventh-straight 100-yard game to open the season, Thielen has set a new record.  Thielen is an obvious elite WR1 and will be involved in a potential shootout next week at home against the Saints.
report: Adam Thielen caught 9-of-10 targets for 110 yards and one touchdown in the Vikings' 37-17, Week 7 win over the Jets.

impact: Thielen went over 100 yards again this week. He also set an NFL record for the most catches in the first eight games of a season. Thielen's touchdown didn’t come until late in the fourth quarter on a goal-line pass from Kirk Cousins. It was another dominant effort from Thielen, but the story of the game was a costly red-zone fumble he lost that flipped the momentum for the Saints. Thielen has been playing at an MVP level this season and will remain a locked-in WR1 for Week 9 against Lions.
report: Adam Thielen caught seven passes for 103 yards and a touchdown in the Vikings' Week 8 loss to the Saints.

impact: Thielen had eclipsed 100 yards receiving in the Vikings' first eight games, setting an NFL record, but that streak is now over.  His seven targets led the team on a day without Stefon Diggs (ribs) in the lineup, but Kirk Cousins attempted just 22 passes with the Vikings winning with relative ease.  Thielen's touchdown was from two yards away.  He also appeared to injure his calf at one point and was getting it wrapped on the sideline while the defense was on the field.  Thielen will get the bye week before going to Chicago in Week 11.
report: Adam Thielen caught 4-of-7 targets for 22 yards and one touchdown in the Vikings' 24-9, Week 9 win over the Lions.

impact: Thielen seemed healthy before the bye week but apparently he's now dealing with calf and lower-back injuries. Regardless, the fifth-year stud should be fine for Sunday night's game in Chicago. Thielen needs just 53 more yards to lock up his second-straight 1,000-yard receiving season.
report: Adam Thielen (back, calf) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Thielen's status for Sunday night's game against the Bears is not in doubt, but it is unideal to come off the bye week with two different injuries. Coming off his quietest game of the season, Thielen is a mid-range WR1 for Week 11.
report: Adam Thielen (lower back, calf) remained "limited" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Stefon Diggs (ribs) was also removed from the injury report. Thielen saw an abbreviated workload at practice this week, but that was likely just for maintenance purposes. Now on the cusp of his second-straight 1,000-yard season, Thielen will be safe to employ as a WR1 in all formats Sunday night in Chi-Town.
report: Adam Thielen (back, calf) wasn't listed on the Vikings' final injury report for Week 11 against the Bears.

impact: He also caught a two-point conversion. It's another down game for Thielen's standards after he was held to four catches before Minnesota's bye. Thielen didn’t make his first reception until the final drive of the first half but saved his night with the Vikings in fourth quarter comeback mode. Thielen will look to get on track in a blowup Week 12 spot against the Packers.
report: Adam Thielen caught 7-of-12 targets for 66 yards in Week 11 against Chicago.

impact: He played through both injuries last week and should be fine for Sunday's home matchup against Green Bay. Thielen destroyed the Packers earlier this year, logging 12 catches for 131 yards and a touchdown in a Week 2 tie.
report: Adam Thielen (calf, low back) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: He had his workload scaled back at practice this week, but there was never much doubt about his availability for Sunday night's game. Thielen produced a stellar 12-131-1 receiving line when he faced the Packers earlier this season and should be in for another huge performance in Week 12.
report: Adam Thielen (calf, back) wasn't listed on the Vikings' injury report for Week 12 against the Packers.

impact: Thielen got off to another slow start, with his first catch not coming until halfway through the second quarter. He finished strong -- leading the Vikings in receiving and scoring a touchdown on a broken red-zone play. Thielen is back to his 100-yard standard after a two-game scuttle. He's a top-10 receiver play for Week 13 against the Patriots.
report: Adam Thielen caught 8-of-9 targets for 125 yards and a touchdown in Week 12 against the Packers.

impact: He's dealt with the injury for weeks. This won't affect his status for Sunday's shootout in Foxboro. Coming off a 125-yard explosion in Week 12, Thielen will be a top-shelf WR1 against New England.
report: Adam Thielen (calf) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Thielen has had the issue for weeks but has yet to miss a game. With Stefon Diggs' status up in the air for Sunday, Thielen could be in for a mammoth workload against New England.
report: Adam Thielen (calf) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: His status was never in doubt. Thielen has been a fantasy Goliath this year, topping the century mark in yards in nine of his 11 games. He's our third-ranked wide receiver for Week 13.
report: Adam Thielen (calf) wasn't listed on the Vikings' final injury report for Week 13 against the Patriots.

impact: Thielen was invisible for much of the first half, delivering his first catch of the game on a five-yard touchdown strike from Kirk Cousins with 15 ticks remaining in the second quarter. He was slightly more involved in the second half, though Jason McCourty did a nice job defending him. Thielen was the intended target on the second of Cousins' two interceptions. This wasn't one of Thielen's better performances, though he still boasts a monster 98-1,166-9 receiving line for the season. Those are WR1 numbers. He'll try to bounce back against the Seahawks in Week 14.
report: Adam Thielen registered five grabs for 28 yards and a touchdown on 10 targets Sunday in the Vikings’ Week 13 loss to the Patriots.

impact: Treadwell dropped his first target of the day on a third down, earning boos from the home crowd.
