But he later answered with a nice 16-yard grab where he picked up some YAC and ran through an arm tackle.  Treadwell is unlikely to have any fantasy appeal unless Adam Thielen or Stefon Diggs gets hurt.
report: Laquon Treadwell caught 2-of-4 targets for 18 yards in the Vikings' Week 1 win over the 49ers.

impact: The day started out well for Treadwell, who caught the first touchdown of his career -- really -- in the first quarter. It was downhill from there, however. He dropped what would have been a third-down conversion in the third quarter, and he almost sabotaged the comeback attempt by letting a pass go right through his hands and into a DB's in the fourth quarter. He also ran the wrong route and dropped another pass in overtime. It would not be surprising if his playing time is scaled back moving forward.
report: Laquon Treadwell hauled in 2-of-6 targets for 23 yards and a touchdown in the Vikings' Week 2 tie with the Packers.

impact: Still reeling from hauling in his first career touchdown in Week 2, Treadwell reverted back to being the Vikings' fourth option in their passing game. Had Minnesota not been trailing 27-0 to start the second half, it's a wonder whether he would have even been asked to play all that much. With Adam Thielen (14-105 Sunday), Kyle Rudolph (5-48-1), and Stefon Diggs (4-17) locked into primary roles, Treadwell's good weeks will be far and few between.
report: Laquon Treadwell hauled in all four of his targets for 33 yards in the Vikings' Week 3 loss to the Bills.

impact: Half of his catches came on the Vikings’ final drive. Treadwell added to his league-leading drop total with another miscue in the third quarter. The 23-year-old has not come close to living up to expectations since entering the league as a first-round pick in 2016. He’ll be well off the fantasy radar in a difficult matchup next week against the Eagles.
report: Laquon Treadwell nabbed four-of-seven targets for 47 yards Thursday in Minnesota’s Week 4 loss to the Rams.

impact: With Dalvin Cook (hamstring) still sidelined, Thomas got a shot as the Vikes' No. 2 back behind Latavius Murray. He drew a red zone target and goal line carry. Perhaps the Jacksonville State UDFA is worth an add in the deepest of Dynasty leagues.
report: Roc Thomas rushed four times for eight yards in the Vikings' Week 5 win over the Eagles, adding a six-yard reception.

impact: Thomas made the team as an UDFA this year after a big preseason that saw him total 195 yards and two scores on 24 touches.  He had rushed eight times for 30 yards in real games.  Thomas was cut in favor of Ameer Abdullah.
report: Vikings waived RB Roc Thomas.

impact: Bibbs was the Redskins' No. 2/change of pace with Chris Thompson sidelined. Thompson seemed close to suiting up this week, so Bibbs is not a compelling waiver wire add.
report: Kapri Bibbs rushed twice for 11 yards in the Redskins' Week 6 win over the Panthers, adding a six-yard reception.

impact: Without Chris Thompson for the second straight week, Bibbs again stepped in as Washington's No. 2 change-of-pace back. He showed his worth on Washington's first drive when he stretched a screen in the flats into a 23-yard touchdown scamper. His 43 receiving yards tied Jordan Reed's for the team lead. Bibbs has been out-carried by Adrian Peterson 41-4 over the last two games, though, and would need more consistent usage to be deemed a potential streamer moving forward. He's worthy of stashing in the event both Peterson and Thompson are ruled out later on.
report: Kapri Bibbs rushed two times for 16 yards, adding four catches for 43 yards and one touchdown through the air in the Redskins' Week 7 win over the Cowboys.

impact: Bibbs got in three limited practices this week and should be fine.  With Chris Thompson (ribs) out, Bibbs is the change-of-pace to Adrian Peterson.  If this one ends up with the Redskins chasing points against Atlanta, Bibbs could see expanded work in the pass game.  He's not an intriguing fantasy play.
report: Kapri Bibbs (shoulder) is questionable for Week 9 against the Falcons.

impact: He was limited with a shoulder injury this week but is good to go in Chris Thompson's (ribs) place.  The Redskins' Week 9 inactives are Thompson, WRs Jamison Crowder and Brian Quick, DBs Adonis Alexander and Kenny Ladler, LT Trent Williams, and C Casey Dunn.  Ty Nsekhe will get the start on Alex Smith's blind side.
report: Kapri Bibbs is active for Week 9 against the Falcons.

impact: Bibbs technically played the "Chris Thompson role," but he was barely a factor in the passing game on a day where Alex Smith looked almost strictly for tight ends and slot receivers rather than wideouts and running backs.  Bibbs' second-half rushing score came from three yards out.  Even if Thompson (ribs) sits again in Week 10, Bibbs would be a weak PPR-only flex play at Tampa Bay.
report: Kapri Bibbs rushed three times for 20 yards and a touchdown and caught his lone target for 15 yards in Washington's Week 9 loss to Atlanta.

impact: With Chris Thompson (ribs) seemingly headed for another absence, Bibbs will likely work as Adrian Peterson's handcuff again in Week 10. Even in deeper leagues, you can probably do better than Bibbs, who has totaled just 120 yards from scrimmage in his six games this year.
report: Kapri Bibbs (shoulder) is practicing in full for Week 10 against the Buccaneers.

impact: Bibbs has been filling in as Chris Thompson's replacement while he's out hurt.  He's a desperation FLEX in deeper PPR leagues when Thompson is out.
report: Kapri Bibbs rushed three times for 28 yards and caught 2-of-4 targets for 13 yards in the Redskins' Week 10 win over the Bucs.

impact: LaFell is a healthy scratch after signing with the Raiders one week ago.  He may not know the playbook.  Washington is recovering from a knee scope.  Carradine is also a healthy inactive after starting 7-of-8 games last season and recording 1.5 sacks.  Nelson, also healthy, is a fourth-round rookie.
report: Raiders declared WR Brandon LaFell, RB DeAndre Washington, DE Tank Carradine, OT T.J. Clemmings, OT Justin Murray, DT Brian Price, and CB Nick Nelson inactive for Week 1 against the Rams.

impact: LaFell joined the Raiders a week ago but wasn't active for Monday's opener against the Rams. Even if he suits Sunday at Denver, the 31-year-old journeyman won't be of much use to fantasy owners.
report: Brandon LaFell (back) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: LaFell was limited to start the week but graduated to a full practice on Thursday, leading the Raiders to take him off their injury report. The ex-Bengal was a healthy scratch for Monday night's opener after signing just a week earlier, but will likely make his Raiders debut Sunday at Denver.
report: Brandon LaFell (back) wasn't listed on the Raiders' final injury report for Week 2 against the Broncos.

impact: LaFell is a healthy scratch. CB Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie (hamstring) and DT P.J. Hall (ankle) will both be active for Sunday's home matchup against Cleveland.
report: Raiders declared WR Brandon LaFell, LB Shilique Calhoun, DL Tank Carradine, OT T.J. Clemmings, S Karl Joseph, OT Justin Murray and RB DeAndre Washington inactive for Week 4 against the Browns.

impact: LaFell punched in a six-yard touchdown late in the first half but was otherwise held in check. That was his first end-zone visit since joining Oakland last month. LaFell will likely take on a bigger role as the Raiders look to replace Amari Cooper, who was traded to Dallas last week. Still, he's best left on the waiver wire.
report: Brandon LaFell chipped in with three catches for 39 yards and a touchdown on four targets Sunday in the Raiders’ Week 8 loss to the Colts.

impact: LaFell came onto the scene last week when he caught three of four targets, and the veteran receiver saw a similar workload in Week 9. It appears that LaFell will be tasked with partially filling the production Amari Cooper left behind, but he's best left on the waiver wire.
report: Brandon LaFell posted 20 yards by catching 3-of-3 targets in the Raiders' Week 9 loss to the 49ers.

impact: Prior to the Cooper trade, Cooper played 40 snaps total and hadn't been on the field since Week 3.  All of the sudden, coach Jon Gruden has made LaFell his team's No. 1 receiver.  The 32-year-old has reeled in six passes for 59 yards and one touchdown on seven targets the last two weeks.  Meanwhile, Martavis Bryant has played 28 snaps in that span.  Bryant can safely be sent back to the wire, but LaFell doesn't need to be owned outside of the deepest of leagues.
report: Brandon LaFell has played 99-of-107 (92.5 percent) offensive snaps since the Raiders traded Amari Cooper.

impact: Oakland's No. 1 receiver at this point, non-Jared Cook division, LaFell started strong with four catches in the first half, but he could not corral either of his targets after the break. One of those was a bad route which almost resulted in an interception at the goal line. LaFell does not need to be rostered in most fantasy leagues.
report: Brandon LaFell hauled in 4-of-6 targets for 47 yards in the Raiders' Week 10 loss to the Chargers.

impact: LaFell skied for a jump ball win in the third quarter but immediately came down hobbled. It's a huge loss for a team already missing Martavis Bryant and Jordy Nelson. LaFell had caught two passes for 29 yards before going down, finding the end zone for a five-yard score where he beat Patrick Peterson. LaFell is headed for an MRI.
report: Brandon LaFell is "feared" to have suffered a ruptured Achilles' tendon in Sunday's game against the Cardinals.

impact: Unfortunately, this is a career-threatening injury for the 33-year-old wideout.  LaFell had strangely emerged as the Raiders' No. 1 wide receiver after the Amari Cooper trade.  He is not under contract for the 2019 season.
report: Raiders placed WR Brandon LaFell on injured reserve with a torn Achilles' tendon, ending his season.

impact: As expected.  Diggs was injured last week late against the Saints.  Not much was made of his injury until late this week after he missed the practice week.  The Vikings figure to roll with Laquon Treadwell and Aldrick Robinson behind Adam Thielen.  Dalvin Cook (hamstring) is active Sunday.
report: Stefon Diggs (ribs) is inactive for Week 9 against the Lions.

impact: "I know I will play," Diggs said on RapSheet's podcast. After sitting out Week 9 and coming off a bye week, Diggs has now had two weeks to heal up. It would be a surprise if he is not ready to face the Bears on Sunday night.
report: Stefon Diggs (ribs) told NFL Network's Ian Rapoport he participated in Monday's practice.

impact: Diggs has had two weeks to rest up with the Vikings' Week 10 bye. He's fully expected to return for Sunday night's game with Chicago.
report: Stefon Diggs (ribs) is practicing Wednesday.

impact: This confirms Diggs will be back for Sunday's divisional showdown at Soldier Field. Diggs was absent for Week 9 but had last week's bye to rest his bruised ribs. Even against an underrated Bears secondary, the 24-year-old should be started in all formats.
report: Updating an earlier report, Stefon Diggs (ribs) is practicing in full for Week 11 against the Bears.

impact: Diggs did almost all his damage in the second half. He could have had a bigger game, but Kirk Cousins overthrew him for what would have been a 40-plus yard touchdown. Diggs was fully healthy after sitting out with a rib injury before Minnesota's bye. With Adam Thielen getting held in check out of the slot, Cousins was locked on to Diggs for most of the night. Diggs got the majority of his yards after the catch and was a bright spot in a game the Vikings struggled to move their offense. He'll remain a WR2 for a likely shootout with the Packers in Week 12.
report: Stefon Diggs caught 13-of-18 targets for 126 yards and a touchdown in the Vikings' Week 11 loss to Chicago.

impact: He also had a 12-yard run. Diggs was left wide open on his 30-yard touchdown. The Packers didn't have an answer for Diggs or Adam Thielen, who torched the Green Bay secondary for 202 yards. Diggs has touchdowns in consecutive weeks after his monster Week 11. He'll remain a WR2 for Week 13's likely shootout with the Patriots.
report: Stefon Diggs caught 8-of-11 targets for 77 yards and a touchdown in Week 12 against the Packers.

impact: Diggs saw his usual workload in Week 12 (66-of-70 offensive snaps), so this could just be a maintenance day. His status will need to be followed closely throughout the week, though at this point, we're expecting him to suit up for Sunday's game in Foxboro.
report: Stefon Diggs (knee) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: Diggs also sat out Wednesday's session. It is still possible the Vikings are simply managing Diggs' reps ahead of a big game against the Patriots, but it is officially time to be worried. He likely needs to get in some work Friday to have a real chance to play.
report: Stefon Diggs (knee) did not practice Thursday.

impact: Although often on the injury report, Diggs has shown increased effectiveness compared to past seasons when playing hurt this year. Barring a Friday "DNP," he should be out there as a high-volume, high-upside WR2 in New England.
report: Stefon Diggs (knee) expects to suit up for Sunday's game against the Patriots.

impact: Diggs returned to practice on Friday, putting him on track to play Sunday at New England. There is some risk with Sunday's kickoff set for 4:25 PM ET, though Diggs promised he'd suit up earlier this week. Riding a three-game touchdown streak, he'll be an elite WR2 against the Pats.
report: Stefon Diggs (knee) is questionable for Week 13 against the Patriots.

impact: We assumed this would be the case after Diggs returned to practice on Friday. Diggs had his left knee wrapped during Friday's session, though he should be able to play through his injury. Even in a tough matchup with Patriots stud Stephon Gilmore, Diggs is still worth firing up as a WR2 for the final week of the fantasy regular season.
report: Ben Goessling of the Minneapolis Star-Tribune reports Stefon Diggs (questionable, knee) will play Week 13 against the Patriots.

impact: This is not a surprise after Ben Goessling of the Minneapolis Star-Tribune reported the same on Friday. Diggs' matchup with the Patriots is not the best, and his history of struggles while playing through injury is a concern. Still, he remains a high-end WR2.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Stefon Diggs (knee) is expected to play Week 13 against the Patriots.

impact: Schefter notes Diggs will have to test the knee in pregame warmups before a decision is made.  It sounds like he's no better than 50-50 to play Sunday afternoon.  It's tough for fantasy footballers with this being a 4:25 PM ET kickoff.  Backup plans need to be in place.  We should know Diggs' official status before 3 PM ET.  Adam Thielen would be a target-hog if Diggs has to sit.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Stefon Diggs' knee swelled up overnight and is now questionable for Week 13 against the Patriots.

impact: So is top corner Xavier Rhodes (hamstring). Both were game-time decisions. Diggs was uncertain for Sunday's game after his injured knee swelled up overnight, but apparently he showed enough in pre-game warmups to get the green light. It's not an ideal matchup for Diggs, who will likely line up against Patriots shutdown corner Stephon Gilmore. Regardless, Diggs belongs in all fantasy lineups. WR Chad Beebe, RB Mike Boone, LB Devante Downs, DT Jalyn Holmes, C Brett Jones, TE David Morgan and QB Kyle Sloter are inactive for Sunday's game in Foxboro.
report: Stefon Diggs (knee) is active for Week 13 against the Patriots.

impact: Diggs didn't look limited at all despite being a game-time decision due to a nagging knee injury. As expected, he saw a fair amount of Stephon Gilmore while Jason McCourty spent the afternoon chasing Adam Thielen. The 49 yards were Diggs' fewest since Week 7. Sunday also snapped a three-game touchdown streak for the talented 25-year-old. Diggs will try to do better when the Vikings travel to Seattle for Monday Night Football in Week 14.
report: Stefon Diggs absorbed all five of his targets for 49 yards Sunday in Minnesota’s Week 13 loss to New England.

impact: Peterson again led Washington's backfield in carries by a healthy margin without Chris Thompson available for the second consecutive week. All Day out-carried third-down back Kapri Bibbs 24-2 on Sunday, now having out-carried the latter 41-4 in the Redskins' last two games. He's bulldozed his way to 196 yards (4.78 YPC) in that span, too. If Thompson remains out in Week 8 against the Giants, Peterson will again be a clear-cut usage-based RB2.
report: Adrian Peterson handled a team-high 24 carries for 99 yards in Washington's Week 7 victory over the Cowboys.

impact: Peterson got the scoring started with a 7-yard receiving TD, then landed a game-clinching haymaker on his 64-yard breakaway touchdown.  Peterson has now tied Barry Sanders for the most 50-plus-yard rushing TDs in league history (15).  Even at age 33, Peterson has settled in as the centerpiece of Washington's offense.  He will be a legitimate RB1 play in Week 9 against the Falcons.
report: Adrian Peterson rushed 26 times for 149 yards and a touchdown and caught a seven-yard score in Washington's Week 8 win over the Giants.

impact: Peterson dislocated his shoulder back in Week 5 but hasn't missed any time. The Redskins have been giving him Wednesdays off. He'll return to full practice Thursday.
report: Adrian Peterson (shoulder) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: Negative game script combined with more offensive line injuries doomed Peterson, who also got vultured on a three-yard rushing TD by Kapri Bibbs in the second half.  And Peterson's best run of the game was negated by a penalty.  The Skins are in danger of heading to Tampa Bay in Week 10 without LT Trent Williams (thumb surgery), LG Shawn Lauvao (knee), and RG Brandon Scherff (shoulder).
report: Adrian Peterson managed 17 yards on nine carries and caught 3-of-3 targets for 16 yards in Washington's Week 9 loss to Atlanta.

impact: Peterson is going to play against the Bucs; he's been battling the shoulder thing for weeks now.  The key for Peterson each week is the Redskins need to be close or in the lead for him to get regular work.  That should happen vs. Tampa.
report: Adrian Peterson (shoulder) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Peterson has a golden matchup against the Bucs but will be missing three, and possibly even four, offensive linemen. Even in the solid spot, Peterson will be a riskier RB2 than usual because of his blocking question marks.
report: Adrian Peterson (shoulder) was upgraded to "full" on Thursday.

impact: He caught both of his targets for a gain of one yard.  It was nothing special in the box score, but getting the ball in Peterson's hands is the Redskins' preferred offense to salt away the clock and keep the ball away from the opponent.  It's a boring brand of ball, but it works for them right now.  Washington is averaging fewer than 20 points per game.  Peterson gets the Texans in Week 11.
report: Adrian Peterson rushed 19 times for 68 yards in the Redskins' Week 10 win over the Bucs.

impact: This is his usual practice routine. Peterson's production has tailed off the last couple of weeks, but he's still on pace for what would be his eighth 1,000-yard rushing season. The 33-year-old can be safely employed as an RB2 when the Redskins host Houston Sunday at FedEx Field.
report: Adrian Peterson (shoulder) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Peterson has been dealing with shoulder and ankle injuries for the past several weeks, but he is finally getting back to normal. "My shoulder, I’m back to bench pressing. I hadn’t did that in three weeks," Peterson said. "So, I’m back to kind of doing the normal things that I was able to do. My ankle is feeling good." Peterson was limited during Wednesday's practice but was upgraded to full participation on Thursday. His health is not a concern at this point.
report: Adrian Peterson (shoulder, ankle) said he is "feeling all the way healthy."

impact: The scores saved his fantasy day because Peterson's rushing impact was otherwise minimal and he didn't draw a single passing-game target.  The downgrade from Alex Smith to Colt McCoy isn't as major as it'll be made out to be, and Washington's run-first approach won't be changing.  Peterson will remain a volume-based, touchdown-reliant RB2 on Thanksgiving against the Cowboys.
report: Adrian Peterson rushed 16 times for 51 yards and two touchdowns in Washington's Week 11 loss to Houston.

impact: Peterson has now been held below 70 yards rushing in four-straight games and is averaging just 3.05 yards per carry in the process. A hollowed out offensive line and quarterback change will do that. Peterson has a tough Week 13 matchup in the Eagles. He is falling down the RB2 ranks.
report: Adrian Peterson rushed 12 times for 35 yards in the Redskins' Week 12 loss to the Cowboys, adding two catches for nine additional yards.

impact: AD has battled a sore shoulder for weeks. This is almost certainly a maintenance day for the 33-year-old. Peterson should be fine for Monday night's game in Philadelphia, though he could lose work to receiving back Chris Thompson (ribs), who is due back from a four-game absence.
report: Adrian Peterson (shoulder) didn't practice on Thursday.

impact: Peterson was held out Thursday for rest purposes. He should be fine for Monday night, though his workload is going to be scaled back with Chris Thompson returning.
report: Adrian Peterson (shoulder) returned to a limited practice Friday.

impact: Peterson was held out early in the week but his status wasn't in doubt. He's our No. 33 ranked running back for Monday night's matchup with the Eagles.
report: Adrian Peterson (shoulder) was removed from the Week 13 injury report.

impact: He wasn't targeted in the passing game.  Peterson scored a 90-yard touchdown on a handoff from Mark Sanchez on Sanchez's first snap of the game after replacing Colt McCoy following a broken fibula.  Peterson did nothing on the rest of his touches.  The nine carries tied an eight-game-low.  Peterson will be faced with stacked boxes the rest of the way with Mark Sanchez at quarterback.  Blowouts will be almost certain.  Peterson will be a very risky RB2 the final month.
report: Adrian Peterson rushed nine times for 98 yards and one touchdown in the Redskins' 28-13, Week 13 loss to the Eagles on Monday night.

impact: Kelley was injured in Sunday's loss to the Colts. It sounds like he will be a candidate for return. Kelley must sit at least eight games. Samaje Perine will slot in as the Redskins' No. 3 back.
report: Redskins placed RB Rob Kelley on injured reserve with a toe injury.

impact: Thompson has battled knee and ribs issues the past few weeks and re-injured his ribs on the other side last week against the Giants.  His role has almost evaporated in recent weeks with Adrian Peterson playing so well.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) is not practicing Wednesday.

impact: As did Jamison Crowder (ankle). Thompson has reached his yearly banged up portion of the season. He is going to miss Sunday's game against the Falcons.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) remained sidelined on Thursday.

impact: He's not going to play against the Falcons, leaving pass-game work to Kapri Bibbs behind workhorse Adrian Peterson.  Peterson has been nails the last month, carrying the offense, and will remain a rock-solid RB2.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) remained sidelined at Friday's practice.

impact: Thompson's presence has had little impact on Adrian Peterson, who still handled 26 carries against the Giants just last week. If game script stays positive for Washington, AP would bolster a majority of the work no matter who's behind him. If the Falcons somehow take a commanding lead over the Redskins, though, note that third-down back Kapri Bibbs would likely get involved over Peterson. All Day is still a low-end RB1 that should dominate against the Falcons' shaky front-seven.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) won't play in Week 9 against the Falcons.

impact: Thompson sat out last week's game with a rib injury and isn't starting this week off on the right foot. Kapri Bibbs would likely spell Adrian Peterson on passing downs if Thompson can't get the green light for Sunday's game in Tampa.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) remained sidelined at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Thompson appears poised to miss yet another game this week. Kapri Bibbs is his fill-in.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) remained sidelined on Thursday.

impact: Thompson will have now missed 4-of-5 games. He doesn't seem particularly close to returning. Kapri Bibbs will try to change the pace/catch passes behind Adrian Peterson. "Try" because the Redskins' offensive line has bene destroyed by injury.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) has been ruled out for Week 10.

impact: This isn't a surprise after Thompson didn't practice Wednesday. The Redskins will continue to go with Kapri Bibbs as their pass-down complement to Adrian Peterson. Thompson remains week to week.
report: Redskins coach Jay Gruden said there's a "good chance" Chris Thompson (ribs) doesn't play in Week 11.

impact: Thompson didn't practice all week, putting his status for Thanksgiving against the Cowboys in jeopardy, too. With Samaje Perine (calf) ruled out, the Redskins will have only Adrian Peterson and Kapri Bibbs available in their backfield Sunday. It's likely the team promotes Byron Marshall from the practice squad just to have another body.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) is out for Week 11 against the Texans.

impact: He hasn't played since Week 8.  It's been a lost season for Thompson.  Kapri Bibbs will continue to work as Adrian Peterson's lightly-used pace-changer.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) is out for Week 12 against the Cowboys.

impact: Thompson has been sidelined since Week 8. A practice this early in the week, especially with Washington not playing until Monday night, strongly suggests Thompson will return this week. Even so, he will not be a strong fantasy option against the Eagles with Adrian Peterson operating as the workhorse.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) returned to practice Monday.

impact: Thompson resumed practicing earlier this week and appears to be on track for Monday night's game in Philadelphia. "When you watch him run there is no issue," said Gruden. "I think he’ll be fine." Assuming he returns from a four-game absence, Thompson will function as a passing-down complement to early-down hammer Adrian Peterson.
report: Redskins coach Jay Gruden believes Chris Thompson (ribs) will be "fine" to play Week 13 against the Eagles.

impact: This was fully expected after he practiced fully all week. Thompson will resume his pass-down role behind Adrian Peterson but should be avoided in his first game back.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) was removed from the Week 13 injury report.

impact: He should slide right into the role Kapri Bibbs was filling as Adrian Peterson's change-of-pace and pass-game specialist.  With the Redskins as road underdogs, it wouldn't be a surprise if Thomspon was heavily involved.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) is active for Week 13 against the Eagles.

impact: Thompson played his first game since Week 8 and did nothing of note.  He reclaimed pass-game work but made zero plays.  It's been a season to forget for Thompson.  He's off the fantasy radar until further notice.
report: Chris Thompson rushed three times for three yards and caught 3-of-5 targets for 18 yards in the Redskins' blowout loss to the Eagles in Week 13.

impact: He was sacked three times for a loss of eight yards. Smith was surgical in his Washington debut, cutting up the Cardinals with his usual precision on short and intermediate passes. The former Chief was so accurate, he completed 13 passes in a row at one point. Smith's favorite target seemed to be receiving back Chris Thompson, who he hooked up with six times for 63 yards and a touchdown. His longest completion came on a 52-yard screen to Adrian Peterson late in the fourth quarter, though AD admittedly did most of the work on that one. With the Redskins up big, Smith only attempted 10 passes after halftime. The 34-year-old could have some streaming appeal against a lackluster Colts secondary in Week 2.
report: Alex Smith completed 21-of-30 passes for 255 yards and a pair of touchdowns while adding 14 yards on eight carries Sunday in Washington’s Week 1 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Smith also lost 23 yards on three sacks. The Redskins’ offense was cooking against the Cardinals last week, but they never got going on Sunday, managing just three field goals in a home loss to Indy. Smith had a quiet first half but let it rip after halftime, tallying 195 of his 292 yards in the second half. Most of it came in garbage time on check-downs to Chris Thompson, though he did connect on a handful of deep balls. Smith and the Redskins will take a 1-1 record into next week’s home matchup against the Packers.
report: Alex Smith completed 33-of-46 passes for 292 yards with no touchdowns or interceptions while supplying 14 yards on four carries Sunday in Washington’s Week 2 loss to the Colts.

impact: He added seven rushes for 20 additional yards. Smith's lone highlight was his 46-yard touchdown strike to Paul Richardson in the first quarter. Smith and Richardson split the defense and Richardson made a diving catch between two defenders near the goal line. Untouched, Richardson got up and finished the job. After that, Smith was dinking and dunking and doing his signature take off and run on nearly every third down. Unable to hit any big plays, Smith and the Redskins kept the Packers in the game. Thankfully for the Redskins, the Packers ruined themselves with drops and penalties. Smith is off to a highly Smith-ian start so far this season but has an attackable Week 5 matchup in the Saints.
report: Alex Smith completed 12-of-20 passes for 220 yards, two touchdowns and an interception in the Redskins' 31-17, Week 3 win over the Packers.

impact: He added a four-yard rushing score, but Smith was far worse than his pedestrian numbers even suggest.  He did some stat-padding late in the blowout loss.  Smith threw multiple hospital balls to his targets in the pass game, getting both Adrian Peterson (knee) and Chris Thompson (ribs) injured, while also spiking numerous passes into the turf well short of his receivers.  Smith lost a hilariously-bad fumble that went about 20 feet into the air and backwards for an easy scoop for the Saints.  It's hard to believe how terrible the Redskins were coming out of their bye.  They're now on a short week ahead of a home game against Carolina.  Smith won't be a fantasy option.
report: Alex Smith completed 23-of-39 passes for 275 yards, no touchdowns, and one interception in the Redskins' 43-19, Week 5 loss to the Saints.

impact: He added five carries for 14 yards. Averaging an inexcusable 4.53 yards per attempt, Smith was mostly dreadful, but the Panthers could never make him pay by creating a turnover. The Redskins won on the back of their running game. Vernon Davis was schemed completely wide open on Smith's first score, though his second was a nice throw to Paul Richardson in the back of the end zone. With seven total touchdowns through five games, Smith will be a last-gasp QB2 against the Cowboys in Week 7.
report: Alex Smith completed 21-of-36 passes for 163 yards and two touchdowns in the Redskins' 23-17, Week 6 win over the Panthers.

impact: In vintage Smith fashion, his only score on the day came on a 23-yard screen pass to change-of-pace back Kapri Bibbs. No receiver topped 43 yards for Washington. Dallas' secondary admittedly presents a tough matchup, but it is the second straight week Smith's failed to exceed 175 passing yards. Given the club's run-first grind-it-out style of play, Smith should only be used in terrific matchups on paper -- like the one the Redskins face in Week 8 against the Giants.
report: Alex Smith completed 14-of-25 passes for 178 yards and one touchdown in Washington's Week 7 win over the Cowboys.

impact: Smith has settled into a low-volume, game-manager role with Adrian Peterson as Washington's offensive centerpiece.  Smith has not finished as a top-12 fantasy quarterback in any of the first seven weeks.  Smith will be a low-ceiling two-quarterback-league play in Week 9 against Atlanta.
report: Alex Smith completed 20-of-32 passes for 178 yards and a touchdown and rushed three times for 13 yards in Washington's Week 8 win over the Giants.

impact: He rushed once for 22 yards and got absolutely leveled by Falcons DB Brian Poole at the end of the sideline scramble.  Sunday's game script did not go in the favor of Washington, which aims to control games and win with strong run defense and a high-volume rushing attack.  The Redskins fell behind the Falcons and couldn't stop the run, so Smith dropped back to pass 49 times with three sacks taken.  Even against the Bucs in Week 10, Smith will remain a two-quarterback-league play only.
report: Alex Smith completed 30-of-46 passes for 306 yards, one touchdown, and one interception in Washington's Week 9 loss to Atlanta.

impact: The Tampa Bay offense thoroughly outplayed the Redskins' unit between the 20s, but the Bucs consistently shot themselves in the foot with horrid turnovers at the goal line and deep in Washington territory.  Smith's lone score was a short hookup with Josh Doctson, while Maurice Harris led the team in receiving with a 5-52 day.  The 6-3 Skins host the Texans in Week 11.
report: Alex Smith completed 19-of-27 passes for 178 yards and one touchdown in the Redskins' 16-3, Week 10 win over the Bucs.

impact: Smith got mauled by two Texans defenders who came free for the sack, and his right leg was hanging by a thread afterwards.  We wouldn't expect to see him for the rest of the year.  Smith finished 12-of-27 passing for 135 yards and two interceptions, including Texans rookie S Justin Reid's 102-yard pick six.  Colt McCoy will take over as the Redskins' starting quarterback.
report: Alex Smith suffered a gruesome leg/ankle injury in the third quarter of Sunday's Week 11 game against Houston.

impact: The compound leg fracture occurred in the third quarter of Week 11's loss to Houston.  Colt McCoy will close out the year as Washington's starting quarterback.  Previously, McCoy and Smith were the only two signal callers on the Redskins' roster.  Smith, who turns 35 next May, will have a long road back from this gruesome injury.  It's fair to wonder whether he'll be ready for Week 1 in 2019.
report: Alex Smith is done for the season with a fractured fibula and tibia.

impact: A compound fracture means the bone pierced through the skin, while a spiral fracture is where a long bone is broken by rotational force, hence the "spiral" motion.  Smith broke both his tibia and fibula, a gruesome injury that will require a lengthy rehab.  It's not 100% Smith will be able to play again.
report: Updating a previous item, Alex Smith's broken right leg involved compound and spiral fractures.

impact: In the two games without Amari Cooper, Nelson has managed just 30 yards on seven targets. The Raiders offense is among the worst in the NFL right now, and things won't be easier for Nelson and Derek Carr against the Chargers. With three straight games with less than 20 receiving yards, Nelson is not a recommended Week 10 start.
report: Jordy Nelson caught just two passes for 16 yards on his three targets in the Raiders' Week 9 loss to the 49ers.

impact: Nelson limped to the sidelines in the second quarter, but he was able to work out what was described as a cramp. He returned to the game in the third quarter.
report: Jordy Nelson exited Week 10 against the Chargers with a quad injury, but he later returned

impact: Nelson briefly left the game with a quad injury, but he returned. Nelson now has a total of 36 yards in the last four games. He can safely be dropped in all formats.
report: Jordy Nelson did not catch his only target in the Raiders' Week 10 loss to the Chargers.

impact: Coach Jon Gruden said Nelson will be listed as questionable. Nelson is dealing with a knee bruise he suffered in Week 10 against the Chargers. With Nelson banged up and Martavis Bryant (MCL) out, the Raiders promoted Saeed Blacknall from the practice squad.
report: Jordy Nelson (knee) could miss Week 11 against the Cardinals.

impact: With Martavis Bryant (knee), Nelson's absence would leave the Raiders laughably thin at wideout. His status will be updated on Friday.
report: Jordy Nelson (knee) remained sidelined on Thursday.

impact: Nelson is questionable, but note that he failed to practice at any point throughout the week. Martavis Bryant (knee) was ruled out, too, potentially leaving Brandon LaFell, Seth Roberts, and Dwayne Harris as Oakland's three primary receivers. None are worth rolling out against the Cardinals' No. 5 pass defense DVOA.
report: Jordy Nelson (knee) is questionable for Week 11 against the Cardinals.

impact: Martavis Bryant (knee) was officially ruled out, too. That leaves Brandon LaFell, Seth Roberts, Dwayne Harris, Marcell Ateman, and practice squad call-up Saeed Blacknall as the only available receiving options for Derek Carr Sunday. Fire up the Cardinals' defense everywhere.
report: Jordy Nelson (knee) is out for Week 11 against the Cardinals.

impact: Specifically, Gruden said Nelson "has a chance" to resume practicing, which would indicate a chance to play.  With Brandon LaFell (Achilles') done for the year and Martavis Bryant (PCL) out indefinitely, Jordy has an opportunity to emerge as the Raiders' No. 1 wide receiver down the stretch.
report: Coach Jon Gruden said Monday that Jordy Nelson (knee, quad) could return in Week 12 against the Ravens.

impact: He's hoping to return for Sunday's game in Baltimore after missing Week 11 with knee and quad injuries. There's opportunity for Nelson to carve out a meaningful role in Oakland's injury-ravaged pass-catching corps, though fantasy owners shouldn't want any part of the Raiders' offense right now.
report: Jordy Nelson (knee) returned to a limited practice on Wednesday.

impact: He's expected to return after getting in a limited week of practice. Nelson has cleared 50 yards receiving just once this year and won't be an appealing fantasy option in a tough road matchup.
report: Jordy Nelson (knee) is questionable for Week 12 against the Ravens.

impact: Perine is a healthy scratch. Adrian Peterson will draw the start at running back against his former team with Chris Thompson spelling him on passing downs. LB Zach Brown (oblique), LB Ryan Kerrigan (hip), QB Colt McCoy (thumb) and OT Trent Williams (knee) are all active for Sunday's opener.
report: Redskins declared RB Samaje Perine, CB Adonis Alexander, DL Caleb Brantley, OL Geron Christian, C Casey Dunn, WR Maurice Harris and LB Josh Keyes inactive for Week 1 against the Cardinals.

impact: His knee injury required only a one-game absence. Nelson has a chance for big volume as the last man standing in Oakland's injury-ruined receiver corps, though the declining 33-year-old hasn't exactly lit it up this year, averaging a mere 39.2 yards in his nine games. In a tough matchup, he can probably be avoided for fantasy purposes.
report: Jordy Nelson (questionable, knee) is expected to play Week 12 against the Ravens.

impact: He's back after sitting out last week's game with a bruised knee. Nelson should see a substantial workload given all of Oakland's injuries at wide receiver, though he draws a tough assignment playing on the road at Baltimore. DE Fadol Brown, WR Martavis Bryant, CB Leon Hall, OG Denver Kirkland, LB Emmanuel Lamur, OT Justin Murray, OT Ian Silberman round out the Raiders' inactives for Week 12.
report: Jordy Nelson (knee) is active for Week 12 against the Ravens.

impact: Nelson returned from a one-week absence but didn't do anything. Derek Carr seemed to favor Marcell Ateman, targeting him a team-high 10 times while only looking Nelson's way on one occasion. Oakland's offense is in shambles and the aging Nelson has done very little to help the cause. Even against a Chiefs defense that gave up 54 points and over 400 yards of offense last week, Nelson won't be of much use to fantasy owners in Week 13.
report: Jordy Nelson came up empty on his lone target Sunday in the Raiders’ Week 12 loss to the Ravens.

impact: Nelson returned from his one-game absence last week but came up empty on his only target. Even with a matchup against the Chiefs, Nelson should be avoided as the No. 3 option behind Jared Cook and Marcell Ateman.
report: Jordy Nelson (knee) is practicing in full for Week 13.

impact: Taking advantage of a mouthwatering matchup, Nelson set a new season high for catches. The yards were his second most. It was just the second time all year Nelson cleared 50 yards. It's encouraging, and proved that Nelson is back to full health, but he will find the sledding tougher in Week 14 against the Steelers.
report: Jordy Nelson caught 10-of-11 targets for 97 yards in the Raiders' Week 13 win over the Chiefs.

impact: Dealing with an elbow injury, Mariota had failed to top 103 yards in any game this season, but he looked quite a bit better in this one. Coming out firing, Mariota had 115 yards in the first quarter despite missing Corey Davis on what should have been a long gain, and he kept pushing the ball downfield all game. His newfound health did not stifle his rushing numbers, either, as he consistently made big plays on the ground. His magnum opus was a 16-play, 75-yard drive in overtime to win the game. He converted one fourth down with a great throw to Taywan Taylor, another with a dump off to Dion Lewis, and found Davis in the end zone for the game-winner. Now healthy, Mariota will be in the QB1 conversation next week in Buffalo.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 30-of-43 passes for 344 yards, two touchdowns, and an interception in the Titans' Week 4, overtime win over the Eagles, adding 46 yards and a touchdown on the ground.

impact: He only rushed twice for ten yards, although one was a hurdling doozy for a key first down.  Mariota was not helped by a back-breaking third-down drop by Nick Williams in the fourth quarter that would have gone for an easy touchdown, but Mariota also got away with numerous head-scratching throws when under duress.  Mariota heads back to Nashville in Week 6 for a brutal matchup versus Baltimore.  He has settled in as a dicey two-quarterback-league play.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 14-of-26 passes for 129 yards and an interception in the Titans' Week 5 loss at Buffalo.

impact: Mariota didn't stand a chance behind the Titans' O-line Sunday afternoon, losing 66 yards on a whopping 11 sacks taken. It was the second time in as many games that Tennessee's offense failed to score a touchdown, and the third time in the last four weeks that Mariota's failed to eclipse the daunting 130-yard mark. Even Corey Davis was dragged down in the Titans' woeful performance, hauling in just one catch for 24 yards. It's possible Mariota's playing through an ailing elbow injury suffered earlier in the year, but Coach Mike Vrabel's offense has still undoubtedly been one of the most disappointing units of 2018. The Titans will attempt to bounce back in Wembley against the Chargers next week.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 10-of-15 passes for 117 yards in the Titans' dreadful Week 6 loss to the Ravens.

impact: He added 38 yards on seven rushes. Mariota led the Titans to a game-tying fourth-quarter drive but failed to hit the two-point conversion. It was an improvement from last week, but Mariota continues to be a huge disappointment under a new coaching staff. The Titans had just three touchdowns in their last 45 drives going into Sunday. Mariota will be a QB2 coming out of the bye in Week 9 against the Cowboys.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 24-of-32 passes for 237 yards with a touchdown and an interception in Week 7 against the Chargers.

impact: He added 32 yards and a third touchdown on 10 attempts as a runner, including a couple late kneel-downs.  Things couldn't have started any worse for the Titans' offense, as Mariota was sack-fumbled on the opening series and then lost a second fumble on the very next possession on a botched handoff with Dion Lewis.  Things quickly turned around in the second quarter and the rest of the way, with Mariota hooking up with Lewis for an 18-yard score on a screen pass.  He also had a perfectly-paced 36-yard deep shot down the middle to Darius Jennings on a bit of a wobbler into triple-coverage.  Mariota's second passing score was a beautifully-read RPO shovel pass to Jonnu Smith from seven yards away.  Mariota has had his two best games of the season against NFC East teams.  The Titans host the Patriots in Week 10.  Mariota will be a QB2.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 21-of-29 passes for 240 yards and two touchdowns in the Titans' 28-14, Week 9 win over the Cowboys on Monday night.

impact: He added a 21-yard reception and two carries for 21 yards on the ground.  Mariota has now been highly efficient in three straight games, the first a one-point loss to the Chargers in a game the Titans very nearly won, and the last two upset victories over Dallas and New England.  Mariota is squarely in the QB1 crosshairs ahead of a potential Week 11 shootout at Indy's Lucas Oil Stadium.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 16-of-24 passes for 228 yards and two touchdowns in the Titans' Week 10 win over the Patriots.

impact: Mariota appears available for emergency duty, but it was Blaine Gabbert who took the field for the third quarter. Mariota went down in the waning moments of the first half. He sat on the field trying to shake his elbow out for several minutes. Gabbert will play out the string of what's shaping up to be a blowout loss.
report: Marcus Mariota was forced from Sunday's game against the Colts with a right (throwing) elbow injury and is questionable to return.

impact: The coach added Mariota is not in the concussion protocol, and he is hopeful the quarterback will be able to play Monday night against the Texans. It is good news Mariota did not re-injure his troublesome elbow, but it is concerning he is dealing with another nerve injury. Blaine Gabbert will get the start if Mariota cannot return. If that happens, the Texans DST will be the top play on the board.
report: Titans coach Mike Vrabel said Marcus Mariota suffered a stinger Week 11 against the Colts.

impact: He considers himself day to day, as most players do when they're injured.  Who knows if he'll start Monday night against the Texans.  The Titans don't have to release an official injury report until Thursday.
report: Marcus Mariota (neck) was limited in Wednesday's practice.

impact: Mariota appears genuinely questionable for Monday's game against the Texans. An upgrade to "full" on Friday would have him on track to start. Blaine Gabbert would be unusable in fantasy were Mariota to sit.
report: Marcus Mariota (neck) remained "limited" on Thursday.

impact: Coach Mike Vrabel also said he expects Mariota to start Monday night. Tennessee is coming off an abysmal letdown against the Colts, but has a tremendous chance to bounce back offensively as long as Mariota's officially under center. He'll be a low-end QB1 in Week 12.
report: Marcus Mariota (neck) was a full participant in practice Friday.

impact: The Titans removed Mariota from the injury report after two straight full practices.  Mariota's neck injury was never expected to keep him out, but he may not be 100 percent. He's our No. 24 ranked quarterback for Week 12.
report: Marcus Mariota (neck) will start Monday night's game against the Texans.

impact: Mariota completed his first 19 passes of the night, channeling his inner Philip Rivers who set the record with 25 straight completions on Sunday  Mariota didn't have his first incompletion until there was 1:06 left in the fourth quarter.  He finished with a near-perfect 147.7 passer rating and threw 61- and 48-yard touchdown passes to Jonnu Smith and Corey Davis, respectively.  Smith did all the work on his, racking up a ton of YAC as he went almost untouched to the end zone after not being covered.  Davis' ball was a deep shot down the right side.  He was wide open.  Mariota added 28 rushing yards.  One of the most unpredictable players at the position, Mariota can pop up for big games in random spots and totally bottom out in perceived good matchups.  This offense is bipolar as a whole.  Mariota will get the Jets at home in Week 13.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 22-of-23 passes for 304 yards and two touchdowns in the Titans' 34-17, Week 12 loss to the Texans on Monday night.

impact: It confirms Mariota is over his neck issue. The Titans listed him with a core injury, but it won't impact his status for a streamable Week 13 matchup with the Jets.
report: Marcus Mariota (core) is practicing fully for Week 13.

impact: Mariota was also the team's leading rusher with 42 yards on five attempts.  The Titans were getting creamed early, losing 16-0 at one point deep into the second quarter.  But Mariota ended up hitting Anthony Firkser for a 12-yard score with 57 second to half to get the Titans on the board.  The teams continued to trade field goals, but Mariota then hit Corey Davis for an 11-yard score on 3rd-and-6 with 36 ticks left in regulation to win the game.  Mariota has now strung together back-to-back good games after his injury-aided dud in Indy three weeks back.  Tennessee will host the Jaguars in Week 14.  Mariota will be more of a mid-range QB2 with upside.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 20-of-35 passes for 282 yards, two touchdowns, and one interception in the Titans' 26-22, Week 13 win over the Jets.

impact: Bryant was mostly invisible except for a fourth quarter end zone target that resulted in Derek Carr's second interception of the day. Bryant was completely blanketed by Xavien Howard. It was an ill-advised throw. Despite his well-known upside, Bryant has given zero indication through two games he will be usable in fantasy leagues as a Raider.
report: Martavis Bryant caught 2-of-5 targets for 30 yards in the Raiders' Week 3 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: Bryant dropped two passes -- including one that would have gone for a touchdown bomb after he got clean behind Cleveland's secondary -- but did contribute positively with a downfield run block on Marshawn Lynch's 59-yard dash.  Oakland's situational deep threat and third receiver behind Amari Cooper and Jordy Nelson, Bryant will be a low-floor WR4/flex option in Week 5 against the Chargers.
report: Martavis Bryant caught 3-of-7 targets for 51 yards in the Raiders' Week 4 win over the Browns.

impact: In just his fourth game with the team, Bryant led the Raiders with 91 receiving yards. A majority of his production admittedly came in the fourth quarter with his team trailing late. Bryant has stayed involved as an over-the-top burner, though, averaging an outstanding 16.8 yards per catch. If involved more down the road, you don't have to squint to spot a legitimate path in which he overtakes Cooper as the team's No. 1 receiver. He's on a FLEX-deemable pace of 45-757 this season.
report: Martavis Bryant hauled in all three of his targets for a team-high 91 yards in the Raiders' Week 5 loss to the Chargers.

impact: The team is "cautiously hopeful" Bryant can play in London on Sunday. If he's unable to suit up, Seth Roberts and veteran Brandon LaFell would start on the outside along with Amari Cooper and Jordy Nelson. Cooper's stock would be slightly increased without Bryant in the lineup, though the former would still be a boom-bust WR3/FLEX.
report: Martavis Bryant (flu) is questionable for Week 6 against the Seahawks.

impact: Bryant has struggled with drops and turnovers this season, and he failed to capitalize on Seth Roberts (concussion) and Amari Cooper's (concussion) early Week 6 exits.  A situational deep threat on a team whose quarterback doesn't enjoy pulling the trigger to go deep, Bryant is all but worthless in fantasy leagues.
report: Martavis Bryant caught 2-of-3 targets for 18 yards in the Raiders' Week 6 loss to Seattle.

impact: "I think it helps a player like Martavis Bryant," Olson said, "because he’s got tremendous skills, tremendous size and speed, and he’s still really kind of learning the system."  Bryant will step in as the starter opposite Jordy Nelson moving forward, with Seth Roberts working the slot.  The Raiders also have Brandon LaFell and practice-squad call-up Marcell Ateman.  Bryant figures to act as the lid-lifting deep threat.  He needs to be added anywhere he's available.
report: Raiders OC Greg Olson talked up Martavis Bryant in the aftermath of the Amari Cooper trade.

impact: The Raiders talked up Bryant throughout the week, hinting that he'd play a bigger role following Amari Cooper's trade to the Cowboys. So naturally he wound up playing just seven snaps. The Raiders ignored Bryant on Sunday and fantasy owners would be wise to do the same Thursday against San Francisco.
report: Martavis Bryant wasn’t targeted Sunday in Oakland’s Week 8 loss to Indianapolis.

impact: Bryant, who wasn't targeted in Week 8, has been an afterthought for weeks now. There was some optimism driven by the Raiders' OC Greg Olsen that Bryant will be more involved with Amari Cooper traded to Dallas, but there's no way Bryant can be trusted in fantasy lineups at this point.
report: Martavis Bryant hauled in 2-of-2 targets for 29 yards in the Raiders' Week 9 loss to the 49ers.

impact: Bryant suffered the injury trying to haul in a pass along the sideline in the third quarter. He was quickly ruled out, suggesting he could be dealing with a serious injury. Bryant caught three passes for 17 yards before exiting.
report: Martavis Bryant exited Week 10 against the Chargers with a knee injury.

impact: Bryant won't know the full scope of his injury until he undergoes an MRI. He's going to miss time, though the Raiders are hopeful Martavis will avoid surgery. With Bryant injured and Amari Cooper now on Dallas, Oakland's pass-catching corps is running on fumes right now. More will be asked of Jared Cook and Brandon LaFell in Bryant's absence.
report: According to NFL Network's Ian Rapoport, Martavis Bryant may have torn his PCL Sunday in the Raiders' Week 10 loss to the Chargers.

impact: With Bryant and Nelson out, the Raiders will be starting Brandon LaFell and Seth Roberts. What a sorry state of affairs.
report: Raiders declared WR Martavis Bryant, WR Jordy Nelson, DE Fadol Brown, G/T Denver Kirkland, LB Emmanuel Lamur, OT Justin Murray and OL Ian Silberman.

impact: It's surprising he drew the questionable tag after not practicing this week. Even against a vulnerable Chiefs secondary, Bryant won't be of any fantasy interest in the unlikely event he actually plays.
report: Martavis Bryant (knee) is questionable for Week 13 against the Chiefs.

impact: Bryant was never going to play after missing his third straight week of practice. The Raiders will continue to go with Marcell Ateman and Jordy Nelson as their top wideouts. Bryant may be targeting a Week 14 return.
report: Martavis Bryant (knee) has been downgraded to doubtful for Week 13.

impact: Bryant remains week to week. The fact that he was listed "doubtful" heading into this afternoon's game suggests there is a chance he returns for Week 14.
report: Raiders declared WR Martavis Bryant, OG Chaz Green, LB Emmanuel Lamur, CB Montrel Meander, OT Justin Murray, OL Ian Silberman and TE Darren Waller inactive for Week 13 against the Chiefs.

impact: Bryant tore his PCL in Week 10 and hadn't played since.  Acquired from the Steelers for a third-round pick, Bryant's 2018 season was a nightmare, catching 19 balls for 266 scoreless yards after initially believed to be facing an indefinite suspension.  27 later this month, Bryant is headed for free agency.
report: Raiders placed WR Martavis Bryant (knee) on injured reserve, ending his season.

impact: A seventh-round, 24-year-old rookie out of Oklahoma State, Ateman was promoted from the practice squad ahead of this week's game. With Martavis Bryant (knee) and Jordy Nelson (knee) both on the shelf, Ateman was pressed into heavy duty after Brandon LaFell went down midway through the third quarter with an Achilles' injury. Even if all three players miss Week 12 against the Ravens, Ateman will not be on the fantasy radar.
report: Raiders WR Marcell Ateman caught 4-of-5 targets for 50 yards in the team's Week 11 victory over the Cardinals.

impact: Meet Marcell Ateman, the Raiders' new No. 1 receiver. The seventh-round rookie saw an exhausting 10 targets in Sunday's defeat, though obviously he wasn't able to take advantage of his monster usage. Ateman played three fewer snaps than teammate Jordy Nelson, but out-targeted him by a commanding 10-1 margin. His fantasy appeal is still limited by Oakland's stagnant offense, but at least he's getting volume. We'll see what kind of workload Ateman sees when the Raiders return home to face the Chiefs in Week 13.
report: Marcell Ateman delivered three catches for 16 yards on 10 targets Sunday in the Raiders’ Week 12 loss to the Ravens.

impact: It was the first score of the seventh-round rookie's career. Ateman nearly had a 32-yarder early in the third quarter but could not hook up with Derek Carr. Although he is playing heavy snaps, Ateman is not producing enough to gain WR5 consideration in re-draft leagues.
report: Marcell Ateman caught 2-of-4 targets for 16 yards and a touchdown in the Raiders' Week 13 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: It's an upset after the Raiders traded for Martavis Bryant and Ryan Switzer, but neither addition worked out, to put it mildly. It's a shame for both Amari Cooper and Jordy Nelson, who could have benefitted from more snaps in the middle of the field. Hopefully new coach Jon Gruden will work to move Cooper around the formation like ex-OC Todd Downing finally did near the end of last season.
report: Seth Roberts will remain the Raiders' slot receiver.

impact: It means Amari Cooper is going to see more snaps out of the slot, buttressing his floor. It also means Martavis Bryant is going to play more snaps. Coach Jon Gruden actually seems to have a shrewd understanding of his offensive personnel, but one of the reasons that personnel is so bad is because of his brutal offseason roster management.
report: Raiders WR Seth Roberts is a healthy scratch for Week 3 against the Dolphins.

impact: After losing Amari Cooper (concussion), the Raiders are down to Jordy Nelson, Martavis Bryant, and Dwayne Harris at wide receiver.  Roberts immediately went to the locker room after suffering his fourth-quarter brain injury.  The slot receiver had five catches for 31 yards on six targets before departing.
report: Raiders WR Seth Roberts left Sunday's Week 6 game with a concussion.

impact: Roberts had the bye week to rest up after his Week 6 concussion. With Amari Cooper gone, Roberts is in line for an expanded role. He should get cleared for Sunday's game with the Colts.
report: Seth Roberts (concussion) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: With Amari Cooper out the picture, Roberts is in line to start alongside Martavis Bryant and Jordy Nelson in three-wide sets moving forward. He's shown a knack for the end zone when given run with the team, but still can't be started at this time. Bryant is the likeliest to play a large role against the Colts Sunday.
report: Seth Roberts (concussion) wasn't listed on the Raiders' final injury report for Week 8 against the Colts.

impact: Some theorized that Roberts' role would expand following Amari Cooper's trade to Dallas, but that obviously didn't come to fruition Sunday as the 27-year-old drew his fewest targets since Week 4. His touchdown came in the second quarter on a 31-yard heave from Derek Carr. That was both the longest catch of the day for Oakland as well as Roberts' longest play this year. Roberts won't be of much fantasy interest Thursday against the Niners.
report: Seth Roberts nabbed two of four targets for 42 yards and a touchdown Sunday in the Raiders’ Week 8 loss to the Colts.

impact: The eight yards were a season-low for Roberts, who has been weirdly less involved in the Raiders' passing attack with Amari Cooper now playing for Jerry Jones. Derek Carr has been spreading the ball evenly to all the Raiders' skill position players without Cooper, which will keep Roberts from making much noise in the second half of the year aside from a couple of random touchdowns.
report: Seth Roberts caught 1-of-2 targets for eight yards in the Raiders' Week 9 loss to the 49ers.

impact: The seven targets matched a season high. Roberts was heavily involved because both Martavis Bryant (knee) and Jordy Nelson (knee) were on the shelf. Brandon LaFell then joined them there with an Achilles' issue. Despite all that, Roberts will be tough to recommend as a WR4 option for next week's trip to Baltimore. The Raiders' passing offense simply is not good enough.
report: Seth Roberts caught 4-of-7 targets for 38 yards in the Raiders' Week 11 win over the Cardinals.

impact: The bulk of his output came on a 44-yard catch on Oakland's opening drive of the second half. He was also on the receiving end of a 34-yard strike from Derek Carr, but that play was called back on offensive pass interference as Roberts appeared to push off his defender. The undrafted 27-year-old has never been a difference-maker, though injuries to Oakland's other pass-catchers have forced him into a larger-than-expected role this season. Even in deeper leagues, Roberts won't be a recommended play when the Raiders host Kansas City in Week 13.
report: Seth Roberts corralled two-of-three targets for a team-high 54 yards Sunday in the Raiders’ Week 12 loss to Baltimore.

impact: "I think Le’Veon’s one of the best in the business, I think we all understand that and can agree on that," Roethlisberger said.  "But when Le’Veon comes back, in no way, shape or form should James just say, ‘OK, it’s all yours.  I’m gonna sit back and when you need me, use me.’  And I will push for James to get as much run as we can because we’ve seen some great things from him in all phases of football.  He’s picking up blitzes, he’s catching the ball, he’s running hard and making plays and playing with a passion, so we need to keep using that."  If Ben wants it, he usually gets it.  Conner seems certain to retain a prominent role when Bell returns, which is expected to be for Week 8.
report: Ben Roethlisberger said James Conner "should not go on the shelf by any means" if/when Le'Veon Bell ends his holdout.

impact: He added four catches for 18 yards on seven targets.  The NFL's leading tackle-shedder, Conner showed it in this one, consistently bulldozing would-be tacklers and injuring a couple along the way as S Shawn Williams was concussed on one of the long runs.  Conner's scores were both of the one-yard plunge variety.  He should have had a third touchdown but was ruled down at the one before getting stuffed on 1st- and 3rd-and-goal runs.  A premier RB1, Conner's workload will now be subject to question with Le'Veon Bell expected to report to the team during the Week 7 bye.
report: James Conner rushed 19 times for 111 yards and two touchdowns in the Steelers' 28-21, Week 6 win over the Bengals.

impact: Conner started off slowly, notching just 33 yards on the ground with 12 yards on one catch in the first half. He then wore the Browns out in the second half, rushing for 14 times for 113 yards and both scores after the break with four catches for 54 yards after the break. He broke long runs of 30 and 22 yards, the latter a game-ending dagger for a touchdown that put the Steelers ahead 33-12. Conner now has four games with over 100-yards rushing and two touchdowns on the season. It remains to be seen when Le'Veon Bell actually returns to the team, but Conner is a set-and-forget RB1 option until that happens, even against a stout Ravens defense on the road in Week 9.
report: James Conner rushed 24 times for 146 yards and two touchdowns while catching 5-of-6 targets for 66 yards in Sunday's Week 8 win over the Browns.

impact: Conner, who spent the bulk of last season filling up Gatorade cups for workhorse Le'Veon Bell, has now gone over 100 yards rushing in four straight games. The knock on Conner has been that most of his damage this year has come against subpar defenses, but obviously that wasn't the case on Sunday. The former Pitt Panther had more yards from scrimmage on the Steelers' first two drives (57) than he did the entire game when he faced the Ravens at home in Week 4 (44 yards on 12 touches). His lone touchdown came on a seven-yard screen from Ben Roethlisberger with time winding down in the first quarter. That marked the first receiving score of his two-year career. With Bell nowhere to be found, Conner will maintain his upper-echelon RB1 status next week when the Steelers host Carolina on Thursday Night Football.
report: James Conner delivered 107 yards on 24 carries while adding seven catches for 56 yards and a touchdown on nine targets Sunday in Pittsburgh’s Week 9 win over the Ravens.

impact: Conner was announced as "questionable" early in the fourth quarter but was never going to return with the Steelers winning 52-14. His status is unclear. Conner was in and out of the medical tent all evening. The abbreviated night helped snap a string of four-straight 129-plus yard performances. In addition to his head injury, the big question for Conner's Week 11 will be the potential return of Le'Veon Bell. Even if Bell is back, we expect Conner to start against the Jaguars.
report: James Conner rushed 13 times for 65 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 10 win over the Panthers, adding an eight-yard reception before departing with a possible concussion.

impact: Conner was never officially ruled out on Thursday night, but he did end up being placed in the protocol. The good news is he has 10 days to gain clearance before the Steelers hit the field again, but nothing can be taken for granted with concussions. It remains to be seen if Conner will have Le'Veon Bell to contend with once he is cleared.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports James Conner was placed in the concussion protocol.

impact: Conner exited Thursday night's game due to concussion-like symptoms but will have 10 days to get healthy ahead of Pittsburgh's Week 11 matchup with Jacksonville. With Le'Veon Bell now expected to sit out the entire season, Conner will be a locked-in RB1 the rest of the way. He could be a legit league winner for owners who were lucky to snag him in the later rounds of fantasy drafts this summer.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports the Steelers are "optimistic" James Conner (concussion) will play Week 11 against the Jaguars.

impact: Conner remains in the concussion protocol, but Tomlin said Wednesday's practice should "lay those discussions to bed." It sounds like Conner will be cleared in the very near future. Assuming Le'Veon Bell does not report Tuesday, Conner will remain an RB1 even in a tough matchup against the Jaguars on Sunday.
report: Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said James Conner (concussion) is expected to practice Wednesday.

impact: It's unclear if Conner ever actually suffered a concussion, though it's a moot point now as the second-year stud is on track to play Sunday at Jacksonville. With Le'Veon Bell done in Pittsburgh, Conner should be an RB1 the rest of the way.
report: Updating an earlier report, James Conner (concussion) was a full participant at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Conner was stifled by a stiff Jacksonville run defense, having just a long gain of nine yards on the ground. The Steelers were then scripted out of the run game chasing points in the second half. Conner added six catches, but they were all dump offs. He had a great opportunity to save his lackluster day on the final drive, but took his eyes of the ball and dropped a gift-wrapped 28-yard touchdown. Conner will look to get back on track in Week 12 at Denver.
report: James Conner rushed nine times for 25 yards while catching 6-of-9 targets for 24 yards in Sunday's Week 11 win over the Jaguars.

impact: After struggling last week against the Jaguars, Conner was not able to get much going early in this one. He recorded just 24 yards on seven first-half carries, although he did add 19 yards on three catches. He started to get things going after the break, gaining 28 yards on five carries, but that momentum came to halt when he lost a fumble at the end of the third quarter. He did not touch the ball again until he was given a shot to redeem himself with under two minutes left in the game, but he was stuffed on second-and-goal. Ben Roethlisberger was intercepted on the next play. Conner has slowed down the last couple weeks, but he will still be a solid RB1 next week against the Chargers.
report: James Conner rushed 13 times for 53 yards and hauled in all four of his targets for 42 yards in the Steelers' Week 12 loss to the Broncos.

impact: Conner went to the locker room after getting rolled up on late in the fourth quarter. He had 74 total yards and two touchdowns before exiting. This has the looks of an injury the may force Conner to miss some time. The Steelers are down to Jaylen Samuels at running back.
report: James Conner was forced from Week 13 against the Chargers with a right leg injury.

impact: Otherwise known as a bruise. Tomlin did not offer a timetable during his press conference, and it is possible a bone bruise, if that is what this ends up being, would force Conner to miss some time. Jaylen Samuels and Stevan Ridley are next up on the depth chart. Samuels is the more interesting waiver add.
report: Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said James Conner suffered a lower leg contusion Sunday night against the Chargers.

impact: RapSheet confirms the injury is not to Conner's ankle and writes, "It seems like he'll be OK." Coach Mike Tomlin called the injury a lower leg contusion after the game on Sunday night. At this point, it looks like Conner has a good shot to suit up against the Raiders on Sunday.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports James Conner's injury is "not considered major at all."

impact: The Steelers initially believed Conner was only dealing with a contusion, but further tests revealed a sprain. There is some belief he is dealing with a high-ankle sprain, which would cause him to miss multiple games. Jaylen Samuels should take over as the starter with Stevan Ridley behind him on the depth chart. Samuels is now the top add for the week.
report: Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said James Conner (ankle) will not play Week 14 against the Raiders.

impact: Bell will supposedly report to the team this week, but the Steelers remain in the dark about his plans. Even if he does, Pittsburgh could decide to pursue a roster exemption for Bell, potentially keeping him on the sidelines and reducing his pay. The Steelers are also expected to keep utilizing James Conner even once Bell returns, limiting the star's fantasy upside. This situation continues to be an absolute mess.
report: NFL Network's Aditi Kinkhabwala reports there has been "no sign of" Le'Veon Bell at the Steelers' facility on Monday.

impact: Just because the Steelers "aren't expecting" it doesn't mean it's not going to happen, as Bell has routinely left the team out of the loop on his plans.  A couple weeks back, ESPN's Jeremy Fowler reported Bell planned to report during the Week 7 bye, which is now.  We'll continue to be on Bell Watch until/if he does report.  The Steelers don't play again for 13 more days.
report: The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette's Ed Bouchette reports the Steelers don't expect holdout Le'Veon Bell to report to the team this week.

impact: Bell was thought to be targeting Week 8 for his return but now that seems unlikely. It appears Bell is waiting to see what happens at next week's trade deadline before ending his holdout. The disgruntled running back can't be traded until he signs his franchise tender, though the Steelers could get around this by granting a trade partner permission to speak with him. The Eagles would seem to be the best fit for Bell given their need at running back, though the sides haven't made much progress in recent trade discussions. When Bell reaches free agency in 2019, he'll reportedly be seeking a long-term deal worth $17 million annually with "heavy guarantees."
report: According to Jason La Canfora of CBS Sports, Steelers executives believe it's "more likely" holdout RB Le'Veon Bell returns in Week 9.

impact: Bell had been expected to return during the bye week, but Jason La Canfora reported Sunday it is "more likely" the running back returns to the team ahead of Week 9. It seems like no one except Bell really knows when he plans to report, and it remains possible he takes his holdout all the way through Week 10, after which he has to report to earn an accrued season and become a free agent. It appears as if James Conner will get at least one more game if not more of workhorse usage.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports Le'Veon Bell did not report to the team on Monday morning.

impact: Bell told ESPN a few weeks ago that he would report to the team between Weeks 7 and 8.  Instead, he's going to stay away at least one more week.  On Monday, NFL Network's Ian Rapoport suggested Bell will hold out through at least the October 31 trade deadline before reporting to the Steelers.  James Conner will continue to operate as Pittsburgh's every-down back in the meantime.
report: Le'Veon Bell's holdout will continue through Week 8.

impact: It's our routine Bell update, as the Steelers begin the work week in preparation for the Ravens.  PFT's Mike Florio brought up an interesting thought Tuesday after Bell wasn't traded ahead of the trade deadline; perhaps the sides have a "wink-nod" agreement that if Bell doesn't show up at this year, the Steelers will agree not to re-tag him next spring and grant him the free agency he so badly craves.  It's clear neither side wants anything to do with the other right now.
report: Holdout RB Le'Veon Bell remains away from the Steelers on Wednesday.

impact: The Steelers have no idea when or if Bell will arrive, though he'll need to report by November 13 in order to play this season. If Bell decides to punt 2018, the Steelers could assign him the transition tag next year, which would be far less expensive than franchise-tagging him for a third straight season. Under the transition tag, the Steelers would be able to match any offer Bell receives elsewhere. Per La Canfora, his projected salary under the transition tag could be as low as $9 million, which is far below the $14.5 million Bell passed up in 2018. The 26-year-old and his agent have played this extremely poorly.
report: According to Jason La Canfora of CBS Sports, the Steelers would consider placing the transition tag on Le'Veon Bell in 2019.

impact: Bell has eight days to report if he wants to play in 2018. As has been the case since the spring, his intentions remain unclear. James Conner keeps feasting in Bell's absence.
report: ESPN's Jeremy Fowler reports the Steelers have had no Week 10 contact with unsigned franchise player Le'Veon Bell, and he is not expected to return for Thursday's game against the Panthers.

impact: Bell tweeted Monday he was leaving his training spot in Miami. There were rumblings he planned to sign his franchise tag this week, but there's a chance he sits out all season. Bell counts as a third-year franchise player in 2019 even if he doesn't sign, so his $25 million tag number will prevent the Steelers from franchising him again in the offseason. Bell will forfeit his remaining $6.84 million salary if he doesn't report before next week.
report: The Athletic's Mark Kaboly reports there's a "real possibility" Le'Veon Bell won’t report by the franchise tag deadline.

impact: Bell was apparently spotted playing basketball at a local gym. Rapsheet reports the Steelers have no clue if Bell is actually planning to report by Tuesday's deadline, but it would stand to reason that he is. Rapsheet also claims the Steelers "really want" Bell back. If Bell finally ends his marathon holdout next week, there's a chance he would be a healthy scratch for Week 11. We will know more soon.
report: NFL.com's Ian Rapoport reports unsigned franchise player Le'Veon Bell is "in Pittsburgh currently."

impact: It means Bell will forfeit his remaining $6.84 million salary and sit out the entire season. Bell already counts as a third-year franchise player for 2019, so there's not much upside in him returning to a timeshare with James Conner. He also avoids injury and potentially extends his career. Bell will either be transition tagged or allowed to walk next offseason, where he'll become one of the highest paid backs in the league. The Steelers can move forward with Conner under team control through 2020.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Le'Veon Bell isn't expected to report before Tuesday's franchise tag deadline.

impact: Tomlin added he has not had contact with the running back and has "no reaction" to reports Bell will sit out the rest of the season. This marriage sounds done. It would be a surprise if that does not become official Tuesday afternoon.
report: Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said "so be it" if Le'Veon Bell does not report by Tuesday's deadline.

impact: What a disaster. By not reporting, Bell forfeits the remaining $6.84 million on his $14.544 million tender. 26-year-old Bell has framed this as betting on himself and doing what is right for his fellow running backs, but this is money he will never make back. There is no guarantee a 27-year-old runner is going to cash in on the open market after sitting out an entire season healthy. Even if he does, a running back passing up $14.544 million guaranteed for one season of play in the modern NFL is not a sound business decision. It's not fair, of course, but it is reality. James Conner will finish out the year as a true bell-cow back/elite RB1. The Steelers could theoretically tag Bell again in the spring, but the sides will undoubtedly divorce.
report: Unsigned Steelers franchise player Le'Veon Bell will not report by Tuesday's 4PM ET deadline and is out for the remainder of the 2018 season.

impact: The NFLPA expects the number to be the $14.5 million Bell forfeited this season. Bell's case is likely to be decided by an arbitrator, creating a new precedent for players who holdout under the franchise tag. We're not sure this makes much of a difference: Bell isn't going to be back in Pittsburgh and he's more likely to land an offer sheet at the lower amount. The Steelers will get to carry over Bell's $14.5M cap hit from this year into 2019 when he signs with another team.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports the Steelers Management council believes they'll be be able to use a $9.5 million transition tag on Le'Veon Bell this offseason.

impact: It's $3 million higher than Todd Gurley's average salary. Bell also wants $45 million guaranteed. It's a lot of money for a 27-year-old coming off a holdout at a devalued position, but Bell is going to get overpaid this offseason. With the Steelers expected to transition tag Bell, teams may be forced to frontload Bell's contract.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports impending free agent Le'Veon Bell is seeking $17 million annually.
