Josh Reynolds stepped up big with two touchdowns in Sunday's Week 8 win over the Packers, but it was clear Jared Goff has missed Kupp the past couple weeks as his safety blanket.  If Kupp was dropped in any formats, he should be added immediately when waiver wires open this week.
report: Coach Sean McVay said there's a "good chance" Cooper Kupp (knee) returns Week 9 against the Saints.

impact: This puts Kupp on track to return after missing the last two weeks. Coach Sean McVay has already said there's a "good chance" Kupp plays Sunday. Even at less than 100 percent, Kupp will be in the WR2 mix in what should be a high-scoring game with the Saints.
report: Cooper Kupp (knee) returned to limited practice Wednesday.

impact: "I know he’s feeling good and confident and excited to be back out there," coach Sean McVay said. Kupp ended up missing only two games after it looked like his season might be over when he went down against the Broncos in Week 6. Including the Denver game, Jared Goff averaged a modest 233 yards during Kupp's absence. Kupp will be a WR2 for Sunday's likely shootout in New Orleans.
report: The Rams expect Cooper Kupp (knee) to return for Sunday's game against the Saints.

impact: Kupp was expected to return this week, but getting taken off the injury report confirms he won't be on any snap restrictions. Kupp is a WR2 for Sunday's projected shootout with the Saints.
report: Cooper Kupp (knee) has been removed from the Week 9 injury report.

impact: He was removed from the injury report at the end of the week, so there was never any doubt he would play. In what could be a shootout, Kupp is a solid WR2 even coming off injury. Rams declared WR Nick Williams, DB Darious Williams, RB John Kelly, OLB Trevon Young, DT Sebastian Joseph-Day, TE Johnny Mundt, and DT Tanzel Smart inactive for Week 9.
report: Cooper Kupp (knee) is active for Week 9 against the Saints.

impact: Kupp was quiet early in his first game back, but he got on the board with a 26-yard catch on a great throw from Jared Goff in the second quarter. That was his only action of the first half. He had a mostly quiet start to the second half, as well, but he caught fire in the fourth quarter, catching three passes including a 41-yard touchdown on a game-tying touchdown drive. The Rams ended up losing, but this was a solid first game back from Kupp. He will be a great option next week against the Seahawks.
report: Cooper Kupp hauled in 5-of-6 targets for 89 yards and a touchdown in the Rams' Week 9 loss to the Saints.

impact: Running a full-speed route before encountering a defender, Kupp went down in non-contact fashion. He immediately grabbed his knee. He was helped to the sideline and then the locker room. He was immediately deemed "doubtful" to return. Kupp had five catches for 39 yards before going down. It's the second time in a month Kupp has injured his knee. The first proved to be a mild MCL sprain. Hopefully we get similarly good news this time around. Josh Reynolds is the next man up.
report: Cooper Kupp was forced from Sunday's game against the Seahawks with a non-contact left knee injury.

impact: Non-contact knee injuries are usually season-enders and McVay's post-game remarks suggest that will likely be the case with Kupp. The second-year slot receiver had just come back from an MCL injury that cost him two games. It's a big loss for the Rams, especially with the Chiefs up next in Week 11,  though L.A.'s receiver corps is still well-stocked with Brandin Cooks and Robert Woods. Assuming Kupp is out for the year or at least facing a lengthy absence, Woods will likely see more slot reps with Cooks and Josh Reynolds working outside.
report: When asked about Cooper Kupp's knee injury after Sunday's Week 10 win over the Seahawks, Rams coach Sean McVay said, "It doesn't look good."

impact: Kupp injured his knee in devastating fashion Sunday against Seattle. It was a non-contact injury and those never end well. The Rams won't know for sure until Kupp undergoes an MRI on Monday, but all signs point to a torn ACL, which would obviously end his season. Coach Sean McVay admitted after the game that Kupp's injury "doesn't look good." Robert Woods should see more slot usage in Kupp's absence while Josh Reynolds will move into three-wide sets opposite deep threat Brandin Cooks.
report: According to NFL Network's Ian Rapoport, the "initial concern" is that Cooper Kupp may have suffered a torn ACL.

impact: This was always the expectation after Kupp went down, and it was confirmed on Monday. It is a terrible blow both for the player, who was on his way to a great sophomore campaign, and one of the best teams in the league. With Kupp done for the season, the Rams should turn to Josh Reynolds as their No. 3 receiver. He caught four passes for 61 yards and two scores without Kupp in the lineup earlier this season. The Rams could also get TE Gerald Everett more involved in the passing game.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Cooper Kupp tore his ACL Week 10 against the Seahawks.

impact: Blue was out-touched 21-5 in the Texans' season opener but closed the gap (16-7) in Week 2. Miller is still being used as an every-down workhorse, but he admittedly lacks explosiveness and hasn't shown a propensity to break tackles yet this season. Until Blue eats into Miller's opportunities, though, it's the latter who's still the back to own in Houston.
report: Alfred Blue rushed seven times for 36 yards in the Texans' Week 2 loss to the Titans.

impact: Meanwhile, Lamar Miller rushed 15 times for 49 yards, so neither runner had much success.  Blue was targeted three times in the pass game, catching none of them.  The 15-12 touch share is a bit concerning for Miller owners.
report: Alfred Blue rushed 12 times for 31 yards in the Texans' Week 4 win over the Colts.

impact: Blue started and had a workhorse role despite Lamar Miller (chest) being active. He was more of a factor in the passing game, but Blue had some nice runs. The Texans never let Blue get in a rhythm and he was passed over for multiple goal-line looks in favor of Deshaun Watson. Miller was close to playing this week, so Blue will likely return to a backup role in Week 6.
report: Alfred Blue rushed 20 times for 46 yards and caught eight passes for 73 yards in Week 5 against the Cowboys.

impact: With Lamar Miller back, Blue went right back into a secondary role against the Bills. He did flash with a 17-yard run early, but he was mostly held in check the rest of the way. D'Onta Foreman's potential return is a concern for Blue's handcuff value moving forward.
report: Alfred Blue rushed seven times for 26 yards and caught 2-of-3 targets for 17 yards in the Texans' Week 6 win over the Bills.

impact: Blue was completely inefficient, averaging just 2.6 YPC against the Broncos' front-seven. His 15 carries are notable, though, because it was three more than Lamar Miller (12/21) received on the day. With D'Onta Foreman eyeing a return in the next few weeks, Blue would only be viable following the Texans' Week 10 bye if he continues seeing at least half of their backfield touches.
report: Alfred Blue rushed 15 times for 39 yards in the Texans' Week 9 victory over the Broncos.

impact: He added a 13-yard catch on his lone target.  Blue's 14 touches were actually one more than Lamar Miller, but Miller easily out-gained him with 167 yards, including a 97-yard touchdown.  Miller got most of the second half off in the comfortable win, so we wouldn't read too much into Blue out-touching his backfield mate.  Blue isn't a fantasy option with Miller healthy and playing well.
report: Alfred Blue rushed 13 times for 49 yards in the Texans' Week 12 win over the Titans.

impact: Williams caught his only target of the night. He was a non-factor in a game Dak Prescott threw for just 160 yards. The Cowboys have been one of the worst pass offenses in the league through two weeks.
report: Terrance Williams caught one pass for 12 yards in Week 2 against the Giants.

impact: Williams has made predictably zero impact through the Cowboys' first two games. We suppose his blocking will be missed if he earns a ban.
report: The Dallas Morning News reports Terrance Williams is facing a 2-4 game suspension for his offseason arrest.

impact: He was in on just nine-of-59 offensive snaps (15.3 percent). It would probably take an injury to one of the Cowboys starters for Williams to have any real fantasy relevance, and even then, that might be a stretch.
report: Terrance Williams wasn’t targeted Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 3 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: Williams saw just nine snaps last week and wasn't targeted. It appears he's fallen out of the Cowboys' rotation. Brice Butler should see an opportunity this week with Williams a healthy scratch. Unable to secure a role in arguably the league's weakest receiving corps, T-Will could be on the outs in Dallas.
report: Terrance Williams won't be active for Week 4 against the Lions.

impact: Williams didn't practice all week with a foot injury. He's also dealing with off-field issues. Brice Butler will see more snaps in place of Williams.
report: Terrance Williams (foot) has been ruled out for Week 5.

impact: It's truly been a waste of a season for Williams, who's battled foot and off-field issues throughout the year. He'll be on the bubble in the offseason. This move hopefully instills rookie Michael Gallup into the offense as the third-rounder quietly played a season-high 40-of-69 snaps in Week 4 against the Lions.
report: Cowboys placed WR Terrance Williams (foot) on injured reserve.

impact: The suspension is related to Williams' May arrest for public intoxication and leaving the scene of an accident. It comes at a fortuitous time, as he is currently on injured reserve with a foot issue. Williams will be a candidate for return later this year.
report: NFL suspended Cowboys WR Terrance Williams three games for violating the league's substance-abuse policy.

impact: It's another bad game from Hurns after getting held to one catch in the opener. The Cowboys talked up Hurns as a No. 1 option this preseason, but he's been invisible through their first two games. With the Cowboys offense spreading it around, Hurns is droppable in shallow leagues.
report: Allen Hurns caught 1-of-2 passes for nine yards in Week 2 against the Giants

impact: Hurns played a season-high 66.1 percent of the Cowboys’ offensive snaps, but didn’t do much with the opportunity. The Cowboys’ passing game continues to be stuck in neutral, though it’s unlikely Hurns will be the one to fix things.
report: Allen Hurns corralled two-of-four targets for 22 yards Sunday in Dallas’ Week 3 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: Signed to be Dallas' No. 1 receiver, Hurns has been a committee player through three weeks, commanding just nine total targets while playing 59 percent of the snaps. "The majority of my snaps, I feel like I can get separation," Hurns said. "It’s just getting to the point, especially when we (haven’t) thrown for 200 yards yet, it’s kinda frustrating." The Cowboys are rotating six receivers through a rotation, and none of them are producing. Perhaps committing to one or two receivers would help, but Dallas could really jump-start the passing attack by being less predictable, especially on first down, and pushing the ball downfield.
report: Allen Hurns said he is "frustrated" by the lack of targets going his way.

impact: This would technically qualify as a step forward for Hurns, who had been limited to a mere 41 yards on four catches over his previous three outings. The ex-Jaguar actually made a few nice grabs on Sunday including a nice sideline catch against All-Pro corner Darius Slay, but it’s clear the Cowboys’ offense will continue to live and die by Zeke Elliott. Fantasy owners who thought they could catch lightning in a bottle by taking a late-round flyer on Hurns this summer have not been rewarded for their efforts. He can be ignored against the Texans in Week 5.
report: Allen Hurns grabbed three-of-five targets for 30 yards Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 4 win over the Lions.

impact: Hurns was left wide open in the back of the end-zone on the Cowboys' first drive of the second half. He was otherwise invisible, finishing with just three targets. None of the Cowboys wideouts are fantasy relevant.
report: Allen Hurns caught a three-yard touchdown in the Cowboys' Week 5 loss to the Texans.

impact: Hurns may have had some butterflies going against his former team for the first time Sunday. Whatever the reason, Hurns couldn't get on the same page with Dak Prescott. Perhaps he'll fare better next week when the Cowboys travel to D.C. for a divisional showdown against the Redskins.
report: Allen Hurns was targeted five times but didn’t record a catch Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 6 win over the Jaguars.

impact: It was the first time Hurns eclipsed the 30-yard mark all year. His only touchdown on the season remains his Week 5 score against the Texans in which he was left wide open in the back of the end zone. The Cowboys can barely support one receiver, let alone two. Hurns shouldn't be owned.
report: Allen Hurns caught 5-of-6 targets for a season-high 74 yards in the Cowboys' Week 7 loss to the Redskins.

impact: Hurns has been relegated to No. 4/5 duties with the addition of Amari Cooper, but he made his one target count by roasting CB Malcolm Butler with a double-move on the touchdown.  Hurns is not a fantasy option.
report: Allen Hurns caught his lone target for a 23-yard touchdown in the Week 9 loss to the Titans.

impact: Hurns was only targeted twice, but he made the most of them. He continued to play behind Amari Cooper, Michael Gallup, and Cole Beasley. Hurns isn't higher than the No. 5 pass-game option.
report: Allen Hurns caught two passes for 40 yards in Week 10 against the Eagles.

impact: In his defense, Cooper's one catch was his only target on the day. Even so, it's been a rollercoaster of a season (career?) thus far for Average Amari, as he's either recorded less than 20 yards or exploded for 110-plus in all five games this season. He'll stay a boom-bust WR3 moving forward.
report: Amari Cooper thankfully caught his only target for 10 yards in the Raiders' Week 5 loss to the Chargers.

impact: Jon Gruden isn't done cleaning house after trading Khalil Mack. Cooper has been inconsistent after a down 2017, but it's hard to see the Raiders making such a franchise-changing move. Oakland is also calling teams about 2016 first-rounder Karl Joseph. It's telling that both players are repped by the same agent as Mack. Cooper is signed through 2019 after the Raiders picked up his fifth-year option.
report: FOX Sports' Jay Glazer reports the Raiders are shopping Amari Cooper.

impact: Seahawks S Bradley McDougald easily could have been flagged for helmet to helmet, but he was not.  Cooper was knocked out for several moments before finally walking to the locker room.  He will surely be tested for a concussion.
report: Amari Cooper went to the locker room in the first half of Sunday's Week 6 game against the Seahawks with head/neck injury.

impact: It's an unfortunate but unsurprising outcome after Cooper was knocked unconscious by Seahawks S Bradley McDougald.  McDougald was not flagged for the helmet-to-helmet hit, but he will almost certainly draw a significant fine.  Cooper finished catch-less on one target.  The Raiders have a Week 7 bye.
report: Amari Cooper is done for the day in Week 6 with a concussion.

impact: It's safe to say they're not going to get it based on Cooper's inconsistency and Week 6 concussion.  Nevertheless, this is further confirmation Jon Gruden is aiming to tear apart the organization after trading Khalil Mack and dangling 2016 first-round S Karl Joseph.  Gruden even benched 2017 first-round CB Gareon Conley last week.  Cooper was in-limbo GM Reggie McKenzie's 2015 first-round pick.  Mack was McKenzie's first-rounder in 2014.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports the Raiders are seeking a first-round pick in exchange for Amari Cooper.

impact: No team is in greater need of pass-catching help than the receiver-starved Cowboys, who are currently trotting out the likes of Cole Beasley, Allen Hurns and rookie Michael Gallup at wide receiver. Dallas has begun to do its due diligence on Cooper, who has also drawn trade interest from the Colts and Redskins. The Raiders have been adamant they won't accept anything less than a first-round pick for Cooper, which is a steep cost for a player whose career has been riddled by inconsistency. The 24-year-old also has health concerns coming off a concussion in Week 6.
report: According to ESPN's Adam Schefter, the Cowboys are "gathering information" on Amari Cooper ahead of next week's trade deadline.

impact: The 3-4 Cowboys — who have featured an unwatchable passing offense this season — are going for it in the wide-open NFC East while the 1-5 Raiders are accelerating their tank in year one of coach Jon Gruden's 10-year, $100 million contract. One of the most inscrutable players in football, Cooper has baffled the past two seasons after beginning his career with back-to-back 1,000-yard campaigns, but he is still only 24 with loads of talent. There are better offenses he could have joined in terms of goosing his production, but he will be the centerpiece of the Cowboys' previously receiver-desperate attack. Cooper is under team control through 2019.
report: Cowboys acquired WR Amari Cooper from the Raiders in exchange for a first-round pick.

impact: Paying a first-round pick for a No. 1 receiver is not an issue, but paying it for a player who has struggled to consistently produce and will require a big extension in the near future is more dubious. Either way, Cooper is a Cowboy now, and he will join the team on Tuesday to start getting ready for what should be his debut in Week 9.
report: Cowboys coach Jason Garrett said a first-round pick is "what a player like [Amari Cooper] costs."

impact: "We’re not really easing him in," Linehan continued. The Cowboys overpaid considerably for Cooper, so we wouldn't expect the team to just "ease him in", anyhow. It's still a question mark how much of an impact he'll make on a run-first offense that doesn't go downfield often. The Titans' underwhelming secondary will be a good first test to see how the Cowboys utilize Amari.
report: Cowboys OC Scott Linehan said Amari Cooper will play a "significant amount" of snaps on Monday.

impact: His eight targets led the team as Cooper was making his Cowboys debut following his acquisition from the Raiders.  He beat Malcolm Butler for a four-yard score in the first quarter.  OC Scott Linehan was clearly trying to scheme him the ball early, but the offense went off the rails in the second half and didn't score after the break.  Still, it's pretty clear the Cowboys plan to force the ball to Cooper, and Dak Prescott's one interception was a forced ball into double-coverage in the end zone to Cooper.  Cooper will be a WR3 next week against the Eagles.
report: Amari Cooper caught 5-of-8 targets for 58 yards and one touchdown in the Cowboys' 28-14, Week 9 loss to the Titans on Monday night.

impact: Cooper got off to a fast start with 50 yards in the first half. He had just one catch after that, but it's another encouraging game after Cooper scored in his Cowboys' debut. Cooper was open on multiple downfield plays, but was overthrown by Dak Prescott. His rest-of-season value is up in Dallas, where Cooper is the clear featured wideout. Cooper is a WR2 for a Week 11 matchup with the Falcons.
report: Amari Cooper caught 6-of-10 targets for 75 yards in the Cowboys' Week 10 win over the Eagles.

impact: It was a step back for Cooper in his third game with the team after amassing an 11-133-1 line in his first two appearances against the Titans and Eagles.  Cooper averaged nine targets per game in those contests.  The matchup against Atlanta was ripe, but Ezekiel Elliott was just cruising all afternoon, totaling 201 yards and a score on 30 touches.  Cooper was held catch-less in the first half but made a couple contested grabs in the third quarter.  Cooper will look to rebound against the Redskins on Thanksgiving.
report: Amari Cooper caught 3-of-5 targets for 36 yards in the Cowboys' 22-19, Week 11 win over the Falcons.

impact: Cooper beat Quinton Dunbar for his first touchdown from 40 yards out then broke away from a weak Fabian Moreau tackle attempt for his monster 90-yard score.  Cooper has seen at least eight targets in 3-of-4 games with the Cowboys and has put together a 22-349-3 line for Dallas.  Cooper has been a legitimate WR2 with upside since the trade and gets New Orleans next Thursday.
report: Amari Cooper caught 8-of-9 targets for 180 yards and two touchdowns in the Cowboys' 31-23, Week 12 win over the Redskins on Thanksgiving.

impact: "Amari looks like he's making a bid for his cash," Jones told reporters after Thursday's win. Cooper has turned around his season since his trade to Dallas, posting at least 75 yards or a touchdown in 3-of-4 games. He's signed through 2019 at $13 million on his fifth-year option, but the Cowboys should extend him this offseason after giving up their first-round pick for him. 24-year-old Cooper will likely top the $16 million AAV Sammy Watkins got from Kansas City.
report: Cowboys owner Jerry Jones suggested Amari Cooper could be extended this offseason.

impact: Cooper also lost a first half fumble where Marshon Lattimore kneed the ball out. The Cowboys are now 4-1 since Cooper's acquisition, with the wideout posting at least 75 yards three times in the process. He has added the desired new element to the Cowboys' offense. He will have a juicy Week 14 matchup against the Eagles' undermanned secondary.
report: Amari Cooper caught 8-of-8 targets for 75 yards in the Cowboys' Week 13 win over the Saints.

impact: Woods tied Cooper Kupp with a team-high nine targets, but actually hauled in only three of them. Even so, Woods was dispersed deep and was clearly a cog in the Rams' high-octane offense. All of Los Angeles' receivers (Brandin Cooks included) could boom/bust on any given week, though Kupp's floor appears to be the safest of their committee's. Woods should continue seeing a high share of targets moving forward.
report: Robert Woods caught 3-of-9 targets for 37 yards and rushed for six yards on one carry in the Rams' Week 1 victory over the Raiders.

impact: Woods did not take advantage of his opportunities in the opener, but he rectified the problem against the Cardinals. He caught three passes for 30 yards in the first quarter, and he kept making plays the rest of the way. His fantasy day could have been much better, but Jared Goff missed him when he was wide open in the end zone in the fourth. The Rams will have a tougher time with the Chargers next week, but Woods will still be a solid WR3.
report: Robert Woods hauled in 6-of-9 targets for 81 yards in the Rams' Week 2 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Going into the game, Woods was a breakout candidate as he was leading the team in targets and air yards but only had 118 scoreless yards to show for it. Today was a different story. The Chargers had no answers for Jared Goff and Woods, who scored two times on the same red zone play and ended with over 100 receiving yards. With at least nine targets in all three games, Woods is a WR2/3 even against the Vikings on Thursday night.
report: Robert Woods caught 10-of-11 targets for 104 yards and two touchdowns in the Rams' Week 3 win over the Chargers.

impact: Despite seeing a season-low in targets, Woods impressed with another huge fantasy week. He was especially effective in the second half, nabbing four of his five catches after the break. Woods stretched the Rams’ lead to 10 by torching Anthony Barr (a frequent victim on Thursday night) for a 31-yard touchdown strike in the closing minutes of the third quarter. His longest gain came in the first half on a play where Woods dusted Trae Waynes for a 36-yard pick-up. Woods has gone over 100 yards receiving in each of his last two games while registering three touchdowns during that span. He’ll look to stay hot against the Seahawks in Week 5.
report: Robert Woods earned five catches for 101 yards and a touchdown on five targets Thursday in the Rams’ Week 4 victory over the Vikings.

impact: With both Brandin Cooks and Cooper Kupp sidelined by concussions, Woods was the No. 1 receiver for most of this game, and he delivered. He made a great move after the catch to pick up third down and a lot more in the second quarter, and he sparked a touchdown drive with a 56-yard gain on a jet sweep in the third quarter. He drew a defensive pass interference on fourth down later that drive to keep it alive. Woods now has at least 100 yards from scrimmage in each of his last three games while Cooks and Kupp are question marks for next week. If they do not play, Woods will be a WR1 against the Broncos.
report: Robert Woods hauled in 5-of-7 targets for 92 yards and rushed twice for 53 yards in the Rams' Week 5 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Woods also drew an end zone DPI that set the Rams up at the one-yard line in the third quarter. With Cooper Kupp (knee) ailing, Woods gobbled up more than half of the Rams' receiving yards. Woods has now cleared 90 yards in four-straight games, and 100 in three of his past four. He's been operating as a poor man's Adam Thielen in the Rams' three-headed attack at wideout. The 49ers are a plus matchup for Week 7.
report: Robert Woods caught 7-of-10 targets for 109 yards in the Rams' Week 6 win over the Broncos, adding a 12-yard rush.

impact: The Rams' passing attack did not have to do much in the easy win, but Woods still managed to top 75 for the sixth game in a row. He helped set up a field goal with a 21-yard gain on third down in the first quarter, and he went for 32 yards to spark another scoring drive in the second. With the Packers likely to offer more resistance, Woods will once again be a high-end WR2 next week.
report: Robert Woods hauled in 5-of-7 targets for 78 yards in the Rams' Week 7 win over the 49ers.

impact: Woods has now cleared 70 yards in seven-straight games, though he has not found the end zone since Week 4. It has been disappointing in fantasy, but Woods' usage and opportunity remain elite. The volume will remain and the scores will come. The Saints are on deck for a likely Week 9 shootout.
report: Robert Woods caught 5-of-7 targets for 70 yards in the Rams' Week 8 win over the Packers.

impact: Woods did not match Brandin Cooks' big game, but he consistently helped Jared Goff move the chains. He made a diving 12-yard grab on the second drive to keep the scoring march moving, came up with another 13-yard gain in the second quarter, and made a great sideline grab to help set up a field goal just before halftime. He picked up right where he left off after the break, catching two passes for 29 yards on the opening touchdown drive. He took a bit of backseat to Cooper Kupp the rest of the way, but it was still another solid outing from Woods, who has at least 70 yards in every game since Week 1. Woods will be a high-end WR2 next week against the Seahawks.
report: Robert Woods hauled in 5-of-9 targets for 71 yards in the Rams' Week 9 loss to the Saints.

impact: Woods has now cleared 70 yards receiving in every game since Week 1. One of the league's most consistent players, Woods' floor will be jacked even higher if Cooper Kupp (knee) is forced to miss significant time. Woods will be a WR1 for Week 11 when the Rams journey to Mexico City to take on the equally high-flying Chiefs.
report: Robert Woods caught 4-of-5 targets for 89 yards in the Rams' Week 10 win over the Seahawks, adding three rushes for 17 additional yards.

impact: Woods got the scoring started with a seven-yard touchdown and then caught a 25-yard pass later in the first half.  His 11 targets were second on the team to Brandin Cooks (12), but Jared Goff had some issues when targeting Woods for whatever reason, sailing some balls over his head in open windows.  He also left one short that Woods had to come back on for a 36-yard gain near the goal line, keeping him out of the end zone.  Woods is still consistent as anyone, having topped 70 yards in 10-straight games.  He'll be a WR1 after the bye when the Rams go to the Lions.
report: Robert Woods caught 4-of-11 targets for 72 yards and one touchdown in the Rams' Week 11 win over the Chiefs on Monday night.

impact: Jared Goff hung Woods out to dry on a first-half hospital ball as the wideout took a lick from Detroit cornerback Quandre Diggs. Luckily Woods bounced back, finding the end zone for his fifth touchdown of the year with 2:28 remaining in the second quarter. Woods hauled in a low throw from Goff while beating his man Darius Slay in coverage. Sunday's effort leaves Woods on the cusp of his first career 1,000-yard season. He'll look to reach that milestone against Chicago in Week 14.
report: Robert Woods snagged five-of-nine targets for 67 yards and a touchdown while adding 11 yards on two rushing attempts Sunday in L.A.’s Week 13 win over the Lions.

impact: Matthews practiced fully on Wednesday, but he missed all of training camp and the preseason recovering from a torn meniscus. With so much missed time in a new scheme, Matthews expects to be limited early. "That is kind of the plan, so wherever they need me," Matthews said. "The young guys have been doing good, so wherever they need me to contribute, I am ready to go in there and do what I have to do." With at least Corey Davis and Delanie Walker ahead of him, Matthews cannot be trusted in fantasy lineups this week, but he has quietly been a solid option the last couple seasons. He is worth a stash in deeper formats.
report: Rishard Matthews suggested his snaps will be limited early in the season.

impact: Matthews apparently played over 30 snaps, but he wasn't seen.  Learning a new offense after missing basically everything to this point, it may take a few weeks until we see Matthews on the same page with his quarterbacks.
report: Rishard Matthews was not targeted in the Titans' Week 1 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: It's the second week in a row that Matthews has basically been invisible. The Titans were admittedly down to their backup quarterback and third-string left tackle, but Matthews still finished sixth on the team in receiving yards. His 2018 campaign is off to a horrendous start after spending most of camp on PUP with a torn meniscus.
report: Rishard Matthews caught 2-of-4 targets for eight yards in the Titans' Week 2 win over the Texans.

impact: He can be dropped with yardage totals of 0, 8, and 3 through three games.
report: Rishard Matthews caught 1-of-2 targets for three yards in Week 3.

impact: Matthews' playing time has been scaled back significantly under Mike Vrabel's new coaching staff after he missed the entire offseason with injuries.  He indicated Wednesday that he is upset with his usage.  "I’ve been the leading receiver for two years," Matthews said on Instagram. "Then all of a sudden I’m barely playing and not even starting. Using my injury as the scapegoat. Look at number of snaps and targets."  Matthews is an above-average No. 2 receiver, but the new coaches have no attachment to him.  Expect more-explosive Taywan Taylor to benefit with increased playing time.
report: Rishard Matthews has reportedly left the Titans and does not intend to rejoin the team.

impact: Unhappy with his playing time, Matthews has left the team and reportedly has no plans to return. Trading him would be the best option for Tennessee, but it seems more likely they are forced to release him. With Matthews on the outs, talented sophomore Taywan Taylor should get more opportunities moving forward, and Corey Davis' stranglehold on targets is even more secure.
report: Paul Kuharsky reports it is "doubtful" the Titans will be able to trade Rishard Matthews.

impact: This was really the only possible outcome after Matthews walked away from the team this week. Tennessee's No. 1 receiver each of the last two seasons, Matthews is talented and has consistently produced when given the opportunity. This incident could scare off a few teams, but it would be a surprise if he does not land somewhere in the near future. With Matthews out the door, Corey Davis is locked into the No. 1 role, and talented sophomore Taywan Taylor should see more opportunities.
report: Titans released WR Rishard Matthews.

impact: Rosenhaus is the most powerful agent in football. Up to this point, Matthews had been representing himself. Rosenhaus claims Matthews has already drawn interest from "multiple teams" and expects him to sign soon. The 28-year-old was let go by Tennessee after going AWOL last week. He'd make sense for a receiver-needy team like Dallas.
report: Free agent WR Rishard Matthews has hired Drew Rosenhaus as his agent.

impact: Cleveland will host Matthews on Monday and the Cards will follow that up with a workout the following day. It's the first visits the free agent's scheduled since hiring Drew Rosenhaus as his agent. Now relying on someone else to manage his negotiations, Matthews will likely land with a suitor soon. The Browns make a lot of sense given coach Hue Jackson's reported plan to reduce rookie Antonio Callaway's snaps moving forward.
report: Free agent WR Rishard Matthews will visit the Browns and Cardinals.

impact: Matthews visited with the Browns and Cardinals last week. Cut by the Titans at the end of September, it is surprising Matthews has not found a new home yet, but perhaps he is just looking for the best possible landing spot. New York just lost Quincy Enunwa to an ankle injury.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports free agent WR Rishard Matthews is working out for the Jets on Tuesday.

impact: "Probably not," Matthews said when asked if he'll sign soon.  "A lot of teams are turned off by my past as if I have some criminal record.  Most likely won't see me until next season."  Matthews forced his way out of Tennessee after he wasn't playing enough under new OC Matt LaFleur.  He's had workouts with the Jets, Cardinals, and Browns, but all have went in other directions.
report: Free agent WR Rishard Matthews admitted he's unlikely to sign with a team this season.

impact: This comes just a week after Matthews said he was unlikely to sign with a team this season. With Quincy Enunwa (ankle) out indefinitely and Terrelle Pryor no longer on the roster, this is a good landing spot for Matthews, but it will likely take him some time to settle in. He is only deep-league stash at this point.
report: Jets signed WR Rishard Matthews.

impact: Miller has been limited in practice this week. That usually means a player will suit up on Sundays, but it sounds like Miller is legitimately questionable. If Miller sits, Alfred Blue would handle the load and be a volume-based RB2/FLEX.
report: Coach Bill O'Brien said Lamar Miller (questionable, chest) will be a game-time decision Week 5 against the Cowboys.

impact: If Miller is indeed out on Sunday Night Football, Alfred Blue would be positioned for 20 or more carries against the Sean Lee-less Cowboys.  Blue is far from a special talent, but Bill O'Brien's staff has shown a willingness to feed him heavy volume before.  And they may be getting fed up with Miller, who ranks a lowly 34th among 38 qualified backs in Football Outsiders' rushing Success Rate.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports the Texans are pessimistic Lamar Miller (chest) will be able to play Sunday night versus Dallas.

impact: This comes as a surprise after reports the Texans were "pessimistic" Miller would play. Miller's workload figures to be scaled back, but this kills any streamining value for Alfred Blue. Will Fuller (hamstring) and Keke Coutee (hamstring) are also active for Sunday night.
report: Lamar Miller (chest) is active for Week 5 against the Cowboys.

impact: Alfred Blue will start, so it sounds like Miller will only be available on an emergency basis. It's a confusing situation, but coach Bill O'Brien has done this before in Will Fuller's rookie season, who was active but didn't see any snaps. Blue is a plug-and-play RB2. Miller shouldn't be in fantasy lineups.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Lamar Miller (chest) "isn't expected to play" despite being active for Sunday night's game with Dallas.

impact: Miller was active for Sunday night's game against the Cowboys, but it was only in an emergency role. That at least meant he was close to being ready, however, so it is not a surprise he is expected to suit up against the Bills on Sunday. He will be a back-end RB2 in that matchup.
report: Texans coach Bill O'Brien expects Lamar Miller (chest) to play Week 6.

impact: Miller took Week 5 off and saw Alfred Blue handle 28 touches and turn them into 119 yards.  Miller has been a huge disappointment this season, failing to score a rushing touchdown despite seeing good-sized workloads.  We wouldn't be surprised if Miller and Blue share the work closer to 50-50.
report: Lamar Miller (chest) said he's "definitely" going to play Week 6 against the Bills.

impact: Miller is due back this week after sitting out Sunday's game with a chest injury. He's been a disappointment this year, averaging under four yards per carry with one touchdown in four games. With Alfred Blue beginning to see more work and D'Onta Foreman (Achilles) expected back in Week 7, Miller's days as a weekly fantasy RB2 could be numbered.
report: Lamar Miller (chest) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Active only on an emergency basis for Week 5, Miller appears on track to actually play against the Bills. Struggling and at less than 100 percent, we are more concerned about Miller's usage than usual. It's possible Alfred Blue remains more involved this week, making for a destitute man's Devonta Freeman/Tevin Coleman type of committee. Miller is best treated as a FLEX option.
report: Lamar Miller (chest) was upgrade to "full" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Alfred Blue got his share of carries in this game, but Miller still operated as the clear lead back. That usage did not lead to a big fantasy day, but Miller played better than his numbers suggest. He also could have had a touchdown on a trick play, but DeAndre Hopkins just missed him. All of that said, a possible D'Onta Foreman return and a tough matchup with Jacksonville will make Miller more of a low-end FLEX option next week.
report: Lamar Miller rushed 15 times for 46 yards and caught 2-of-3 targets for 25 yards in the Texans' Week 6 win over the Bills.

impact: The Texans stayed committed to their rushing attack as underdogs on the road, and Miller rewarded them with his best game of the season.  He out-touched Alfred Blue 23 to 8 as Houston reeled off its fourth straight victory following an 0-3 start.  Suddenly favorites to win the AFC South, the Texans go back home for Week 8 Thursday Night Football against the Dolphins.  Back in Houston's featured-back role, Miller will be a quality RB2 play in that game.
report: Lamar Miller rushed 22 times for 100 yards and a touchdown and caught 1-of-3 targets for -1 yard in the Texans' Week 7 win over the Jaguars.

impact: The 133 yards on the ground were Miller's second most as a Texan and came against the team that let him walk in free agency in 2016. Miller has now hit the century mark in back-to-back games, suddenly saving a fantasy season that had been circling the drain. Tonight was a soft matchup, but the Jags were anything but in Week 7. The Broncos will be another soft matchup for Week 9. Miller is once again looking like a safe RB2.
report: Lamar Miller rushed 18 times for 133 yards and a touchdown in the Texans' Week 8 win over the Dolphins.

impact: His 27 receiving yards (on just two catches) through the air were more than he could muster on 12 carries on the ground, hence why Alfred Blue came in and out-carried Miller 15-12 on the day. The broadcast noted that coach Bill O'Brien discussed scaling Miller's workload back to "keep him healthy" during their production meeting, so that's another explanation. Miller was completely ineffective, though, averaging 1.8 YPC. Alfred Blue didn't perform much better (2.6 YPC), but it's still concerning the two essentially split work. Miller was coming off of consecutive standout 100-yard outings and he'll look to replicate that (as long as the volume is there) when Houston returns from their bye against the Redskins.
report: Lamar Miller basically fell down on all 12 of his carries, rushing for 21 yards in the Texans' Week 9 win over the Broncos.

impact: He out-touched Alfred Blue 23 to 8 after Blue and Miller shared carries in Week 9, prior to Houston's Week 10 bye.  When healthy, it's clear Miller is coach Bill O'Brien's preferred backfield option.  Ahead of a difficult Week 12 matchup versus Tennessee's stout run defense, Miller will remain a volume-based RB2.
report: Lamar Miller rushed 20 times for 86 yards and caught 3-of-5 targets for 22 yards in the Texans' Week 11 win over Washington.

impact: Miller was peeling off big runs the entire first half, with gains of 21, 12, and 15 before Demaryius Thomas caught a 12-yard score a couple plays later.  He then wrecked the game for the Titans with a 97-yard touchdown run one play after Tennessee went for it on fourth down from the three-yard line only to get stuffed for no gain.  Miller took it easy in the second half with Alfred Blue getting more work.  Miller has 100 total yards and/or a touchdown in four of the last five games.  He's established himself as a volume RB2 heading into Week 13 against the Browns.
report: Lamar Miller rushed 12 times for 162 yards and one touchdown in the Texans' 34-17, Week 12 win over the Titans on Monday night.

impact: This was Miller's second 100-yard rushing game in a row and the fourth that he's had over his past six games. With the Texans continuing to control games, Miller has turned his season around and worked his way into weekly RB2 status. Miller will be a solid option once again next week at home when the Texans host the Colts.
report: Lamar Miller rushed 19 times for 103 yards while catching one pass for 12 yards in Sunday's Week 13 win over the Browns.

impact: Foreman tore his Achilles' last November and should be at or near 100 percent.  With Lamar Miller struggling in the lead role and without a touchdown, Foreman could come back to an open backfield with a chance to gain ground on Miller and Alfred Blue relatively quickly.  He's worth an add if you have roster space.
report: Coach Bill O'Brien said D'Onta Foreman (Achilles', PUP) is "on track" to return when first eligible in Week 7.

impact: "I don't think he's quite ready," O'Brien added. Houston originally expected Foreman to be ready Week 1, and now he is not even healthy enough to play six weeks into the season. Coming back from a tough injury for running backs, Foreman is just a weak bench stash in deeper leagues.
report: Texans coach Bill O'Brien does not expect D'Onta Foreman (Achilles', PUP) to be activated this week.

impact: Foreman has been eligible to practice since last month but wasn't cleared. Practicing next week would start the 21-day window to activate him. With an upcoming bye, the Texans may be targeting a Week 11 return for Foreman.
report: Texans coach Bill O'Brien expects D'Onta Foreman (Achilles, PUP) to practice next week.

impact: Foreman was expected to begin practicing during the bye week, but it sounds like Houston could hold off opening his 21-day activation window until next week. Houston has consistently moved back the goal posts on Foreman's return. He is only a bench stash in deeper leagues at this point.
report: Texans coach Bill O'Brien said he is not sure when they will activate D'Onta Foreman (PUP, Achilles').

impact: "He had a good year last year, but that was a long time ago," said O'Brien.  "Let's just see where he's at."  Should the Texans bring Foreman off PUP, they would then have 21 days to decide whether to activate him to the 53-man roster.  Foreman tore his Achilles' last November 19 and will be a full year removed from the injury next Monday.  He's not worth stashing beyond Dynasty leagues.
report: Texans coach Bill O'Brien was entirely noncommittal on Monday when asked if D'Onta Foreman (Achilles/PUP) will play this year.

impact: It opens a 21-day window for Foreman's return to the active roster. Foreman is a full year removed from his torn Achilles but coach Bill O'Brien suggested his conditioning is an issue. The Texans will get him some practice reps, but it's going to be a stretch for Foreman to play Sunday. Foreman will regain his role as the No. 2 back over Alfed Blue whenever he's cleared.
report: Texans activated RB D'Onta Foreman (Achilles) from the PUP list.

impact: "Can he carry the ball more than two times in a row without having to go get a drink of water," O'Brien asked rhetorically. "What type of shape is he in? ... He had a good year last year. That was a long time ago, so let's just ... see where he's at." We do expect Foreman to be activated before his three-week window is up, but at best, he will be returning to a committee. He's unlikely to be of much help in fantasy leagues.
report: Speaking Wednesday, Texans coach Bill O'Brien did not guarantee that D'Onta Foreman (Achilles', PUP) would return this season.

impact: "I think he feels good," O'Brien said. "We've got a little more time on that decision." Foreman has been practicing for two weeks, but it does not sound like he will be activated ahead of this week's matchup with the Browns. It is also notable O'Brien left open the possibility of Foreman staying on the PUP the rest of the season. The Texans have until next Wednesday to make that decision.
report: Texans coach Bill O'Brien said D'Onta Foreman (Achilles', PUP) is "not all the way back yet."

impact: Foreman has been practicing since November 14, meaning Houston only has until Wednesday to activate him or leave him on the PUP for the rest of the season. Given how Foreman's timetable has consistently been moved back since the offseason, it seems likely he sticks on the PUP. Even if he returns, Foreman will be a change-of-pace option behind resurgent starter Lamar Miller.
report: Coach Bill O'Brien said the Texans have yet to decide if they will activate D'Onta Foreman (Achilles', PUP).

impact: The Texans had until Wednesday to decide. Coach Bill O'Brien has continually hedged on Foreman's potential 2018 contributions. We wouldn't be surprised if the second-year back ended up spending a week or two as a "healthy scratch." He is not going to provide re-draft fantasy value behind Lamar Miller.
report: Texans activated RB D'Onta Foreman (Achilles') from the reserve/PUP list.

impact: Foreman was activated from the PUP list Tuesday. He looks on track to play this week after sitting the first 12 games. Foreman's role figures to be limited as a change-up to Lamar Miller.
report: D'Onta Foreman (Achilles) is practicing in full for Week 14.

impact: Butt's injury is unclear. With eight catches on 12 targets through three games, Butt is trying to get himself on the TE2 streaming radar.
report: Broncos TE Jake Butt was absent from Thursday's practice.

impact: Butt didn't appear to be practicing, at least from the vantage of team reporters, but apparently he got in a limited session. The second-year tight end has handled eight-of-12 targets for 85 scoreless yards this season.
report: Updating an earlier report, Broncos TE Jake Butt (knee) was limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: It appears Butt suffered the injury on Thursday. If so, the news is ominous. The Broncos have an unimpressive tight end group even with Butt. Without him, it's Jets-level.
report: Broncos TE Jake Butt is undergoing an MRI on his knee after suffering a non-contact injury during a walk-through.

impact: It has since been confirmed. It's beyond brutal for the one-time promising prospect, who is now dealing with his third career ACL tear. The first two were to his right knee. For the Broncos, it further hollows out an already thin tight end group. Neither of Jeff Heuerman or Matt LaCosse are going to become a factor catching the ball in Butt's absence. Butt is still only 23, but his NFL career is headed in the wrong direction. He can be dropped in Dynasty leagues.
report: NFL.com's Ian Rapoport reports "the fear" is Broncos TE Jake Butt suffered a non-contact left ACL tear in Thursday's walk-through.

impact: Jones will be an elite WR1 against the Bengals.
report: Julio Jones (calf) returned to Falcons practice Thursday.

impact: Jones sat out Wednesday's practice, but he was never in real danger of sitting out this week. He will be a high-end WR1 against the Bengals.
report: Julio Jones (calf) was not listed on the final injury report for Week 4.

impact: Jones remains too classy for touchdowns, but he was once again a monster in this game. Seemingly open every time Matt Ryan needed a big play, Jones converted third down after third down for an offense which was rarely stopped. He padded his stats with 66 yards on the Falcons' final, desperation drive. While a touchdown or two would be cool, Jones is averaging 126 yards a game and has a great matchup with the Steelers on deck. He remains a high-end WR1.
report: Julio Jones hauled in 9-of-12 targets for 173 yards in the Falcons' Week 4 loss to the Bengals.

impact: It's more maintenance for Jones, who rarely practices. Coming off  last week's 173-yard game, Jones has another blowup spot against the Steelers.
report: Julio Jones (ankle, hand) was held out of Wednesday's practice.

impact: Jones is not injured. A locked-in top-three receiver, Jones will have an excellent shot at breaking touchdown drought against the Steelers' struggling defense.
report: Julio Jones (ankle, hand) returned to a limited practice on Thursday.

impact: The Falcons have been managing his reps, but Jones was never in danger of sitting. He's a top-five receiver play for Week 5.
report: Julio Jones (ankle, hand) was removed from the Week 5 injury report.

impact: Stunningly, Jones was held without a catch for three quarters. He did a decent job of salvaging his fantasy line in the fourth quarter, when a non-competitive game was already over. Despite the disappointing day, Jones still has a monster 564 yards through five games. He will be in the WR1 overall discussion for Week 6 against the pathetic Bucs.
report: Julio Jones caught 5-of-9 targets for 62 yards in the Falcons' Week 5 loss to the Steelers.

impact: Jones remained allergic to the end zone even with Calvin Ridley and Mohamed Sanu leaving early, but that did not stop him from making play after play against the Bucs' overmatched secondary. He was seemingly running free all game, and he converted several big third downs throughout. Even with a couple down games thrown in, Jones is on pace for 1,885 yards through six games. A touchdown or two would be nice, but Jones remains a high-end WR1.
report: Julio Jones hauled in 10-of-14 targets for 143 yards in the Falcons' Week 6 win over the Bucs.

impact: Standard day at the office for Jones; he got his 100 yards and remains without a touchdown on the season.  There was an opening for one, but Matt Ryan underthrew Jones on what should have been a walk-in 60-yard touchdown.  Ryan hit his hand on a helmet on the follow-through, and Jones had to stop for the ball, drawing a 38-yard pass interference instead.  On two of the next three plays, Ryan tried to get Jones the ball in the end zone, but Jones was double-covered both times.  Jones also lost a fumble in this one.  The Falcons are on their bye now before going to D.C. in Week 9.
report: Julio Jones caught 9-of-12 targets for 104 yards in the Falcons' 23-20, Week 7 win over the Giants on Monday night.

impact: You read that right; a Julio Jones touchdown.  Jones' score came on a fourth-quarter quick screen where an offensive lineman took out Josh Norman in press coverage and Julio broke Ha Ha Clinton-Dix's tackle attempt in front of the goal line before diving in.  The touchdown was Julio's first in a string of 90 consecutive scoreless catches.  Jones dominated Norman all game, also gaining 46 yards on a flagrant defensive pass interference flag when Norman literally tackled him from behind to prevent another would-be long score.  Jones will remain an elite WR1 play in Week 10 at Cleveland, which lost impressive rookie CB Denzel Ward to a hip injury in their loss to Kansas City.
report: Julio Jones caught 7-of-10 targets for 121 yards and a touchdown in the Falcons' Week 9 win over the Redskins.

impact: Jones also drew a 13-yard DPI. Jones' score — his second of the season — was his second in as many weeks. He caught a bubble screen with the Falcons on the one-yard line. Jones has now cleared 100 yards in four-straight games and six times on the season. He's up to 1,040 yards, putting him on pace for 1,849. That would be third most all time. Jones' 1,871 from 2015 is second most all time. The Falcons face the Cowboys in Week 11.
report: Julio Jones caught 7-of-11 targets for 107 yards and a touchdown in the Falcons' Week 10 loss to the Browns.

impact: Since snapping his insane touchdown-less streak, Jones has now scored in three-straight games and has topped 100 yards in all three.  Jones has topped 100 yards in five consecutive games and six of the last seven.  Jones had a quiet first half against Dallas (2-38) but got going after the break and skied over the top of CB Chidobe Awuzie for a 34-yard score to tie the game at 19-19 deep in the fourth quarter.  Julio gets the Saints on Thanksgiving.  He went 5-96 against New Orleans in Week 3.
report: Julio Jones caught 6-of-9 targets for 118 yards and one touchdown in the Falcons' 22-19, Week 11 loss to the Cowboys.

impact: The Saints surprisingly utilized former No. 10 overall pick Eli Apple in shadow coverage on Jones, allowing the stud receiver to dominate on a team-high 14 targets. Even so, Jones was responsible for one of Atlanta's three lost fumbles in the red zone Thursday. Another fumble occurred when Matt Ryan lost the ball while waiting on Julio to separate on a designed play for him inside the 10. Although Atlanta's offense as a whole leaves much to be desired, Jones has benefitted from a concerted effort to get him involved in the red zone since the team's bye. He's now on pace for a whopping 122/1,898/4, which would slot his 2018 campaign at No. 2 all-time in single-season receiving yards. He's a weekly WR1 whether he hits pay dirt or not.
report: Julio Jones hauled in 11-of-14 targets for 147 yards in Atlanta's Week 13 loss to the Saints.

impact: Jones was seen getting his right hand taped early in the game but was never announced with an injury. The Falcons simply could not sustain drives against the Ravens' elite defense. Jones was dealing with sticky coverage on nearly every play. Even if Jones sees a heavy dose of impressive rookie Jaire Alexander in Week 14, he will bounce back as an elite WR1 against the Packers.
report: Julio Jones caught 2-of-8 targets for 18 yards in the Falcons' Week 13 home loss to the Ravens.

impact: It's an out of nowhere injury for Jones, who played 77 percent of snaps last week. Coach Dan Quinn didn't show much concern when asked about his status. We'll have an update on Jones when Atlanta returns to practice Thursday.
report: Julio Jones (foot) didn't practice Wednesday.

impact: Brown was the No. 2 option behind Michael Crabtree. He got open in the red-zone for his touchdown, scoring from seven yards out. Brown was talked up all training camp and looks to have a good rapport with Joe Flacco. He's on the WR4 radar for a Week 2 matchup with the Bengals.
report: John Brown caught 3-of-4 targets for 44 yards and a touchdown in Week 1 against Buffalo.

impact: Brown's 10 targets tied Michael Crabtree for the team lead. They were six more than he drew in the opener. Brown now has two touchdowns through two games as a Raven and made two nearly impossible catches this evening. The first was a 45-yarder that should have been picked in triple coverage. The second was his 21-yard touchdown in the fourth quarter, where he simply took the ball from Dre Kirkpatrick in the end zone. Fully healthy and playing a legitimate amount of snaps, Brown is shaping up as an upside WR3.
report: John Brown caught 4-of-10 targets for 92 yards and a touchdown in the Ravens' Week 2 loss to the Bengals.

impact: He finished with one fewer target than Michael Crabtree, but he easily led the team in receiving yardage on a day which could have been bigger. Brown just missed a couple long catches down the sideline in the first half before Joe Flacco hit him with a beautiful pass for a 44-yard gain in the second quarter. At worst the 1B receiver in a quietly solid passing attack, Brown will be an upside WR3 next week against the Steelers.
report: John Brown hauled in 5-of-9 targets for 86 yards in the Ravens' Week 3 win over the Broncos.

impact: We're still waiting on the injury details. Brown was spotted on the field early but went inside before individual drills started. It's not a good sign for his Week 4 status.
report: John Brown didn't practice Wednesday.

impact: Brown's Wednesday absence was not injury related. He will be a WR3 for what could be a high-scoring game with the Steelers.
report: John Brown returned to Ravens practice Thursday.

impact: Brown burned past Steelers CB Joe Haden for a 33-yard touchdown on the opening drive of the night. He added a 71-yard deep shot in the second quarter, but faded after halftime. Brown has been locked-in with Joe Flacco over the first four games and is tied for the league lead on passes traveling 30 or more air yards. He'll be a boom/bust WR3 against the Browns in Week 5.
report: John Brown caught 3-of-7 targets for 116 yards and a touchdown in Week 4 against the Steelers.

impact: Brown led the Ravens in targets on Sunday, but failed to turn all of those looks into much as he and Flacco were not on the same page frequently. Brown's long gain of the day was a 28-yard catch and run, giving him a 25-yard plus reception in all five games this season. Brown has established himself as the Ravens' best playmaker through five weeks and will enter Week 6 as a WR2 option against the Titans.
report: John Brown caught 5-of-14 passes for 58 yards in Sunday's Week 5 loss to the Browns.

impact: Brown's two-catch day wouldn't have been so bad had he not seen 14 targets just last week. Instead it was Michael Crabtree (6/93/1) who finally broke out, with Willie Snead (7/60) quietly leading all in targets (10) and catches (7). There are better days on the horizon for Brown, who's still the team's primary deep threat and second on the Ravens with a 17% target share. Consider both he and Crabtree simultaneous WR2's against New Orleans' porous secondary in Week 7.
report: John Brown hauled in 2-of-3 targets for 28 yards in the Ravens' Week 6 win over the Titans.

impact: Coming off back-to-back quiet games, Brown set new season highs in catches and yards. 56 of his yards came on a dig route where Brown was allowed to run free. He got tackled at the two-yard line. Despite the big day, Brown did get out-targeted by Michael Crabtree. Brown's big-play volatility keeps him on the WR2/3 borderline. The Panthers are on deck for Week 8.
report: John Brown caught 7-of-7 targets for 134 yards and a touchdown in the Ravens' Week 7 loss to the Saints.

impact: It was a big step back from Brown after going 7-134-1 last week against the Saints.  He's sandwiched that day with a pair of 28-yard games.  Brown gets the Steelers in Week 9, who he went 3-116-1 against in Week 4.
report: John Brown caught 3-of-7 targets for 28 yards in the Ravens' Week 8 loss to the Panthers.

impact: Brown balled out when these teams squared off back in Week 4 (3-116-1) but a repeat effort wasn't in the cards. He didn't break off any big plays, managing a long gain of just six yards. His largest contribution came in the second quarter when he drew a 33-yard pass interference flag on safety Terrell Edmunds. This won't go down as one of Brown's better weeks, though by now, fantasy owners should be well-aware of his boom-or-bust tendencies. The struggling Ravens—losers of three straight—will have the bye week to figure things out.
report: John Brown managed only three catches for 17 yards on six targets Sunday in Baltimore’s Week 9 loss to Pittsburgh.

impact: Regardless of matchups, Brown is going to be extremely volatile with low floors going forward.  The Ravens completed only 13 passes for 150 yards with Lamar Jackson at quarterback, and Jackson is expected to start again in Week 12.
report: John Brown caught his lone target for 23 yards in the Ravens' Week 11 win over Cincinnati.

impact: Brown is well-known for his boom-or-bust tendencies and obviously Sunday's clunker falls squarely in the "bust" category. Smokey got off to a strong start, nabbing a 25-yard dart from Lamar Jackson early in the first quarter. That marked Brown's eighth catch of at least 25 yards this season. He committed a head-scratching drop later in the quarter, though Jackson probably could have put more mustard on it. Brown also had a 48-yard grab come off the board due to a holding penalty on the offensive line. The fifth-year deep threat has pulled in just eight-of-21 targets during his current four-game touchdown drought. We'll see what he can cobble together against Atlanta in Week 13.
report: John Brown managed just one catch for 25 yards on seven targets Sunday in the Ravens’ Week 12 victory over Oakland.

impact: Brown should have had a 51-yard touchdown early in the second quarter, but Lamar Jackson flat missed him despite having time to set his feet and uncork a deep ball. The Ravens ran the same play later in the game, but the Falcons were ready for it that time. Brown now has just two catches in three games with dual-threat Jackson under center. Joe Flacco could be returning for Week 14, though Jackson is not going to be outright benched. Brown cannot be trusted for the fantasy playoffs.
report: John Brown was held without a catch on four targets in the Ravens' Week 13 win over the Falcons.

impact: Heuerman caught Case Keenum's first three completions of the night and was never heard from again before a 36-yard pickup on the game's final drive.  His seven targets tied for the team lead in the Broncos' first game without Jake Butt (knee), so Heuerman appears to have No. 1 TE duties on lock in Denver.  Regardless, he's a real weak fantasy option ahead of Week 5 at the Jets.
report: Jeff Heuerman caught 4-of-7 targets for 57 yards in the Broncos' Week 4 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: Heuerman was hardly heard from despite the Broncos teeing up a season-high 51 pass attempts, which is concerning for Heuerman's streamer viability going forward.  He will be a low-end TE2 in Week 6 against the Rams.
report: Jeff Heuerman caught 2-of-4 targets for 18 yards in the Broncos' Week 5 loss.

impact: The yards were Heuerman's second most of the season. He's done little to suggest he will be anything more than a last-gasp TE2 in fantasy leagues.
report: Jeff Heuerman caught 3-of-6 targets for 23 yards in the Broncos' Week 6 loss to the Rams.

impact: Heuerman actually was targeted once — catching a 10-yard touchdown — but it was erased by an offensive pass interference penalty. Heuerman will offer last-gasp TE2 appeal for what should hopefully be a high-scoring game with the Chiefs in Week 8.
report: Jeff Heuerman wasn't targeted in the Broncos' Week 7 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Heuerman was the recipient of a four-yard touchdown early in the fourth quarter, though he and Case Keenum were rarely on the same page. The end-zone visit was Heuerman's first since Week 15 of last season and only the third of his career. Even as a contrarian DFS punt play, using Heuerman would probably be a stretch. The fourth-year tight end faces Houston in Week 9.
report: Jeff Heuerman netted one grab for four yards and a touchdown on five targets Sunday in Denver’s Week 8 loss to Kansas City.

impact: In Denver's first game without Demaryius Thomas, it was unexpectedly Heuerman who led the team across the board in targets, catches, and receiving yards. He was hogging red zone usage all along, leading the team in targets inside the 10-yard line (7) prior to Sunday, but he was averaging just 3.8 targets on the year. His 11 looks Sunday were a season high. Given the landscape and desecration at his position, Heuerman is a viable season-long flier just in case this amount of volume unexpectedly continues to be thrown his way.
report: Jeff Heuerman hauled in 10 catches for 83 yards and one score on a team-high 11 targets in the Broncos' Week 9 defeat to the Texans.

impact: Playing for the first time since his 10-catch, 83-yard breakout in Week 9, Heuerman mostly disappointed, managing a long gain of just six yards. He also committed a head-scratching drop in the fourth quarter, though luckily it didn't cost the Broncos, who stole a 23-22 win on a last-second field goal by Brandon McManus. The 25-year-old won't be an appealing streamer when the Steelers come to town for Week 12.
report: Jeff Heuerman came down with four catches for 20 yards on five targets Sunday in the Broncos’ Week 11 win over the Chargers.

impact: Heuerman helped set up a first-quarter field goal with a 29-yard catch, but he had to watch as Matt LaCosse caught two quick passes at the end of the second quarter including a ten-yard touchdown. Heuerman added a 15-yard catch in the second half, enough to give him the second-most yards on the team, but he left in the fourth quarter with a back injury. If that injury ends up being minor, he will be a streaming option next week against the spiraling Bengals.
report: Jeff Heuerman hauled in 2-of-3 targets for 44 yards in the Broncos' Week 12 win over the Steelers.

impact: The fourth-year pro operated as the Broncos' lead tight end this season, catching a career-high 31 passes for 281 yards. His previous bests were nine and 142, respectively. Heuerman was sidelined for his entire rookie season with a torn ACL and missed the occasional game in 2016-17. Now 26, he is headed to free agency.
report: Broncos TE Jeff Heuerman suffered broken ribs and a bruised lung in Sunday's win over the Steelers and is done for the season.

impact: Crabtree bounced back from two drops on his first three targets. He showed good body control to on his touchdown, getting his feet down in the back of the end-zone from 12 yard out. Crabtree could've had more yards but was rested in the second half. He'll be a high-floor WR2 for Thursday night's game with the Bengals.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 3-of-6 passes for 38 yards and a touchdown in Week 1 against Buffalo.

impact: Crabtree now has eight catches for 94 yards and a touchdown through two games as a Raven. That comes out to 11.8 yards per pop, which would be Crabtree's highest mark since 2013. Don't expect it to hold. Crabtree is a possession, chain-moving receiver who will leave your fantasy team feeling cold when he doesn't find the end zone.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 5-of-10 targets for 56 yards in the Ravens' Week 2 loss to the Bengals.

impact: John Brown has been the explosive option in the passing game, but Crabtree continues to be a reliable set of hands for Joe Flacco. He made a couple big catches when the game was in doubt including a third-down conversion in the second quarter. His possession role is not going to result in much fantasy upside when he does not find the end zone, but Crabtree is at worse a solid option in PPR formats. He will be even better than that in a good matchup against the Steelers next week.
report: Michael Crabtree hauled in 7-of-10 targets for 61 yards in the Ravens' Week 3 win over the Broncos.

impact: Crabtree should've had a touchdown, but was overthrown by Joe Flacco in the first quarter. It was a rough night for Crabtree, who dropped a pass and is up to six drops on the year. Crabtree is on pace for 112 catches but just 736 yards and four touchdowns through the first month of the season.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 3-of-8 passes for 29 yards in Week 4 against the Steelers.

impact: Crabtree's 66 yards were a season-high, but it was the 11th consecutive game that he failed to reach 70-yards receiving in a game. He dropped multiple passes on the day, including a potential game-winning touchdown in the final seconds of regulation. Crabtree will be a WR3 in Week 6 against the Titans.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 6-of-12 targets for 66 yards in Sunday's Week 5 loss to the Browns.

impact: The volume had been there all along, but Crabtree still hadn't recorded more than 70 yards in a single game prior to Sunday. He finally turned in a terrific outing against Tennessee, hauling in the team's only receiving score on the day. John Brown (2/28) still profiles as the Ravens' deep threat, but both wideouts are capable of WR2-type outings on any given week. Pending who the Saints stick Marshon Lattimore on, both wideouts have a chance for monumental performances against New Orleans' shoddy secondary next week.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 6-of-9 targets for 93 yards and one touchdown in the Ravens' Week 6 victory over the Titans.

impact: Crabtree got out-caught and out-gained by John Brown today, but Crabtree has out-targeted Brown four of the past five games. He's also cleared 60 yards four of the past five games. Crabtree has vanishingly-little upside but continues to maintain one of the safest WR3 floors in fantasy football. The Panthers are on tap for Week 8.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 5-of-9 targets for 66 yards in the Ravens' Week 7 loss to the Saints.

impact: The five targets mark a new season-low for Crabtree after he saw at least eight Weeks 2-7.  Crabtree will look to bounce back against the Steelers next week.  He went 3-29-0 in Week 4 against Pittsburgh.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 3-of-5 targets for 31 yards in the Ravens' Week 8 loss to the Panthers.

impact: It was another listless outing for the drop-prone veteran. Crabtree had the end zone in his sights on a second-quarter pass from Joe Flacco, but couldn't come up with it. It wasn't the sharpest throw in the world but Crabtree still should have had it. Even with Baltimore in catch-up mode in the second half, Crabtree did almost nothing to move the needle. The 31-year-old has committed an embarrassing 10 drops this year, which leads the league. Crabtree and the rapidly-fading Ravens will face the Raiders at home after their bye week.
report: Michael Crabtree corralled two-of-six targets for 25 yards Sunday in the Ravens’ Week 9 loss to the Steelers.

impact: Crabtree won't be a fantasy option in the Ravens' new run-dominant attack.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 1-of-3 targets for seven yards in the Ravens' Week 11 win over the Bengals.

impact: Crabtree gashed his former team for an eight-yard touchdown on a quick slant from Lamar Jackson early in the fourth quarter. That was his only catch of the second half. Crabtree is a familiar name to fantasy owners, but he's not the same player he was early in his career. With Baltimore turning to a run-first approach, fantasy owners shouldn't expect much from Crabtree down the stretch. He'll be tough to trust, even with a favorable matchup on tap against Atlanta in Week 13.
report: Michael Crabtree chipped in with three catches for 21 yards and a touchdown on six targets Sunday in the Ravens’ Week 12 win over the Raiders.

impact: Crabtree has seven catches for 64 yards since Lamar Jackson was inserted under center three weeks ago. The Ravens will have to open it up more against the Chiefs in Week 14, but Crabtree will still be hard to recommend as a WR4. Joe Flacco's return would further complicate matters, as it would not be as an every-snap starter.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 3-of-4 targets for 36 yards in the Ravens' Week 13 win over the Falcons.

impact: Snead didn't make much noise in the preseason, but he worked as the clear No. 3 wideout behind Michael Crabtree and John Brown. His role looks larger than expected in Baltimore's offense, but this may end up one of his better games. Playing on a short week, Snead would be a low-upside waiver-wire flyer.
report: Willie Snead caught 4-of-6 targets for 49 yards and a touchdown in Baltimore's Week 1 win over Buffalo.

impact: Snead has firmly established himself as the No. 3 in the Ravens' three-wide sets, but it has translated to a modest nine catches for 103 yards through two games. You can do better if you are looking for an upside flier on the waiver wire, especially ahead of next week's tough matchup against the Broncos.
report: Willie Snead caught 5-of-8 targets for 54 yards in the Ravens' Week 2 loss to the Bengals.

impact: This was actually Snead's worst game of the season, but he still managed a couple big plays including a third-down conversion in the third quarter. Snead does not offer much upside as the No. 3 option in the passing game, but he can provide value in deeper PPR leagues.
report: Willie Snead hauled in 3-of-5 targets for 39 yards in the Ravens' Week 3 win over the Broncos.

impact: It was a typical game from Snead. He continued to do most of his damage on third downs and out of the slot. Snead has a solid floor but very little upside as Baltimore's No. 3 receiver. He gets a matchup with the Browns in Week 5.
report: Willie Snead caught 6-of-7 targets for 56 yards in Week 4 against the Steelers.

impact: Snead was fourth on the team in targets as he's established himself as the possession receiver for the Ravens. Snead has four or more catches in four of five games this season, but has yet to reach 60-yards in any game to this point. The Ravens play at Tennessee in Week 6.
report: Willie Snead caught 5-of-7 targets for 55 yards in Sunday's Week 5 loss to the Browns.

impact: His catches and targets were both team-highs, with Michael Crabtree (6/93/1) leading the Ravens with 93 receiving yards. Snead has established himself as the club's possession wideout, but even finished with the second-most air yards (123) among Baltimore's receivers Sunday. It was all at the expense of John Brown, who recorded just two catches for 23 yards. Crabtree and Brown will still rank higher in Week 7 against the Saints.
report: Willie Snead hauled in a team-high 7-of-10 targets for 60 yards in the Ravens' Week 6 victory over the Titans.

impact: Amazingly, this was Snead's worst game of the season. He's averaging a solid 48 weekly yards but not really doing much with them in the way of catches or scores. He hasn't found the end zone since Week 1. Snead is just a desperation PPR fill-in.
report: Willie Snead caught 3-of-7 targets for 23 yards in the Ravens' Week 7 loss to the Saints.

impact: The 11 targets led the team and were four more than John Brown.  Snead has drawn double-digit looks in two of the last three games, but he hasn't scored since Week 1.  Five catches for roughly 50 yards has become what to expect from Snead.  He'll be a low-upside WR4 next week versus Pittsburgh.
report: Willie Snead caught 5-of-11 targets for 54 yards in the Ravens' Week 8 loss to the Panthers.

impact: Snead padded his stats in garbage time with six second-half catches, though none of them were for big gains. The fourth-year Ball State alum continues to see a heavy workload—he's drawn seven or more targets in each of his last six games. Unfortunately he hasn't scored a touchdown since the Ravens' opener and has only reached 60 yards once this season. Snead will get the Raiders at home after Baltimore's bye week.
report: Willie Snead came down with seven catches for 58 yards on eight targets Sunday in the Ravens’ Week 9 loss to Pittsburgh.

impact: Snead led Baltimore in targets, but as a team they only threw for 150 yards.  With Lamar Jackson expected to continue starting in a run-focused attack, Snead will be a low-upside WR4 specific to PPR leagues going forward.
report: Willie Snead caught 5-of-8 targets for 51 yards in the Ravens' Week 11 win over Cincinnati.

impact: He was on the field for 49 of the Ravens' 70 offensive snaps on Sunday but Lamar Jackson never looked to him. Snead's no-show was surprising after leading the team in receiving yards in his previous three games. He'll look to rebound next week against Atlanta.
report: Willie Snead wasn’t targeted Sunday in the Ravens’ Week 12 win over the Raiders.

impact: Lamar Jackson completed just 12 passes, so there simply was not any volume for the Ravens' passing attack. Snead now has just six catches in three games with Jackson under center. Snead won't be a recommended WR5 even if Joe Flacco returns for Week 14. There are simply too many better options with bye weeks over.
report: Willie Snead caught 1-of-3 targets for eight yards in the Ravens' Week 13 win over the Falcons.

impact: Watson took a beating in Sunday's win over Dallas but insists he'll be fine for Week 6. The second-year signal-caller has been an absolute stud this season, topping 300 yards passing in four straight games while also leading all quarterbacks with 201 rushing yards. He'll be a no-brainer QB1 against Buffalo.
report: Deshaun Watson (chest) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: The Texans are just managing Watson's reps. The quarterback has expressed zero concern about his Week 6 status. He will be an elite QB1 against the Bills.
report: Deshaun Watson (chest) remained "limited" in Thursday's practice.

impact: There's no doubt over Watson's status despite the questionable tag. Watson has been on fire since a shaky Week 1, throwing for over 300 yards in four straight games. He's our fifth-ranked quarterback for Sunday's matchup with Buffalo.
report: Deshaun Watson (chest) is questionable for Week 6 against Buffalo.

impact: There never appeared to be much doubt about his availability, but it is still good to get some confirmation. Watson's faces an understatedly tough matchup against the Bills, but he remains a solid QB1.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Deshaun Watson (chest) is expected to play Week 6 against the Bills.

impact: There was never much doubt about his status despite a lingering chest injury. Watson is a locked-in QB1 this week. Houston declared CB Aaron Colvin (ankle), WR Vyncint Smith, ILB Brian Peters (ankle), OLB Deashon Hall, OT David Sharpe, DE Carlos Watkins, and DE Christian Covington inactive for Week 6.
report: Deshaun Watson (chest) is active for Week 6 against the Bills.

impact: Watson also fumbled three times, losing one, and was sacked seven times in a game he almost certainly wants to forget. Things started out perfectly for the quarterback, who was five-for-five with 62 yards and a touchdown to start the game, but it all went downhill from there. Houston's only meaningful offense in the second half came when Will Fuller drew a defensive pass interference play in the end zone. Houston could not get convert that into a touchdown, but the defense bailed them out with a pick-six to close out the game. Watson can point to a tough matchup, but the road will not get any easier next week in Jacksonville. He will be just a borderline QB1 in that matchup.
report: Deshaun Watson completed 15-of-25 passes for 177 yards, one touchdown, and two interceptions in the Texans' Week 6 win over the Bills.

impact: Watson played at less than 100 percent last week, but it was never more than a pain-tolerance issue. He has another tough matchup with Jacksonville after Buffalo held him to one touchdown. We like Watson as a back-end QB1 for Week 7.
report: Deshaun Watson (chest) is practicing in full for Week 7.
