report: Tarik Cohen rushed eight times for 30 yards and caught 12-of-14 targets for 156 yards in the Bears' 30-27, Week 13 overtime loss to the Giants, adding a one-yard touchdown pass.

impact: Coach Steve Wilks is also on board with getting more work for Williams and Kirk, who combined to catch one-of-five targets in Sunday's season-opening loss to Washington. "We targeted Larry [Fitzgerald] a lot last week, but I think those other guys are more than capable of making plays," said Wilks. "We've got to spread it around." Bradford showed zero chemistry with Arizona's non-Fitzgerald receivers in Week 1 and could be in danger of being replaced with first-round rookie Josh Rosen waiting in the wings. Offensively, the Cardinals are a disaster right now.
report: Sam Bradford wants to get Chad Williams and Christian Kirk more involved in the Cardinals' passing game, especially early in games.

impact: Williams played his normal allotment of snaps last time out against the 49ers in Week 8 but is now injured coming out of the bye week.  The second-year pro has caught 11-of-27 targets for 113 yards and a score this year.
report: Chad Williams (ankle) did not practice Wednesday.

impact: He also sat out Wednesday and Thursday, making him almost certain to be ruled out on Friday afternoon. With Williams sidelined, Christian Kirk could see a bump in targets.
report: Chad Williams (ankle) did not practice Friday.

impact: J.J. Nelson, Kendall Wright, or Trent Sherfield will fill-in for Williams as the team's third wideout. This should ultimately lead to a slight increase in targets for both Larry Fitzgerald and rookie Christian Kirk in OC Byron Leftwich's new uptempo scheme. Kirk remains a WR3/FLEX in a four-team bye week.
report: Chad Williams (ankle) is out for Week 10 against the Chiefs.

impact: Williams was out in Week 10 and it inevitably resulted in more opportunity for Larry Fitzgerald, Christian Kirk, and Ricky Seals-Jones. Expect J.J. Nelson to stick as the team's third wideout. Even so, he isn't viable for fantasy purposes.
report: Chad Williams (ankle) is out for Week 11 against the Raiders.

impact: He's likely going to miss at least another week. J.J. Nelson will fill in for Williams, with Larry Fitzgerald and Christian Kirk picking up more targets.
report: Chad Williams (ankle) remained sidelined at Wednesday's practice.

impact: This will be his third straight absence. The second-year wideout has yet to become a difference-maker at the next level, converting just 14-of-38 targets for 144 yards and a touchdown over 14 NFL appearances.
report: Chad Williams (ankle) is out for Week 12 against the Chargers.

impact: It's his first practice since going down in Week 9. Williams has a chance to return this week but he's likely going to need to get in a full practice to play.
report: Chad Williams (ankle) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Williams resumed practicing on a limited basis this week. He hasn't suited up since Week 8. Even if Williams gets the green light for Sunday's game at Lambeau, we wouldn't advise using him in fantasy.
report: Chad Williams (ankle) is questionable for Week 13 against the Packers.

impact: The rest of Arizona's inactives are LT D.J. Humphries, LB Deone Bucannon, CB Quinten Rollins, CB Dontae Johnson, LB Thurston Armbrister, and DE Cameron Malveaux.
report: Cardinals WR Chad Williams (ankle) is out for Week 13 at Green Bay.

impact: The Rams' offense understandably started slow as no starters played at any point in the preseason. Gurley still found a way to produce, catching a 19-yard shovel pass from Jared Goff in the first quarter for his only score of the night. Los Angeles eventually fed him down the stretch, constantly putting the rock in his belly and allowing him to ice the game. With rookie John Kelly inactive, backup RB Malcolm Brown (1-5) was the only other running back to see even a single carry. It's a tremendous start for those who drafted Gurley No. 1 overall.
report: Todd Gurley rushed for 108 yards on 23 carries and hauled in 3-of-5 targets for 39 yards and one touchdown in the Rams' Week 1 win over the Raiders.

impact: Despite sitting out all of the fourth quarter due to cramps, Gurley did his fantasy backers right in the blowout win. He scored three times from short distance, and he backed up two of those scores with two-point conversions. Completely healthy -- Gurley was walking around the sidelines in the fourth and almost certainly would have reentered the game if not for the score -- Gurley will be the top overall running back option next week against the Chargers.
report: Todd Gurley rushed 19 times for 42 yards and three touchdowns and caught all three of his targets for 31 yards in the Rams' Week 2 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Gurley now has at least 19 carries in all three games. As he usually does, Gurley converted a goal line carry for his fourth touchdown of the year. With a 28-13 lead in the third quarter, Gurley was fed carries and the Chargers were unable to stop him. Through three games, Gurley is averaging 25.5 PPR points and will remain an elite RB1 against the Vikings on Thursday night.
report: Todd Gurley rushed 23 times for 105 yards and one touchdown and caught five passes for 51 yards in the Rams' Week 3 win over the Chargers.

impact: Gurley got his touchdown out of the way early, beating linebacker Anthony Barr (who was victimized on three of the Rams’ five touchdowns) on a wheel route for an eight-yard score late in the first quarter. The reigning NFL Offensive Player of the Year did more damage in the second half, breaking off a 56-yard catch-and-run on a play that probably should have been waved off (Rodger Saffold was initially called for a block in the back, but the referee inexplicably picked up his flag). Gurley poured salt in the wound with a 10-yard gallop late in the fourth quarter, getting the first down to seal the game for Los Angeles. The 24-year-old will bring a four-game touchdown streak into next week’s matchup against the Seahawks.
report: Todd Gurley delivered 83 yards on 17 carries while snagging four-of-six targets for 73 yards and a touchdown Thursday in L.A.’s Week 4 win over the Vikings.

impact: Gurley averaged just 3.5 yards per carry, but that does not matter on a day he scores three times. The first two came from two yards out, and the third was a five-yarder in the fourth quarter. Gurley almost had a fourth score, but he was ruled down at the one and then stuffed at the goal line on the next play in the second quarter. Gurley now had at least one score in every game and two three-touchdown performances in just five games. He will remain the overall RB1 next week in Denver.
report: Todd Gurley rushed 22 times for 77 yards and three touchdowns while catching 4-of-5 targets for 36 yards in the Rams' Week 5 win over the Seahawks.

impact: One week after Isaiah Crowell demolished the Broncos' crumbling run defense, Gurley wrecked it for a new career high in rushing yards. Gurley was ripping chunk gains essentially every time he touched the ball, averaging 7.42 yards per carry. For the season, Gurley's YPC now rests at 4.82, while he's scored 11 total touchdowns, putting him on pace for 29. Gurley should run all over the 49ers, who will be playing on a short week, in Week 7.
report: Todd Gurley rushed 28 times for 208 yards and a pair of touchdowns in the Rams' Week 6 win over the Broncos, adding two receptions for 17 additional yards.

impact: He scored a touchdown because that is what he does, but Gurley was mostly held in check in the first half. That changed in the third quarter when he went for nine and 18 yards on back-to-back carries, and he managed to find the end zone again from one yard out later that quarter. Following a long punt return, he ended his day and any doubt about the outcome of the game with a 12-yard touchdown catch on a screen pass in the fourth. That score gave Gurley 14 for the season and tied him with Priest Holmes for the most touchdowns through seven games in NFL history. He now has three games with three touchdowns this season and eight total the last three weeks. He will look to keep things going next week against the Packers.
report: Todd Gurley rushed 15 times for 63 yards and two touchdowns and caught 4-of-5 targets for 23 yards and another score in the Rams' Week 7 win over the 49ers.

impact: In a devastating moment for fantasy owners, Gurley passed up a 21-yard touchdown run on the Rams' game-sealing drive, opting instead to go down at the four so the Rams could run out the clock. It was unequivocally the right decision, though one Gurley might later regret as he pursues the single-season touchdown record. Gurley was often running into brick walls but still came out the other side with a 4.56 YPC. With the Pack doing an excellent job on Brandin Cooks and Robert Woods, Jared Goff kept targeting Gurley against S Jermaine Whitehead. Gurley has a tough Week 9 matchup in the Saints' lockdown run defense, but matchups do not matter for Sean McVay's primary touchdown scorer.
report: Todd Gurley rushed 25 times for 114 yards in the Rams' Week 8 win over the Packers, adding six receptions for 81 yards and a touchdown.

impact: Not to be outdone by Alvin Kamara’s fast start, Todd Gurley rumbled for a couple big plays on his opening drive including an eight-yard touchdown in which he beat the defense to the corner. He stalled a bit following that series, finishes the first half with "just" 34 total yards on nine touches. He got back on the right track on the second drive of the second half, making a good cut in the backfield to get loose for a 24-carry, but that was about it for the star back. This goes down as a "quiet" game by Gurley's standards, but he is still the RB11 heading into Sunday night, showing how ridiculously high he has set the bar. He will obviously be a must-start next week against the Seahawks.
report: Todd Gurley rushed 13 times for 68 yards and a touchdown and hauled in 6-of-7 targets for 11 yards in the Rams' Week 9 loss to the Saints.

impact: Running with a head of steam on a toss play, Gurley's 17-yard score was sprung by a big Robert Woods block. Gurley has now cleared 150 yards from scrimmage five times this season. He has 17 touchdowns in 10 games. He should threaten for 200 yards in next Monday's Mexico City showdown with the Chiefs.
report: Todd Gurley rushed 16 times for 120 yards and a touchdown in the Rams' Week 10 win over the Seahawks, adding three receptions for 40 additional yards.

impact: Gurley had 28 yards at halftime and was a relative non-factor considering these teams combined for 105 points and 1,001 yards with 14 touchdowns.  Gurley appeared to hurt himself following a seven-yard catch in the first half, as Malcolm Brown got a little more run than normal out of the backfield.  Gurley remained in the game plan, however, and isn't truly injured.  He'll get the Week 12 bye to rest up ahead of a Week 13 road date with the Lions where he should bounce back.
report: Todd Gurley rushed 12 times for 55 yards and caught all three of his targets for 39 yards in the Rams' 54-51, Week 11 win over the Chiefs on Monday night.

impact: Gurley rolled his ankle early in the proceedings but stayed in the game. He was never announced with an injury. In one of the more tilting fantasy moments of the season, he failed to find the end zone in the Rams' 54-51 victory. With the Week 12 bye to heal up, Gurley will resume dominating against the Lions in Week 13.
report: Speaking Tuesday, Rams coach Sean McVay confirmed Todd Gurley was limited by an ankle issue against the Chiefs but is expected to be fine going forward.

impact: Gurley was limited after an in-game ankle tweak against the Chiefs in Week 11, but he was left off the Rams' Week 13 injury report following the team's bye week. Gurley is the top running back play on a weekly basis.
report: Speaking Thursday, Rams coach Sean McVay said Todd Gurley (ankle) will be his "normal self" against the Lions in Week 13.

impact: The Rams as a whole looked sluggish coming off last week's bye, but Gurley sure didn't. After mostly taking a backseat in L.A.'s entertaining win over Kansas City two weeks ago (an ankle injury hampered him in that game), Gurley returned to the limelight with a stellar showing in the Motor City. Working as the Rams' only healthy back (backup Malcolm Brown was lost to a shoulder injury in the first half), Gurley added his 18th and 19 touchdowns of the season with both scores coming in the second half. Gurley teased fantasy owners by purposely going down on the one-yard line on what should have been a walk-in touchdown with little time remaining (he pulled a similar stunt against the Packers earlier this year), but he saved fantasy owners a panic attack by scoring later in the drive. The win clinched L.A.'s second straight division title. The NFC-leading Rams will head to Chicago next week to face the Bears on Sunday Night Football. That game, of course, will be shown on NBC.
report: Todd Gurley rumbled to 132 yards and two touchdowns on 23 carries while adding three catches for 33 yards on five targets Sunday in the Rams’ Week 13 victory over the Lions.

impact: Howard was the focal point on offense, out touching Tarik Cohen (five carries, three catches) by a wide margin. He put Chicago in position to win late, but their defense couldn't hold on. Howard had a larger third-down role than last year, but still ceded pass game snaps to Cohen. He'll remain a high-floor RB2 for Week 2 against Seattle.
report: Jordan Howard had 15 carries for 82 yards and caught five passes for 25 yards in Week 1 against the Packers.

impact: Howard is averaging 19 touches per game through two weeks but has yet to find the end zone and had a long run of just seven yards Monday night.  He continues to be the clear backfield focal point over Tarik Cohen, who touched the ball just five times in this one after eight times in Week 1.  Howard will look to find pay dirt next week in a soft road date against the Cardinals.
report: Jordan Howard rushed 14 times for 35 yards and caught 3-of-4 targets for 33 yards in the Bears' Week 2 win over the Seahawks.

impact: When speaking about Howard's limited fourth quarter workload -- he received just two carries and one target in Monday's fourth quarter -- Nagy said, "I think probably a few more carries is probably the answer to that." The coach also mentioned that the Bears need to be playing with a lead for Howard to get the "typical 8-10 fourth quarter carries." Howard is already averaging 19 touches per game, but a few more carries would certainly help his fantasy value.
report: Bears coach Matt Nagy said Jordan Howard needs "probably a few more carries."

impact: Howard found little room to operate on the ground for the second straight week, but was able to get into the end zone on a 1-yard plunge for the Bears' lone touchdown of the game. After a strong 15-82 rushing line to start the season in Week 1, Howard has now carried 38 times for 96 yards the past two weeks. Howard will remain a strong volume-based fantasy Week 4 at home against the Buccaneers coming off a short week.
report: Jordan Howard rushed 24 times for 61 yards and a touchdown while catching 2-of-2 targets for 20 yards in Sunday's Week 3 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Chicago led 38-3 at the half, which would usually make for terrific game script for Howard to go out and ice the rest of the game. But it was Tarik Cohen who stayed involved from kick-off to the final whistle, leading the Bears in both targets and carries. Howard failed to haul in his only target Sunday, too. The argument to start Howard has been strictly usage-based to this point as he has yet to eclipse the 100-yard mark despite averaging 16 carries per game. If Cohen continues cutting into his playing time, it will be time for owners to rethink their position on him. This timeshare will be worth monitoring when the Bears return from their bye in Week 6.
report: Jordan Howard rushed 11 times for 25 yards in the Bears' Week 4 victory over the Bucs.

impact: The Bears had easily their best day of the season on offense, but Howard was left out of the fun, rushing just 11 times for 25 yards despite what seemed like his perfect gamescript. On Monday, coach Matt Nagy made it sound like Howard's lack of involvement was game-plan specific. "He has a big-time role. But if it’s an advantage to us to go a different direction for that game or for that play or that series, we’re going to do that," Nagy said. "And Jordan is good with that. He understands it." It sounds like Howard will return to the No. 1 role against the Dolphins this week, but it might not be a coincidence the offense looked its best with Tarik Cohen as the main back. Howard's rest-of-season workload is now at least a question mark.
report: Jordan Howard said he "wasn’t frustrated" by his role Week 4 against the Bucs.

impact: Howard contributed a handful of big runs but was again out-shined by backfield-mate Tarik Cohen, who impressed with 121 yards from scrimmage. Despite assurances from coach Matt Nagy that Howard would play a bigger role in the passing game this year, he's mostly been a non-factor in that area, just as he's been throughout his career. Howard had a chance for a touchdown in the first half but coughed it up on the goal line, resulting in a turnover. With Cohen's workload on the rise, Howard is looking like a fringe RB2, which isn't what fantasy owners thought they were getting when they drafted him in August. We'll see how Chicago's backfield distribution shakes out next week against New England.
report: Jordan Howard logged 69 yards on 14 carries while failing to reel in his lone target Sunday in Chicago’s Week 6 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: He added nine yards on one catch. Howard continued to split carries with Tarik Cohen even when the game was close and struggled to find consistent success on the ground, but he helped out his fantasy backers with a two-yard touchdown in the second quarter. He appeared to have another score on the first drive of the second half, but the play was negated by an illegal formation penalty. He did surprise with a twisting catch on his only target, but Howard mostly took a backseat from that point on with the Bears trailing. He now has 14 or fewer touches in each of his last three games. Howard will be an RB3/FLEX option next week against the Jets.
report: Jordan Howard rushed 12 times for 39 yards and a touchdown in the Bears' Week 7 loss to the Patriots.

impact: Tarik Cohen stole the show early, but Howard sealed the win for Chicago with a late fourth-quarter TD. Howard didn't have any highlights outside of his touchdown and wasn't involved in the pass game. He's been more touchdown dependent than usual this year, but Howard has double-digit carries in every game this season. Howard will be an RB2 for a Week 9 matchup against Buffalo.
report: Jordan Howard had 22 carries for 81 yards and a touchdown in Chicago's Week 8 win over the Jets.

impact: Fantasy owners were fortunate to come away with the scores -- one at the goal line and the other from 18 yards out -- because Howard would have been a major dud without them.  He didn't see a single target in the passing game in a matchup where the Bears barely even had the ball because their defense scored twice.  Howard did out-touch Tarik Cohen 14 to 7.  Nevertheless, Howard will remain a touchdown-dependent RB2 option when the Bears host the Lions next.
report: Jordan Howard rushed 14 times for 47 yards and two touchdowns in the Bears' Week 9 romp over Buffalo.

impact: Sunday spelled an end to Howard's three-game touchdown streak. Tarik Cohen out-touched Howard by a commanding 11-2 margin in the first half and was even featured on the goal line. Howard took on more work with Chicago looking to kill clock in the second half, but obviously he wasn't able to take advantage. The third-year back has been lousy as a ball-carrier recently, averaging an underwhelming 3.13 yards per carry over his last four games. He'll be a touchdown-or-bust RB2 when the Vikings come to town in Week 11.
report: Jordan Howard scrounged up 21 yards on 11 carries while securing his lone target for an 11-yard gain Sunday in Chicago’s Week 10 win over the Lions.

impact: It's a solid game against a tough Vikings run defense. Howard had more touches than Tarik Cohen (10), but they played close to the same amount of snaps. Howard's 18 carries were the most since Week 8. There haven't been many big games from Howard this year, with fewer than 50 rushing yards in four of the last seven weeks. He'll be an RB2 for Week 12 against Detroit.
report: Jordan Howard had 18 carries for 63 yards in Chicago's Week 11 win over the Vikings.

impact: Brutal. With Chase Daniel presenting zero down-field threat, the Bears could not get anything on the ground against the Lions' improving run defense. The 15 yards from scrimmage were by far Howard's fewest of the season, though he was also head to 32 two weeks ago. Completely touchdown-or-bust as a run-only running back, Howard is a low-upside RB2/3.
report: Jordan Howard rushed seven times for 13 yards in the Bears' Week 12 win over the Lions, adding a two-yard reception.

impact: Howard was impressive in the first half, gaining 68 yards on the ground before the break.  He had pickups of 21 and 25 yards to set up a touchdown to Adam Shaheen.  Howard disappeared after that as Tarik Cohen took over and totaled 186 yards with a passing score.  Howard will be a TD-or-bust RB2/3 next week at home against the Rams.  He's a tough sell every week.
report: Jordan Howard rushed 16 times for 76 yards in the Bears' Week 13 loss to the Giants.

impact: Todd Gurley was dealing with cramps, so Brown got all the work in the fourth quarter. He played well and seems like he would be a reliable starter if something were to happen to Gurley. The Rams also have rookie John Kelly, who has been inactive the first two weeks.
report: Malcolm Brown rushed 12 times for 46 yards in the Rams' Week 2 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Rookie John Kelly was a healthy scratch for the third straight week meaning Malcolm Brown is the handcuff to Todd Gurley. With Gurley healthy, Brown is solely a change-of-pace back for the Rams, and he can't be started in fantasy.
report: Malcolm Brown rushed five times for 42 yards in the Rams' Week 3 win over the Chargers.

impact: Brown does not get many touches behind Todd Gurley, but he has been effective when given a shot this year. He was even better than that on the first drive of the second half. After making a catch in the flat, Brown somehow avoided a tackler, acrobatically tip-toed down the sideline, and went in for an 18-yard score. Brown remains the best handcuff in the game, and he could get a start or two late in the year if the Rams lock things up early
report: Malcolm Brown turned his only target into an 18-yard touchdown in the Rams' Week 9 loss to the Saints.

impact: Kelly was the star of the Rams' preseason as a sixth-round rookie.  The Rams routinely only had two running backs active on game days last season.  Malcolm Brown is Todd Gurley's backup.  Barron has an ankle injury.
report: Rams declared RB John Kelly, QB Brandon Allen, ILB Mark Barron, RB Justin Davis, LB Trevon Young, DL Sebastian Joseph-Day, and DL Tanzel Smart inactive for Week 1 against the Raiders.

impact: It is the second healthy scratch in a row for the rookie. Malcolm Brown looks like the handcuff to roster behind Todd Gurley.
report: Rams declared RB John Kelly inactive for Week 2 against the Cardinals.

impact: This is the third healthy scratch in a row for the rookie who is behind Malcolm Brown as Todd Gurley's handcuff. The rest of the Rams inactives are LB Mark Barron, K Greg Zuerlein, OL Brian Allen, DT Sebastian Joseph-Day, DT Tanzel Smart, and OLB Trevon Young. Zuerlein is expected to be out "at least a few weeks."
report: Rams declared RB John Kelly inactive for Week 3 against the Chargers.

impact: His performance might not be as surprising as Will Dissly leading the Seahawks in receiving, but Lindsay certainly was not expected to finish with the same number of carries and rushing yards as Royce Freeman in the season opener. That said, this is probably not a fluke. Lindsay earned his roster spot with a big training camp, and he saw plenty of snaps with the first-team offense in the third preseason game. While he might not get as many chances in the running game moving forward – it seemed to be something of a "hot hand" situation – he looks like the No. 2 ahead of Devontae Booker.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 15 times for 71 yards and hauled in 2-of-3 targets for 31 yards and a touchdown in the Broncos' Week 1 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Lindsay is fully expected to play. He appeared on Thursday's injury report with an ailing knee but practiced in full to end the week. Both he and rookie teammate Royce Freeman are in a tremendous spot against Oakland's lackluster front seven in Week 2.
report: Phillip Lindsay (knee) practiced Friday.

impact: Lindsay had 15 touches compared to eight for Royce Freeman and three for Devontae Booker as he was the first Denver running back to ever have over 100-yards from scrimmage in each of his first two career games in franchise history. Lindsay has built off a strong preseason to overtake a lead role in this Denver backfield, but still doesn't have a firm grasp on the goal line work, which will keep him as a RB2/FLEX option Week 3 when the Broncos head to Baltimore.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 14 times for 107 yards with one reception for four yards in Sunday's win over the Raiders.

impact: "Our deal with that room is more of game plan," Joseph said.  "It's what they do best.  It's more of who has the hot hand that day."  Rookie UDFA Phillip Lindsay (178 yards) is third in the league in rushing as we wind down Week 2, trailing only Matt Breida (184) and Joe Mixon (179).  Joseph is "not considering" starting Lindsay, but he said "it doesn't matter."  Lindsay has the "hot hand" at the moment and has had it since arriving at Broncos camp.  Lindsay has played nine more snaps than fellow rookie Royce Freeman and 13 more than Devontae Booker.
report: Coach Vance Joseph said the Broncos will continue using a "hot hand" approach in the backfield.

impact: Lindsay threw several "punches" during a scrum for a loose football at the end of the second quarter. They were more arm swings than punches, and none of them seemed to land. It was right under the nose of an official, however, and he ended up getting tossed. Lindsay had 20 yards on four carries before exiting. Royce Freeman and Devontae Booker should see more snaps with Lindsay in the locker room.
report: Phillip Lindsay was ejected from Week 3 against the Ravens for throwing a punch.

impact: After being ejected from last week's loss against the Ravens, Lindsay resumed his spot as the lead dog in this backfield.  He out-touched Royce Freeman 14-8 with Devontae Booker a distant third at two touches.  Both Lindsay and Freeman scored red-zone rushing touchdowns, with Lindsay's coming from one yard away.  Despite his 5'8/190 frame, Lindsay is a tough inside runner with great speed.  He could have read his blocks a bit better tonight, but Lindsay continues to produce when given the ball.  He'll be an RB2/3 next week at the Jets.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 12 times for 69 yards and one touchdown in the Broncos' Week 4 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: He out-touched Royce Freeman 15 to 8, while Devontae Booker was active only in the passing game with five catches.  Despite coachspeak the Broncos "want to involve Freeman more," Lindsay has earned and run away with Denver's lead-back job.  Lindsay will remain a quality RB2/flex option against the Rams in Week 6.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 12 times for 61 yards and caught 3-of-4 targets for 20 yards in the Broncos' Week 5 loss to the Jets.

impact: Lindsay appeared to have a 12-yard receiving score in the third quarter, but it got called back by a Courtland Sutton offensive pass interference penalty. For the first time in a full game, Lindsay got out-carried by Royce Freeman, though he still out-touched and out-gained his rookie teammate. Both players continued to lose passing-down snaps to Devontae Booker, a weekly unforced error from the Broncos' under siege coaching staff. It was encouraging to see Lindsay catch six passes, a number that doubled his previous best total. Lindsay will remain on the RB2/3 borderline for Denver's short-week TNF matchup with the Cardinals.
report: Phillip Lindsay caught 6-of-7 targets for 48 yards in the Broncos' Week 6 loss to the Rams, adding four carries for 18 additional yards.

impact: Lindsay added a six-yard reception. It felt like Lindsay was delivering chunk gains every time he touched the ball, so it was disappointing that he got the rock just 16 times in a 45-10 victory. Part of the problem was short drives, as five Cardinals turnovers kept setting the Broncos up with gorgeous field position. Seven of Lindsay's 14 carries gained at least five yards, while five gained at least nine. Lindsay also had a 24-yarder called back by holding. Running circles around Royce Freeman every week — although good in his own right most of the year, Freeman went just 13/37/1 this evening — Lindsay is well established as an RB2.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 14 times for 90 yards and a touchdown in the Broncos' Week 7 win over the Cardinals.

impact: He punched in a goal-line touchdown during the first quarter and also had a two-point try later in the game he could not convert. The 18 carries were a career-high for Lindsay, who has now gone for 90-plus rushing yards in back-to-back weeks. The undrafted rookie could have had a bigger day but he had at least two long runs erased by holding penalties on his offensive line. Lindsay's speed was evident Sunday as the 24-year-old Colorado State alum broke off chunk gains whenever he had an opening. He out-touched back-field mate Devontae Booker (who was also excellent on Sunday) by a significant 21-13 margin. Lindsay will see his workload reduced once Royce Freeman returns from his sprained ankle, but in the meantime, he's worth firing up as an RB2 in all fantasy formats. He'll face the Texans at home in Week 9.
report: Phillip Lindsay rumbled to 95 yards and a touchdown on 18 carries while also contributing three catches for 17 yards on three targets Sunday in the Broncos’ Week 8 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: He added 24 yards on two catches, too. The Texans boast what's arguably the league's top rush defense, inevitably keeping Lindsay bottled up for 3.5 YPC on 17 hard-fought totes. Devontae Booker frustratingly vultured the Broncos' only rushing score of the day, but Lindsay still worked ahead and out-touched him 19-5. Including Week 8, Lindsay's now out-touched Booker 40-18 in Denver's last two games without Royce Freeman. The undrafted rookie will see his recent surge in touches reduced once Freeman returns after the bye, but it's clear the team has no fear in featuring him if Freeman misses any further action.
report: Phillip Lindsay fought for 60 yards on 17 carries in the Broncos' Week 9 loss to the Texans.

impact: The rookie flashed his signature speed with a 41-yard touchdown burst during the second quarter, then made a second end-zone visit in the fourth, this time scoring on a direct snap from two yards out. Lindsay butchered a fourth-and-one chance during the second quarter, but that was his only false step in an otherwise flawless performance. Even with Royce Freeman back from a two-game absence, Lindsay still won the touch battle 15-8 while out-gaining Freeman by 76 yards. At 5'8/190, Lindsay isn't the biggest dog in the fight, but he hits the hole as hard as any back in the league. The former Colorado Buffalo will remain a locked-in RB2 when the Broncos return home to face Pittsburgh in Week 12.
report: Phillip Lindsay blew up for 79 yards and two touchdowns on 11 carries while nabbing four catches for 27 yards on five targets Sunday in the Broncos’ Week 11 win over the Chargers.

impact: Denver’s offense was mostly held in check in the first half, but Lindsay broke things open with a 32-yard explosion to kick-start a touchdown drive at the end of the second quarter. Lindsay stayed hot after the break, ripping off 12- and 14-yard runs on the opening drive of the third quarter. He also opened the fourth with a flurry of big plays, and he gave the Broncos the lead in the final quarter with a two-yard score. The only thing holding Lindsay back right now is a lack of carries -- for some reason, he has just 25 in the last two games despite averaging 7.6 per carry. He will be a borderline RB1 in a great matchup with the Bengals next week.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 14 times for 110 yards and a touchdown in the Broncos' Week 12 win over the Steelers.

impact: The Broncos always had a good shot to follow in the footsteps of other opposing offenses and paste the Bengals' defense for numerous points, but Lindsay made it look easy throughout the day. Not only did he outrun Cincinnati's entire secondary to put the Broncos on the board with a 65-yard touchdown sprint, he later showed patience in waiting for his blocking from six yards out and running up the middle for his second score of the day. Lindsay's now out-touched teammate Royce Freeman 34-18 in the last two games, efficiently rushing for a total of 267 yards (8.09 YPC) and three scores in that stint. Clearly the team's leading back for the rest of the season, he'll again be an RB1 in San Francisco next week.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 19 times for 157 yards and two touchdowns in the Broncos' Week 13 win over the Bengals.

impact: The Rams' offense understandably sputtered out the gates after having sat the entire preseason. Goff still found a way to produce in the first half, recording a 19-yard touchdown to Todd Gurley on a shovel pass. His second score was a beautifully designed play inside the 10-yard line that resulted in a Cooper Kupp score in the flats. Goff wasn't needed in the fourth quarter as Los Angeles simply played defense and fed the ball to Gurley to ice the game. It was still a promising outing for the 23-year-old, who will see better game scripts in the coming weeks.
report: Jared Goff completed 18-of-33 passes for 233 yards and two touchdowns in the Rams' Week 1 win over the Raiders.

impact: The only thing not to like about Goff’s performance was he only threw one touchdown. He probably should have had two more, but he underthrew Brandin Cooks, who had to come back to the ball and the defender, and missed a wide-open Robert Woods in the end zone. Neither play ultimately mattered in a game the Rams won going away. Goff might need to be sharper next week against the Chargers, though.
report: Jared Goff completed 24-of-32 passes for 354 yards, a touchdown, and an interception in the Rams' Week 2 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Goff has back-to-back games with 354 passing yards, but his three touchdowns are the most since Week 15 of 2017. Robert Woods was Goff's primary target today as the two connected for two touchdowns, but Brandin Cooks came just one foot short of his first touchdown too. Sean McVay has this offense cooking right now -- they have scored at least 33 points in all three games -- but they have a test with the Vikings coming up on Thursday Night Football.
report: Jared Goff completed 29-of-36 passes for 354 yards, three touchdowns, and an interception in the Rams' Week 3 win over the Chargers.

impact: He was sacked once for a loss of nine yards. Goff was an absolute mad man in the first half, slinging four touchdowns on 13-of-17 passing before the break. Two of those scores went to Cooper Kupp, who had a career night with nine catches for 162 yards. Goff had his deep ball working against the Vikes, including late in the first half when he connected on a 47-yard touchdown to Brandin Cooks. Goff’s five touchdowns tied a franchise record. He also set a career-high in passing yards while becoming the first Ram to go over 400 yards since Marc Bulger in 2005. Goff recorded a perfect 158.3 quarterback rating in the victory. Unstoppable isn’t a word we throw around too often at Rotoworld, but that’s how the Rams offense has looked this year. Goff and the Rams will take a 4-0 record into next week’s matchup against the Seahawks.
report: Jared Goff completed 26-of-33 passes for 465 yards and five touchdowns while adding seven yards on two carries Thursday in the Rams’ Week 4 win over the Vikings.

impact: It was not pretty, but Goff helped lead the Rams to a 5-0 start with three scoring drives in the second half and some timely plays, most notably a fourth-down conversion on a sneak to ice the game late in the fourth quarter. Goff's first interception was a forced throw which was tipped into the air at the goal line, but the second came on a Hail Mary at the end of the first half. That said, he probably deserved at least two interceptions and got lucky on several throws. Goff could have had another score, but Todd Gurley was ruled down at the one on a jet shovel pass in the second quarter. Goff has now thrown for at least 320 yards in four straight games. He will be a back-end QB1 next week in Denver.
report: Jared Goff completed 23-of-32 passes for 321 yards, a touchdown, and two interceptions in the Rams' Week 5 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Goff had his first scoreless start of the season as the Rams gutted the Broncos on the ground. He now has just one touchdown and three picks over his past two starts, both Rams victories. Today's giveaway came on a twice-tipped pass. There has been little overt reason for alarm. It just seems to be the normal ebbs and flows of a fantasy campaign. Goff nearly received some awful news this afternoon when Cooper Kupp appeared to shred his knee, but he miraculously returned after the break. Goff will remain a locked-in QB1 for Week 7 against the 49ers.
report: Jared Goff completed 14-of-28 passes for 201 yards, zero touchdowns and an interception in the Rams' 23-20, Week 6 win over the Broncos.

impact: With the 49ers turning it over for fun, Goff did not have to do much in this one. He still managed a respectable fantasy outing with two touchdowns. The first came on a great route by Brandin Cooks in the second quarter, and the second was on a screen pass to Todd Gurley in the fourth. After a hot run, Goff has now thrown for just 403 yards and two scores total in his last two games. He should fare better next week against the Packers.
report: Jared Goff completed 18-of-24 passes for 202 yards and two touchdowns in the Rams' Week 7 win over the 49ers.

impact: Goff had a shaky first half in a hostile Coliseum — the Rams' stadium was taken over by Packers fans — but he survived to get cooking after the break. The three scores were as many as Goff totaled in Weeks 5-7. With his receivers dealing with sticky coverage, Goff relentlessly found Todd Gurley on S Jermaine Whitehead. The Rams are headed for what should be another shootout with the Saints in Week 9.
report: Jared Goff completed 19-of-35 passes for 295 yards and three touchdowns in the Rams' 29-27, Week 8 win over the Packers.

impact: Not to be outdone by Drew Brees on the other side, Goff had an outstanding start to this game. Following an opening touchdown drive, Goff hit Brandin Cooks in stride for a 48-yard catch before finding the receiver again in the back of the end zone. He made an even better throw to Cooper Kupp on the next series, letting the ball go well before the receiver made his break. Things went a bit downhill from there as Goff did not see Alex Anzalone, who came up with a great interception, but he recovered to lead a field goal drive just before the half. He came out firing after the break, completing 7-of-9 passes including an 18-yard score to get the Rams back in the game and then finding Kupp for a 41-yard touchdown to tie it up. That was the end of the magic, however, and the Rams failed to score on their final two possessions of the loss. Even so, Goff played well and now has multiple scores in three straight. He will be on the QB1 map next week against the Seahawks.
report: Jared Goff completed 28-of-40 passes for 391 yards, three scores, and an interception in the Rams' Week 9 loss to the Saints.

impact: Goff missed a few easy throws but otherwise guided the Rams to a huge home victory. The Rams can now clinch the NFC West as early as next week. The big news, however, is Cooper Kupp's knee injury. Were Kupp to be lost for the season, it would be the biggest test the Rams have faced during the Sean McVay era. Josh Reynolds is the next man up in three-receiver sets. Even if Kupp is absent, Goff will be locked and loaded as a top-five QB1 for next Monday's guaranteed shootout with the Rams. It has game of the year potential.
report: Jared Goff completed 28-of-39 passes for 318 yards and two touchdowns in the Rams' 36-31, Week 10 win over the Seahawks.

impact: This was the best game of the season ... by a long shot.  The Rams had two separate double-digit leads, leading by 13 and 10 at times, before the Chiefs erased both.  Both offenses just traded blows all evening, while the defenses mixed in to land a couple haymakers of their own with sack-fumbles, touchdowns, and interceptions.  Goff added a fifth score on the ground from seven yards out.  His four passing scores went to Robert Woods, Josh Reynolds, and two to Gerald Everett, including the game-winning 40-yarder on a dime down the right sideline.  The sad thing is Goff left a ton of throws on the field, missing a number of throws.  But he came up big when it mattered most.  The 105 combined points in this game were third-most ever and the most in Monday Night Football history.  We can only hope for a rematch in the Super Bowl.  The Rams get a much-needed bye before going to Detroit in Week 13.
report: Jared Goff completed 31-of-49 passes for 413 yards and four touchdowns in the Rams' 54-51, Week 11 win over the Chiefs on Monday night.

impact: Booker operated as the third-down back early in the game and saw passing-down work all day, but he appeared to fall down the depth chart in this one. Following a 29-yard touchdown catch in the first quarter, Phillip Lindsay worked as the No. 2 running back and even matched Royce Freeman in rushing attempts and yards. Looking like the third option in a committee backfield, Booker does not need to be rostered in standard-sized redraft leagues.
report: Devontae Booker rushed twice for four yards and hauled in both his targets for 11 yards in the Broncos' Week 1 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Denver's No. 3 back, Booker took on a bigger role in the second half after Phillip Lindsay was ejected just before halftime. He did not do much with it, and he should fall back behind Lindsay in the pecking order next week.
report: Devontae Booker hauled in 5-of-7 targets for 34 yards and rushed five times for 10 yards in the Broncos' Week 3 loss to the Ravens.

impact: He remains the third wheel in Denver's backfield, but still an active one.  And Booker's activity spiked a bit this week because the Broncos got destroyed by the Jets and played passing-game specialist Booker more than usual.  Booker would still need a Phillip Lindsay or Royce Freeman injury to become a legit flex option, but he is worth stashing in 14- and 16-team PPR leagues.
report: Devontae Booker caught 5-of-6 targets for 59 yards in the Broncos' Week 5 loss to the Jets.

impact: With Royce Freeman (ankle) absent, the 26-year-old set season-highs in both touches and yards from scrimmage. He was especially productive in the second half, delivering 76 of his 101 yards after the break. He delivered the game's longest run (though not the longest play from scrimmage) on a 26-yard burst in the fourth quarter. Despite drawing eight fewer touches than teammate Phillip Lindsay (he won the touch battle 21-13), Booker is still worth owning in most leagues, at least while Freeman is out. He gets the Texans at home in Week 9.
report: Devontae Booker collected 78 yards on nine carries while also snagging four catches for 23 yards on four targets Sunday in the Broncos’ Week 8 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: Booker's touchdown was essentially a vulture-job as he was drastically out-touched by teammate Phillip Lindsay 19-5. It was a severe reduction in his workload sans Royce Freeman in Week 8, having totaled 13 touches against the Chiefs. Given the Broncos' timid and horrid play-calling, Lindsay (the apparent workhorse) need be the only back considered moving forward if Freeman misses any further time.
report: Devontae Booker rushed three times for 15 yards and one score, tacking on two catches for nine yards in the Broncos' Week 9 loss to the Texans.

impact: Booker spent most of the day spectating, playing just 11-of-56 offensive snaps. With Royce Freeman back from injury and Phillip Lindsay enjoying a breakout season, Booker's opportunities going forward will be few and far between. He can be ignored next week against Pittsburgh.
report: Devontae Booker corralled his lone target for four yards Sunday in the Broncos’ Week 11 win over Los Angeles.

impact: The Broncos ruled Freeman (ankle) out on Friday. His absence will open up work for impressive rookie Phillip Lindsay. ILB Brandon Marshall (knee) and OLB Von Miller (ankle) are both active for the Broncos.
report: Broncos declared RB RB Royce Freeman, C Nico Falah, WR DaeSean Hamilton, LB Alexander Johnson, OLB Shane Ray, S Darian Stewart and OT Jared Veldheer inactive for Week 8 against the Chiefs.

impact: Phillip Lindsay piled up a season-high 21 touches with Freeman out last week and turned them into 112 yards.  In replace of Freeman, Devontae Booker played 44% of the snaps and turned 13 touches into 101 yards.  Lindsay and Booker will again form the one-two punch against the Texans this week.
report: Royce Freeman (ankle) is not practicing Wednesday.

impact: His level of participation is unclear, though he was seen wearing a helmet at the start of practice. This would be a quick recovery for Freeman, who is only two weeks removed from suffering a high-ankle sprain. If Freeman returns for Sunday's home game against the Texans, it would be a downgrade for both Phillip Lindsay and Devontae Booker. The Broncos may err on the side of caution with their coming up in Week 10.
report: Royce Freeman (ankle) returned to practice on Thursday.

impact: It had been reported earlier that Freeman was present for Thursday's practice, though apparently he didn't get enough work for the Broncos to list him as a limited participant. Coming off a high-ankle sprain, Freeman was always a long shot to suit up this week. Look for impressive Phillip Lindsay to lead the backfield again Sunday when the Broncos host Houston.
report: Updating an earlier report, Royce Freeman (ankle) remained sidelined at Thursday's practice.

impact: Freeman tried to go Thursday, but he reportedly wasn't able to do enough to be considered 'limited.' He's a true question mark for Sunday. If Freeman's unable to suit up, rookie Phillip Lindsay would again garner high-end RB1 consideration in what should be terrific game script at home. Devontae Booker would stay playing a role on passing downs behind Lindsay, making him a deep league PPR FLEX play.
report: Royce Freeman (ankle) is questionable for Week 9 against the Texans.

impact: Reportedly dealing with a high-ankle sprain, it would have been a stretch for Freeman to return just two weeks after suffering the injury. He appears close, however, and should be ready to go following Denver's Week 10 bye. With Freeman out, Phillip Lindsay will once again work as the No. 1 with Devontae Booker filling in on passing downs.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Royce Freeman (ankle) is not expected to play Week 9 against the Texans.

impact: Phillip Lindsay and, to a lesser extent, Devontae Booker will again be tasked in leading Denver's backfield against the Texans. Houston will be without LB Zach Cunningham, potentially boosting Lindsay's receptions out of the backfield. He's a strong RB1 in this matchup, whereas Booker remains a deep-league PPR FLEX flier.
report: Broncos declared RB Royce Freeman, WR DaeSean Hamilton, S Darian Stewart, CB Bradley Roby, LB Brandon Marshall, OL Sam Jones, and OL Nico Falah inactive for Week 9 against the Texans.

impact: This was always the most likely scenario after Freeman went down in Week 7. Freeman got in a limited practice last Friday but was held out for the second straight week. Barring setbacks, he looks on track to return after Denver's bye.
report: Broncos coach Vance Joseph hopes to get Royce Freeman (ankle) back after the Week 10 bye.

impact: Dealing with a high ankle sprain, Freeman has been out since Week 7.  He will return to a committee alongside Phillip Lindsay and Devontae Booker.  Freeman was a touchdown-or-bust flex option early in the season, and we wouldn't expect that to change in the back half.  Lindsay has outplayed him all year.
report: The Broncos expect Royce Freeman (ankle) back for Week 11 against the Chargers.

impact: This was expected after Freeman got in a limited practice before Week 9. Freeman should be over the high-ankle sprain that cost him two games coming off Denver's bye. Barring a setback, he'll return to a committee role with Phillip Lindsay for Sunday's matchup against the Chargers.
report: Royce Freeman (ankle) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: He's back after missing the previous two games with a high-ankle sprain. Freeman has spent most of the season working in a timeshare with fellow rookie Phillip Lindsay. That should remain the case Sunday in L.A.
report: Royce Freeman (ankle) will play Week 11 against the Chargers.

impact: Freeman is back after missing two games with a high-ankle sprain. He'll work in tandem with fellow rookie Phillip Lindsay. OG Max Garcia, OG Nico Falah, LB Alexander Johnson, LB Brandon Marshall, S Dymonte Thomas, S Shamarko Thomas and DE DeMarcus Walker are inactive for Sunday's game in Los Angeles.
report: Royce Freeman (ankle) is active for Week 11 against the Chargers.

impact: Freeman appeared healthy in his return from a high-ankle sprain but didn't move the needle much for Denver, managing a long run of just seven yards. He salvaged the day somewhat by punching in a three-yard touchdown—his fifth of the season—during the third quarter, though the rookie saw seven fewer touches than Phillip Lindsay. Freeman has been operating as the 1B to Lindsay's 1A, though his size advantage over Lindsay makes him a threat to vulture goal-line carries. The Broncos host Pittsburgh in Week 12.
report: Royce Freeman delivered 23 yards and a touchdown on seven carries while securing his lone target for a seven-yard pickup Sunday in Denver’s Week 11 win over the Chargers.

impact: The clear No. 2 in the backfield, Freeman could not get anything going on his limited attempts in this one. He also lost the goal-line opportunity to Phillip Lindsay, who managed to score from two yards out. Freeman is just a handcuff at this point.
report: Royce Freeman rushed six times for 17 yards in the Broncos' Week 12 win over the Steelers.

impact: Don't let his touches fool you. Six of Freeman's 12 carries came during the team's final two possessions when they were leading by two scores. It was Phillip Lindsay who continued to pave the way to RB1 stardom, finishing with 19/157/2 on a team-high 19 carries. Lindsay's also out-touched Freeman 34-18 in the duo's last two games. Unless something drastic happens mid-week, Freeman is merely a handcuff at this point.
report: Royce Freeman rushed 12 times for 48 yards in the Broncos' Week 13 victory over the Bengals.

impact: According to ESPN Ravens reporter Jamison Hensley, Collins "looks like he's ready to play" against the Steelers on Sunday.  Collins is touchdown-or-bust RB2 facing a Steelers run defense that is No. 3 in fantasy points allowed.
report: Alex Collins (foot) returned to practice Friday.

impact: He should be fine after getting in a full practice on Friday. Collins scored a touchdown when he faced Pittsburgh earlier this year but also lost a fumble in that game. He finds himself squarely on the RB2/3 borderline for Week 9.
report: Alex Collins (foot) is questionable for Week 9 against the Steelers.

impact: Collins was a full participant in practice Friday and seems good to go for Sunday. It's still a nightmarish spot since the Ravens will be without starting tackles Ronnie Stanley (ankle, out) and James Hurst (ankle, out) in the team's debut of its new three-headed backfield committee. Note that Collins hadn't played 50% of Baltimore's snaps in any game prior to Ty Montgomery joining the team.
report: Alex Collins (foot) is expected to play in Week 9 against the Steelers.

impact: There was some concern about Collins' status after he missed Thursday's practice but that went out the window as soon as he returned to full participation on Friday. With Ty Montgomery absent, it will just be Collins, Javorius Allen and Gus Edwards at running back for the Ravens. Collins will be a touchdown-dependent RB2 against Pittsburgh.
report: Alex Collins (foot) is active for Week 9 against the Steelers.

impact: Collins lucked into a goal-line touchdown after teammate Mark Andrews drew a pass interference flag at the one-yard line. Aside from the touchdown—his fourth in four games—Collins was mostly held in check, though obviously his chances were limited with Baltimore playing from behind in the second half. The 10 touches were Collins' fewest since Week 1 and his workload could be even more diluted once the Ravens finally incorporate trade acquisition Ty Montgomery into their offense. Collins and the struggling Ravens will take a three-game losing skid into next week's bye.
report: Alex Collins turned nine carries into 35 yards and a touchdown while adding a four-yard catch on his lone target Sunday in the Ravens’ Week 9 loss to Pittsburgh.

impact: Collins was completely ineffective outside of his seven-yard scoring run, and the Ravens determined UDFA Gus "The Bus" Edwards showed a hotter early-game hand.  Collins touched the ball just once after halftime.  Even ahead of a mouth-watering Week 12 date with Oakland, Collins will be very difficult to trust as a flex option.  Edwards appears to be the Ravens' new lead back.
report: Alex Collins rushed seven times for 18 yards and a touchdown in the Ravens' Week 11 win over the Bengals.

impact: Mid-week adds are never good, but they are especially worrisome when they are "DNP" instead of "limited." Collins will need at least a limited session on Friday for a shot at a committee role against the Raiders. Gus Edwards' outlook continues to improve.
report: Alex Collins was added to the Ravens' injury report on Thursday, missing practice with a foot issue.

impact: Collins always seems to miss a practice here and there for maintenance purposes, but he should be good to go Sunday against Oakland.  However, he's not a fantasy start after getting benched for Gus Edwards last week.
report: Alex Collins (foot) returned to practice Friday.

impact: Collins will likely play, but he's an extremely dicey RB3/FLEX after Gus 'The Bus' Edwards got 17 carries last week. With Lamar Jackson slated to make his second consecutive start, Collins would only provide fantasy production if lucks into a touchdown on the goal line. Javorius Allen and Ty Montgomery will still soak up limited snaps behind him, too.
report: Alex Collins (foot) is questionable for Week 12 against the Raiders.

impact: This was the expectation after Collins got in a full practice on Friday. Collins has a juicy home matchup against the Raiders, though it appears undrafted rookie Gus Edwards has supplanted him as the Ravens' lead back. With Edwards ahead of him on the depth chart, Collins is best viewed as a touchdown-or-bust RB3.
report: Alex Collins (questionable, foot) is expected to play Week 12 against the Raiders.

impact: Collins' inactivity is a surprise after he practiced fully on Friday and NFL Network reported Sunday morning that he would play. Instead, rookie Gus "The Bus" Edwards will start.
report: Alex Collins (foot) will not play Sunday against the Raiders.

impact: Coach John Harbaugh continues to call Collins day to day after he was held out last week against the Raiders.  Gus Edwards is entrenched as the No. 1 back.  Ty Montgomery's role has grown on passing downs for the Ravens.
report: Alex Collins (foot) remained sidelined at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Collins sat out Week 12 and Wednesday's practice with a foot injury. This session puts him on track to play against the Falcons, but it is unclear how much work he will get behind Gus Edwards. Collins is at best a desperation FLEX at this point.
report: Alex Collins (foot) returned to a limited practice on Thursday.

impact: Gus Edwards (ankle) is additionally questionable for Sunday. Coach John Harbaugh still hinted RB Kenneth Dixon could make his regular season debut, undoubtedly pushing Javorius Allen out of the team's rotation altogether. Edwards practiced in full on Friday, and is still the best bet to lead the Ravens in carries against the Falcons. Collins could vulture goal line work, but is still an extremely dicey FLEX option.
report: Alex Collins (foot) is questionable for Week 13 against the Falcons.

impact: After bursting onto the scene with a breakout 212/973/6 in 12 starts for the Ravens last season, Collins' injury-riddled follow-up campaign tragically ends with 114/411/7 over 10 starts. Unlike last season, Collins stayed stuck in a weekly timeshare and never separated himself. He'll be a restricted free agent this offseason. The Ravens activated Kenneth Dixon in a corresponding move.
report: Ravens placed RB Alex Collins (foot) on injured reserve, ending his season.

impact: The Ravens plan to use Lamar Jackson in some packages, so this is gameplan related. ESPN's Chris Mortensen reports Griffin is still likely the No. 2 quarterback if something happens to Joe Flacco. The rest of Baltimore's inactives are WR Jordan Lasley, CB Darious Williams, DT Willie Henry, OL Jermaine Eluemunor, TE Hayden Hurst and DT Zach Sieler.
report: Robert Griffin III is inactive for Week 1 against Buffalo.

impact: As expected, the Ravens will again roll with just two active quarterbacks (Joe Flacco, Lamar Jackson) on game day. It's a slightly better spot for their offense than initially expected given the absences of LB Wesley Woodyard and S Kenny Vaccaro for the Titans.
report: Ravens declare QB Robert Griffin III, FB/DL Patrick Ricard, WR Jordan Lasley, C Hroniss Grasu, OLB Tyus Bowser, DT Zach Sieler and CB Anthony Averett inactive for Week 6 against the Titans.

impact: This isn't the first time we've seen Griffin as an option over Lamar Jackson if Joe Flacco (hip) sits. Griffin outplayed Jackson in the preseason, but Jackson has been active as the No. 2 quarterback for his role in Baltimore's dual-QB packages. The expectation has been that Jackson would get the start, but this is a situation worth monitoring.
report: The Athletic's Jeff Zrebiec reports the Ravens have "continually mentioned" Robert Griffin III as a candidate to start this week.

impact: Per Rapoport, the Ravens have "messed around" with using Griffin III  in two-quarterback formations just as they have with Lamar Jackson throughout the year. Of course this week Jackson will be starting in place of Joe Flacco, who is out with an injured hip. The plan is for RG3 to only see a handful of reps, though the Ravens could turn to him in a pinch if Jackson falters in what equates to a must-win game for Baltimore. It's worth noting that Jackson didn't see his usual practice reps this week after spending Thursday in the hospital with a stomach illness.
report: According to NFL Network's Ian Rapoport, Robert Griffin III is expected to see snaps against the Bengals in Week 11.

impact: The Ravens (4-5) are still in the playoff hunt despite losing three straight games. Jackson has been active over Robert Griffin III for Baltimore's dual-QB packages, but it's possible they could turn to Griffin if Flacco is out next week. The "expectation" is that it will be Jackson, though the Ravens have been noncommittal on their depth chart behind Flacco.
report: The Athletic's Jeff Zrebiec suggests Lamar Jackson isn't a lock to start if Joe Flacco (hip) misses time.

impact: It's an extremely minor issue, but it means Robert Griffin III was the only Ravens quarterback practicing Thursday. The Ravens are probably going to be much more leery of throwing Jackson out there if he's only had two practices. It could end up a huge missed opportunity for the No. 32 overall pick. Of course, RGIII will be an immediate derailment threat against the Bengals. Even if RGIII gets the call, Jackson could be called upon. The situation will be updated multiple times over the next 24 hours.
report: Lamar Jackson's Thursday missed practice was due to a "stomach issue."

impact: ESPN Ravens reporter Jamison Hensley predicts Jackson as the likely starter against the Bengals on Sunday with Robert Griffin III "mixing in" for some series and snaps.  Joe Flacco (hip) hasn't practiced at all this week.  With all the uncertainty, Alex Collins is the only trustworthy player in this offense.
report: Lamar Jackson (illness) returned to practice Friday.

impact: There was some thought the Ravens would turn to Robert Griffin III with Joe Flacco (hip) out, but Schefter called Jackson the "expected starting QB." The rookie could not have a better matchup for his career debut. The Bengals are banged up on the defensive side of the ball, and they were having trouble stopping opposing quarterbacks even when they were healthy. Jackson carries risk in his first start, but he also has high-end QB1 upside.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Lamar Jackson is expected to start Week 11 against the Bengals.

impact: This had been the expectation all along with Joe Flacco (hip) unable to practice this week. Robert Griffin III is expected to see a handful of reps in two-quarterback formations but for the most part, it will be Jackson running the show on offense. The former Heisman Trophy winner gets an attackable matchup in his first career start playing at home against a team that just fired its defensive coordinator, though he'll obviously carry risk given his experience. Even if Jackson struggles as a passer, his rushing upside puts him in play as a cheap DFS option.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport confirms Lamar Jackson will start Week 11 against the Bengals.

impact: The Ravens' game plan was definitive in this one.  They ran the ball on the first 13 plays of the game and wound up with a whopping 54-to-19 run-to-pass ratio.  Jackson's lone turnover came on a third-quarter broken play where he forced a pass with his feet unsettled, trying to make something happen.  Otherwise, he looked under control and exceptionally dynamic on the ground.  Robert Griffin III barely made an appearance.  If Jackson gets another start -- which is pending Joe Flacco's (hip) health -- he will be an upside QB1 play in Week 12 against the Raiders.
report: Lamar Jackson rushed 27 times for 117 yards and completed 13-of-19 passes for 150 yards and an interception in the Ravens' Week 11 win over the Bengals.

impact: Joe Flacco needs at least another week to recover from his hip injury. Jackson didn't do much throwing in his starting debut last week, but he was brilliant as a ball-carrier, logging 119 yards on 26 carries in a win over Cincinnati. Going against one of the league's worst defenses, Jackson will be an upper-echelon streamer this week.
report: Ravens coach John Harbaugh confirmed Lamar Jackson will start Week 12 against the Raiders.

impact: Jackson has another cupcake matchup with the Raiders after beating an injury-ravaged Bengals defense last week. He hasn't shown much as a passer, but it's going to be hard for the Ravens to turn back to Flacco if Jackson leads them to consecutive wins. Flacco is expected to return to practice next week, so the narrative lines up for Jackson to take over as the starter.
report: CBS Sports' Jason La Canfora reports Lamar Jackson has a "strong shot" to keep the starting job when Joe Flacco (hip) returns.

impact: He was sacked once for a four-yard loss. Jackson rarely looked to run in the first half, accruing just 11 yards on two carries. He adopted a new philosophy after halftime, however, showing off his signature speed with a number of impressive scrambles including a 39-yard burst late in the fourth quarter. L-Jax also added his second career rushing touchdown, cramming it in from five yards out with 8:10 remaining in the third quarter. Jackson looked green at times, struggling to get the play off on numerous occasions while also taking an inexcusable delay of game penalty. Both of his interceptions came on tipped passes. Jackson showed off his arm strength in the second quarter by threading the needle to tight end Mark Andrews for a 74-yard pick-up. With Joe Flacco (hip) expected to resume practicing on Wednesday, it will be interesting to see if the Ravens turn back to their long-time starter or give Lamar another look next week against Atlanta.
report: Lamar Jackson completed 14-of-25 passes for 178 yards and a touchdown with two interceptions while adding an additional 71 yards and a touchdown on 11 carries Sunday in the Ravens’ Week 12 win over the Raiders.

impact: Joe Flacco (hip) has not be cleared to play yet, so the Ravens are planning on letting Jackson make his third NFL start. Garafolo does mention that Flacco could still practice this week, so it's unclear if the Ravens don't think there is enough time for Flacco to get ready or if the Ravens are ready for Jackson to be the future. In Jackson's two starts, the dual-threat quarterback has averaged 164 passing yards and 95 rushing yards with one touchdown per game. Jackson will be in the QB1 conversation against the Falcons.
report: NFL Network's Mike Garafolo says that the Ravens plan to start Lamar Jackson in Week 13 against the Falcons.

impact: Jackson is a low-end QB1 as he makes his first road start in Atlanta.
report: Lamar Jackson is officially the Ravens' Week 13 starter at quarterback.

impact: Jackson was injured running into LT Ronnie Stanley on a failed red zone run. His status for the rest of the game is unclear.
report: Lamar Jackson was forced from Sunday's game against the Falcons with a potential concussion.

impact: Jackson was evaluated for nearly 20 minutes but was cleared to return after a long visit to the locker room. There is one quarter of play to go.
report: Lamar Jackson (concussion) has been cleared to return to Sunday's game against the Falcons.

impact: Jackson fumbled twice, losing one that was returned for a touchdown. Jackson missed nearly 20 minutes of real time in the second half as he was evaluated for a concussion but was finally cleared to return for the fourth quarter. His 13-yard rushing score was a true option where he took a big hit near the goal line but managed to clear the plane. Jackson missed a few easy throws, none easier than what should have been a long touchdown to John Brown early in the second quarter. Jackson had his feet set but just couldn't hit his wideout. With Joe Flacco (hip) likely returning for Week 14, it is unclear what the Ravens plan to do at quarterback. The team has hinted at a college-style timeshare. Harbaugh did say after the game that Jackson has "done enough" to keep the starting job.
report: Lamar Jackson completed 12-of-21 passes for 125 yards in the Ravens' 26-16, Week 13 win over the Falcons, adding 17 carries for 75 yards and a touchdown.

impact: Jackson was checked for a concussion in last week's win over the Falcons but passed the tests and has no ill effects.  Joe Flacco (hip) is "doing more" at Wednesday's practice but isn't a full participant.  The Ravens are 3-0 since Jackson took over under center.  The Chiefs will be a tough test.
report: ESPN Ravens reporter Jamison Hensley expects Lamar Jackson to start Week 14 against the Chiefs.

impact: "It's not a surgical thing," Harbaugh said of Flacco's injury. "It's a calming down type of thing with the hip. I'm not a doctor. I'm not even a TV doctor, so we'll see." Harbaugh seemed to bristle at questions about his quarterback situation, praising the job Lamar Jackson did against the Bengals but making it clear he will stick with Flacco when healthy. The question is, why? Perhaps Jackson can change Harbaugh's mind if he has another successful start against the Raiders.
report: Speaking Monday, Ravens coach John Harbaugh said there was a "chance" Joe Flacco (hip) returned for Week 12.

impact: Lamar Jackson is going to get another start after leading the Ravens to a win last week over the Bengals.  He'll look to make it two in a row against a hapless Raiders team.  Flacco may never get his job back.
report: Joe Flacco (hip) remained sidelined at Wednesday's practice.

impact: All signs continue to point toward No. 32 overall pick Lamar Jackson making another start. Flacco's absence could be formalized as early as Friday.
report: Joe Flacco (hip) remained sidelined on Thursday.

impact: He's not going to play, giving Lamar Jackson another start after his impressive debut as the starter last week.  He gets another cupcake spot against the Raiders coming cross-country for an early start.  Jackson is a QB1.
report: Joe Flacco (hip) remained sidelined at Friday's practice.

impact: Flacco remains week-to-week with a hip injury. Rookie Lamar Jackson will start for the second week in a row. He'll be in play as a QB1 against the Raiders' bottom-rung defense.
report: Joe Flacco (hip) is out for Week 12 against the Raiders.

impact: Flacco is healthy enough to practice after resting his injured hip the last two weeks. He may not be returning to a starting role if Lamar Jackson pulls off what should be another win against the bottoming-out Raiders. Flacco wasn't playing terrible before going down, averaging 274 YPG with a 12:6 TD/INT ratio. There should be clarity on Baltimore's QB situation next week.
report: Joe Flacco (hip) is expected to return to practice next week.

impact: Flacco is expected to resume practicing next week, though it's far from a sure thing that he'll return to a starting role, especially if Lamar Jackson impresses Sunday against Oakland. Alex Collins (foot) is also out for Baltimore, leaving lead ball-carrier duties in the hands of Gus Edwards.
report:
Ravens declared QB Joe Flacco, RB Alex Collins, OT James Hurst, WR Jordan Lasley, DT Zach Sieler, 
OLB Tim Williams and CB Tavon Young inactive for Week 12 against the Raiders.

impact: That apparently includes splitting drives once Joe Flacco (hip) is cleared. "We’ll just do what gives us the best chance and try to use all of our players the best way we can," Harbaugh said. Splitting drives certainly would not achieve that goal. Harbaugh has ramped up his hedging on Flacco's status, suggesting he's prepared to stick with Lamar Jackson even once Flacco gets cleared. Flacco is visiting the doctor on Monday. Harbaugh said the issue is the "protection" of Flacco's hip, and that it must be "strong and stable."
report: Speaking Monday, Ravens coach John Harbaugh said "everything is on the table" with the team's quarterback situation.

impact: This confirms Mike Garafolo's report that the Ravens plan on starting Lamar Jackson in Week 13 since Flacco hasn't been cleared to play yet. Flacco may end up getting in a practice or two this week, but it looks like the earliest he can return is Week 14 against the Chiefs. Coach John Harbaugh said "everything is on the table" when Flacco returns, so there could be a situation where both quarterbacks are used, but it will be harder for the Ravens to take Jackson off the field if he moves to 3-0 this Sunday.
report: The Athletic's Jeff Zrebiec says Joe Flacco (hip) will need a full week of practice before he is able to play.

impact: He's not going to play this week in Atlanta.  Lamar Jackson will be an upside QB1.
report: Joe Flacco (hip) remained sidelined at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Lamar Jackson is still expected to start this week -- Flacco reportedly appeared "limited" during the session -- but this practice does suggest Flacco will be healthy enough to play in Week 14. That would create an interesting situation for coach John Harbaugh, who has refused to discuss what he will do. It will be difficult for Harbaugh to bench Jackson if he leads another win this week in Atlanta.
report: Joe Flacco (hip) returned to a limited practice on Thursday.

impact: Flacco didn't have any setbacks on Friday, but is still considered doubtful to suit up in the Georgia Dome. In his usual Friday conference, coach John Harbaugh suspiciously noted Flacco being "an option" Sunday. Either way, this is rookie Lamar Jackson's job to lose moving forward. Even though the Falcons will have stud MLB Deion Jones back manning the middle of the field, Jackson's rushing floor alone makes him a serviceable QB1 in Week 13.
report: Joe Flacco (hip) is doubtful for Week 13 against the Falcons.

impact: Flacco never had a chance at suiting up, though it appears he may get cleared for Week 14, at which point the Ravens will have to decide what they want to do at quarterback. Also inactive for the Ravens are RT James Hurst, S Tony Jefferson, OLB Tim Williams, WR Jordan Lasley, DL/FB Patrick Ricard and DT Zach Sieler.
report: Joe Flacco (hip) is inactive for Week 13 against the Falcons.

impact: Rapoport conceded it's "hard to imagine" Jackson losing his starting job if he beats Atlanta in Week 13, though he added Flacco could also see snaps against Kansas City. Per Rapsheet, coach John Harbaugh "loves the intrigue" of using both quarterbacks and enjoys how difficult it is for teams to prepare for their opposite skill sets. Jackson is the better fantasy bet due to his rushing expertise, but he'll be difficult to trust if Harbaugh is serious about using both quarterbacks.
report: According to NFL Network's Ian Rapoport, Joe Flacco could share quarterback duties with Lamar Jackson in Week 14 against the Chiefs.

impact: Flacco did more on Wednesday, but he's still not cleared for full practice. It sets up for another week of Lamar Jackson starting, though the Ravens have yet to announce anything. The Ravens haven't ruled out using both Flacco and Jackson against the Chiefs.
report: Joe Flacco (hip) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Ryan also fumbled and absorbed four sacks. It felt like many more, especially on third down. Ryan was holding onto the ball for far too long. His interception was a wild underthrow to Julio Jones. Ryan did find Jones 10 times for 169 yards but beyond that was inexcusably bad. He missed what should have been a 68-yard touchdown to Jones early in the third quarter. Ryan seemed to be operating more than a few ticks slow, and his deep balls routinely fell short. As was his Achilles' heel last season, Ryan was truly awful in the red zone. The Falcons had three separate drives end inside the Eagles' 15-yard line without points. The Falcons could have won the game in the dying seconds, but Ryan kept throwing uncatchable balls into the end zone. He seemed more interested in avoiding another pick than actually making a play. It was simply a brutal night. Things won't get much easier when the Falcons host the Panthers in Week 2.
report: Matt Ryan completed 21-of-42 passes for 251 yards, zero touchdowns and an interception in the Falcons' 18-12, Week 1 loss to the Eagles.

impact: Ryan and the offense got off to a sleepy start, scoring three points in the first quarter and trailing 10-3 at one point, but Atlanta went on to score three unanswered touchdowns.  Ryan sneaked in from one yard away on his first score, and then helicoptered in from eight yards out on his second rushing score.  His two via the pass went to Calvin Ridley and Austin Hooper.  All four scores were of the red-zone variety, a huge improvement from Week 1 when the offense went 0-of-5 in the red area.  Ryan will be a back-end QB1 next week against the Saints.
report: Matt Ryan completed 23-of-28 passes for 272 yards, two touchdowns, and one interception in the Falcons' 31-24, Week 2 win over the Panthers, adding 18 yards and two additional touchdowns on four carries.

impact: He took three sacks for a loss of 15 yards. Halloween isn’t for another month but Ryan was handing out touchdowns like candy on Sunday, dropping dimes all over the gridiron. Three of his touchdowns went to rookie Calvin Ridley, who broke out for 146 yards on seven catches. Matty Ice probably should have had a sixth touchdown but slightly underthrew Julio Jones on what ended up being a 58-yard catch. As dominant as he was, Ryan’s afternoon ended on a low note when Atlanta's last drive stalled out, forcing a punt with 16 seconds left in regulation. That would be the last time Atlanta touched the football as New Orleans walked it off on a Drew Brees touchdown in overtime. Ryan has redeemed himself since his meltdown against the Eagles in Week 1 and is once again safe to pencil in as an every-week QB1. He’ll get the Bengals at home in Week 4.
report: Matt Ryan completed 26-of-35 passes for five touchdowns while adding 12 rushing yards on four carries Sunday in Atlanta’s Week 3 loss to the Saints.

impact: Atlanta ended up losing this game, but Ryan should not shoulder much of the blame. He did miss a few passes which perhaps could have iced things late in the fourth quarter, but he consistently answered a Bengals offense which Atlanta's defense struggled to stop all game. Two of his touchdowns were wide-open throws to Logan Paulsen and Calvin Ridley, but he made a great tight-window throw on Ridley's other score. Ryan now has 793 yards and eight touchdowns in his last two games. He will be a high-end QB1 in a great matchup against the Steelers next week.
report: Matt Ryan completed 29-of-39 passes for 419 yards and three touchdowns in the Falcons' Week 4 loss to the Bengals.

impact: Ryan also lost a fumble that the Steelers returned for a touchdown. Under siege — he took six sacks and was pressured countless other times — Ryan played really poorly in this one, going three full quarters before finally finding Julio Jones for a reception. He was addicted to checking down to Austin Hooper. Ryan was lucky to escape with only one turnover. Ryan has now struggled mightily in each of his road starts while having big days at home. The Falcons host the Bucs in Week 6. That's an obvious smash spot in fantasy.
report: Matt Ryan completed 26-of-38 passes for 285 yards, one touchdown and zero interceptions in the Falcons' 41-17, Week 5 loss to the Steelers.

impact: The X-rays checked out okay, and Ryan is fully expected to start in a prime Week 6 bounce-back spot against Tampa Bay's league-worst pass defense.
report: Matt Ryan underwent X-rays on his foot following Sunday's loss to Pittsurgh.

impact: Ryan came out firing, completing all five of his passes on the opening drive for 74 yards and a touchdown and 11-of-11 for 125 yards in the first quarter, and he did not slow down from there. The offense did have a lull in the third quarter, but Ryan was hitting open receivers all game and answered Tampa's comeback attempt with two scoring drives of his own. Ryan has now thrown for at least 350 yards in three of his last four games. He will be a high-end QB1 next week against the Giants.
