report: Josh Allen completed 18-of-33 passes for 231 yards, two touchdowns, and two interceptions while rushing for 135 yards on nine carries in the Bills' Week 13 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: All four catches came in the first half, including a four-yard touchdown grab with eight seconds remaining in the second quarter. That marked Reed’s first end-zone visit since Week 7 of last year, when he broke out for two touchdowns in a loss to Philadelphia. Reed likely would have done more damage had this been a competitive game, but with Washington running circles around the overmatched Cardinals, there was no reason to air it out in the second half. Finally healthy (knock on wood) after an injury-plagued 2017 campaign, the former Florida Gator is safe to pencil in as a TE1 next week in a mouth-watering matchup against the Colts.
report: Jordan Reed corralled four-of-five targets for 48 yards and a touchdown Sunday in the Redskins’ Week 1 win over the Cardinals.

impact: He went most of the first half without drawing a target, finally getting a look from Alex Smith with six minutes to go in the second quarter. Reed came through with five catches for 51 yards after halftime but also committed a costly fumble in the fourth quarter that essentially handed Indy the game. The 28-year-old has always been a productive player when healthy and that should continue to be the case next week when the Redskins host Green Bay at FedEx Field.
report: Jordan Reed handled six-of-eight targets for 55 yards Sunday in the Redskins’ Week 2 loss to the Colts.

impact: It was a strong statline on an afternoon where Alex Smith completed just 12 passes. Reed's yardage has now gone up each week, though he has not scored since Week 1. He will have a great shot at rectifying that in Week 5 against the Saints. New Orleans' defense has given back all the gains it made in 2017.
report: Jordan Reed caught 4-of-7 targets for 65 yards in the Redskins' Week 3 win over the Packers.

impact: Reed had as many tackles as catches and wasn't even targeted in the first half.  On his lone catch, Reed had to make a really difficult grab on a poorly-aimed pass on the sideline.  Alex Smith was terrible in this one.  Reed will look to rebound as a locked-in TE1 at a shallow position next week against Carolina.
report: Jordan Reed caught 1-of-2 targets for 21 yards in the Redskins' Week 5 loss to the Saints.

impact: The Panthers are a gorgeous matchup for opposing tight ends, but it was Vernon Davis who took advantage for a wide-open touchdown. Reed did lead the team in targets on a quiet day for Alex Smith. Reed is averaging a modest weekly 4/45 through his first five games, but his usage has remained that of a TE1. There should be big games to come.
report: Jordan Reed caught 5-of-9 targets for 36 yards in the Redskins' Week 6 win over the Panthers.

impact: The good news is Reed's 43 yards were a team-high. The bad news is Reed's 43 yards were a team-high. It's easy to say he's a TE1 based on past performance, but that feeling is beginning to waiver with his third consecutive game under 50 yards. He also has yet to eclipse 70 yards in a single outing this season. His usage remains that of a TE1, so owners are still advised to hang tight and hope to weather the storm.
report: Jordan Reed caught 2-of-4 targets for 43 yards in the Redskins' Week 7 win over the Cowboys.

impact: The score was Davis' first of the season. He was left uncovered on a 22-yarder. Davis will pop up for the occasional big play but won't see enough volume for fantasy relevance in the Redskins' Alex Smith-led offense.
report: Vernon Davis caught 3-of-3 targets for 48 yards and a touchdown in the Redskins' Week 6 win over the Panthers.

impact: Odd. Even without Jamison Crowder and Paul Richardson Sunday, Davis didn't even see one target. Jordan Reed tied backup RB Kapri Bibbs with a team-high 43 receiving yards. Davis will undoubtedly pop if Reed misses time, but should remain on waivers until that day comes.
report: Vernon Davis failed to record a single target in Washington's Week 7 win over the Cowboys.

impact: Quinn ankle bent awkwardly on a tackle early in the third quarter. He was carted to the locker room, which is not an encouraging sign. The seventh-round rookie returned two punts for 12 yards prior to exiting. With Quinn done for the day, the Redskins are down to just Jamison Crowder, Josh Doctson and Paul Richardson at receiver.
report: Trey Quinn left Sunday's Week 1 game against the Cardinals with an ankle injury and will not return.

impact: So has fellow WR Cam Sims. Coach Jay Gruden is unsure if Quinn requires surgery. It sounds like the special teamer is headed for a stay on injured reserve.
report: Redskins WR Trey Quinn has been diagnosed with a high-ankle sprain.

impact: Quinn suffered a high-ankle sprain in Week 1. He could return later this year if he avoids surgery. The Redskins promoted Jehu Chesson from the practice squad to replace Quinn.
report: Redskins placed WR Trey Quinn (ankle) on injured reserve.

impact: Floyd spent training camp and preseason with the Saints but was an easy cut for them after catching one ball in exhibitions.  Now 28, the former first-rounder is running out of chances in the NFL and is unlikely to be a difference-maker in D.C.  He's not a great fit with Alex Smith at quarterback.
report: Redskins signed WR Michael Floyd.

impact: Walker appeared to dislocate his ankle, or at very least break his leg.  Being the warrior he is, Walker waved to fans as he made his way to the locker room on the cart.  Walker finished the game with four catches for 52 yards.  We don't expect to see him back on the field anytime soon.
report: Delanie Walker was carted off the field with a gruesome ankle/leg injury in the fourth quarter of Sunday's Week 1 game in Miami.

impact: As expected.  Walker had his ankle rolled up underneath a defender, bending it unnaturally, requiring an immediate air cast.  Walker is a warrior but simply can't play through this one.  Walker is signed through 2020 and will be 35 the next time he steps on the field.  Jonnu Smith figures to take over at tight end for the Titans, but Corey Davis is going to gobble up pass-game targets.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports Delanie Walker has been diagnosed with a dislocated ankle along with a fracture and is "almost certainly" done for the season.

impact: The Titans have since made it official. Walker will undergo surgery. Essentially, Walker wrecked his ankle. There's a lot of bad stuff going on in there. It's a brutal blow for the Titans, who must adapt to the loss of their No. 1 passing game weapon as they try to sort out the depth chart in their receiver corps. Promising second-year pro Jonnu Smith will step into Walker's void at tight end, offering immediate TE2 streamer appeal with the upside for more. Walker will be 35 when he's next on the field.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter confirms Delanie Walker is dealing with ligament damage in addition to a dislocated ankle and will miss the remainder of the season.

impact: Smith was already a starter, but with Delanie Walker on IR, he's going to see a larger rest of season target share. A 92nd-percentile SPARQ, there's breakout upside for Smith on an offense built around high-percentage throws. Smith is stepping into a role that produced 74 catches in 2017. He has a streamable Week 2 matchup with a Texans defense that's coming off 123 yards and a touchdown to Rob Gronkowski.
report: ESPN's Turron Davenport expects TE Jonnu Smith to see "plenty of opportunities" in Sunday's game with the Texans.

impact: Smith was reportedly expected to see "plenty of opportunities" without Delanie Walker. In his first post-Walker outing, he was out-targeted 2-0 by Luke Stocker. The Titans won't always have to start their backup quarterback and third-string tackle, so all hope isn't lost for Smith just yet. The 92nd-percentile SPARQ monstrosity will have another week to prove he can produce on a full-time basis.
report: Jonnu Smith didn't receive a target in the Titans' Week 2 win over the Texans.

impact: Smith is a promising talent in theory, but the dysfunctional nature of the passing game in which he plays strips Smith of any streamer appeal in re-draft leagues.
report: Jonnu Smith caught 1-of-2 targets for nine yards in the Titans' Week 3 win over the Jaguars.

impact: Smith continues to play the majority of snaps, but he now has just two catches on seven targets this season. One of his missed connections in this game was a bad drop on third down. He is not an option in redraft leagues.
report: Jonnu Smith did not haul in either of his targets in the Titans' Week 4 win over the Eagles.

impact: Smith has been targeted five times by Marcus Mariota this year, catching none.
report: Titans TE Jonnu Smith was held catch-less on two targets in Week 5.

impact: Smith was tackled just short of the end-zone on one of his catches. He had only three targets, but he's been more involved the last few weeks. The Titans are on a bye in Week 8.
report: Jonnu Smith caught two passes for 11 yards in Week 7 against the Chargers.

impact: Not only did Brate put up a goose egg, but he was also out-snapped 43-24 by teammate and fellow tight O.J. Howard. Dating back to last season, the Harvard alum has totaled an embarrassing 186 yards over his last 10 games. Even at a thin fantasy position, the 27-year-old doesn’t carry much weight.
report: Cameron Brate failed to catch either of his two targets Sunday in the Buccaneers’ Week 1 victory over the Saints.

impact: Catch-less through two weeks, Brate lacks fantasy value behind O.J. Howard.
report: Cameron Brate was held catch-less in Week 2 against the Eagles.

impact: O.J. Howard saw eight targets and surpassed 50-yards receiving for the third consecutive game, but it was inevitably Brate who was utilized in the red zone and found pay dirt. Brate was still held catchless in the Bucs' first two games and can't be trusted over Howard (or another streamer) unless an injury to his aforementioned teammate occurs.
report: Cameron Brate caught 3-of-4 targets for 34 yards and one touchdown in the Bucs' Week 3 loss to the Steelers.

impact: Brate has either been Jekyll or Hyde through the Bucs' first four games, being held catchless in Tampa's first two contests only to cross pay dirt in the next two. O.J. Howard (knee) did get knocked out in the second quarter Sunday and wasn't able to return. Brate has historically performed much better with Jameis Winston under center, and he'll arguably be a TE1 against the Falcons' ailing secondary if Howard remains out after the bye.
report: Cameron Brate caught 3-of-4 targets for 29 yards and one touchdown in the Bucs' Week 4 loss to the Bears.

impact: Even with Howard back, Brate did his fantasy backers proud by catching a touchdown on the opening drive. Jameis Winston showed a lot of trust in his tight end on the throw, and Brate made it count by going up over De’Vondre Campbell for the score. Brate now has a touchdown in three straight games. Unfortunately for his value moving forward, that was his only target as O.J. Howard went for 62 yards. He will be just a TE2 next week against the Browns.
report: Cameron Brate hauled in his only target for a 15-yard touchdown in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Brate lost a fumble on one of his three catches that the Bucs were fortunate to not have come back to haunt them. Brate has just 15 targets on the season and only has true fantasy value if something were to happen to O.J. Howard.
report: Cameron Brate caught 3-of-4 targets for 23 yards in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: James suffered a back injury in the third preseason game, but he is good to go for the season opener. With Vance McDonald (foot) out, James should be the primary option at tight end against the Browns.
report: Steelers TE Jesse James (back) is not listed on the Week 1 injury report.

impact: James drew the start and opportunity with Vance McDonald still sidelined with a foot injury. He will only be a fringe TE2 option in Week 2 against the Chiefs if McDonald remains inactive.
report: Steelers TE Jesse James caught 3-of-5 targets for 60 yards in Sunday's Week 1 game versus the Browns.

impact: James also drew a defensive holding penalty in the end zone. The 100-yard game was the first of James' career, and came in spite of Vance McDonald making his 2018 debut. James was left completely uncovered multiple times by a Chiefs defense preoccupied with stopping Antonio Brown and JuJu Smith-Schuster. Today won't be the last time that happens, but especially with McDonald now involved, James' big days are going to be too difficult to see coming to consider him an appealing TE2 streamer.
report: Jesse James caught 5-of-5 targets for 138 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 2 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: Roles were reversed in Week 3 as it was Vance McDonald (4-112-1) who shined in the Steelers' passing game. James had benefitted as Pittsburgh's sole pass-catching tight end to start the year, but he'll likely fall back to the end of the line with McDonald now healthy. James can be dropped in every format.
report: Jesse James caught his only target for seven yards in the Steelers' Week 3 win over the Buccaneers.

impact: He was essentially invisible on Sunday as the third-year wideout was out-targeted by teammates Chris Thompson, Paul Richardson, Jordan Reed and Jamison Crowder. Doctson definitely has rebound potential next week against a sluggish Indy secondary, but at this point, it’s hard to trust the former first-round pick as anything more than a last-ditch WR4/5.
report: Josh Doctson totaled just one catch for 11 yards on three targets Sunday in Washington’s Week 1 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Doctson committed a head-scratching drop in the first quarter but redeemed himself somewhat by beating Pierre Desir for a 14-yard grab down the sideline later in the afternoon. He almost came down with a touchdown about midway through the third quarter, but couldn’t quite pull it in. Doctson’s Week 2 wasn’t anything to write home about, though at least he saw seven targets, good for third-most on the team behind only Chris Thompson (13) and Jordan Reed (eight). The 2016 first-rounder gets the Packers at home in Week 3.
report: Josh Doctson nabbed four-of-seven targets for 37 yards Sunday in the Redskins’ Week 2 loss to Indianapolis.

impact: Doctson's only production came on two first quarter DPIs totaling 15 yards. Doctson has been an every-down player this season but predictably has zero chemistry with Alex Smith. He's caught five balls for 48 yards in three games. You can safely cut bait in re-draft leagues if you haven't already.
report: Josh Doctson was held without a catch on three targets in the Redskins' Week 3 win over the Packers.

impact: Doctson got stepped on in Wednesday's session. It's not a good development for a player with a history of Achilles' issues. Doctson has made zero fantasy impact with Alex Smith as his quarterback, but he has been close to an every-down player thus far.
report: Josh Doctson (heel) missed Thursday's practice.

impact: Doctson has an extra day with the Redskins playing on Monday night in New Orleans, but he's looking doubtful for that one at the moment.  Michael Floyd could be elevated, but neither player is a fantasy option.
report: Josh Doctson (heel) remained sidelined at Friday's practice.

impact: It suggests Doctson is unlikely to be active this week, though walking boots can be precautionary. The Redskins play on Monday night, so Doctson has an extra day to get ready. We'll know his official status Saturday.
report: Josh Doctson (heel) was in a walking boot on Friday.

impact: Doctson was in a walking boot Friday. He's on the wrong side of questionable, with most beat reporters not expecting him to play. Maurice Harris will start if Doctson sits.
report: Josh Doctson (heel) is questionable for Week 5 against the Saints.

impact: Doctson was in a walking boot all week, so this isn't a surprise even though Doctson was listed questionable.  The Redskins will start Maurice Harris in Doctson's place opposite Paul Richardson, with Jamison Crowder continuing to work in the slot.  Harris won't be a fantasy factor.  Also out for the Redskins are S Troy Apke, RB Samaje Perine, CB Adonis Alexander, DL Geron Christian, LG Shawn Lauvao, and DL Caleb Brantley.  LT Trent Williams (knee) is active.
report: Josh Doctson (heel) is inactive for Week 5 against the Saints on Monday night.

impact: Doctson saw out Monday night's loss to the Saints, but he could return this week following a limited week of practices. Even if he does, he is not a fantasy factor right now.
report: Josh Doctson (heel) is questionable for Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: Doctson's return comes with Jamison Crowder (ankle) sitting. Doctson, Paul Richardson and Maurice Harris will be the Redskins' three-receiver set against the Panthers. Doctson has predictably shown zero chemistry with Alex Smith and is not an appealing WR4.
report: Josh Doctson (heel) is active for Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: Doctson was playing through a questionable tag for a heel injury. The first-round bust has 68 yards this season.
report: Josh Doctson caught 3-of-6 targets for 20 yards in the Redskins' Week 6 win over the Panthers.

impact: His 42 yards were a season-high, but it doesn't make him any more fantasy relevant than he was prior to kick-off. Doctson is a candidate to fade away completely once Jamison Crowder and Paul Richardson return.
report: Josh Doctson hauled in 3-of-6 targets for 42 yards in Washington's Week 7 victory over the Cowboys.

impact: He's either being called "doubtful" because the injury is severe enough, or the Redskins are just not going to put him back in with them getting their faces smashed in 43-13 at the start of the fourth quarter.  Before leaving, Richardson caught 4-of-5 targets for 50 yards, making one of the best plays of the night for Washington.  Injuries have been an issue for Richardson this year.
report: Paul Richardson exited Monday night's Week 5 blowout loss to the Saints with a right knee injury and is doubtful to return.

impact: Richardson tweaked his knee during Monday night's loss to New Orleans. It's too early to speculate on his status for Week 6, though in order to play, he'll likely need to get in a limited session by Friday. Regardless, the 26-year-old is just a bench stash, even in deeper redraft leagues.
report: Paul Richardson (knee) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: Richardson is now looking doubtful after he was spotted with ice on his knee in Monday's blowout loss to the Saints. Friday will tell the tale.
report: Paul Richardson (knee, shoulder) remained sidelined on Thursday.

impact: The Skins are dealing with a plethora of injuries as Richardson, Jamison Crowder (ankle), Chris Thompson (rib), Adrian Peterson (shoulder, ankle, knee), and Josh Doctson (heel) are all officially questionable Sunday. Backup WR Maurice Harris is in line for another full-time outing if any of Washington's wideouts are ruled inactive.
report: Paul Richardson (knee, shoulder) is questionable for Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: The Redskins are a hot mess heading into Week 6 with injuries to most of their top contributors on offense. That includes Richardson, who is feeling the effects of knee and shoulder injuries. If P-Rich sits against Carolina, it will open up snaps for Brian Quick, who would work in three-wide sets alongside Josh Doctson and Maurice Harris. Carolina should be among the highest-owned defenses on DFS sites this week.
report: According to NFL Network's Ian Rapoport, Paul Richardson (questionable, knee/shoulder) will be a game-time decision Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: Richardson doesn't seem particularly close to 100 percent but will be heavily needed with Jamison Crowder (ankle) on the shelf. Even with Crowder and Chris Thompson sidelined, Richardson is not an attractive WR4 against the Panthers.
report: Paul Richardson (knee, shoulder) is active for Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: Richardson added a two-yard rush. Richardson's score came as he got loose at the back of the end zone as Alex Smith scrambled around for time. The high-dollar free agent addition has 13 catches for 212 yards through five games as a Redskin. That's not going to cut it in fantasy leagues.
report: Paul Richardson caught 3-of-5 targets for 31 yards and a touchdown in the Redskins' Week 6 win over the Panthers.

impact: Neither is Jamison Crowder (ankle), but it was already known he'd be sidelined until at least Friday.  Richardson has battled numerous injuries through his first five games with the Skins, but he should be okay for Week 7.
report: Paul Richardson (knee) is not practicing Wednesday.

impact: This is actually the routine Richardson followed last week before suiting up against the Panthers. As of Thursday, we have not seen evidence that his status is in doubt against the Cowboys.
report: Paul Richardson (knee, shoulder) remained sidelined on Thursday.

impact: If there's good news, it's that an MRI was not required. "We’re trying to get to the bottom of it," coach Jay Gruden said. "We’re being extra cautious right now." Richardson's Week 7 availability appears genuinely up in the air. The Redskins promoted WR Jehu Chesson from the practice squad on Thursday.
report: Paul Richardson had his ailing knee re-examined on Thursday.

impact: Richardson went to the doctor to have his knee re-evauated on Thursday and it doesn't sound like he got good news. With Jamison Crowder (ankle) already ruled out and P-Rich likely to follow suit, look for the Redskins to roll with Josh Doctson, Maurice Harris and Brian Quick in three-wide sets against Dallas.
report: Paul Richardson (knee, shoulder) is doubtful for Week 7 against the Cowboys.

impact: The Redskins will be extremely thin at wideout Sunday and will be forced to start Josh Doctson, Maurice Harris, and Michael Floyd in three-wide sets. Brian Quick will mix in as depth. Without Thompson available, third-down back Kapri Bibbs will play behind Adrian Peterson (who initially came into Sunday questionable, too). Expect more multiple tight end sets from Washington's offense.
report: Redskins declare WR Paul Richardson, CB Quinton Dunbar, WR Jamison Crowder, RB Chris Thompson, S Troy Apke, OL Geron Christian and C Casey Dunn inactive for Week 7 against the Cowboys.

impact: After missing the entire practice week and being inactive against Dallas, this is a step in the right direction for Richardson.  Signs are positive he'll be able to return against the Giants.  Jamison Crowder (ankle) remains sidelined.
report: Paul Richardson (knee, shoulder) was limited in Wednesday's practice.

impact: Richardson sat out last week's game with knee and shoulder injuries but has practiced on a limited basis this week and looks on track to play Sunday against New York. P-Rich hasn't made much noise this year, delivering just 16 catches for 212 yards and two touchdowns over five appearances. Even with several teams on bye, Richardson won't be of much use to fantasy owners this week.
report: Redskins coach Jay Gruden said the team is "hopeful" Paul Richardson (knee, shoulder) will return for Week 8 against the Giants.

impact: Richardson has been a limited participant since initially returning from injury in Week 5, but has still mustered 7/81/1 in the Skins' hapless passing offense over the last two games. He's fully expected to play alongside Josh Docton and Maurice Harris. Jordan Reed remains the likeliest candidate to break out of his rut with Jamison Crowder (out, ankle) missing his third consecutive game.
report: Paul Richardson (knee) is questionable for Week 8 against the Giants.

impact: It appears the UDFA out of Alabama needs surgery to repair a severe high-ankle sprain. Sims was working on special teams.
report: Redskins placed WR Cam Sims on injured reserve with an ankle injury.

impact: The good news is Davis drew by far a team-high 13 targets.  The bad news is he didn't do much with them, lost Marcus Mariota to a shoulder/elbow injury, and couldn't beat Minkah Fitzpatrick on a touchdown opportunity inside the five-yard line in the first half.  Davis' going-forward outlook will very much depend on Mariota's health.  He'll be far less appealing if Gabbert is forced to start.
report: Corey Davis caught 6-of-13 targets for 62 yards in the Titans' Week 1 loss to Miami.

impact: It's a concern with his history of hamstring issues. Davis should play Sunday, but he may not get in a full practice this week in an effort to avoid setbacks.
report: Corey Davis (hamstring) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Davis was limited during Wednesday's practice, a concern given his history with hamstring injuries. The receiver is not concerned, however, and should be ready to face the Texans on Sunday. Coming off a 13-target opener, Davis will be a back-end WR2.
report: Corey Davis said his hamstring is "fine."

impact: Despite not seeing his usual practice reps, the second-year wideout insists his hamstring is "fine." We'll take him at his word and assume he'll be ready for Week 2 against Houston. Davis led the Titans with 13 targets in last week's opener. He will be needed even more going forward with Delanie Walker out for the season.
report: Corey Davis (hamstring) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Davis insisted his hamstring was "fine" throughout the week and he responded with full participation in practice on Friday. He's no longer listed on Tennessee's injury report. Davis commanded 13 targets in last week's opener but will have to make due with both Marcus Mariota (questionable, elbow) and Blaine Gabbert sharing reps at quarterback.
report: Corey Davis (hamstring) was removed from the Titans' injury report and will play in Week 2 against the Texans.

impact: Davis led Tennessee in targets for the second consecutive week, already putting him at the 20-target mark for the year. Though they weren't efficient targets, Davis used his athleticism to catch-and-run for additional yards throughout the day. His ceiling is much lower with Blaine Gabbert under center, but as long as Davis remains the focal point of Tennessee's passing offense, he'll stay a low-end WR2 for the rest of the year.
report: Corey Davis caught 5-of-7 targets for 55 yards in the Titans' Week 2 win over the Texans.

impact: Tennessee's passing game was nonexistent, managing 108 yards from Marcus Mariota and Blaine Gabbert combined.  Davis' 34 receiving yards actually led the team.  Davis gets a good Week 4 matchup against a beatable Eagles cornerback unit, but the state of this offense always renders him a high-risk WR3/flex option.
report: Corey Davis caught 2-of-4 targets for 34 yards in the Titans' Week 3 win over the Jaguars.

impact: Consistently getting targets, Davis always seemed likely to break out once Marcus Mariota returned to full health, and that is exactly what happened against the Eagles. He had already set a new season-high in yardage by midway through the second quarter, and that was with Mariota missing him for what would have been a long gain. Mariota found him for that long play in the fourth quarter, but that was not the end of the action. Following an Eagles field goal, the Titans needed a touchdown to win, and Davis delivered with a leaping grab with just five seconds left. With Mariota looking healthy, Davis will be a top-24 option next week against the Bills.
report: Corey Davis hauled in 9-of-15 targets for 161 yards and a touchdown in the Titans' Week 4 win over the Eagles.

impact: The Titans got Davis matched up with other defenders at times, but he mostly squared off with Bills top CB Tre'Davious White, who handily won their one-on-one draws.  As Tennessee's passing game has gone, Davis' box-score production has gone.  He gets an even tougher Week 6 matchup against Baltimore's shutdown pass defense.
report: Corey Davis caught 4-of-6 targets for 49 yards in the Titans' Week 5 loss to the Bills.

impact: Davis fell victim to the Titans' miserable pass protection, hauling in just one catch from Marcus Mariota, who was on his back 11 times throughout the afternoon. The only positive to come from this is that four of Mariota's 15 attempts were directed at Davis. As the Titans' O goes, Davis goes, and both went nowhere in a hurry Sunday. He'll remain a low-end WR2 in Week 7 against the Chargers' secondary.
report: Corey Davis vacuumed just one of his four targets for 24 yards in the Titans' Week 6 romping to the Ravens.

impact: It's another rough game from Davis, who was led to 24 yards last week. Davis was out-targeted by Tajae Sharpe and had couldn't come down with an end-zone look in the fourth quarter. He hasn't been on the same page with Marcus Mariota over the last few weeks. Davis will be a WR3 when the Titans come out of their bye in Week 9.
report: Corey Davis caught 3-of-7 passes for 10 yards in Week 7 against the Chargers.

impact: He saw a target in the first quarter, then wasn't heard from again.  Until this offense shows any signs of functional ability, Taywan will be waiver-wire material in fantasy leagues.  He played behind Tajae Sharpe in the opener.
report: Taywan Taylor went catch-less in Week 1 against the Dolphins.

impact: Pour some out for Josh Norris. Taylor played 27 fewer snaps than Rishard Matthews, who sat out all of camp, and 49 fewer than Tajae Sharpe. Taylor could bring some much-needed explosiveness to Tennessee's offense, but it does not look like that is in the plans at this point. He is not a must-hold in redraft leagues.
report: Taywan Taylor played 9-of-69 (13 percent) snaps Week 1 against the Dolphins.

impact: Taylor only saw four targets but made the most of one in particular when he shook off several tackles and ran 18 yards for Tennessee's only offensive score of the day. The team's only other touchdown came on a 66-yard direct-snap pass on fourth down from special teamers Dan Cruikshank and Kevin Byard. Taylor still isn't involved enough to consider him a weekly WR3, but his potential was certainly flashed Sunday. He's worth stashing in deeper leagues.
report: Taywan Taylor caught 3-of-4 targets for 32 yards and one touchdown in the Titans' Week 2 victory over the Texans.

impact: Taylor led the Titans in targets, but no one in this pass-catcher corps was ever going to produce on a day where Marcus Mariota and Blaine Gabbert combined for 108 passing yards.  Despite his big-play ability, Taylor has not yet put enough production or usage in the box score for Week 4 fantasy consideration against Philadelphia.
report: Taywan Taylor caught 4-of-5 targets for 30 yards in the Titans' Week 3 win over the Jaguars.

impact: This seems like good news for Taywan Taylor, who is in line for an increase in play time after Matthews (50 percent of snaps) was released. Taylor ranks third on the team in targets (10) and receptions (7) despite playing only 34 percent of snaps this season. Taylor went from nine to 24 to 32 snaps in each of the first three weeks and should see another bump Sunday against the Eagles.
report: Titans GM Jon Robinson said he is not looking to immediately add a receiver following the release of Rishard Matthews.

impact: This is the usage fantasy players were hoping for in the first game without Rishard Matthews. Working as the clear No. 2, Taylor was consistently involved all game, and he made perhaps the most important play of the day when he converted a fourth-and-long in overtime with a 19-yard catch along the sideline. Talented as they come and the No. 2 option in an ascending passing game, Taylor should be rostered in all formats.
report: Taywan Taylor hauled in 7-of-9 targets for 77 yards in the Titans' Week 4 win over the Eagles.

impact: Taylor flashed his big-play potential on a gain of 19, but he also cost the Titans with a first-quarter fumble that Buffalo turned into a Josh Allen rushing TD.  And that proved to be more than the difference in the game as Tennessee fell 13-12.  Taylor will be a WR5 in Week 6 against Baltimore's shutdown secondary.
report: Taywan Taylor caught 3-of-5 targets for 30 yards in the Titans' Week 5 loss to the Bills.

impact: It was a step back for Taylor, who was in on 63 percent of the snaps in Week 4. Taylor also played eight fewer snaps than Tajae Sharpe. Taylor remains an upside stash in deeper formats, but he will not be a reliable fantasy option unless his usage stabilizes, especially with the Titans still struggling on offense.
report: Taywan Taylor played 25-of-54 snaps (46 percent) Week 5 against the Bills.

impact: Taylor's involvement has only gone downhill since it (coincidently) peaked a few short weeks ago, now seeing him account for just the fourth-most receiving yards on Tennessee. Despite his obvious athletic edge and explosiveness over incumbent No. 2 Tajae Sharpe, the latter was still heavily used and led the Titans in receiving (33 yards). Taylor is unfortunately only worth a stash in deeper leagues at this point.
report: Taywan Taylor hauled in his only target for a measly 13 yards in the Titans' abysmal Week 6 loss to the Ravens.

impact: Taylor had a bad drop on what would have been a 20-plus yard catch. He's been a non-factor over the last couple weeks and is behind Tajae Sharpe for targets. Taylor is just a dynasty stash.
report: Taywan Taylor one pass for eight yards in Week 7 against the Chargers.

impact: Maybe it's all part of a Week 1 plan to manage McDonald's practice reps, but players who downgrade to "DNP" after getting in a limited session the previous day usually sit out. Were that to happen, Jesse James would get the start and serve as a TE2 streamer against the Browns.
report: Vance McDonald (foot) was downgraded to "DNP" in Thursday's practice.

impact: We assumed this would be the case when McDonald was downgraded to DNP at Thursday's practice after getting in a limited session on Wednesday. McDonald has shown potential when healthy including last year when he erupted for 116 yards in Pittsburgh's playoff loss to Jacksonville but he's had an extremely difficult time staying on the field. Jesse James will fill in at tight end but doesn't belong on the streaming radar for Week 1.
report: Vance McDonald (foot) is out for Week 1 against the Browns.

impact: As expected McDonald is out to open the season. He only got in a limited practice this week after missing nearly the entirety of the preseason. Jesse James will draw the start in place of McDonald and caught 6-of-8 targets for 41 yards and two touchdowns in this Week 1 matchup a year ago but is only an option in deep formats. McDonald will look to return Week 2 at home against the Chiefs.
report: Steelers declared TE Vance McDonald, QB Mason Rudolph, CB Coty Sensabaugh, S Marcus Allen, OT Matt Feiler, OT Zach Banner and DE L.T. Walton inactive for Sunday’s Week 1 game versus the Browns.

impact: It's a good sign for McDonald's Week 2 availability ahead of Pittsburgh's projected shootout versus Kansas City.  McDonald missed almost all of camp in addition to Week 1, so his playing time will remain uncertain.  Jesse James was the Steelers' full-time Week 1 tight end, catching three balls for 60 yards.
report: Vance McDonald (foot) returned to a full practice on Wednesday.

impact: McDonald has been a full participant at practice all week, suggesting he should be fine for Sunday's home opener. He gets an enticing matchup against a Chiefs secondary missing star safety Eric Berry, though McDonald is best treated as a mid-range TE2 for fantasy purposes.
report: Vance McDonald (foot) is questionable for Week 2 against the Chiefs.

impact: It appears McDonald will make his season debut Sunday against Kansas City after sitting out the opener with a nagging foot injury. Jesse James filled in for him last week, logging three catches for 60 yards in a tie with Cleveland. Going against a vulnerable Chiefs secondary, McDonald should have a chance to return TE2 value this week.
report: Vance McDonald (questionable, foot) is expected to play Week 2 against the Chiefs.

impact: McDonald's biggest impact came when he was called for an illegal block in the back penalty. He got soundly out-produced by Jesse James, though both players drew five targets. Per Pro Football Focus, James out-snapped McDonald just 45-37. For now, James and McDonald are going to cancel each other out as TE2s in fantasy.
report: Vance McDonald caught 3-of-5 targets for 26 yards in the Steelers' Week 2 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: McDonald ran more routes than teammate Jesse James in Week 2, but it was the latter who still finished with better receiving numbers (5-138-1). That wasn't the case Monday night as Ben Roethlisberger hit McDonald in-stride during the team's third possession and watched him bulldoze (literally) his way through Bucs S Chris Conte and scamper down the sideline for a 75-yard score. Although James is technically considered Pittsburgh's blocking tight end, McDonald quietly graded better than James in run-blocking (per PFF) just last year. McDonald was talked about highly throughout offseason activities and training camp and, barring health, could easily emerge as an every-down tight end.
report: Vance McDonald caught 4-of-5 targets for 112 yards and one touchdown in the Steelers' Week 3 victory over the Buccaneers.

impact: McDonald carried over his strong Week 3, tying Antonio Brown for the team lead in receiving. He lost a fumble on the Steelers' first drive but rebounded with a couple of nice catches over the middle. McDonald's physical play has been a trigger point for the Steelers offense. He's a back-end TE1 for a matchup with the Falcons in Week 5.
report: Vance McDonald caught five passes for 62 yards in Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: McDonald got out-produced by Jesse James as Ben Roethlisberger focused on getting Antonio Brown going. McDonald has had some monster games but has also yet to draw more than five targets in a contest. He will be a volatile TE1 in a down year for the position.
report: Vance McDonald caught 1-of-2 targets for six yards in the Steelers' Week 5 win over the Falcons.

impact: McDonald did almost all of his damage in the first half, catching five balls for 67 yards.  Jesse James then got most of the looks in the second half, catching five balls for 26 yards.  McDonald has big games here and there and is long on talent.  He'll be a TE1 Week 8 against the Browns after the bye.
report: Vance McDonald caught 7-of-8 targets for 68 yards in the Steelers' Week 6 win over the Bengals.

impact: Bryant's suspension, which has been among the worst-kept secrets in football this offseason, could be announced as soon as this week. This is the 26-year-old's third ban under the league's substance abuse policy. Let go by the Raiders following a dismal training camp, Bryant's career is hanging by a thread. At this point, the odds of Bryant playing another NFL down are less than 50 percent.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports free agent WR Martavis Bryant is facing a year-long suspension for violating the league's substance abuse policy.

impact: Adam Schefter reported Bryant is facing a possible year-long suspension for violating the league's substance abuse policy, but he could still play until the actual suspension is handed down. It's still an odd occurrence, even for coach Jon Gruden and the 2018 Raiders. Released by Oakland following a dismal training camp just 10 days ago, Bryant's career was thought to be hanging by a thread. We give up on trying to figure out Gruden's blueprint for building a team.
report: Free agent WR Martavis Bryant is talking with the Raiders about a possible return.

impact: Tom Pelissero was first to report the Raiders closing in on a new deal for Bryant. It's an unexpected chain of events as Bryant is still facing a possible year-long suspension for violating the league's substance abuse policy. Derek Carr did complete only five passes to receivers (out of 42 drop backs) in the Raiders' Week 1 loss to the Rams, so it's possible coach Jon Gruden wanted to add speed to the field by any means necessary. Bryant, who was cut by the Raiders only 10 days go, is expected to suit up and play Sunday.
report: Raiders re-signed Martavis Bryant to a one-year contract.

impact: "I think he’s healthy. I think he’s ready to go," the coach continued. "I’ve said it before: when he’s right, he can be a difference maker and we’re hoping he can be one sooner rather than later." A suspension looms, but it sounds like the Raiders will play Bryant until the NFL tells them otherwise. He cannot be trusted in fantasy lineups right now, but he is not a bad speculative add.
report: Raiders coach Jon Gruden said Martavis Bryant is "in a good place right now."

impact: "I don’t know nothing about none of that," Bryant said. It's hardly a denial that something is/was brewing. Fantasy owners should consider Bryant a week-to-week proposition until clarity is gained. He's not worth a Week 2 speculative start against the Broncos' strong secondary.
report: Speaking Thursday, Martavis Bryant declined comment on reports that he is facing another suspension.

impact: There had been confusion about whether Bryant was actually facing another suspension, but the circumstantial evidence was long overwhelming. Per Schefter, Bryant is "confident that he has a chance to win the appeal." It will be heard in the "next couple of weeks." The desperate Raiders are going to trot Bryant out there when/until his ban is upheld. A player with Bryant's history has little shot of getting the benefit of the doubt.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Martavis Bryant has indeed been given another year-long suspension, but that the NFL is allowing him to play while it is on appeal.

impact: Bryant was mostly invisible except for a fourth quarter end zone target that resulted in Derek Carr's second interception of the day. Bryant was completely blanketed by Xavien Howard. It was an ill-advised throw. Despite his well-known upside, Bryant has given zero indication through two games he will be usable in fantasy leagues as a Raider.
report: Martavis Bryant caught 2-of-5 targets for 30 yards in the Raiders' Week 3 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: Bryant dropped two passes -- including one that would have gone for a touchdown bomb after he got clean behind Cleveland's secondary -- but did contribute positively with a downfield run block on Marshawn Lynch's 59-yard dash.  Oakland's situational deep threat and third receiver behind Amari Cooper and Jordy Nelson, Bryant will be a low-floor WR4/flex option in Week 5 against the Chargers.
report: Martavis Bryant caught 3-of-7 targets for 51 yards in the Raiders' Week 4 win over the Browns.

impact: In just his fourth game with the team, Bryant led the Raiders with 91 receiving yards. A majority of his production admittedly came in the fourth quarter with his team trailing late. Bryant has stayed involved as an over-the-top burner, though, averaging an outstanding 16.8 yards per catch. If involved more down the road, you don't have to squint to spot a legitimate path in which he overtakes Cooper as the team's No. 1 receiver. He's on a FLEX-deemable pace of 45-757 this season.
report: Martavis Bryant hauled in all three of his targets for a team-high 91 yards in the Raiders' Week 5 loss to the Chargers.

impact: The team is "cautiously hopeful" Bryant can play in London on Sunday. If he's unable to suit up, Seth Roberts and veteran Brandon LaFell would start on the outside along with Amari Cooper and Jordy Nelson. Cooper's stock would be slightly increased without Bryant in the lineup, though the former would still be a boom-bust WR3/FLEX.
report: Martavis Bryant (flu) is questionable for Week 6 against the Seahawks.

impact: Bryant has struggled with drops and turnovers this season, and he failed to capitalize on Seth Roberts (concussion) and Amari Cooper's (concussion) early Week 6 exits.  A situational deep threat on a team whose quarterback doesn't enjoy pulling the trigger to go deep, Bryant is all but worthless in fantasy leagues.
report: Martavis Bryant caught 2-of-3 targets for 18 yards in the Raiders' Week 6 loss to Seattle.

impact: "I think it helps a player like Martavis Bryant," Olson said, "because he’s got tremendous skills, tremendous size and speed, and he’s still really kind of learning the system."  Bryant will step in as the starter opposite Jordy Nelson moving forward, with Seth Roberts working the slot.  The Raiders also have Brandon LaFell and practice-squad call-up Marcell Ateman.  Bryant figures to act as the lid-lifting deep threat.  He needs to be added anywhere he's available.
report: Raiders OC Greg Olson talked up Martavis Bryant in the aftermath of the Amari Cooper trade.

impact: Brown had a lackluster start, catching just two passes for 14 yards in the first half against a very strong performance versus rookie Denzel Ward. In the second half, Brown got going, catching a 22-yard touchdown strike in blanket coverage from Ward that out the Steelers up 21-7 in the 3rd quarter. Brown remains the premier fantasy wideout and will be the consensus WR1 next week at home versus the Chiefs.
report: Steelers WR Antonio Brown caught 9-of-16 targets for 93 yards and touchdown in Sunday's Week 1 game versus the Browns.

impact: Although he was never officially announced with an injury, Brown spent most of the second half gutting through a right calf issue. It was his calf that bothered him late last season. Brown was slowed in the summer by a quad ailment. Brown was spotted bickering with coaches multiple times on the sideline. It was a frustrating day despite the monster usage. JuJu Smith-Schuster and the Steelers' tight ends were getting the end zone looks. Brown gets the Bucs' burnable secondary in Week 3.
report: Antonio Brown caught 9-of-17 targets for 67 yards in the Steelers' Week 2 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: The tweet came from someone who previously handled public relations for the Steelers, so Brown is not responding to anyone with any power. Still, his emphatic response is at least notable after he was seen bickering with the coaching staff multiple times during the Week 2 loss to the Chiefs. Pittsburgh is certainly not going to trade Brown, but it seems like the receiver is unhappy with how things are going early in the season.
report: Responding to a tweet saying Ben Roethlisberger is the reason he puts up numbers, Antonio Brown wrote, "Trade me let’s find out."

impact: Ed Bouchette and Gerry Dulac temper the report by saying they are not sure if the absence was excused, but it is still notable considering it came a day after Brown got into it with coaches on the sideline. Brown also tweeted, "Trade me let’s find out," on Monday in response to a tweet from a former Steelers employee questioning how good he would be without Ben Roethlisberger. The most likely outcome here is Brown being at practice Wednesday and suiting up Monday night, but there is a lot of smoke suggesting Brown is not happy.
report: The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reports Antonio Brown did not report for meetings and film review on Monday.

impact: Tomlin refused to say if the absence was excused, but it did not sound as if it was. The coach added Brown has not requested a trade despite his, "Trade me let’s find out," tweet on Monday -- reading that tweet as a trade request was always a major stretch. The coach said he hopes to meet with Brown on Tuesday to discuss the situation and the tweet. Despite all the drama, it would be shocking if Brown is not ready to face the Bucs on Monday night.
report: Steelers coach Mike Tomlin confirmed Antonio Brown was not present on Monday.

impact: "I talked to the team about it," rep Drew Rosenhaus said. "His issue was unrelated to the tweet or his relationship with the team." We actually take Rosenhaus at face value that Brown does not want to be traded. His tweet was clearly just a frustrated player blowing off steam to a Twitter troll. As for Brown's Monday absence, the team has yet to say it was excused. We are not expecting any long-term consequences, but the sides' relationship is certainly looking a bit frosty right now.
report: Antonio Brown's agent insists his client does not want a trade and says his Monday absence was related to a "personal matter."

impact: This non-story of a "story" should disappear within the week.  Brown's bigger concern is a calf issue he gutted through in the second half in the Week 2 loss.
report: Antonio Brown returned to the team on Wednesday.

impact: "He and I met yesterday for an extended period of time," said Tomlin. "I'll leave the nature of that conversation between us. There was discipline involved for his missed meeting on Monday." It's been an eventful week for Brown, who got into it with OC Randy Fichtner on the sidelines in Sunday's loss to Kansas City, then tweeted "Trade me, let's find out" in response to a Twitter troll. Brown is clearly frustrated and obviously so is Tomlin, though there's been no indication that AB will be benched for Week 3 against Tampa Bay. With Brown upset and Le'Veon Bell still MIA, Pittsburgh's locker room has seen better days.
report: Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said Antonio Brown was disciplined for missing a team meeting on Monday.

impact: "I’m still grateful to put on my uniform, grateful to be part of this organization," Brown said. "I don’t take it for granted. Obviously it was a stupid remark online. I just got to stay away from online and the distractions." From his Twitter moment to his blowing off of Monday's team activities, Brown had an eventful week. It will all be forgotten with a big game against the Bucs on Monday Night Football.
report: Speaking Thursday, Antonio Brown said "obviously I don't want to be traded."

impact: Backed by a strong "squeaky wheel" narrative, Brown underwhelmed (by his standards) with merely six catches for 50 yards Monday night. Ben Roethlisberger hit him for a 27-yard touchdown prior to the half, which ultimately salvaged his day. Brown should still be considered fantasy's overall WR1, but the emergence of receiving TE Vance McDonald (4-112-1 Monday night) and JuJu Smith-Schuster's constant peppering of targets (11 against the Bucs) are both slightly concerning. Brown still ranks second in the league with 42 targets and is eventually bound to explode, perhaps even as soon as Week 4 when the Steelers host an injury-riddled Ravens defense.
report: Antonio Brown hauled in 6-of-9 targets for 50 yards and one touchdown in the Steelers' Week 3 win over the Buccaneers.

impact: Brown's touchdown came on a broken play where he made a double move and high-pointed the ball in the end-zone. He was otherwise held in check by Ravens CB Marlon Humphrey. Browns got almost all of his yards in the first half before the Steelers' offense stalled out. It was an underwhelming game for his standards. Brown will be a top-five option for a Week 5 blowup spot against the Falcons.
report: Antonio Brown caught 5-of-11 targets for 62 yards and a touchdown in Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: Ben Roethlisberger was forcing the ball to his No. 1 receiver in the first half, but Brown entered the break just 2-of-8 for 15 yards. The duo finally got in sync in the second half, with the highlight being Brown's 47-yard score down the left sideline. Brown soundly beat Robert Alford and Roethlisberger hit him in stride. It was off to the races after that. The 100-yard game was Brown's first of the season. He will have a shot at getting a hot streak going against the Bengals in Week 6.
report: Antonio Brown caught 6-of-13 targets for 101 yards and two touchdowns in the Steelers' Week 5 win over the Falcons.

impact: Brown was quiet most of the day before going 49 yards on a second-half catch-and-run for his longest play of the season to date.  He then scored from 31 yards out with 10 seconds left and the Steelers trailing by one point.  The six targets were third on the team behind JuJu Smith-Schuster (10) and Vance McDonald (8).  The Steelers are entering their bye week and will host the Browns in Week 8.  Brown went 9-93-1 on 16 targets versus Cleveland in Week 1.
report: Antonio Brown caught 5-of-6 targets for 105 yards and one touchdown in the Steelers' 28-21, Week 6 win over the Bengals.

impact: Howard took advantage of his limited workload, pulling in a 35-yard grab in tight coverage before nabbing a 19-yarder on a well-placed back-shoulder throw from Ryan Fitzpatrick. He out-snapped teammate Cameron Brate by a significant 43-24 margin. Howard will be in the TE2 mix next time out against Philadelphia.
report: O.J. Howard absorbed both of his targets for 54 yards Sunday in Tampa Bay’s Week 1 win over the Saints.

impact: Howard caught a 35-yard pass in tight coverage for his big Week 1 play, then delivered a 75-yard catch-and-run touchdown to pad Ryan Fitzpatrick's stats on Sunday versus Philly.  Howard only has target totals of 2 and 4 through two weeks.  He will remain a volatile TE1 option in Week 3 against the Steelers, who served up a pair of Travis Kelce touchdowns in Week 2.
report: O.J. Howard caught 3-of-4 targets for 96 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 2 win over the Eagles.

impact: Howard out-targeted fellow TE Cameron Brate 8-4 on the night, but it was the latter who was used (and scored) in the red zone. Howard has still recorded at least 50 yards receiving in all three games so far this year and continues to progressively see more usage with every passing week. He's the tight end to own in Tampa Bay.
report: O.J. Howard caught 6-of-8 targets for 72 yards in the Bucs' Week 3 loss to the Steelers.

impact: Howard suffered a knee injury in the second quarter of Sunday's loss to Chicago and wasn't able to return. The Bucs don't believe the injury is serious, but they still want him to get checked out. Luckily for fantasy owners, Howard will have the bye week to heal up. Cameron Brate would fill in at tight end if Howard can't go against the Falcons in Week 6.
report: O.J. Howard (knee) will undergo an MRI on Monday.

impact: It is ultimately positive news given what MRIs can reveal, but it is still a tough break for a player who started the season hot. The good news is the Bucs are on bye this week, so Howard might end up missing just one game. Cameron Brate will be a back-end TE1 if he gets the start against the Falcons in Week 6.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports O.J. Howard is out two-to-four weeks with a sprained MCL.

impact: It is not a surprise considering Howard was expected to miss two-to-four weeks with an MCL sprain. Cameron Brate should start and be a back-end TE1 against the Falcons this week.
report: O.J. Howard (knee) did not participate during Monday's practice.

impact: Howard sprained his MCL in Week 4 ahead of last week's bye, so the week off apparently did him a lot of favors.  He was in a brace on Wednesday, but it's an encouraging sign.  Howard will be a TE1 if healthy Sunday against Atlanta.  If he sits, Cameron Brate is a plug-and-play option at the weak position.
report: O.J. Howard (knee) was a limited participant at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Howard is less than two weeks removed from a sprained MCL but is trending toward playing Sunday against the Falcons. He'll be in an excellent spot against Atlanta's beat-up secondary.
report: O.J. Howard (knee) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Much to the dismay of Cameron Brate owners, O.J. Howard was surprisingly a full participant in practice Friday. If ruled active, expect Howard to play outside the 20-yard line with Brate continuing to soak up a majority of red zone looks. It's a terrific opportunity for both against a Falcons defense missing five key defenders Sunday.
report: O.J. Howard (knee) is questionable for Week 6 against the Falcons.

impact: Howard was initially expected to miss a couple of games after suffering a sprained MCL in Week 4, but he is ready to go coming out of the bye week. He might be limited, but Howard will be tough to sit considering the landscape at tight end. With Howard back, Cameron Brate is more of a desperation option.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports O.J. Howard (knee) is expected to play Week 6 against the Falcons.

impact: This was the expectation after he got in a full practice Friday. It is possible Howard is limited coming off a sprained MCL, but he is a back-end starter at a weak position. Bucs declared OG Alex Cappa, CB Carlton Davis (groin), QB Ryan Griffin, OL Michael Liedtke, DT Rakeem Nunez-Roches, DE Noah Spence, and RB Shaun Wilson inactive for Week 6.
report: O.J. Howard (knee) is active Week 6 against the Falcons.

impact: Howard was not limited at all despite coming back quickly from his sprained MCL. HIs first catch of the game was a 10-yard touchdown in which he out-muscled a linebacker, and but he really took over in the second half, catching three passes for 52 yards. Apparently fully healthy, Howard will be a TE1 next week against the Browns.
report: O.J. Howard hauled in all four of his targets for 62 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Howard's nine targets were the most he's had in a game this season. His best play of the day came on a 24-yard catch over a defender in which he was down at the 2-yard line. Howard now has 20 catches for 351 yards and two scores through six games and will be a lower-TE1 option in Week 8 against a Bengals team that has struggled to defend the tight end position all season.
report: O.J. Howard caught 5-of-9 passes for 67 yards in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: He's a healthy scratch for the third straight week. The rest of the Steelers inactives are CB Mike Hilton, S Morgan Burnett, QB Mason Rudolph, S Marcus Allen, OT Zach Banner, and DE L.T. Walton.
report: Justin Hunter is inactive for Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: He was shut out in the first half, but was more effective after halftime, chipping in with three catches on four second-half targets. Humphries took a screen pass from Ryan Fitzpatrick 65 yards to the house late in the second quarter, but the play was called back for an illegal block by left tackle Donovan Smith. In a busy Bucs’ receiving corps, Humphries is unlikely to be a major fantasy factor next week against the Eagles.
report: Adam Humphries supplied three catches for 27 yards on five targets Sunday in the Buccaneers’ Week 1 win over the Saints.

impact: Humphries only ended up with four targets, but he made the most of them. His biggest play came on a 51-yard catch-and-run early in the third quarter. Despite that big play, Humphries is not a viable fantasy option outside of deep leagues.
report: Adam Humphries hauled in 3-of-4 targets for 82 yards in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Humphries continues to work as the Bucs true WR2 in terms of snaps and routes and Sunday he was only out-targeted by Mike Evans (10) and O.J. Howard (nine). Humphries is the worst kind of player because he is not valuable for fantasy purposes on his own merit while remaining a thorn in the side of the fantasy ceilings for the members of the Tampa Bay passing game. He is not a viable fantasy option Week 8 against the Bengals.
report: Adam Humphries caught 4-of-8 targets for 37 yards in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: Godwin came out hot with three first-half catches including a nine-yard touchdown strike from Ryan Fitzpatrick with a little under five minutes remaining in the second quarter. He also made a phenomenal diving catch for a 16-yard pick-up in the first quarter. Godwin did cough up the football once, but was able to recover it. Despite his strong start, the second-year wideout was only targeted once after halftime as the Bucs milked the clock by leaning on their ground game. With DeSean Jackson in the concussion protocol, Godwin could be a near every-down player against the Eagles in Week 2.
report: Chris Godwin collected three catches for 41 yards and a touchdown on four targets Sunday in the Buccaneers’ Week 1 win over New Orleans.

impact: Godwin has now scored in each of the Bucs' first two games, although he continues to play in a rotation on Tampa Bay's deep pass-catcher corps.  DeSean Jackson has been white hot, and Mike Evans is playing at one of the highest levels of his career.  Godwin will be a WR3/flex option in Week 3 versus Pittsburgh.
report: Chris Godwin caught 5-of-6 targets for 56 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 2 win over Philadelphia.

impact: Godwin's toe injury doesn't appear to be anything serious. We'd expect him to see his usual snaps Monday against Pittsburgh. With teammate DeSean Jackson off to an impressive start, Godwin is just a back-end WR3 for fantasy purposes.
report: Chris Godwin (toe) was limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Godwin's toe injury was never considered to be anything serious, and Auman noted the second-year pro "looked fine" when media watched him in practice. Godwin will still likely get slapped with the 'questionable' tag when the Bucs release their injury report. Consider him probable for Monday night against the Steelers.
report: Chris Godwin (toe) is expected to play in Week 3 against the Steelers.

impact: Godwin came out rusty, dropping two passes and fumbling all in the first half. He eventually shook it off and dominated downfield with Mike Evans (6-137-1), overpowering his defender inside the five-yard line for his only score of the night. Although Godwin benefitted from the Bucs trailing 30-10 in the second half, the second-year pro has now scored in every game this season. Godwin's proved he can flourish catching passes from Jameis Winston, but it would certainly help him if it's Ryan Fitzpatrick's gun-slinger style of play that remains under center.
report: Chris Godwin caught 5-of-10 targets for 74 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 3 loss to the Steelers.

impact: It's the first time all year that Godwin failed to score. With the Bucs trailing big at the half for the second time in as many weeks, it was DeSean Jackson (5-112) and Mike Evans (6-59) who unsurprisingly flourished ahead of Godwin. Adam Humphries continues to stick in a WR3 machination with the second-year pro, finishing with 6-36 on the afternoon. Consider it one bad day for Godwin. He's still a WR4/FLEX with Jameis Winston under center after Tampa Bay's Week 5 bye.
report: Chris Godwin caught his only two targets for 22 yards in Sunday's Week 4 trouncing to the Bears.

impact: The total was eight fewer than DeSean Jackson and 18 fewer than Adam Humphries. Godwin did make some mistakes in Week 3, but it was still surprising to see him log just two targets after scoring in each of the first three games. The Bucs should spend the bye making sure their talented sophomore gets the ball.
report: Chris Godwin played 31-of-63 snaps (49 percent) Week 4 against the Bears.

impact: Godwin was shockingly uninvolved in the blowout loss before the bye, but he bounced back in this one. He had two catches on Tampa's opening touchdown drive, and he finished tied for the team lead with nine targets. His touchdown came from nine yards out on a play he was left open just short of the goal line. With four touchdowns in five games this season, Godwin will be a FLEX option next week against the Browns.
report: Chris Godwin caught 6-of-9 targets for 56 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Godwin did most of his damage in the first half, catching four passes for 36 yards before the break. Afterwards, he received just two targets as he's still running behind all of Mike Evans, Adam Humphries and DeSean Jackson. Godwin remains a touchdown-or-bust fantasy option Week 8 against the Bengals.
report: Chris Godwin caught 5-of-6 passes for 59 yards in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: This was his highest snap share since Week 1. It is notable considering Godwin had been splitting time with DeSean Jackson while Adam Humphries dominated slot snaps. Humphries was limited to 57 snaps in this contest, and Jackson played just 43. Despite the playing time, Godwin still finished fourth on the team with six targets. Godwin's inconsistent target share will make him a volatile fantasy option, but he has four touchdowns in six games as a prominent red-zone threat in a good passing offense. He will be an upside WR3 this week against the Bengals.
report: Chris Godwin played 66-of-95 snaps (69 percent) Week 7 against the Browns.

impact: Jackson took a tumble in the fourth quarter after coming down with a 35-yard catch. He had a monster game prior to getting hurt, delivering five receptions for 146 yards and two touchdown on just five targets. His absence will open up snaps for Chris Godwin at wide receiver, though the Bucs are leading and looking to kill clock right now.
report: DeSean Jackson left Sunday's Week 1 game against the Saints with a concussion and will not return.

impact: Auman calls Jackson a "major question mark" for Week 2 against the Eagles.  D-Jax absolutely lit up the Saints in the opener to the tune of a 5-146-2 outing, finishing as the overall WR3 for Week 1 behind Michael Thomas and Tyreek Hill.  Chris Godwin is expected to soak up snaps against Philly.
report: The Athletic's Greg Auman reports DeSean Jackson (concussion) is also dealing with a shoulder injury.

impact: Jackson is in the league's concussion protocol and also has a shoulder issue.  He's looking more doubtful than anything this week against the Eagles.  Chris Godwin should get the start, with Adam Humphries in the slot.
report: DeSean Jackson (concussion, shoulder) is not practicing Wednesday.

impact: Jason Pierre-Paul (knee) was also present following Wednesday's DNP. We'll have to see how the Bucs list him—Jackson may not have done enough to earn the "limited" tag coming off last week's concussion. Regardless, he seems to be trending in the right direction. If the veteran deep threat isn't cleared for Sunday's home opener against the Eagles, Chris Godwin would be in for a bigger workload.
report: DeSean Jackson (concussion, shoulder) was seen during the open portion of Thursday's practice.

impact: This was the expectation after D-Jax was spotted with a helmet during the portion of Bucs practice open to the media. D-Jax returning to split snaps and targets with Chris Godwin against the Eagles' stout defense would significantly lower both players' floor and ceiling. D-Jax should be treated as a high-risk WR4 if he plays.
report: DeSean Jackson (concussion, shoulder) returned to Bucs practice Thursday, getting in a limited session.

impact: Jackson must still clear the concussion protocol, but he now has at least a chance to suit up after returning to a limited practice on Thursday. D-Jax went wild with 146 yards in the opener but he'll face a bigger challenge this week going against the reigning champs. Jackson being active would be a downgrade for Chris Godwin's fantasy outlook.
report: DeSean Jackson (concussion, shoulder) is questionable for Week 2 against the Eagles.

impact: This puts Jackson on track to play Sunday against the Eagles. D-Jax had a huge game in Week 1 but a repeat of that is going to be harder against one of the league's tougher defenses. Chris Godwin would have been an interesting DFS play had Jackson sat out, but now that ship has probably sailed.
report: DeSean Jackson (questionable, concussion) was upgraded to a full practice on Friday.

impact: Jackson was a full participant in practice Friday. Barring any unforeseen circumstances, he'll clear the protocol and suit up Sunday. Jackson was a monster in Week 1, hauling in all five of his targets for 146 yards and two touchdowns, but he'll be hard-pressed to replicate that performance against the Eagles' stout secondary. Jackson's availability puts Chris Godwin back into a time-share.
report: DeSean Jackson (concussion) is expected to play in Week 2 against the Eagles.

impact: This was the expectation after Jackson got in a full practice Friday. With Jackson back and the Bucs unlikely to score 48 points against the Eagles, neither he nor Chris Godwin is anything more than a WR4/FLEX play with upside. For those who like revenge narratives, Jackson did average 88 yards per game with two scores in five meetings with the Eagles while he was in Washington.
report: NFL Network's Peter Schrager reports DeSean Jackson cleared the concussion protocol and will play against the Eagles.

impact: He was listed as questionable with a concussion and shoulder injury, but it became clear D-Jax was likely to play after he practiced fully on Friday.  DE Jason Pierre-Paul (knee) is also active against Philly.
report: DeSean Jackson is active for Week 2 against the Eagles.

impact: Incredibly, Jackson has now caught all nine of his targets for 275 yards and three touchdowns two games in.  The Bucs are destroying opponents on play-action passes and calling aggressive deep shots on first-down plays, when defenses are in their base personnel and not equipped to handle Jackson's devastating speed.  Keep D-Jax rolling as an upside WR2/3 play in Week 3 versus Pittsburgh.
report: DeSean Jackson caught 4-of-4 targets for 129 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 2 win over the Eagles.

impact: Jackson's boom-bust style of play finally came crashing back to Earth as he failed to eclipse 100 yards or score for the first time all season. He nearly salvaged his day with a vintage punt return for a score, but the highlight-reel run was inevitably called back due to holding. Chris Godwin (5-74-1) recorded 10 targets on the day and still has the higher floor moving forward.
report: DeSean Jackson caught 3-of-5 targets for 37 yards in the Bucs' Week 3 loss to the Steelers.

impact: Much like last week, the Bears trailed by multiple scores at the half. That only fueled Jackson's boom-bust style, allowing the burner to top 100-yards for the third time this season. He notably finished second on the team in targets behind Mike Evans (9). Jackson will stay a bye-week commodity even with Jameis Winston under center following the Bucs' Week 5 bye.
report: DeSean Jackson caught 5-of-8 targets for 112 yards in the Bucs' Week 4 loss to the Bears.

impact: He did not manage to top 100 yards, but Jackson kept his good run going in this one despite a less than efficient outing. It could have been an even bigger game, but Jackson was not able to catch up to a deep target in the second half, and Jameis Winston was picked off on another deep attempt to his speedy receiver. Getting consistent opportunities, Jackson will be an upside WR3 next week against the Browns.
report: DeSean Jackson hauled in 4-of-9 targets for 77 yards in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Jackson scored the first touchdown of the game on a 14-yard end around in the first quarter. He then nearly reeled in a touchdown on the following drive that was broken up by Denzel Ward. Ward followed Jackson for the majority of the afternoon as Ward's size and speed was best suited for Jackson rather than that of Mike Evans. Jackson's 14-yard catch in overtime on third down set up the game-winning field goal. Heading into Week 8, Jackson will be a boom-or-bust WR3 option against the Bengals.
report: DeSean Jackson caught 2-of-5 targets for 25 yards while rushing twice for eight yards and a touchdown in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: Rudolph didn't see his first target until there was about five minutes left in the third quarter.  Both Vikings backup TEs David Morgan and Tyler Conklin caught a pass before Rudolph was targeted, but Rudolph saved his day with the red-zone touchdown.  His lack of targets is still alarming, especially after Rudolph was targeted just once in the preseason despite playing a full game's worth of snaps.  Rudolph will be a TD-or-bust TE1 next week in Green Bay.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught 1-of-2 targets for an 11-yard touchdown in the Vikings' Week 1 win over the 49ers.

impact: It was the quietest 72 yards in history. Rudolph did get loose for 23 yards in the third quarter, but that was his only catch of more than 12. Still, it was a welcome bounceback after Rudolph went for just 11 yards total in Week 1. He will be a back-end TE1 next week against the Bills.
report: Kyle Rudolph hauled in 7-of-8 targets for 72 yards in the Vikings' Week 2 tie with the Packers.

impact: Rudolph was one of the primary beneficiaries from the Vikings' 27-0 first half deficit. His lone score came in garbage time with less than two minutes to play while Minnesota was still getting blanked. Even so, the touchdown alone was enough to vault him into the top-three at his position in Week 3. The Rams have been exploited by tight ends in the middle of the field so far this season, so expect another juicy outing from Rudolph Thursday night.
report: Kyle Rudolph hauled in 5-of-6 targets for 48 yards and one touchdown in the Vikings' Week 3 loss to the Bills.

impact: All five of his catches came before halftime as Rudolph was targeted just once over the final two quarters. The Notre Dame alum has been reasonably effective in the early going, logging five-plus catches in each of his last three games. Playing on the road against the Eagles’ elite defense, Rudolph belongs on the lower end of the TE1 spectrum next week.
report: Kyle Rudolph secured five-of-six targets for 57 yards Thursday in the Vikings’ Week 4 loss to the Rams.

impact: That's as standard issue as a Rudolph game gets. Rudolph has two scores through five games. He's an uninspiring, but consistent and locked in, TE1. The Cardinals are on tap for Week 6.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught 5-of-5 targets for 41 yards in the Vikings' Week 5 win over the Eagles.

impact: It's another standard Rudolph game. Rudolph has just two touchdowns this season and hasn't scored since Week 3. He'll be a back-end TE1 against the Jets in Week 7.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught four passes for 37 yards in Week 6 against the Cardinals.

impact: Rudolph has been held below 50 yards in 5-of-7 games and hasn't scored since Week 3.  However, he remains a TE1 at a weak position going into a potential shootout next week at home against a bad Saints defense.
report: Kyle Rudolph caught just 1-of-4 targets for 16 yards in the Vikings' Week 7 win over the Jets.

impact: Evans disappointed in his matchups against Marshon Lattimore last season but he flipped the script Sunday, owning the reigning Defensive Rookie of the Year from start to finish. The Bucs stud left the field with an injury early in the second half but showed no ill effects upon his return, dusting Lattimore on a 50-yard touchdown strike from red-hot Ryan Fitzpatrick. The 147 yards were Evans’ most in a game since Week 9 of 2016 against Atlanta. He’s now just one receiving touchdown away from tying Jimmie Giles’ team record of 34. Next week’s matchup with Philadelphia won’t be an easy one, though Evans is still worthy of WR1 consideration against the reigning World Champs.
report: Mike Evans tallied seven catches for 147 yards and a touchdown on seven targets Sunday in the Buccaneers’ improbable Week 1 win over the Saints.

impact: Evans didn't get loose for vertical bombs, but he out-physicaled the Eagles' defensive backs en route to a high-volume game.  His touchdown came on an easy four-yard route where Evans simply used his big body to shield himself from beleaguered Eagles CB Jalen Mills.  The Steelers' defense has been getting torched early on, and Evans will catch them on Monday Night Football in Week 3.
report: Mike Evans caught 10-of-12 targets for 83 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 2 win over the Eagles.

impact: Evans was given chance after chance downfield and delivered, fighting through double-coverage multiple times to eventually finish with 137 yards. Normally DeSean Jackson would join him in the mix downfield, but it was primarily Evans and Chris Godwin (5-74-1) who were trusted with jump-balls throughout the evening. Now at 23-367-3 on the year, Evans remains a strong WR1 whether it's Ryan Fitzpatrick or Jameis Winston under center in Week 4.
report: Mike Evans hauled in 6-of-11 targets for 137 yards and one touchdown in the Bucs' Week 3 loss to the Steelers.

impact: Unlike last week, it was DeSean Jackson (5-112) who benefited immensely as the Bucs trailed 38-3 after two quarters. Evans' nine targets were still a team-high, with Adam Humphries (6-36) seeing seven. Evans has proved to be a true WR1 with Jameis Winston, who replaced Ryan Fitzpatrick at the half, under center and that should continue once the Bucs return from their Week 5 bye.
report: Mike Evans hauled in 6-of-9 targets for 59 yards in the Bucs' Week 4 loss to the Bears.

impact: It is an extremely disappointing result considering Jameis Winston threw for 395 yards and four touchdowns. That said, Evans did not make any glaring mistakes or play poorly. He just did not really get the opportunities. That should change next week against the Browns.
report: Mike Evans hauled in 4-of-5 targets for 58 yards in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: After two slow weeks with 107 yards combined through the air, Evans led the Bucs across the board in receiving on Sunday. With Denzel Ward following DeSean Jackson, Evans worked mostly on Damarious Randall on the afternoon. After scoring a touchdown in each of the opening three weeks of the season, Evans has failed to reach the end zone over the past three games. Despite that, he remains a high-end WR1 option in Week 8 on the road against the Bengals.
report: Mike Evans caught 7-of-10 targets for 107 yards in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: The Bucs’ backup played sparingly and was ineffective in the few instances when he was called upon, managing a long gain of just three yards. Peyton Barber served as Tampa’s workhorse in the opener, leading the Bucs’ backfield with 19 touches. We’d expect that trend to continue next week against the Eagles.
report: Jacquizz Rodgers rushed twice for only one yard while catching his lone target for a two-yard gain Sunday in the Buccaneeers’ Week 1 win over the Saints.

impact: The Titans opened the game trying to "establish" Derrick Henry -- Henry handled the first eight touches in Tennessee's backfield -- but Lewis eventually took over as the team's clearly-superior option.  Lewis' all-purpose game gives the Titans' offense more diversity than one-dimensional Henry brings to the table.  Elevate Lewis to a borderline RB2 when the Titans host the Texans next.
report: Dion Lewis rushed 16 times for 75 yards and a touchdown and caught 5-of-8 targets for 35 yards in the Titans' Week 1 loss to Miami.

impact: It was a game best-suited for Tennessee to lean on teammate Derrick Henry, which is exactly what the club did. Henry out-touched Lewis 18-15, with all of the former's touches coming via carries. Unfortunately for owners of this backfield, performances like this are bound to occur throughout the year depending on game script. Lewis remains the more coveted of the duo considering his usage in the Titans' passing game.
report: Dion Lewis rushed 14 times for 42 yards and hauled in his only target for one yard in the Titans' Week 2 win over the Texans.

impact: Derrick Henry was Tennessee's main back in this one, out-touching Lewis 18 to 12.  Lewis' touch counts have descended each week, falling from 21 in the opener to 15 in Week 2 and 12 today.  With an inconsistent timeshare role, Lewis will remain a shaky flex option when the Titans host the Eagles in Week 4.
