report: Dion Lewis rushed nine times for 26 yards and caught 3-of-3 targets for 14 yards in Tennessee's Week 3 upset win over Jacksonville.

impact: He "added" zero yards on four carries. A struggling running game and a second-half deficit conspired to keep Lewis on the field instead of Derrick Henry, and he responded with a nice PPR outing. He made a couple big plays in the passing game in the second half, but his biggest was a fourth-down conversion in which he made a man miss and went 17 yards up the sideline in overtime. With the offense looking better and Buffalo on deck, Lewis will be an RB3 next week.
report: Dion Lewis hauled in all nine of his targets for 66 yards in the Titans' Week 4 win over the Eagles.

impact: He out-touched Derrick Henry 15 to 11 and has seemingly emerged as the Titans' preferred back, although it remains a fairly even committee.  Still rarely scoring touchdowns and firmly in a timeshare, Lewis will be a low-upside flex option when Tennessee hosts Baltimore in Week 6.
report: Dion Lewis rushed 12 times for 34 yards and caught 3-of-4 targets for 14 yards in the Titans' Week 5 loss to Buffalo.

impact: That's right, 14 yards on seven touches (2.0 yards per touch) for Lewis in Week 6. It was an abysmal outing for anyone donning silver and navy blue as everyone fell victim to Baltimore's 11-sack shutout defensive stand. Derrick Henry out-touched Lewis 8-7 but even he managed just 26 yards and an average 3.25 yards per touch. Lewis will be needed (and should out-touch Henry) in the Titans' Week 7 matchup against the Chargers' explosive offense.
report: Dion Lewis handled five carries for nine yards and caught both of his targets for another five yards in the Titans' Week 6 loss to the Ravens.

impact: Lewis carried the Titans' offense, outrushing Derrick Henry and finishing behind only Tajae Sharpe in receiving. It's a nice rebound after Lewis managed just 14 total yards last week. Lewis has been better than Henry through the first seven games and there's no reason to downgrade his rest-of-season outlook. The Titans have a matchup against Dallas after their Week 9 bye.
report: Dion Lewis rushed 13 times for 93 yards and caught six passes for 64 yards in Week 7 against the Chargers.

impact: The Redskins had little reason to air it out while leading comfortably, which would account for Crowder’s abbreviated workload. Obviously Crowder’s season debut was short on fantasy pyrotechnics, but the contract-year slot receiver should have a chance to rebound next week in a favorable matchup against Indy’s Swiss-cheese secondary.
report: Jamison Crowder managed three catches for 32 yards on four targets Sunday in Washington’s Week 1 victory over the Cardinals.

impact: He got the ball on Washington’s first play from scrimmage, chewing up 25 yards on a reverse. Crowder didn’t see much work after that, though he was involved with a controversial play in the second quarter. Darius Leonard appeared to strip the ball from Crowder following a four-yard catch, though the play was later overturned after replay showed Crowder was down by contact. The contract-year receiver is off to an underwhelming start with just five catches for 40 yards through his first two contests. We’ll see what the former Duke Blue Devil can cook up next week against the Packers.
report: Jamison Crowder absorbed two-of-four targets for eight yards while adding a team-leading 29 rushing yards on two carries Sunday in the Redskins’ Week 2 loss to the Colts.

impact: Crowder doubled his Weeks 1 and 2 production while catching his first touchdown pass from Alex Smith. We thought Crowder would mesh well with Smith's conservative skill-set, but Smith has been more locked onto Jordan Reed and Chris Thompson. Crowder has yet to make a viable WR4 case. He does have a juicy for Week 5 when the Redskins come off their bye against the Saints.
report: Jamison Crowder caught 4-of-4 targets for 39 yards and a touchdown in the Redskins' Week 3 win over the Packers.

impact: The 55 yards led the team and marked a new season-high for Crowder after he managed a 9-79-1 line Weeks 1-3 before the bye.  The eight targets matched a team high.  Crowder's best grab was an over-the-shoulder catch on fourth down, while he also made a good catch over the middle earlier in the game.  Crowder remains a WR4/5 in PPR leagues ahead of Week 6 against Carolina.
report: Jamison Crowder caught 4-of-8 targets for 55 yards in the Redskins' Week 5 loss to the Saints.

impact: The Redskins opted for a walkthrough instead of practicing coming off their Monday night game in New Orleans. Crowder has flirted with PPR relevance in the past but not this season. The Duke-educated slot receiver has managed just 13 catches for 131 yards and a single touchdown through five games. Fantasy owners can do better.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: As did Paul Richardson (knee, shoulder). Both players are now looking on the wrong side of questionable for Sunday's game against the Panthers, though there is still the chance it's just extra maintenance after Monday night's loss. Richardson initially seemed more injured than Crowder.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) remained sidelined on Thursday.

impact: Crowder, Chris Thompson (rib), Adrian Peterson (shoulder, ankle, knee), Josh Doctson (heel), and WR Paul Richardson (shoulder/knee) are all officially questionable for Sunday. Both Crowder and Richardson were both sidelined Thursday, too, potentially paving the way for WR Maurice Harris to play another full set of reps. Harris would start if any of Washington's wideouts were deemed inactive.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is questionable for Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: It is not a surprise considering he sat out all week. With both Paul Richardson (shoulder, knee) and Josh Doctson (heel) questionable, Washington could be without their top three receivers on Sunday as well as Chris Thompson (rib, knee). That makes Maurice Harris at least interesting in DFS, and Vernon Davis could see more targets than usual as well.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Jamison Crowder (ankle) is not expected to play Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: Crowder is week to week. Maurice Harris is starting in his absence against the Panthers.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is inactive for Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: In other words, he's almost certainly going to remain sidelined for Week 7. Maurice Harris started in Crowder's absence against the Panthers.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) won't resume practicing until Friday at the earliest.

impact: He'll miss another game with his ankle injury. With Paul Richardson (knee, shoulder) also a long shot to play, look for Josh Doctson and Jordan Reed to see more involvement this week.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is out for Week 7 against the Cowboys.

impact: Crowder has missed the past two games and isn't off to a good start to the practice week.  Crowder has been totally nonexistent for fantasy purposes.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) did not practice Wednesday.

impact: It's the third consecutive game Crowder will miss due to an ankle injury. Maurice Harris has been utilized as a starting receiver in that time, but it's amounted to just 9/82 on 15 targets. Paul Richardson (questionable, shoulder) and Chris Thompson (questionable, knee) are the stronger options Sunday if they suit up.
report: Jamison Crowder (ankle) is out for Week 8 against the Giants.

impact: Henry got eight touches before Dion Lewis even touched the ball at all, but the Titans switched gears thereafter.  Lewis wound up out-touching Henry by a whopping 21 to 3 margin from that point on.  Henry's lack of effectiveness is a major concern in a competitive situation where he must perform to earn carries over his counterpart.  Henry did have a long touchdown run negated by a Delanie Walker holding penalty.  Nevertheless, Henry can only be viewed as a TD-or-bust flex option for Week 2 against the Texans.
report: Derrick Henry rushed ten times for 26 yards and caught his lone target for five yards in the Titans' Week 1 loss to Miami.

impact: Henry rushed just 10 times for 26 scoreless yards and played just 20 snaps to Dion Lewis' 47.  Henry also had a 62-yard touchdown wiped off the board due to a Delanie Walker holding call.  Anytime the Titans fall behind, Henry's playing time is going to be a concern because he simply hasn't been a productive pass-game member in his college or pro careers.  Henry needs to be treated as a high-ceiling, low-floor RB2/3 this week against the Texans.
report: Derrick Henry said he is "pissed" about his Week 1 performance against the Dolphins.

impact: It was a tremendous game script for Henry, who will typically be called upon to ice games when the Titans are trying to secure a lead. He out-carried Dion Lewis 18-14, but both struggled mightily for breathing room without starting tackles Jack Conklin and Taylor Lewan available. Henry merely averaged 3.1 YPC, slightly better than Lewis' 3.0 Sunday. With only one target under his belt through two weeks of play, Henry (albeit immensely talented and an able receiver out of Tennessee's backfield) can't be considered anything more than a touchdown-dependent RB4 until further notice.
report: Derrick Henry rushed 18 times for 56 yards in the Titans' Week 2 win over the Texans.

impact: It's a new injury, but the limited practice suggets it's not a Week 3 concern. With Tennessee's offensive line banged up, Henry has a shy-away matchup with Jacksonville.
report: Derrick Henry (back) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: There's been no indication Henry is in danger of missing Sunday's game against the Jaguars. From both an opponent and game-flow standpoint, the matchup could not be more poor. Henry is a fringe RB3 for Week 3.
report: Derrick Henry (back) remained "limited" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Henry was removed from Tennessee's injury report and was a full participant in Friday's practice. Even so, he's been out-snapped, out-targeted, and has received fewer carries than teammate Dion Lewis so far this season. Henry is merely an RB3/RB4 stuck in a terrible matchup in Week 3.
report: Derrick Henry (back) is expected to play in Week 3 against the Jaguars.

impact: He was targeted once and didn't catch it.  Henry did out-touch Dion Lewis 18 to 12, but he remains scoreless on the year and has no passing-game role.  Henry will remain a touchdown-or-bust flex option in Week 4 against the Eagles.
report: Derrick Henry rushed 18 times for 57 yards in the Titans' Week 3 win over the Jaguars.

impact: Henry opened the day on a positive note with a 13-yard catch and a 14-yard run, but that was about it for the struggling running back. He did have a nice eight-yard run in overtime, but he played far fewer snaps than Dion Lewis in a game the Titans were trailing throughout the second half. On the bright side, Marcus Mariota looked healthy in this one, which should open up the running game and create more scoring opportunities. Henry will be an interesting DFS play in a bounce-back spot next week against the Bills.
report: Derrick Henry rushed eight times for 24 yards and caught two passes for seven yards in the Titans' Week 4 win over the Eagles.

impact: Dion Lewis out-touched him 15 to 11.  Henry drew just one target and missed it, and he is averaging one target per game five weeks in.  He is also scoreless on the year.  Henry will be a poor flex option in Week 6 versus Baltimore.
report: Derrick Henry rushed 11 times for 56 yards in the Titans' Week 5 loss to Buffalo.

impact: The only positive to takeaway is that Henry out-carried teammate Dion Lewis 7-5. He still averaged just 3.0 YPC on the day and has seen one target per game this season. As a touchdown-dependent back who hasn't scored a touchdown, he's droppable if a roster spot is needed.
report: Derrick Henry rushed seven times for 21 yards and caught his only target for five yards in the Titans' dreadful Week 6 loss to the Ravens.

impact: This was one of the better games of the season for Henry. He saw fewer touches than Dion Lewis but converted a goal-line carry for his touchdown. Henry added 30 yards on two catches and looked good when the Titans got him in open space. With Marcus Mariota getting closer to full health, Henry's ROS value is slightly trending up.
report: Derrick Henry had 12 carries for 33 yards and a touchdown in Week 7 against the Chargers.

impact: Gabbert was predictably bad, but the bigger story is the Titans may have to start him in Week 2 with Marcus Mariota (elbow) ailing.  The Titans host the Texans next.  We'll have a better idea of Mariota's injury on Monday.
report: Blaine Gabbert completed 11-of-22 passes for 117 yards and an interception in the Titans' Week 1 loss to Miami.

impact: Marcus Mariota (elbow) was limited in warm-ups and is still struggling to grip the football. There is no official word from the Titans just yet, but it sounds like Gabbert will be starting behind a makeshift offensive line missing both starting tackles.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports it's "looking more" like Blaine Gabbert will start in Week 2 against the Texans.

impact: Both Gabbert and Marcus Mariota (elbow) warmed up for the Titans' Week 2 division bout against the Texans, but it was the former who took all reps with the first-string offense. The Titans only have two available quarterbacks, so Mariota could still stay glued to the sidelines despite being active. There has been no official announcement on Tennessee's starter.
report: Blaine Gabbert is warming up with the Titans' first string offense.

impact: Marcus Mariota (elbow) is active but may only be used in an emergency. The Titans will notably be without tackles Jack Conklin, Taylor Lewan, and second-stringer Dennis Kelly against the Texans' daunting pass rush.
report: Blaine Gabbert will start in Week 2 against the Texans.

impact: Gabbert barely cracked the century mark in his spot-start for Marcus Mariota (elbow), tossing for 117 yards and an abysmal 5.8 YPA. Gabbert's fantasy production typically derives (and hinges on) his legs, but he mustered only two scrambles for two yards in Tennessee's Week 2 win. Corey Davis (5-55) still managed to lead all Titans skill players with a team-high seven targets, so consider him the focal point of Tennessee's passing game no matter who is under center moving forward.
report: Blaine Gabbert completed 13-of-20 passes for 117 yards and one touchdown in the Titans' Week 2 win over the Texans.

impact: The Titans are "hoping" Marcus Mariota (elbow) can "grip the football as soon as possible", which is a vague timeline that leaves his return wide open. Blaine Gabbert is expected to make his second consecutive start in the interim. Gabbert completed 13-of-20 passes for 117 yards and one score against the Texans in Week 2 and, if looking for a positive note, will have LT Taylor Lewan (concussion) back protecting his blindside. Although they'll be on the field for nearly every offensive play, WR Corey Davis and TE Jonnu Smith can be promptly downgraded until Mariota returns.
report: Titans QB Blaine Gabbert is expected to start in Week 3 against the Jaguars.

impact: Gabbert took a first-quarter hit so massive that he was noticeably woozy and eventually left the field with trainers.  Marcus Mariota, dealing with a nerve problem in his throwing-arm elbow, has taken over at quarterback against Jacksonville.
report: Blaine Gabbert left Sunday's Week 3 game with a concussion.

impact: Gabbert suffered a concussion in Week 3 and remains in the league's protocol. Marcus Mariota is still working back from a pinched nerve in his throwing elbow but played through the pain last week against the Jags. Mariota should get the nod Sunday when the Titans host Philadelphia.
report: Blaine Gabbert (concussion) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: Gabbert has yet to pass the concussion protocol. Even if he gets cleared, the Titans are starting Marcus Mariota at less than 100 percent this week. Austin Davis will back up Mariota if Gabbert sits.
report: Blaine Gabbert (concussion) is questionable for Week 4 against the Eagles.

impact: With Gabbert down, the Titans will turn to Austin Davis behind Marcus Mariota. Tennessee also declared CB Kenneth Durden, RB David Fluellen (groin), OG Aaron Stinnie, OT Dennis Kelly (illness), DL Darius Kilgo, and DL Matt Dickerson inactive for Week 4.
report: Titans declared QB Blaine Gabbert (concussion) inactive for Week 4 against the Eagles.

impact: Gabbert is one of the least-effective backups in the league.
report: Blaine Gabbert has cleared the concussion protocol.

impact: Smith-Schuster won in the slot often when faced off against Briean Boddy-Calhoun with the highlight of his day being a 67-yard catch and run that set up a Steelers touchdown in the 3rd quarter. Building off an impressive rookie season, Smith-Schuster will be a starting option next week at home versus the Chiefs.
report: Steelers WR JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 5-of-8 targets for 119 yards in Sunday's Week 1 game versus the Browns.

impact: With Antonio Brown gutting out a calf injury, Smith-Schuster set new career highs in both targets and catches. He benefitted from the Steelers spending literally the entire game in comeback mode. Smith-Schuster's touchdown was a two-yarder where he displayed ridiculously strong hands while getting tackled in tight coverage. He drew another end zone target later in the game but could not hook up with Ben Roethlisberger. The Steelers' No. 2 wideout is now sitting at 18/240/1 through two games. He's flirting with every-week WR1 value.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 13-of-19 targets for 121 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 2 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: It was just another 100-plus yard evening for Smith-Schuster, who's up to 27-356-1 on 38 targets this season. He also helped notched the game on the Steelers' final drive, separating from his defender and getting loose over the middle to bring down Ben Roethlisberger's across-the-body heave and secure Pittsburgh's 30-27 win. JuJu has now scored a touchdown and/or eclipsed the 100-yard mark in seven consecutive games. He's an every-week matchup-proof WR2.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 9-of-11 targets for 116 yards in the Steelers' Week 3 win over the Buccaneers.

impact: It's possible, if not likely, that Smith-Schuster is just getting a breather following Monday night's win over Tampa Bay. After leading all rookies in receiving yards last season, JuJu has been even better this year, topping 100 yards in each of his three contests. Assuming this is only a minor setback for Smith-Schuster, the former USC Trojan will be a borderline WR1 Sunday night when the Steelers host Baltimore.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster (abdomen) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: Smith-Schuster got the day off on Wednesday coming off the Monday night game. His participation on Thursday, albeit in a limited capacity, suggests he'll be fine for Sunday night's tilt with Baltimore. One of only two players in the league (the other being Minnesota's Adam Thielen) to top 100 yards receiving in each of his first three games, JuJu will be in the WR1 mix for that one.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster (abdomen) returned to a limited practice on Thursday.

impact: Smith-Schuster was upgraded to full participation at Friday's practice after sitting out Wednesday and getting in a limited session on Thursday. There was never much doubt about his availability for Sunday night's rivalry game with Baltimore. Through three weeks of action, JuJu ranks third in the league in receiving yards per game behind only Michael Thomas and Mike Evans. The 21-year-old has quickly ascended to weekly WR1 status in fantasy.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster (abdomen) wasn't listed on the Steelers' final injury report for Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: It was the first time Smith-Schuster has been held under 100 yards all season. He tied for a team high with 11 targets, but the Steelers offense couldn't get anything going downfield and were shut out in the second half. Smith-Schuster missed time with a core injury going into Sunday night, but looked fully healthy. He'll remain a WR1 for Week 5's Falcons matchup.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 4-of-11 targets for 60 yards in Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: With Ben Roethlisberger (successfully) fixated on getting Antonio Brown going, Smith-Schuster had his quietest game of the season. Thankfully for fantasy owners, it included a touchdown. With just eight catches over his past two games, Smith-Schuster will look to get cooking again in Week 6 against the Bengals.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 4-of-4 targets for 34 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 5 win over the Falcons.

impact: His 10 targets led the team.  JuJu made an incredible catch over the top of CB Darqueze Dennard at the goal line and was ruled down at the one, setting up a second one-yard touchdown for James Conner.  This was Smith-Schuster's fourth 100-yard game of the season as the Steelers head into their bye before hosting the Browns in Week 8.  JuJu went 5-119 in Week 1 vs. Cleveland.
report: JuJu Smith-Schuster caught 7-of-10 targets for 111 yards in the Steelers' Week 6 win over the Bengals.

impact: Cook was arguably the only reason Oakland managed to stay competitive. A clear favorite of Derek Carr's, Cook was surprisingly treated as an in-line receiver, even lining up in the slot at times. An early best ball favorite and undervalued TE2 with TE1 upside, Cook need be picked off waivers immediately if he's still available.
report: Raiders TE Jared Cook caught 9-of-12 targets for 180 yards in Monday's Week 1 loss to the Raiders.

impact: After a massive opening week to the season, Cook fell back in line with his career output, but was still tied for second on the team in targets. Catching 13-of-16 targets to open the season, Cook will remain a fringe TE1 entering Week 3 versus the Dolphins.
report: Jared Cook caught 4-of-4 targets for 49 yards in Sunday's Week 2 loss to the Broncos.

impact: Cook appeared to find the end zone for his first touchdown of the season in the third quarter, but replay review revealed he was down at the one. Cook has been the Raiders' only consistent pass catcher, notching at least four receptions every week out. He is proving to be a legitimate TE1 in his age-31 season.
report: Jared Cook caught 5-of-6 targets for 31 yards in the Raiders' Week 3 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: Cook dropped at least two targets, but he atoned with twin seven-yard scores and several chunk gains between the twenties.  Through four games, Cook leads the Raiders in every meaningful receiving category and has easily been the team's most-consistent pass catcher.  Cook has solidified himself as an every-week fantasy TE1 and will remain so in Week 5 against the Chargers.
report: Jared Cook caught 8-of-13 targets for 110 yards and two touchdowns in the Raiders' Week 4 win over Cleveland.

impact: Cooks' six targets on the day were still encouraging despite the results. It was always plausible this day would come given his history in boom-bust performances, too. Having said that, Cook again dropped another potential touchdown inside the 10-yard line. Given the landscape (a.k.a. wasteland) of tight ends in 2018, Cook remains a weekly matchup-proof TE1.
report: Jared Cook caught 4-of-6 targets for 20 yards in the Raiders' Week 5 loss to the Chargers.

impact: We're going to get outcomes like this when Derek Carr has no time to throw and is unwilling to make difficult throws, and both scenarios played out against the Seahawks.  Cook will enter the Raiders' Week 7 bye coming off two slow games.  He remains a huge part of the passing offense as an every-week TE1.
report: Jared Cook caught 2-of-2 targets for 10 yards in the Raiders' Week 6 loss to Seattle.

impact: Rookie second-round RB Ronald Jones will replace Wilson (healthy scratch) in his first regular season game action of the year. Incumbent starter Peyton Barber has mustered just 124 yards on 43 carries (2.8 YPC) this season and will likely now be thrusted into an underwhelming timeshare. With third-stringer Ryan Griffin inactive, the Bucs have no choice but to turn to Jameis Winston if Ryan Fitzpatrick struggles early against the Bears' terrifying pass rush.
report: Bucs declared RB Shaun Wilson, DT Beau Allen, G Alex Cappa, QB Ryan Griffin, OL Michael Liedtke, DE Noah Spence, and S Jordan Whitehead inactive for Week 4 against the Bears.

impact: That means a bigger role for rookie James Washington after Hunter played 51-of-84 snaps against the Browns in Week 1. Washington was on the field for just 11 plays. That will change against the Chiefs in what could be an extremely high-scoring game. If you're already in the deepest of binds, there's a case for Washington as a blindfold, dart throw WR5.
report: Steelers WR Justin Hunter is a healthy scratch for Week 2 against the Chiefs.

impact: Washington played just 11 snaps in Week 1 but was far more involved today with Justin Hunter a healthy scratch. Washington was targeted on the Steelers' first play from scrimmage and drew four looks in the first quarter, one of which was nullified by a Steelers penalty. The Steelers went away from the strategy as Washington's looks proved fruitless, though he did score a 14-yard touchdown late in the second quarter where a scrambling Ben Roethlisberger was almost entirely across the line of scrimmage. Washington is going to bust some big plays, but he's not currently re-draft relevant.
report: James Washington caught 1-of-5 targets for 14 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 2 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: Washington was stuck behind Justin Hunter in the season opener, but Hunter was a healthy scratch in Week 2. That allowed Washington to play a massive role in a game Ben Roethlisberger attempted 60 passes. He was inefficient with his work, catching just one of his five targets for 14 yards and a score, but the usage is promising.
report: James Washington played 66-of-82 (80 percent) snaps Week 2 against the Chiefs.

impact: Washington's four targets were behind Antonio Brown, JuJu Smith-Schuster, and Ryan Switzer. His usage has been down since his big Week 2, but the Steelers should look to get him more involved as the season progresses. Washington would be a plug-and-play WR2 if Brown or Smith-Schuster gets injured.
report: James Washington caught 2-of-4 passes for 10 yards in Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: Treadwell dropped his first target of the day on a third down, earning boos from the home crowd.  But he later answered with a nice 16-yard grab where he picked up some YAC and ran through an arm tackle.  Treadwell is unlikely to have any fantasy appeal unless Adam Thielen or Stefon Diggs gets hurt.
report: Laquon Treadwell caught 2-of-4 targets for 18 yards in the Vikings' Week 1 win over the 49ers.

impact: The day started out well for Treadwell, who caught the first touchdown of his career -- really -- in the first quarter. It was downhill from there, however. He dropped what would have been a third-down conversion in the third quarter, and he almost sabotaged the comeback attempt by letting a pass go right through his hands and into a DB's in the fourth quarter. He also ran the wrong route and dropped another pass in overtime. It would not be surprising if his playing time is scaled back moving forward.
report: Laquon Treadwell hauled in 2-of-6 targets for 23 yards and a touchdown in the Vikings' Week 2 tie with the Packers.

impact: Still reeling from hauling in his first career touchdown in Week 2, Treadwell reverted back to being the Vikings' fourth option in their passing game. Had Minnesota not been trailing 27-0 to start the second half, it's a wonder whether he would have even been asked to play all that much. With Adam Thielen (14-105 Sunday), Kyle Rudolph (5-48-1), and Stefon Diggs (4-17) locked into primary roles, Treadwell's good weeks will be far and few between.
report: Laquon Treadwell hauled in all four of his targets for 33 yards in the Vikings' Week 3 loss to the Bills.

impact: Half of his catches came on the Vikings’ final drive. Treadwell added to his league-leading drop total with another miscue in the third quarter. The 23-year-old has not come close to living up to expectations since entering the league as a first-round pick in 2016. He’ll be well off the fantasy radar in a difficult matchup next week against the Eagles.
report: Laquon Treadwell nabbed four-of-seven targets for 47 yards Thursday in Minnesota’s Week 4 loss to the Rams.

impact: Diggs beat Richard Sherman for a nice gain on his first catch of the day and then bested Ahkello Witherspoon for a 22-yard touchdown on a perfectly-placed ball by Kirk Cousins down the left sideline.  It was put only where Diggs could catch it.  Diggs' day was pretty quiet after the early second-quarter score.  Diggs will be on the WR1/2 borderline next week in Green Bay.
report: Stefon Diggs caught 3-of-6 targets for 43 yards and one touchdown in the Vikings' Week 1 win over the 49ers.

impact: Diggs already was having a fine fantasy day heading into the fourth quarter after converting a well-designed play at the goal line into his second touchdown of the season, but he did not settle for fine. With the Vikings trailing in the fourth, Diggs got loose down the field, and Kirk Cousins hit him with a beautiful pass for a 75-yard touchdown. He also absolutely worked the corner to get wide open on the game-tying two-point conversion late in the fourth quarter, and he added three more catches in overtime. Up to three scores on 19 targets through two games, Diggs will be a locked-in WR1 next week against the Bills.
report: Stefon Diggs hauled in 9-of-13 targets for 128 yards and two touchdowns in the Vikings' Week 2 tie with the Packers.

impact: Unlike teammates Adam Thielen (14-105) and Kyle Rudolph (5-48-1), Diggs was unable to benefit from the Vikings' second-half blitzkrieg following their 27-0 first half deficit. He's seen 29 targets through three games, highlighted by his Week 2 overtime performance (9-128-2) against the Packers. Kirk Cousins was unable to keep his eyes downfield as the Bills' defensive line completely surprised and crushed Minnesota's pass protection throughout the afternoon. There are better days ahead for Diggs, including more top-ten scoring weeks, as long as he stays healthy.
report: Stefon Diggs caught 4-of-10 targets for 17 yards in the Vikings' Week 3 loss to the Bills.

impact: Diggs was especially active in the first half, tallying seven of his 11 grabs before the break. He made an astounding catch for a 24-yard gain in the third quarter on a ball tipped by Rams cornerback Sam Shields. This was a nice bounce-back outing for Diggs coming off a sluggish 17-yard performance in last week’s loss to Buffalo. The 24-year-old of Minneapolis Miracle fame will draw a tough assignment next week against a stingy Eagles secondary.
report: Stefon Diggs chipped in with 11 catches for 123 yards on 15 targets Thursday in the Vikings’ Week 4 loss to the Rams.

impact: The 10-catch game was Diggs' second straight, while he's now drawn 10 targets in four straight games after a disappointing Week 1. He's cleared 90 yards in 3-of-5 contests. It has been Adam Thielen making the splash plays in the Vikings' receiver corps thus far, but it is only a matter of time before Diggs has a true blow-up game. He has stayed healthy and is seeing the requisite volume. The Vikings host the bottom-three Cardinals in Week 6.
report: Stefon Diggs caught 10-of-11 targets for 91 yards in the Vikings' Week 5 win over the Eagles, adding two carries for 25 additional yards.

impact: Diggs took a backseat to Adam Thielen, who accounted for over half of Kirk Cousins' yards. The five targets were the lowest he's seen all year. Diggs should rebound in a matchup with the Jets in Week 7.
report: Stefon Diggs caught 3-of-5 passes for 33 yards in Week 6 against the Cardinals.

impact: Adam Thielen hung a 9-110-1 day up on 10 targets while Diggs struggled in Morris Claiborne's coverage much of the afternoon.  Diggs was getting targets close to the line of scrimmage and had trouble getting anything after the catch.  The 14 targets were his second-most of the season.  Diggs will look to get back on track next week in a home game against the Saints.  The last time he saw them, in the playoffs, Diggs became a legend with the Minnesota Miracle.
report: Stefon Diggs caught 8-of-14 targets for 33 yards in the Vikings' Week 7 win over the Jets.

impact: Kelley was injured in Sunday's loss to the Colts. It sounds like he will be a candidate for return. Kelley must sit at least eight games. Samaje Perine will slot in as the Redskins' No. 3 back.
report: Redskins placed RB Rob Kelley on injured reserve with a toe injury.

impact: Thielen had a really quiet preseason but absolutely tore up the interior of the 49ers' defense, running a good majority of his routes out of the slot.  Thielen's 12 looks were five more than Dalvin Cook and six more than Stefon Diggs to lead the team.  His biggest grab was a 34-yard catch-and-run on third down when the 49ers didn't even cover him.  Thielen should have no trouble answering his breakout 2017 and will be a WR1 next week in Green Bay.
report: Adam Thielen caught 6-of-12 targets for 102 yards in the Vikings' Week 1 win over the 49ers.

impact: Stefon Diggs is getting his as well, but Thielen has been Kirk Cousins’ favorite receiver. He now has 25 targets through two games and, more importantly, came up with a great touchdown catch with defenders all around him to help tie this game late in the fourth quarter. He added a 25-yard catch in overtime to help set up one of the two missed field goals. With the Bills on deck, Thielen should remain locked into fantasy lineups.
report: Adam Thielen hauled in 12-of-13 targets for 131 yards and a touchdown in the Vikings' Week 2 tie with the Packers.

impact: Thielen benefited from negative game script as the Vikings found themselves down 27-0 for the entire second half of play. He's quietly accrued at least 12 targets and eclipsed the 100-yard mark in all three of Minnesota's games this season. Stefon Diggs (4-17 Sunday) remains a factor on the outside, seeing 10 targets against Buffalo, but it's clear who Cousins' favorite receiver between the duo is. Thielen again has the easier path to production Thursday in the slot against the Rams' stout outside corners.
report: Adam Thielen hauled in 14-of-19 targets for 105 yards in the Vikings' Week 3 loss to the Bills.

impact: Another night, another 100-yard receiving game for the ultra-consistent 28-year-old. Thielen was furious when the referee made him get checked for a concussion after taking a knee to the helmet in the third quarter, though he wound up missing just one play. The Minnesota State alum was the recipient of a 45-yard touchdown bomb from Kirk Cousins, losing Sam Shields (who was filling in for an injured Aqib Talib) for an easy score. Thielen’s 473 yards are the most by a Vikings receiver through four games in franchise history. He’ll look to continue his torrid start next week against the Eagles.
report: Adam Thielen corralled eight-of-12 targets for 135 yards and a touchdown Thursday in the Vikings’ Week 4 loss to the Rams.

impact: With the effort, Thielen becomes just the third player in league history to post 100 yards in each of his team's first five games. Thielen's season
report: Adam Thielen caught 7-of-10 targets for 116 yards and a touchdown in the Vikings' Week 5 win over the Eagles.

impact: It's the sixth straight game Thielen has went over 100 yards. The Vikings pass offense went through Thielen, who caught Kirk Cousins' only touchdown on a red-zone pass in the middle of the end-zone. He also had a highlight diving sideline catch in third quarter. Thielen has been the highest floor receiver in the league this year. He'll remain a locked-in WR1 for Week 7 against the Jets.
report: Adam Thielen caught 11-of-15 targets for 123 yards and a touchdown in the Vikings' Week 6 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Thielen got the scoring started with a 34-yard touchdown on the opening drive, beating backup-turned-starter CB Darryl Roberts as he was falling away in the end zone.  With his seventh-straight 100-yard game to open the season, Thielen has set a new record.  Thielen is an obvious elite WR1 and will be involved in a potential shootout next week at home against the Saints.
report: Adam Thielen caught 9-of-10 targets for 110 yards and one touchdown in the Vikings' 37-17, Week 7 win over the Jets.

impact: Bibbs was the Redskins' No. 2/change of pace with Chris Thompson sidelined. Thompson seemed close to suiting up this week, so Bibbs is not a compelling waiver wire add.
report: Kapri Bibbs rushed twice for 11 yards in the Redskins' Week 6 win over the Panthers, adding a six-yard reception.

impact: Without Chris Thompson for the second straight week, Bibbs again stepped in as Washington's No. 2 change-of-pace back. He showed his worth on Washington's first drive when he stretched a screen in the flats into a 23-yard touchdown scamper. His 43 receiving yards tied Jordan Reed's for the team lead. Bibbs has been out-carried by Adrian Peterson 41-4 over the last two games, though, and would need more consistent usage to be deemed a potential streamer moving forward. He's worthy of stashing in the event both Peterson and Thompson are ruled out later on.
report: Kapri Bibbs rushed two times for 16 yards, adding four catches for 43 yards and one touchdown through the air in the Redskins' Week 7 win over the Cowboys.

impact: A whopping 10 of Thompson’s career-high 13 receptions came after halftime with the Redskins playing from behind. Obviously Thompson had little success as a ball-carrier in this one but he was incredibly efficient as a pass-catcher, hauling in all but one of his 14 targets from Alex Smith. Through two games Thompson has shown zero ill effects from last year’s broken leg and already has the look of a PPR monster. He’ll be a flex consideration against the Packers in Week 3.
report: Chris Thompson rushed for just one yard on four carries but made up for that lack of production by snagging 13 catches for a team-leading 92 yards on 14 targets Sunday in the Redskins’ Week 2 loss to the Colts.

impact: Thompson stunningly drew just two targets on an afternoon where Alex Smith attempted only 20 passes. The Redskins' offense did not have to do much with the Packers making one mistake after another. Thompson should immediately bounce back when the Redskins come off bye against the Saints in Week 5.
report: Chris Thompson rushed six times for 17 yards in the Redskins' Week 3 win over the Packers, gaining zero yards on his lone reception.

impact: Thompson had to leave the game late in the fourth quarter with a ribs injury after Alex Smith threw him a hospital ball at the goal line on a two-point conversion attempt following a Kapri Bibbs rushing score.  The Redskins never got the ball back, and Thompson was announced as questionable to return.  Thompson was very good the first two weeks of the season but has managed just 34 rushing yards and 45 yards through the air on 21 scoreless touches the last two games.  He'll look to rebound next week at home against the Panthers as an RB3 if healthy.
report: Chris Thompson rushed eight times for 17 yards and caught 6-of-8 targets for 45 yards in the Redskins' Week 5 loss to the Saints.

impact: It gives Thompson a shot at suiting up against the Panthers, though he still has a long way to go. We knew Thompson would be listed with his ribs, but the knee is an unwelcome addition.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs, knee) was limited in Wednesday's practice.

impact: Thompson is still recovering from the rib injury that limited him in practice this week. There's been no real concern over his status. Thompson is coming off a rough two game stretch, but he's in a solid rebound spot against the Panthers.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs, knee) is questionable for Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: It is a bit of a surprise considering he was able to practice, albeit on a limited basis, all week. With Thompson out and Adrian Peterson banged up, Kapri Bibbs could see a surprising number of snaps. He is an option for fantasy teams desperate for a starter.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Chris Thompson (rib, knee) is not expected to play Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: As is Jamison Crowder (ankle). Thompson's absence leaves Adrian Peterson as the unquestioned lead dog in the Redskins' backfield, though change-of-pace Kapri Bibbs should get some decent run. With Crowder out, it will be Jordan Reed #szn against a Panthers defense that has struggled up the seam. Also inactive for the Redskins are OG Shawn Lauvao, DL Caleb Brantley, CB Adonis Alexander, S Troy Apke and OL Geron Christian.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs, knee) is inactive for Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: Thompson practiced all last week before being deactivated against the Panthers. A "full" session on Wednesday or Thursday would mean Thompson is returning against the Cowboys. Thompson was sorely missed against Carolina. Kapri Bibbs is not an effective player.
report: The Redskins consider Chris Thompson (knee, ribs) day to day.

impact: Thompson was limited last Wednesday before ultimately being inactive Week 6 against the Panthers.  It's too early to say if he'll play versus Dallas.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) was limited in Wednesday's practice.

impact: Thompson will be slapped with another "limited" tag. Thompson practiced last week before sitting out against the Panthers. There's a good chance Thompson returns against the Cowboys, but he could end up a game-time decision.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) practiced again on Thursday.

impact: Thompson looks on track to return after sitting last week. His status may not be known until game-time, so owners need to have backup plans in place. Thompson will be an RB3/FLEX is he plays.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs) is questionable for Week 7 against Dallas.

impact: It is the second week in a row Thompson has practiced all week but sat out the game. Kapri Bibbs should once again fill in as the change-of-pace option, but he saw just three touches last week on 37 percent of the snaps. If anything, Thompson sitting locks Adrian Peterson in as a solid RB2.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Chris Thompson (ribs, knee) is not expected to play Week 7 against the Cowboys.

impact: Thompson practice on a limited basis last week but was still inactive against the Cowboys, so it's too early to tell if he'll return this week against the Giants.  If Thompson does play, Kapri Bibbs would go back to No. 3 duties.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs, knee) was limited in Wednesday's practice.

impact: It's unclear what his level of participation was, though it's probably safe to assume he was limited again. Either way, Thompson should have a chance to return this week after sitting out the previous two games with rib and knee injuries. Even having not played the last two weeks, the fifth-year Florida State product still leads the Redskins in catches with 26.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs, knee) practiced again on Thursday.

impact: Thompson should be back this week after getting in limited work at practice. This matchup skews more towards Adrian Peterson, though the pass-catching back still merits flex consideration in PPR leagues, especially with so many teams on bye.
report: Chris Thompson (ribs, knee) is questionable for Week 8 against the Giants.

impact: Perine is a healthy scratch. Adrian Peterson will draw the start at running back against his former team with Chris Thompson spelling him on passing downs. LB Zach Brown (oblique), LB Ryan Kerrigan (hip), QB Colt McCoy (thumb) and OT Trent Williams (knee) are all active for Sunday's opener.
report: Redskins declared RB Samaje Perine, CB Adonis Alexander, DL Caleb Brantley, OL Geron Christian, C Casey Dunn, WR Maurice Harris and LB Josh Keyes inactive for Week 1 against the Cardinals.

impact: Peterson looks ready to roll for his return to New Orleans on Monday night.  He'll be a fine RB2 play in that matchup.  The final injury report will be out Saturday.
report: Adrian Peterson (ankle) is again practicing on Friday.

impact: Peterson was rested Wednesday, but practiced the last three days. He's healthy coming off Washington's bye and should see his normal workload. Peterson has a revenge narrative after getting traded from the Saints last year. He's our RB21 for Week 5.
report: Adrian Peterson (ankle) was removed from the Week 5 injury report.

impact: Peterson didn't touch the ball in the second half with the Redskins getting spanked up and down the field.  It was all Chris Thompson and Kapri Bibbs after the break.  Peterson was targeted on Alex Smith's first pass of the game and got his legs taken out on a true hospital ball from Smith that put Peterson right in the line of fire.  He limped badly to the sideline with a left knee issue and was checked for a hyperextension before shaking it off and coming back in.  Peterson will be an RB2/3 next week in a home date with the Panthers.
report: Adrian Peterson rushed four times for six yards and caught 2-of-3 targets for 36 yards in the Redskins' Week 5 loss to the Saints.

impact: Peterson will have an MRI on Tuesday, but he is not worried about the injury. "It's not going to keep me out," Peterson said. "I came back into the game. It was just a situation where it was sore." Peterson also suffered a knee injury in the first quarter, but he was able to play through that issue as well, although the injuries could explain why Kapri Bibbs was in at the goal line in the fourth quarter. At this point, it sounds like Peterson will be ready to face the Panthers on Sunday.
report: Adrian Peterson said he suffered a dislocated shoulder in Monday night's loss to the Saints.

impact: We wouldn't take Peterson's word for it. Players are notoriously optimistic about their injuries, and Peterson is a 33-year-old who could not finish Monday night's loss. He has a short week to get cleared to face the Panthers. If AD does play, he will be a borderline RB2.
report: Adrian Peterson is seeking a second opinion on his strained shoulder but expects to suit up for Week 6.

impact: Chris Thompson (ribs, knee) was also limited on Wednesday. Peterson has said he intends to play through his strained shoulder. This tentatively puts him on track to do so. His fantasy fortunes will depend on Thompson's health.
report: Adrian Peterson (ankle, knee, shoulder) was limited in Wednesday's practice.

impact: Peterson was listed as a limited participant at Wednesday's practice, which was actually a walk-through. The veteran is dealing with a myriad of minor injuries, though Peterson is adamant he'll be out there against the Panthers on Sunday. Game script has hurt Peterson in recent weeks as Washington continues to lean on pass-catcher Chris Thompson when playing from behind. That could be a problem again for him in Week 6.
report: Adrian Peterson (ankle, knee, shoulder) practiced again on Thursday.

impact: This was expected despite Peterson dislocating his shoulder in Monday night’s loss to the Saints. Peterson has a myriad of injuries, but he's expected to play this week. In a matchup that projects as a negative gameflow script, Peterson isn't more than a low-end RB2.
report: Adrian Peterson (ankle, knee, shoulder) is questionable for Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: Peterson is all kinds of banged up, but the 33-year-old plans to tough it out against Carolina. He should play a full complement of snaps including most passing downs with sidekick Chris Thompson (questionable, knee/rib) a long shot to play. Kapri Bibbs will handle change-of-pace duties with Thompson sidelined.
report: Adrian Peterson (questionable, ankle/knee/shoulder) is expected to play Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: Chris Thompson is out, meaning Peterson will have to carry the load in the Redskins' backfield. Peterson seems to be at far less than 100 percent, but his likely workload makes him a locked-in RB2. Kapri Bibbs is the pace changer.
report: Adrian Peterson (knee, ankle, shoulder) is active for Week 6 against the Panthers.

impact: Peterson failed to corral his lone target in the passing game. Although he was playing through knee, ankle and shoulder issues, Peterson looked no worse for the wear, routinely pushing the pile in a knock down, drag out game. Peterson's YPC is now up to 4.40. Provided he avoided setbacks with his various ailments, Peterson will be a low-end RB2 for next week's game with the Cowboys.
report: Adrian Peterson rushed 17 times for 97 yards in the Redskins' Week 6 win over the Panthers.

impact: Peterson was absent on Wednesday, though it seems like he was just getting a maintenance day. Peterson said he feels much better than he did a week ago, calling the difference "night and day." AD will be on the RB2 map Sunday when the Redskins host Dallas.
report: Adrian Peterson (ankle, shoulder) returned to a limited practice on Thursday.

impact: The Redskins managed Peterson's reps this week but he's expected to play. Peterson is an RB2 for Sunday's matchup with Dallas.
report: Adrian Peterson (ankle, shoulder) is questionable for Week 7 against the Cowboys.

impact: Peterson claims to be feeling much better than he did a week ago. That's good news because the Redskins will certainly need him with Chris Thompson (knee, ribs) on the shelf. Coming off a 97-yard performance in Week 6, AD should be treated as a volume-based RB2 in all fantasy leagues.
report: Adrian Peterson (questionable, ankle/shoulder) is expected to play against the Cowboys in Week 7.

impact: Peterson again led Washington's backfield in carries by a healthy margin without Chris Thompson available for the second consecutive week. All Day out-carried third-down back Kapri Bibbs 24-2 on Sunday, now having out-carried the latter 41-4 in the Redskins' last two games. He's bulldozed his way to 196 yards (4.78 YPC) in that span, too. If Thompson remains out in Week 8 against the Giants, Peterson will again be a clear-cut usage-based RB2.
report: Adrian Peterson handled a team-high 24 carries for 99 yards in Washington's Week 7 victory over the Cowboys.

impact: The Titans only have two available quarterbacks on their roster, so Mariota will be active whether he plays or not. He reportedly struggled to throw and grip the ball in warm-ups. If Mariota can't go or is limited, signal-calling duties would fall in the hands of backup Blaine Gabbert. WR Cameron Batson, OT Jack Conklin, DL Matt Dickerson, OT Dennis Kelly, S Kendrick Lewis, OT Taylor Lewan and LB Aaron Wallace round out the Titans' inactives for Week 2.
report: Marcus Mariota (elbow) is active for Week 2 against the Texans.

impact: Both Mariota and Blaine Gabbert are warming up during the Titans' pregame workout. With only two available quarterbacks on their roster, Mariota is active for Week 2. There has been no official announcement on Tennessee's starter.
report: Marcus Mariota (elbow) is warming up pregame for Tennessee's Week 2 matchup against the Texans.

impact: Per Vrabel, "there are still throws Mariota can't make." Mariota was active against the Texans but only on an emergency basis. Injuries have been a concern for Mariota each season of his four-year career. If he starts Week 3, it will be against the Jaguars' elite defense.
report: Speaking Monday, Titans coach Mike Vrabel said Marcus Mariota's (elbow) status hasn't changed.

impact: Mariota and Blaine Gabbert split the first-team reps in Wednesday's session, and coach Mike Vrabel said he'd continue to prepare both to play Sunday against the Jaguars.  Neither would be a fantasy option whatsoever.
report: Marcus Mariota (elbow) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: On Monday, coach Mike Vrabel said there were "still throws Mariota can't make," but the quarterback was able to practice on Wednesday and seems to be moving in the correct direction. "It’s really the whole hand, but the numbness and the tingliness is a couple fingers, the weakness is kind of the whole hand and that’s what I’ve been working on," Mariota said. "Honestly, I think it’s close." Mariota will likely come down to a game-time decision again this week, but he appears to have a much better shot to play.
report: Marcus Mariota said the nerve issue in his arm needs "time to settle down."

impact: According to the assembled press, Mariota was throwing the ball with more velocity. Neither Mariota nor coach Mike Vrabel have inspired much confidence about his Week 3 status, but it's looking like there's a legitimate chance he takes the reins back from Blaine Gabbert. If he does, Mariota will be facing the worst possible matchup in the Jaguars.
report: Marcus Mariota (elbow) practiced again on Thursday.

impact: Coach Mike Vrabel said Mariota's status is the "same" as last week. He'll reportedly decide on Mariota's availability for Sunday within the next 24 hours. No matter who starts under center, the Titans' offensive line is in store for immediate improvement with LT Taylor Lewan (concussion) cleared to play. Although he recorded a team-high target share from Gabbert in Week 2, Corey Davis ultimately needs Mariota at the helm to breakout.
report: Marcus Mariota (elbow) is questionable for Week 3 against the Jaguars.

impact: Blaine Gabbert is starting, but Mariota is available for backup duties.  Of course, they're the only two quarterbacks on Tennessee's roster.  Dealing with a nerve problem in his elbow that prevents him from fully gripping the ball, Mariota may still be weeks away from making his next official start.
report: Marcus Mariota (elbow) is active for Week 3 against the Jaguars.

impact: Coming off the bench to replace concussed Blaine Gabbert from the first quarter on, Mariota's passes consisted of wobbly, egg-beater floaters that were difficult for his receivers to catch.  Mariota is playing with a nerve problem in his throwing elbow.  But he showed impressive toughness, racking up yards on the ground and doing just enough to eke out the three-point win.  Mariota isn't roster worthy in 12-team leagues, but we would guess he'll start in Week 4 against Philadelphia.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 12-of-18 passes for 100 yards and rushed seven times for 51 yards in the Titans' Week 3 win over the Jaguars.

impact: Mariota was forced into Sunday's game against the Jaguars after Blaine Gabbert was concussed. It appears Mariota will start Week 4. Vrabel is hopeful the team can run a bigger package of plays this time around. The team will not sign a third quarterback, indicating it does indeed believe Mariota's health is getting better. Mariota will not be a viable QB2 against the Eagles' swarming defense.
report: Speaking Monday, Titans coach Mike Vrabel said there are still throws Marcus Mariota (elbow) can't make.

impact: It was an easy call for Vrabel with Blaine Gabbert in the concussion protocol. Mariota's elbow isn't 100 percent yet, but he was at least serviceable in Week 3, throwing for 100 yards on 12-of-18 passing against Jacksonville while adding seven carries for 51 rushing yards. He'll be backed up by Austin Davis, who was signed earlier this week.
report: Titans coach Mike Vrabel confirmed Marcus Mariota (elbow) will start Week 4 against the Eagles.

impact: Dealing with an elbow injury, Mariota had failed to top 103 yards in any game this season, but he looked quite a bit better in this one. Coming out firing, Mariota had 115 yards in the first quarter despite missing Corey Davis on what should have been a long gain, and he kept pushing the ball downfield all game. His newfound health did not stifle his rushing numbers, either, as he consistently made big plays on the ground. His magnum opus was a 16-play, 75-yard drive in overtime to win the game. He converted one fourth down with a great throw to Taywan Taylor, another with a dump off to Dion Lewis, and found Davis in the end zone for the game-winner. Now healthy, Mariota will be in the QB1 conversation next week in Buffalo.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 30-of-43 passes for 344 yards, two touchdowns, and an interception in the Titans' Week 4, overtime win over the Eagles, adding 46 yards and a touchdown on the ground.

impact: He only rushed twice for ten yards, although one was a hurdling doozy for a key first down.  Mariota was not helped by a back-breaking third-down drop by Nick Williams in the fourth quarter that would have gone for an easy touchdown, but Mariota also got away with numerous head-scratching throws when under duress.  Mariota heads back to Nashville in Week 6 for a brutal matchup versus Baltimore.  He has settled in as a dicey two-quarterback-league play.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 14-of-26 passes for 129 yards and an interception in the Titans' Week 5 loss at Buffalo.

impact: Mariota didn't stand a chance behind the Titans' O-line Sunday afternoon, losing 66 yards on a whopping 11 sacks taken. It was the second time in as many games that Tennessee's offense failed to score a touchdown, and the third time in the last four weeks that Mariota's failed to eclipse the daunting 130-yard mark. Even Corey Davis was dragged down in the Titans' woeful performance, hauling in just one catch for 24 yards. It's possible Mariota's playing through an ailing elbow injury suffered earlier in the year, but Coach Mike Vrabel's offense has still undoubtedly been one of the most disappointing units of 2018. The Titans will attempt to bounce back in Wembley against the Chargers next week.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 10-of-15 passes for 117 yards in the Titans' dreadful Week 6 loss to the Ravens.

impact: He added 38 yards on seven rushes. Mariota led the Titans to a game-tying fourth-quarter drive but failed to hit the two-point conversion. It was an improvement from last week, but Mariota continues to be a huge disappointment under a new coaching staff. The Titans had just three touchdowns in their last 45 drives going into Sunday. Mariota will be a QB2 coming out of the bye in Week 9 against the Cowboys.
report: Marcus Mariota completed 24-of-32 passes for 237 yards with a touchdown and an interception in Week 7 against the Chargers.

impact: He was sacked three times for a loss of eight yards. Smith was surgical in his Washington debut, cutting up the Cardinals with his usual precision on short and intermediate passes. The former Chief was so accurate, he completed 13 passes in a row at one point. Smith's favorite target seemed to be receiving back Chris Thompson, who he hooked up with six times for 63 yards and a touchdown. His longest completion came on a 52-yard screen to Adrian Peterson late in the fourth quarter, though AD admittedly did most of the work on that one. With the Redskins up big, Smith only attempted 10 passes after halftime. The 34-year-old could have some streaming appeal against a lackluster Colts secondary in Week 2.
report: Alex Smith completed 21-of-30 passes for 255 yards and a pair of touchdowns while adding 14 yards on eight carries Sunday in Washington’s Week 1 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Smith also lost 23 yards on three sacks. The Redskins’ offense was cooking against the Cardinals last week, but they never got going on Sunday, managing just three field goals in a home loss to Indy. Smith had a quiet first half but let it rip after halftime, tallying 195 of his 292 yards in the second half. Most of it came in garbage time on check-downs to Chris Thompson, though he did connect on a handful of deep balls. Smith and the Redskins will take a 1-1 record into next week’s home matchup against the Packers.
report: Alex Smith completed 33-of-46 passes for 292 yards with no touchdowns or interceptions while supplying 14 yards on four carries Sunday in Washington’s Week 2 loss to the Colts.

impact: He added seven rushes for 20 additional yards. Smith's lone highlight was his 46-yard touchdown strike to Paul Richardson in the first quarter. Smith and Richardson split the defense and Richardson made a diving catch between two defenders near the goal line. Untouched, Richardson got up and finished the job. After that, Smith was dinking and dunking and doing his signature take off and run on nearly every third down. Unable to hit any big plays, Smith and the Redskins kept the Packers in the game. Thankfully for the Redskins, the Packers ruined themselves with drops and penalties. Smith is off to a highly Smith-ian start so far this season but has an attackable Week 5 matchup in the Saints.
report: Alex Smith completed 12-of-20 passes for 220 yards, two touchdowns and an interception in the Redskins' 31-17, Week 3 win over the Packers.

impact: He added a four-yard rushing score, but Smith was far worse than his pedestrian numbers even suggest.  He did some stat-padding late in the blowout loss.  Smith threw multiple hospital balls to his targets in the pass game, getting both Adrian Peterson (knee) and Chris Thompson (ribs) injured, while also spiking numerous passes into the turf well short of his receivers.  Smith lost a hilariously-bad fumble that went about 20 feet into the air and backwards for an easy scoop for the Saints.  It's hard to believe how terrible the Redskins were coming out of their bye.  They're now on a short week ahead of a home game against Carolina.  Smith won't be a fantasy option.
report: Alex Smith completed 23-of-39 passes for 275 yards, no touchdowns, and one interception in the Redskins' 43-19, Week 5 loss to the Saints.

impact: He added five carries for 14 yards. Averaging an inexcusable 4.53 yards per attempt, Smith was mostly dreadful, but the Panthers could never make him pay by creating a turnover. The Redskins won on the back of their running game. Vernon Davis was schemed completely wide open on Smith's first score, though his second was a nice throw to Paul Richardson in the back of the end zone. With seven total touchdowns through five games, Smith will be a last-gasp QB2 against the Cowboys in Week 7.
report: Alex Smith completed 21-of-36 passes for 163 yards and two touchdowns in the Redskins' 23-17, Week 6 win over the Panthers.

impact: In vintage Smith fashion, his only score on the day came on a 23-yard screen pass to change-of-pace back Kapri Bibbs. No receiver topped 43 yards for Washington. Dallas' secondary admittedly presents a tough matchup, but it is the second straight week Smith's failed to exceed 175 passing yards. Given the club's run-first grind-it-out style of play, Smith should only be used in terrific matchups on paper -- like the one the Redskins face in Week 8 against the Giants.
report: Alex Smith completed 14-of-25 passes for 178 yards and one touchdown in Washington's Week 7 win over the Cowboys.

impact: LaFell is a healthy scratch after signing with the Raiders one week ago.  He may not know the playbook.  Washington is recovering from a knee scope.  Carradine is also a healthy inactive after starting 7-of-8 games last season and recording 1.5 sacks.  Nelson, also healthy, is a fourth-round rookie.
report: Raiders declared WR Brandon LaFell, RB DeAndre Washington, DE Tank Carradine, OT T.J. Clemmings, OT Justin Murray, DT Brian Price, and CB Nick Nelson inactive for Week 1 against the Rams.

impact: LaFell joined the Raiders a week ago but wasn't active for Monday's opener against the Rams. Even if he suits Sunday at Denver, the 31-year-old journeyman won't be of much use to fantasy owners.
report: Brandon LaFell (back) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: LaFell was limited to start the week but graduated to a full practice on Thursday, leading the Raiders to take him off their injury report. The ex-Bengal was a healthy scratch for Monday night's opener after signing just a week earlier, but will likely make his Raiders debut Sunday at Denver.
report: Brandon LaFell (back) wasn't listed on the Raiders' final injury report for Week 2 against the Broncos.

impact: LaFell is a healthy scratch. CB Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie (hamstring) and DT P.J. Hall (ankle) will both be active for Sunday's home matchup against Cleveland.
report: Raiders declared WR Brandon LaFell, LB Shilique Calhoun, DL Tank Carradine, OT T.J. Clemmings, S Karl Joseph, OT Justin Murray and RB DeAndre Washington inactive for Week 4 against the Browns.

impact: Nelson finished third on the team in targets behind Jared Cook (12) and Jalen Richard (11). Compared to Amari Cooper's pedestrian 1-9 receiving line, Nelson's performance was outstanding. Until further notice, Nelson (and all of Oakland's wideouts for that matter) can't be trusted.
report: Jordy Nelson caught 3-of-4 targets for 23 yards in the Raiders' Week 1 loss to the Rams.

impact: Nelson caught a 23-yard pass on the second offensive play of the game then all but disappeared afterwards. He has now posted 35 receiving yards or less in 11 consecutive games dating back to last season. Nelson is not a starting option Week 3 versus the Dolphins.
report: Jordy Nelson caught 2-of-4 targets for 30 yards in Sunday's Week 2 loss to the Broncos.

impact: Nelson more than tripled his season yardage total. He went 2/73/1 on the Raiders' opening drive, capping it off by getting completely free in the end zone for a 12-yard score. 139 of Nelson's yards came in the first six minutes. He was obviously much quieter thereafter, but it was more than enough to keep Nelson on the fantasy radar. With the Raiders rotating big receiver days, Nelson will be a WR3/4 for Week 4 against the Browns.
report: Jordy Nelson caught 6-of-8 targets for 173 yards and a touchdown in the Raiders' Week 3 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: Nelson has turned it up since the Raiders moved him to slot receiver two games ago, shredding Cleveland and Miami for a combined 11/221/2 stat line.  He tacked on a pair of two-point conversions in Sunday's overtime win.  Nelson has earned WR3/flex treatment entering a Week 5 date with the Chargers.
report: Jordy Nelson has caught 5-of-8 targets for 48 yards and a touchdown in the Raiders' Week 4 win over the Browns.

impact: This was a very disappointing outcome in a game where Amari Cooper (concussion) and Seth Roberts (concussion) both went down.  Derek Carr refused to pull the trigger on difficult throws, however, and Seattle's pass rush dominated Oakland's beat-up offensive line.  Nelson will emerge from the Raiders' Week 7 bye as a shaky WR3/flex option.
report: Jordy Nelson caught 2-of-3 targets for six yards in Week 6 versus Seattle.

impact: It's an upset after the Raiders traded for Martavis Bryant and Ryan Switzer, but neither addition worked out, to put it mildly. It's a shame for both Amari Cooper and Jordy Nelson, who could have benefitted from more snaps in the middle of the field. Hopefully new coach Jon Gruden will work to move Cooper around the formation like ex-OC Todd Downing finally did near the end of last season.
report: Seth Roberts will remain the Raiders' slot receiver.

impact: It means Amari Cooper is going to see more snaps out of the slot, buttressing his floor. It also means Martavis Bryant is going to play more snaps. Coach Jon Gruden actually seems to have a shrewd understanding of his offensive personnel, but one of the reasons that personnel is so bad is because of his brutal offseason roster management.
report: Raiders WR Seth Roberts is a healthy scratch for Week 3 against the Dolphins.

impact: After losing Amari Cooper (concussion), the Raiders are down to Jordy Nelson, Martavis Bryant, and Dwayne Harris at wide receiver.  Roberts immediately went to the locker room after suffering his fourth-quarter brain injury.  The slot receiver had five catches for 31 yards on six targets before departing.
report: Raiders WR Seth Roberts left Sunday's Week 6 game with a concussion.

impact: Roberts had the bye week to rest up after his Week 6 concussion. With Amari Cooper gone, Roberts is in line for an expanded role. He should get cleared for Sunday's game with the Colts.
report: Seth Roberts (concussion) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: With Amari Cooper out the picture, Roberts is in line to start alongside Martavis Bryant and Jordy Nelson in three-wide sets moving forward. He's shown a knack for the end zone when given run with the team, but still can't be started at this time. Bryant is the likeliest to play a large role against the Colts Sunday.
report: Seth Roberts (concussion) wasn't listed on the Raiders' final injury report for Week 8 against the Colts.

impact: He's not currently on the active roster; that's why. He is now listed under the Reserve/Franchise Player section. Carry on.
report: Le'Veon Bell was removed from the Steelers' active roster on the team website.

impact: They're satisfied with what James Conner has given the offense through two games and are looking to move on from the Bell situation, which has caused major off-field distractions.  Bell has shown no intention of wanting to play anytime soon, seemingly more concerned with his musical career than football during the prolonged holdout.  Any team interested in trading for Le'Veon would almost certainly want to work out a long-term deal before the move is made, and that creates several different obstacles to work around, including Bell's suspension and injury histories in addition to what's left of his commitment to playing football.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports the Steelers are now listening to trade offers for holdout RB Le'Veon Bell.

impact: Per reporter Manish Mehta, the Jets have "not made a concrete offer," but they believe the Steelers are "serious" about trading their running back. ESPN's Adam Schefter first reported Bell was available on Sunday. The Jets are the first team to be linked.
report: The New York Daily News reports the Jets have "reached out" to the Steelers about acquiring holdout unsigned franchise player Le'Veon Bell.

impact: Initially the Steelers were just "listening" on offers for Bell, but now they're the ones making calls. Per Rapsheet, the Steelers are looking for at least a second-round pick and a "good player" in exchange for Bell. That's a high asking price for a rental, especially considering Bell can't negotiate an extension until after the season. James Conner will continue to serve as Pittsburgh's workhorse with Bell MIA.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports the Steelers are "actively shopping" holdout RB Le'Veon Bell.

impact: The 1-2-1 Steelers host the Falcons and visit the Bengals before their open date, so James Conner appears to have two more weeks atop the depth chart.  He's been wholly unimpressive since his huge Week 1 and okay Week 2.  Over the last two games, Conner has rushed 24 times for 80 scoreless yards.  He's been helping in the pass game with and 18-164-0 receiving line, but it's become very evident that Bell is the far superior player.  Bell will evidently play the final 10 games (and the playoffs, if they make it) and then head to free agency next March.
report: ESPN's Jeremy Fowler reports holdout Le'Veon Bell is expected to report to the Steelers during their Week 7 bye.

impact: This comes after the report that Bell plans to end his holdout during the Steelers' Week 7 bye, which falls just ahead of the trade deadline.  If the Steelers want to compete for a Super Bowl and turn their season around, it would be in their best interest to keep Bell.  James Conner has been pretty underwhelming much of the past three weeks.  The Steelers would already get a compensatory pick in 2020 if Bell decides to walk as a free agent next spring, which is the expectation.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports the Steelers are still "expected to be interested in listening to trade offers" for holdout Le'Veon Bell.

impact: Bell reportedly plans to return to the team during the Week 7 bye, but the coach is not looking that far ahead. "We'll cross that bridge when we come to it," Tomlin said. "Nothing has changed from my perspective in that regard." It is exactly what an NFL coach is expected to say, but it is notable after ESPN's Adam Schefter reported the Steelers are still listening to trade offers despite Bell's plan to return. Bell is going to play this year, but it remains possible it is not with the Steelers.
report: Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said, "I have not talked to Le'Veon [Bell] and I really have no Le'Veon update."

impact: This is speculation from Bouchette, but he quizzed players in the locker room on the topic and makes several important points.  Most important is the fact that Bell is concerned about his workload, not wanting to be overused by the Steelers as he prepares for 2019 free agency.  Conner has been terrific in Bell's absence, more than earning a role in this potential RBBC.  Bell also struggled initially to get into football shape following his 2017 training camp holdout.
report: The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette's Ed Bouchette suggests Le'Veon Bell and James Conner could be used in a committee when Bell ends his holdout.

impact: Bell singled out the Eagles as a potential destination spot for himself when he spoke to ESPN's Jeremy Fowler last week, but the Eagles don't appear to be willing to pay the Steelers' asking price and then hand Bell a gargantuan contract.  With Jay Ajayi done for the year with a torn ACL, the Eagles' initial plan looks to be to lean on Corey Clement and Wendell Smallwood.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports the Eagles "have not pursued a trade" for holdout Le'Veon Bell and "have no plans to do so."

impact: Most reports suggest the disgruntled running back will end his holdout during the Steelers' upcoming bye week, though no one in the organization has heard from him yet. James Conner has performed admirably in Bell's absence, drawing praise from Ben Roethlisberger, who believes Conner should maintain a large role in the Steelers' offense even when Bell eventually comes back. When it comes to Bell and his return, the Steelers remain in "wait-and-see mode."
report: According to ESPN's Adam Schefter, holdout RB Le'Veon Bell has had "no contact" with the Steelers despite his expected return in Week 7.

impact: Bell will supposedly report to the team this week, but the Steelers remain in the dark about his plans. Even if he does, Pittsburgh could decide to pursue a roster exemption for Bell, potentially keeping him on the sidelines and reducing his pay. The Steelers are also expected to keep utilizing James Conner even once Bell returns, limiting the star's fantasy upside. This situation continues to be an absolute mess.
report: NFL Network's Aditi Kinkhabwala reports there has been "no sign of" Le'Veon Bell at the Steelers' facility on Monday.

impact: Just because the Steelers "aren't expecting" it doesn't mean it's not going to happen, as Bell has routinely left the team out of the loop on his plans.  A couple weeks back, ESPN's Jeremy Fowler reported Bell planned to report during the Week 7 bye, which is now.  We'll continue to be on Bell Watch until/if he does report.  The Steelers don't play again for 13 more days.
report: The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette's Ed Bouchette reports the Steelers don't expect holdout Le'Veon Bell to report to the team this week.

impact: Bell was thought to be targeting Week 8 for his return but now that seems unlikely. It appears Bell is waiting to see what happens at next week's trade deadline before ending his holdout. The disgruntled running back can't be traded until he signs his franchise tender, though the Steelers could get around this by granting a trade partner permission to speak with him. The Eagles would seem to be the best fit for Bell given their need at running back, though the sides haven't made much progress in recent trade discussions. When Bell reaches free agency in 2019, he'll reportedly be seeking a long-term deal worth $17 million annually with "heavy guarantees."
report: According to Jason La Canfora of CBS Sports, Steelers executives believe it's "more likely" holdout RB Le'Veon Bell returns in Week 9.

impact: Bell had been expected to return during the bye week, but Jason La Canfora reported Sunday it is "more likely" the running back returns to the team ahead of Week 9. It seems like no one except Bell really knows when he plans to report, and it remains possible he takes his holdout all the way through Week 10, after which he has to report to earn an accrued season and become a free agent. It appears as if James Conner will get at least one more game if not more of workhorse usage.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports Le'Veon Bell did not report to the team on Monday morning.

impact: Bell told ESPN a few weeks ago that he would report to the team between Weeks 7 and 8.  Instead, he's going to stay away at least one more week.  On Monday, NFL Network's Ian Rapoport suggested Bell will hold out through at least the October 31 trade deadline before reporting to the Steelers.  James Conner will continue to operate as Pittsburgh's every-down back in the meantime.
report: Le'Veon Bell's holdout will continue through Week 8.

impact: Dalvin Cook played every snap of the first two series before Murray opened the third series and then handled much of the clock-killing work in the fourth quarter.  Neither back found the end zone, while Murray wasn't targeted in the pass game.  Murray is little more than a handcuff to Cook owners.
report: Latavius Murray rushed 11 times for 42 yards in the Vikings' Week 1 win over the 49ers.

impact: Murray was stuck on two carries before Dalvin Cook left with a hamstring injury in overtime. That issue is reportedly minor -- Cook described it as a cramp -- but it is enough to keep Murray on fantasy rosters for now. That said, he is nothing more than a handcuff.
report: Latavius Murray rushed four times for 19 yards in the Vikings' Week 2 tie with the Packers.

impact: Oof. What initially appeared to be the perfect game script situation for Murray turned out to be an absolute nightmare for the Vikings' offense. Minnesota's offensive line was a travesty throughout the afternoon, allowing Kirk Cousins to be blindsided and fumble on the team's first two offensive possessions. By the time the Vikings got the ball back for their third possession, they were already staring down the barrel of a 17-0 deficit. Minnesota's backfield received a paltry four carries on the day, totaling 12 rushing yards (3.0 YPC). Murray's five catches fortunately salvaged what could've been an even bigger disaster of an outing. Dalvin Cook is expected to return on Thursday against the Rams.
report: Latavius Murray rushed two times for one yard and added five catches for 30 receiving yards in the Vikings' Week 3 loss to the Bills.

impact: Even with lead back Dalvin Cook on a pitch count in his return from a hamstring injury, Murray failed to make an impact. Minnesota essentially abandoned its running game playing from behind in the second half, which obviously didn’t help matters. Murray’s biggest contribution came when he converted a two-point conversion on a screen pass from Kirk Cousins late in the third quarter. Latavius has managed just three yards on four carries over his last two games and won’t be an appealing fantasy option against the Eagles in Week 5.
report: Latavius Murray collected just two yards on two carries while adding two catches for 16 yards on two targets Thursday in Minnesota’s Week 4 loss to the Rams.
