impact: It was yet another disappointing affair for a player who is now averaging 3.53 yards per carry. Ominously, Murray ceded both a red zone target and goal line carry to "Roc Thomas." If Dalvin Cook (hamstring) can ever get healthy, Murray might have a hard time carving out a role. For now, Cook seems unlikely to play in Week 6, leaving Murray in the desperation FLEX mix against the Cardinals.
report: Latavius Murray rushed 11 times for 42 yards in the Vikings' Week 5 win over the Eagles, adding two receptions for 14 additional yards.

impact: With Dalvin Cook out, Murray rebounded from his disappointing Week 5. He ripped the Cardinals for three 20-plus yard runs, with his touchdown coming on a highlight 21-yarder where he stiff-armed into the end-zone. Murray came into Sunday averaging just 3.5 YPC, but he made a case for a role when Dalvin Cook returns. Cook would be a plug-and-play RB2 if Cook isn't back for Week 7.
report: Latavius Murray rushed 24 times for 155 yards and a touchdown in the Vikings' Week 6 win over the Cardinals.

impact: He added two catches for 14 yards on a pair of targets.  Murray's first score was an 11-yard scamper up the middle, and the second was an untouched run through the left side from 38 yards away.  With Dalvin Cook still struggling to get healthy, Murray has emerged as a strong RB2 with reliable workloads.  If Cook sits again, Murray will again be in play Week 8 against the Saints.
report: Latavius Murray rushed 15 times for 69 yards and two touchdowns in the Vikings' Week 7 win over the Jets.

impact: Conner had one blip on his resume with a fumble in the 4th quarter that let the Browns back in the game, but other than that, had a dominant game as a dual purpose back. Conner had an untouched 4-yard rushing score in the 2nd quarter and then a 22-yard touchdown run in the 3rd quarter. On top of his performance, no other Steeler RB even registered a touch in the game. As long as Le'Veon Bell continues his hold out, Conner is a RB1 for fantasy purposes.
report: Steelers RB James Conner rushed 31 times for 135 yards and two touchdowns while catching 5-of-6 targets for 57 yards in Sunday's Week 1 game versus the Browns.

impact: With the Steelers down 21-0 by the end of the first quarter, they never bothered to establish the run. Conner missed some time with an injury, but the Steelers never announced what was bothering him. Stevan Ridley ran in his place. Conner was on the field to finish the game. Provided Le'Veon Bell does not report this week, Conner will again be a usage-based RB1 for Week 3 against the Bucs.
report: James Conner rushed eight times for 17 yards and a touchdown in the Steelers' Week 2 loss to the Chiefs, adding five receptions for 48 additional yards.

impact: The Steelers had a chance to establish Conner even further with a 30-10 lead heading into the third quarter, but were ultimately forced to try and match the Bucs' second-half onslaught and stick to passing against Tampa Bay's funnel defense. Conner was still involved out of the backfield, hauling in 5-of-6 targets on the day. With no real threat behind him, Conner remains a usage-based RB1 no matter the matchup.
report: James Conner rushed 15 times for 61 yards and added five catches for 34 yards in the Steelers' Week 3 win over the Bucs.

impact: Conner fell victim to gameflow with the Ravens winning time of possesion. The Steelers went pass-heavy after getting behind early and didn't have any red-zone trips. Conner managed to catch a two-point conversion to save his night, but it was still his worst game to date. Conner will be an RB2 for Week 5 against the Falcons.
report: James Conner rushed nine times for 19 yards and caught 3-of-7 targets for 25 yards in Week 4 against the Ravens.

impact: "It’s just like quarterbacks, too," Fichtner continued.  "You get into a rhythm.  And all good running backs, they need that rhythm."  Conner has been a relative disappointment Weeks 2-4 following his huge opener.  Over the last three games, Conner has rushed 24 total times for 97 yards and one touchdown, adding 13 catches.  The catch numbers are nice, but that's not a Le'Veon Bell-type workload on the ground after Conner went 31-135-2 as a runner in Week 1.  This week presents a huge get-right spot for Conner and the Steelers offense against a depleted Falcons team with the highest game total of 2018 at 58 points.
report: Steelers OC Randy Fichtner admitted he "probably just needs to do a better job heating up" James Conner with more carries early in games.

impact: Conner touched the ball seven times for 72 yards and a score on the opening drive and never looked back. He was piling on yards after first contact against the Falcons' injury-ruined defense. Conner has now hit 185 yards from scrimmage in 2-of-5 games, though he's totaled just 204 yards across his other three contests. Thankfully for his fantasy owners, the Bengals are an attackable Week 6 matchup. The Steelers then go on bye in Week 7. That is when Le'Veon Bell is expected to finally return.
report: James Conner rushed 21 times for 110 yards and two touchdowns in the Steelers' Week 5 win over the Falcons, adding four receptions for 75 additional yards.

impact: "I think Le’Veon’s one of the best in the business, I think we all understand that and can agree on that," Roethlisberger said.  "But when Le’Veon comes back, in no way, shape or form should James just say, ‘OK, it’s all yours.  I’m gonna sit back and when you need me, use me.’  And I will push for James to get as much run as we can because we’ve seen some great things from him in all phases of football.  He’s picking up blitzes, he’s catching the ball, he’s running hard and making plays and playing with a passion, so we need to keep using that."  If Ben wants it, he usually gets it.  Conner seems certain to retain a prominent role when Bell returns, which is expected to be for Week 8.
report: Ben Roethlisberger said James Conner "should not go on the shelf by any means" if/when Le'Veon Bell ends his holdout.

impact: He added four catches for 18 yards on seven targets.  The NFL's leading tackle-shedder, Conner showed it in this one, consistently bulldozing would-be tacklers and injuring a couple along the way as S Shawn Williams was concussed on one of the long runs.  Conner's scores were both of the one-yard plunge variety.  He should have had a third touchdown but was ruled down at the one before getting stuffed on 1st- and 3rd-and-goal runs.  A premier RB1, Conner's workload will now be subject to question with Le'Veon Bell expected to report to the team during the Week 7 bye.
report: James Conner rushed 19 times for 111 yards and two touchdowns in the Steelers' 28-21, Week 6 win over the Bengals.

impact: Jones is a healthy scratch coming off a dreadful preseason. With Jones absent, the Bucs will roll with Jacquizz Rodgers behind starter Peyton Barber. OT Donovan Smith (knee), OL Evan Smith (hip) and CB M.J. Stewart (foot) are all active for Sunday's opener.
report: Buccaneers declared RB Ronald Jones, OL Alex Cappa, OL Adam Gettis, CB Brent Grimes, OL Mike Liedtke, DT Vita Vea and WR Justin Watson inactive for Week 1 against the Saints.
source_text: Tampa Bay Buccaneers Communications on Twitter

impact: Jones is buried on the depth chart as what amounts to Tampa Bay's No. 4 running back behind Peyton Barber, Jacquizz Rodgers, and Shaun Wilson.  With Vea again on the shelf, the Bucs are missing their top-two draft picks for a second straight week.
report: Bucs declared RB Ronald Jones, OLs Alex Cappa and Michael Liedtke, WR Justin Watson, DE Noah Spence, DT Vita Vea, and CB Brent Grimes inactive for Week 2 against the Eagles.

impact: Although Peyton Barber has struggled in efficiency, second-round RB Jones failed to crack the Bucs' active list for the third consecutive game. Tampa Bay will roll with Jacquizz Rodgers and Shaun Wilson behind Barber. First-round DT Vea was limited in practice throughout the week and out Monday but is reportedly close to returning to help shore up the Bucs' trenches. Starting CB Brent Grimes (groin) is active for Monday night.
report: Bucs declared rookie RB Ronald Jones, DT Vita Vea, DT Beau Allen, CB Marcus Williams, OL Alex Cappa, OL Mike Liedtke, and WR Justin Watson inactive for Week 3 against the Steelers.

impact: Jones was a healthy scratch the first three weeks. With Peyton Barber struggling, he'll be thrown into Tampa's backfield mix.  Jones had a rough preseason, but there's not much in his way for touches.
report: Bucs rookie RB Ronald Jones is expected to be active for Week 4.

impact: It was the rookie's regular season debut. With Tampa Bay trailing 38-3 at the half, Jones and teammate Peyton Barber never stood a chance on the ground. One positive takeaway is that Jones out-touched Barber 11-8 and led the Buccaneers in rushing yards (29). He'll likely be the first man up when the Bucs return from their Week 5 bye.
report: Ronald Jones handled 10 carries for 29 yards in the Bucs' Week 4 loss to the Bears.

impact: The total was 11 fewer than Peyton Barber, but the rookie out-touched Barber 11-8 and led the team in rushing, albeit with a measly 29 yards. Barber has not shown much of anything over the first month, so it would not be surprising if Jones emerges from the bye week as the lead back.
report: Ronald Jones played 20-of-63 snaps (32 percent) Week 4 against the Bears.

impact: There was some hope Jones would emerge from the bye with a bigger role, but that did not happen. Peyton Barber both started and worked as the clear lead back. Jones appeared to be the back of choice in passing situations throughout the game, but Barber was in late and ended up with a receiving score. Jones is just a bench stash at this point.
report: Ronald Jones rushed once for three yards and hauled in all three of his targets for 16 yards in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Jones was hardly used until Peyton Barber appeared to suffer an injury in the third quarter. After that, he tallied five of his six touches in the game, including a 2-yard rushing score set up by a long O.J. Howard reception. Jones may get an uptick if Barber is indeed injured heading into Week 8, but he is only a FLEX option at best when the Bucs head to Cincinnati.
report: Ronald Jones rushed six times for 13 yards and a touchdown while catching his lone target for 15 yards in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: Peyton Barber didn't practice with an undisclosed injury.  That left Jones and Shaun Wilson along with special-teamer and pass-pro specialist Jacquizz Rodgers.  If Barber is unable to play Sunday, Jones would enter the RB3/FLEX mix, but the Bucs' way to move the ball is obviously through the air as one of the most pass-heavy teams in the league.  It's a situation to monitor.
report: Rondald Jones handled the "majority" of the first-team reps at Wednesday's practice.

impact: He wasn’t targeted in the passing game. Barber impressed in the first half, tallying 50 yards on eight carries before the break. His longest run of the afternoon came on a 23-yard burst with just over four minutes remaining in the first quarter. Tampa Bay built a big lead and tried to salt the clock by feeding it to Barber, though that approach mostly backfired as the Saints limited him to just 19 yards on 11 second-half carries (1.72 yards per attempt). Barber out-touched backup Jacquizz Rodgers by a commanding 19-3 margin in the victory while further establishing himself as the Bucs’ clear lead back. He’ll be a mere RB3 in a tough matchup with Philadelphia in Week 2.
report: Peyton Barber logged 69 yards on 19 carries Sunday in Tampa Bay’s Week 1 victory over the Saints.

impact: He has 91 yards on 35 carries this season; "good" for 2.6 yards per rush.  That isn't going to cut it for the Bucs' running game, making it imperative for them to give rookie Ronald Jones a longer look on the practice field this week.  Barber will remain a touchdown-or-bust flex option in Week 3 versus Pittsburgh.
report: Peyton Barber managed 22 yards on 16 carries and caught 1-of-2 targets for seven yards in the Bucs' Week 2 win over the Eagles.

impact: With Tampa Bay having no initial answer to the Steelers' 30-point first half, Barber was essentially game-scripted out of this one as soon as it began. Barber won't accrue check-down targets at the line of scrimmage given OC Todd Monken's exhilarating play-calling and, at the time, he's mustered only 124 yards on 43 carries (2.8 YPC) this season. The days until second-round rookie Ronald Jones, who may struggle in his own right, is active are dwindling.
report: Peyton Barber rushed eight times for 33 yards in the Bucs' Week 3 loss to the Steelers.

impact: Second-round rookie Ronald Jones was also active, and promptly took his place at the table, out-touching Barber 11-8. Jones also led the Bucs in rushing yards (29) on an otherwise porous day from both. Tampa Bay will likely come out of their Week 5 bye with Jameis Winston and Ronald Jones as starters, seemingly making Barber droppable across all formats.
report: Peyton Barber rushed seven times for 24 yards in the Bucs' Week 4 loss to the Bears.

impact: There was some thought (hope) Ronald Jones would take on a bigger role coming out of the bye, but that did not materialize. Barber started and worked as the clear lead back. Jones seemed to be getting snaps in passing situations, but Barber was on the field late in the game and came down with a five-yard touchdown. Barber will face a tougher test next week against the Browns, but he will be a FLEX option.
report: Peyton Barber rushed 13 times for 82 yards and hauled in all four of his targets for 24 yards and a touchdown in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Barber failed to secure either of his two targets in the passing game. He appeared to injure his ankle on his final target of the game in the third quarter and although the Bucs provided no update on his status in game, he never returned to the field the rest of the way. Barber's status will be one to monitor early in the week, but even if he is good to go in Week 8, he is at best a low-level FLEX option on the road against the Bengals.
report: Peyton Barber rushed 11 times for 30 yards in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: "We'll be putting out an injury report on Wednesday," the embattled Koetter said as he sought a #CompetitiveAdvantage on the Bengals for Week 8. The Bengals will undoubtedly be having sleepless nights until they learn Barber's status. Ronald Jones is the next man up.
report: Speaking Monday, coach Dirk Koetter confirmed Peyton Barber picked up an injury late in the Bucs' overtime win over the Browns but declined to disclose its nature.

impact: The Bucs are listing him with an ankle injury. At this point, he has to be considered truly 50-50 for Week 8 against the Bengals. With Barber out on Wednesday, Ronald Jones handled the bulk of the first-team reps.
report: Peyton Barber (ankle) did not practice Wednesday.

impact: Barber was "limited," but it puts him on track to play against the Bengals. A usage-based fantasy option, Barber will be on the RB2/3 borderline if he suits up.
report: Peyton Barber (ankle) returned to Bucs practice on Thursday.

impact: Barber has been a relative disappointment, though hopes were never that high for him in this pass-heavy offense.  He's nothing more than a last-ditch RB3.
report: Coach Dirk Koetter confirmed Peyton Barber (ankle) is "good to go" for Week 8 against the Bengals.

impact: With Dalvin Cook (hamstring) still sidelined, Thomas got a shot as the Vikes' No. 2 back behind Latavius Murray. He drew a red zone target and goal line carry. Perhaps the Jacksonville State UDFA is worth an add in the deepest of Dynasty leagues.
report: Roc Thomas rushed four times for eight yards in the Vikings' Week 5 win over the Eagles, adding a six-yard reception.

impact: Filling in for a suspended Jameis Winston, Fitzpatrick was sensational in his season debut, embarrassing the Saints on their home turf. The Harvard man was especially dominant in the first half, completing 11-of-14 passes for 210 yards and two touchdowns before the break while submitting a perfect 158.3 quarterback rating. The Saints’ secondary looked out of sorts on Sunday and Fitzpatrick took full advantage of their ineptitude by hurling four touchdowns including a 58-yard seed to DeSean Jackson on the Bucs’ opening drive. That was the first of two scores for D-Jax, who registered 146 yards on five catches. FitzMagic was also Tampa’s second-leading rusher and sealed the game with a 12-yard scramble late in the fourth quarter. It’s doubtful the 35-year-old will overtake Winston for the starting job but he’s certainly worked his way into the streaming conversation. Even in a daunting matchup against the Eagles next week, he could be worth a try.
report: Ryan Fitzpatrick completed 21-of-28 passes for a career-high 417 yards with four touchdowns and no interceptions while adding 36 yards and a touchdown on 12 carries Sunday in the Buccaneers’ Week 1 win over the Saints.

impact: Bucs playcaller Todd Monken came out as aggressive as ever, calling a play-action bomb on the first play from scrimmage.  DeSean Jackson smoked Jalen Mills and scored from 75 yards out.  O.J. Howard added a 75-yard catch-and-run TD, and Chris Godwin and Mike Evans both chipped in red-zone scores.  Firing on all cylinders in an entertaining offense, Fitzpatrick has earned QB1 treatment ahead of next Monday night's home date with Pittsburgh.  As the Bucs have started 2-0, it's becoming very fair to wonder if Fitzpatrick will keep the starting quarterback job when Jameis Winston's suspension ends in Week 4.
report: Ryan Fitzpatrick completed 27-of-33 passes for 402 yards, four touchdowns, and one interception in the Bucs' Week 2 win over the Eagles.

impact: This has been the Bucs' party line since August. In the interim, Ryan Fitzpatrick McGregor has gone completely ballistic, becoming just the third quarterback in league history with back-to-back 400-yard, four-touchdown performances. Fitzpatrick has another potential shootout foil for Week 3 in the Steelers. Working in Fitz's favor for Week 4 is that the Bucs will be on a short week after playing on Monday Night Football. Winston's time with the Bucs is at a crossroads. The franchise seems to have lost faith in him amidst his off-the-field issues.
report: Speaking Monday, Bucs coach Dirk Koetter declined to commit to Jameis Winston as the team's starting quarterback when he comes off suspension in Week 4.

impact: Fitzpatrick wasn't listed last week so it's a new "injury." There's been zero indication Fitz will be slowed against the Steelers, where, inexplicably, he can be fired up as a QB1 streamer.
report: Ryan Fitzpatrick is listed on the Week 3 injury report with a knee issue but is practicing in full.

impact: The Bucs listed Fitzpatrick with a knee injury earlier in the week, but he practiced fully. Fitzpatrick is our No. 9-ranked quarterback for Monday night's matchup with the Steelers.
report: Ryan Fitzpatrick was removed from the Week 3 injury report.

impact: Fitzpatrick became the first quarterback in league history to pass for 400 yards in three consecutive games. The night started slow for Fitzmagic and the Bucs' offense, who went into the half trailing 30-10. Tampa Bay rallied and scored the final 17 points of the evening, though, falling just one Ben Roethlisberger scramble-and-heave to JuJu Smith-Schuster away from getting the ball back and potentially pulling off the comeback win. Fitzpatrick has been absurd through three games, totaling 1,230 passing yards, 11 touchdowns, and four picks. With Jameis Winston set to return, only time will tell whether the record book's newest member will have a starting gig in Week 4.
report: Ryan Fitzpatrick completed 30-of-50 passes for 411 yards, three touchdowns, and three interceptions in the Bucs' Week 3 loss to the Steelers.

impact: This has been expected for awhile. With Tampa coming off a short week, Fitzpatrick is in line to make at least another start. It's his job to lose after three straight 400-plus yard games. The Bucs plan to use their roster exemption on Jameis Winston, so there might not be anything official until later in the week.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports "all signs point" to Ryan Fitzpatrick starting Week 4 against Chicago.

impact: Though the Bucs haven't made an official decision yet, all signs point to Fitzpatrick keeping his job for at least another week. It makes sense with Fitzpatrick off to the best start of his career and Jameis Winston coming off a three-week absence. The Bucs also have their bye coming up in Week 5, which would give Winston another week to get up to speed. FitzMagic's Week 4 matchup against Chicago poses a difficult challenge, though we said the same when the 35-year-old went up against the Saints and Eagles earlier this year and look how that turned out.
report: According to NFL Network's Ian Rapoport, Ryan Fitzpatrick received a majority of the reps at Wednesday's practice.

impact: As expected. Fitzpatrick received a majority of the Bucs' first-team reps at practice this week, a telling sign he'll be under center at kick-off. The decision to roll with "FitzMagic" makes sense given that Jameis Winston is coming off a three-week absence and Tampa Bay's bye is right around the corner in Week 5. The Bearded Wonder is tasked with an incredibly difficult matchup versus the Bears' daunting pass rush, but he did slice up the Eagles' and Steelers' secondary earlier in the year. The 35-year-old could legitimately land the Bucs' starting gig with another terrific outing Sunday.
report: Ryan Fitzpatrick is expected to start in Week 4 against the Bears.

impact: Koetter strongly considered benching Fitzpatrick for Ryan Griffin (seriously) after his third interception in last week's Monday night loss to Pittsburgh. Fitzpatrick recovered after that and eventually wound up throwing for over 400 yards, but it's clear that he'll be entering Week 4 on an extremely short leash. With Fitzpatrick at risk of an in-game benching, don't be surprised if the recently-activated Jameis Winston sees action Sunday at Soldier Field.
report: According to NFL Network's Ian Rapoport, Buccaneers coach Dirk Koetter was "one or two plays away" from benching Ryan Fitzpatrick in Week 3.

impact: Fitzpatrick was reportedly only "one or two plays away" from being benched in Week 3, too. Coach Dirk Koetter pulled the trigger in Week 4 as the Bucs went into the half trailing 38-3. Fitzpatrick totaled 126 yards and one interception before riding the pine.
report: Ryan Fitzpatrick was replaced by Jameis Winston to start the third quarter in Week 4 against the Bears.

impact: This follows comments from GM Jason Licht last month that Winston isn't guaranteed to start. With the Bucs coming off a Monday night game in Week 3, Winston may be moved back slowly from his suspension. Winston is still the future in Tampa, but the Bucs are prepared to ride Ryan Fitzpatrick for at least the first month of the season.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports the Bucs "might hold off" on starting Jameis Winston when he returns from suspension in Week 4.

impact: Kate P. and her legal team also believe Winston still doesn't understand the impact of his actions, and they want "exemplary or punitive damages to punish and deter such conduct." The lawsuit offers "little new information" about the incident, so nothing should alter Winston's eligibility with the NFL, but he will have to answer to the suit nonetheless. Winston is eligible to return Week 4 but his starting job is very much in doubt with Ryan Fitzpatrick playing well to start the season.
report: Jameis Winston is being sued by his former Uber driver to pay for damages that include "emotional distress as well as future therapy expenses."

impact: Winston is eligible to return from his three-game suspension, but it does not appear as if a starting job is waiting for him following Ryan Fitzpatrick's hot start. "Jameis is a member of our team and anxious to get him back," coach Dirk Koetter said after the game on Monday night. "And I know Jameis, whatever role he ends up in, I know Jameis will embrace that role and give it everything he's got." The last line tells the story, and that tale is one in which Fitzpatrick remains the starter for at least another week. It would be a surprise if that is not confirmed on Tuesday.
report: The Tampa Bay Times' Rick Stroud wrote it "seems unlikely" Jameis Winston starts this week against the Bears.

impact: All signs have pointed toward red-hot Ryan Fitzpatrick staying under center for Week 4, but coach Dirk Koetter has yet to publicly disclose his plans. He has told Winston and Fitzpatrick. Fitzpatrick has been receiving more first-team reps, and will be a QB1 if he's indeed the starter against Chicago.
report: Bucs activated QB Jameis Winston from the reserve/suspended list.

impact: Trailing 38-3 during the first half due to Mitchell Trubisky's career performance, the Bucs had no choice but to turn one dimensional and telegraph their play-calling. Fitzpatrick, who threw for 126 yards and one interception before exiting, didn't stand a chance against the Bears' pass rush. Winston will finish the game under center.
report: Jameis Winston replaced Ryan Fitzpatrick to start the third quarter.

impact: An 80% completion rate is actually impressive given that Winston was suspended and away from football during the first three weeks. He replaced Ryan Fitzpatrick, who tossed an interception in his own right, at the half and will seemingly stay under center (barring injury) for the remainder of the season. Winston will have the entire bye week to become acclimated to football again and will return in Week 6 as a sneaky low-end QB1 against the Falcons' injury-riddled secondary.
report: Jameis Winston completed 16-of-20 passes for 145 yards, one touchdown, and two picks in the Bucs' Week 4 loss to the Bears.

impact: Ryan Fitzpatrick saw to that against the Bears, erasing the remaining goodwill he built up in Weeks 1 and 2. Winston will be returning against the Falcons' perpetual-shootout machine defense. The matchup could not be more gorgeous. Forward-thinking fantasy owners should add Winston now with an eye toward streaming him in Week 6.
report: The Bucs have confirmed Jameis Winston will be their starting quarterback when they come off bye in Week 6.

impact: Winston made a couple mistakes in this game, but he delivered the big fantasy performance everyone was expecting. He was sharp early, completing four of his five passes on the opening drive including a good throw to Cameron Brate for a 15-yard touchdown, but the offense fell into a lull after that. Following an interception in the second quarter, Winston bounced back to lead a big touchdown drive he capped with a 10-yard throw to O.J. Howard, and the offense was in sync from that point on. Winston did throw an end-zone interception on the first drive of the second half -- a forced pass was tipped into the air -- but he led three straight scoring drives after that to make it a game. He got Tampa in position for a potential game-winner, but a wild final play in which he took a draw up the middle before attempting a lateral fell short. Winston faces a tougher matchup next week against the Browns, but he should be in the QB1 conversation the rest of the season.
report: Jameis Winston completed 30-of-41 passes for 395 yards, four touchdowns, and two interceptions in the Bucs' Week 6 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Winston is dealing with a minor hip injury though it shouldn't impact his status for Week 7. Coming off a dominant performance Sunday in Atlanta, Winston should be in the QB1 mix against Cleveland.
report: Jameis Winston (hip) is practicing in full for Week 7 against the Browns.

impact: Winston turned in one his specials where he showcased all of the positives that made him the first overall selection in the 2015 draft and all of the mistakes that keep his status as a franchise quarterback in question. Winston threw two telegraphed interceptions and a lost a fumble on a scramble, but also shook off multiple sacks and extended drives in the run game consistently all afternoon. The highlight of his day was a 14-yard touchdown run where he sacrificed his body and dove for the end zone in the second quarter. Winston has now turned in games of 395 and 365 passing yards in his two starts. 300-yard passing games are just about something we should expect weekly in this Tampa Bay passing game. Despite his propensity for turnovers each week, Winston will be a high-floor fantasy option in Week 8 on the road against the Bengals.
report: Jameis Winston completed 32-of-52 passes for 365 yards with an interception while rushing 10 times for 55 yards and a touchdown in Sunday's Week 7 win over the Browns.

impact: Lynch may not get in a full practice all year. At age 32, he doesn't need to. Beast Mode will be ready to rock and roll against Cleveland in Week 4. He'll be taking a three-game touchdown streak into that matchup.
report: Marshawn Lynch (shoulder) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: The Raiders have been limiting Marshawn's practice reps all year. He's in no danger of missing Week 4 against Cleveland.
report: Marshawn Lynch (shoulder) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Lynch has been following this pattern most of the season, practicing on a limited basis throughout the week before being removed from the injury report on Friday. Beast Mode will be safe to fire up as an RB2 Sunday against Cleveland.
report: Marshawn Lynch (shoulder) wasn't listed on the Raiders' final injury report for Week 4 against the Browns.

impact: Lynch's highlight came on a pitch play where he got to the perimeter of the Browns' defense and followed an impressive downfield block by Martavis Bryant to gain 59 yards.  Lynch failed to score due to repeated goal-line stuffs, but this was his biggest rushing-yardage performance since 2014 with Seattle.  Lynch now has 20 or more touches in three straight games.  In an improving Raiders offense, he will be a high-end RB2 play in Week 5 at the Chargers.
report: Marshawn Lynch rushed 20 times for 130 yards and caught 3-of-5 targets for 27 yards in the Raiders' Week 4 win over the Browns.

impact: The Raiders have been managing Lynch's practice reps all year.  Lynch is a high-end RB2 for Week 5 at the Chargers.
report: Marshawn Lynch (shoulder) didn't practice Wednesday.

impact: Lynch was just getting a breather on Wednesday. He'll be fine to play his normal snaps Sunday against the Chargers. The 32-year-old has already put up 300 rushing yards this year, which ranks fourth in the league behind only Ezekiel Elliott, Todd Gurley and Matt Breida.
report: Marshawn Lynch (shoulder) returned to practice on Thursday.

impact: Lynch was previously listed with his shoulder. Lynch will be a high-end RB2 for Sunday's matchup with the Chargers.
report: Marshawn Lynch was limited in Thursday's practice with an abdomen issue.

impact: Lynch was limited by an abdominal injury at Thursday's practice, but there was never any doubt about his status for Sunday's game. When asked about the possibility of scaling back Lynch's workload, coach Jon Gruden said, "We’ll just keep feeding him Skittles and keep sending him out there as long as he can." Coming off a 157-yard eruption last week against Cleveland, Beast Mode is a worthy RB2 in all formats.
report: Marshawn Lynch (abdomen) wasn't listed on the Raiders' final injury report for Week 5 against the Chargers.

impact: Lynch's volume goes as the Raiders' game script goes, and the Raiders' game script got completely out of hand in this one. Jalen Richard even got involved late with Oakland in full-on catch-up mode, finishing with six catches on the day. Lynch is still averaging 15.4 carries and has received at least 18 in Oakland's three competitive games this season. With Seattle next up, Lynch should resume the RB2-usage we're accustomed to.
report: Marshawn Lynch rushed nine times for 31 yards, adding two catches for 10 yards in the Raiders' Week 5 romping by the Chargers.

impact: It's a new injury for Lynch. The Raiders like to manage his practice reps, so this isn't a Week 6 concern. Lynch is an RB2 for Sunday's matchup with Seattle.
report: Marshawn Lynch (hip) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: It was a frustrating day for the entire Raiders' offense, which would have gotten shut out if not for a garbage-time field goal to "cut the deficit" to 27-3.  Lynch has been Oakland's best offensive player, but he has been boom or bust in fantasy because the Raiders have too often found themselves in negative game script.  Lynch now draws a Week 7 bye to rest his 32-year-old legs.
report: Marshawn Lynch rushed 13 times for 45 yards and caught 3-of-5 targets for 14 yards in the Raiders' Week 6 loss to Seattle.

impact: Yikes. It sounds like Lynch will be seeing some doctors during the Raiders' Week 7 bye. Ageless Lynch has a been rare bright spot for Jon Gruden's unmitigated disaster of a team so far this season. His loss would be massive on offense. Although Jalen Richard is catching a ton of passes, Doug Martin is the next man up for Lynch's role.
report: Raiders coach Jon Gruden admits the team is concerned about Marshawn Lynch's groin injury, and that it could be a long-term issue.

impact: It's another blow to the Raiders' offense. Lynch has been a bright spot for Oakland this year, averaging a respectable 4.2 yards per carry with three touchdowns through his first six games. Without him, the Raiders will turn to a committee featuring some combination of Doug Martin and Jalen Richard. Perhaps Oakland will scour the free agent market to see what running backs are available.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports Marshawn Lynch will miss at least a month with his groin injury.

impact: Lynch is expected to miss at least a month with his groin injury. He'll rehab for now, but surgery hasn't been ruled out. Going on IR would effectively end Lynch's season. Doug Martin will replace Lynch on early downs, with Jalen Richard and DeAndre Washington playing change-up roles.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports injured reserve is a "strong possibility" for Marshawn Lynch.

impact: Lynch is officially out of commission until Week 16 at soonest, although he has undoubtedly played his final down in Oakland.  The tanking Raiders had no use for Lynch, and will move forward with Doug Martin, Jalen Richard, and DeAndre Washington.  Lynch's tenure in Oakland certainly fell short of his personal hopes, but his on-field performance was quietly excellent.  He was the Raiders' best offensive player from midway through the 2017 season up until his 2018 core muscle injury.  We suspect Lynch will retire for good at age 32.  He is not under contract for 2019.
report: Raiders placed RB Marshawn Lynch (groin/core muscle) on injured reserve.

impact: Washington went under the knife in mid-August. Doug Martin and Jalen Richard will back up Marshawn Lynch against the Rams. Washington will be returning to No. 3/4 duties whenever he finally gets healthy.
report: DeAndre Washington (knee scope) has yet to resume practicing.

impact: It's his first practice since mid-August surgery. Washington figures to be moved back slowly after the extended layoff. He isn't needed behind Marshawn Lynch, Doug Martin, and Jalen Richard.
report: DeAndre Washington (knee scope) returned to a limited practice on Wednesday.

impact: Washington returned to practice for the first time this week. He only got in limited reps, so it would be a surprise if he was active. The Raiders have no reason to rush Washington with Marshawn Lynch, Doug Martin, and Jalen Richard all healthy.
report: DeAndre Washington (knee) is questionable for Week 2 against the Broncos.

impact: Washington is healthy enough to return, but that does not mean he will be active with Marshawn Lynch, Doug Martin, and Jalen Richard all ahead of him on the depth chart. He can be left on the wire in redraft leagues.
report: DeAndre Washington (knee) is not listed on the Week 3 injury report.

impact: Roethlisberger also lost two fumbles on sacks as he compiled five turnovers on the afternoon in heavy rain. Outside of the bulk yardage, his lone bright spot was a 22-yard touchdown strike to Antonio Brown in the 3rd quarter. Roethlisberger has now thrown one or fewer touchdown passes in 16 of his past 22 games on the road in early starts. Despite his poor start, Roethlisberger will be a starting fantasy option at home next week against the Chiefs.
report: Ben Roethlisberger completed 23-of-41 passes for 335 yards with one touchdowns and three interceptions in Sunday's Week 1 tie versus the Browns.

impact: This does not seem serious at all -- we are not even marking him with an injury -- but it is at least worth noting. Roethlisberger will be limited and might even miss a practice early this week, but he should be good to go on Sunday. Despite a rough opener, Roethlisberger will be a back-end QB1 in a good matchup against the Chiefs this week.
report: Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said Ben Roethlisberger has a minor elbow injury which could limit him early this week.

impact: This was fully expected. The Steelers plan to limit Roethlisberger's practice reps this week, but he's not in any danger of sitting out Sunday's game.
report: Ben Roethlisberger (elbow) missed Wednesday's practice.

impact: "We’ll see how I feel tomorrow," Roethlisberger said. If Roethlisberger has an injury, he likes to keep the uncertainty high for as long as possible. We remain extremely skeptical there is any chance he will sit against the Chiefs, but any time a player misses back-to-back practices, you can't ignore it. Josh Dobbs would get the call in a gorgeous spot against the Chiefs on the off chance Ben actually sits.
report: Ben Roethlisberger (elbow) remained sidelined on Thursday.

impact: Ben sat out Wednesday and Thursday due to an elbow injury but there was never much concern about his status for Week 2. Roethlisberger struggled with turnovers last week, but he should fare much better Sunday against a Kansas City secondary that was just burned for over 400 yards. RotoPat ranked him as his No. 2 quarterback this week.
report: Ben Roethlisberger (elbow) returned to a full practice on Friday.

impact: Roethlisberger got in a full practice Friday, a sign he'll be out there after the Steelers managed his reps this week. Coming off a rough season opener, Roethlisberger is in a rebound spot against a Chiefs defense that allowed 400-plus yards to Philip Rivers. He's behind only Drew Brees in our Week 2 rankings.
report: Ben Roethlisberger (elbow) is questionable for Week 2 against Kansas City.

impact: As expected. Roethlisberger was a full participant in practice Friday and was never truly in doubt of missing Week 2. He's ranked as Roto Pat's No. 2 QB, behind only Drew Brees.
report: Ben Roethlisberger (elbow) will play in Week 2 against the Chiefs.

impact: Despite Roethlisberger's best efforts to appear genuinely questionable, the Steelers dropped the act on Friday. Roethlisberger is an elite play in a game that could shoot into the scoring stratosphere.
report: Ben Roethlisberger (elbow) is active for Week 2 against the Chiefs.

impact: With the Steelers down 21-0 after 13 minutes, Roethlisberger had nearly an entire afternoon of comeback mode/garbage time. The Steelers were unwatchable early on, beginning the game with two three-and-outs. Ben then got cooking, targeting Antonio Brown and JuJu Smith-Schuster a combined 36 times. He also consistently found TE Jesse James for big plays. Rookie big-play threat James Washington was heavily involved early after a Week 1 mothballing. The Steelers actually came close to pulling off the comeback, but the early deficit was too much to overcome on an afternoon where Patrick Mahomes piled up six touchdowns. Roethlisberger has an attackable matchup in the Bucs for Week 3.
report: Ben Roethlisberger completed 39-of-60 passes for 452 yards and three touchdowns in the Steelers' 42-37, Week 2 loss to the Chiefs, adding a rushing score.

impact: Roethlisberger and the Steelers' offense shook off a quick three-and-out and interception during their first two possessions to eventually take a 30-10 lead into the half. Big Ben's first touchdown was a YAC-filled 75-yard touchdown pass over the middle to emerging starter Vance McDonald, followed by touchdowns to Antonio Brown and Ryan Switzer before heading to the locker room. Pittsburgh was shutout in the second half, but Roethlisberger did enough damage early on to finish as the week's QB10. The Steelers have a divisional showdown next Sunday night against a Ravens defense that could be without both CB Jimmy Smith and LB C.J. Mosley.
report: Ben Roethlisberger completed 30-of-38 passes for 353 yards, three touchdowns, and one interception in the Steelers' Week 3 victory over the Buccaneers.

impact: Roethlisberger had a solid first half, but the Steelers' offense went in the tank over the final two quarters. His only touchdown came on an extended play to Antonio Brown from 26 yards out. It's the first game of the season Roethlisberger hasn't passed for at least 300 yards. Roethlisberger is on pace for 32 touchdowns and  21 interceptions through the first month of the season. He'll get a matchup with the Falcons in Week 5.
report: Ben Roethlisberger completed 27-of-47 passes for 274 yards with one touchdown and an interception in the Steelers' Week 5 loss to the Ravens.

impact: Roethlisberger was on track for a disappointing day before he finally got his Antonio Brown connection going in the second half. After entering the break 2-of-8 for eight yards and an interception targeting his No. 1 wideout, Ben found Brown six times for 93 yards and two scores over the final two quarters. The second was the highlight. Brown got a step on Robert Alford down the left sideline and Roethlisberger hit him in stride for a 47-yarder. Roethlisberger gets the Bengals on the road for Week 6.
report: Ben Roethlisberger completed 19-of-29 passes for 250 yards, three touchdowns and an interception in the Steelers' 41-17, Week 5 win over the Falcons.

impact: Big Ben had a clean pocket all day, not getting sacked at all, and was pretty unlucky to only have one touchdown pass.  JuJu Smith-Schuster was ruled down at the one-yard line on a play where it appeared he actually did score.  The Steelers also failed to convert a 1st-and-goal situation from the one-yard line, settling for a field goal.  Ben's lone score was a 31-yard quick slant, game-winner to Antonio Brown with 10 seconds left.  The Steelers now head into their bye week.
report: Ben Roethlisberger completed 32-of-46 passes for 369 yards and one touchdown in the Steelers' Week 6 win over the Bengals.

impact: Graham was an afterthought behind Davante Adams, Randall Cobb, and Geronimo Allison. There should be better days ahead for Graham, but it's a reminder of his touchdown dependence. Graham gets a Week 2 matchup with Minnesota.
report: Jimmy Graham caught 2-of-4 passes for seven yards in Week 1 against Chicago.

impact: It was a much better second outing for Graham, but he could have had an even bigger fantasy day. He just missed on two deep targets including one in which he was clearly interfered, and he had a touchdown called back on a questionable holding call. He had another chance deep down the field on a free play, but the ball was knocked away. Even so, this was a promising performance for Graham’s rest-of-season outlook. He will be a solid TE1 next week in Washington.
report: Jimmy Graham hauled in 6-of-8 targets for 95 yards in the Packers' Week 2 tie with the Vikings.

impact: The Packers had trouble getting into the red zone thanks to drops and penalties. Hence, a quiet day for Graham. At some points today, Graham looked like he was playing in full armor. He's going to need near-weekly touchdowns to be a true top-eight TE1.
report: Jimmy Graham caught 5-of-7 targets for 45 yards in the Packers' Week 3 loss to the Redskins.

impact: This may be a rest day given Graham's knee history. Graham played a season-high 64 snaps in Week 3.
report: Jimmy Graham (knee) didn't practice Wednesday.

impact: Coach Mike McCarthy called Graham's absence on Wednesday a "maintenance" day. It would be surprising if Graham is not suited up to face the Bills on Sunday.
report: Jimmy Graham (knee) will return to a limited practice on Thursday.

impact: He saw a lighter workload than usual at practice this week but obviously his knee injury isn't serious. Graham is still in search of his first Packers touchdown, though he's seen good volume with a combined 15 targets the past two weeks. He'll be in play as a TE1 in a mouth-watering home matchup against Buffalo.
report: Jimmy Graham (knee) wasn't listed on the Packers' final injury report for Week 4 against the Bills.

impact: The score was Graham's first in a Packers uniform. Graham was left uncovered on a three-yard rollout. Graham was also the target on Aaron Rodgers' interception, tipping the ball into the air for a pick. Graham is on pace for 64/676/4. With the exception of the touchdown rate increasing, that seems entirely plausible.
report: Jimmy Graham caught 3-of-6 targets for 21 yards and a touchdown in the Packers' Week 4 win over the Bills.

impact: The Packers have been managing Graham's reps the last few weeks. He should return to practice Thursday.
report: Jimmy Graham (knee) didn't practice Wednesday.

impact: The Packers are just managing Graham's practice reps, which they will likely do all season. With the injuries at receiver, Graham should be a focal point of the passing game this week against the Lions.
report: Jimmy Graham (knee) will practice Thursday.

impact: Graham has been getting regular days off, but his status was never in doubt. He should see a larger target share this week with Randall Cobb and Geronimo Allison sidelined.
report: Jimmy Graham (knee) was removed from the Week 5 injury report.

impact: The 11 targets were a new season-high and second on the team to Davante Adams (12).  Graham could have had a much bigger day, as he fell down on an end-zone fade pass at the goal line and then had a 21-yard touchdown go right through his hands later in the second half.  Graham left a lot of plays on the field.  He'll remain a top-four TE1 next week against the Niners.
report: Jimmy Graham caught 6-of-11 targets for 76 yards in the Packers' Week 5 loss to the Lions.

impact: It's Graham's weekly rest day. He will remain a mid-range TE1 for Week 6 against the 49ers.
report: Jimmy Graham (knee) was held out of Thursday's practice.

impact: Graham was rested on Thursday. He'll be fine for his normal snaps against the 49ers.
report: Jimmy Graham (knee) practiced fully on Friday.

impact: It's the same routine as last week. The Packers have been giving Graham days off, but he's fully healthy for Week 6.
report: Jimmy Graham (knee) was removed from the Week 6 injury report.

impact: Graham has seen a combined 21 targets the last two weeks with Randall Cobb and Geronimo Allison hurt.  He's put the yards on the board, but Graham hasn't found pay dirt in that span.  He ran free for a 54-yard gain in the first half of this one and bailed the offense out with a number of tough third-down grabs with Aaron Rodgers in trouble.  Graham gets the Rams in Week 8 after the bye and will remain an every-week TE1, even with Cobb and Allison coming back.
report: Jimmy Graham caught 5-of-9 targets for 104 yards in the Packers' Week 6 win over the 49ers.

impact: Cousins came out peppering Dalvin Cook with early targets, beating an aggressive Niners defense for chunk gains.  He later threw a dime over the top of CB Ahkello Witherspoon to hit Stefon Diggs for a 22-yard touchdown down the left sideline.  It was a perfectly-placed ball.  Cousins' second score was an 11-yard hookup to Kyle Rudolph.  He was also cooking with Adam Thielen, who had 102 yards on six grabs, killing the Niners out of the slot.  Cousins' debut couldn't have gone much better.  The 1-0 Vikings will head on the road to Green Bay in Week 2.
report: Kirk Cousins completed 20-of-36 passes for 244 yards and two touchdowns in the Vikings' 24-16, Week 1 win over the 49ers.

impact: It was a tie, but Cousins did everything he could to win this game despite facing an underrated defense. He threw a laser to Laquon Treadwell for his first score of the day, and his third was a beautiful pass to Stefon Diggs for a 75-yard touchdown, almost all of that coming in the air. He was even better with the game on the line. Despite an interception which went right through Treadwell’s hands, Cousins was able to lead the Vikings back with an eight-play touchdown drive he finished with an outstanding tight-window throw to Adam Thielen and a two-point conversion to Diggs to tie the game. He led what should have been two scoring drives in overtime, but Daniel Carlson missed both field goals including one as time expired. With Buffalo up next, Cousins will be a locked-in QB1 next week.
report: Kirk Cousins completed 35-of-48 passes for 425 yards, four touchdowns, and an interception in the Vikings' Week 2 tie with the Packers.

impact: The Vikings' offensive line didn't help matters, allowing Cousins to be blindsided and strip-sacked on the team's first two possessions. Minnesota's passing offense was playing catch-up from that point forward as Cousins was forced to attempt 55 passes under duress for the remainder of the afternoon. Cousins' lone touchdown came in garbage time when he found Kyle Rudolph in the end zone down 27-0 with less than two minutes to play. The Vikings have another tough test on the road against the Rams Thursday night.
report: Kirk Cousins completed 40-of-55 passes for 296 yards, one touchdown, and an interception in the Vikings' Week 3 loss to the Bills.

impact: Cousins lost 30 yards on four sacks. Coming off an embarrassing loss to Buffalo on their home turf, the Vikings came out firing on their first drive with Cousins completing 6-of-8 passes for 68 yards and a touchdown pass to Aldrick Robinson. Cousins followed that up with another touchdown strike to Robinson in the second quarter. Kirk’s longest completion on the night came on a 45-yard touchdown pass to Adam Thielen on a play where Cousins looked off the safety before hitting Thielen down the seam for a wide-open TD. Cousins’ night ended in disappointment when he coughed up the ball on a strip sack by John Franklin-Myers with 1:29 remaining in the fourth quarter. The Vikes haven’t been the juggernaut they were billed as going into the year, but Cousins has still been extremely productive, topping 400 yards in two of his last three outings. We’ll see what he does for an encore next week against the Eagles.
report: Kirk Cousins completed 36-of-50 passes for 422 yards and three touchdowns while adding a team-leading 28 rushing yards on four carries Thursday in the Vikings’ Week 4 loss to the Rams.

impact: Cousins also lost a fumble on a botched sideways pass. As has become a theme, Cousins was attempting and converting heat check throws in the first half. His touchdown was a three-yarder where only Adam Thielen could catch it in the end zone. Cousins has made as many "wow" passes as anyone in football so far this season. The Vikings' offense was far less effective after halftime but got back into rhythm in time to close the game out in the fourth quarter. Cousins is making hay with his elite receiver duo of Thielen and Stefon Diggs. He'll be a high-end QB1 for next week's home date with the abysmal Cardinals.
report: Kirk Cousins completed 30-of-37 passes for 301 yards and a touchdown in the Vikings' 23-21, Week 5 win over the Eagles.

impact: He added a touchdown on a seven-yard run. Cousins fumbled on a sack that was returned for a touchdown, but he was sharp in this one, completing 71 percent of his passes. Cousins' only passing TD was a perfect throw over the middle to Adam Thielen. He's now led the Vikings to consecutive wins after losing to Buffalo and the Rams. Cousins gets a matchup with the Jets in Week 7.
report: Kirk Cousins completed 24-of-34 passes for 233 yards with a touchdown and an interception in the Vikings' Week 6 win over the Cardinals.

impact: It was a struggle much of the day as both offenses really had trouble moving the ball.  At one point, both teams were a combined 0-for-12 on third downs.  Cousins, however, did throw a 34-yard touchdown to Adam Thielen on the opening drive before then hitting Aldrick Robinson for a second 34-yard score in the fourth quarter.  Both were dimes from Cousins in tight coverage.  Cousins will look to get back on track with big numbers next week against the Saints at home.
report: Kirk Cousins completed 25-of-40 passes for 241 yards and two touchdowns in the Vikings' Week 7 win over the Jets.

impact: Cook got some reps in Friday's practice after missing the last two days. He's on the wrong side of questionable for Sunday, but the Vikings will take him to game time. Latavius Murray will be an RB3/FLEX if Cook sits.
report: Dalvin Cook (questionable, hamstring) will be a game-time decision for Week 5 against the Eagles.

impact: Per RapSheet, Cook would need "an impressive turnaround" to play on Sunday, unsurprising after the Vikings inexplicably played him on a short week in last Thursday night's loss to the Rams.  Cook aggravated his hamstring pull in that game, predictably, and Latavius Murray will operate as Minnesota's Week 5 lead back with UDFAs Mike Boone and Roc Thomas working in behind him.  An injury risk coming out of Florida State before tearing his ACL as a rookie, Cook has been one of the biggest early-round fantasy busts of the 2018 season.  The Vikings need to let his hamstring heal before running him back out there.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports Dalvin Cook (hamstring) is unlikely to play Sunday at Philadelphia.

impact: Cook didn't seem terribly close to suiting up this week and should be considered genuinely questionable for Week 7. Latavius Murray, who has made a habit of goose egging in Cook's absences this year, will be a risky FLEX option. UDFAs Mike Boone and Roc Thomas should mix in for an inconsequential amount of work. Also inactive for the Vikings are DE Everson Griffen, DE Tashawn Bower, CB Trae Waynes, CB Marcus Sherels, QB Kyle Sloter and LB Devante Downs.
report: Dalvin Cook (hamstring) is inactive for Week 5 against the Eagles.

impact: This would seemingly put Cook on track to play Sunday versus Arizona, though given all the setbacks he's had with his balky hamstring, fantasy owners shouldn't get comfortable. The Vikings desperately need to get their ground game going. So far, they're the only team in the league without a rushing touchdown.
report: Dalvin Cook (hamstring) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Barring yet another setback, Cook is now fully on track to return against the Cardinals, who have been leaky on the ground so far this season. There will be some re-injury risk, but Cook would immediately slot back in as an upside RB2.
report: Dalvin Cook (hamstring) was upgraded to "full" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Cook indicated he only wanted to play if he was back at full health. "Me going out there 80 percent, 70 percent, I’m not going to be able to help my team like that," he said. "We got a bunch of guys that are 100 percent that can help the team win football games. At this point, it’s just me getting 100 percent so I can go out there and be who I am and that’s be explosive." He was notably a full participant in practice on Thursday. It sounds like Cook will only be active if he's in full form, returning him to prominent low-end RB1 status if he plays.
report: Dalvin Cook (hamstring) is questionable for Week 6 against the Cardinals.

impact: Cook isn't 100 percent but did enough in practice this week to be active. The Vikings only expect him to play 20-25 snaps, so he'll be in a committee with Latavius Murray. Cook's limited role and setback risks make him a dodgy fantasy play. He's a volatile RB2 for Week 6.
report: The Minneapolis Star Tribune reports the plan is for Dalvin Cook (questionable, hamstring) to play in Week 6 against the Cardinals.

impact: Schefter reports Cook will play "only about half the offensive snaps, if that." It could be a similar situation to Week 4, when Cook saw 10 carries on 18 snaps in the first half and then did not see the field again. Cook has a great matchup against the Cardinals, but playing-time uncertainty makes him no more than a risky FLEX option.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Dalvin Cook (hamstring) is expected to play Week 6 against the Cardinals, but he will be on a snap count.

impact: This comes as a surprise after multiple reports expected Cook to play on a snap count. Cook didn't show enough in warmups and will miss his third game in the last four weeks. It leaves Latavius Murray in line for the bulk of carries, with Roc Thomas in a change-up role. Murray is a plug-and-play RB2.
report: Dalvin Cook (hamstring) is inactive for Week 6 against the Cardinals.

impact: Cook was a surprise inactive last week but appears to be on track for Sunday's game in East Rutherford. With Cook's hamstring giving him problems—he's already had one setback—it's hard for fantasy owners to start him with any kind of confidence. Latavius Murray fared well in Cook's absence last week (24 carries for 155 yards and a touchdown), though he's also been inconsistent. Only four teams have averaged fewer rushing yards per game than Minnesota this year.
report: Dalvin Cook (hamstring) is practicing in full for Week 7 against the Jets.

impact: A reporter caused a mini-Twitter furor when he posted that Cook had "left" practice, but it was not anything out of the ordinary. We have been conditioned to expect Cook setbacks, but this was not one of them. He will be back against the Jets. Cook is a risk/reward RB2 in an ugly running back landscape.
report: Dalvin Cook (hamstring) remained "full" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Alrighty then. The "DNP" designation comes less than an hour after coach Mike Zimmer appeared to say Cook was "not limited" on Thursday. What he actually meant was that the running back did not even get in a limited session. Cook's status is now genuinely up in the air. Hopefully the Vikings were just managing his reps. Cook's Friday listing will tell the story of his Week 7 status.
report: Updating an earlier item, Dalvin Cook (hamstring) was officially "DNP" on Thursday.

impact: This was expected after Cook was held out of Thursday's practice. Cook's had multiple setbacks with his hamstring injury, so he's not a lock to be back next week. Latavius Murray will make another start in Cook's place.
report: Dalvin Cook (hamstring) has been ruled out for Week 7 against the Jets.

impact: No surprises in this group.  Latavius Murray will get the nod at running back against the Jets and is a locked-in RB2 play.
report: Vikings declared RB Dalvin Cook, S Andrew Sendejo, DE Everson Griffen, DT Linval Joseph, OT Riley Reiff, LB Devante Downs, and QB Kyle Sloter inactive for Week 7 against the Jets.

impact: It's been a lost season for Cook after last year's ACL tear.  He's battled an ongoing hamstring injury suffered last month against the Rams.  Cook has tried numerous times to practice, but he's seemingly aggravated it each time.  The Vikings appear ready to just sit him down through the bye week in hopes of having Cook for the stretch run.  Latavius Murray will continue to carry the load in the meantime with rookies Roc Thomas and Mike Boone as the backups.
report: ESPN Vikings reporter Courtney Cronin reports multiple league sources have indicated Dalvin Cook (hamstring) will be out through the Week 10 bye.

impact: It was a tough night for Ertz, who committed multiple drops. He didn't help out a struggling Nick Foles. The Bucs wouldn't seem to be a daunting matchup for Week 2, though they did allow the third fewest tight end fantasy points in 2017.
report: Zach Ertz caught 5-of-10 targets for 48 yards in the Eagles' Week 1 win over the Falcons.

impact: He led the team in targets, just ahead of Nelson Agholor (12).  Ertz has been the Eagles' most-targeted pass catcher with Nick Foles under center dating back to last season.  Carson Wentz (knee) is tentatively due back for Week 3 against the Colts, however, and Wentz's return would boost Ertz's touchdown probability.  Ertz has yet to reach pay dirt on 23 targets through two games.
report: Zach Ertz caught 11-of-13 targets for 94 yards in the Eagles' Week 2 loss to Tampa Bay.

impact: Ertz and Wentz more than less picked up where they left off as Ertz lead the Eagles across the board in targets, receptions and yards. Despite failing to score through three games, Ertz leads the Eagles in targets (33), receptions (21) and receiving yardage (215). He will be a set-and-forget option next week against the Titans.
report: Zach Ertz caught 5-of-10 targets for 73 yards in Sunday's Week 3 win over the Colts.

impact: It is about what we have come to expect from Ertz, who now has at least 10 targets in every game this season. The Titans simply had no answer for him as he consistently made plays across the middle on the way to his first 100-yard game of the season. With Wentz looking better every week, Ertz will remain a high-end TE1 as long as he is healthy.
report: Zach Ertz hauled in 10-of-14 targets for 112 yards in the Eagles' Week 4 loss to the Titans.

impact: Ertz has now caught 10 passes in 3-of-5 games this season. He's on pace for 1,398 yards after entering 2018 with a career high of 853. His production has come with both Nick Foles and Carson Wentz under center and withstood the return of Alshon Jeffery. Ertz will jockey with Rob Gronkowski and Travis Kelce for the TE1 rank going forward.
report: Zach Ertz caught 10-of-11 targets for 110 yards and a touchdown in the Eagles' Week 5 loss to the Vikings.

impact: The nine targets were actually Ertz's fewest of the season. That's how consistently he's been used. The score was his second in as many games. He dusted Janoris Jenkins in the end zone. Ertz will be a cinch top-three tight end for Week 7 against the Panthers.
report: Zach Ertz caught 7-of-9 targets for 43 yards and a touchdown in the Eagles' Week 6 win over the Giants.

impact: Ertz was legitimately unstoppable, relentlessly beating the Panthers’ linebackers and safeties on slants and exploiting every hole known to man in Carolina’s zone coverage. Ertz came oh-so close to a second-quarter touchdown, but he was tackled just short of the goalline.  As the NFL’s premier route-running tight end, Ertz has also been fantasy football’s most-consistent TE1. Even against the Jaguars in London in Week 8, Ertz will be a top-three option at the position at worst.
report: Zach Ertz caught 9-of-11 targets for 138 yards in the Eagles’ Week 7 loss to the Panthers.

impact: One of Goedert's missed connections was in the end zone. Despite the Eagles' depth issues at receiver and lots of summer talk of continued two-tight end sets, Goedert played fewer than 20 snaps in his NFL debut. He was also the intended target on Nick Foles' interception. Foles dropped a pass in late. Goedert got his hands on it but was immediately blown up, sending the ball into the air. Goedert won't be a realistic TE2 streamer against the Bucs in Week 2.
report: Dallas Goedert caught 1-of-3 targets for four yards in the Eagles' Week 1 win over the Falcons.

impact: A standout all preseason, Goedert has barely been involved in the Eagles' passing game so far in real games.  It was concerning that he played behind Josh Perkins in this one.  Perkins caught four passes for 57 yards.
report: Dallas Goedert was held catch-less in the Eagles' Week 2 loss to the Bucs.

impact: After getting benched a week ago, Goedert was a huge part of the offensive game plan in Week 3. He started the game off with his first career touchdown, a 13-yard score in which he was uncovered. Despite the promising game, Goedert will not be a fantasy option heading into Week 4 against the Titans.
report: Dallas Goedert caught 7-of-7 targets for 73 yards and a touchdown in Sunday's Week 3 win over the Colts.

impact: There was always a chance Goedert's break out performance in Week 3 was something of a fluke, and those chances grew once Alshon Jeffery was cleared to return. Goedert was not targeted in the first half of this game, and he only played around half the snaps. Goedert should have some a couple more big games this season, but predicting them will be difficult while Zach Ertz is healthy.
report: Dallas Goedert hauled in both his targets for 13 yards in the Eagles' Week 4 loss to the Titans.

impact: Goedert now has four catches for 29 yards since Alshon Jeffery's healthy return. He is off the TE2 radar until further notice.
report: Dallas Goedert caught 2-of-2 targets for 16 yards in the Eagles' Week 5 loss to the Vikings.

impact: Goedert’s involvement in Philly’s weekly game plans has been inconsistent, but he was a big part of this week’s. The Eagles got him rolling on an early 21-yard screen pass Goedert nearly took to the house, and the second-round rookie did find pay dirt later in the second quarter from one yard out. Goedert is merely a volatile TE2, but he would be a locked-in TE1 if Zach Ertz were ever to miss time.
report: Dallas Goedert caught 4-of-5 targets for 43 yards and a touchdown in the Eagles’ Week 7 loss to Carolina.

impact: His longest catch went for 21 yards. Three of Watson’s four grabs came after halftime as the Saints did their best to chip away at a 24-point deficit. The veteran carries mild streaming appeal as a proven pass-catcher in a high-scoring attack, though most weeks, the Saints will run their offense through Michael Thomas and Alvin Kamara.
report: Ben Watson corralled all four of his targets for 44 yards Sunday in New Orleans’ Week 1 loss to the Buccaneers.

impact: Watson's overall line was a disappointment, but he had a wide open touchdown opportunity in the first quarter in which he was overthrown. Through two games, Watson has just nine catches for 63 yards and is only a desperation TE2 option in Week 3 versus the Falcons.
report: Ben Watson caught 3-of-5 targets for 19 yards in Sunday's Week 2 win over the Browns.

impact: Watson made a number of contested catches including a 19-yard grab that set up a Saints field goal late in the first half. Even at his advanced age, Watson remains a physical presence and a tough matchup for opposing defenses. Still, with so many mouths to feed in New Orleans, he’s best viewed as a TE2 for fantasy purposes.
report: Benjamin Watson nabbed five-of-six targets for 71 yards Sunday in New Orleans’ Week 3 win over the Falcons.

impact: Watson dropped a seven-yard touchdown on one of his missed connections, and the Saints had to settle for one of their four first-half field goals.  It was a step back for Watson in a glorious spot.  He'll be a fringe TE1/2 next week when the Saints go back home to face the Redskins at the Superdome.
report: Ben Watson caught 1-of-3 targets for 23 yards in the Saints' Week 4 win over the Giants.

impact: Watson has taken a step back over the last two weeks, catching just five balls total for 53 scoreless yards in that span after nabbing 12 passes Weeks 1-3.  He's still going to remain on the TE1 fringe for the foreseeable future at a position that has been totally ravaged by injuries.  The Ravens are up next in Week 7.
report: Ben Watson caught all four of his targets for 30 yards in the Saints' Week 5 win over the Redskins.

impact: Both the grabs and targets were Watson's most of the season. The score was his first of the year. Watson is averaging just 38 weekly yards, but that is more than enough to make him a weekly TE2 in a down campaign for the position.
report: Ben Watson caught 6-of-6 targets for 43 yards and a touchdown in the Saints' Week 7 win over the Ravens.

impact: Seferian-Jenkins suffered from awful touchdown luck last season in New York, and it seems to have followed him to Jacksonville. ASJ got open for a 10-yard touchdown early in the second quarter, but the play was called back on a penalty. It is a tough break, but such is life with a touchdown-or-bust fantasy option. That is what Seferian-Jenkins will be next week against the Patriots.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins hauled in 3-of-5 targets for 25 yards in the Jaguars' Week 1 win over the Giants.

impact: ASJ played through his core injury last week against the Giants, totaling 25 yards on three catches. Even if he's listed as questionable, expect the tight end to suit up against New England in Week 2.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins (core) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Seferian-Jenkins has been limited at practice the past two weeks while battling a core injury. He played his usual snaps in Week 1 and will gut it out again Sunday versus New England. ASJ comes in at No. 17 in RotoPat's Week 2 tight end rankings.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins (core) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Seferian-Jenkins practiced on a full basis Friday after being a limited participant on both Wednesday and Thursday. He was targeted five times in last week's opener but only managed three catches for 25 yards and no touchdowns. ASJ will be a weak TE2 against New England.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins (core) wasn't listed on the Jaguars' final injury report for Week 2 against the Patriots.

impact: The rarest of rarities — an ASJ touchdown that was not called back. ASJ was freed by a pick play in the end zone on his four-yard score in the second quarter. The catch-and-fall specialist is averaging eight yards through his first six Jaguars receptions. He's a low-end TE2.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins caught 3-of-5 targets for 23 yards and a touchdown in the Jaguars' Week 2 win over the Patriots.

impact: ASJ's core muscle injury isn't going away, though it hasn't kept him from playing the past two weeks. Coming off a touchdown in Week 2, Seferian-Jenkins will remain in the TE2 mix for Sunday's home matchup against the Titans.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins (core) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: It appears as if Seferian-Jenkins' practice reps will be limited for some time as he works his way back from a core muscle injury, but it would be a surprise if he misses any game time. The tight end will be his usual touchdown-or-bust self against the Titans.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins (core) returned to a limited practice Thursday.

impact: ASJ returned to a full practice on Friday after being limited earlier this week. Seferian-Jenkins is RotoPat's No. 20 tight end for Week 3.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins (core) wasn't listed on the Jaguars' final injury report for Week 3 against the Titans.

impact: ASJ never logs big yardage numbers and is always a touchdown-or-bust streamer option. He will draw a "revenge" matchup in Week 4 against the Jets.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins caught 3-of-5 targets for 18 yards in the Jaguars' Week 3 loss to Tennessee.

impact: Seferian-Jenkins has been dealing with a core muscle injury all year but hasn't missed any games. He's on the streaming radar for a Week 4 matchup with the Jets.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins (core) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: His status was never in doubt. Seferian-Jenkins has been playing through a core muscle injury all year. There's some narrative to his matchup with the Jets this week as a touchdown-dependent streamer.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins (core) was removed from Jacksonville's injury report.

impact: Seferian-Jenkins wasn't much of a factor playing against his former team. He's been an afterthought in Jacksonville's offense this year, failing to go over 25 yards in any game. Seferian-Jenkins gets a matchup against the Chiefs in Week 5.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins caught 2-of-4 passes for 24 yards in Week 4 against the Jets.

impact: Seferian-Jenkins began the week with a DNP before being upgraded to limited practice on Thursday. He closed out the week by getting in a full session, prompting the Jags to take him off their injury report. ASJ hasn't been of much use to fantasy owners this year, though the potential for a big week does exist against a subpar Chiefs secondary.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins (core) wasn't listed on the Jaguars' final injury report for Week 5 against the Chiefs.

impact: Seferian-Jenkins could not come up with the pass on a fourth-and-two target in the second quarter. That was his last involvement in the game, and he did not play many snaps if any at all in the second half. Seferian-Jenkins has been struggling with a core-muscle injury all season, and it is possible that issue flared up against Kansas City. Niles Paul, who finished with 65 yards on seven catches, would be next up at tight end.
report: Austin Seferian-Jenkins did not catch his only target in the Jaguars' Week 5 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: Coach Doug Marrone said it is possible Seferian-Jenkins returns this season. ASJ has been dealing with a core-muscle injury all year, but he appeared to aggravate the injury against the Chiefs on Sunday. Niles Paul caught seven passes for 65 yards filling in for Seferian-Jenkins in the second half. He is worth a look with tight end as thin as ever.
report: Jaguars placed Austin Seferian-Jenkins (core muscle) on injured reserve.

impact: Jacksonville has lost Austin Seferian-Jenkins (groin, IR) and Niles Paul (sprained MCL) in the last two weeks, so they needed help. Bell will offer depth behind James O'Shaughnessy.
report: Jaguars signed TE Blake Bell.

impact: Filling in for Austin Seferian-Jenkins, who appeared to aggravate his core-muscle injury, Paul racked up five of his catches in the second half. If ASJ is forced to miss time, Paul would get into the TE2 conversation at a desolate position.
report: Niles Paul hauled in 7-of-9 targets for 65 yards in the Jaguars' Week 5 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: Paul caught seven passes for 65 yards against the Chiefs in Week 5 filling in for an injured Austin Seferian-Jenkins. He was expected to keep that role moving forward, but he suffered a knee injury after just three snaps against the Cowboys. He will likely miss a couple of games at least. James O'Shaughnessy is next up on the depth chart, although the Jaguars could add some help.
report: Jaguars TE Niles Paul suffered a sprained MCL Week 6 against the Cowboys.

impact: Richard finished second on the team in targets only to Jared Cook (12-9-180). It was admittedly a favorable game script for the third-year pro, who primarily played behind both Marshawn Lynch (11-41-1) and Doug Martin (4-20). He's worth stashing if only for his receiving prowess, but don't expect coach Jon Gruden to lean on him unless need be (despite his talent over the rest of the backfield).
report: Jalen Richard rushed for 24 yards on five carries and hauled in 9-of-11 targets for 55 yards in the Raiders' Week 1 loss to the Rams.

impact: Richard was a hot waiver name after seeing 11 targets in the season opener, but that usage was clearly script driven. Behind both Marshawn Lynch and Doug Martin in the pecking order, Richard could have some spike games, but they will only happen when the Raiders are down big. On the bright side, that could be the case often this season.
report: Jalen Richard played 8-of-65 (12 percent) snaps Week 2 against the Broncos.

impact: Backfield mate Marshawn Lynch handled just nine carries since the game was out of hand early. Richard was involved late, finishing second on the team in receiving yards. Richard has shown a propensity to produce when involved — the issue being he's never involved. If Lynch ever misses time, there's no doubt Richard will sneak into strong RB3/FLEX consideration.
report: Jalen Richard caught all six of his targets for 53 yards and one touchdown in the Raiders' Week 5 stomping to the Chargers.

impact: When the Raiders play from behind, Richard's usage spikes as a frequent checkdown target for checkdown-loving Derek Carr.  The team's leading receiver in Sunday's blowout loss, Richard will remain a negative-game-script-dependent, PPR-only flex option when Oakland emerges from its Week 7 bye.
report: Jalen Richard caught 7-of-8 targets for 48 yards and rushed twice for three yards in the Raiders' Week 6 loss to Seattle.

impact: We were told throughout camp that Martin has "jumped out" and could even compete with Marshawn Lynch for first-string carries. Martin has responded by averaging a mediocre 4.09 YPC on the 11 rushing attempts he's received with Oakland (preseason included). With Oakland falling behind in the second half, third-stringer Jalen Richard popped for 74 total yards on 14 touches. Richard should compete with Martin moving forward, though that may not be Gruden's plan despite the former's oblivious talent.
report: Doug Martin rushed for 20 yards on four carries and caught both of his targets for -3 yards in the Raiders' Week 1 loss to the Rams.

impact: Sharing time with Jalen Richard as the Raiders' backups to Marshawn Lynch, Martin is worth rostering in fantasy leagues only as a deep-league handcuff/stash.
report: Doug Martin managed 11 yards on five carries in the Raiders' Week 4 win.

impact: Good luck.  Martin hasn't done anything notable since 2015 and is averaging a foul 2.99 YPC over his last 309 attempts spanning the 2016-18 seasons.  He has six touchdowns on the ground in 25 games over that span.  But the Raiders have nowhere else to turn really; Jalen Richard is more of a pass-game back than featured runner.  Whenever the Raiders are competitive, Martin could flirt with 15-18 carries, and that may be the case this week at home against the 2-5 Colts.
report: Coach Jon Gruden said Doug Martin is "ready to go" as the Raiders' "feature back" with Marshawn Lynch (groin) on injured reserve.

impact: Carr was near-flawless in the first half, completing 20-of-24 passes for 199 yards. The wheels fell off in the second half as the Rams outgained the Raiders 267 to 141. Carr short-armed his first interception down the sideline to Jared Cook (9-180). His second pick to no one in particular was a real treat as he lobbed a duck to the flats thinking Jalen Richard would be there. The cherry on top came when the Raiders were in full catchup-mode, having a pass tipped at the line and land in the arms of Marcus Peters for a pick-six. Carr and the Raiders travel to Broncos Stadium in Week 2, so a similar outcome in altitude is in the cards. He's a fringe QB3 in two-QB leagues moving forward.
report: Derek Carr completed 29-of-40 passes for 303 yards and three interceptions in the Raiders' Week 1 loss to the Rams.

impact: "(I) don’t have any doubts that Derek Carr is going to be great and I can’t wait to get started and get ready for the Broncos," Gruden said. "Knowing how good Derek is, it gives us hope that we can get it all solved." Carr actually got off to a strong start against the Rams, completing 20-of-24 passes for 199 yards in the first half, but had a complete meltdown after the break, tossing a pair of unspeakably bad interceptions. Carr was feeling pressure that wasn't there and seemed scared to throw deep. It was concerning to watch. Things are not going to get easier against Von Miller and the Broncos in Week 2.
report: Raiders coach Jon Gruden gave Derek Carr a vote of confidence at his Tuesday press conference.
