impact: Green broke the Bengals record with his 32nd 100-yard game. He was getting open with ease despite getting shadowed by Dolphins shutdown CB Xavien Howard. Green was held out of the end-zone against a Dolphins defense that leads the league in red-zone defense, but he's had a great start to the season, going over 50 yards in every game. Green gets a matchup with the Steelers in Week 6.
report: A.J. Green caught 6-of-10 targets for 112 yards in Week 5 against the Dolphins.

impact: Green had a couple drops in the first quarter.  His day was relatively quiet as he dealt with Joe Haden's coverage.  Green should bounce back in a big way next week in a shootout spot against the high-octane Chiefs.
report: A.J. Green caught 7-of-12 targets for 85 yards in the Bengals' Week 6 loss to the Steelers.

impact: Green had over 100 yards in the first half. He was a huge mismatch for Orlando Scandrick, but the Bengals struggled to sustain drives all night. Green had a near-touchdown but tripped and was tackled inside the five-yard line. He faded in the second half, finishing with just one catch over the final two quarters. Green will remain a WR1 for Week 8’s matchup with the Bucs.
report: A.J. Green caught 7-of-14 targets for 117 yards in Week 7 against the Chiefs.

impact: Moore appeared to be buried on the depth chart in the preseason, and that continued into Week 1. He played fewer snaps than Devin Funchess (57), Torrey Smith (51), and Jarius Wright (31) while finishing without a target. While he should climb the depth chart this season, Moore is not a must-hold in redraft leagues.
report: D.J. Moore played 17-of-67 (25 percent) snaps Week 1 against the Cowboys.

impact: Moore played just 17-of-67 snaps against the Cowboys, drawing zero targets. Despite Rivera's words, the sense of urgency probably does increase with Greg Olsen sidelined indefinitely. That doesn't make Moore worth a re-draft hold, but he could still come onto the radar in short order.
report: Panthers coach Ron Rivera says the team won't rush D.J. Moore's development.

impact: Moore has played just 17 snaps each of the first two games of the season, but he flashed with a 51-yard touchdown against Atlanta in which he made a few defenders miss on his way into the end zone. Cam Newton seems to like Jarius Wright, but Moore simply gives the offense more upside. He needs to be used more moving forward.
report: Panthers coach Ron Rivera said the team "has to put more on D.J. Moore's plate."

impact: Coach Ron Rivera promised more playing time for Moore entering Week 3, but he continued to play behind Devin Funchess, Jarius Wright, and Torrey Smith.  Carolina's coaching staff will have its Week 4 bye to consider increasing Moore's usage.  Moore remains barely roster worthy in 14-team leagues.
report: D.J. Moore managed one catch for three yards on two targets in the Panthers' Week 3 win over the Bengals.

impact: Moore finished the game with just one catch on two targets, but it was a step in the correct direction for his playing time. He actually out-snapped Jarius Wright by seven, and he was just 11 plays behind Torrey Smith. His role will hopefully expand coming out of the bye.
report: D.J. Moore played 33-of-67 snaps (49 percent) Week 3 against the Bengals.

impact: Moore made the most of his limited opportunities, especially after halftime when the rookie pulled in three catches for 45 yards. He flashed impressive wheels on his lone carry, chewing up 18 yards on a double reverse. Moore saw as many targets Sunday as he had in his first three games combined. He’s not fantasy-relevant yet, but he’s getting there.
report: D.J. Moore corralled each of his four targets for 49 yards while gaining 18 yards on his lone carry Sunday in the Panthers’ Week 5 win over the Giants.

impact: Moore is lucky he saw as many targets as he did, as his first half giveaways were the difference in the game. He muffed a punt that set the Redskins up at the Panthers' 22-yard line. The Redskins scored one play later. He then let the ball get "Peanut punched" out in the second quarter, setting up three more Redskins points. To coach Ron Rivera's credit, he did not bench his first-round pick and he was productive the rest of the game. Moore will be a boom/bust WR4/5 for Week 7 against the Eagles.
report: D.J. Moore caught 4-of-5 targets for 59 yards in the Panthers' Week 6 loss to the Redskins, adding 18 yards rushing while losing a pair of fumbles.

impact: The rookie lost two fumbles in the first half, but his coach stood by him. "We’re trying to develop a football team," Rivera said. "I’m not too concerned about punishing players for making mistakes as much as we are about developing them and making sure they’re learning and growing and being able to go forward with them." Moore continues to play fewer snaps than Torrey Smith and Jarius Wright, but his role is growing. He is a fine bench stash in deeper leagues.
report: Panthers coach Ron Rivera did not consider benching D.J. Moore.

impact: Carolina’s first-round pick also committed a penalty and continues to struggle with mental errors, but Moore’s explosiveness on the field is evident. Moore could end up with more Week 8 playing time if Torrey Smith can’t go after requiring X-rays following Sunday’s thrilling comeback win. Either way, Moore won’t be a fantasy option against the Ravens. Moore is just a Dynasty and deep-league stash for now.
report: D.J. Moore caught 3-of-5 targets for 29 yards in the Panthers’ Week 7 win over the Eagles.

impact: Smith is a "starter," but he has no fantasy value.  During their Week 4 bye, the Panthers need to find a way to cut Smith's snaps in favor of D.J. Moore.
report: Torrey Smith caught 3-of-6 targets for 19 yards in the Panthers' Week 3 win over the Bengals.

impact: Smith was completely anonymous despite seeing the field on 45-of-71 offensive snaps, but at least he got in some good cardio. Cam Newton must have either forgotten he existed or just chose not to acknowledge him. Either way, the well-traveled 29-year-old can be safely ignored in all fantasy formats.
report: Torrey Smith came up empty on his lone target Sunday in the Panthers’ Week 5 victory over New York.

impact: Smith, whose touchdown came on a goal line look, also converted a two-point attempt. The score was Smith's second as a Panther. Smith just crossed the 100-yard threshold for the season this afternoon. He's miles from fantasy relevance.
report: Torrey Smith caught 5-of-5 targets for 43 yards and a touchdown in the Panthers' Week 6 loss to the Redskins.

impact: He was seen limping to the X-ray room after the game.  Smith contributed a massive 35-yard catch on fourth down with only a few minutes remaining to keep alive what wound up being the game-winning drive. Smith finished with four catches for 61 yards on six targets. If he can’t play in Week 8 against the Ravens, D.J. Moore and Curtis Samuel could get more playing time.
report: Torrey Smith needed X-rays following Sunday’s Week 7 win over Philadelphia.

impact: Smith's knee swelled up after he hit the ground hard late in the Week 7 win, but it looks like he has avoided a serious injury. Smith caught four passes for 61 yards against the Eagles.
report: Panthers coach Ron Rivera said there is no structural damage to Torrey Smith's knee.

impact: He also sat out Wednesday's session, putting him on the wrong side of questionable for Sunday's matchup against the Ravens. D.J. Moore would see an expanded role if Smith is forced to sit.
report: Torrey Smith (knee) did not practice Thursday.

impact: Sunday will make only the fifth missed game for Smith spanning over his eight-year career. Coach Ron Rivera said to "expect an increased workload" for explosive rookie D.J. Moore and gadget WR Curtis Samuel sans Smith against the Ravens' daunting secondary. Neither should be trusted in this particular matchup.
report: Torrey Smith (knee) is out for Week 8 against the Ravens.

impact:
The Colts did not stretch the field -- just one of Luck's 39 completions gained more than 20 yards -- but Luck looked mostly comfortable against a talented Bengals pass rush and picked apart the defense at times in Frank Reich's up-tempo, no-huddle attack.  He absorbed only nine hits and two sacks among 61 total dropbacks. 
 Luck showed enough in this game to be viewed as a locked-in QB1 going forward.  He gets a softer Week 2 matchup in Washington.
report: Andrew Luck completed 39-of-53 passes for 319 yards, two touchdowns, and an interception in the Colts' Week 1 loss to Cincinnati.

impact: He was sacked once for a two-yard loss. Luck got off to a hot start, completing four-of-five passes for 40 yards on the Colts’ opening drive including a seven-yard touchdown strike to tight end Eric Ebron. He had his most success throwing to T.Y. Hilton, connecting seven times for 83 yards and a touchdown. That touchdown came on a two-yard bunny with 7:32 remaining in the fourth quarter. Luck endured his share of struggles despite the victory. He was intercepted twice, both by safety D.J. Swearinger. The first pick was on a ball tipped at the line of scrimmage but the second came on a pass Luck never should have thrown as Swearinger read his eyes the whole way. Sunday marked Luck’s first win as a starter since Week 17 of 2016. He’ll try to make it two in a row next week when the Colts travel to Philadelphia to take on the reigning World Champs.
report: Andrew Luck completed 21-of-31 passes for 179 yards with two touchdowns and two interceptions while adding two yards on four carries Sunday in the Colts’ Week 2 win over the Redskins.

impact: Luck struggled through the rain and continued to fail to push the ball downfield on his throwing attempts. He had just 80 yards passing before the final two possessions, the latter closed with him being pulled for Jacoby Brissett on the Hail Mary attempt to win the game. Luck's yards per pass attempt have progressively dropped each week, going from 6.0 to 5.8 to 4.1 this week. Luck's athleticism is still prevalent and he added a 33-yard run down the sideline, but his limitations driving the ball through the air have turned him into a dink-and-dunk passer. Luck will enter Week 4 as QB2 against the Texans.
report: Andrew Luck completed 25-of-40 passes for 164 yards with a touchdown in Sunday's Week 3 loss to the Eagles.

impact: The Colts are almost never challenging defenses in the vertical passing game, and they pulled Luck for Jacoby Brissett to attempt Sunday's last-gasp Hail Mary pass against the Eagles. "What I've seen is he makes all the throws," Reich insisted. "There's been plenty of throws down the field, in my mind ... (What) I've seen is a guy who is extremely accurate.  I have no concerns about velocity."  The Colts return home to face J.J. Watt's Texans next.
report: Colts coach Frank Reich insisted Monday that the team is not concerned with Andrew Luck's arm strength.

impact: He's practicing in full, so it's not a concern to his status. Luck has a rebound matchup with a Texans secondary that allowed Eli Manning to complete 86 percent of his passes in Week 3.
report: Andrew Luck is listed on the Week 4 injury report with a groin injury.

impact: Luck is averaging just 5.1 yards per attempt through three games, and his average depth of target is all the way down at 5.2 yards, a full three yards fewer than in 2016. Much of that is by design as the offense looks to hide a shoddy offensive line with quick passing, but it was telling the Colts decided to sub in Jacoby Brissett for the Hail Mary at the end of last week's game. Perhaps his arm strength is simply a work in progress following so much downtime, but it is a concern right now.
report: Andrew Luck said he "can make all the throws" and has his "full arsenal."

impact: The 62 attempts and 464 yards both set new career-highs for Luck.  At one point, the Colts trailed by three possessions in the second half.  But Luck rallied the team back as the Texans tried to give it away to the Colts, who were able to force overtime.  Luck entered the day at the bottom of the barrel in yards-per-attempt, but he unleashed more downfield throws in this one, hitting T.Y. Hilton for a pair of 40-plus-yard grabs.  Hilton eventually pulled his hamstring in the fourth quarter, leaving Nyheim Hines as Luck's top target.  The two hooked up for two red-zone touchdowns, with the other two going to Zach Pascal and Eric Ebron.  Luck's arm figures to surely be a bit tender this week ahead of a Thursday night date in Foxboro with the Patriots where he'll be a volume-driven QB1.  The Colts have zero running game.
report: Andrew Luck completed 40-of-62 passes for 464 yards and four touchdowns in the Colts' 37-34, Week 4 loss to the Texans.

impact: Although Luck's 6.18 yards per attempt was once again shaky, tonight was nothing but positives. Luck's spiral continued to tighten as he showed feathery ball placement in the short-to-intermediate parts of the field. Luck's deep ball is still not all the way back. He is lacking his pre-injury drive and appeared to lack feel the few times he really uncorked it. That should not bury the lede that he was confident and commanding with what was essentially an entire second-team offense thanks to injuries. His only real mistake was his first pick, a forced throw under pressure. The 29-year-old quarterback is firmly on the comeback trail. He has 10 days to rest up for a road trip to New York to face the Jets.
report: Andrew Luck completed 38-of-59 passes for 365 yards, three touchdowns and two interceptions in the Colts' 38-24, Week 5 loss to the Patriots.

impact: Luck survived countless drops and pass-catcher injuries for a monster fantasy performance, even in the face of defeat.  Throwing to the likes of Mo Alie-Cox, Erik Swoope, "Marcus Johnson," and "Zach Pascal," Luck kept the Colts in the game even as their defense collapsed.  Performances like these are a testament to Luck's legitimate greatness.  He may have lost deep-ball prowess, but he is a surefire every-week fantasy starter.  The Colts host the reeling Bills next.
report: Andrew Luck completed 23-of-43 passes for 301 yards, four touchdowns, and three interceptions in the Colts' Week 6 loss to the Jets.

impact: He wasn’t sacked. Sunday ended Luck’s streak of three straight 300-yard passing games, though he still had a productive week with four touchdowns, a total he’s now reached in three of his last four outings. Two of Luck’s TDs went to T.Y. Hilton, who returned this week following a two-game absence. Luck took it easy with Indy up big in the second half, attempting just eight passes after halftime and ceding the final two drives to backup Jacoby Brissett. The 29-year-old’s only real slip-up came when he let a high snap go through the back of the end zone, resulting in a safety. The former first overall pick will look to stay hot next week when the Colts travel to Oakland for a date with the 1-5 Raiders.
report: Andrew Luck completed 17-of-23 passes for 156 yards and four touchdowns while adding three rushes for five yards Sunday in the Colts’ Week 7 victory over Buffalo.

impact: It was a lowly day for Carolina's passing game as a whole as Dallas' ferocious pass rush limited any and all big-play ability. Christian McCaffrey ended up leading the Panthers across the board in targets (9), catches (6), and receiving yards (45). At 6-foot-4, 232 Funchess still commands red zone looks. He's a buy-low candidate if Greg Olsen (foot) is out for an extended period.
report: Devin Funchess caught 3-of-5 targets for 41 yards in the Panthers' Week 1 win over the Cowboys.

impact: Funchess had a terrible third-down drop in the first half and went into the break with a measly three grabs for 16 yards on five targets.  He played better in the second half, making a nifty sideline grab on the final drive to give Carolina a chance.  Funchess saw four more targets than he did in Week 1 and figures to continue to see increased usage as a fantasy WR3 without Greg Olsen (foot).
report: Devin Funchess caught 7-of-9 targets for 77 yards in the Panthers' Week 2 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Funchess was Carolina's leading receiver in a game where Cam Newton completed only 15 passes for 150 yards, and Ron Rivera's team leaned heavily on its running game for the win.  As Greg Olsen remains "month to month" with a broken foot, Funchess will be an every-week WR2 for the foreseeable future.  Fantasy owners need to hang onto Funchess tightly through Carolina's Week 4 bye.
report: Devin Funchess caught 4-of-7 targets for 67 yards and a touchdown in the Panthers' Week 3 win over the Bengals.

impact: Funchess had his most success after halftime, corralling three of his five second-half targets for 41 yards. His biggest play didn’t show up in the box score as Funchess delivered a crushing block on Janoris Jenkins, freeing Curtis Samuel to score a 25-yard touchdown in the first quarter. Funchess battled dehydration throughout the afternoon and even left for a brief stretch to get an IV in the second half, though he only missed a handful of snaps. The 24-year-old has drawn seven-plus targets in each of his last four games, though his workload will likely take a hit with Greg Olsen due back in Week 6. The Panthers are in D.C. next week.
report: Devin Funchess delivered four catches for 53 yards on seven targets Sunday in the Panthers’ Week 5 win over New York.

impact: It was arguably Funchess' best overall game of the year, which is encouraging since it came as Greg Olsen made his return to the lineup. Funchess made a few excellent catches, but the highlight was his 23-yard touchdown grab in the second quarter. Funchess skied over Quinton Dunbar in the end zone before essentially taking the ball off Dunbar's chest. Producing as a solid WR3, Funchess has an appetizing Week 7 matchup in the Eagles' struggling secondary.
report: Devin Funchess caught 5-of-8 targets for 74 yards and a touchdown in the Panthers' Week 6 loss to the Redskins.

impact: Funchess’ touchdown came on a sluggo route to beat Eagles top CB Ronald Darby from 18 yards away. Funchess came out of Michigan younger than most prospects and needed a few years to develop as a rotational receiver, but he is a legit No. 1 at this point. And he has stayed productive despite Greg Olsen’s (foot) return. Nevertheless, Funchess will be more WR3 than WR2 when the Panthers host a stingy Ravens defense next.
report: Devin Funchess caught 6-of-11 targets for 62 yards and a touchdown in the Panthers’ Week 7 win over the Eagles.

impact: Jones was targeted on a couple deep balls, but he and Matthew Stafford were unable to hook up on any big plays against an underrated Jets secondary.  Better days are obviously ahead.  Jones will be a WR2 next week in San Francisco.
report: Marvin Jones caught 4-of-8 targets for 54 yards in the Lions' Week 1 loss to the Jets.

impact: Jones routinely created separation from the Niners' secondary but Matthew Stafford couldn’t find his deep ball on Sunday. The most egregious misfire from Stafford came in the second quarter when Jones had nothing but green grass in front of him but the two couldn’t connect. That must have been frustrating for fantasy owners, though Stafford delivered a peace offering in the form of a five-yard touchdown pass to Jones with 8:36 left in the fourth quarter. Jones has now caught exactly four passes for 54 yards in each of his first two games. Say what you will about Marvin, but at least the man's consistent. Jones and the Lions will host the Patriots in Week 3.
report: Marvin Jones hauled in four catches for 54 yards and a touchdown Sunday in the Lions’ Week 2 loss to the 49ers.

impact: Jones was a full participant earlier in the week, which suggests he was injured late Thursday. He was a limited participant Friday. Second-year standout Kenny Golladay has essentially been a full-time player ahead of Jones so far, setting up T.J. Jones for more snaps if the latter is ruled out. The Lions operate the league's most pass-heavy offense from 3-WR sets and are bound to be in a shootout against New England's secondary Sunday night.
report: Marvin Jones (ankle) is questionable for Week 3 against the Patriots.

impact: Jones was a late addition to the injury report, getting in a limited practice Friday. He'll be monitored throughout the day, but it sounds like the Lions are expecting him to play. Jones was getting outsnapped by Kenny Golladay before going down and could see his role scaled back at less than 100 percent. He can't be trusted in Week 3 lineups.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports "there's optimism" Marvin Jones (questionable, ankle) plays in Sunday night's game with the Patriots.

impact: Darius Slay (concussion) is also active after being listed as questionable. Jones went down late in the practice week and came down to a game-time decision, so his snaps may be limited. The Lions will be without Ziggy Ansah (shoulder) for Sunday night's game. Ameer Abdullah, DE Kerry Hyder, OG Joe Dahl, OT Andrew Donnal and WR Brandon Powell are also inactive.
report: Marvin Jones (ankle) is active for Week 3 against the Patriots.

impact: Jones started and looked close to 100 percent playing through his ankle injury. He got wide open out of the slot for a deep 33-yard touchdown for his only highlight of the night. Jones finished behind Golden Tate (8) and Kenny Golladay (7) in targets, but there hasn't been much dropoff from his strong 2017. Jones is a FLEX play for Week 4 against the Cowboys.
report: Marvin Jones caught 4-of-6 passes for 69 yards and a touchdown in Week 3 against the Patriots.

impact: Jones made a highlight-reel catch in the second quarter, pulling in an absurd over-the-shoulder grab to beat Chidobe Awuzie for a 34-yard pickup. He was targeted in the end zone later in the half but the pass from Matthew Stafford was off the mark. Jones hasn’t had a blow-up game yet in 2018 and it’s fair to expect fewer of those this season with Kenny Golladay becoming a bigger part of the Lions’ passing game. Of course, both of them took a backseat to Golden Tate (8-132-2) on Sunday. Jones will be a mere WR3 next week against the Packers.
report: Marvin Jones chipped in with three catches for 56 yards on six targets Sunday in the Lions’ Week 4 loss to the Cowboys.

impact: Jones was added to the injury report Friday, being listed as a limited practice participant. That's not an encouraging sign for his Week 5 status. If Jones ends up sitting against the Packers, more work would fall on the plates of Golden Tate and Kenny Golladay.
report: Marvin Jones (ankle) is questionable for Week 5 against the Packers.

impact: Jones was a late addition to Friday's injury report, but this has happened frequently with Detroit receivers this year, and none of them has missed a game.  Jones has tormented the Packers historically.  He's an upside WR2 play.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter confirmed Marvin Jones (ankle, questionable) remains on track to play Sunday versus the Packers.

impact: Jones was a late addition to the injury report during the week but is good enough to go in the NFC North tilt.  At less than 100 percent and with Kenny Golladay and Golden Tate balling, Jones is a boom-bust WR3 play.
report: Marvin Jones (ankle) is active for Week 5 against the Packers.

impact: Playing through an ankle injury, Jones made his one catch count with a diving touchdown in the back of the end zone.  He almost had a second score from 42 yards out on a shot play when the defense jumped offside, but Jones was unable to control the ball through the ground after diving for it.  Jones gets a week to rest and get healthy with the Lions heading into their bye.
report: Marvin Jones caught an eight-yard touchdown on four targets in the Lions' Week 5 win over the Packers.

impact: Jones also drew a 25-yard DPI. It was a quiet day for the Lions' entire receiver corps, but Jones now has just 93 yards over his past three games. He is averaging a disappointing 45 on the year. Jones should still have blow-up games, but Kenny Golladay's emergence has rendered him a low-end WR3 in fantasy.
report: Marvin Jones caught 3-of-4 targets for 29 yards in the Lions' Week 7 win over the Dolphins.

impact: Tate had a real quiet first half and dropped a couple balls this evening, but he did score the Lions' only offensive touchdown.  The Lions marched right down the field on the first possession of the third quarter, with Tate capping it off with a 24-yard touchdown.  Tate's 15 targets were three more than Kenny Golladay and seven more than Marvin Jones to lead the team.  Fire Tate up as a WR2 with upside next week in a mouthwatering date against the 49ers.
report: Golden Tate caught 7-of-15 targets for 79 yards and one touchdown in the Lions' Week 1 loss to the Jets.

impact: Tate was having a rather quiet day until he broke off an enormous gain in the fourth quarter, torching K’Waun Williams for a 67-yard pickup. That was the longest play from scrimmage for either team, beating Matt Breida’s third-quarter touchdown run by a single yard. The catch was also Tate’s longest since Week 17 of last year when he nabbed a 71-yard touchdown against the Packers. Even with Kenny Golladay taking on a much larger role this year, Tate continues to be a volume monster, amassing 28 targets over his first two games. Fantasy owners can start him with confidence against New England in Week 3.
report: Golden Tate chipped in with seven catches for 109 on 13 targets Sunday in Detroit’s Week 2 loss to the Niners.

impact: He led the Lions in targets and tied for a team high in yards. It was still a mostly quiet night for Tate with Kenny Golladay and Marvin Jones doing all the scoring. Tate doesn’t play in two wide sets, but he’s still getting 80 percent of snaps. He's a Week 4 FLEX against the Cowboys.
report: Golden Tate caught 6-of-8 passes for 69 yards in Week 3 against the Patriots.

impact: Tate was a surprise addition to Detroit's Friday injury report. If he's unable to play, T.J. Jones would step in and primarily lead the Lions' receivers in slot routes. Marvin Jones and Kenny Golladay are both still WR3s against a Cowboys defense missing Sean Lee in the middle of field. Dallas' defense notably struggled across the board without Lee in 2017.
report: Golden Tate (hip) is questionable for Week 4 against the Cowboys.

impact: Tate was considered a game-time decision after injuring his hip at practice this week but he'll be out there for Sunday's 1 PM ET start. Kenny Golladay has been playing ahead of Tate in two-wide sets this year but Tate has still been productive, tallying 257 yards and a touchdown on 20 catches through three games. He'll be in play as a borderline WR2 against Dallas.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports Golden Tate (questionable, hip) will play Week 4 against the Cowboys.

impact: It seemed that whenever the Lions needed a big play on Sunday, Tate was there waiting to unleash mayhem on Dallas. The veteran slot man got his day started with a masterful 45-yard touchdown, making Jeff Heath and Jordan Lewis miss on his way to the end zone. Tate came up huge on the Lions' final drive, dusting Xavien Woods for a 35-yard pick-up before capping the drive with a 38-yard touchdown on a deep heave from Matthew Stafford, which gave Detroit a one-point lead with 2:17 left in the fourth quarter. This was Tate's first career game with 100-plus yards and two touchdowns. The stud 30-year-old will hope to keep the train rolling when the Lions return home to face Green Bay in Week 5.
report: Golden Tate secured eight catches for 132 yards and two touchdowns on eight targets Sunday in the Lions’ Week 4 loss to the Cowboys.

impact: Tate came back to earth after his 8-132-2 day in Dallas last week.  Matthew Stafford attempted just 26 passes with the Lions smashing the Packers 24-0 at halftime.  Tate didn't get his first catch until late in the second quarter.  A borderline WR1/2, Tate and the Lions are off until Week 7 at the Dolphins.
report: Golden Tate caught 5-of-7 targets for 42 yards in the Lions' Week 5 win over the Packers.

impact: Tate had the most yards from scrimmage of the Lions' "big three" at receiver. It was a quiet day for all involved with the Lions gutting the Dolphins on the ground. The Lions had their biggest rushing day since 1997. With just 78 yards receiving over his past two games, Tate will look to get cooking again as a mid-range WR2 against the Seahawks in Week 8.
report: Golden Tate caught 4-of-6 targets for 36 yards in the Lions' Week 7 win over the Dolphins, adding a 30-yard rush.

impact: This appears to be a new injury for Tate, who delivered a season-low 36 yards in last week's victory over Miami. In all likelihood, the Lions are probably just limiting his practice reps. If active, Tate will be in the WR2 picture Sunday versus his former team, the Seahawks.
report: Golden Tate (ankle) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: It confirms Tate's Week 8 status is not in doubt. Mired in a bit of a slump, Tate will be a mid-range WR2 against the Seahawks.
report: Golden Tate (ankle) was upgraded to "full" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Tate started the week as a limited participant at practice but got in full sessions on both Thursday and Friday. There was never much concern over his status for Week 8. The ironman wide receiver hasn't missed a game in over six years. He'll be in the WR2 mix against his former team.
report: Golden Tate (ankle) wasn't listed on the Lions' final injury report for Week 8 against the Seahawks.

impact: Baldwin hasn't played or practiced since injuring his knee in Week 1. Tyler Lockett and Brandon Marshall will be the featured receivers Sunday against Dallas.
report: Doug Baldwin (knee) is out for Week 3 against the Cowboys.

impact: Baldwin practiced Wednesday for the first time since Week 1. There's some hedging in Carroll's comments, but Baldwin reportedly "looks really good" despite sitting the last two games. Seattle's pass offense has went in the tank without Baldwin, so there's incentive to push him at less than 100 percent. Getting in a full practice would put Baldwin on track to return.
report: Seahawks coach Pete Carroll said he's confident Doug Baldwin (knee) has a chance to play this week.

impact: It's a great sign for Baldwin's availability against the Cardinals, though obviously he's not out of the woods just yet. While it would be tempting to immediately reinstall Baldwin as the focal point of Seattle's passing game, which has been largely dormant this year, it's possible the Seahawks ease him in to avoid re-injury. A wait-and-see approach might be best here.
report: Doug Baldwin (knee) returned to a limited practice on Wednesday.

impact: Baldwin was "limited" on Wednesday and will likely remain so on Thursday. Russell Wilson said Baldwin "looks great," but that it is up to the coaching staff if he returns after missing the past two weeks. It's tentatively looking like Baldwin will be out there against the Cardinals, but it is far from a slam dunk. Baldwin could end up a game-time call.
report: Speaking Thursday, Doug Baldwin (knee) said he "chomping at the bit" to return and "ready to go."

impact: The wideout declared himself "ready to go" for Week 4, though whether the medical staff clears him remains to be seen. Even if Baldwin does get the nod for Sunday's game in Arizona, it's likely he'll be eased in coming off a two-week absence. Baldwin's return would obviously come as great news to Russell Wilson, who ranks just 19th among NFL quarterbacks in passing yards per game.
report: Doug Baldwin (knee) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: "He looked great [in practice]," coach Pete Carroll said during an appearance on a local radio show. "He caught the ball great. You could just feel he and Russ hooking up on different stuff. Russ was so confident throwing him the football in his routes, so we're really excited for him to play in this game." Baldwin had been limited in practice Wednesday and Thursday but sounds as if he's a full go for the Hawks' division matchup in Arizona Sunday. Tyler Lockett owners should be bearish as he's averaged 6.5 targets and 4.5-68.5-1 in his last two games without Baldwin.
report: Doug Baldwin (knee) will play in Week 4 against the Cardinals.

impact: Coach Pete Carroll has already said Baldwin will play this week. After missing the last two games, it's possible Baldwin doesn't see a full complement of snaps, but he's still the favorite for targets. Baldwin's return downgrades Tyler Lockett to WR4 status.
report: Doug Baldwin (knee) is questionable for Week 4 against the Cardinals.

impact: Baldwin will return Sunday, but he's only two weeks removed from a torn MCL. He's also dealing with a separate issue on his left knee that limited him in practice. Even at less than full health, Baldwin is a good bet to lead Seattle in targets, but he's at risk of getting rested in the second half of a potential blowout.
report: The Seattle Times reports Doug Baldwin (questionable, knee) "may not be 100 percent" for Sunday's game with the Cardinals.

impact: Baldwin was playing in his first game since exiting Week 1 with a knee injury after he missed the entire preseason with a knee injury to his other knee. Baldwin lead the Seahawks in targets on Sunday and will enter Week 5 as a lower-end WR2 option against a Rams team that has been vulnerable to interior wideouts.
report: Doug Baldwin caught 5-of-7 passes for 41 yards in Sunday's Week 4 win over the Cardinals.

impact: The 'Hawks are likely just managing Baldwin's reps after his Week 4 return. He'll be a WR3 for a tough matchup with the Rams.
report: Doug Baldwin (knee) was added to the Seahawks' injury report on Thursday, getting in a limited session.

impact: He was downgraded to limited practice on Thursday, but that was probably just for maintenance purposes. Baldwin saw his usual snaps in Week 4, logging five catches for 41 yards in his return from a two-game absence. He'll be on the WR2/3 borderline Sunday against the Rams.
report: Doug Baldwin (knee) wasn't listed on the Seahawks' final injury report for Week 5 against the Rams.

impact: Baldwin appeared to play his normal complement of snaps and did not look hampered by his knee injury as he blocked play after play. The real problem was Russell Wilson attempted just 21 passes as Seattle consistently gashed the Rams' defense on the ground. Baldwin should have better games moving forward, but Seattle's new emphasis on the running game is very concerning for his rest-of-season outlook. He should be considered a WR3 next week against the Raiders.
report: Doug Baldwin caught his only target for one yard in the Seahawks' Week 5 loss to the Rams.

impact: That's dead last in the pass-happy NFL.  It's affecting Doug Baldwin in a big way, as he has just nine targets in three games and has turned those into six catches for 42 scoreless yards.  Russell Wilson attempted just 21 passes last week in a shootout against the Rams, and it's having a big drain on his numbers as well.  Wilson is currently the fantasy QB19 and isn't being allowed to scramble as much as years past.  Meanwhile, Baldwin is growing increasingly frustrated and says his balky knee isn't to blame.  After a one-catch for one-yard afternoon on one target against L.A., it's really hard to trust Baldwin in fantasy.
report: The Seahawks have thrown the ball just 42.93 percent of the time over the last three weeks.

impact: Baldwin's knee probably won't be 100 percent all season, but right now, it's as good as it's going to be. The veteran wideout was mostly used as a decoy in Week 5, drawing just one target in a loss to the Rams. Perhaps he'll fare better Sunday when the Seahawks travel to London for a game against the Raiders.
report: Doug Baldwin (knee) is practicing in full for Week 6 against the Raiders.

impact: Baldwin's one-target Week 5 game sent the fantasy community into a tailspin, but he rebounded for a solid game against an Oakland defense that has struggled mightily to cover the slot.  Baldwin's eight targets were easily a team high; the next-closest Seahawks pass catcher had only four.  Despite his slow start, Baldwin will emerge from Seattle's Week 7 bye as an every-week fantasy WR2.  He is a recommended buy-low target in fantasy leagues.
report: Doug Baldwin caught 6-of-8 targets for 91 yards in the Seahawks' Week 6 win over the Raiders.

impact: Watkins was targeted on Patrick Mahomes' first pass of the game but ended up getting out-targeted by both Tyreek Hill and Travis Kelce. That's not surprising, of course. Watkins had to contend with a few poor throws from Mahomes, though he did catch a blazing, low fastball for his second reception. Watkins is going to have big games in the Chiefs' high-octane offense, but they will be harder to see coming than Hill or Kelce's. He is best treated as a WR4 in fantasy.
report: Sammy Watkins caught 3-of-5 targets for 21 yards in the Chiefs' Week 1 win over the Chargers.

impact: The Chiefs made a point of getting Watkins going after his quiet Week 1, targeting him five times in the first 16 minutes. Despite the obvious intent, Watkins' usage did not feel forced. He was running fluidly in the Chiefs' high-octane attack. Watkins is going to be a feast-or-famine player behind Tyreek Hill and Travis Kelce, but today serves as a good reminder of his unusual upside for a WR3/4.
report: Sammy Watkins caught 6-of-7 targets for 100 yards in the Chiefs' Week 2 win over the Steelers, adding 31 yards on an end around.

impact: He added another 20 yards on two carries. Watkins' role in the passing game expanded last week, and he hauled in his first touchdown with the Chiefs in this game. The score was a 12-yard reception late in the second quarter in which Watkins ran through a few tacklers. An emerging part of the best offense in the league, Watkins will be an upside WR3 next week in Denver.
report: Sammy Watkins hauled in 5-of-8 targets for 55 yards and a touchdown in the Chiefs' Week 3 win over the 49ers.

impact: Watkins exited midway through the first half after catching no passes on one target.  Demarcus Robinson and Chris Conley will see increased reps behind Tyreek Hill for however long Watkins is out.  He's questionable to return.
report: Sammy Watkins exited Week 4 against the Broncos with a hamstring injury.

impact: He went catch-less on one target before leaving midway through the first half.  On a short week ahead of Week 5 against the Jaguars, Watkins will be up against it to play.  He wouldn't be a recommended play in that matchup anyway.  Chris Conley and Demarcus Robinson are next up on the depth chart.
report: Sammy Watkins (hamstring) has been ruled out for the remainder of Week 4 against the Broncos.

impact: It's unknown in what capacity, but we would assume Watkins is limited after pulling his hamstring Monday night early in the first half and being unable to return.  However, this is a promising sign for his Week 5 availability against the Jaguars where he'll be a WR4 in an extremely tough matchup.
report: Sammy Watkins (hamstring) is practicing Wednesday.

impact: Watkins is tentatively on track to suit up after tweaking his hamstring on Thursday night, though he's never been the most predictable when it comes to injuries. Watkins would be valuable even as a decoy against the Jags' elite secondary. Attention he occupies would be attention that could not be devoted to Tyreek Hill and Chris Conley.
report: Sammy Watkins (hamstring) remained "limited" on Thursday.

impact: The Chiefs limited Watkins in practice all week. Coach Andy Reid didn't sound overly concern with his status, so it would be a surprise if Watkins didn't play. He'll be just a WR4 for a tough matchup with the Jaguars' secondary.
report: Sammy Watkins (hamstring) is listed as questionable for Week 5 against Jacksonville.

impact: Watkins is ready to lace 'em up after getting in a limited week of practice. The 25-year-old should avoid Jalen Ramsey, but he still gets a difficult matchup against one of the league's premier secondaries. It's also worth noting that rain has been falling all morning in Kansas City. Even with quarterback Patrick Mahomes on an insane hot streak, Watkins is best viewed as a WR3/4 against the Jags.
report: Sammy Watkins (questionable, hamstring) is expected to play Week 5 against the Jaguars.

impact: It appeared as if Watkins would miss some time after leaving last week's game with a hamstring injury, but he was able to participate all week in practice and is ready to go. Perhaps he is slightly limited, and he faces a tough matchup. Even so, he is worth using as a WR3 as a major cog in a great offense.
report: Sammy Watkins (hamstring) is active for Week 5 against the Jaguars.

impact: Watkins entered the game nursing a hamstring injury, but he looked healthy on Sunday. His biggest play of the day came when he found a hole in zone coverage for a 33-yard gain on third down in the first half. Clearly healthy and a major cog in the best offense in the league, Watkins will be an upside WR3 play next week in New England.
report: Sammy Watkins hauled in 6-of-8 targets for 78 yards in the Chiefs' Week 5 win over the Jaguars.

impact: Watkins played through a questionable tag last week. This confirms he didn't have any setbacks. Coming off one of his better games, Watkins is a WR3 for Week 6.
report: Sammy Watkins (hamstring) is practicing in full for Week 6.

impact: Watkins didn’t make first catch until late in the third quarter. He took a backseat to Tyreek Hill after outplaying him over the last couple weeks. There should be better days ahead from Watkins. He's a WR3 for a Week 7 matchup with the Bengals.
report: Sammy Watkins caught 2-of-4 passes for 18 yards in Week 6 against the Patriots.

impact: Watkins was on his way to another quiet game, but he salvaged his night with a 50-yard catch to open the second half. He wasn't much of a factor, though his seven targets were behind only Tyreek Hill. Watkins got banged up late in the fourth quarter but wasn't announced with an injury. He'll have a tough matchup with Denver's secondary in Week 8.
report: Sammy Watkins caught 4-of-7 passes for 74 yards in Week 7 against the Bengals.

impact: Stewart got some run after Wayne Gallman left with an injury, but he was the clear No. 3 back before that. Even if something happened to Saquon Barkley, Stewart would not be an enticing fantasy play. He does not need to be rostered in any format.
report: Jonathan Stewart rushed twice for eight yards in the Giants' Week 1 loss to the Jaguars.

impact: Stewart has just six carries this year. He's buried behind Saquon Barkley and Wayne Gallman as the No. 3 back.
report: Jonathan Stewart (foot) didn't practice Wednesday.

impact: Stewart is nowhere near fantasy radars.  Wayne Gallman is the Giants' No. 2 back.
report: Jonathan Stewart (foot) is out for Week 4 against the Saints.

impact: Stewart's Giants tenure has been an utter mess, resulting in just six carries for 17 yards (2.83 YPC). Wayne Gallman has seamlessly transitioned in as the Giants' backup and should stay there for the remainder of the year even if Stewart returns.
report: Giants placed Jonathan Stewart (foot) on injured reserve.

impact: The coach says Stewart will be sidelined eight weeks by a foot injury, a timetable which conveniently fits with the time he must miss after being placed on injured reserve last week. Even if Stewart is healthy enough to return later in the season, there would be little reason to bring him back unless something happened to Saquon Barkley or Wayne Gallman.
report: Giants coach Pat Shurmur said Jonathan Stewart (foot, injured reserve) could return this season.

impact: Gallman was working as the clear No. 2 running back behind Saquon Barkley, but he picked up a knee injury in the third quarter. Jonathan Stewart, who has not lost a step, will serve as the backup while Gallman is out.
report: Giants RB Wayne Gallman (knee) is questionable to return Week 1 against the Jaguars.

impact: Gallman left Week 1 against the Jaguars with a knee injury, but he said that was just precautionary. The sophomore was working as the No. 2 back before going down.
report: Wayne Gallman (knee) expects to play Week 2.

impact: He finished second among Indy backs in touches behind Jordan Wilkins (17).  Hines was used heavily on screens and also gained 17 yards on a route where he lined up at wide receiver.  Even when Marlon Mack (hamstring) returns, Hines has a chance to carve out PPR flex value in this catch-first role.  The Colts are playing dink-and-dunk passing offense, and Hines' game suits that style of play.
report: Nyheim Hines rushed five times for 19 yards and caught 7-of-9 targets for 33 yards in the Colts' Week 1 loss to the Bengals.

impact: Hines impressed with a spinning, eight-yard touchdown dash in the second quarter but was a non-factor otherwise. All but two of his touches came in the first half. Hines spent most of the afternoon working behind Jordan Wilkins and Marlon Mack and that will likely be the case again next week against the Eagles. The fourth-round rookie is just a bench stash at this point.
report: Nyheim Hines contributed seven yards and a touchdown on four carries while catching his lone target for a loss of two yards Sunday in the Colts’ Week 2 win over the Redskins.

impact: Hines "led" the Colts backfield in Week 3, but hardly was noteworthy. Through three games, Hines has carried 14 times for 44 yards while catching 13 passes for 56 yards. He is not a fantasy option Week 4 against the Texans.
report: Nyheim Hines rushed five times for 18 yards while catching 5-of-5 targets for 25 yards in Sunday's Week 3 loss to the Eagles.

impact: Hines' 11 targets tied with Chester Rogers for the team lead on a day Andrew Luck uncorked a career-high 62 pass attempts.  With no Jack Doyles (hip) and T.Y. Hilton in and out of the game with chest and hamstring injuries, Hines became Luck's most trustworthy option.  Both of his scores were red-zone successes, from 14 and nine yards out.  The 14-yarder was an incredible leaping catch over the top of Tyrann Mathieu.  With the Colts having zero run game, Hines is essentially the extension of their nonexistent rushing offense.  He needs to be owned in all formats.
report: Nyheim Hines rushed four times for 10 yards and caught 9-of-11 targets for 63 yards and two touchdowns in the Colts' Week 4 loss to the Texans.

impact: The 15 carries were a new season high by 10, though as you can see, Hines struggled to do anything with them. Jordan Wilkins was more involved in the second half but marred his night with a soft giveaway. Things change fast in a backfield this injured and ineffective, but Hines figures to remain the only Indy runner with any fantasy appeal for Week 6 against the Jets.
report: Nyheim Hines rushed 15 times for 45 yards in the Colts' Week 5 loss to the Patriots, adding seven receptions for 45 additional yards.

impact: Hines dropped an early would-be touchdown on third-and-goal to force a field goal, and he wasn't heard from much after that.  Marlon Mack led the backfield in Week 6 touches and sparked the rushing attack with 89 yards on 12 carries.  In a multi-headed RBBC, Hines is suddenly back in the shaky PPR-flex-option mix.
report: Nyheim Hines rushed three times for 14 yards and caught 2-of-3 targets for 21 yards in the Colts' Week 6 loss to the Jets.

impact: Hines played well when called upon, which wasn't often with Marlon Mack in the midst of a career game. Mack wound up out-touching Hines by a substantial 21-6 margin while also losing the snap battle 38-17. Hines will continue to have a role, especially when Indy is playing from behind, but he's now a distant second to Mack in the Colts' backfield pecking order. The fourth-round rookie gets the Raiders on the road in Week 8.
report: Nyheim Hines tallied 47 yards on five carries while adding one catch for -5 yards on two targets Sunday in the Colts’ Week 7 victory over the Bills.

impact: He'll face a Bengals run defense that is missing WLB Vontaze Burfict (hamstring) but remains largely stout up front.  Of more concern for Wilkins' fantasy outlook is his RBBC with Christine Michael and Nyheim Hines.  New Colts coach Frank Reich was a committee-backfield proponent during his time in Philadelphia.
report: Jordan Wilkins will be the Colts' starting running back in Week 1.

impact: The good news is Wilkins led Indy's backfield with 17 touches compared to Nyheim Hines' 12 and Christine Michael's two.  The bad news is the Colts continued to struggle to run block, and Wilkins struggled for effiency on his opportunities.  Marlon Mack (hamstring) could also return as soon as Week 2, which would further muddy up the running back distribution.  At best, Wilkins will be a low-end flex option at Washington in the second game.
report: Jordan Wilkins rushed 14 times for 40 yards and caught 3-of-3 targets for 21 yards in the Colts' Week 1 loss to the Bengals.

impact: He went down about midway through the second quarter. Wilkins delivered 25 yards on five carries along with one catch for no gain upon exiting. With Wilkins banged up, Indy's backfield reps will be split between Marlon Mack and Nyheim Hines.
report: Jordan Wilkins left Sunday's Week 2 game against the Redskins with an ankle injury and is questionable to return.

impact: Wilkins left briefly after tweaking his ankle in the second quarter but the injury didn’t seem to bother him in the second half. The fifth-round rookie failed to impress in last week’s debut against Cincinnati (2.9 yards per carry) but he did a nice job of moving the chains in this one. His 18-yard scamper with under five minutes remaining in the fourth quarter essentially sealed the win for Indy. Wilkins out-touched teammate Marlon Mack by a slim 12-11 margin, though he held a decisive edge in yards from scrimmage (64-36). The Colts seem committed to using a timeshare at running back, so we’d expect similar usage for both players next week against the Eagles.
report: Jordan Wilkins tallied 61 yards on 10 carries while collecting two catches for three yards on two targets Sunday in the Colts’ Week 2 win over Washington.

impact: Wilkins started in place of Marlon Mack, but found little room to run as the Eagles dominated on the defensive front. Wilkins now has rushed 30 times for 120 yards with seven catches for 25 yards through three games. He is not a starting-caliber option heading into Week 4 versus the Texans.
report: Jordan Wilkins rushed six times for 19 yards while catching two passes for one yard in Sunday's Week 3 loss to the Eagles.

impact: Wilkins got another start with Marlon Mack injured, but he again did nothing of note.  Over the past two weeks, Wilkins has 35 yards on 14 carries.  Wilkins wasn't active in the pass game, either, failing to catch his lone target against Houston.  Wilkins doesn't belong in fantasy lineups Week 5 at New England.
report: Jordan Wilkins rushed eight times for 16 yards in the Colts' Week 4 loss to the Texans.

impact: Wilkins got out-touched 22-8 by Nyheim Hines. He marred what could have been a promising night with a soft second half fumble as he fought for extra yardage. Regardless of Marlon Mack's health, Wilkins simply has not been able to make it happen behind the Colts' banged up offense line. Mack now has 10 more days to get healthy for Week 6.
report: Jordan Wilkins rushed six times for 39 yards in the Colts' Week 5 loss to the Patriots, adding two receptions for nine additional yards.

impact: Even as Marlon Mack and Nyheim Hines both made major miscues and Robert Turbin left with a potentially severe shoulder injury, Wilkins was not used by the coaching staff.  Wilkins is safe to drop in 12-team season-long leagues.
report: Jordan Wilkins did not touch the ball in Week 6.

impact: With Robert Turbin (shoulder) sidelined, Wilkins saw his first touches in three weeks. He got the last series all to himself with Indy up big in the fourth quarter. Wilkins had some fantasy relevance early on, but now that Marlon Mack is back from his hamstring injury, he's no longer worth rostering.
report: Jordan Wilkins collected 46 yards on six carries while securing his lone target for an eight-yard gain Sunday in the Colts’ Week 7 win over Buffalo.

impact: This is the way Mack had been trending after the Colts promoted Jeremy McNichols from the practice squad. Mack got in some limited practice this week, so he looks on track to return in Week 5. Jordan Wilkins and Nyheim Hines will continue to form a committee against Houston.
report: Marlon Mack (questionable, hamstring) is not expected to play Week 4 against the Texans.

impact: Mack was questionable but wasn't expected to play.  The Colts promoted Jeremy McNichols from the practice squad as depth behind Jordan Wilkins and Nyheim Hines.  Also inactive for the Colts are TE Jack Doyle (hip), LT Anthony Castonzo (hamstring), DE Tarell Basham, DT Hassan Ridgeway, DT Grover Stewart, and CB Quincy Wilson.  Mack has missed two games in a row.
report: Marlon Mack (hamstring) is inactive Week 4 against the Texans.

impact: He was limited in multiple practices last week, then did not play against the Texans. Mack won't be rushed back with Robert Turbin returning from suspension.
report: Marlon Mack (hamstring) was listed as a limited participant in the Colts' practice on Monday.

impact: It has Mack tentatively on track to return for Thursday night's game against the Patriots. With T.Y. Hilton (hamstring) sidelined, the Colts could be forced to lean more on the run, though their short-passing attack will continue to function as an extension of the ground game. If Mack does suit up, he will not be a recommended FLEX in any format. He's missed too much time, and the situation is too uncertain.
report: Marlon Mack (hamstring) practiced again on Tuesday.

impact: Mack has been practicing each of the past two weeks, but has been a somewhat surprising inactive both Weeks 4 and 5 now.  Jordan Wilkins and Nyheim Hines will continue to dominate the backfield snaps with Hines being the far superior fantasy play after his two-touchdown game against Houston.
report: Marlon Mack (hamstring) is out for Week 5 against the Patriots.

impact: Mack also practiced last week before sitting out the game against the Patriots. He should have a better shot to suit up this week, but at best he will be in a committee with Jordan Wilkins and Robert Turbin. Nyheim Hines is the player to roster in this backfield.
report: Marlon Mack (hamstring) is participating in Monday's practice.

impact: A nagging hamstring injury has sidelined Mack for much of the season, though it appears he'll suit up Sunday in East Rutherford. He'll be returning to a backfield committee featuring rookies Nyheim Hines and Jordan Wilkins. Of the three, Hines commands the most fantasy attention.
report: Marlon Mack (hamstring) is practicing in full for Week 6 against the Jets.

impact: Mack got in a full week of practice for the first time this season. Barring a setback, he'll return after sitting the last three games. Mack is the favorite for early-down work in the Colts' committee, but Nyheim Hines is going to remain involved. Owners should take a wait-and-see approach before plugging Mack into lineups.
report: Marlon Mack (hamstring) is expected to start in Week 6 against the Jets.

impact: The Colts' inactives are DTs Denico Autry and Margus Hunt, TE Jack Doyle, S Clayton Geathers, OL Denzelle Good, CB Art Maulet, and WR T.Y. Hilton.  Mack is expected to share time with Jordan Wilkins behind lead back Nyheim Hines.
report: Marlon Mack is active for Week 6 against the Jets.

impact: He now has 11 and 13 touches through two 2018 appearances.  Mack shook off a first-drive dropped pass that was pick-sixed by Mo Claiborne to give the Colts' running game a jolt after it struggled mightily in the first five weeks.  The backfield remains a timeshare situation, however, and Mack has passing-game limitations.  He will be a boom-bust flex option in Week 7 versus Buffalo.
report: Marlon Mack rushed 12 times for 89 yards and caught 1-of-2 targets for four yards in the Colts' Week 6 loss to the Jets.

impact: Mack supplied his first touchdowns since Week 17 of last season while setting career-highs in rushing yards, yards from scrimmage and touches. The second-year USF alum burned the Bills for a number of big plays including a 29-yard touchdown off a screen pass from Andrew Luck during the second quarter. He added another score in the fourth, breaking loose for a 20-yard rushing touchdown. Mack was slowed by a hamstring injury early in the year but he hasn't shown any ill effects the last two weeks, exploding for 252 yards (215 rushing, 37 receiving) on 34 touches during that span. Now firmly entrenched as Indy's lead back, Mack will be in the RB2 discussion when the Colts travel to Oakland for Week 8.
report: Marlon Mack broke out for 126 yards and a touchdown on 19 carries while also chipping in with two catches for 33 yards and another touchdown on three targets Sunday in the Colts’ Week 7 win over the Bills.

impact: It's a new injury for Mack, who missed time with a hamstring issue earlier this year. His presence at Wednesday's practice, albeit in a limited capacity, suggests he'll be fine to face Oakland in Week 8. Coming off a career game in Week 7 (159 yards, two touchdowns in a win over Buffalo), the second-year USF alum will be an appealing RB2 against the struggling Raiders.
report: Marlon Mack (ankle) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: It's possible Mack is just getting extra treatment, but mid-week downgrades are never good news. For now, Mack should be considered genuinely questionable. The Colts would return to a three- or four-man committee in Mack's potential absence against the Raiders. If Mack can go, he will be an RB1 against the Raiders' soft and tanking defense.
report: Marlon Mack (ankle) was downgraded to "DNP" on Thursday.

impact: This would seem to be good news for Mack's status for Sunday in Oakland.  We'll have official injury report designations within the next hour or two.
report: Marlon Mack (ankle) returned to practice Friday.

impact: Mack is listed as questionable, but notably got in a full practice on Friday. That clearly puts him on track to play against the Raiders. Mack's presence would be a massive downgrade to Nyheim Hines, who's played sparingly since Mack's initial hamstring injury healed. Note that the second-year pro handled 19 carries on 56.1% of the Colts' offensive snaps (both season-highs) in a full-time role just last week.
report: Marlon Mack (ankle) is questionable for Week 8 against the Raiders.

impact: Conley's score was a bullet on a first quarter post route. Conley got the inside track on Artie Burns. It was a nice play, but Conley has just three targets through two games. Patrick Mahomes is working miracles, but he can't make Conley fantasy relevant.
report: Chris Conley caught 2-of-2 targets for 17 yards and a touchdown in the Chiefs' Week 2 win over the Steelers.

impact: Hill also rushed twice for four yards. It was a completely ridiculous performance, with Hill's punt return score the Chiefs' first touch of the season. He added a 58-yard receiving touchdown just seven minutes later. Hill's second passing strike was a one-yard shovel from Patrick Mahomes. There was a scary moment in the first quarter when Hill was evaluated for both a concussion and shoulder injury after an awkward landing, but he was cleared to remain in the game. The dream chemistry Hill displayed with Mahomes in the preseason carried over against the Chargers' (supposedly) elite defense. Hill gets the Steelers in Week 2.
report: Tyreek Hill caught 7-of-8 targets for 169 yards and a pair of touchdowns in the Chiefs' Week 1 win over the Chargers, adding a 91-yard punt return score.

impact: Hill wasn't even targeted in the first half, so 5/90/1 was quite an accomplishment, even if that's quiet by Hill's standards. Hill's score was a 29-yarder where he got several steps on Artie Burns down the left sideline. Hill will try to torment the 49ers in the Chiefs' Week 3 home opener.
report: Tyreek Hill caught 5-of-6 targets for 90 yards and a touchdown in the Chiefs' Week 2 win over the Steelers.

impact: With Patrick Mahomes spreading the ball around, Hill did not have a blow-up game, but he still made his presence known by going up high to reel in a 42-yard catch in the second quarter. He also should have had a 49-yard touchdown, but Mahomes just underthrew him, allowing the defender to catch up. Hill will have some down games, but his upside is as high as any receiver in the league. He will remain a locked-in WR1 next week against the Broncos.
report: Tyreek Hill hauled in 2-of-5 targets for 51 yards in the Chiefs' Week 3 win over the 49ers.

impact: He "added" two yards on one carry.  The Broncos did a really good job of containing Hill, but Travis Kelce and Kareem Hunt were able to pick up the slack, combining for 253 yards and a couple scores.  Hill has had a quiet last two games with no touchdowns and will be a WR2 next week vs. Jacksonville.
report: Tyreek Hill caught 9-of-13 targets for 54 yards in the Chiefs' Week 4 win over the Broncos.

impact: Jalen Ramsey's shadow should be Hill's toughest test of the season, but that did not stop him from making big plays. He opened the game with a 40-yard run on Kansas City's first offensive play, although it was reduced to 21 yards because of a penalty. He added a 36-yard catch in the third quarter on a great throw by Patrick Mahomes. Always a threat for a big play, Hill should have a much easier time next week in New England.
report: Tyreek Hill hauled in 4-of-7 targets for 61 yards and rushed twice for 26 yards in the Chiefs' Week 5 win over the Jaguars.

impact: Even the huge stats don't do justice to how good of a night Hill had. Hill’s first two touchdowns came in the red-zone, and he smoked the Patriots on a blown assignment for a 75-yard TD to tie the game with under four minutes. Hill got most of his yardage on chunk plays, but his speed was too much for New England's zone schemes. It’s a needed breakout for Hill after he'd been held to 166 scoreless yards over the last three games. Hill is in a great spot against the Bengals in another Sunday night matchup next week.
report: Tyreek Hill caught 7-of-12 targets for 142 yards and three touchdowns in the Chiefs' Week 6 loss to the Patriots.

impact: Hill was featured heavily but didn’t break any huge plays. He should've had a 35-yard touchdown but dropped a wide open pass in the end-zone. Hill made up for it a few plays later with a goal-line TD. He's now scored touchdowns in consecutive games after a three-week scoring drought. Hill has a matchup with the Broncos in Week 8.
report: Tyreek Hill caught 7-of-10 passes for 68 yards and a touchdown in Week 7 against the Bengals.

impact: Thomas re-fractured his leg at Thursday's practice. It's the same injury that ended his 2017 season. Thomas doesn't need surgery, but he's headed for IR.
report: Chiefs KR De'Anthony Thomas is out indefinitely with a leg injury.

impact: Thomas suffered his second leg fracture in two seasons in practice this week. He doesn't need surgery but isn't going to be back this year. Tremon Smith will take over as Kansas City's kick returner.
report: Chiefs placed KR De'Anthony Thomas (leg) on injured reserve.

impact: His biggest play, however, was a terrible drop in the fourth quarter that ended up popping into the air for an easy Falcons interception.  Anderson has 10 carries for 64 yards through two weeks and obviously is not a fantasy option.  He'll only be one if Christian McCaffrey ever gets injured.
report: C.J. Anderson rushed three times for 31 yards in the Panthers' Week 2 loss to the Falcons.

impact: He now has three touches in consecutive games.  Anderson's big Week 3 play came on a screen pass where he did a nice job reading his blocks before reaching pay dirt.  Anderson has no standalone fantasy value, but he is a worthwhile handcuff to Christian McCaffrey.  McCaffrey had 30 touches in Sunday's victory.
report: C.J. Anderson rushed twice for nine yards and caught his lone target for a 24-yard touchdown in the Panthers' Week 3 win over the Bengals.

impact: Anderson remained a non-factor on Sunday, losing the touch battle 22-4 to Christian McCaffrey. Unless low-volume handcuffs are your jam, the ex-Bronco doesn’t belong on any fantasy rosters.
report: C.J. Anderson totaled just nine yards on four carries Sunday in the Panthers’ Week 5 victory over the Giants.

impact: This looks like a healthy scratch after Walton was removed from the injury report. Walton doesn't play special teams, so this doesn't change anything with his depth chart standing.
report: Mark Walton is inactive for Week 1.

impact: Walton was a healthy scratch the first two weeks. He doesn't play special teams, so it's not a sign of his standing with the Bengals. Walton started the fourth preseason game over Tra Carson and is listed ahead of him on the depth chart. A fourth-round pick, Walton had some Day 1 hype before missing most of his junior year to ankle surgery. The Bengals could pair Walton in a committee with Giovani Bernard until Mixon returns.
report: Bengals rookie Mark Walton is expected to be active in Week 3 with Joe Mixon (knee surgery) sidelined.

impact: "Giovani [Bernard] and Mark Walton will shoulder the load for the next few weeks," Lewis told SiriusXM's Ross Tucker. The quote could be read as the coach promising a timeshare, but it would still be surprising if Bernard did not handle the majority of the work. Even so, Walton is worth stashing on the bench to see how this situation shakes out.
report: Bengals coach Marvin Lewis confirmed Mark Walton will be the No. 2 running back while Joe Mixon is sidelined.

impact: Walton was more involved than last week before exiting in the third quarter, catching two passes for 28 yards and taking four carries five yards. With Walton out, Giovani Bernard is the Bengals' only active running back. This injury will be a concern if Joe Mixon is not ready to return next week.
report: Bengals RB Mark Walton exited week 4 against the Falcons with a possible concussion.

impact: Walton played sparingly behind Giovani Bernard the last two weeks but made a few highlights with his touches. With Joe Mixon coming off knee surgery and not in great conditioning, he's in line for his biggest workload of the year. Bernard's MCL sprain likely locks Walton into the No. 2 role for the next month. There's handcuff value with Walton if Mixon suffers another setback.
report: The Cincinnati Enquirer reports the Bengals are counting on Mark Walton to "fill in on more snaps."

impact: The Bengals were expected to get Walton more touches this week. He played sparingly behind Joe Mixon, failing to get a single carry. Walton has flashed when given chances, but he's just a handcuff until Giovani Bernard returns.
report: Mark Walton caught 2-of-3 passes for three yards in Week 5 against Miami.

impact: All are healthy aside from Smith, who has a hamstring issue.
report: Panthers declared RB Cameron Artis-Payne, OG Brendan Mahon, OG Amini Silatolu, DE Marquis Haynes, DE Bryan Cox, LB Andre Smith, and CB Corn Elder inactive Week 7 against the Eagles.

impact: Newton's 13 carries and 58 yards rushing were both team-highs. Dallas' defense did a tremendous job keeping Newton bottled up through the air, but the eight-year pro eventually took care of business on the ground, including a score inside the five-yard line. Cam averaged a career-high 8.6 rushing attempts per game last season, so perhaps more lines like Sunday's are in store for the 2015 MVP over the next 15 games. Carolina's backfield essentially split carries behind Newton as Christian McCaffrey handled 10 carries and C.J. Anderson mustered seven.
report: Cam Newton completed 17-of-26 passes for 161 yards and bulldozed his way to 58 yards and one touchdown on 13 carries in the Panthers' Week 1 win over the Cowboys.

impact: Newton added 42 yards on five carries to lead the Panthers in rushing.  At the end of one of those runs, early in the first half, Newton was illegally helmet-to-helmet-ed by Falcons S Damontae Kazee.  Kazee was ejected, and Cam looked to truly be concussed, and dazed at the very least.  He supposedly quickly passed a concussion test and didn't miss a play.  Newton still didn't miss a beat; his receivers merely let him down multiple times with drops.  The scores went to Jarius Wright (five yards), Torrey Smith (three), and rookie D.J. Moore (51).  A final heave from 26 yards out to Moore on the final play fell incomplete.  Newton will get the Bengals next week.
report: Cam Newton completed 32-of-45 passes for 335 yards, three touchdowns, and one interception in the Panthers' 31-24, Week 2 loss to the Falcons.

impact: Christian McCaffrey did the heavylifting with 194 yards from scrimmage, but Newton was the red-zone executioner with touchdowns to Devin Funchess and C.J. Anderson, one zone-read keeper, and another where Newton bootlegged around the left edge to pay dirt.  Newton will head into Carolina's Week 4 bye hot with back-to-back top-seven weekly fantasy quarterback performances.  The Panthers should get back stud RG Trai Turner (concussion) after the break.
report: Cam Newton completed 15-of-24 passes for 150 yards and two touchdowns, and rushed 10 times for 36 yards and two additional scores in the Panthers' 31-21 win over the Bengals in Week 3.

impact: He was sacked once for a loss of five. This game got all the way off the rails and Newton played a huge part in the insanity. Cam got off to a decent start, connecting with Curtis Samuel on a 25-yard touchdown in the first quarter (Samuel deserves credit for breaking a number of tackles on his way to the end zone). Newton was mostly held in check after that, however, shooting the Panthers in the foot with a pair of second-half interceptions, both on passes intended for tight end Ian Thomas. He redeemed himself somewhat by leading a scoring drive on the game's final possession, setting up a miraculous, 63-yard, walk-off field goal by Graham Gano. Newton didn't look particularly sharp coming off the Panthers' bye week. Perhaps he'll fare better with Greg Olsen (foot) due back from injury next week at Washington.
report: Cam Newton completed 21-of-35 passes for 237 yards with two touchdowns and two interceptions while adding 29 yards on four carries Sunday in the Panthers’ Week 5 victory over the Giants.

impact: The Panthers struggled to get into a rhythm on an afternoon where the Redskins dominated time of possession. Newton didn't help with some inaccurate passes, though he was keeping drives alive with tough runs. Things might have been different if not for a pair of lost D.J. Moore fumbles. Newton found a returning Greg Olsen four times for 48 yards. Newton has an attackable Week 7 matchup in the Eagles' struggling secondary.
report: Cam Newton completed 27-of-40 passes for 275 yards, two touchdowns and an interception in the Panthers' 23-17, Week 6 loss to the Redskins, adding nine carries for 43 additional yards.

impact: Newton shook off a dreadful first half to complete 21-of-30 passes for 245 yards and two touchdowns in the final two quarters, finding Devin Funchess for an 18-yard score and Greg Olsen for the game winner at the goal line as Carolina overcame a 17-0 deficit for the 21-17 victory.  Newton's second-half performance was truly heroic, particularly a fourth-down completion to Torrey Smith for 35 yards.  Newton gets a tougher Week 8 matchup against Baltimore, but he has been a high-floor, high-ceiling fantasy quarterback all year regardless of opponents.
report: Cam Newton completed 25-of-39 passes for 269 yards and two touchdowns and rushed seven times for 49 yards in the Panthers' Week 7 upset win over Philadelphia.

impact: It's his right (throwing) shoulder.  Coach Ron Rivera said Newton is "sore" and a little "tired" after last week's fourth-quarter comeback.  It doesn't sound serious.  We'd expect Cam out there against the Ravens this week.
report: Cam Newton (shoulder) was limited in Wednesday's practice.

impact: There was some concern after beat reporters noticed Newton wasn't throwing during the open portion of Thursday's practice, though apparently he got some reps in once the media left. OC Norv Turner admitted that Cam is dealing with "soreness" in his throwing shoulder but expects him to be "fine" for Sunday's matchup with Baltimore. Newton is No. 10 in our Week 8 quarterback rankings.
report: Cam Newton (shoulder) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Newton has seen limited practice reps this week while working through a sore shoulder but he'll be out there when it matters on Sunday. It's not an ideal matchup for Cam, though the former MVP will still be a QB1 consideration in all formats.
report: Panthers coach Ron Rivera said there's "no doubt" Cam Newton (shoulder) will play against the Ravens in Week 8.

impact: Newton was limited for the third consecutive practice on Friday, but his activity was reportedly scaled back for "maintenance" reasons to be sure he's healthy come Sunday. Coach Ron Rivera said "there is no doubt" Newton suits up against the Ravens. He's a QB1 for his rushing floor alone despite playing in an unfavorable matchup in Week 8.
report: Cam Newton (shoulder) wasn't listed on Carolina's Week 8 injury report against the Ravens.

impact: There's no concern over Bernard's status for Sunday's game in Atlanta. With Joe Mixon (knee) out another week, Bernard is in play as an RB1 for a gorgeous matchup. The Falcons have been extremely generous to pass-catching running backs, allowing a combined 29 catches to Christian McCaffrey and Alvin Kamara the past two weeks.
report: Giovani Bernard (thigh) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: A.J. Green (groin) was also taken off the injury report, as both practiced in full.  Bernard and Green will be RB1 and WR1 plays Sunday against the Falcons.
report: Giovani Bernard (thigh) was removed from the Week 4 injury report.

impact: Those two are Giovani Bernard and rookie Mark Walton. It is the same story as last week when Bernard played 88 percent of the snaps and was the only running back to touch the ball. Perhaps Walton gets a few more opportunities this week, but Bernard is a solid RB1 as a workhorse in a great matchup.
report: Bengals only have two running backs active for Week 4.

impact: He added 27 yards on four catches. Bernard did cede more work to Mark Walton than last week, but he still operated as the clear lead back. His first touchdown came on a 10-yard run in which he cut to the outside and easily got the corner, and he added another one from one-yard out in the second quarter. Despite the good performance, Bernard's run as an RB1 could be at an end with Joe Mixon looking likely to return next week.
report: Giovani Bernard rushed 15 times for 69 yards and two touchdowns in the Bengals' Week 4 win over the Falcons.

impact: It's a new injury for Bernard after he was listed on the injury report with a thigh issue last week.  Bernard was the Bengals' only healthy running back last week after Mark Walton had to leave the game, and Bernard suffered a late knee injury against Atlanta.  With Joe Mixon (knee) looking likely to be back this week, he may be stepping right back into his normal huge workload.
report: Giovani Bernard (knee) did not practice Wednesday.

impact: The Bengals have been getting Bernard some rest during the week, but two missed practices in a row suggest this is more than that. He is looking doubtful to face the Dolphins. Joe Mixon (knee) should have a big workload in his first game back.
report: Giovani Bernard (knee) did not practice Thursday.

impact: ESPN Bengals reporter Katherine Terrell doesn't expect Bernard to play against the Dolphins.  With Joe Mixon (knee) back and Bernard now sidelined, Mixon should slide right back into heavy work as a borderline RB1/2.
report: Giovani Bernard (knee) remained sidelined at Friday's practice.

impact: It was fun while it lasted; Bernard piled up 182 yards and three touchdowns in two spot starts in place of Joe Mixon, but Bernard got hurt at the end of last week's win over the Falcons.  Mixon is now back and will step right into a heavy workload.  He's squarely back in the mix as a high-volume RB1.
report: Giovani Bernard (knee) is out for Week 5 against the Dolphins.

impact: Bernard replaces Mixon on the trainer's table with Mixon off a knee injury of his own and back in the starting lineup.  Bernard filled in well with three touchdowns in two games but can probably be dropped where owners need room.
report: NFL Network's Tom Pelissero reports Giovani Bernard is expected to miss 2-4 weeks with a sprained MCL.

impact: Team reporter Geoff Hobson expects Bernard to miss another game Sunday against Kansas City, which would be his third straight absence. Gio was playing well before his injury but with Joe Mixon occupying close to an every-down role, he'll just be a handcuff/change-of-pace option upon his return.
report: Giovani Bernard (knee) remained sidelined at Wednesday's practice.

impact: He also sat out Wednesday's session, and it would be a shock if he is ready to return this week. With Bernard out, Joe Mixon is a workhorse back in a great matchup against the Chiefs.
report: Giovani Bernard (knee) did not practice Thursday.

impact: It'll again be Mark Walton in the lightly-used changeup spot behind Joe Mixon.
report: Giovani Bernard (knee) is out for Week 7 against the Chiefs.

impact: He continues to work on a side field and appears doubtful for Week 8.
report: Giovani Bernard (knee) remained sidelined at Wednesday's practice.

impact: He also sat out on Wednesday. Bernard appears headed to his fourth absence in a row.
report: Giovani Bernard (knee) did not practice Thursday.

impact: This will be his fourth straight absence. Lead back duties will again fall in the hands of second-year stud Joe Mixon. Gio will aim to return after the Bengals' bye in Week 9.
report: Giovani Bernard (knee) is out for Week 8 against the Buccaneers.

impact: Greg Olsen exited early with a foot injury, which allowed McCaffrey to flourish even more in Carolina's passing game. His nine targets and 45 receiving yards were both team-highs. It's still concerning that Cam Newton used his towering 6'5" 245-pound frame to bowl over defenders inside the five-yard line, essentially robbing CMC of a goal line score. It's also an issue for McCaffrey's future outlook that he handled only three more carries (10) than C.J. Anderson (7). His floor is safe due to his involvement as a receiver, but at least through Week 1, McCaffrey isn't being used like the bell-cow coach Ron Rivera promised he'd be.
report: Christian McCaffrey rushed 10 times for 50 yards and caught 6-of-9 targets for 45 yards in the Panthers' Week 1 victory over the Cowboys.

impact: McCaffrey touched the ball "just" 16 times in Week 1. Speaking Thursday, OC Norv Turner characterized it was a "week-to-week deal." McCaffrey himself said his day would have been bigger had Cam Newton not kept it on so many read options. That, of course, is going to be a common occurrence. Even if he's getting the ball "just" 16-18 times per game, McCaffrey is going to be in the RB1 mix.
report: Panthers coach Ron Rivera would still like Christian McCaffrey to rush 15-20 times per game while catching "6-10 passes."
