Hunt converted a goal-line carry for his rushing score on the Chiefs first drive of the second half. It's the second straight week Hunt's had an expanded pass game role after going over 100 yards receiving against the Patriots. Hunt has been on fire with a touchdown in five straight weeks. He'll remain a locked-in RB1 for Week 8 against Denver.
report: Kareem Hunt had 15 carries for 86 yards and a touchdown and caught 5-of-6 passes for 55 yards and two touchdowns in Week 7 against the Bengals.

impact: Relentlessly hyped all offseason, Mahomes came out and made a statement against the Chargers' Joey Bosa-less defense. His third pass was a 58-yard touchdown strike to Tyreek Hill. Mahomes found Hill a silly seven times for 169 yards and a pair of TDs. Two of Mahomes' four scores were goal line shovel passes. In addition to the passing, Mahomes was used frequently as a runner, both on traditional and read options. Mahomes looked like a born playmaker in just his second NFL start. There are going to be growing pains with any young player, but Mahomes could rapidly become an every-week QB1. He gets the Steelers in Pittsburgh for Week 2.
report: Patrick Mahomes competed 15-of-27 passes for 256 yards and four touchdowns in the Chiefs' 38-28, Week 1 win over the Chargers, adding five rushes for 21 additional yards.

impact: With 10 touchdowns, Mahomes now owns the record for the most scores through the first two weeks of the season. Mahomes was just reaving souls, ripping chunk plays whenever and wherever he wanted. Unlike last week's Tyreek Hill-dominated affair, Mahomes got everyone involved, finding each of Hill, Travis Kelce and Sammy Watkins for at least 90 yards. Mahomes was throwing lasers into tight coverage in the red zone, finding Kelce and Chris Conley for impressive scores. Mahomes is the real deal and could not have a better setup on a videogame. He will look to stay scorching as an elite QB1 in Week 3 against the 49ers.
report: Patrick Mahomes completed 23-of-28 passes for 326 yards and six touchdowns in the Chiefs' 42-37, Week 2 win over the Steelers.

impact: The three scores give Mahomes the record for most touchdown passes (13) in the first three games of a season, and he could have had more. He missed a couple throws in the first half including what should have been a touchdown to Tyreek Hill, and the Chiefs attempted just 13 passes in the second half of the easy win. Leading what looks like an unstoppable offense, blowouts might be the only thing which can stop Mahomes from putting up massive fantasy days. A trip to Denver next Monday night might look daunting, but the Broncos' defense has struggled a bit early in the season. Mahomes will be the top overall quarterback next week.
report: Patrick Mahomes completed 24-of-38 passes for 314 yards and three touchdowns in the Chiefs' Week 3 win over the 49ers.

impact: He also rushed for an eight-yard touchdown, his first score on the ground this season.  Mahomes got off to a real rough start, heading into halftime with just 65 yards passing.  The Broncos were coming at him from all angles, and Mahomes was running for his life most of the night.  His 192 yards passing outside the pocket, according to ESPN, are the most in the last decade.  The Chiefs were down by 10 with just over 12 minutes left, and Mahomes ended up engineering an incredible comeback, creating plays with his legs, throwing darts on the run, and even completing a pass left-handed to Tyreek Hill while running for his life on third down.  He also overcame a 2nd-and-30 situation in the fourth quarter with pass plays of 23 and 35 yards.  The box-score numbers don't tell the whole story.  Mahomes is a star and gets a tough Jaguars defense in K.C. for Week 5.
report: Patrick Mahomes completed 28-of-45 passes for 304 yards and one touchdown in the Chiefs' 27-23, Week 4 win over the Broncos on Monday night.

impact: This was the toughest test of Mahomes' young career, and he passed with flying colors. He was extremely sharp early, spreading the ball around in his trademark fashion, and capped the opening drive with a four-yard rushing score off a bootleg. He did throw his first interception on the season in the second quarter on a high pass across the middle, but that was the only time Kansas City's offense was stopped in the first half. He did not have much to do in the second half, but Mahomes answered a Jacksonville touchdown drive with one of his own in which he hit Tyreek Hill with a great pass for 36 yards up the sideline. He threw another careless interception in the fourth, but it did not ultimately matter. The fantasy stats were not spectacular, but Mahomes has proven he is matchup-proof. He will be a high-end play next week in New England.
report: Patrick Mahomes completed 22-of-38 passes for 313 yards and two interceptions and rushed four times for 13 yards and a touchdown in the Chiefs' Week 5 win over the Jaguars.

impact: Mahomes struggled in the first half before exploding over the final two quarters.  He hit Kareem Hunt for a 67-yard touchdown on the opening drive of second half, with all three of his other TDs going to Tyreek Hill. Mahomes got some help from a Patriots secondary that let Hill get past them for huge gains with broken coverages. The Chiefs lost on a last second field goal, but this was another strong showing from Mahomes after leading the Chiefs to a win over Jacksonville last week. Mahomes will be a top-three quarterback play against the Bengals in Week 7.
report: Patrick Mahomes completed 23-of-36 passes for 352 yards with four touchdowns and two interceptions in Kansas City's Week 6 loss to the Patriots.

impact: Mahomes’ first two touchdowns were dumpoffs to Kareem Hunt. He hit a wide open Demetrius Harris and Tyreek Hill in the red-zone for his other scores. Mahomes underthrew Hill on a deep shot for his interception but was otherwise flawless in the blowout win. Mahomes is playing at an MVP level with a 22:5 TD/INT ratio through seven games. Even in a tough matchup with Denver, he's a top-five quarterback play for Week 8.
report: Patrick Mahomes completed 28-of-39 passes for 358 yards with four touchdowns and an interception in the Chiefs' Week 7 win over the Bengals, adding four rushes for 45 yards.

impact: It means he will miss his third-straight game and be questionable at best for Week 4. The Ravens are going with a preposterously large tight end committee in Hurst's absence.
report: Ravens TE Hayden Hurst (foot) will not resume practicing this week.

impact: It his first practice since going down in the preseason. Coming off an extended layoff, Hurst seems unlikely to play this week, but this is a step in the right direction. The Ravens may be targeting Week 5 for Hurst's return.
report: Ravens TE Hayden Hurst (foot) returned to practice Wednesday.

impact: Hurst returned to a limited practice on Wednesday. He said he felt some soreness after the practice, but it sounds like he will get in some work again during Thursday's session. Perhaps Hurst will not return this week after sitting out over a month, but he is getting close.
report: Ravens TE Hayden Hurst (foot) said he is "day-to-day."

impact: Hurst is hoping to make his NFL debut Sunday night against Pittsburgh after sitting out the first three games with a stress fracture in his foot. In his absence, the Ravens have used a committee approach at tight end, allotting snaps to Maxx Williams, Nick Boyle and third-round rookie Mark Andrews.
report: Ravens TE Hayden Hurst (foot) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Hurst is trending in the right direction but it may be another week before the Ravens deem him game-ready. Even if he does suit up, it will be hard for fantasy owners to wait out his status with Baltimore playing in the Sunday night game this week. The first-round tight end is coming back from foot surgery.
report: Ravens TE Hayden Hurst (foot) is questionable for Week 4 against the Steelers.

impact: Hurst returned to practice this week but he was always a long shot to suit up. The Ravens saw enough from him to list him as questionable, so he has a good chance to return in Week 5.  Also inactive for Baltimore are QB Robert Griffin III, OL Hroniss Grasu, DL Zach Sieler, WR Jordan Lasley, CB Anthony Averett and DT Willie Henry.
report: Ravens TE Hayden Hurst (foot) is inactive for Week 4 against the Steelers.

impact: Hurst resumed practicing last week. The Ravens want to see him out there in full this week. The Ravens need Hurst's pass-catching threat, but he will be returning to a sprawling committee at tight end. He's a name to keep an eye on at an injury-ravaged fantasy position, but he is unlikely to pay immediate dividends.
report: Speaking Monday, Ravens coach John Harbaugh said there's a "good chance" TE Hayden Hurst (foot) makes his NFL debut in Week 5.

impact: Hurst returned to limited practice last week but couldn't get cleared. Coach John Harbaugh said there's a "good chance" he'll make his debut Sunday. Hurst figures to be on a snap count in his first game back.
report: Hayden Hurst (foot) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: So far, Hurst is on the same track he was last week. Hurst could not get cleared to face the Steelers. We should have a good idea of his Week 5 status by Friday. Hurst will immediately enter the TE2 conversation but would not be a recommended streamer against the Browns in his NFL debut.
report: Hayden Hurst (foot) remained limited in Thursday's practice.

impact: Hurst has been practicing on a limited basis the last two weeks. He looks to have a realistic chance at making his debut Sunday. Hurst may be on a snap count, but he's the favorite for targets in Baltimore's tight end committee.
report: Hayden Hurst (foot) is questionable for Week 5 against the Browns.

impact: The rookie is finally ready to debut after missing the first four games of the year while recovering from foot surgery. Hurst is worth rostering at a thin fantasy position but a wait-and-see approach is probably best, especially given how many other tight ends Baltimore employs.
report: Ravens TE Hayden Hurst (questionable, foot) is expected to play Week 5 against the Browns.

impact: The Ravens first-round pick has missed all four games to begin the season recovering from a stress fracture in his foot that he suffered at the end of August. After a promising start to the preseason, Hurst returns to situation that has made the most of their depth chart in his absence. Baltimore tight ends have 24 percent of the team targets on the season and have accounted for 5-of-12 passing targets inside of the 10-yard line this season. Hurst is only a deep play in his first week back in the lineup, but should be added on teams that are thin at the tight end position.
report: Ravens TE Hayden Hurst (foot) is active for Sunday's Week 5 game versus the Browns.

impact: Hurst got in the action early, catching a seven-yard pass on the second drive of the game, but failed to reel in another pass on the day. Tight ends Mark Andrews (three targets) and Nick Boyle (two) each were involved as much as Hurst. This is likely going to be a frustrating split for the short term until Hurst claims a grasp on the job, leaving him as a TE2 Week 6 against the Titans.
report: Hayden Hurst caught 1-of-2 targets for seven yards in Sunday's Week 5 loss to the Browns.

impact: "He was knocking a little bit of rust off last week, and then, man I was excited, because he practiced really well (Wednesday)," Mornhinweg said. Mornhinweg characterized Hurst as "on the rise." Hurst played just 21-of-87 snaps in his Week 5 debut. He might need to double that number before becoming a legitimate TE2.
report: Ravens OC Marty Mornhinweg talked up Hayden Hurst on Thursday.

impact: Hurst has just one catch on five targets since returning from a foot injury in Week 5. "He’s a first-round pick, talented guy. He’s practicing really well. He’s a rookie –- that’s the other side of it -- and he missed a significant portion," Harbaugh said of Hurst's slow start. "It’s important for us to have him rolling in our offense." Hurst is not a usable fantasy option right now, but he is a stash in Dynasty leagues and deep TE premium formats.
report: Ravens coach John Harbaugh said it is "important" to get first-round TE Hayden Hurst "involved going forward."

impact: Dallas kept Gathers on the 53-man roster following his arrest for drug possession but will oddly make him inactive on game day. CB Chidobe Awuzie is available and will start on the opposite side of Byron Jones.
report: Cowboys declared TE Rico Gathers, QB Mike White, S Xavier Woods, DT Datone Jones, LB Chris Covington, C Adam Redmond, and C Travis Frederick inactive for Week 1 against the Panthers.

impact: Gathers will make his regular season debut after being a healthy scratch last week. The Cowboys will be without DE Randy Gregory (concussion), but are mostly healthy on defense. Also inactive are QB Mike White, S Xavier Woods, DE Datone Jones, C Travis Frederick, OG Xavier Su’a-Filo, and TE Dalton Schultz.
report: Cowboys TE Rico Gathers is active for Week 2 against the Giants.

impact: Beasley led all Cowboys receivers in targets, catches, and receiving yards. Ex-Bills castoff Deonte Thompson finished second on the team with 27 yards. Beasley mustered just 314 yards last season but will likely lead Dallas in receiving until explosive rookie Michael Gallup gets up to speed in the league. Beasley should be on the radar as a low-ceiling PPR FLEX option.
report: Cole Beasley caught 7-of-8 targets for 73 in the Cowboys' Week 1 loss to the Panthers.

impact: The Cowboys' No. 1 passing game weapon was apparently injured in Thursday's practice. As of now, there's no indication he will sit out Sunday's game against the Seahawks, but Friday's practice will tell the tale.
report: Cole Beasley was added to the Cowboys' injury report on Thursday, getting in a limited session with an ankle issue.

impact: Beasley sprained his ankle towards the end of Wednesday's practice and was limited at week's end. Deonte Thompson and Tavon Austin would likely play larger roles if Beasley, Dallas' current leader in targets, is inactive. There's still no indication he'll actually miss Dallas' Week 3 matchup against the Seahawks.
report: Cole Beasley (ankle) is questionable for Week 3 against the Seahawks.

impact: Beasley sprained his ankle mid-week and was limited Friday. Even so, he'll be active for the Cowboys in Seattle. Beasley currently leads Dallas' skill players in targets (11) but has an extremely low ceiling given the team's propensity to run early and often. Ezekiel Elliott remains the only matchup-proof weekly starter among Dallas' offense.
report: Cole Beasley (ankle) will play in Week 3 against the Seahawks.

impact: The Cowboys’ supposed lead receiver was out-targeted by both Ezekiell Elliott and Geoff Swaim. Even with Dallas in catch-up mode for most of the second half, Beasley was unable to make a difference. He’ll be tough to trust against the Lions in Week 4.
report: Cole Beasley reeled in three-of-five targets for 46 yards Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 3 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: It's the same injury that limited him in practice late last week. The Cowboys are likely just managing his reps. Playing at less than 100 percent, Beasley shouldn't be in Week 4 lineups.
report: Cole Beasley (ankle) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Beasley was questionable for Week 3 with the same injury but still suited up. He recorded three catches for 46 yards. With Dallas' offense continuing to sink and feature 5-6 receivers to no avail, Beasley should be off fantasy radars until further notice.
report: Cole Beasley (ankle) is questionable for Week 4 against the Lions.

impact: Beasley also played through his ankle injury last week. His status was never in much doubt. Beasley isn't on the Week 4 fantasy radar.
report: Cole Beasley (questionable, ankle) is expected to play in Week 4 against the Lions.

impact: Beasley was non-existent in the first half (one catch for 12 yards), but he fared much better after the break. He made a clutch grab on third-and-long in the third quarter, setting Dallas up with a fourth-and-one opportunity at the three-yard line, which Ezekiel Elliott converted for a first down. Beasley has drawn five or fewer targets in three of four games this year and with Dallas committing to a run-first offense, his workload is unlikely to increase. He shouldn’t be in any fantasy lineups for next week’s Sunday night matchup against Houston.
report: Cole Beasley brought in four catches for 55 yards on five targets Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 4 win over Detroit.

impact: Beasley has been playing through his ankle injury the last few weeks. He's not going to get in many practice reps but his Week 5 status isn't in doubt.
report: Cole Beasley (ankle) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Beasley has been bothered by an ankle injury for a few weeks now, though it hasn't cost him any game action yet. He should be out there Sunday night at Houston, though his fantasy prospects for that game are minimal at best.
report: Cole Beasley (ankle) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Beasley didn’t have a catch going into overtime. His three targets were behind Ezekiel Elliott and Deonte Thompson. Even as the Cowboys' No. 1 wideout, Beasley remains well off the fantasy radar.
report: Cole Beasley caught one pass for eight yards in Week 5 against  the Texans.

impact: The first of Beasley's two touchdowns came on a play where he was left inexplicably wide open, taking it to the house for a 17-yard score in the second quarter. He followed that up with a nine-yarder just before halftime. Sunday's breakout ended a 12-game touchdown drought for Beasley. It was also the 29-year-old's first 100-yard receiving game in almost three years. Despite his success against Jacksonville, Beasley won't be of much fantasy interest next week at Washington.
report: Cole Beasley racked up nine catches for 101 yards and two touchdowns on 11 targets Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 6 victory over the Jaguars.

impact: Beasley came crashing back to Earth following his outta-nowhere 9/101/2 performance against the Jaguars last week, catching his typical seven passes for a median amount of yards versus the Redskins. He reverted back into a possession receiver used strictly over the middle or near the sidelines, helping move the ball rather than erupt for explosive over-the-top plays. Expect a similar performance once the Cowboys return and face the Titans following next week's bye.
report: Cole Beasley recorded seven receptions on a team-high eight targets for 56 yards in the Cowboys' Week 7 heart-breaking loss to the Redskins.

impact: EVP Stephen Jones said Austin would receive "a dozen to two dozen" touches per game immediately after acquiring him. That was a real quote. We assume that statement was an anagram for "one carry and no targets." Cole Beasley is currently the Cowboys' leading receiver after hauling in 7-of-8 targets for 73 yards Sunday.
report: Tavon Austin rushed one time for one yard in the Cowboys' Week 1 loss to the Panthers.

impact: Austin burned the Giants for a 64-yard TD on the third play of the night. He had one catch after that, but added 15 yards on a reverse. Austin's touchdown was his first since 2016. Despite the big game, Austin should remain limited to a gadget role moving forward.
report: Tavon Austin caught two passes for 79 yards and a touchdown in Week 2 against the Giants.

impact: Incredibly, Austin has been on the receiving end of both of Dak Prescott's touchdown passes this year. Of course, we use the word "pass" very loosely as Prescott merely underhanded it to Austin for a three-yard pickup during garbage time. The 28-year-old has speed for days and can still be an entertaining gadget player, though he remains miles away from fantasy relevance.
report: Tavon Austin delivered three catches for two yards and a touchdown while gaining 18 yards on his lone carry Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 3 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: Austin came down hard after dropping what should have been a touchdown early in the second quarter. That drop was his only target prior to exiting. Austin's injury shouldn't have much impact on fantasy owners.
report: Tavon Austin left Sunday's Week 4 game against the Lions with a right shoulder injury and is questionable to return.

impact: He was in and out of the game after coming down with a first-half shoulder injury. Austin seems to be okay, though obviously he wasn’t a factor on Sunday. The 28-year-old beat Darius Slay down the field on his lone target but dropped what should have been a relatively easy touchdown. Six years into his career, Austin still doesn’t have a real position. He’ll break off a big play here and there, but he’s not someone fantasy owners can count on for consistent production.
report: Tavon Austin failed to haul in his only target while adding a single carry for seven yards Sunday in Dallas’ Week 4 win over the Lions.

impact: Austin was having a quiet night before making a 44-yard catch on a broken play late in the fourth quarter. He had three targets, but dropped a pass that led to one of Dak Prescott’s interceptions. Austin can continue to be ignored in fantasy leagues.
report: Tavon Austin caught one pass for 44 yards in Week 5 against the Texans.

impact: Austin suffered a groin injury at the end of a third-quarter run and never returned. He is questionable for Week 7.
report: Tavon Austin corralled his only target for a five-yard gain while adding a pair of carries for 14 yards Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 6 win over the Jags.

impact: Jones hinted Austin is dealing with a multi-week injury. Austin did not have much fantasy value of his own, but his absence could solidify Michael Gallup's snap share.
report: Jerry Jones said Tavon Austin (groin) is "not looking good" for Week 7.

impact: There could be a distinct lack of Cowboys jet sweeps against the Redskins.
report: Tavon Austin (groin) is out for Week 7.

impact: Perhaps the most surprising development for the Cowboys is that rookie TE Dalton Schultz isn't among the team's inactives for the first time all year. Dallas will therefore enter Sunday with four active tight ends (Geoff Swaim, Blake Jarwin, Rico Gathers, Schultz). Ross is among the only noteworthy players missing on the Cowboys' D-line.
report: Cowboys declare WR Tavon Austin, QB Mike White, LB Joe Thomas, OL Xavier Su'a-Filo, DE Daniel Ross, LB Chris Covington, and DT Caraun Reid inactive for Week 7 against the Redskins.

impact: The Rams' tight ends are not usually involved in the offense, but that changed after both Brandin Cooks and Cooper Kupp left this game with concussions. Everett recorded all of his catches after Cooks left the game, and two of them came with Kupp out. He was also tackled at the one in the third quarter. If Cooks and Kupp are forced to sit, he could be a streaming option in deep two-tight end formats.
report: Gerald Everett hauled in all three of his targets for 24 yards in the Rams' Week 5 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Gerald Everett also got his first catch of the season in this one, taking a late target 17 yards. Despite Sean McVay's history, the tight end position has simply not been a focal point of the Rams' passing game. Neither player is worth rostering in redraft formats.
report: Tyler Higbee hauled in 1-of-2 targets for three yards and a touchdown in the Rams' Week 2 win over the Cardinals.

impact: The Rams other tight end Gerald Everett also had two targets against the Chargers. Higbee found the end zone last week against the Cardinals, but he's not worthy of a roster spot with just four targets on the year. Sean McVay will continue to ride Gurley, Cooks, Woods, and Kupp.
report: Tyler Higbee caught both of his targets for 35 yards in the Rams' Week 3 win over the Chargers.

impact: Higbee returned to practice Friday, putting him on track to play this week. He's not on the Week 5 streaming radar.
report: Tyler Higbee (knee) is questionable for Week 5 against the Seahawks.

impact: Higbee only practiced once this week, but he will give it a go on a bad knee. The Rams do not use their tight ends enough for Higbee to have any fantasy value. Los Angeles declared K Greg Zuerlein, KR/PR JoJo Natson, RB John Kelly, OLB Trevon Young, DT Sebastian Joseph-Day, and DT Tanzel Smart inactive for Week 5.
report: Rams TE Tyler Higbee (knee) is active for Week 5 against the Seahawks.

impact: One of Higbee's catches bounced off Cooper Kupp and into his hands for a 17-yard gain. He added another grab in the second quarter, but Gerald Everett was the tight end of choice in the second half. Normally the Rams do not heavily utilize Higbee's position, but that could change with both Brandin Cooks and Kupp dealing with concussions. Even so, Higbee is not even a good desperation option in standard formats.
report: Tyler Higbee hauled in 2-of-4 targets for 26 yards in the Rams' Week 5 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Despite exiting early in Week 4, Fuller's status for Sunday was never in doubt. Remarkably, Fuller has caught a touchdown pass every time he's shared the field with Deshaun Watson (that's seven games) going back to last year. He can be safely employed as a WR2 in all formats.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport confirms Will Fuller (questionable, hamstring) is expected to play Week 5 against the Cowboys.

impact: Keke Coutee is also active after being a game-time decision. Inactive for Houston are WR Vyncint Smith, CB Aaron Colvin, LB Brian Peters, DE Christian Covington, OT David Sharpe, DE Carlos Watkins, and LB Daeshon Hall
report: Will Fuller (hamstring) is active for Week 5 against the Cowboys.

impact: It was the first time Fuller was held under 100 yards in a game he wasn't injured in this season. Fuller came into Sunday night questionable with a hamstring setback, so he may not have been 100 percent. This should go down as one of Fuller's worst games. Fuller gets a matchup with Buffalo in Week 6.
report: Will Fuller caught 2-of-3 passes for 15 yards in Week 5 against Dallas.

impact: The Texans have been listing Fuller with a hamstring injury for weeks, though he hasn't missed a game since the opener. Fuller got off to a booming start with 100-plus yards in each of his first two games this year but has slowed down the past two weeks, totaling just six catches for 64 yards during that span. He'll be a WR2/3 for Sunday's home matchup against Buffalo.
report: Will Fuller (hamstring) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Fuller will play, but it is unclear how healthy he is. He struggled in Week 5 as Keke Coutee once again soaked up targets. Fuller is on the WR2/3 borderline for Week 6.
report: Will Fuller (hamstring) remained "limited" on Thursday.

impact: It is the second down game in a row for Fuller, who did not have his first catch until the fourth quarter and whose biggest contribution was drawing a DPI deep down the field to set up a game-tying field goal. He should have had a long touchdown before those plays, but Deshaun Watson just missed him. The duo will hit on those plays eventually, but it might not happen next week in Jacksonville. Fuller will be more of a WR3 in that spot.
report: Will Fuller hauled in 2-of-3 targets for 33 yards in the Texans' Week 6 win over the Bills.

impact: Fuller was listed with a hip injury after dealing with hamstring issues the last few weeks. This doesn't look like a concern for his Week 7 status.
report: Will Fuller (hip) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: The Texans have been managing Fuller's practice reps all season. He's been quiet since the arrival of rookie Keke Coutee and could be in for another slow week against Jacksonville's elite secondary.
report: Will Fuller (hip) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Fuller was limited at all three practices this week, though there was never much concern about his status for Week 7. In a tough road matchup, Fuller is best viewed as a low-end WR3.
report: Will Fuller (hip) wasn't listed on the Texans' final injury report for Week 7 against the Jaguars.

impact: Fuller led the team in receiving and tied DeAndre Hopkins for the team lead in targets, a good sign after Fuller spent the last two weeks effectively running wind sprints as a decoy with three targets in each game. Hopefully, finally over his longstanding hamstring injury, Fuller should resume WR2/3 treatment when the Texans face the Dolphins on Thursday Night Football next. Keke Coutee (hamstring) won’t play, freeing up a few extra targets for Fuller.
report: Will Fuller caught 6-of-8 targets for 68 yards in the Texans’ Week 7 win over the Jaguars.

impact: It's notable for Week 8 because Coutee is not expected to play after aggravating his hamstring in last week's win.  Whereas Fuller has finished below 70 yards in each of Coutee’s four appearances, Fuller’s stat lines with Coutee on the shelf are 8/113/1 and 5/101/1. Fuller also led the Texans in Week 7 receiving yards as Coutee didn't play the full game.  You can read more stats and analysis like this in Evan Silva's Dolphins-Texans writeup at the link below.
report: Will Fuller has significant production splits with and without Keke Coutee on the field.

impact: Fuller should be close to 100 percent after playing through a hip injury last week. With Keke Coutee (hamstring) sidelined and DeAndre Hoping getting shadowed by Xavien Howard, Fuller has a great Week 8 matchup.
report: Will Fuller (hip) isn't listed on the Week 8 injury report.

impact: Fuller was injured on a fourth quarter play where he was getting mugged in the end zone. Fuller went down and immediately massaged his knee. He was helped to the sideline and quickly ruled out. The Texans were routing the Dolphins at the time, but a quick rule out is never a good sign, especially for a player with Fuller's injury history. Fuller had feasted before going down, catching 5-of-6 targets for 124 yards and a 73-yard touchdown. Hilariously, Fuller was left wide open on his score when Bobby McCain incorrectly thought he had safety help.
report: Will Fuller was forced from Thursday's game against the Dolphins with a right knee injury and will not return.

impact: Friday testing will confirm, but it certainly appears Fuller's age-24 campaign is over. It's a crushing blow to a Texans offense that has flirted with dominate at times this season. When healthy, Fuller has lid-lifting speed that few can match, clearing space for DeAndre Hopkins. If Fuller is indeed done, rookie Keke Coutee will have to carry an enormous load opposite Hopkins. Fuller is a special talent, but it is possible he heads into 2019 having appeared in just 31-of-48 possible career games.
report: The Houston Chronicle reports the Texans fear Will Fuller suffered a torn right ACL in Thursday's win over the Dolphins.

impact: Just brutal.  Fuller exploded for a 5-124-1 night against the Dolphins before tearing the ACL on a deep shot late in the blowout win.  The Texans are now headed into a mini-bye and need to figure out their receiving corps.  Keke Coutee (hamstring) wasn't close to playing Thursday night.  Bruce Ellington (hamstring) remains on I.R. and can't return until Week 12 at the earliest.  Vyncint Smith was next man up against Miami, playing eight late snaps.  He's the in-house favorite for the No. 2 role at the moment, but Houston will almost certainly add some help.
report: Coach Bill O'Brien confirmed Will Fuller suffered a torn ACL in the Week 8 win over the Dolphins and is done for the season.

impact: Running as the No. 2 for the Texans' undermanned receiver corps, Ellington's touchdown was just the sixth of his career. He will offer some desperation appeal for as long as Will Fuller (hamstring) is sidelined. The Texans get the Titans in Week 2.
report: Bruce Ellington caught 4-of-8 targets for 37 yards and a touchdown in the Texans' Week 1 loss to the Patriots.

impact: With Keke Coutee and Sammie Coates out, Ellington continued his run as Houston's clear-cut No. 3 receiver. Unfortunately, that position serves little to no value with Will Fuller (8-113-1) and DeAndre Hopkins (6-110-1) manning the outside. Coutee, who has a much higher ceiling than Ellington, should mix-in as the team's primary slot receiver once he's healthy.
report: Bruce Ellington caught all three of his targets for 45 yards in the Texans' Week 2 loss to the Titans.

impact: He's questionable to return. With Keke Coutee and Sammie Coates out, 	the Texans should go with tight heavy sets.
report: Bruce Ellington left Week 3 against the Giants with a hamstring injury.

impact: It's the last thing the Texans' top-heavy receiver corps needs. Although not effective, Ellington had already soaked up 131 snaps this season. That's despite leaving after just three in Week 3. The Texans really need rookie slot man Keke Coutee (hamstring) to get healthy. Ellington will be a candidate to return after eight weeks.
report: Texans placed WR Bruce Ellington on injured reserve with a hamstring injury.

impact: Hopkins came into the week questionable due to various nicks and bruises, but he looked like his normal self in this one, working over an undermanned Colts secondary that didn't have any answers for the WR1.  Hopkins' score was of the five-yard variety on a perfect fade from Deshaun Watson.  Especially after Will Fuller left early in the second half with a hamstring injury, Hopkins and Keke Coutee were the targets on virtually every Watson pass.  The Cowboys are up next.
report: DeAndre Hopkins caught 10-of-12 targets for 169 yards and one touchdown in the Texans' 37-34, Week 4 win over the Colts.

impact: Hopkins looked fine playing through the injuries last week. With Will Fuller (hamstring) looking questionable for Sunday night, Hopkins could see a larger than normal target share.
report: DeAndre Hopkins (ankle, hamstring, thumb) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: None of the issues are serious. Hopkins will be a top-five WR1 against the Cowboys.
report: DeAndre Hopkins (ankle, hamstring, thumb) remained limited on Thursday.

impact: Hopkins hasn't been practicing much with some minor injuries, but he's played in every game. He's our overall WR4 for Sunday night's matchup with Dallas.
report: DeAndre Hopkins (ankle, hamstring, thumb) wasn't listed on the Texans' final injury report for Week 5 against the Cowboys.

impact: With Will Fuller and Keke Coutee playing at less than 100 percent, Hopkins carried the load for Houston’s pass offense. He single-handily won the game for the Texans, breaking three tackles on a 49-yard catch that set up an overtime field goal. Hopkins was held out of the end-zone, but had a near-touchdown when he was tackled on the one-yard line. His only blunder was a fumble trying to reach for a first down on the opening drive of the second half. Hopkins was shadowed by Cowboys CB Byron Jones for most of the night. He'll get another tough matchup with TreDavious White in Week 6.
report: DeAndre Hopkins caught 9-of-13 passes for 151 yards in the Texans' Week 5 win over Dallas.

impact: Hopkins was listed with a myriad of injuries last week and still saw his usual snaps Sunday against Dallas. It should be the same drill this week. Nuk leads the NFL in receiving yards with 594 and is fourth in catches with 39. He'll be a must-start against the Bills in Week 6, even in a tough matchup versus stud corner Tre'Davious White.
report: DeAndre Hopkins (foot) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Hopkins hasn't gotten in a full practice in what feels like forever, though he's yet to miss a game this season. The NFL's receiving yards leader will be a locked-in WR1 against Buffalo, even with underrated Tre'Davious White likely to shadow him.
report: DeAndre Hopkins (foot) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Hopkins was the only reliable part of the Texans' attack on Sunday. Even with Deshaun Watson struggling behind an overmatched offensive line, he comfortably won his battle with Tre'Davious White. He drew two holding penalties on the young corner in the first half, and he out-muscled him for his touchdown in the first quarter. He slowed down with the rest of the offense in the second half, but he did chip in a 24-yard catch after the break. Hopkins faces a tough matchup with the Jaguars next week, but he is a must-start option no matter the matchup.
report: DeAndre Hopkins hauled in 5-of-6 targets for 63 yards and a touchdown in the Texans' Week 6 win over the Bills.

impact: Hopkins hasn't practiced fully in weeks. He's in no danger of sitting out Sunday's game.
report: DeAndre Hopkins (foot) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: It's likely just a form of rep management, though DNPs always need to be taken seriously. Hopkins also had by far his quietest game of the season in Week 7. His Friday status will be key. Provided Hopkins does play, he will be hobbled and squaring off with Jalen Ramsey. He's shaping up as a back-end WR1 for Week 7.
report: DeAndre Hopkins (foot) was downgraded to "DNP" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Hopkins worried us a little with Thursday's DNP, though it looks like he was just getting a maintenance day. Nuk draws a tough matchup against Jalen Ramsey this week, though obviously benching him in season-long leagues is not an option.
report: DeAndre Hopkins (foot) wasn't listed on the Texans' final injury report for Week 7 against the Jaguars.

impact: As expected.  Hopkins missed practice time with a foot injury this week, but he was not listed on the final injury report.  The Texans' Week 7 inactives are WR Vyncint Smith, CB Aaron Colvin, TE Ryan Griffin, DE Joel Heath, OG Zach Fulton, LB Brian Peters, and CB Shareece Wright.
report: DeAndre Hopkins is active for Week 7 against the Jaguars.

impact: Hopkins scored an early touchdown, and that was about all the Texans needed to take down the Jags in a smooth-sailing 20-7 victory. Hopkins has eight or more targets in 7-of-7 games. A matchup-agnostic WR1, Hopkins can expect to tangle with Xavien Howard’s shadow coverage on Thursday Night Football next.
report: DeAndre Hopkins caught 3-of-8 targets for 50 yards and a touchdown in the Texans’ Week 7 win over the Jaguars.

impact: Hopkins was limited in practice all week, but his status was never in doubt. Even with Hopkins facing shadow coverage from Xavien Howard, he remains a locked-in WR1.
report: DeAndre Hopkins (foot) was removed from the Week 8 injury report.

impact: It was an easy night at the office for Hopkins and company. The superstar wideout was left completely uncovered on his 49-yard touchdown to begin the fourth quarter. He literally had time to stop and wait for the ball before taking it untouched to the end zone. Score No. 2 came later in the period against Xavien Howard. Hopkins got free and corralled a perfectly thrown two-yarder near the back line. Hopkins and Howard exchanged words during the week. Hopkins got the final word, though is worth noting that he lost a long reception to OPI. The dubious call negated a bonkers one-handed catch. Look up the replay. The Broncos are on deck for Week 9. If Will Fuller (knee) is sidelined, 10 targets will be Hopkins' bare minimum in Denver.
report: DeAndre Hopkins caught 6-of-7 targets for 82 yards and two touchdowns in the Texans' Week 8 win over the Dolphins.

impact: Andrews got his day started with a 30-yard catch in the first quarter in which he hurdled a defender, and he had another long catch in the third. Andrews is not getting enough work in the Ravens' tight end committee, but he could become a fantasy option if that changes.
report: Mark Andrews caught 2-of-3 targets for 59 yards in the Ravens' Week 3 win over the Broncos.

impact: Herndon contributed two big plays; a 24-yard gain and a 32-yard touchdown where Sam Darnold easily found him en route to a pay dirt on a beautiful play design by OC Jeremy Bates.  The Jets' tight end situation could become worth monitoring if Quincy Enunwa's ankle injury costs him significant time.
report: Jets rookie TE Chris Herndon caught 2-of-2 targets for 56 yards in Sunday's Week 6 win over the Colts.

impact: Herndon is emerging as one Sam Darnold's favorite targets with touchdowns in back-to-back games.  He nearly had a second score on Sunday, but it was called back as Herndon stepped out of bounds just before reaching the pylon.  Herndon is very much a streaming option moving forward at a weak tight end position.  The Jets will travel to face the Bears in Week 8.
report: Chris Herndon caught 4-of-7 targets for 42 yards and one touchdown in the Jets' Week 7 loss to the Vikings.

impact: That was a fairly-typical line for Hooper last season. Hooper will have occasional outbursts, but the Falcons' continual red zone woes make him hard to get excited about as a TE2 streamer.
report: Austin Hooper caught 3-of-4 targets for 24 yards in the Falcons' Week 1 loss to the Eagles.

impact: Cornerbacks Brian Poole (ankle) and Isaiah Oliver (ankle) were also limited at Wednesday's session. Hooper looked fine in last week's opener, nabbing three catches for 24 yards over 59 offensive snaps. We anticipate he'll be ready for Week 2 against the Panthers, though the 23-year-old only merits back-end TE2 consideration.
report: Austin Hooper (knee) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Hooper was limited on Wednesday, but he was a full participant the rest of the week. The knee is not a concern, but the matchup and Hooper's track record are. There are better TE2 options.
report: Austin Hooper (knee) was not listed on the final injury report.

impact: The only difference from Hooper's normal day is he caught a touchdown.  Otherwise, the yards and five targets are par for the course for him.  Hooper's score came from eight yards out.  When he scores, he's an obvious fantasy difference-maker, but those touchdowns are hard to predict.  For now, Hooper will remain a TE2 most weeks but has streamer appeal Week 3 against the Saints.
report: Austin Hooper caught all five of his targets for 59 yards and one touchdown in the Falcons' Week 2 win over the Panthers.

impact: It was a quiet afternoon for the Falcons tight end, though he did chip in with a two-point conversion following Tevin Coleman’s touchdown early in the fourth quarter. Hooper has only topped 30 yards once this season and won’t be an appealing streamer against the Bengals in Week 4.
report: Austin Hooper turned in three catches for 23 yards on four targets Sunday in Atlanta’s Week 3 loss to the Saints.

impact: Hooper went for 59 yards and a touchdown in Week 2, but he has predictably scuffled since, catching just four passes for 42 yards in two games. He did have an end-zone target in this game, and that usage makes him a touchdown-or-bust fantasy option.
report: Austin Hooper hauled in 1-of-2 targets for 19 yards in the Falcons' Week 4 loss to the Bengals.

impact: Under constant pressure, Matt Ryan was constantly checking down. That includes a first half "Hail Mary." The receptions were a new personal best while the yards were the third most of Hooper's career. Hooper might actually stay hot for Week 6, where the Falcons host the Bucs. No team has allowed more fantasy points to opposing tight ends.
report: Austin Hooper caught 9-of-12 targets for 77 yards in the Falcons' Week 5 loss to the Steelers.

impact: It is Hooper's second game in a row with nine catches after failing to top seven in any of his first 34 games. His touchdown came on a delay route where he was left wide open in the flat and stiffed armed a corner to the ground on his way into the end zone. He also came up with a big third-down conversion on the Falcons' final drive to help set up a field goal. With Calvin Ridley (ankle) and Mohamed Sanu (hip) questionable, Hooper will be a back-end TE1 next week.
report: Austin Hooper hauled in 9-of-10 targets for 71 yards and a touchdown in the Falcons' Week 6 win over the Bucs.

impact: It was a fall back to earth for the tight end after totaling 18 catches for 145 yards and a touchdown the previous two weeks.  Hooper made a big 36-yard catch in this one.  He maybe should have had a 22-yard touchdown as well, but Matt Ryan threw it behind him at the goal line in the first half.  Hooper will remain a TE1 going forward coming out of the bye in Week 9 against the Skins.
report: Austin Hooper caught 3-of-4 targets for 48 yards in the Falcons' Week 7 win over the Giants.

impact: Woods tied Cooper Kupp with a team-high nine targets, but actually hauled in only three of them. Even so, Woods was dispersed deep and was clearly a cog in the Rams' high-octane offense. All of Los Angeles' receivers (Brandin Cooks included) could boom/bust on any given week, though Kupp's floor appears to be the safest of their committee's. Woods should continue seeing a high share of targets moving forward.
report: Robert Woods caught 3-of-9 targets for 37 yards and rushed for six yards on one carry in the Rams' Week 1 victory over the Raiders.

impact: Woods did not take advantage of his opportunities in the opener, but he rectified the problem against the Cardinals. He caught three passes for 30 yards in the first quarter, and he kept making plays the rest of the way. His fantasy day could have been much better, but Jared Goff missed him when he was wide open in the end zone in the fourth. The Rams will have a tougher time with the Chargers next week, but Woods will still be a solid WR3.
report: Robert Woods hauled in 6-of-9 targets for 81 yards in the Rams' Week 2 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Going into the game, Woods was a breakout candidate as he was leading the team in targets and air yards but only had 118 scoreless yards to show for it. Today was a different story. The Chargers had no answers for Jared Goff and Woods, who scored two times on the same red zone play and ended with over 100 receiving yards. With at least nine targets in all three games, Woods is a WR2/3 even against the Vikings on Thursday night.
report: Robert Woods caught 10-of-11 targets for 104 yards and two touchdowns in the Rams' Week 3 win over the Chargers.

impact: Despite seeing a season-low in targets, Woods impressed with another huge fantasy week. He was especially effective in the second half, nabbing four of his five catches after the break. Woods stretched the Rams’ lead to 10 by torching Anthony Barr (a frequent victim on Thursday night) for a 31-yard touchdown strike in the closing minutes of the third quarter. His longest gain came in the first half on a play where Woods dusted Trae Waynes for a 36-yard pick-up. Woods has gone over 100 yards receiving in each of his last two games while registering three touchdowns during that span. He’ll look to stay hot against the Seahawks in Week 5.
report: Robert Woods earned five catches for 101 yards and a touchdown on five targets Thursday in the Rams’ Week 4 victory over the Vikings.

impact: With both Brandin Cooks and Cooper Kupp sidelined by concussions, Woods was the No. 1 receiver for most of this game, and he delivered. He made a great move after the catch to pick up third down and a lot more in the second quarter, and he sparked a touchdown drive with a 56-yard gain on a jet sweep in the third quarter. He drew a defensive pass interference on fourth down later that drive to keep it alive. Woods now has at least 100 yards from scrimmage in each of his last three games while Cooks and Kupp are question marks for next week. If they do not play, Woods will be a WR1 against the Broncos.
report: Robert Woods hauled in 5-of-7 targets for 92 yards and rushed twice for 53 yards in the Rams' Week 5 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Woods also drew an end zone DPI that set the Rams up at the one-yard line in the third quarter. With Cooper Kupp (knee) ailing, Woods gobbled up more than half of the Rams' receiving yards. Woods has now cleared 90 yards in four-straight games, and 100 in three of his past four. He's been operating as a poor man's Adam Thielen in the Rams' three-headed attack at wideout. The 49ers are a plus matchup for Week 7.
report: Robert Woods caught 7-of-10 targets for 109 yards in the Rams' Week 6 win over the Broncos, adding a 12-yard rush.

impact: The Rams' passing attack did not have to do much in the easy win, but Woods still managed to top 75 for the sixth game in a row. He helped set up a field goal with a 21-yard gain on third down in the first quarter, and he went for 32 yards to spark another scoring drive in the second. With the Packers likely to offer more resistance, Woods will once again be a high-end WR2 next week.
report: Robert Woods hauled in 5-of-7 targets for 78 yards in the Rams' Week 7 win over the 49ers.

impact: Both targets came with Dallas playing from behind in the second half. The fact that Thompson, a 29-year-old, undrafted journeyman, is playing significant snaps shows how desperate the Cowboys are for pass-catching help. Thompson can be left on the waiver wire for next week’s matchup against the Lions.
report: Deonte Thompson nabbed both of his targets for 23 yards Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 3 loss to Seattle.

impact: Snead didn't make much noise in the preseason, but he worked as the clear No. 3 wideout behind Michael Crabtree and John Brown. His role looks larger than expected in Baltimore's offense, but this may end up one of his better games. Playing on a short week, Snead would be a low-upside waiver-wire flyer.
report: Willie Snead caught 4-of-6 targets for 49 yards and a touchdown in Baltimore's Week 1 win over Buffalo.

impact: Snead has firmly established himself as the No. 3 in the Ravens' three-wide sets, but it has translated to a modest nine catches for 103 yards through two games. You can do better if you are looking for an upside flier on the waiver wire, especially ahead of next week's tough matchup against the Broncos.
report: Willie Snead caught 5-of-8 targets for 54 yards in the Ravens' Week 2 loss to the Bengals.

impact: This was actually Snead's worst game of the season, but he still managed a couple big plays including a third-down conversion in the third quarter. Snead does not offer much upside as the No. 3 option in the passing game, but he can provide value in deeper PPR leagues.
report: Willie Snead hauled in 3-of-5 targets for 39 yards in the Ravens' Week 3 win over the Broncos.

impact: It was a typical game from Snead. He continued to do most of his damage on third downs and out of the slot. Snead has a solid floor but very little upside as Baltimore's No. 3 receiver. He gets a matchup with the Browns in Week 5.
report: Willie Snead caught 6-of-7 targets for 56 yards in Week 4 against the Steelers.

impact: Snead was fourth on the team in targets as he's established himself as the possession receiver for the Ravens. Snead has four or more catches in four of five games this season, but has yet to reach 60-yards in any game to this point. The Ravens play at Tennessee in Week 6.
report: Willie Snead caught 5-of-7 targets for 55 yards in Sunday's Week 5 loss to the Browns.

impact: His catches and targets were both team-highs, with Michael Crabtree (6/93/1) leading the Ravens with 93 receiving yards. Snead has established himself as the club's possession wideout, but even finished with the second-most air yards (123) among Baltimore's receivers Sunday. It was all at the expense of John Brown, who recorded just two catches for 23 yards. Crabtree and Brown will still rank higher in Week 7 against the Saints.
report: Willie Snead hauled in a team-high 7-of-10 targets for 60 yards in the Ravens' Week 6 victory over the Titans.

impact: Amazingly, this was Snead's worst game of the season. He's averaging a solid 48 weekly yards but not really doing much with them in the way of catches or scores. He hasn't found the end zone since Week 1. Snead is just a desperation PPR fill-in.
report: Willie Snead caught 3-of-7 targets for 23 yards in the Ravens' Week 7 loss to the Saints.

impact: After running with the first-string offense and showing rapport with Dak Prescott in the preseason, Gallup discouragingly finished fourth among Dallas' receivers in total routes run (17). He even finished behind journeyman Deonte Thompson (19), who played 30-of-64 offensive snaps. Gallup is worth holding onto, but shouldn't sniff so much as a FLEX start until the Cowboys decide to feature receivers with upside.
report: Cowboys third-round WR Michael Gallup caught his only target for nine yards in Sunday's Week 1 loss to the Panthers.

impact: It's another disappointing target share for Gallup after one catch in the season opener. The Cowboys have played Gallup behind journeyman Deonte Thompson despite his strong preseason, and re-signed Brice Butler this week, further muddling their receivers. Gallup remains a strong hold in dynasty, but it may take an injury for Dallas to realize his potential.
report: Michael Gallup caught 1-of-2 targets for five yards in Week 2 against the Giants.

impact: The rookie bobbled a ball that eventually found its way into the hands of Earl Thomas. That was one of two interceptions for Thomas, who may have been auditioning to be Gallup’s teammate in Dallas. Even in a wide-open pass-catching corps, the third-rounder has failed to make a difference. He’s managed just three catches over his first three NFL appearances.
report: Michael Gallup pulled in one-of-four targets for 17 yards Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 3 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: Gallup skied over Nevin Lawson for an impressive 37-yard catch in the first quarter. That’s more yards than he had in his previous three games combined. The rookie drew an end-zone target from Dak Prescott later on that same drive but the two couldn’t connect. For all his talent, Gallup has managed to haul in just five-of-12 targets this year. Maybe his day will come but right now, the Colorado State alum is miles off the fantasy radar.
report: Michael Gallup pulled in two catches for 45 yards on five targets Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 4 win over the Lions.

impact: Gallup was a non-factor despite coming off one of his better games. The Cowboys pass offense continues to be a disaster under Dak Prescott this season. Gallup has shown flashes when given touches, but there's been no signs of his role expanding. It's shaping as a lost year for Gallup.
report: Michael Gallup caught 1-of-3 passes for six yards in Week 5 against Houston.

impact: Gallup nearly made a brilliant touchdown catch in double coverage during the first half but he didn't get both of his feet in bounds. The rookie has shown flashes here and there but not enough for him to warrant redraft consideration.
report: Michael Gallup chipped in with one catch for 27 yards on two targets Sunday in Dallas’ Week 6 win over the Jaguars.

impact: With Tavon Austin inactive, Gallup was afforded additional opportunity and delivered with a team- and career-high 81 receiving yards. 49 yards came on a deep-ball over the top in which Gallup simply beat the defense and found himself wide open near the sideline. Dallas' leading receiver seems to rotate weekly, but this is a great development for the rookie in the event Austin misses any further time. The Cowboys are on bye next week.
report: Michael Gallup hauled in 3-of-5 targets for a team-high 81 yards and one score in Dallas' Week 7 loss to the Redskins.

impact: It is a season-high for the rookie a week after he played 81 percent of the offensive snaps. Gallup also set new season marks with three catches for 81 yards and his first touchdown. With Dallas finally committing to him and the passing game showing signs of life, Gallup is suddenly an interesting bench stash even with the Cowboys on bye this week.
report: Michael Gallup played 56-of-66 snaps (85 percent) Week 7 against Washington.

impact: Williams caught his only target of the night. He was a non-factor in a game Dak Prescott threw for just 160 yards. The Cowboys have been one of the worst pass offenses in the league through two weeks.
report: Terrance Williams caught one pass for 12 yards in Week 2 against the Giants.

impact: Williams has made predictably zero impact through the Cowboys' first two games. We suppose his blocking will be missed if he earns a ban.
report: The Dallas Morning News reports Terrance Williams is facing a 2-4 game suspension for his offseason arrest.

impact: He was in on just nine-of-59 offensive snaps (15.3 percent). It would probably take an injury to one of the Cowboys starters for Williams to have any real fantasy relevance, and even then, that might be a stretch.
report: Terrance Williams wasn’t targeted Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 3 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: Williams saw just nine snaps last week and wasn't targeted. It appears he's fallen out of the Cowboys' rotation. Brice Butler should see an opportunity this week with Williams a healthy scratch. Unable to secure a role in arguably the league's weakest receiving corps, T-Will could be on the outs in Dallas.
report: Terrance Williams won't be active for Week 4 against the Lions.

impact: Williams didn't practice all week with a foot injury. He's also dealing with off-field issues. Brice Butler will see more snaps in place of Williams.
report: Terrance Williams (foot) has been ruled out for Week 5.

impact: It's truly been a waste of a season for Williams, who's battled foot and off-field issues throughout the year. He'll be on the bubble in the offseason. This move hopefully instills rookie Michael Gallup into the offense as the third-rounder quietly played a season-high 40-of-69 snaps in Week 4 against the Lions.
report: Cowboys placed WR Terrance Williams (foot) on injured reserve.

impact: The suspension is related to Williams' May arrest for public intoxication and leaving the scene of an accident. It comes at a fortuitous time, as he is currently on injured reserve with a foot issue. Williams will be a candidate for return later this year.
report: NFL suspended Cowboys WR Terrance Williams three games for violating the league's substance-abuse policy.

impact: It's another bad game from Hurns after getting held to one catch in the opener. The Cowboys talked up Hurns as a No. 1 option this preseason, but he's been invisible through their first two games. With the Cowboys offense spreading it around, Hurns is droppable in shallow leagues.
report: Allen Hurns caught 1-of-2 passes for nine yards in Week 2 against the Giants

impact: Hurns played a season-high 66.1 percent of the Cowboys’ offensive snaps, but didn’t do much with the opportunity. The Cowboys’ passing game continues to be stuck in neutral, though it’s unlikely Hurns will be the one to fix things.
report: Allen Hurns corralled two-of-four targets for 22 yards Sunday in Dallas’ Week 3 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: Signed to be Dallas' No. 1 receiver, Hurns has been a committee player through three weeks, commanding just nine total targets while playing 59 percent of the snaps. "The majority of my snaps, I feel like I can get separation," Hurns said. "It’s just getting to the point, especially when we (haven’t) thrown for 200 yards yet, it’s kinda frustrating." The Cowboys are rotating six receivers through a rotation, and none of them are producing. Perhaps committing to one or two receivers would help, but Dallas could really jump-start the passing attack by being less predictable, especially on first down, and pushing the ball downfield.
report: Allen Hurns said he is "frustrated" by the lack of targets going his way.

impact: This would technically qualify as a step forward for Hurns, who had been limited to a mere 41 yards on four catches over his previous three outings. The ex-Jaguar actually made a few nice grabs on Sunday including a nice sideline catch against All-Pro corner Darius Slay, but it’s clear the Cowboys’ offense will continue to live and die by Zeke Elliott. Fantasy owners who thought they could catch lightning in a bottle by taking a late-round flyer on Hurns this summer have not been rewarded for their efforts. He can be ignored against the Texans in Week 5.
report: Allen Hurns grabbed three-of-five targets for 30 yards Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 4 win over the Lions.

impact: Hurns was left wide open in the back of the end-zone on the Cowboys' first drive of the second half. He was otherwise invisible, finishing with just three targets. None of the Cowboys wideouts are fantasy relevant.
report: Allen Hurns caught a three-yard touchdown in the Cowboys' Week 5 loss to the Texans.

impact: Hurns may have had some butterflies going against his former team for the first time Sunday. Whatever the reason, Hurns couldn't get on the same page with Dak Prescott. Perhaps he'll fare better next week when the Cowboys travel to D.C. for a divisional showdown against the Redskins.
report: Allen Hurns was targeted five times but didn’t record a catch Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 6 win over the Jaguars.

impact: It was the first time Hurns eclipsed the 30-yard mark all year. His only touchdown on the season remains his Week 5 score against the Texans in which he was left wide open in the back of the end zone. The Cowboys can barely support one receiver, let alone two. Hurns shouldn't be owned.
report: Allen Hurns caught 5-of-6 targets for a season-high 74 yards in the Cowboys' Week 7 loss to the Redskins.

impact: Cooper had a dreadful Week 1, catching 1-of-3 targets for nine yards while adding a nine-yard rush. Gruden actually did his best to get Cooper going against the Rams, featuring him out of the slot 45.2 percent of the time. That's compared to 21.8 percent a season ago. Derek Carr's struggles aren't helping. Busting Cooper's deepening slump is going to be extra difficult against the Broncos' stout secondary in Week 2.
report: Speaking Tuesday, Raiders coach Jon Gruden said it was going to be "easier said than done" to spark Amari Cooper going forward.

impact: Olson said the same is true of Jared Cook. "Critical to our success," Olson emphasized. Olson and coach Jon Gruden lived up to that pledge on Monday, running Cooper out of the slot on 45.2 percent of his routes. That's compared to 21.8 percent in 2017. Cooper had just one catch for nine yards on three targets, but Gruden believes he got open plenty, and not so subtly admonished Derek Carr for passing up open looks to his No. 1 wideout. It's going to be hard for Cooper to get going against Chris Harris and company in Week 2.
report: Raiders OC Greg Olson said the team plans to move Amari Cooper around the formation "a lot."

impact: Cooper had just 17 receptions for 160 yards in six career games versus the Broncos prior to today, so this was an extremely positive game for Cooper after catching just one pass for nine yards in Week 1. No other Oakland player had more than four targets as Cooper played inside and outside during the game and was the clear number one target in the offense. Being a boom-or-bust option to this point in his career, Cooper will look to build off this game Week 3 versus the Dolphins.
report: Amari Cooper caught 10-of-10 targets for 116 yards in Sunday's Week 2 loss to the Broncos.

impact: It was back into hiding for Cooper, who appeared to run the wrong route on Derek Carr's first interception and committed an inexplicable second half drop. Cooper, an NFL receiver, let the ball go right through his hands without touching it. His quiet day came as Jordy Nelson exploded and Martavis Bryant drew as many targets. Cooper is simply too volatile to be counted on as an every-week WR3. He has a tough Week 4 matchup in the Browns.
report: Amari Cooper caught 2-of-5 targets for 17 yards in the Raiders' Week 3 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: All of the Raiders' pass catchers got "theirs" in this overtime shootout as Derek Carr threw for 447 yards.  Browns CBs Denzel Ward and T.J. Carrie were no match for Amari, who now has topped 100 yards in two of the Raiders' first four games but was held below 20 yards in the other two.  Cooper will remain a volatile WR3/flex play when Oakland draws Casey Hayward's Chargers next.
report: Amari Cooper caught 8-of-12 targets for 128 yards and a touchdown in the Raiders' Week 4 win over the Browns.

impact: It seems like the Raiders are just rationing his practice reps. Coming off a season-high 128 yards in last week's victory over Cleveland, Cooper will get a tough road matchup Sunday against the Chargers. He'll likely draw shadow coverage from Casey Hayward.
report: Amari Cooper (foot) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Cooper was a limited participant at all three practices this week. He's coming off an excellent game in Week 4 (128 yards in a win over Cleveland) but will have a tough draw Sunday against shutdown corner Casey Hayward. For fantasy purposes, Amari remains a boom-or-bust WR3.
report: Amari Cooper (foot) wasn't listed on the Raiders' final injury report for Week 5 against the Chargers.

impact: In his defense, Cooper's one catch was his only target on the day. Even so, it's been a rollercoaster of a season (career?) thus far for Average Amari, as he's either recorded less than 20 yards or exploded for 110-plus in all five games this season. He'll stay a boom-bust WR3 moving forward.
report: Amari Cooper thankfully caught his only target for 10 yards in the Raiders' Week 5 loss to the Chargers.

impact: Jon Gruden isn't done cleaning house after trading Khalil Mack. Cooper has been inconsistent after a down 2017, but it's hard to see the Raiders making such a franchise-changing move. Oakland is also calling teams about 2016 first-rounder Karl Joseph. It's telling that both players are repped by the same agent as Mack. Cooper is signed through 2019 after the Raiders picked up his fifth-year option.
report: FOX Sports' Jay Glazer reports the Raiders are shopping Amari Cooper.

impact: Seahawks S Bradley McDougald easily could have been flagged for helmet to helmet, but he was not.  Cooper was knocked out for several moments before finally walking to the locker room.  He will surely be tested for a concussion.
report: Amari Cooper went to the locker room in the first half of Sunday's Week 6 game against the Seahawks with head/neck injury.

impact: It's an unfortunate but unsurprising outcome after Cooper was knocked unconscious by Seahawks S Bradley McDougald.  McDougald was not flagged for the helmet-to-helmet hit, but he will almost certainly draw a significant fine.  Cooper finished catch-less on one target.  The Raiders have a Week 7 bye.
report: Amari Cooper is done for the day in Week 6 with a concussion.

impact: It's safe to say they're not going to get it based on Cooper's inconsistency and Week 6 concussion.  Nevertheless, this is further confirmation Jon Gruden is aiming to tear apart the organization after trading Khalil Mack and dangling 2016 first-round S Karl Joseph.  Gruden even benched 2017 first-round CB Gareon Conley last week.  Cooper was in-limbo GM Reggie McKenzie's 2015 first-round pick.  Mack was McKenzie's first-rounder in 2014.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports the Raiders are seeking a first-round pick in exchange for Amari Cooper.

impact: No team is in greater need of pass-catching help than the receiver-starved Cowboys, who are currently trotting out the likes of Cole Beasley, Allen Hurns and rookie Michael Gallup at wide receiver. Dallas has begun to do its due diligence on Cooper, who has also drawn trade interest from the Colts and Redskins. The Raiders have been adamant they won't accept anything less than a first-round pick for Cooper, which is a steep cost for a player whose career has been riddled by inconsistency. The 24-year-old also has health concerns coming off a concussion in Week 6.
report: According to ESPN's Adam Schefter, the Cowboys are "gathering information" on Amari Cooper ahead of next week's trade deadline.

impact: The 3-4 Cowboys — who have featured an unwatchable passing offense this season — are going for it in the wide-open NFC East while the 1-5 Raiders are accelerating their tank in year one of coach Jon Gruden's 10-year, $100 million contract. One of the most inscrutable players in football, Cooper has baffled the past two seasons after beginning his career with back-to-back 1,000-yard campaigns, but he is still only 24 with loads of talent. There are better offenses he could have joined in terms of goosing his production, but he will be the centerpiece of the Cowboys' previously receiver-desperate attack. Cooper is under team control through 2019.
report: Cowboys acquired WR Amari Cooper from the Raiders in exchange for a first-round pick.

impact: Paying a first-round pick for a No. 1 receiver is not an issue, but paying it for a player who has struggled to consistently produce and will require a big extension in the near future is more dubious. Either way, Cooper is a Cowboy now, and he will join the team on Tuesday to start getting ready for what should be his debut in Week 9.
report: Cowboys coach Jason Garrett said a first-round pick is "what a player like [Amari Cooper] costs."

impact: Kupp was mysteriously not on the field during the Rams' first drive of the second half before the team announced he was being evaluated for a concussion. It is not clear when he suffered the injury. Kupp had six catches for 90 yards and a touchdown in the first half before exiting. With Brandin Cooks also out, Josh Reynolds exploded for 49 yards on three touches on the first drive of the third quarter.
report: Cooper Kupp exited Week 5 against the Seahawks to be evaluated for a concussion.

impact: It would have been a shock if Cooks was able to return to the game, but Kupp's outlook was less clear. Both have been placed in the protocol and will have to be cleared in order to suit up next week in Denver. Robert Woods will serve as the No. 1 in the interim, and Josh Reynolds is worth a look on the waiver wire.
report: Rams ruled out Cooper Kupp and Brandin Cooks for the rest of Week 5 against the Seahawks with concussions.

impact: He said the same of Brandin Cooks, who is also dealing with a concussion. "They felt good today. They didn’t have any symptoms or things like that," McVay said. "We’ll go through the standard operating procedure, and if everything checks out...then we’re hopeful to get those guys this week." McVay's optimism is promising, but both players still have hurdles to clear before they are ready to go. If Kupp sits, TE Gerald Everett could see an expanded role.
report: Rams coach Sean McVay is "hopeful" Cooper Kupp (concussion) will be cleared to play this week.

impact: He was ultimately listed as a non-participant, but Kupp's attendance at Wednesday's walkthrough is still an encouraging sign for his Week 6 status. Brandin Cooks is also in the concussion protocol. Coach Sean McVay said he "feels good" about both players chances of suiting up against the Broncos.
report: Cooper Kupp (concussion) took part in the Rams’ walkthrough on Wednesday.

impact: Kupp will be listed as "limited," but coach Sean McVay said he will be "full" on Friday as long as he avoids setbacks. Along with Brandin Cooks (concussion), Kupp is now set to face the Broncos. He will be a mid-range WR2.
report: Cooper Kupp (concussion) practiced again on Thursday.

impact: Same goes for Brandin Cooks, who also experienced a concussion in Los Angeles' Week 5 divisional match versus the Seahawks. Both receivers were full participants in practice Friday and are expected to be cleared from the league's protocol on Saturday. Josh Reynolds would start in the unlikely event either are suddenly ruled out.
report: Cooper Kupp (concussion) is expected to play in Week 6 against the Broncos.

impact: Kupp and Cooks were both full participants in practice on Friday and were cleared Saturday morning, as expected. The Rams will be near full-health in what projects as a sneaky shootout given the recent defensive tendencies of both sides against the Broncos. Expect no limitations for either Kupp or Cooks.
report: Cooper Kupp (concussion) will play in Week 6 against the Broncos.

impact: This one had the looks of a potential season-ender. Finishing off a 12-yard run in the second quarter, Kupp got horse-collar tackled by Darian Stewart and immediately went down in agony. Stewart's dirty tackle is the exact reason the horse-collar was outlawed in 2005. Kupp was examined on the sideline for a few moments before being carted to the locker room. Josh Reynolds will finish the game in Kupp's place in three-receiver sets.
report: Cooper Kupp was forced from Sunday's game against the Broncos with a left knee injury and will not return.

impact: It looked like Kupp's season might be over in the first half after he was carted to the locker room following a horse-collar tackle. He was reportedly extremely stiff upon arriving to the locker room. Evidently it was all downhill from there. Perhaps Kupp will mostly be a second half decoy, but his return is the best possible news for the Rams.
report: Cooper Kupp (knee) returned for the second half of Sunday's game against the Broncos.

impact: Kupp appeared to wreck his knee in the first half before stunningly returning after the break. It ended up a technicality, however, as Kupp was barely out there as the Rams gutted out an ugly road victory. Kupp's initial tests brought back good news, but we would not take his Week 7 status for granted. Further testing might be required on Monday, while the Rams could take a conservative approach with the 49ers on deck for Week 7.
report: Cooper Kupp was held without a catch on one target in the Rams' Week 6 win over the Broncos.

impact: This is typically a multi-week injury, but far from a season ender.  Kupp's Week 7 availability seems unlikely, which would make TE Gerald Everett and No. 4 WR Josh Reynolds intriguing dart throws against the 49ers on Sunday.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Cooper Kupp has been diagnosed with an MCL sprain.

impact: "Most likely he probably will miss this game," McVay said.  "And then dependent on how he responds it will just kind of be on a week-to-week basis."  The Rams will turn to sophomores Gerald Everett and Josh Reynolds in Kupp's absence.  Both will be deep down the totem pole for targets behind Robert Woods, Brandin Cooks, and Todd Gurley.  Kupp shouldn't miss much time.
report: Coach Sean McVay expects Cooper Kupp (knee) to miss Week 7 against the 49ers.

impact: Kupp's knee injury looked much worse than it was, though he's still dealing with an MCL sprain, which is usually a multi-week injury. The second-year slot man has played well this season but the Rams still have plenty of receiving weapons to surround Jared Goff including Todd Gurley, Robert Woods and Brandin Cooks. Consider Kupp week to week.
report: Rams coach Sean McVay confirmed Cooper Kupp (knee) is out for Week 7 against the 49ers.

impact: The Rams have not ruled Kupp out for next week, but it is likely he ends up missing multiple games. DB Darious Williams, RB Justin Davis, RB John Kelly, OL Brian Allen, DL Sebastian Joseph-Day, and DL Tanzel Smart are also out.
report: Rams declared Cooper Kupp (knee) inactive for Week 7 against the 49ers.

impact: Kupp is said to be making "good progress" in his recovery from an MCL sprain, but he was never likely to play this week. Brandin Cooks and Robert Woods should see more looks in his absence.
report: Rams coach Sean McVay said Cooper Kupp (knee) is doubtful for Week 8 against the Packers.

impact: Heuerman caught Case Keenum's first three completions of the night and was never heard from again before a 36-yard pickup on the game's final drive.  His seven targets tied for the team lead in the Broncos' first game without Jake Butt (knee), so Heuerman appears to have No. 1 TE duties on lock in Denver.  Regardless, he's a real weak fantasy option ahead of Week 5 at the Jets.
report: Jeff Heuerman caught 4-of-7 targets for 57 yards in the Broncos' Week 4 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: Heuerman was hardly heard from despite the Broncos teeing up a season-high 51 pass attempts, which is concerning for Heuerman's streamer viability going forward.  He will be a low-end TE2 in Week 6 against the Rams.
report: Jeff Heuerman caught 2-of-4 targets for 18 yards in the Broncos' Week 5 loss.

impact: The yards were Heuerman's second most of the season. He's done little to suggest he will be anything more than a last-gasp TE2 in fantasy leagues.
report: Jeff Heuerman caught 3-of-6 targets for 23 yards in the Broncos' Week 6 loss to the Rams.

impact: Heuerman actually was targeted once — catching a 10-yard touchdown — but it was erased by an offensive pass interference penalty. Heuerman will offer last-gasp TE2 appeal for what should hopefully be a high-scoring game with the Chiefs in Week 8.
report: Jeff Heuerman wasn't targeted in the Broncos' Week 7 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Brown was the No. 2 option behind Michael Crabtree. He got open in the red-zone for his touchdown, scoring from seven yards out. Brown was talked up all training camp and looks to have a good rapport with Joe Flacco. He's on the WR4 radar for a Week 2 matchup with the Bengals.
report: John Brown caught 3-of-4 targets for 44 yards and a touchdown in Week 1 against Buffalo.

impact: Brown's 10 targets tied Michael Crabtree for the team lead. They were six more than he drew in the opener. Brown now has two touchdowns through two games as a Raven and made two nearly impossible catches this evening. The first was a 45-yarder that should have been picked in triple coverage. The second was his 21-yard touchdown in the fourth quarter, where he simply took the ball from Dre Kirkpatrick in the end zone. Fully healthy and playing a legitimate amount of snaps, Brown is shaping up as an upside WR3.
report: John Brown caught 4-of-10 targets for 92 yards and a touchdown in the Ravens' Week 2 loss to the Bengals.

impact: He finished with one fewer target than Michael Crabtree, but he easily led the team in receiving yardage on a day which could have been bigger. Brown just missed a couple long catches down the sideline in the first half before Joe Flacco hit him with a beautiful pass for a 44-yard gain in the second quarter. At worst the 1B receiver in a quietly solid passing attack, Brown will be an upside WR3 next week against the Steelers.
report: John Brown hauled in 5-of-9 targets for 86 yards in the Ravens' Week 3 win over the Broncos.

impact: We're still waiting on the injury details. Brown was spotted on the field early but went inside before individual drills started. It's not a good sign for his Week 4 status.
report: John Brown didn't practice Wednesday.

impact: Brown's Wednesday absence was not injury related. He will be a WR3 for what could be a high-scoring game with the Steelers.
report: John Brown returned to Ravens practice Thursday.

impact: Brown burned past Steelers CB Joe Haden for a 33-yard touchdown on the opening drive of the night. He added a 71-yard deep shot in the second quarter, but faded after halftime. Brown has been locked-in with Joe Flacco over the first four games and is tied for the league lead on passes traveling 30 or more air yards. He'll be a boom/bust WR3 against the Browns in Week 5.
report: John Brown caught 3-of-7 targets for 116 yards and a touchdown in Week 4 against the Steelers.

impact: Brown led the Ravens in targets on Sunday, but failed to turn all of those looks into much as he and Flacco were not on the same page frequently. Brown's long gain of the day was a 28-yard catch and run, giving him a 25-yard plus reception in all five games this season. Brown has established himself as the Ravens' best playmaker through five weeks and will enter Week 6 as a WR2 option against the Titans.
