report: John Brown caught 5-of-14 passes for 58 yards in Sunday's Week 5 loss to the Browns.

impact: Brown's two-catch day wouldn't have been so bad had he not seen 14 targets just last week. Instead it was Michael Crabtree (6/93/1) who finally broke out, with Willie Snead (7/60) quietly leading all in targets (10) and catches (7). There are better days on the horizon for Brown, who's still the team's primary deep threat and second on the Ravens with a 17% target share. Consider both he and Crabtree simultaneous WR2's against New Orleans' porous secondary in Week 7.
report: John Brown hauled in 2-of-3 targets for 28 yards in the Ravens' Week 6 win over the Titans.

impact: Coming off back-to-back quiet games, Brown set new season highs in catches and yards. 56 of his yards came on a dig route where Brown was allowed to run free. He got tackled at the two-yard line. Despite the big day, Brown did get out-targeted by Michael Crabtree. Brown's big-play volatility keeps him on the WR2/3 borderline. The Panthers are on deck for Week 8.
report: John Brown caught 7-of-7 targets for 134 yards and a touchdown in the Ravens' Week 7 loss to the Saints.

impact: Miller wasn't targeted in the pass game against a Colts defense that has shown an inability to cover running backs.  Instead, the Texans opted to feature rookie WR Keke Coutee in the short passing game, targeting him a team-high 15 times.  Miller remains without a rushing touchdown through four games and ceded 12 carries to Alfred Blue, who mustered just 31 yards.  Miller has been a steady RB2 to this point, but has provided no ceiling.  He gets the Cowboys in Week 5.
report: Lamar Miller rushed 15 times for 49 yards in the Texans' Week 4 win over the Colts.

impact: Miller is often a little banged up. It sounds like he could miss some practice time this week but ultimately be out there for Sunday night's game against the Cowboys. Miller is merely the RB34 by average points thus far.
report: Speaking Monday, Texans coach Bill O'Brien said Lamar Miller came out of Sunday's game "a little banged up," but that he believes Miller should be "OK."

impact: This was expected after coach Bill O'Brien said Miller was "a little banged up" after Sunday's win. Miller may not see much practice time this week, but he should play against Dallas.
report: Lamar Miller (chest) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Miller's health isn't a concern, but his play is. Miller will find himself on the RB2/3 borderline for Sunday night's game against the Cowboys. He's at risk of losing more carries to Alfred Blue.
report: Lamar Miller (chest) remained "limited" on Thursday.

impact: Miller has been limited in practice this week. That usually means a player will suit up on Sundays, but it sounds like Miller is legitimately questionable. If Miller sits, Alfred Blue would handle the load and be a volume-based RB2/FLEX.
report: Coach Bill O'Brien said Lamar Miller (questionable, chest) will be a game-time decision Week 5 against the Cowboys.

impact: If Miller is indeed out on Sunday Night Football, Alfred Blue would be positioned for 20 or more carries against the Sean Lee-less Cowboys.  Blue is far from a special talent, but Bill O'Brien's staff has shown a willingness to feed him heavy volume before.  And they may be getting fed up with Miller, who ranks a lowly 34th among 38 qualified backs in Football Outsiders' rushing Success Rate.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports the Texans are pessimistic Lamar Miller (chest) will be able to play Sunday night versus Dallas.

impact: This comes as a surprise after reports the Texans were "pessimistic" Miller would play. Miller's workload figures to be scaled back, but this kills any streamining value for Alfred Blue. Will Fuller (hamstring) and Keke Coutee (hamstring) are also active for Sunday night.
report: Lamar Miller (chest) is active for Week 5 against the Cowboys.

impact: Alfred Blue will start, so it sounds like Miller will only be available on an emergency basis. It's a confusing situation, but coach Bill O'Brien has done this before in Will Fuller's rookie season, who was active but didn't see any snaps. Blue is a plug-and-play RB2. Miller shouldn't be in fantasy lineups.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Lamar Miller (chest) "isn't expected to play" despite being active for Sunday night's game with Dallas.

impact: Miller was active for Sunday night's game against the Cowboys, but it was only in an emergency role. That at least meant he was close to being ready, however, so it is not a surprise he is expected to suit up against the Bills on Sunday. He will be a back-end RB2 in that matchup.
report: Texans coach Bill O'Brien expects Lamar Miller (chest) to play Week 6.

impact: Miller took Week 5 off and saw Alfred Blue handle 28 touches and turn them into 119 yards.  Miller has been a huge disappointment this season, failing to score a rushing touchdown despite seeing good-sized workloads.  We wouldn't be surprised if Miller and Blue share the work closer to 50-50.
report: Lamar Miller (chest) said he's "definitely" going to play Week 6 against the Bills.

impact: Miller is due back this week after sitting out Sunday's game with a chest injury. He's been a disappointment this year, averaging under four yards per carry with one touchdown in four games. With Alfred Blue beginning to see more work and D'Onta Foreman (Achilles) expected back in Week 7, Miller's days as a weekly fantasy RB2 could be numbered.
report: Lamar Miller (chest) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Active only on an emergency basis for Week 5, Miller appears on track to actually play against the Bills. Struggling and at less than 100 percent, we are more concerned about Miller's usage than usual. It's possible Alfred Blue remains more involved this week, making for a destitute man's Devonta Freeman/Tevin Coleman type of committee. Miller is best treated as a FLEX option.
report: Lamar Miller (chest) was upgrade to "full" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Alfred Blue got his share of carries in this game, but Miller still operated as the clear lead back. That usage did not lead to a big fantasy day, but Miller played better than his numbers suggest. He also could have had a touchdown on a trick play, but DeAndre Hopkins just missed him. All of that said, a possible D'Onta Foreman return and a tough matchup with Jacksonville will make Miller more of a low-end FLEX option next week.
report: Lamar Miller rushed 15 times for 46 yards and caught 2-of-3 targets for 25 yards in the Texans' Week 6 win over the Bills.

impact: The Texans stayed committed to their rushing attack as underdogs on the road, and Miller rewarded them with his best game of the season.  He out-touched Alfred Blue 23 to 8 as Houston reeled off its fourth straight victory following an 0-3 start.  Suddenly favorites to win the AFC South, the Texans go back home for Week 8 Thursday Night Football against the Dolphins.  Back in Houston's featured-back role, Miller will be a quality RB2 play in that game.
report: Lamar Miller rushed 22 times for 100 yards and a touchdown and caught 1-of-3 targets for -1 yard in the Texans' Week 7 win over the Jaguars.

impact: The 133 yards on the ground were Miller's second most as a Texan and came against the team that let him walk in free agency in 2016. Miller has now hit the century mark in back-to-back games, suddenly saving a fantasy season that had been circling the drain. Tonight was a soft matchup, but the Jags were anything but in Week 7. The Broncos will be another soft matchup for Week 9. Miller is once again looking like a safe RB2.
report: Lamar Miller rushed 18 times for 133 yards and a touchdown in the Texans' Week 8 win over the Dolphins.

impact: Foreman tore his Achilles' last November and should be at or near 100 percent.  With Lamar Miller struggling in the lead role and without a touchdown, Foreman could come back to an open backfield with a chance to gain ground on Miller and Alfred Blue relatively quickly.  He's worth an add if you have roster space.
report: Coach Bill O'Brien said D'Onta Foreman (Achilles', PUP) is "on track" to return when first eligible in Week 7.

impact: "I don't think he's quite ready," O'Brien added. Houston originally expected Foreman to be ready Week 1, and now he is not even healthy enough to play six weeks into the season. Coming back from a tough injury for running backs, Foreman is just a weak bench stash in deeper leagues.
report: Texans coach Bill O'Brien does not expect D'Onta Foreman (Achilles', PUP) to be activated this week.

impact: Blue was out-touched 21-5 in the Texans' season opener but closed the gap (16-7) in Week 2. Miller is still being used as an every-down workhorse, but he admittedly lacks explosiveness and hasn't shown a propensity to break tackles yet this season. Until Blue eats into Miller's opportunities, though, it's the latter who's still the back to own in Houston.
report: Alfred Blue rushed seven times for 36 yards in the Texans' Week 2 loss to the Titans.

impact: Meanwhile, Lamar Miller rushed 15 times for 49 yards, so neither runner had much success.  Blue was targeted three times in the pass game, catching none of them.  The 15-12 touch share is a bit concerning for Miller owners.
report: Alfred Blue rushed 12 times for 31 yards in the Texans' Week 4 win over the Colts.

impact: Blue started and had a workhorse role despite Lamar Miller (chest) being active. He was more of a factor in the passing game, but Blue had some nice runs. The Texans never let Blue get in a rhythm and he was passed over for multiple goal-line looks in favor of Deshaun Watson. Miller was close to playing this week, so Blue will likely return to a backup role in Week 6.
report: Alfred Blue rushed 20 times for 46 yards and caught eight passes for 73 yards in Week 5 against the Cowboys.

impact: With Lamar Miller back, Blue went right back into a secondary role against the Bills. He did flash with a 17-yard run early, but he was mostly held in check the rest of the way. D'Onta Foreman's potential return is a concern for Blue's handcuff value moving forward.
report: Alfred Blue rushed seven times for 26 yards and caught 2-of-3 targets for 17 yards in the Texans' Week 6 win over the Bills.

impact: Butt's injury is unclear. With eight catches on 12 targets through three games, Butt is trying to get himself on the TE2 streaming radar.
report: Broncos TE Jake Butt was absent from Thursday's practice.

impact: Butt didn't appear to be practicing, at least from the vantage of team reporters, but apparently he got in a limited session. The second-year tight end has handled eight-of-12 targets for 85 scoreless yards this season.
report: Updating an earlier report, Broncos TE Jake Butt (knee) was limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: It appears Butt suffered the injury on Thursday. If so, the news is ominous. The Broncos have an unimpressive tight end group even with Butt. Without him, it's Jets-level.
report: Broncos TE Jake Butt is undergoing an MRI on his knee after suffering a non-contact injury during a walk-through.

impact: It has since been confirmed. It's beyond brutal for the one-time promising prospect, who is now dealing with his third career ACL tear. The first two were to his right knee. For the Broncos, it further hollows out an already thin tight end group. Neither of Jeff Heuerman or Matt LaCosse are going to become a factor catching the ball in Butt's absence. Butt is still only 23, but his NFL career is headed in the wrong direction. He can be dropped in Dynasty leagues.
report: NFL.com's Ian Rapoport reports "the fear" is Broncos TE Jake Butt suffered a non-contact left ACL tear in Thursday's walk-through.

impact: Jones saw close to his normal workload (48-of-63 offensive snaps) in Sunday's win over Carolina, so it's possible this is just a maintenance day. As long as he returns to practice by Friday, Julio should be good to go for Week 3 against New Orleans.
report: Julio Jones (calf) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: Jones battled some minor calf tightness in last week's win over Carolina but claims to be "fine." Julio should be up to his usual tricks Sunday against New Orleans. He's RotoPat's No. 2 wide receiver for Week 3.
report: Julio Jones (calf) confirmed that his absence from Wednesday's practice was "precautionary."

impact: Jones told the media Thursday that his absence was just a precaution after his calf tightened up in Sunday's win over Carolina. We'd expect him to close out the week with a limited session on Friday. Even with Defensive Rookie of the Year Marshon Lattimore likely to shadow him, Jones will be safe to pencil in as a WR1 in all formats.
report: Julio Jones (calf) remained sidelined at Thursday's practice.

impact: Jones returned to practice Friday and was able to do "quite a bit," according to Quinn. Despite missing the first two practices of the week with calf tightness, Julio's Week 3 status was never in doubt. He wasn't even listed on the team's final injury report. Jones should be in for a big week against a Saints secondary that has allowed the fourth-most yards per game this season.
report: Falcons coach Dan Quinn confirmed Julio Jones (calf) will play Week 3 against the Saints.

impact: Julio was invisible in the first half, drawing just two targets from Matt Ryan. Jones’ biggest contribution of the afternoon came when he dusted Ken Crawley for a 58-yard pickup in the fourth quarter. It should have been an easy touchdown but Ryan didn’t put enough air under it. This was a serviceable game for Jones, though the veteran was vastly overshadowed by teammate and fellow Alabama alum Calvin Ridley (7-146-3). After tangling with Marshon Lattimore on Sunday, Jones will get another tough draw next week against underrated Bengals corner William Jackson. At least it will be a home game for Atlanta.
report: Julio Jones contributed five catches for 96 yards on six targets Sunday in the Falcons’ Week 3 loss to New Orleans.

impact: Jones didn't practice much last week before playing 54-of-68 snaps in Sunday's loss. There's no concern over his Week 4 status.
report: Julio Jones (calf) isn't practicing Wednesday.

impact: Jones will be an elite WR1 against the Bengals.
report: Julio Jones (calf) returned to Falcons practice Thursday.

impact: Jones sat out Wednesday's practice, but he was never in real danger of sitting out this week. He will be a high-end WR1 against the Bengals.
report: Julio Jones (calf) was not listed on the final injury report for Week 4.

impact: Jones remains too classy for touchdowns, but he was once again a monster in this game. Seemingly open every time Matt Ryan needed a big play, Jones converted third down after third down for an offense which was rarely stopped. He padded his stats with 66 yards on the Falcons' final, desperation drive. While a touchdown or two would be cool, Jones is averaging 126 yards a game and has a great matchup with the Steelers on deck. He remains a high-end WR1.
report: Julio Jones hauled in 9-of-12 targets for 173 yards in the Falcons' Week 4 loss to the Bengals.

impact: It's more maintenance for Jones, who rarely practices. Coming off  last week's 173-yard game, Jones has another blowup spot against the Steelers.
report: Julio Jones (ankle, hand) was held out of Wednesday's practice.

impact: Jones is not injured. A locked-in top-three receiver, Jones will have an excellent shot at breaking touchdown drought against the Steelers' struggling defense.
report: Julio Jones (ankle, hand) returned to a limited practice on Thursday.

impact: The Falcons have been managing his reps, but Jones was never in danger of sitting. He's a top-five receiver play for Week 5.
report: Julio Jones (ankle, hand) was removed from the Week 5 injury report.

impact: Stunningly, Jones was held without a catch for three quarters. He did a decent job of salvaging his fantasy line in the fourth quarter, when a non-competitive game was already over. Despite the disappointing day, Jones still has a monster 564 yards through five games. He will be in the WR1 overall discussion for Week 6 against the pathetic Bucs.
report: Julio Jones caught 5-of-9 targets for 62 yards in the Falcons' Week 5 loss to the Steelers.

impact: Jones remained allergic to the end zone even with Calvin Ridley and Mohamed Sanu leaving early, but that did not stop him from making play after play against the Bucs' overmatched secondary. He was seemingly running free all game, and he converted several big third downs throughout. Even with a couple down games thrown in, Jones is on pace for 1,885 yards through six games. A touchdown or two would be nice, but Jones remains a high-end WR1.
report: Julio Jones hauled in 10-of-14 targets for 143 yards in the Falcons' Week 6 win over the Bucs.

impact: Standard day at the office for Jones; he got his 100 yards and remains without a touchdown on the season.  There was an opening for one, but Matt Ryan underthrew Jones on what should have been a walk-in 60-yard touchdown.  Ryan hit his hand on a helmet on the follow-through, and Jones had to stop for the ball, drawing a 38-yard pass interference instead.  On two of the next three plays, Ryan tried to get Jones the ball in the end zone, but Jones was double-covered both times.  Jones also lost a fumble in this one.  The Falcons are on their bye now before going to D.C. in Week 9.
report: Julio Jones caught 9-of-12 targets for 104 yards in the Falcons' 23-20, Week 7 win over the Giants on Monday night.

impact: He was overshadowed by Emmanuel Sanders, but Thomas overcame a slow start to post a pretty good line. His touchdown came from four yards out and ended up being the game-winner. While Case Keenum's apparent affinity for Sanders is a concern, Thomas will remain a solid WR2 next week against the Raiders.
report: Demaryius Thomas hauled in 6-of-10 targets for 63 yards and a touchdown in the Broncos' Week 1 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Thomas was a non-factor Sunday despite the high target count, including two dropped passes. Through two weeks, Thomas has secured just 11-of-21 targets for 81 yards as it appears the receiver you want to own for fantasy in this offense is Emmanuel Sanders. Thomas will head into a Week 3 matchup versus the Ravens as a WR3 for fantasy purposes.
report: Demaryius Thomas caught 5-of-11 targets for 18 yards in Sunday's Week 2 win over the Raiders.

impact: It still was not a great fantasy day, but Thomas was much more efficient in this one. He made a great catch in the third quarter to help get the offense moving, and he had another long gain called back by a penalty. He did briefly leave with what looked like a knee injury in the fourth quarter, but he returned a few plays later. Assuming he is healthy, Thomas will be a WR2 in a good matchup against the Chiefs next Monday night.
report: Demaryius Thomas hauled in all five of his targets for 63 yards in the Broncos' Week 3 loss to the Ravens.

impact: Thomas has been held under 25 yards in 2-of-4 games and has yet to top 65 yards in a game.  He continues to battle drops.  Thomas should have had a walk-in game-winning 28-yard touchdown on the final drive Monday night, but Case Keenum missed him running wide-open down the right sideline.  Thomas may have also slowed up prematurely on the route.  Either way, Thomas has been a massive disappointment.  He'll be a WR3 next week on the road at the Jets.
report: Demaryius Thomas caught 4-of-7 targets for 24 yards in the Broncos' Week 4 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: Thomas was a non-factor for most of the game, then was fortunate to score a 42-yard touchdown deep in garbage time of Denver's 34-16 blowout loss.  This was just the second time Thomas has topped 70 yards over his last 16 games.  Thomas will remain a solid-if-unexciting WR2/3 option when the Broncos host the Rams next.  That game's shootout potential does enhance his Week 6 upside.
report: Demaryius Thomas caught 5-of-6 targets for 105 yards and a touchdown in the Broncos' Week 5 loss to the Jets.

impact: Thomas also drew a 19-yard DPI. 45 of Thomas' yards came on a badly-underthrown sideline deep ball from Case Keenum. Thomas managed to come back to the pass and make a nice grab. He displayed fancy footwork on his one-yard score in the fourth quarter. Thomas has scored in back-to-back games but could have a hard time making it 3-for-3 against the Cardinals' decent pass defense in Week 7.
report: Demaryius Thomas caught 3-of-4 targets for 57 yards and a touchdown in the Broncos' Week 6 loss to the Rams.

impact: They were disappointing stats on a night the Broncos won 45-10, but there was not much for Thomas to do with Cardinals QB Josh Rosen continually handing the ball to the Broncos' defense and setting up either touchdowns or excellent field position. Thomas will be firmly in the WR2 mix against the Chiefs' awful defense in Week 8.
report: Demaryius Thomas caught 5-of-6 passes for 42 yards in the Broncos' Week 7 win over the Cardinals.

impact: The Broncos are getting ready to blow it all up and that could mean moving their long-time wide receiver at next week's trade deadline. Emmanuel Sanders has also drawn interest, though the Broncos are reportedly reluctant to trade him. With Demaryius nearing the end of his prime and rookie Courtland Sutton pushing for a larger role in the Broncos' passing game, it makes sense for the rebuilding Broncos to at least field offers for the veteran.
report: According to ESPN's Adam Schefter, the Broncos are "listening" to trade offers for Demaryius Thomas.

impact: Klis says it's a "good bet" Thomas finishes the season in Denver.  The soon-to-be 31-year-old (in December) is signed through 2019 at a $14 million salary next year.  We'd say it's a "good bet" this is Thomas' last year with the team, at least on that contract.  He's likely to be cut or dealt in the offseason.
report: 9 News Denver's Mike Klis reports the Broncos will not trade and are not shopping Demaryius Thomas ahead of next Tuesday's trade deadline.

impact: Thomas must have picked up the injury last week at Arizona. Regardless, he'll be all systems go for Sunday's divisional game against the Chiefs. Thomas posted a sluggish 4-24-0 line when he faced Kansas City earlier this month.
report: Demaryius Thomas (wrist) is practicing in full for Week 8 against the Chiefs.

impact: The one target is real concerning for Anderson owners, but the good news is Anderson scored, and Sam Darnold only attempted 21 passes in the lopsided win.  Anderson also had to deal with CB Darius Slay much of the night.  His touchdown was a pass-off to S Tavon Wilson, who didn't stand a chance.  But with Quincy Enunwa back from his neck injury and seeing 10 targets in this one, Anderson's volume might take a sizable hit.  Move forward with Anderson as a big-play WR3 for next week's home opener against the Dolphins.
report: Robby Anderson caught his lone target for a 41-yard touchdown in the Jets' Week 1 win over the Lions.

impact: He's been out-targeted 21 to 6 by Quincy Enunwa through two games.  Anderson's big-play potential gives him theoretical upside each week, but his usage has been very disappointing in an offense that features shorter passing and not necessarily deep shots down the sideline.  Anderson will remain a boom-bust WR3/flex option when Gang Green visits Cleveland next.
report: Robby Anderson caught 3-of-5 targets for 27 yards in the Jets' Week 2 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: Anderson's lost fumble, which came at the Jets' 26-yard line, was a back-breaker, setting the Browns up for an easy third quarter field goal as they began their Baker Mayfield-fueled comeback. Anderson also suffered a nose injury on the play. With the Jets trying to hide Sam Darnold as he learns the NFL ropes, Anderson has become invisible, catching six passes for 90 yards and a score through the Jets' first three games. He's barely rosterable in re-draft leagues.
report: Robby Anderson caught 2-of-4 targets for 22 yards in the Jets' Week 3 loss to the Browns, also losing a fumble.

impact: Anderson's early-season struggles continued. He has just eight catches for 108 yards and a score through the Jets' first four games while dealing with fumbles and drops. It's shaping as a lost year for Anderson.
report: Robby Anderson caught 2-of-6 passes for 18 yards in Week 4 against Jacksonville.

impact: That's great news, but Anderson has been wholly disappointing through four weeks.  He caught a 41-yard touchdown on his lone target in Week 1 and has failed to top 27 yards each of the past three games, securing 7-of-15 targets in that span.  Quincy Enunwa played 53 snaps to Jermaine Kearse's 48 and Anderson's 42 in Week 4.  Anderson can be dropped in 12-team leagues.
report: Robby Anderson will not be suspended by the NFL after his two arrests in the past year.

impact: Anderson dusted Bradley Roby relentlessly in this one, first beating him for a 12-yard catch on a nasty out route, then blowing past Roby for a 76-yard touchdown bomb, then rinsing Roby again for a 35-yard score on a pinpoint-placement throw by Sam Darnold.  Anderson's lack of volume has rendered him highly untrustworthy from a fantasy standpoint, but his big-play potential is undeniable.  He will remain a boom-bust WR3/flex option in Week 6 versus the Colts.
report: Robby Anderson caught 3-of-5 targets for 123 yards and two touchdowns in the Jets' Week 5 win over the Broncos.

impact: Five to six targets has become Anderson's weekly expectation, and he needs to connect on low volume in order to produce usable fantasy results.  Sam Darnold tried to go to Anderson for a big play in the first half of Sunday's win, but Darnold underthrew the pass and it was picked off easily by Malik Hooker.  Anderson will remain a boom-bust WR3/flex option in Week 7 against the Vikings.
report: Robby Anderson caught 3-of-5 targets for 39 yards in the Jets' Week 6 win over the Colts.

impact: All three of Quincy Enunwa (ankle), Terrelle Pryor (groin), and Anderson didn't practice Wednesday.  It's still early in the week, but this is a lot of missing firepower at wideout, as Enunwa has already been ruled out.  We should have a better idea later in the week, but Jermaine Kearse is the only healthy one right now.
report: Robby Anderson (hamstring) did not practice Wednesday.

impact: Anderson sat out Wednesday's session. It is likely he is limited on Thursday, but this is still a great sign for his availability. With Quincy Enunwa (ankle) set to sit, Anderson could see a bump in his target share.
report: Robby Anderson (hamstring) returned to practice Thursday.

impact: This confirms that he was just getting a maintenance day on Wednesday. Anderson will be ready to roll for Sunday's Week 7 matchup against the Vikings. The third-year deep threat has had a quiet year to this point, though he could see an uptick in usage now that Quincy Enunwa is on the shelf with a high-ankle sprain.
report: Updating an earlier report, Robby Anderson (hamstring) returned to full participation at Thursday's practice.

impact: His 10 targets were a team-high, but Sam Darnold was not good while completing just 40.5% of his passes and overthrowing Anderson on a potential 81-yard touchdown bomb over the top when Anderson had separation.  Anderson appeared to be shaken up in the second as he got tangled up with CB Xavier Rhodes, but he came back in the game.  Anderson will try to rebound next week on the road against the Bears, but that's a tough matchup with a rookie quarterback.
report: Robby Anderson caught 3-of-10 targets for 44 yards in the Jets' Week 7 loss to the Vikings.

impact: Last week, it was a hamstring problem that Anderson missed practice before playing through.  Toward the end of last week's loss to the Vikings, Anderson and Xavier Rhodes got tangled up on the sideline, and both had to be helped off the field.  If Anderson can't play, newly-signed Rishard Matthews may have to play immediately alongside Jermaine Kearse at wideout.
report: Robby Anderson (ankle) did not practice Wednesday.

impact: Supposedly his sprain is between a "high" and "low" injury. Whatever it is, Anderson is looking doubtful for Sunday's game against the Bears. His absence would thrust Rishard Matthews into an immediate, major role.
report: Robby Anderson (ankle) remained sidelined on Thursday.

impact: Battling a "mid" ankle sprain, Anderson seems week to week.  The Jets will go into Chicago with Jermaine Kearse as the default No. 1 receiver, followed up by Andre Roberts, Charone Peake, and newcomer Rishard Matthews.
report: Robby Anderson (ankle) is doubtful for Week 8 against the Bears.

impact: Gabriel played ahead of Anthony Miller in two-wide sets. He wasn't much of a factor after missing most of the preseason. Gabriel is the No. 3 option behind Allen Robinson and Trey Burton in an offense that struggles to support multiple receivers. He's not on the Week 2 fantasy radar.
report: Taylor Gabriel caught five passes for 25 yards in Week 1 against the Packers.

impact: The seven targets were easily second-most on the team but a distant second to Allen Robinson's 14.  Gabriel has nine grabs for a meager 55 yards through two games.  He's well off the fantasy map ahead of Week 3 at Arizona.
report: Taylor Gabriel caught 4-of-7 targets for 30 yards in the Bears' Week 2 win over the Seahawks.

impact: It's the third consecutive game that Gabriel's seen at least seven targets. He even out-shined perennial No. 1 Allen Robinson (2-23-1) on Mitchell Trubisky's career six-score day. The Bears' offense has quietly developed and thus progressively improved in every outing so far this season, slowly raising Gabriel's stock with every passing game. He'll come out of Chicago's Week 5 bye as a strong FLEX option against the Dolphins.
report: Taylor Gabriel brought in all seven of his targets for a career-high 104 yards and two touchdowns in the Bears' Week 4 win over the Bucs.

impact: Make that two 100-yard receiving games in a row for Gabriel, who went off for 104 yards against Tampa Bay prior to the Bears' bye week. Gabriel didn't find the end zone in this one but he still made his presence felt with a number of big plays, the first of those coming on a 47-yard deep bomb from Mitchell Trubisky during the second quarter. He bettered that with a 54-yarder in the third quarter, again dusting overmatched corner Torry McTyer for a huge gain. The speedy 27-year-old has quickly emerged as Trubisky's preferred deep threat. He'll look to keep it going against New England in Week 7.
report: Taylor Gabriel snagged all five of his targets for 110 yards while adding a nine-yard rush Sunday in the Bears’ Week 6 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: With Mitchell Trubisky struggling early, Gabriel caught just one pass in the first half for seven yards. He did get a carry inside the 10-yard line in the third quarter and drew a long defensive pass interference on the next series, but this was a big letdown after back-to-back 100-yard games. He will look to get back on track next week against the Jets.
report: Taylor Gabriel hauled in 3-of-4 targets for 26 yards in the Bears' Week 7 loss to the Patriots.

impact: Crabtree bounced back from two drops on his first three targets. He showed good body control to on his touchdown, getting his feet down in the back of the end-zone from 12 yard out. Crabtree could've had more yards but was rested in the second half. He'll be a high-floor WR2 for Thursday night's game with the Bengals.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 3-of-6 passes for 38 yards and a touchdown in Week 1 against Buffalo.

impact: Crabtree now has eight catches for 94 yards and a touchdown through two games as a Raven. That comes out to 11.8 yards per pop, which would be Crabtree's highest mark since 2013. Don't expect it to hold. Crabtree is a possession, chain-moving receiver who will leave your fantasy team feeling cold when he doesn't find the end zone.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 5-of-10 targets for 56 yards in the Ravens' Week 2 loss to the Bengals.

impact: John Brown has been the explosive option in the passing game, but Crabtree continues to be a reliable set of hands for Joe Flacco. He made a couple big catches when the game was in doubt including a third-down conversion in the second quarter. His possession role is not going to result in much fantasy upside when he does not find the end zone, but Crabtree is at worse a solid option in PPR formats. He will be even better than that in a good matchup against the Steelers next week.
report: Michael Crabtree hauled in 7-of-10 targets for 61 yards in the Ravens' Week 3 win over the Broncos.

impact: Crabtree should've had a touchdown, but was overthrown by Joe Flacco in the first quarter. It was a rough night for Crabtree, who dropped a pass and is up to six drops on the year. Crabtree is on pace for 112 catches but just 736 yards and four touchdowns through the first month of the season.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 3-of-8 passes for 29 yards in Week 4 against the Steelers.

impact: Crabtree's 66 yards were a season-high, but it was the 11th consecutive game that he failed to reach 70-yards receiving in a game. He dropped multiple passes on the day, including a potential game-winning touchdown in the final seconds of regulation. Crabtree will be a WR3 in Week 6 against the Titans.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 6-of-12 targets for 66 yards in Sunday's Week 5 loss to the Browns.

impact: The volume had been there all along, but Crabtree still hadn't recorded more than 70 yards in a single game prior to Sunday. He finally turned in a terrific outing against Tennessee, hauling in the team's only receiving score on the day. John Brown (2/28) still profiles as the Ravens' deep threat, but both wideouts are capable of WR2-type outings on any given week. Pending who the Saints stick Marshon Lattimore on, both wideouts have a chance for monumental performances against New Orleans' shoddy secondary next week.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 6-of-9 targets for 93 yards and one touchdown in the Ravens' Week 6 victory over the Titans.

impact: Crabtree got out-caught and out-gained by John Brown today, but Crabtree has out-targeted Brown four of the past five games. He's also cleared 60 yards four of the past five games. Crabtree has vanishingly-little upside but continues to maintain one of the safest WR3 floors in fantasy football. The Panthers are on tap for Week 8.
report: Michael Crabtree caught 5-of-9 targets for 66 yards in the Ravens' Week 7 loss to the Saints.

impact: Matthews practiced fully on Wednesday, but he missed all of training camp and the preseason recovering from a torn meniscus. With so much missed time in a new scheme, Matthews expects to be limited early. "That is kind of the plan, so wherever they need me," Matthews said. "The young guys have been doing good, so wherever they need me to contribute, I am ready to go in there and do what I have to do." With at least Corey Davis and Delanie Walker ahead of him, Matthews cannot be trusted in fantasy lineups this week, but he has quietly been a solid option the last couple seasons. He is worth a stash in deeper formats.
report: Rishard Matthews suggested his snaps will be limited early in the season.

impact: Matthews apparently played over 30 snaps, but he wasn't seen.  Learning a new offense after missing basically everything to this point, it may take a few weeks until we see Matthews on the same page with his quarterbacks.
report: Rishard Matthews was not targeted in the Titans' Week 1 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: It's the second week in a row that Matthews has basically been invisible. The Titans were admittedly down to their backup quarterback and third-string left tackle, but Matthews still finished sixth on the team in receiving yards. His 2018 campaign is off to a horrendous start after spending most of camp on PUP with a torn meniscus.
report: Rishard Matthews caught 2-of-4 targets for eight yards in the Titans' Week 2 win over the Texans.

impact: He can be dropped with yardage totals of 0, 8, and 3 through three games.
report: Rishard Matthews caught 1-of-2 targets for three yards in Week 3.

impact: Matthews' playing time has been scaled back significantly under Mike Vrabel's new coaching staff after he missed the entire offseason with injuries.  He indicated Wednesday that he is upset with his usage.  "I’ve been the leading receiver for two years," Matthews said on Instagram. "Then all of a sudden I’m barely playing and not even starting. Using my injury as the scapegoat. Look at number of snaps and targets."  Matthews is an above-average No. 2 receiver, but the new coaches have no attachment to him.  Expect more-explosive Taywan Taylor to benefit with increased playing time.
report: Rishard Matthews has reportedly left the Titans and does not intend to rejoin the team.

impact: Unhappy with his playing time, Matthews has left the team and reportedly has no plans to return. Trading him would be the best option for Tennessee, but it seems more likely they are forced to release him. With Matthews on the outs, talented sophomore Taywan Taylor should get more opportunities moving forward, and Corey Davis' stranglehold on targets is even more secure.
report: Paul Kuharsky reports it is "doubtful" the Titans will be able to trade Rishard Matthews.

impact: This was really the only possible outcome after Matthews walked away from the team this week. Tennessee's No. 1 receiver each of the last two seasons, Matthews is talented and has consistently produced when given the opportunity. This incident could scare off a few teams, but it would be a surprise if he does not land somewhere in the near future. With Matthews out the door, Corey Davis is locked into the No. 1 role, and talented sophomore Taywan Taylor should see more opportunities.
report: Titans released WR Rishard Matthews.

impact: Rosenhaus is the most powerful agent in football. Up to this point, Matthews had been representing himself. Rosenhaus claims Matthews has already drawn interest from "multiple teams" and expects him to sign soon. The 28-year-old was let go by Tennessee after going AWOL last week. He'd make sense for a receiver-needy team like Dallas.
report: Free agent WR Rishard Matthews has hired Drew Rosenhaus as his agent.

impact: Cleveland will host Matthews on Monday and the Cards will follow that up with a workout the following day. It's the first visits the free agent's scheduled since hiring Drew Rosenhaus as his agent. Now relying on someone else to manage his negotiations, Matthews will likely land with a suitor soon. The Browns make a lot of sense given coach Hue Jackson's reported plan to reduce rookie Antonio Callaway's snaps moving forward.
report: Free agent WR Rishard Matthews will visit the Browns and Cardinals.

impact: Matthews visited with the Browns and Cardinals last week. Cut by the Titans at the end of September, it is surprising Matthews has not found a new home yet, but perhaps he is just looking for the best possible landing spot. New York just lost Quincy Enunwa to an ankle injury.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports free agent WR Rishard Matthews is working out for the Jets on Tuesday.

impact: "Probably not," Matthews said when asked if he'll sign soon.  "A lot of teams are turned off by my past as if I have some criminal record.  Most likely won't see me until next season."  Matthews forced his way out of Tennessee after he wasn't playing enough under new OC Matt LaFleur.  He's had workouts with the Jets, Cardinals, and Browns, but all have went in other directions.
report: Free agent WR Rishard Matthews admitted he's unlikely to sign with a team this season.

impact: This comes just a week after Matthews said he was unlikely to sign with a team this season. With Quincy Enunwa (ankle) out indefinitely and Terrelle Pryor no longer on the roster, this is a good landing spot for Matthews, but it will likely take him some time to settle in. He is only deep-league stash at this point.
report: Jets signed WR Rishard Matthews.

impact: He must have picked up the injury in last week's loss to Cincinnati. Sanu played well in that game, topping 100 yards receiving for the first time in almost four years. He'll be fine for Sunday's shootout in Pittsburgh.
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Although he's coming off a rare 100-yard game, Sanu lacks for fantasy relevance behind Julio Jones and Calvin Ridley.
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) was upgraded to "full" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Sanu practiced fully the last two days after a limited Wednesday session. He should play his normal snaps, but it's only a matter of time before Calvin Ridley replaces Sanu in two-wide sets.
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) was removed from the Falcons' injury report.

impact: Sanu's score was a 43-yarder. It was a short pass Matt Ryan delivered perfectly into traffic, hitting Sanu with a head of steam. The Falcons' No. 3 receiver now has 184 yards over his past two games. He will be in the WR4 mix for next week's plus matchup with the Bucs.
report: Mohamed Sanu caught 4-of-7 targets for 73 yards and a touchdown in the Falcons' Week 5 loss to the Steelers.

impact: It's maintenance for Sanu, who played through his hip injury last week. Sanu isn't in any danger of sitting out Week 6.
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Sanu was limited with the same injury last week. He'll be fine for Sunday's showdown with Tampa Bay. No team has allowed more passing yards per game than the Bucs this year (358).
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: He missed practice time this week with a hip injury, and he appeared to aggravate the issue in the third quarter. He was shown standing on the sidelines after suffering the injury, but he never returned. Sanu finished with two catches for 46 yards and a touchdown.
report: Mohamed Sanu exited Week 6 against the Bucs with a hip injury.

impact: The Falcons will be hosting the Giants for Monday Night Football, so they have an extra day to get healthy. Sanu's issue appears to be a minor aggravation of a previous ailment, while Ridley has a bone bruise. The Falcons will issue their first injury report on Thursday.
report: Falcons coach Dan Quinn is "hopeful" Mohamed Sanu (hip) and Calvin Ridley (ankle) will be ready for Week 7.

impact: Sanu was sidelined during the second half of the win over the Bucs because of a lingering hip issue. It does not appear to be a long-term concern, however, and he looks on track to face the Giants on Monday night. Despite missing those snaps, Sanu is averaging 67 yards a game with three touchdowns in his last four.
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) is expected to practice Thursday.

impact: Sanu's Week 7 is off on the wrong foot. Calvin Ridley, who was also held out on Thursday, appears to have a better shot at suiting up against the Giants on Monday.
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) was held out of Thursday's practice.

impact: It's not a good sign for his Monday night availability though perhaps he'll return to practice on Saturday. If he can't get the green light, Justin Hardy would see more run in three-wide sets.
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) remained sidelined at Friday's practice.

impact: It's unclear how involved he was, but Sanu was spotted running routes and participating in team drills. Teammate Calvin Ridley (ankle) also practiced for the second consecutive day. Both seem on track to play Monday night against the Giants. We'll receive an official word on both following the team's practice.
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) returned to practice Saturday.

impact: Coach Dan Quinn said Sanu (hip), Calvin Ridley (ankle), DE Derrick Shelby, and DT Grady Jarrett are all expected to play Monday night. Sanu hadn't practiced leading up to the weekend but was unable to do enough to gain the confidence of Quinn heading into Monday night. He's considered a WR3 as he'll play away from Janoris Jenkins.
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) is expected to play against the Falcons in Week 7.

impact: It's a surprise after Sanu only got in one limited practice this week. This puts Sanu on track for his normal snaps in Monday night's game with the Giants. With Julio Jones drawing Janoris Jenkins, Sanu may see a few more targets this week.
report: Mohamed Sanu (hip) was removed from the Week 7 injury report.

impact: Sanu had no issues with his hip injury; he just didn't see many targets as Julio Jones garnered 12 and deep reserve WR Marvin Hall also caught a 47-yard score.  Sanu will be a WR4 in Week 9 at the Redskins after the bye.
report: Mohamed Sanu caught both of his targets for 21 yards in the Falcons' Week 7 win over the Giants.

impact: His 64 yards tied Julio Jones for the team lead, while Ridley scored the Falcons' first touchdown through the air from 11 yards out, beating fellow rookie CB Donte Jackson.  Ridley put up a goose egg on two targets in the opener, but coach Dan Quinn said he wanted Ridley more involved, and OC Steve Sarkisian made it happen.  His five targets were three more than Mohamed Sanu for second on the team behind Jones (nine).  Ridley is worth watching on the waiver and perhaps nabbing in 12- and 14-team leagues as a WR4/5 ahead of Week 3 against New Orleans.
report: Calvin Ridley caught 4-of-5 targets for 64 yards and one touchdown in the Falcons' Week 2 win over the Panthers.

impact: This won’t happen every week, but on Sunday, Ridley was the better of Atlanta’s two Alabama receivers. Ridley went absolutely hog-wild in the first half, cruising to 129 yards and two touchdowns including a 75-yard jailbreak in the second quarter. The rookie embarrassed P.J. Williams to such an extent that he was actually benched for Ken Crawley for a portion of the second half. In addition to his three touchdowns (the same number teammate Julio Jones had all of last season), Ridley also drew a pass interference flag that moved the Falcons up 45 yards in the third quarter. After seeing just two looks from Matt Ryan in the opener, the 23-year-old has been the recipient of 13 targets over his last two outings. He’ll be an acceptable WR3/flex option against the Bengals next week and needs to be picked up in all formats.
report: Calvin Ridley corralled seven-of-eight targets for 146 yards and three touchdowns while gaining nine yards on his lone carry Sunday in the Falcons’ Week 3 loss to the Saints.

impact: Ridley disappointingly saw just six targets, but he made the most of his work. His first touchdown was a good slant route to give Matt Ryan a throwing window, and he cooked Dre Kirkpatrick on a double move for a 30-yard score in the fourth quarter. The two scores made him the first rookie receiver in NFL history to have six touchdowns in his first four games. Ridley seeing three fewer targets than Mohamed Sanu is a bit of a concern, but he is a highly-talented receiver getting consistent work in a red-hot passing attack. He will be an upside WR3 in a great matchup against the Steelers next week.
report: Calvin Ridley hauled in 4-of-6 targets for 54 yards and two touchdowns in the Falcons' Week 4 loss to the Bengals.

impact: Ridley did fantasy players proud by finding the end zone twice, but his snap share took a step back from Week 3. He also saw three fewer targets than Mohamed Sanu. Ridley is still worth using this week in a prime matchup against the Steelers, but his floor does not look particularly sturdy.
report: Calvin Ridley played 38-of-70 snaps (54 percent) Week 4 against the Bengals.

impact: It was Ridley's first game without a score since Week 1. Ridley, who leads the Falcons in red zone looks, did draw a target from the Steelers' 21-yard line. Ridley will remain a solid WR3 for next week's matchup with the Bucs' awful defense.
report: Calvin Ridley caught 4-of-5 targets for 38 yards in the Falcons' Week 5 loss to the Steelers.

impact: Ridley was shown on the sidelines trying to walk off the injury, so it is possible he is able to return. He is officially questionable. Ridley was on his way to a good game before leaving, catching three passes for 47 yards in the opening quarter.
report: Calvin Ridley exited Week 6 against the Bucs with an ankle injury.

impact: Ridley tried to work out his ankle on the sideline after suffering the injury in the first half, but he was ruled out after the break. He finishes with three catches for 47 yards. Justin Hardy has been playing in his place in three-wide sets.
report: Calvin Ridley (ankle) has been ruled out for Week 6 against the Bucs.

impact: Coach Dan Quinn is "hopeful" Ridley will be ready for Week 7. Per McClure, Ridley's MRI "came back pretty clean." It sounds like there's a real chance Ridley could suit up against the G-Men, though the Falcons are headed on bye in Week 8. Teams often opt for caution and maximum rest in that situation. Ridley's status will be updated no later than Thursday when the Falcons return to practice.
report: ESPN Falcons reporter Vaughn McClure reports Calvin Ridley (ankle) has been diagnosed with a bone bruise.

impact: Ridley suffered what is believed to be a bone bruise in his ankle last week against the Bucs. "The good news is, we're anticipating him even getting a little bit of work today," Quinn said in an interview on 92.9 The Game. "As we go through the week, we'll have a better assessment. But as we're heading into it, he's one tough dude." Mohamed Sanu (hip) is also expected to practice Thursday.
report: Falcons coach Dan Quinn expects Calvin Ridley (ankle) to practice Thursday.

impact: As was Mohamed Sanu (hip). It's not a good start for Ridley ahead of Monday's game against the Giants, as coach Dan Quinn had expected him to suit up on Thursday. Ridley is dealing with a bone bruise. It's still quite possible he gets in limited sessions on Friday, Saturday or both and gets the go-ahead. If Ridley plays, he will be a boom/bust WR3.
report: Calvin Ridley (ankle) was held out of Thursday's practice.

impact: This would seem to put Ridley on track for Monday night's game against the Giants. With Mohamed Sanu (hip) still absent from practice, Ridley could be in for a bigger workload this week. The first-round rookie is tied for the NFL lead with six touchdown receptions.
report: Calvin Ridley (ankle) returned to a limited practice on Friday.

impact: It's unknown if Ridley, who was limited on Friday, was a full participant on Saturday. Either way, it's tremendous progress and puts him on pace to play Monday night against the Giants. Teammate Mohamed Sanu (hip) was also seen running routes and participating in drills. Coach Dan Quinn will have a status update on both following the team's practice.
report: Calvin Ridley (ankle) participated in his second consecutive practice on Saturday.

impact: The Falcons also removed Mohamed Sanu (hip) from the injury report. Both wideouts were limited in Saturday's practice. It's a best case scenario with Atlanta playing on Monday night. We like Ridley at an upside FLEX against the Giants.
report: Calvin Ridley (ankle) wasn't listed on the Week 7 injury report.

impact: Both players looked good in pregame warmups and are ready to roll after not being listed on the final injury report.  Inactive for the Falcons are K Matt Bryant, RB Brian Hill, CB Blidi Wreh-Wilson, DE Steven Means, OG Zac Kerin, OT Matt Gono, and DT Michael Bennett.  Ridley is a fine WR2/3.
report: Calvin Ridley (ankle) and Mohamed Sanu (hip) are both active for Week 7 against the Giants on Monday night.

impact: Ridley's ankle didn't seem to be a problem at all.  His six targets were second-most on the team to Julio Jones' 12, but Ridley was unable to do anything big with them.  Ridley will get the bye week to get back to 100 percent ahead of a Week 9 road date with the Redskins where he'll again be a WR2/3.
report: Calvin Ridley caught 5-of-6 targets for 43 yards in the Falcons' Week 7 win over the Giants.

impact: He added five carries for 19 yards on the ground. Prescott didn't turn the ball over, but he also didn't throw a single touchdown. It's the seventh time in his last nine games that Prescott has failed to eclipse the 200-yard mark. Although Dak shoulders the blame as quarterback, rookie LG Connor Williams was as advertised (and not in a good way) in pass-protection and OC Scott Linehan could not have taken a more vanilla approach to Sunday's gameplan. It's early, but Prescott's ceiling may be lower than initially thought if slot receiver Cole Beasley continues being his clear-cut target in the flats.
report: Dak Prescott completed 19-of-29 passes for 170 yards in the Cowboys' Week 1 loss to the Panthers.

impact: Prescott was listed with an ankle injury, which he must have picked up in last week's loss to Carolina. Regardless, he should be ready to roll against the Giants on Sunday Night Football. With the offensive line struggling and limited weapons in the Cowboys' receiving corps, Prescott can't be trusted as anything more than a back-end QB2 in fantasy.
report: Dak Prescott (ankle) is practicing in full for Week 2 against the Giants.

impact: Prescott wasn't asked to do much with the Cowboys defense shutting down the Giants. His touchdown was a 64-yard catch and run by Tavon Austin on the third play of the night. Prescott managed the game after that, but he added 45 yards on seven rushes. Through two weeks, Prescott has looked like the quarterback he was in the second half of last year. He gets a matchup with Seattle in Week 3.
report: Dak Prescott completed 16-of-25 passes for 160 yards and a touchdown in Week 2 against the Giants.

impact: Dak took five sacks for a loss of 31 yards. Plagued by a patchwork receiving corps and a declining offensive line, Prescott limped to just 40 yards on 6-of-13 passing in the first half. He was only marginally better after the break and spent much of his day trying to escape Frank Clark, who dominated up front for Seattle. Prescott’s lone touchdown "pass" came on a shovel throw to Tavon Austin with 7:11 left in the fourth quarter. Any chance of a late comeback ended when Earl Thomas pulled in his second interception of the day on a pass intended for Blake Jarwin. Perhaps Prescott will fare better against an attackable Lions defense at home next week, but with the Cowboys’ offense struggling in all facets, Dak will be little more than a back-end QB2 in fantasy.
report: Dak Prescott completed 19-of-34 passes for 168 yards with a touchdown and two interceptions while adding 21 yards on two carries Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 3 loss to Seattle.

impact: Prescott lost 24 yards on three sacks in the victory. Sunday marked Dak's first 200-yard passing game since Week 15 of last season. He spread the wealth, targeting eight different receivers including Ezekiel Elliott, who led the way with 88 yards and a touchdown on four catches. Prescott's first touchdown of the afternoon came on a screen to Zeke, who took it 38 yards to the house late in the second quarter. Dak later found tight end Geoff Swaim for a one-yard touchdown off a play-action pass, which stretched the Cowboys lead to 10 with under three minutes to go in the third quarter. That lead would evaporate but Dak kept his poise down the stretch, leading a late-scoring drive keyed by a 34-yard completion to Elliott down the right sideline. This was easily Prescott's best outing of 2018, which admittedly wasn't a high bar to clear after struggling mightily in his first three games. We'll see if he can build off this performance next week at Houston.
report: Dak Prescott completed 17-of-27 passes for 255 yards and two touchdowns while adding two yards on three carries Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 4 victory over the Lions.

impact: Prescott’s struggles resurfaced coming off his best game in Week 5. Both of his interceptions were on dropped passes, but Prescott was off the mark on the throws.  Prescott somewhat salvaged his night with 36 yards rushing. He doesn't have much of a supporting cast, but it's clear Prescott has regressed from last year. Prescott will be a back-end QB2 for a tough Week 6 matchup with Jacksonville.
report: Dak Prescott completed 18-of-29 passes for 208 yards with a touchdown and two interceptions in the Cowboys' Week 5 loss to the Texans.

impact: He lost 11 yards on three sacks in the victory. Going against arguably the league's toughest defense, Dak didn't blink, making Jacksonville pay for ignoring slot receiver Cole Beasley (nine catches for 101 yards and two touchdowns). Prescott also had a good day running the football, breaking out for a career-high 82 yards with a long gain of 28 yards. He probably would have had a bigger day had the score been closer but with Dallas winning big, Prescott only attempted nine passes after halftime. Next the Cowboys head to Washington for a division showdown against the Redskins in Week 7.
report: Dak Prescott completed 17-of-27 passes for 183 yards and two touchdowns while adding 82 yards and another touchdown on 11 rushes Sunday in the Cowboys’ Week 6 victory over Jacksonville.

impact: Prescott ate a shoulder pad directly to his helmet while sliding near the sideline early in the first half, which forced Dallas' training staff to bring out the blue medical tent. He was cleared soon after with what was comically declared as a 'hand' injury. Prescott did encouragingly keep to his running ways, though, recording six carries for the third consecutive game. He's now averaged 7.6 rushes, 49.6 rushing yards, and 0.6 rushing touchdowns in the last three games for Dallas. Prescott will return from the Cowboys' Week 8 bye as a sneaky streaming QB2 versus the Titans.
report: Dak Prescott completed 22-of-35 passes for 273 yards and one touchdown, chipping in another 33 yards and one score on the ground in the Cowboys' Week 7 loss to the Redskins.

impact: We'll have to see what happens, but it looks like Kearse is going to give it a go at Thursday's practice. It was reported earlier this week that Kearse would miss Week 1, so we'd still consider him a long shot for Monday night's opener in Detroit. Assuming that's the case, Robby Anderson, Terrelle Pryor and Quincy Enunwa will function as the Jets' main receivers.
report: Jermaine Kearse (abdomen) was dressed and wearing a helmet at the start of Thursday's practice.

impact: Pre-practice reports had Kearse sporting a helmet, but he didn't do enough to earn a "limited" tag. Kearse is the kind of player who could get in one limited session on Friday or Saturday and be declared ready to go for Monday's game against the Lions, but right now, he is looking likely to sit.
report: Jermaine Kearse (abdomen) was officially "DNP" in Thursday's practice.

impact: It's the first time he's practiced all week. The Jets open in Detroit on Monday night, so his injury designation won't be known until Saturday. Most reports suggest he won't play, though Kearse could end up a game-time decision. Regardless, he's not someone fantasy owners should be relying on.
report: Jermaine Kearse (abdomen) returned to a limited practice on Friday.

impact: This isn't a surprise despite Kearse getting in limited practice this week. The Jets will go with Robby Anderson, Quincy Enunwa, and Terrelle Pryor as their starting wideouts. Kearse looks on track for a Week 2 return.
report: Jermaine Kearse (abdomen) is doubtful for Monday night's Week 1 game against the Lions.

impact: As expected. Kearse got in limited practice throughout the week but was listed as doubtful over the weekend. The Jets will start Robby Anderson and Terrelle Pryor on the outside with Quincy Enunwa being featured as a hybrid slot/tight end receiver over the middle.
report: Jets declared WR Jermaine Kearse, OL Ben Braden, G Dakota Dozier, DL Foley Fatukasi, CB Derrick Jones, S Marcus Maye, and OLB Josh Martin inactive for Week 1 against the Lions.

impact: It puts Kearse on track to play after sitting out the opener. His return further muddles Sam Darnold's target distribution after spreading it out in Week 1. Kearse's presence should demote Terrelle Pryor to four-wide sets.
report: Jermaine Kearse (abdomen) is practicing in full for Week 2.

impact: Kearse's return figures to cut into Terrelle Pryor's playing time after Pryor operated as Gang Green's No. 3 receiver last week.  Quincy Enunwa and Robby Anderson are locked in as the Nos. 1 and 2.  The Jets' Week 2 inactives are CB Derrick Jones, FS Marcus Maye, CB Juston Burris, OG Dakota Dozier, OLB Josh Martin, TE Jordan Leggett, and DL Folo Fatukasi.
report: Jermaine Kearse is active for Week 2 against the Dolphins.

impact: Kearse worked as the Jets' No. 4 receiver behind Quincy Enunwa, Robby Anderson, and Terrelle Pryor.  He only saw two targets and lacks fantasy value.
report: Jermaine Kearse netted -1 yard in the Jets' Week 2 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: This will be about Kearse's ceiling for as long as the Jets are holding Sam Darnold's hand on offense.
report: Jermaine Kearse caught 3-of-6 targets for 35 yards in the Jets' Week 3 loss to the Browns.

impact: Kearse didn't make his first catch until deep in the third quarter. He's a non-factor in a Jets offense that can't support more than one wideout.
report: Jermaine Kearse caught 2-of-5 passes for 23 yards in Week 4 against the Jagaurs.

impact: Kearse would likely need Quincy Enunwa to miss time to become a fantasy factor.
report: Jermaine Kearse caught 1-of-4 targets for 14 yards in the Jets' Week 5 win.

impact: Kearse's stock was pointing up after taking over as Gang Green's slot receiver in Week 5, and he made good on increased playing time following Quincy Enunwa's second-quarter ankle injury.  Enunwa did not return, and Kearse went to work on the interior of Indianapolis' defense with crisp routes and chunk gains on slants.  There are indications Enunwa's injury could be severe.  Kearse will be worth grabbing in 12- and 14-team PPR leagues this week.
report: Jermaine Kearse caught 9-of-10 targets for 94 yards in the Jets' Week 6 win over the Colts.

impact: Sam Darnold was horrendous in this one, throwing three interceptions, and completing just 40.5% of his passes, doing a lot of work on the final meaningless possession with dump-offs to Trenton Cannon out of the backfield.  Kearse was a hot name in fantasy this week after he caught 9-of-10 targets for 94 yards against the Colts last week.  He was expected to play a major role with Quincy Enunwa (ankle) and Terrelle Pryor (groin) both out.  He wasn't targeted in the second half and had no chance on his two first-half ones.  Kearse will be tough to get behind next week on the road in Chicago.
report: Jermaine Kearse failed to catch either of his two targets in the Jets' 37-17, Week 7 loss to the Vikings.

impact: It's a disappointing game after Burton's strong preseason. Burton saw the second most targets behind Allen Robinson but didn't look on the same page with Mitchell Trubisky. Chicago should do a better job of getting him involved moving forward. Burton is a back-end TE1 for Week 2 against Seattle.
report: Trey Burton caught 1-of-6 targets for 16 yards in Week 1 against the Packers.

impact: He caught his first target for a three-yard score on a shovel pass to kick off the scoring in this one.  Other than that, it was another quiet night for Burton, who has 36 yards and the score on 10 targets through two games.  Allen Robinson has 21 targets in that span as the Bears' clear No. 1 pass-game option.  Burton will remain a TE1 next week in Arizona only because of positional weakness.  The good news is the Cardinals have surrendered a TD to a TE each of the first two games.
report: Trey Burton caught all four of his targets for 20 yards and one touchdown in the Bears' Week 2 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Burton had caught just five passes for 35 yards through two weeks, so this could be considered an explosion by the marks he set through the first two weeks. Through three weeks, Burton has just nine catches for 90 yards and a touchdown as Mitchell Trubisky has struggled to generate little tangible production for the pass catchers in this offense. Despite his down production, Burton will still be in the TE1 mix at a dreadful fantasy position Week 4 when the Bears host the Buccaneers.
report: Trey Burton caught 4-of-5 passes for 55 yards in Sunday's Week 3 win over the Cardinals.

impact: After plodding through subpar performances during Chicago's first three games, Burton went as Mitchell Trubisky went, corralling one of the second-year pro's career-high six touchdowns on the day. To this point, Burton had merely posted a season-high of 55 yards and had yet to get into the end zone. Burton's lone touchdown on the day admittedly occurred during a complete breakdown in the Bucs' hapless secondary. It won't always be this easy for the Bears' offense, but it was good to see Burton finally get off the schneid and flash the rapport he showed with Trubisky in the preseason. He'll remain a low-end TE1 moving forward given the position's dreadful drop-off from years past.
report: Trey Burton hauled in 2-of-4 passes for 86 yards and one score in Sunday's Week 4 win over the Bucs.

impact: It was a quiet afternoon for Burton, though he salvaged the day somewhat by turning a Mitchell Trubisky shovel pass into a nine-yard touchdown during the third quarter. Burton has now scored in three of his last four games while catching 14-of-17 targets (82.4 percent) during that span. The 26-year-old will remain a borderline TE1 when he faces the Patriots in Week 7. Burton was involved in one of the most iconic plays in NFL history—the Philly Special—the last time he squared off against New England in Super Bowl LII.
report: Trey Burton handled all four of his targets for 23 yards and a touchdown Sunday in Chicago’s Week 6 loss to Miami.

impact: Burton was the only player Mitchell Trubisky could trust early in this game. He was the target on four of the quarterback’s eight first-half completions including a fourth-down conversion on a second-quarter touchdown drive. He kept it going after the break, catching five more passes for another 70 yards and a late touchdown. Although he has scored in four of the last five games, this was easily Burton’s best outing of the season, and he did it with Tarik Cohen the only other player making plays in the passing game. He will remain a back-end TE1 next week against the Jets.
report: Trey Burton hauled in 9-of-11 targets for 126 yards and a touchdown in the Bears' Week 7 loss to the Patriots.

impact: He was the third receiver behind Allen Robinson and Taylor Gabriel. Miller didn't have any notable plays, but his role should rise as the season progresses. Miller is just a dynastry stash until he passes Gabriel on the depth chart.
report: Anthony Miller caught 2-of-3 passes for 14 yards in Week 1 against the Packers.

impact: Miller's touchdown came from 10 yards out on a fine play by Mitchell Trubisky to throw with his right while running left.  Still, Miller is deep down the totem pole for targets in what is currently an ugly passing offense.  He has five grabs for 25 yards and the score through two games.  Leave him on the wire.
report: Anthony Miller caught 2-of-3 targets for 11 yards and one touchdown in the Bears' Week 2 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Miller appeared to suffer a hand or arm injury late in the game and didn't return, but the Bears were quiet on in-game news. Through three weeks, Miller has caught 8-of-11 targets for 60 yards and a touchdown.
report: Anthony Miller caught 4-of-5 targets for 35 yards in Sunday's Week 3 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Miller played through the injury against the Cardinals before being forced to the sideline in the third quarter. Miller missed a season in college with a right shoulder injury. Miller is a promising prospect in the slot but production has been hard to come by with Mitchell Trubisky at quarterback.
report: Bears WR Anthony Miller is "day to day" with a dislocated left shoulder.

impact: Miller is still feeling the effects of a dislocated shoulder suffered in Sunday's win at Arizona. With Mitchell Trubisky as his quarterback, Miller faces an uphill climb in his quest for fantasy relevance.
report: Anthony Miller (shoulder) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: That is great news, but Miller did not practice Wednesday and does not seem particularly likely to play this week after suffering a dislocated shoulder on Sunday. Behind Taylor Gabriel in the pecking order even when healthy, Miller is a weak bench stash in redraft leagues at this point.
report: Bears coach Matt Nagy said he does not expect Anthony Miller (shoulder) to need surgery.

impact: The Bears consider him week-to-week, though Miller's dislocated shoulder will not require surgery. Kevin White and Josh Bellamy will see more run in his absence.
report: Anthony Miller (shoulder) is out for Week 4 against the Buccaneers.

impact: Miller is considered week-to-week with a dislocated shoulder. Preseason standout and jump-ball specialist WR Javon Wims is active in Miller's stead for the first time all season. Coach Matt Nagy noted that Josh Bellamy would still start at slot receiver, with Allen Robinson mixing in throughout. S DeAndre Houston-Carson will also make his regular season debut. Although the Bears will take the field thin at corner, their daunting pass rush should be enough to force Ryan Fitzpatrick into costly turnovers.
report: Bears declared WR Anthony Miller, CB Prince Amukamara, CB Marcus Cooper, LB Isaiah Irving, LB Kylie Fitts, OL Rashaad Coward, and DT Nick Williams inactive for Week 4 against the Bucs.

impact: Miller is back after sitting out Week 4 with a dislocated shoulder. Because of Chicago's early bye, the injury only cost him one game. It will be interesting to see how the Bears use Miller following Taylor Gabriel's two-touchdown breakout in Week 4.
report: Anthony Miller (shoulder) is practicing in full for Week 6 against the Dolphins.

impact: Miller was out prior to the Bears' bye but practiced in full on both Thursday and Friday. Coach Matt Nagy said he'll play. Expect Josh Bellamy to return to the sideline, with Allen Robinson and Taylor Gabriel running a majority of their routes from the outside. Miller's a fringe WR4 in his first game back.
report: Anthony Miller (shoulder) will play in Week 6 against the Dolphins.

impact: Miller only missed one game with his dislocated shoulder. CB Prince Amukamara (hamstring) is also good to go. FB Michael Burton, CB Marcus Cooper, OT Rashaad Coward, OLB Kylie Fitts, DT Nick Williams, WR Javon Wims and OT Bryan Witzmann round out the Bears' inactives for Week 6.
report: Anthony Miller (shoulder) is active for Week 6 against the Dolphins.

impact: This was the rookie's first game back from a dislocated shoulder. Miller's day, at least for fantasy purposes, would have been a lot different had he pulled in a Mitchell Trubisky deep bomb in the first quarter. He was wide open but Trubisky badly overthrew him. Miller did visit the end zone later on, snagging a 29-yard touchdown grab to put Chicago back ahead (at least briefly) in the fourth quarter. The second-round pick has scored in two of his past three outings, though he's averaged just 25 receiving yards per game during that span. Miller will remain off the fantasy radar next week against New England.
report: Anthony Miller secured one-of-four targets for 29 yards and a touchdown Sunday in the Bears’ Week 6 loss to Miami.

impact: Miller earned an end-zone target in the first half, but he failed to haul it in. He came back with an important third-down conversion late in the third quarter and added a catch on the final drive, but that was it despite seven targets, although Mitchell Trubisky's play certainly did not help. Miller is just a bench stash at this point.
report: Anthony Miller hauled in 2-of-7 targets for 35 yards in the Bears' Week 7 loss to the Patriots.

impact: White had not caught a pass coming into this game, but he got a bit more run with Allen Robinson hobbled by a groin injury. That playing time almost led to a spectacular moment when White came down with the potential game-tying Hail Mary on the final play of the game, but he made the catch just short of the goal line and was pushed back by a group of defenders. Despite the big play and Robinson's injury, White is not a fantasy option.
report: Kevin White hauled in both of his targets for 64 yards in the Bears' Week 7 loss to the Patriots.

impact: Filling in for Brandin Cooks and Cooper Kupp, who both left the game with concussions, Reynolds came out hot following halftime. He had a 22-yard catch on the second offensive play of the half, a 17-yard grab the next play, and he rushed for 10 yards the play after that. He did not touch the ball again the rest of the game, but Reynolds is a talented young receiver who might be forced into playing time with Cooks and Kupp questionable. He should be added in most formats.
report: Josh Reynolds hauled in 2-of-3 targets for 39 yards and rushed once for 10 yards in the Rams' Week 5 win over the Seahawks.

impact: The story of Reynolds' Week 6 was Cooper Kupp's knee injury. It appeared Kupp's season was over before he miraculously returned for the second half (and barely played). Provided Kupp continues to get good news, Reynolds will remain on the outside looking in of fantasy value for Week 7 against the 49ers.
report: Josh Reynolds caught 1-of-2 targets for -2 yards in the Rams' Week 6 win over the Broncos.

impact: Reynolds isn't a player we blurb about often but he's someone to monitor this week with Cooper Kupp sidelined by a knee injury. The limited tag suggests Reynolds will be active against the Niners in Week 7. The 23-year-old could be an interesting dart throw in DFS if he gets the green light.
report: Josh Reynolds (hand) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Reynolds will be running as the Rams' No. 3 receiver for however long Cooper Kupp (knee) is sidelined. He could see a decent amount of Richard Sherman in Week 7 but is an intriguing, bottom-dollar dart throw in DFS.
report: Rams WR Josh Reynolds (hand) was upgraded to "full" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Even with Cooper Kupp sidelined, Reynolds did not see a big boost. He did set up a touchdown with a 19-yard catch down to the one-yard line in the third quarter, but that was his only involvement. Even with uncertainty about Kupp’s availability, Reynolds can be sent back to the wire.
report: Josh Reynolds caught his only target for 19 yards in the Rams' Week 7 win over the 49ers.

impact: Robinson led the team in receiving and targets. Week 1 confirmed he's Chicago's clear No. 1 option, but his upside is limited in a Mitchell Trubisky offense. The main takeway is Robinson is fully healthy and primed for a bounce back year. He'll match up with Shaquill Griffin next Monday night.
report: Allen Robinson caught 4-of-7 targets for 61 yards in Chicago's Week 1 loss to the Packers.

impact: Robinson has now led the Bears in receiving and targets in both games to open the season, averaging 10.5 targets per in that span.  The yards haven't been great (61 in Week 1), and Robinson has yet to find the end zone.  However, it's pretty obvious Robinson is Mitchell Trubisky's No. 1 option.  Robinson will have a tough battle with Patrick Peterson on the road in Week 3.
report: Allen Robinson caught 10-of-14 targets for 83 yards in the Bears' 24-17, Week 2 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Calling them targets is being generous as the bulk of his opportunity came from uncatchable passes and 50/50 jump balls. His lone highlight was a 39-yard connection where Robinson beat the defender at the line of scrimmage and Mitchell Trubisky put on the money. Robinson is dominating passing-game opportunity with the Bears, receiving 28 targets through three games, but has turned all of those targets into a modest 194 yards through three games with no scores. Things get much better in Week 4, however, as the Bears host a porous Tampa Bay secondary on a short week.
report: Allen Robinson caught 3-of-7 targets for 50 yards in Sunday's Week 3 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Robinson's 20 yards and ensuing touchdown wouldn't ordinarily be a letdown, but it came on a day in which Mitchell Trubisky threw for career-highs in yards (354) and touchdowns (6). Normally the recipient during the majority of his drop backs, Trubisky instead fed backup RB Tarik Cohen (7-121-1), Taylor Gabriel (7-104-2), and Trey Burton (2-86-1) rather than A-Rob. Robinson should still be the primary beneficiary moving forward now that the Bears' offense appears to be clicking on all cylinders. Unless he's shadowed by premier CB Xavien Howard after the bye, Robinson will stay a low-end WR2 against the Dolphins.
report: Allen Robinson caught 2-of-4 targets for 23 yards and one touchdown in the Bears' Week 4 victory over the Buccaneers.

impact: Robinson found himself on the receiving end of a 12-yard touchdown strike from Mitchell Trubisky in the third quarter, which came immediately following Kyle Fuller's interception of Brock Osweiler. That marked his second touchdown in as many games. Robinson's other contributions included a nice back-shoulder catch for a 21-yard gain in the fourth quarter and drawing a pass interference flag that eventually led to a Bears touchdown. A-Rob gets a date with New England in Week 7.
report: Allen Robinson pulled in five catches for 64 yards and a touchdown on six targets Sunday in Chicago’s Week 6 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: Robinson looked fine in last week's loss to Miami, delivering five catches for 64 yards and a touchdown. We're guessing the Bears are just rationing his practice reps. Assuming he suits up, A-Rob will find himself on the WR2/3 borderline for Sunday's home game against New England.
report: Allen Robinson (groin) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Robinson had been "limited" on Wednesday. The Chicago Tribune considers Robinson's status for Sunday's game against the Patriots "unknown." Robinson's absence would thrust Taylor Gabriel into a potential WR2 role while also creating more target opportunities for Trey Burton, Tarik Cohen and Anthony Miller.
report: Allen Robinson (groin) was downgraded to "DNP" on Thursday.

impact: Robinson returned to practice on Friday, which puts him on track to suit up Sunday against New England. It's an attackable matchup for A-Rob, though he might not be at full strength. If that's the case and Robinson ends up being more of a decoy, it would open up work for Taylor Gabriel and Anthony Miller.
report: Allen Robinson (groin) is questionable for Week 7 against the Patriots.

impact: Robinson practiced Friday and was considered on track to play. He'll continue to start in 3-WR sets with Taylor Gabriel and slot wideout Anthony Miller. Robinson arguably has the toughest matchup (albeit a winnable one) among Chicago's wideouts as he'll likely draw shadow coverage from Stephen Gilmore. He remains a risky WR2 considering he tweaked his groin only four days ago.
report: Allen Robinson (groin) is expected to play against the Patriots in Week 7.

impact: This was the expectation after Robinson got in a limited practice on Friday. He might not be 100 percent, but he is in a good spot in a game in which the Bears could be playing from behind. He remains a back-end WR2 despite the injury concern.
report: Allen Robinson (groin) is active for Week 7 against the Patriots.

impact: Robinson did not have anything to show for his early opportunities in this one. He was unable to get loose on a deep target on the opening drive, and he dropped what would have been a third-down conversion on the second series.
