impact: Booker operated as the third-down back early in the game and saw passing-down work all day, but he appeared to fall down the depth chart in this one. Following a 29-yard touchdown catch in the first quarter, Phillip Lindsay worked as the No. 2 running back and even matched Royce Freeman in rushing attempts and yards. Looking like the third option in a committee backfield, Booker does not need to be rostered in standard-sized redraft leagues.
report: Devontae Booker rushed twice for four yards and hauled in both his targets for 11 yards in the Broncos' Week 1 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Denver's No. 3 back, Booker took on a bigger role in the second half after Phillip Lindsay was ejected just before halftime. He did not do much with it, and he should fall back behind Lindsay in the pecking order next week.
report: Devontae Booker hauled in 5-of-7 targets for 34 yards and rushed five times for 10 yards in the Broncos' Week 3 loss to the Ravens.

impact: He remains the third wheel in Denver's backfield, but still an active one.  And Booker's activity spiked a bit this week because the Broncos got destroyed by the Jets and played passing-game specialist Booker more than usual.  Booker would still need a Phillip Lindsay or Royce Freeman injury to become a legit flex option, but he is worth stashing in 14- and 16-team PPR leagues.
report: Devontae Booker caught 5-of-6 targets for 59 yards in the Broncos' Week 5 loss to the Jets.

impact: It means Jackson will be active Sunday. We wouldn't expect Jackson to have much of a role, but the Ravens could use him in some run-based sub packages. Jackson ran for 136 yards in five games this preseason.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports the Ravens have packages for Lamar Jackson in their Week 1 gameplan.

impact: The Rams' offense understandably sputtered out the gates after having sat the entire preseason. Goff still found a way to produce in the first half, recording a 19-yard touchdown to Todd Gurley on a shovel pass. His second score was a beautifully designed play inside the 10-yard line that resulted in a Cooper Kupp score in the flats. Goff wasn't needed in the fourth quarter as Los Angeles simply played defense and fed the ball to Gurley to ice the game. It was still a promising outing for the 23-year-old, who will see better game scripts in the coming weeks.
report: Jared Goff completed 18-of-33 passes for 233 yards and two touchdowns in the Rams' Week 1 win over the Raiders.

impact: The only thing not to like about Goff’s performance was he only threw one touchdown. He probably should have had two more, but he underthrew Brandin Cooks, who had to come back to the ball and the defender, and missed a wide-open Robert Woods in the end zone. Neither play ultimately mattered in a game the Rams won going away. Goff might need to be sharper next week against the Chargers, though.
report: Jared Goff completed 24-of-32 passes for 354 yards, a touchdown, and an interception in the Rams' Week 2 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Goff has back-to-back games with 354 passing yards, but his three touchdowns are the most since Week 15 of 2017. Robert Woods was Goff's primary target today as the two connected for two touchdowns, but Brandin Cooks came just one foot short of his first touchdown too. Sean McVay has this offense cooking right now -- they have scored at least 33 points in all three games -- but they have a test with the Vikings coming up on Thursday Night Football.
report: Jared Goff completed 29-of-36 passes for 354 yards, three touchdowns, and an interception in the Rams' Week 3 win over the Chargers.

impact: He was sacked once for a loss of nine yards. Goff was an absolute mad man in the first half, slinging four touchdowns on 13-of-17 passing before the break. Two of those scores went to Cooper Kupp, who had a career night with nine catches for 162 yards. Goff had his deep ball working against the Vikes, including late in the first half when he connected on a 47-yard touchdown to Brandin Cooks. Goff’s five touchdowns tied a franchise record. He also set a career-high in passing yards while becoming the first Ram to go over 400 yards since Marc Bulger in 2005. Goff recorded a perfect 158.3 quarterback rating in the victory. Unstoppable isn’t a word we throw around too often at Rotoworld, but that’s how the Rams offense has looked this year. Goff and the Rams will take a 4-0 record into next week’s matchup against the Seahawks.
report: Jared Goff completed 26-of-33 passes for 465 yards and five touchdowns while adding seven yards on two carries Thursday in the Rams’ Week 4 win over the Vikings.

impact: It was not pretty, but Goff helped lead the Rams to a 5-0 start with three scoring drives in the second half and some timely plays, most notably a fourth-down conversion on a sneak to ice the game late in the fourth quarter. Goff's first interception was a forced throw which was tipped into the air at the goal line, but the second came on a Hail Mary at the end of the first half. That said, he probably deserved at least two interceptions and got lucky on several throws. Goff could have had another score, but Todd Gurley was ruled down at the one on a jet shovel pass in the second quarter. Goff has now thrown for at least 320 yards in four straight games. He will be a back-end QB1 next week in Denver.
report: Jared Goff completed 23-of-32 passes for 321 yards, a touchdown, and two interceptions in the Rams' Week 5 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Goff had his first scoreless start of the season as the Rams gutted the Broncos on the ground. He now has just one touchdown and three picks over his past two starts, both Rams victories. Today's giveaway came on a twice-tipped pass. There has been little overt reason for alarm. It just seems to be the normal ebbs and flows of a fantasy campaign. Goff nearly received some awful news this afternoon when Cooper Kupp appeared to shred his knee, but he miraculously returned after the break. Goff will remain a locked-in QB1 for Week 7 against the 49ers.
report: Jared Goff completed 14-of-28 passes for 201 yards, zero touchdowns and an interception in the Rams' 23-20, Week 6 win over the Broncos.

impact: With the 49ers turning it over for fun, Goff did not have to do much in this one. He still managed a respectable fantasy outing with two touchdowns. The first came on a great route by Brandin Cooks in the second quarter, and the second was on a screen pass to Todd Gurley in the fourth. After a hot run, Goff has now thrown for just 403 yards and two scores total in his last two games. He should fare better next week against the Packers.
report: Jared Goff completed 18-of-24 passes for 202 yards and two touchdowns in the Rams' Week 7 win over the 49ers.

impact: His performance might not be as surprising as Will Dissly leading the Seahawks in receiving, but Lindsay certainly was not expected to finish with the same number of carries and rushing yards as Royce Freeman in the season opener. That said, this is probably not a fluke. Lindsay earned his roster spot with a big training camp, and he saw plenty of snaps with the first-team offense in the third preseason game. While he might not get as many chances in the running game moving forward – it seemed to be something of a "hot hand" situation – he looks like the No. 2 ahead of Devontae Booker.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 15 times for 71 yards and hauled in 2-of-3 targets for 31 yards and a touchdown in the Broncos' Week 1 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Lindsay is fully expected to play. He appeared on Thursday's injury report with an ailing knee but practiced in full to end the week. Both he and rookie teammate Royce Freeman are in a tremendous spot against Oakland's lackluster front seven in Week 2.
report: Phillip Lindsay (knee) practiced Friday.

impact: Lindsay had 15 touches compared to eight for Royce Freeman and three for Devontae Booker as he was the first Denver running back to ever have over 100-yards from scrimmage in each of his first two career games in franchise history. Lindsay has built off a strong preseason to overtake a lead role in this Denver backfield, but still doesn't have a firm grasp on the goal line work, which will keep him as a RB2/FLEX option Week 3 when the Broncos head to Baltimore.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 14 times for 107 yards with one reception for four yards in Sunday's win over the Raiders.

impact: "Our deal with that room is more of game plan," Joseph said.  "It's what they do best.  It's more of who has the hot hand that day."  Rookie UDFA Phillip Lindsay (178 yards) is third in the league in rushing as we wind down Week 2, trailing only Matt Breida (184) and Joe Mixon (179).  Joseph is "not considering" starting Lindsay, but he said "it doesn't matter."  Lindsay has the "hot hand" at the moment and has had it since arriving at Broncos camp.  Lindsay has played nine more snaps than fellow rookie Royce Freeman and 13 more than Devontae Booker.
report: Coach Vance Joseph said the Broncos will continue using a "hot hand" approach in the backfield.

impact: Lindsay threw several "punches" during a scrum for a loose football at the end of the second quarter. They were more arm swings than punches, and none of them seemed to land. It was right under the nose of an official, however, and he ended up getting tossed. Lindsay had 20 yards on four carries before exiting. Royce Freeman and Devontae Booker should see more snaps with Lindsay in the locker room.
report: Phillip Lindsay was ejected from Week 3 against the Ravens for throwing a punch.

impact: After being ejected from last week's loss against the Ravens, Lindsay resumed his spot as the lead dog in this backfield.  He out-touched Royce Freeman 14-8 with Devontae Booker a distant third at two touches.  Both Lindsay and Freeman scored red-zone rushing touchdowns, with Lindsay's coming from one yard away.  Despite his 5'8/190 frame, Lindsay is a tough inside runner with great speed.  He could have read his blocks a bit better tonight, but Lindsay continues to produce when given the ball.  He'll be an RB2/3 next week at the Jets.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 12 times for 69 yards and one touchdown in the Broncos' Week 4 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: He out-touched Royce Freeman 15 to 8, while Devontae Booker was active only in the passing game with five catches.  Despite coachspeak the Broncos "want to involve Freeman more," Lindsay has earned and run away with Denver's lead-back job.  Lindsay will remain a quality RB2/flex option against the Rams in Week 6.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 12 times for 61 yards and caught 3-of-4 targets for 20 yards in the Broncos' Week 5 loss to the Jets.

impact: Lindsay appeared to have a 12-yard receiving score in the third quarter, but it got called back by a Courtland Sutton offensive pass interference penalty. For the first time in a full game, Lindsay got out-carried by Royce Freeman, though he still out-touched and out-gained his rookie teammate. Both players continued to lose passing-down snaps to Devontae Booker, a weekly unforced error from the Broncos' under siege coaching staff. It was encouraging to see Lindsay catch six passes, a number that doubled his previous best total. Lindsay will remain on the RB2/3 borderline for Denver's short-week TNF matchup with the Cardinals.
report: Phillip Lindsay caught 6-of-7 targets for 48 yards in the Broncos' Week 6 loss to the Rams, adding four carries for 18 additional yards.

impact: Lindsay added a six-yard reception. It felt like Lindsay was delivering chunk gains every time he touched the ball, so it was disappointing that he got the rock just 16 times in a 45-10 victory. Part of the problem was short drives, as five Cardinals turnovers kept setting the Broncos up with gorgeous field position. Seven of Lindsay's 14 carries gained at least five yards, while five gained at least nine. Lindsay also had a 24-yarder called back by holding. Running circles around Royce Freeman every week — although good in his own right most of the year, Freeman went just 13/37/1 this evening — Lindsay is well established as an RB2.
report: Phillip Lindsay rushed 14 times for 90 yards and a touchdown in the Broncos' Week 7 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Freeman found the end zone for a one-yard touchdown plunge on the opening drive of the second half, but hardly found any traction with the Broncos playing from behind all game. Freeman has now totaled 23 carries for 99 yards through two weeks with no receptions and has been out-touched by fellow rookie Phillip Lindsay 32-to-23 so far through two weeks. Freeman appears to be a touchdown-or-bust fantasy option moving forward and a fringe FLEX option Week 3 versus the Ravens.
report: Royce Freeman rushed eight times for 28 yards and a touchdown in Sunday's Week 2 win over the Raiders.

impact: It was fewer than both Phillip Lindsay (28) and Devontae Booker (22). Game script certainly played a role in Freeman's depressed usage, but he has now been out-touched by Lindsay 32-to-23 through two weeks. He should be downgraded to a FLEX option until his usage picks up.
report: Royce Freeman played 16-of-66 (24 percent) snaps Week 2 against the Raiders.

impact: He added a catch for five yards. Denver's special teams unit set up the offense at the six-yard line following a punt block early in the first quarter, and Freeman made good on the opportunity with a six-yard touchdown on his first carry. Despite the score, Freeman appeared on his way to another timeshare throughout the first half, but that changed when Phillip Lindsay was ejected late in the second quarter. Freeman responded with 37 yards on eight carries in the second half including several long gains. Unfortunately for Freeman, Lindsay should be back in the rotation next week, keeping him in the FLEX range despite a good matchup against the Chiefs.
report: Royce Freeman rushed 13 times for 53 yards and a touchdown in the Broncos' Week 3 loss to the Ravens.

impact: He wasn't targeted in the pass game.  Freeman was out-touched 14-8 by Phillip Lindsay, who gained 79 yards and also scored a one-yard touchdown.  Freeman's score was more impressive from 14 yards out as he looked to be bottled up for a loss before plowing through a couple defenders on his way to the end zone.  The Broncos were running the ball down the Chiefs' throat all night, but OC Bill Musgrave went away from the ground game late for some reason.  Freeman has scored in three-straight games and will be a TD-dependent RB2 next week at the Jets.
report: Royce Freeman rushed eight times for 67 yards and one touchdown in the Broncos' Week 4 loss to the Chiefs.

impact: "He needs more opportunities because he is playing good football," Joseph said. Freeman lit the Chiefs up for 67 yards on just eight carries, but he touched the ball just once in the fourth quarter of that game. His coach does not want that to happen again, but getting Freeman more work could mean taking some away from Phillip Lindsay, who has also been outstanding so far this season. With that kind of competition, Freeman is unlikely to escape a committee this year, but a few more touches would solidify his RB2 case.
report: Broncos coach Vance Joseph wants Royce Freeman to get "more touches."

impact: He now has single-digit touches in three of his last four games, disappointing after many fantasy owners blew fourth-round picks on Freeman.  Freeman quickly lost Denver's lead back job to Phillip Lindsay, who out-touched him 15 to 8 in Sunday's blowout loss.  Freeman will remain a touchdown-dependent flex option when the Broncos return home to host the high-flying Rams next.
report: Royce Freeman rushed five times for 31 yards and caught 3-of-4 targets for 16 yards in Denver's Week 5 loss to the Jets.

impact: Freeman was not targeted in the passing game. For the first time in a game in which Phillip Lindsay did not get ejected, Freeman out-carried him, though Lindsay still out-touched and out-gained his rookie teammate. As you can see from Freeman's stats, he did not do anything to make that the new balance of power going forward. Lindsay will still be the preferred fantasy play for Week 7 against the Cardinals.
report: Royce Freeman rushed nine times for 22 yards in the Broncos' Week 6 loss to the Rams.

impact: As Phillip Lindsay was running all over the Cardinals' pathetic run defense, Freeman had one of his quietest contests of the season. He's now been held below three yards per carry in back-to-back games, dropping his YPC from 5.10 to 4.35. Freeman has been solid as a rookie, Lindsay has simply been better. Freeman will be a touchdown-dependent FLEX for Week 8 against the Chiefs.
report: Royce Freeman rushed 13 times for 37 yards and a touchdown in the Broncos' Week 7 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Per Schefter, Freeman "could miss some time."  The Broncos have 10 days off ahead of a divisional game against the Chiefs.  We'll know more next week.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Royce Freeman suffered a sprained ankle in Thursday night's win over the Cardinals.

impact: He'll undergo an MRI. High-ankle sprains are considered more serious and often result in multi-week absences, though Matt Breida was able to play through a similar injury last week. Per Rapsheet, the Broncos have "some optimism" regarding Freeman's injury and believe he may not miss any time. The Broncos have nine days off before their next game against Kansas City.
report: According to NFL Network's Ian Rapoport, Royce Freeman's injury is a high-ankle sprain.

impact: This would suggest Freeman isn't dealing with a high-ankle spain. Freeman will have an MRI, but the Broncos are hoping this is something he can play through. There should be more clarity on Freeman's status next week.
report: Broncos coach Vance Joseph said Royce Freeman (ankle) is day to day.

impact: Freeman is reportedly battling a high-ankle sprain, even if the Broncos are calling him day to day.  We doubt he's able to play this week against the Chiefs, meaning Phillip Lindsay should be locked and loaded in fantasy lineups as an upside RB2.  Devontae Booker will likely also see increased work.
report: Royce Freeman (ankle) is not practicing Wednesday.

impact: Freeman has little chance of suiting up this this week after sustaining a high-ankle sprain in last week's win at Arizona. We imagine he'll be ruled out when the Broncos release their final injury report on Friday. Without him, the Broncos will turn to Phillip Lindsay against the Chiefs in Week 8. Freeman's likely absence would also open up work for change-of-pace back/pass-catcher Devontae Booker.
report: Royce Freeman (ankle) remained sidelined at Thursday's practice.

impact: Freeman has apparently shed his walking boot, though he did not practice either Wednesday or Thursday. He needs to get in at least a "limited" session on Friday to have any shot at suiting up.
report: ESPN's Jeff Legwold reports the Broncos remain "hopeful" Royce Freeman (ankle) suits up for Sunday's game against the Chiefs.

impact: This was the likely scenario once Freeman was spotted in a walking boot earlier in the week. It's slightly concerning that third-down back Devontae Booker could be unleashed on the road in an unfavorable rushing game script for the Broncos, but Phillip Lindsay's leading role on the ground and involvement in Denver's passing game still make him an easy high-end RB2 in season-long leagues. If Denver somehow manages to keep this one close, Lindsay is undoubtedly eyeing 15-20 touches.
report: Royce Freeman (ankle) is out for Week 8 against the Chiefs.

impact: His return could not come at a better time for a Patriots passing attack which was scuffling even before Rob Gronkowski went down with an ankle injury. Edelman should immediately settle in as Tom Brady's top target and will be a top-30 option against the Colts on Thursday night.
report: Julian Edelman's four-game suspension has ended.

impact: Bill Belichick gave a more muted "we'll see" when asked about Edelman's role for Thursday night, but Brady seems to expect the receiver to play a lot. "There’s a lot that he does well, and hopefully it’s a smooth transition," Brady said. "It’s going to be a big week of prep and then we’ll go out there and play Thursday night and see where we’re at." Especially with Rob Gronkowski questionable, Edelman's return comes at a great time. He will be a top-30 option against the Colts on Thursday.
report: Tom Brady said he has "no doubt" Julian Edelman will hit the ground running coming off his four-game suspension.

impact: Making his first appearance since the 2016 season — he was interrupted by an ACL tear then PED suspension — Edelman caught three passes for 28 yards on the Patriots' opening drive. He was quieter thereafter, but ESPN's Mike Reiss charted him as playing 50-of-71 snaps. Edelman could have had a bigger night but dropped what would have been a long completion on a first half third down. Edelman will be an upside WR2/3 for next week's likely shootout with the Chiefs.
report: Julian Edelman caught 7-of-9 targets for 57 yards in the Patriots' Week 5 win over the Colts.

impact: It was a similar game to last week for Edelman, who had 57 yards in his debut. He got behind Kendall Fuller for a 17-yard touchdown but was quiet after that. Even with the addition of Josh Gordon, Edelman has remained Tom Brady’s most trusted target. He’s a low-end WR2 for Week 7 against Chicago.
report: Julian Edelman caught 4-of-7 passes for 54 yards and a touchdown in Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: It's the first time Edelman has appeared on the injury report since returning from suspension. We didn't see Edelman get injured in Sunday night's Week 6 win over Kansas City. There should be more clarity on his status Thursday.
report: Julian Edelman (heel) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: The Patriots limited Edelman in practice all week. There's been nothing to suggest he's in danger of sitting, but we likely won't know his status until Sunday. Josh Gordon (hamstring) was also listed as questionable but is expected to play.
report: Julian Edelman (heel) is questionable for Week 7 against Chicago.

impact: Like most of New England's skill players, Edelman was listed as 'limited' throughout the week. There's been no indication he'll actually miss the Pats' matchup against the Bears Sunday. Josh Gordon (hamstring) was also listed as questionable but, like Edelman, is fully expected to play.
report: Julian Edelman (heel, questionable) is traveling with the Patriots to Chicago.

impact: Sony Michel (knee) and Josh Gordon (hamstring) will also be active for Week 7. With Rob Gronkowski (back, ankle) sidelined, Edelman should see a steady diet of targets from Tom Brady Sunday in the Windy City. He's No. 19 in RotoPat's Week 7 wide receiver rankings.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport confirms Julian Edelman (questionable, heel) is expected to play against the Bears in Week 7.

impact: As are Sony Michel (knee) and Josh Gordon (hamstring). Rob Gronkowski (back) is out, however, meaning Edelman could see more targets than usual. He is an upside WR2 this week.
report: Julian Edelman (heel) is active Week 7 against the Bears.

impact: Edelman earned his early touchdown, making a man miss and going through a couple others on his way to a nine-yard score on a screen pass on the opening drive of the game. He was not able to build on his hot start, however. He was targeted just once after halftime, and he did not record a catch in the second half. He has yet to top 57 yards since returning. Edelman will always be a touchdown threat in this offense, but there is at least some reason for concern, especially with Rob Gronkowski expected back next week.
report: Julian Edelman hauled in 5-of-8 targets for 36 yards and a touchdown in the Patriots' Week 7 win over the Bears.

impact: Collins was breaking tackles — especially on his 24-yard catch-and-rumble in the third quarter — but coach John Harbaugh was addicted to giving Buck Allen touches. At one point in the broadcast, color commentator Troy Aikman matter of factly referred to Allen as the Ravens' goal-line back. Allen indeed converted from the one-yard line for a second quarter score. Collins failed on a one-yard attempt of his own just before the break. On a 3rd-and-1 in the fourth, Harbaugh dialed up a
report: Alex Collins rushed nine times for 35 yards in the Ravens' Week 2 loss to the Bengals, adding three catches for 55 additional yards.

impact: Players almost always play through illnesses, so this shouldn't have any bearing on Collins' Week 3 status. The bigger concern is Javorius Allen, who only saw one fewer touch than Collins in last week's loss to Cincinnati. For fantasy purposes, Collins is shaping up as more of a back-end RB2.
report: Alex Collins (illness) didn't practice on Wednesday.

impact: Collins' Week 3 status was never in doubt. He will be a low-end RB2 against the Broncos.
report: Alex Collins (illness) returned to Ravens practice as a full participant on Thursday.

impact: He added another six yards on three catches. Collins did lose some goal-line work to Javorius Allen, who scored two touchdowns including a short rushing score, but Collins saw his fair share of work near the goal line including a six-yard touchdown run in the first quarter. More importantly, he continues to look like a much better player than his backfield partner. Allen's role is a concern, but Collins will remain an RB2 next week against the Steelers.
report: Alex Collins rushed 18 times for 68 yards and a touchdown in the Ravens' Week 3 win over the Broncos.

impact: Collins was left uncovered in the flats for a three-yard touchdown after an early Steelers turnover.  He later fumbled at the goal-line and was benched for the rest of the first half. Ball security has been a concern for Collins going back to last year, and he's lost two fumbles through four weeks. Collins was already losing red-zone work to Javorius Allen and may continue to see his role decline there moving forward.
report: Alex Collins rushed 11 times for 42 yards and caught a three-yard touchdown in Baltimore's Week 4 win over the Steelers.

impact: Harbaugh made his justifiable displeasure known on Sunday, benching Collins for the rest of the first half after he coughed the ball up. Harbaugh said the defense will try to punch the ball out more in practice. Collins' fumbling woes are probably going to keep Buck Allen locked in near the goal line for the foreseeable future, but Collins is still an RB2.
report: Asked about Alex Collins' fumbling issues on Monday, Ravens coach John Harbaugh said "can't have it."

impact: It's the first time Collins has been listed with an injury this year. The limited practice suggests it's nothing serious. Collins should be fine for Sunday's Browns matchup
report: Alex Collins (knee) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Collins is moving in the wrong direction after getting in a limited session on Wednesday. Perhaps he will still get slapped with a token "limited" tag today, but it does not appear that will be the case. Collins is now genuinely questionable for Sunday's game against the Browns. His Friday status will be paramount. Buck Allen would be a (low-end) plug-and-play RB2 were Collins to sit.
report: Alex Collins (knee) was downgraded to "DNP" for Thursday's practice.

impact: Per Pelissero, the Ravens want Collins "ready to rip" against the Browns. Collins was downgraded from limited to DNP on Thursday, which usually signals an absence. If Collins does indeed suit up, he will find himself on the RB2/3 borderline thanks to his fumbling issues and Buck Allen's goal-line work.
report: NFL.com's Tom Pelissero reports Alex Collins' (knee) absence from Thursday's practice was "precautionary."

impact: Panic set in across the fantasy community when Collins sat out Thursday's practice after being a limited participant on Wednesday, but NFL Network's Tom Pelissero later reported his absence was precautionary. Coach John Harbaugh said he has "no concern" about Collins' injury status for Week 5 against Cleveland. After fumbling on the goal line in last week's win at Pittsburgh, Collins could cede more work to Javorius Allen on Sunday.
report: Alex Collins (knee) returned to a full practice on Friday.

impact: A knee injury kept Collins from practicing on Thursday but he was back to full participation on Friday. Collins has scored a touchdown in three of four games this season, though he's also lost a pair of fumbles including one on the goal line last week at Pittsburgh. He'll be in the RB2 mix Sunday versus Cleveland.
report: Alex Collins (knee) wasn't listed on the Ravens' final injury report for Week 5 against the Browns.

impact: Collins' first touch of the game was a 19-yard run, but he found little room or opportunity to do much else afterwards. Collins was out-touched by Javorius Allen 14-to-13 despite out-rushing Allen 12-to-8 and was lifted for Allen at the goal line once again. Collins has been shaky to start out the season, receiving 14 or fewer touches in four of the first five games of the season. He will be a lower-end RB2 option at best Week 6 when the Ravens head to Tennessee.
report: Alex Collins rushed 12 times for 59 yards while catching 1-of-4 targets for seven yards in Sunday's Week 5 loss to the Browns.

impact: "We need to spread the load," Harbaugh said. Collins played just 27-of-87 snaps in the Ravens' dispiriting loss to the Browns. His 31 snap percentage was his lowest of the season. Harbaugh might be keeping Collins fresh, but he's doing so at the cost of Buck Allen averaging 2.82 yards per carry and 6.2 yards per catch. Those are wasted plays in the National Football League.
report: Responding to questions about Alex Collins' workload, Ravens coach John Harbaugh said "a fresh running back is a good thing."

impact: Finally handed the utmost perfect game script on a silver platter, Collins notably out-carried teammate Javorius Allen 19-1 on the day. It only amounted to a measly 2.8 YPC, but Collins benefited by punching in one of his two carries inside the five-yard line for a score. His other touchdown came on a scamper from 13-yards out. His volume was still tremendously encouraging given that he played just 27-of-87 snaps last week, his lowest mark of the season. He'll again be a touchdown-dependent RB2 in what should be a faster paced game in Week 7 against the Saints.
report: Alex Collins rushed 19 times for 54 yards and two scores in the Ravens' Week 6 trouncing of the Titans.

impact: Collins out-touched Buck Allen 14-6, though he's now been held below 60 yards rushing in four-straight games. Collins has yet to have a 70-yard game on the ground. The Ravens' offensive line has been banged up of late. Collins will be an uninspiring RB2 for Week 8 against the Panthers.
report: Alex Collins rushed 11 times for 38 yards in the Ravens' Week 7 loss to the Saints, adding three receptions for 10 additional yards.

impact: The Ravens plan to use Lamar Jackson in some packages, so this is gameplan related. ESPN's Chris Mortensen reports Griffin is still likely the No. 2 quarterback if something happens to Joe Flacco. The rest of Baltimore's inactives are WR Jordan Lasley, CB Darious Williams, DT Willie Henry, OL Jermaine Eluemunor, TE Hayden Hurst and DT Zach Sieler.
report: Robert Griffin III is inactive for Week 1 against Buffalo.

impact: As expected, the Ravens will again roll with just two active quarterbacks (Joe Flacco, Lamar Jackson) on game day. It's a slightly better spot for their offense than initially expected given the absences of LB Wesley Woodyard and S Kenny Vaccaro for the Titans.
report: Ravens declare QB Robert Griffin III, FB/DL Patrick Ricard, WR Jordan Lasley, C Hroniss Grasu, OLB Tyus Bowser, DT Zach Sieler and CB Anthony Averett inactive for Week 6 against the Titans.

impact: Darnold, the youngest starting quarterback in the Super Bowl era, started off about as miserably as one could, having his first pass of the game picked off and returned for a touchdown by S Quandre Diggs.  But the rookie had nowhere to go but up from that point, and up he went.  Darnold showed the poise of a 10-year veteran and bounced back with a 21-yard touchdown to Quincy Enunwa and a perfect deep ball to Robby Anderson for another score from 41 yards out.  Darnold and Enunwa had a real connection, with Enunwa seeing a team-high 10 targets.  (The next closes Jet had three.)  Darnold should pick up right where he left off at home in Week 2 against Miami.
report: Making his NFL debut, Sam Darnold completed 16-of-21 passes for 198 yards, two touchdowns, and one interception in the Jets' 48-17, Week 1 win over the Lions.

impact: Darnold averaged over eight yards per attempt for the second straight week, but his two picks were costly in a one-score game.  The second wasn't necessarily Darnold's fault; Terrelle Pryor appeared to cut off his route in the back of the end zone, allowing Xavien Howard to catch it.  Darnold also missed a would-be game-changing play when he overthrew wide-open Quincy Enunwa in the back of the end zone in the second half.  Darnold will be a QB2 when the Jets visit Cleveland on Thursday Night Football in Week 3.
report: Sam Darnold completed 25-of-41 passes for 334 yards, one touchdown, and two interceptions in the Jets' Week 2 loss to the Dolphins.

impact: Whereas Baker Mayfield stole the show, Darnold stunk up the joint. He might as well have had "rookie" tattooed on his forehead. For their part, the Jets were terrified of Darnold making a mistake, calling a horizontal passing offense. It resulted in some nice catch-and-runs for Quincy Enunwa but severely capped the Jets' point ceiling for the evening. Of course, Darnold proved the Jets' caution correct when he immediately tossed a pair of late-game picks when forced into comeback mode. Darnold has now turned in back-to-back unimpressive performances after his Week 1 throttling of the Lions. He has 10 days to review tape before a foreboding Week 4 matchup with the Jaguars.
report: Sam Darnold completed 15-of-31 passes for 169 yards, zero touchdowns and two interceptions in New York's 21-17, Week 3 loss to the Browns.

impact: It's another rough game for Darnold after throwing two interceptions last week. Darnold managed to salvage his game with a late touchdown to Jordan Leggett, but the Jets offense continued to struggle. Darnold has went through some expected early-season growing pains, failing to throw multiple touchdowns since the season opener. He'll have another dificult matchup in Week 5 against the Broncis.
report: Sam Darnold completed 17-of-34 passes for 167 yards and a touchdown in Week 4 against the Jaguars.

impact: He only took one sack and three hits all game as the Jets neutralized Von Miller and leaned on their running game on a career day for Isaiah Crowell.  Darnold was terrific in his own right, though, finding Robby Anderson in stride on a 76-yard touchdown bomb, then showing pinpoint ball placement on Anderson's 35-yard score and Terrelle Pryor's 20-yard TD.  Darnold has struggled in tough matchups, unsurprising for a rookie.  He got a favorable one Sunday against Denver's overrated pass defense, and draws an above-average one at home against the Colts in Week 6.
report: Sam Darnold completed 10-of-22 passes for 198 yards, three touchdowns, and an interception in the Jets' Week 5 win over the Broncos.

impact: With the exception of a telegraphed pick Colts FS Malik Hooker easily jumped all over, Darnold was fantastic for the second straight week.  He carved up the Colts' interior defense on slant routes, took only two sacks, and made numerous plays with his feet outside the pocket.  Darnold had a predictable Weeks 3-4 rough patch in road trips to Cleveland and Jacksonville, but otherwise his performance has been highly promising for the NFL's youngest-ever Week 1 starting quarterback.  Darnold will be a two-QB-league play when Gang Green hosts the Vikings next.
report: Sam Darnold completed 24-of-30 passes for 280 yards, two touchdowns, and an interception in the Jets' Week 6 win over the Colts.

impact: Darnold hurt his throwing elbow trying to make a tackle after throwing an interception last week, but he still got his usual reps in on Wednesday. Coming off one of his better games, Darnold will be an acceptable QB2 against Minnesota.
report: Sam Darnold (elbow) is practicing in full for Week 7 against the Vikings.

impact: Darnold was horrible with one of the worst quarterback performances of the season.  He missed open receivers, overthrew Robby Anderson on a potential 81-yard touchdown, and was also hurt by a couple drops.  The interceptions were a pass thrown right to CB Holton Hill, another tipped by Xavier Rhodes to Harrison Smith, and a drop-turned-INT by Charone Peake to Trae Waynes.  Darnold was able to score a one-yard rushing touchdown to boost his stats, but his 40.5% completion rate is ugly.  Darnold will be harassed next week in Chicago.
report: Sam Darnold completed just 17-of-42 passes for 206 yards, one touchdown, and three interceptions in the Jets' 37-17, Week 7 loss to the Vikings.

impact: Ryan also fumbled and absorbed four sacks. It felt like many more, especially on third down. Ryan was holding onto the ball for far too long. His interception was a wild underthrow to Julio Jones. Ryan did find Jones 10 times for 169 yards but beyond that was inexcusably bad. He missed what should have been a 68-yard touchdown to Jones early in the third quarter. Ryan seemed to be operating more than a few ticks slow, and his deep balls routinely fell short. As was his Achilles' heel last season, Ryan was truly awful in the red zone. The Falcons had three separate drives end inside the Eagles' 15-yard line without points. The Falcons could have won the game in the dying seconds, but Ryan kept throwing uncatchable balls into the end zone. He seemed more interested in avoiding another pick than actually making a play. It was simply a brutal night. Things won't get much easier when the Falcons host the Panthers in Week 2.
report: Matt Ryan completed 21-of-42 passes for 251 yards, zero touchdowns and an interception in the Falcons' 18-12, Week 1 loss to the Eagles.

impact: Ryan and the offense got off to a sleepy start, scoring three points in the first quarter and trailing 10-3 at one point, but Atlanta went on to score three unanswered touchdowns.  Ryan sneaked in from one yard away on his first score, and then helicoptered in from eight yards out on his second rushing score.  His two via the pass went to Calvin Ridley and Austin Hooper.  All four scores were of the red-zone variety, a huge improvement from Week 1 when the offense went 0-of-5 in the red area.  Ryan will be a back-end QB1 next week against the Saints.
report: Matt Ryan completed 23-of-28 passes for 272 yards, two touchdowns, and one interception in the Falcons' 31-24, Week 2 win over the Panthers, adding 18 yards and two additional touchdowns on four carries.

impact: He took three sacks for a loss of 15 yards. Halloween isn’t for another month but Ryan was handing out touchdowns like candy on Sunday, dropping dimes all over the gridiron. Three of his touchdowns went to rookie Calvin Ridley, who broke out for 146 yards on seven catches. Matty Ice probably should have had a sixth touchdown but slightly underthrew Julio Jones on what ended up being a 58-yard catch. As dominant as he was, Ryan’s afternoon ended on a low note when Atlanta's last drive stalled out, forcing a punt with 16 seconds left in regulation. That would be the last time Atlanta touched the football as New Orleans walked it off on a Drew Brees touchdown in overtime. Ryan has redeemed himself since his meltdown against the Eagles in Week 1 and is once again safe to pencil in as an every-week QB1. He’ll get the Bengals at home in Week 4.
report: Matt Ryan completed 26-of-35 passes for five touchdowns while adding 12 rushing yards on four carries Sunday in Atlanta’s Week 3 loss to the Saints.

impact: Atlanta ended up losing this game, but Ryan should not shoulder much of the blame. He did miss a few passes which perhaps could have iced things late in the fourth quarter, but he consistently answered a Bengals offense which Atlanta's defense struggled to stop all game. Two of his touchdowns were wide-open throws to Logan Paulsen and Calvin Ridley, but he made a great tight-window throw on Ridley's other score. Ryan now has 793 yards and eight touchdowns in his last two games. He will be a high-end QB1 in a great matchup against the Steelers next week.
report: Matt Ryan completed 29-of-39 passes for 419 yards and three touchdowns in the Falcons' Week 4 loss to the Bengals.

impact: Ryan also lost a fumble that the Steelers returned for a touchdown. Under siege — he took six sacks and was pressured countless other times — Ryan played really poorly in this one, going three full quarters before finally finding Julio Jones for a reception. He was addicted to checking down to Austin Hooper. Ryan was lucky to escape with only one turnover. Ryan has now struggled mightily in each of his road starts while having big days at home. The Falcons host the Bucs in Week 6. That's an obvious smash spot in fantasy.
report: Matt Ryan completed 26-of-38 passes for 285 yards, one touchdown and zero interceptions in the Falcons' 41-17, Week 5 loss to the Steelers.

impact: The X-rays checked out okay, and Ryan is fully expected to start in a prime Week 6 bounce-back spot against Tampa Bay's league-worst pass defense.
report: Matt Ryan underwent X-rays on his foot following Sunday's loss to Pittsurgh.

impact: Ryan came out firing, completing all five of his passes on the opening drive for 74 yards and a touchdown and 11-of-11 for 125 yards in the first quarter, and he did not slow down from there. The offense did have a lull in the third quarter, but Ryan was hitting open receivers all game and answered Tampa's comeback attempt with two scoring drives of his own. Ryan has now thrown for at least 350 yards in three of his last four games. He will be a high-end QB1 next week against the Giants.
report: Matt Ryan completed 31-of-41 passes for 354 yards and three touchdowns in the Falcons' Week 6 win over the Bucs.

impact: Ryan took three first-half sacks but wasn't sacked after the break; anytime he had time to throw, Ryan was dicing up this defense with relative ease.  He hit deep reserve WR Marvin Hall for a 47-yard touchdown over the top.  Ryan should have had a 60-yard touchdown to Julio Jones on top of that but underthrew the ball as he hit his hand on a helmet on the follow-through.  Atlanta had to settle for a trio of Giorgio Tavecchio field goals tonight.  Ryan and the Falcons are going into their bye week ahead of a road date with the Redskins in Week 9.
report: Matt Ryan completed 31-of-39 passes for 379 yards and one touchdown in the Falcons' Week 7 win over the Giants.

impact: Trubisky had a solid first half before fizzling over the final two quarters. His only touchdown was a designed run at the goal-line, with the rest of his rushng coming on broken play scrambles. Trubisky had a good rapport with Allen Robinson, who lead the team in receiving. It's a step in the right direction for Trubisky after a rough rookie season, but there's not a ton to get excited about with his Year 2 outlook.
report: Mitchell Trubisky completed 23-of-35 passes for 171 yards in Sunday night's Week 1 loss to the Packers, adding seven carries for 32 yards and a rushing touchdown.

impact: The second game of the second year of his pro career seems like a good time to start focusing on these basic fundamentals. Trubisky was utterly horrendous against the Packers in Week 1, generating a pathetic 72 yards on 26 attempts after the first quarter. If anything, Trubisky might need to go more off script and make more plays outside the pocket and with his legs.
report: Mitchell Trubisky wants to focus on "better pocket awareness, calm feet in the pocket (and) trusting his eyes."

impact: It's been a disgusting start to the season for the sophomore, who is averaging a pitiful 5.4 YPA on his first 69 attempts.  Only Sam Bradford's 4.0 YPA mark has been worse among qualified quarterbacks.  Trubisky should have had a third interception in the end zone at the end of the first half, but CB Justin Coleman flat-out dropped it.  Trubisky's first pick was a terribly underthrown sideline shot to Allen Robinson, while the other was a ball batted at the line of scrimmage.  The touchdowns were a three-yard shovel pass to Trey Burton and an off-balance, 10-yarder to Anthony Miller.  Trubisky flashes upside at rare times but mostly plays wildly inaccurate with a tendency to run.  He's one of the worst fantasy quarterbacks and won't be on the radar next week in Arizona, even against that horrendous defense.
report: Mitchell Trubisky completed 25-of-34 passes for 200 yards, two touchdowns, and two interceptions in the Bears' Week 2 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Trubisky also rushed twice for eight yards, losing a fumble on a scramble. He played with fire on multiple occasions, throwing a few would-be interceptions had defenders secured the ball. Trubisky has now averaged just 5.7 yards per pass attempt through three games and has struggled to connect on anything down the field. The silver lining is that his yards per pass attempt have risen in each game, but Trubisky and the Bears are indeed not the second coming of Sean McVay and Jared Goff if the opening three weeks are any indication of the rest of the season.
report: Mitchell Trubisky completed 24-of-35 passes for 220 yards with one interception in Sunday's Week 3 win over the Cardinals.

impact: He also led the team with 53 yards rushing. Trubisky came only one-score short of tying the NFL record for most touchdown passes in a single game. It was the perfect storm for the second-year pro, who not only found milk carton candidates Trey Burton (2-86-1) and Tarik Cohen (7-121-1 receiving), but who was also helped by the Bucs' ineptitude on defense. Even Taylor Gabriel was involved in Chicago's efforts Sunday, recording a career-high 104 receiving yards and two scores. This can't possibly be expected from Trubisky moving forward, but it's certainly a positive that his yards per attempt have increased in every outing this season. Matt Nagy's offense should continue developing and clicking against the Dolphins after the bye.
report: Mitchell Trubisky completed 19-of-26 passes for 354 yards and six touchdowns in the Bears' Week 4 win over the Buccaneers.

impact: He was dropped for two sacks, which resulted in a loss of 13 yards. Trubisky has now thrown for nine touchdown passes over his last two outings, the same number he had in his first 15 starts. The 2017 first-rounder did almost all of his damage after halftime, throwing for 222 yards on 12-of-16 passing in the second half. Trubisky was far from perfect—he was bailed out on a handful of spectacular catches (the most absurd of the bunch coming on a 47-yard deep heave to Taylor Gabriel in the second quarter) and was intercepted in the end zone on a pass he never should have thrown. But for fantasy purposes, the 24-year-old has done just fine. We'll see how he fares when the Bears host New England in Week 7.
report: Mitchell Trubisky completed 22-of-31 passes for 316 yards with three touchdowns and one interception while adding 47 yards on eight carries Sunday in the Bears’ Week 6 loss to Miami.

impact: Trubisky was just 8-for-20 in the first half, but he also made important plays in big spots including a Hail Mary which fell just inches short on the final play. He converted two third downs early in the game on scrambles, and he did even better on the third drive, making the Patriots pay for a fumble on a spectacular "eight-yard" touchdown scramble in which he escaped several defenders in the backfield. He continued to hurt the Patriots with his legs early in the second half, scrambling for 39 yards down to the one-yard line on the opening touchdown drive. The scrambles eventually dried up, however, and Trubisky struggled to get anything going down the field. His risky throws caught up to him on an interception near the end of the third quarter, and he was picked again early in the fourth on an underthrown pass. He did find Trey Burton for a touchdown late and connected on the Hail Mary, but this was not a good showing. He will look to rebound next week against the Jets.
report: Mitchell Trubisky completed 26-of-50 attempts for 333 yards, two touchdowns, and two interceptions in the Bears' Week 7 loss to the Patriots, adding 81 yards and a touchdown on six carries.

impact: There are no surprises on this list. The Broncos are healthy heading into Week 1.
report: Broncos declared QB Kevin Hogan, LB Alexander Johnson, C Sam Jones, WR Isaiah McKenzie, DE DeMarcus Walker, OT Elijah Wilkinson, and CB Isaac Yiadom inactive for Week 1 against the Seahawks.

impact: With no injuries a week ago, these are the exact same inactives that Denver had in Week 1.
report: Broncos declared QB Kevin Hogan, G/C Sam Jones, LB Alexander Johnson, S Shamarko Thomas, DE DeMarcus Walker, T Elijah Wilkinson, and CB Isaac Yiadom inactive for Sunday's Week 2 game versus the Raiders.

impact: Gresham continues to make progress, though it's unclear if he'll be ready for Sunday's opener against Washington. His absence would open up more playing time for second-year tight end Ricky Seals-Jones.
report: Cardinals TE Jermaine Gresham (Achilles) remained limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Gresham practiced on a limited basis this week but might need more time after missing the entirety of training camp while recovering from last season's torn Achilles. Even if he plays, Gresham will mostly be used as a blocker and shouldn't warrant fantasy consideration.
report: Cardinals TE Jermaine Gresham (Achilles) is questionable for Week 1 against the Redskins.

impact: Gresham was able to practice this week but is still working back from a torn Achilles. He may have a chance to return in Week 2. DT Robert Nkemdiche (foot) and DT Olsen Pierre (toe) are both good to go after being listed as questionable.
report: Cardinals declared TE Jermaine Gresham, OL Korey Cunningham, QB Mike Glennon, DE Markus Golden, RB T.J. Logan, CB Deatrick Nichols and OL Jeremy Vujnovich inactive for Week 1 against the Redskins.

impact: He got in limited practice all week. That was also the case in Week 1, though Gresham was inactive for Arizona's opener against Washington. Coming off a torn Achilles, he might not be game-ready yet. Ricky Seals-Jones would play close to an every-down role at tight end if Gresham can't go against the Rams.
report: Jermaine Gresham (Achilles) is questionable for Week 2 against the Rams.

impact: Gresham has been limited the last two weeks but has yet to get in a full practice. He's getting close to returning, but the Cardinals should hold him out another game. Gresham not playing would lock Ricky Seals-Jones into an every-down role.
report: Jermaine Gresham (questionable, Achilles) isn't expected to play in Week 2 against the Rams.

impact: Gresham got in three limited practices this week, but he is still not ready to return from last year's Achilles' tear. Ricky Seals-Jones will retain his every-down role for at least another week.
report: Cardinals declared TE Jermaine Gresham (Achilles') inactive for Week 2 against the Rams.

impact: Gresham didn't play through questionable tags the first two weeks. He finally looks over last year's torn Achilles and should play Sunday. Gresham's return is going to cut into Ricky Seals-Jones' snaps.
report: Jermaine Gresham (Achilles) is practicing in full for Week 3.

impact: He's coming off a torn Achilles but should be good to go after putting in a full week of practice. Gresham's return would put a damper on Ricky Seals-Jones' fantasy outlook.
report: Jermaine Gresham (Achilles) is questionable for Week 3 against the Bears.

impact: It's standard practice-reps management. Gresham will be fine for his normal snaps in Week 5.
report: Jermaine Gresham (Achilles) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: He was able to get in a full session to close out the week after being limited on Wednesday and Thursday. Gresham has mostly functioned as a blocker this year (though not a good one), seeing just two targets over 50 offensive snaps since coming back from a torn Achilles. Even at a thin fantasy position, Gresham isn't relevant.
report: Jermaine Gresham (Achilles) wasn't listed on the Cardinals' final injury report for Week 5 against the 49ers.

impact: Gresham has been practicing on a limited basis since returning in Week 3. This looks to be rest related. Gresham should play against the Vikings.
report: Jermaine Gresham (Achilles) didn't practice Wednesday.

impact: He's good to go for Sunday's game with the Vikings. Gresham has just three targets since returing in Week 3.
report: Jermaine Gresham (Achilles) was removed from the Week 6 injury report.

impact: Gresham was a late addition to the injury report after a limited practice Friday. This looks related to his Achilles injury. Ricky Seals-Jones would have an every-down role if Gresham sits.
report: Jermaine Gresham (heel) is questionable for Week 8 against the 49ers.

impact: Gronkowski was limited at practice throughout the week, though there's never been any doubt about his status for Sunday night's showdown against the undefeated Chiefs. This should be a smash spot for Gronk, especially with stud safety Eric Berry (doubtful, heel) on the shelf. He's our top-ranked tight end for Week 6.
report: Rob Gronkowski (questionable, ankle) is expected to play Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: Gronkowski was invisible for most of the game, getting held without a catch in the second half before a 42-yard catch and run with four minutes remaining. He came into Sunday night questionable with an ankle injury but looked healthy. It’s been a rocky year for Gronk, who hasn’t topped 100 yards or found the end-zone since Week 1. Gronk has a tough matchup with Chicago in Week 7.
report: Rob Gronkowski caught 3-of-4 passes for 97 yards in the Patriots' Week 6 win over the Chiefs.

impact: The Patriots are just managing his reps. Gronkowski's in no danger of sitting out this week.
report: Rob Gronkowski (ankle) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Gronkowski is dealing with a back issue in addition to his ankle injury. He practiced on a limited basis Friday and should play barring a setback. Gronk is our No. 3-ranked tight end for Week 7.
report: Rob Gronkowski (ankle, back) is questionable for Week 7 against Chicago.

impact: Gronkowski hasn't been ruled out, but players who don't travel with the team never play. This looks related to the back injury Gronk picked up at Friday's practice. Gronkowski has a history of back issues, so this may be a concern beyond this week. The Patriots have Dwayne Allen and Jacob Hollister behind Gronk.
report: The Boston Globe's Jim McBride reports Rob Gronkowski (questionable, back/ankle) didn't travel with the team to Chicago.

impact: This became obvious after Gronkowski didn't travel with the team to Chicago. Gronk's ankle is fine, but his back injury is going to sideline him for at least one week. This has the makings for a potential multi-game absence given Gronk's longstanding back problems. Julian Edelman (questionable, heel) and Chris Hogan will see more underneath targets with Gronkowski out.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Rob Gronkowski (doubtful, back/ankle) is "highly unlikely" to play in Week 7 against Chicago.

impact: Gronkowski could be looking at a multi-game absence. Jacob Hollister (hamstring) was also downgraded to out, leaving Dwayne Allen as the only healthy tight end. The Patriots figure to run heavy four-wide sets this week.
report: The Patriots downgraded Rob Gronkowski (back, ankle) to doubtful for Week 7 against Chicago.

impact: There was at least some concern about Gronkowski's long-term outlook after he tweaked his troublesome back, but Schefter reports it will just be a one-game absence. With Jacob Hollister (hamstring) also out, Dwayne Allen should play nearly every snap against the Bears.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Rob Gronkowski (back) is not expected to play Week 7 against the Bears, but he is expected back for Week 8.

impact: Gronk didn't make the trip to Chicago after having his back lock up on him during Friday's practice. The Patriots are optimistic he'll be back for next week's Monday night showdown in Buffalo. With Jacob Hollister (hamstring) also sidelined, Dwayne Allen should play close to an every-down role at tight end. Gronkowski's absence will open up targets for Josh Gordon, Julian Edelman and James White, among others.
report: Rob Gronkowski (back, ankle) is out for Week 7 against the Bears.

impact: This was the expectation, but Adam Schefter reports Gronk has a good chance to return next week against the Bills. New England also declared RT Marcus Cannon (concussion), TE Jacob Hollister (hamstring), DE John Simon (shoulder), DE Geneo Grissom (ankle), OL Brian Schwenke, and DL Keionta Davis inactive for Week 7.
report: Patriots declared Rob Gronkowski (back) inactive for Week 7 against the Bears.

impact: Per Giardi, Gronk missed Week 7 with "painful" back spasms that popped up on Friday, but it is believed to be a "short-term thing." Gronk, of course, has a history of back problems, so nothing can be taken for granted. The Pats won't push matters against the expansion-level Bills.
report: NFL Network's Michael Giardi reports Rob Gronkowski (back) could be ready for next Monday's game against the Bills.

impact: Sony Michel (knee) is also not practicing.  Gronkowski sat out Week 7 in Chicago because of back spasms.  Early word is he's expected back Monday night against the Bills.  There won't be an official practice report until Thursday.
report: Rob Gronkowski (back) is not practicing Wednesday.

impact: He will likely be listed as limited, but it is a big step after he sat out Wednesday's session. Reporting has suggested Gronkowski will be ready to face the Bills on Monday night, and this practice puts him on track. Despite his recent struggles, Gronkowski will be a must-start if he is active.
report: Rob Gronkowski (back) is practicing Thursday.

impact: Gronk is now tentatively on track to return against the Bills on Monday, but it is far from certain. He could end up a game-time call, which isn't exactly ideal for MNF. Owners need to keep their back-up plan at the ready.
report: Rob Gronkowski (back) was officially "limited" on Thursday.

impact: Gronkowski sat out last week's game after having his back lock up during practice, but most reports suggest he'll be back for Monday night's game in his hometown of Buffalo. Dwayne Allen filled in for Gronk at tight end last week against the Bears, but didn't draw any targets from Tom Brady.
report: Rob Gronkowski (back, ankle) remained limited at Friday's practice.

impact: After throwing just seven interceptions last season, Keenum did not start off on the right foot with his new team. He made up for it with a 75-yard drive he capped with a four-yard touchdown, his third of the game, to Demaryius Thomas to put Denver ahead for good. With Thomas and Emmanuel Sanders, who had a 10/135/1 line on Sunday, to target, Keenum will be worth streaming consideration in good matchups all season. He gets one of those next week against the Raiders.
report: Case Keenum completed 25-of-39 passes for 329 yards, three touchdowns, and three interceptions in the Broncos' Week 1 win over the Seahawks.

impact: Keenum added 16 yards rushing and a touchdown on the ground. After a quiet first half in which he completed just 5-of-11 passes for 38 yards, Keenum bounced back in the second half to complete 14-of-24 passes for 184 yards and lead the Broncos on four scoring drives. Keenum will be a lower-end QB2 for fantasy in Week 3 on the road versus the Ravens.
report: Case Keenum completed 19-of-35 passes for 222 yards with an interception in Sunday's Week 2 win over the Raiders.

impact: 9 News Denver's Mike Klis reports the DNP is "precautionary," and Keenum is expected to practice Thursday and play Sunday in Baltimore.  Keenum guided a late Week 2 comeback in the win over the Raiders but is a low QB2.
report: Case Keenum (knee) is not practicing Wednesday.

impact: He was "full." Keenum's absence was always believed to be precautionary. It's unideal that Keenum already needs his practice reps rationed, but he will be out there for a tough matchup with the Ravens. Keenum is a fringe Week 3 starter in two-quarterback leagues.
report: Case Keenum (knee) resumed practicing on Thursday.

impact: Keenum did not practice Wednesday, but there was never any real concern about his availability. He will be a back-end QB2 in a tough matchup against the Ravens this week.
report: Case Keenum (knee) was left off the final injury report for Week 3.

impact: Keenum was not good in this one. Consistently settling for the short pass amid pressure, Keenum had just 104 yards heading into the fourth quarter. After two touchdowns to open the game -- one set up by a blocked punt -- the Broncos punted seven straight times. The next play ended when Keenum was picked off on second-and-goal from the 15, and the final drive ended on fourth down deep in Baltimore territory. The good news is Keenum will get to face the Chiefs' defense at home next Monday night.
report: Case Keenum completed 22-of-34 passes for 192 yards, zero touchdowns, and an interception in the Broncos' Week 3 loss to the Ravens.

impact: The Broncos held what looked like a pretty commanding 23-13 lead with just over 12 minutes left, but then Patrick Mahomes happened and led an incredible comeback as Keenum simultaneously collapsed.  This was as good of an on-paper matchup as Keenum is going to see this season.  The Chiefs were playing the worst pass defense in the league entering Week 4, and Keenum was unable to attack it.  He had one big shot to Courtland Sutton early for 42 yards, but that was about it.  Keenum then missed a wide-open Demaryius Thomas with less than a minute to play on what should have been a walk-in 28-yard touchdown.  Keenum has been dreadful four weeks into his Broncos career, tossing six picks to three touchdowns.  He hasn't thrown for a score since Week 1 and won't be a fantasy option next week at the Jets.
report: Case Keenum completed 21-of-33 passes for 245 yards, no touchdowns, and one interception in the Broncos' 27-23, Week 4 loss to the Chiefs on Monday night.

impact: There is a major gap between reality and Keenum's stat line; he was dreadfully inaccurate when this game was in doubt, took four sacks, fumbled twice, and was a major part of the problem in the Broncos' 34-16 loss.  Keenum padded his stats with a garbage-time 42-yard touchdown to Demaryius Thomas.  Still not yet the subject of benching rumors, Keenum will be a two-quarterback-league play in next week's potential shootout against the Rams.
report: Case Keenum completed 35-of-51 passes for 377 yards, two touchdowns, and an interception in the Broncos' Week 5 loss to the Jets.

impact: It was Keenum's second-straight 300-yard game, though he hardly looked good doing it. A huge chunk of Keenum's yards came on a pair of underthrown deep balls to Demaryius Thomas and Courtland Sutton. Keenum's arm appeared limited all afternoon. Keenum briefly checked out at the end of the first half as he was evaluated for a concussion, but he thankfully cleared. With just eight total touchdowns through six games, Keenum is barely staying on the QB2 radar. He gets the Cardinals on Thursday Night Football for Week 7.
report: Case Keenum completed 25-of-41 passes for 322 yards, two touchdowns and an interception in the Broncos' 23-20, Week 6 loss to the Rams.

impact: "Case is our quarterback," Joseph said after yet another Broncos loss on Sunday.  Keenum was checked for a concussion at the end of the first half, and sophomore Chad Kelly came into a standing ovation from Broncos fans to kneel it out on the final play of the second quarter.  Kelly was also tremendous in the preseason.  Keenum hasn't been the worst of the Broncos' problems, but his play also leaves the rest of the team zero margin for error since he's simply unable to deliver anything more than mediocre quarterbacking.  There haven't been more than a couple worse starting quarterbacks in the league through six weeks.  Keenum is tied for the league lead with eight interceptions, and only Josh Allen and Marcus Mariota have worse passer ratings.  Joseph and Keenum will go down with arms linked.
report: Coach Vance Joseph remains committed to Case Keenum as the Broncos' starting quarterback.

impact: Keenum added four carries for four yards. They're disappointing numbers considering the lopsided nature of the score, though five Cardinals turnovers kept setting the Broncos up with gorgeous field position, limiting Keenum's yardage opportunities. The Broncos' defense also housed a pair of pick sixes. Lastly, Emmanuel Sanders threw a 28-yard touchdown on a trick play. Keenum has been barely playable in two-quarterback leagues this season, but he will be a top-18 option against the Chiefs' barely-there defense in Week 8.
report: Case Keenum completed 14-of-21 passes for 161 yards, one touchdown and an interception in the Broncos' 45-10, Week 7 win over the Cardinals.

impact: Wouldn't you know it, the Patriots are about to play Anderson's former team Houston. A 2016 UDFA, Anderson had some 2017 fantasy relevance for the Texans' banged up tight end group, catching 25 passes for 342 yards. He will probably end up making regular season appearances this year, either in New England or elsewhere.
report: Patriots signed TE Stephen Anderson to the practice squad.

impact: There's no way to spin what was an extremely disappointing performance. Hogan's five targets were fourth on the team behind Rob Gronkowski, Phillip Dorsett and James White. Fantasy owners need to shake it off — Hogan is still the team's No. 1 receiver while Julian Edelman is sidelined — but a Week 2 bounce-back will be difficult against the Jaguars' elite secondary.
report: Chris Hogan caught 1-of-5 targets for 11 yards in the Patriots' Week 1 win over the Texans.

impact: Hogan's first score came on Jalen Ramsey in man-to-man coverage in the end zone. He got free as a diving Ramsey couldn't find him. TD2 came as Tom Brady got the Jags to bite on a short fake and hit Hogan over the middle of the field. Hogan did the rest of the work on the 29-yard grab. Hogan has just four catches through two games, but that's a number he should at least double in Week 3 against the Lions, especially if CB Darius Slay (concussion) is sidelined.
report: Chris Hogan caught 3-of-5 targets for 42 yards and two touchdowns in the Patriots' Week 2 loss to the Jaguars.

impact: Hogan was invisible on a night Tom Brady threw for only 133 yards. He saw fewer targets than both Rob Gronkowski and Phillip Dorsett. Hogan's ROS outlook is trending down after the Patriots' trade for Josh Gordon. New England also gets Julien Edelman back in Week 5.
report: Chris Hogan caught 3-of-4 passes for 31 yards in Week 3 against the Lions.

impact: Hogan's baffling downward trend continues. Today was the first time all season he drew fewer than four looks. Josh Gordon returned, but he played just 18 snaps. Hogan has not been on the same page with Tom Brady over the middle, and Brady is struggling mightily deep. With Julian Edelman set to return for Week 5, a Hogan breakout will get that much more difficult. Sitting on 8/109/2 for the season, Hogan can't be trusted as a WR4 until he shows something more.
report: Chris Hogan caught 1-of-1 targets for 25 yards in the Patriots' 38-7, Week 4 win over the Dolphins.

impact: Hogan's missed connection was an awful muff that resulted in a Tom Brady "interception." Hogan is sitting on 143 yards while he has yet to draw more than five targets in a game. Especially with Julian Edelman back in the mix, Hogan is hard to justify holding at this point. It is worth noting that he still led the Patriots' receiver corps in snaps this evening.
report: Chris Hogan caught 3-of-4 targets for 34 yards in the Patriots' Week 5 win over the Colts.

impact: Hogan's thigh injury looks to be minor. He hasn't been a factor this year and now that Julian Edelman is back from suspension, Hogan is barely worth roster consideration in fantasy leagues.
report: Chris Hogan (thigh) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Hogan is now headed in the wrong direction for Sunday night's game against the Chiefs. Although he's yet to clear 42 yards this season, Hogan's absence would free up snaps and targets for Josh Gordon.
report: Chris Hogan (thigh) was downgraded to "DNP" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Hogan sat out Thursday but is back on track to play Sunday night against the Chiefs.  Hogan has been unplayable in fantasy through five weeks.  He's behind at least Julian Edelman, Rob Gronkowski, and James White for looks.
report: Chris Hogan (thigh) returned to practice Friday.

impact: Hogan should play despite a mid-week downgrade. Even in a plus matchup, Hogan doesn't have enough target share to warrant fantasy consideration.
report: Chris Hogan (thigh) is questionable for Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: He showed up on the injury report with a thigh issue this week, though there's never been much concern about his status for Sunday night's game. Hogan has mostly been invisible this year, managing just 11 catches for 143 yards and two touchdowns across five games. With Josh Gordon's workload on the rise and Julian Edelman back from suspension, Hogan can probably be abandoned in most fantasy formats.
report: Chris Hogan (questionable, thigh) is expected to play Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: Hogan was a non-factor before a 45-yard catch late in the fourth quarter. This ended up being one of his better games, but Hogan is no higher than the No. 4 pass-game option. Hogan shouldn’t be in Week 7 fantasy lineups.
report: Chris Hogan caught four passes for 78 yards in Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: Hogan appeared to suffer a leg injury on the opening drive, but he quickly returned to the game. He was not heavily involved early, catching his first pass midway through the second quarter, but he surprisingly notched three quick catches in the third quarter and added a 19-yard grab on a fourth-quarter touchdown drive. He now has two solid games in a row, but it will be tough for him to build on this mini-breakout with Rob Gronkowski expected back next week. That said, it was still a step in the correct direction.
report: Chris Hogan hauled in 6-of-7 targets for 63 yards in the Patriots' Week 7 win over the Bears.

impact: Hill took a helmet to his right knee early in the third quarter and was immediately ruled out for the remainder of the game. That is never a good sign. Hill was involved on both offense and special teams before going down, blocking a punt and rushing the ball four times for 25 yards. He added a six-yard reception. A long-term loss would increase the need for Sony Michel (knee) to get cleared.
report: Patriots RB Jeremy Hill was forced from Sunday's game against the Patriots with a knee injury and will not return.

impact: Hill touched the ball five times in Sunday's win before going down. He took a helmet to the knee. Hill had also made an impact on special teams before his injury, blocking a punt. His absence will only clarify matters in the Patriots' backfield until Sony Michel returns, which could be as soon as Week 2. Hill turns 26 next month. He could have enough time to get healthy before training camp next summer. Hill is playing on a one-year deal.
report: Patriots placed RB Jeremy Hill on injured reserve with a torn right ACL, ending his season.

impact: All of his catches came after halftime as the Cardinals were forced to air it out trailing by 21. Seals-Jones was the intended receiver on Sam Bradford’s interception in the second half, which seemed to be a miscommunication. He also dropped a would-be touchdown in the fourth quarter, though Bradford could have placed the ball better. It was a rough opener for the second-year tight end, though his workload was somewhat encouraging. RSJ should probably be avoided next week in a difficult matchup against the Rams.
report: Ricky Seals-Jones chipped in with three catches for 19 yards on six targets Sunday in the Cardinals’ Week 1 loss to the Redskins.

impact: Seals-Jones disappointed by catching just 3-of-6 targets for 19 yards and dropping what should have been a touchdown, but his snap share is exactly what upside hunters were hoping to see. Perhaps he loses snaps when Jermaine Gresham (Achilles') is able to return, but he should be a streaming option in good matchups all season. Unfortunately, he gets the Rams next week.
report: Ricky Seals-Jones played 49-of-53 (92 percent) snaps Week 1.

impact: It is a disappointing line for Seals-Jones, but it is not his fault. Arizona's passing game is comatose with Sam Bradford under center. Unfortunately, Seals-Jones will not be a fantasy option until that changes, especially with Jermaine Gresham on the way back.
report: Ricky Seals-Jones hauled in 4-of-6 targets for 17 yards in the Cardinals' Week 2 loss to the Rams.

impact: Seals-Jones made his presence felt early with a 35-yard score down the left side where he was left all alone by the Chicago defense and walked into the end zone. His failed to convert his other two targets for receptions. Jermaine Gresham made a return on Sunday and drew a pair of targets as he will cut into a small portion of Seals-Jones' opportunity, which wasn't exactly strong to begin with. Seals-Jones now has eight catches for 61 yards through three games.
report: Ricky Seals-Jones caught 1-of-3 targets for 35 yards and a touchdown in Sunday's Week 3 loss to the Bears.

impact: The highlight of his day came on a 31-yard catch down the right sideline in which Josh Rosen put right on the money. It was second consecutive game in which Seals-Jones had a 30-yard reception. Through four weeks, Seals-Jones has reeled in 10-of-19 targets for 123 yards and a touchdowns. He will enter Week 5 as a TE2 option against the 49ers.
report: Ricky Seals-Jones caught 2-of-4 targets for 52 yards in Sunday's Week 4 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: Just brutal. RSJ still carries mild streaming appeal at an injury-ravaged fantasy position, though obviously the early returns for him have not been encouraging. The second-year tight end will look to rebound from Sunday's 0-for next time out against the Vikings.
report: Ricky Seals-Jones didn’t catch any of his six targets Sunday in the Cardinals’ Week 5 win over San Francisco.

impact: It's a solid rebound after Jones was held without a catch on six targets last week. He did almost all of his damage early before the Cardinals offense stalled out in the second half. Seals-Jones' highlight was a jump ball over Harrison Smith for 40 yards. He's a TE2 for Thursday night's matchup against the Broncos.
report: Ricky Seals-Jones caught 5-of-6 passes for 69 yards in Week 6 against the Vikings.

impact: The story of Seals-Jones' night was his apparent arm break in the second half, though he said after the game he escaped with a bruise. Although Josh Rosen went all the way off the rails this evening, RSJ will remain a low-end TE2 for Week 8 if he can get cleared.
report: Ricky Seals-Jones caught 2-of-4 targets for 12 yards in the Cardinals' Week 7 loss to the Broncos.

impact: It confirms he avoided what looked like a serious injury on Thursday night. With Josh Rosen struggling, Seals-Jones isn't a Week 8 streaming option.
report: Ricky Seals-Jones (forearm) is practicing fully for Week 8.

impact: Gordon's hamstring looked fine in last week's win over Indianapolis and he should be good to go for Sunday night's showdown with undefeated Kansas City. The 27-year-old was the recipient of Tom Brady's 500th career touchdown pass last week, which was also Gordon's first TD as a member of the Patriots. He'll be in a great spot against a sluggish Chiefs secondary this week, though with so many mouths to feed in Foxboro, Gordon will likely max out as a WR3 in fantasy.
report: Josh Gordon (hamstring) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: The Pats have yet to list Gordon as "full." With Chris Hogan (thigh) suddenly looking doubtful, perhaps Gordon can finally break through for a bigger snap and target share against the Chiefs' burnable defense.
report: Josh Gordon (hamstring) remained "limited" on Thursday.

impact: Josh Gordon hasn't had a full practice since getting traded to the Patriots, but he'll continue to play through his hamstring issues. With a matchup against the Chiefs' secondary, Gordon has the makings for a Week 6 breakout.
report: Josh Gordon (hamstring) is questionable for Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: As he has the past two weeks, Gordon will continue to play through his hamstring injury. Gordon has an inviting matchup against a sluggish Chiefs secondary but with so many mouths to feed in Foxboro, he's best viewed as a borderline WR3 for fantasy purposes.
report: Josh Gordon (questionable, hamstring) is expected to play Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: Gordon saw a season-high in snaps after being eased in the last two weeks. He missed a few plays with a shoulder injury in the first half but was cleared to return. Gordon's nine targets led the Patriots, so this is an encouraging game despite the middling stats. Gordon's role should continue to grow as he gets acclimated to OC Josh McDaniels' system.
report: Josh Gordon caught 5-of-9 passes for 42 yards in the Patriots' Week 6 win over the Chiefs.

impact: Only Julian Edelman played more snaps among the receivers, and Chris Hogan was in on just 47 plays. He also commanded a team-high nine targets. He only turned those looks into five catches for 42 yards, but this was a big step forward from a usage perspective. With his role growing, Gordon will finally worth considering as a starter this week against the Bears.
report: Josh Gordon played 63-of-78 snaps (81 percent) Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: That was certainly the case against the Chiefs when Gordon played 63-of-78 snaps on his way to nine targets. He only managed five catches for 42 yards with that opportunity, but he is clearly trending in the correct direction. He will be an upside WR3 this week against the Bears.
report: Patriots coach Bill Belichick said Josh Gordon's "role is expanding weekly."

impact: Gordon has still yet to get in a full practice since getting traded to the Patriots. He played a season-high 81 percent of snaps against the Chiefs and should continue to see his role grow in Week 7.
report: Josh Gordon (hamstring) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Gordon is fully healthy. He should see close to the 80 percent of snaps he played in Week 6.
report: Josh Gordon (hamstring) is questionable for Week 7 against Chicago.

impact: Gordon has been healthy for weeks, though the Patriots continue to list him on their injury report. The ex-Brown drew a season-high nine targets in Week 6 and should see another robust workload Sunday in Chicago, especially with Rob Gronkowski (back, ankle) sitting.
report: Josh Gordon (questionable, hamstring) is expected to play against the Bears in Week 7.
