impact: As are Julian Edelman (heel) and Sony Michel (knee). Gordon saw his playing time and target share jump last week, and he could see even more work with Rob Gronkowski (back) sidelined against the Bears. He is an upside WR3.
report: Josh Gordon (hamstring) is active for Week 7 against the Bears.

impact: The Patriots mostly focused on the short passing game early, but Gordon made his presence known with a great 20-yard catch in traffic on the final play of the first quarter. He dropped his second target on a low pass he probably should have worked back to, but he quickly made up for it by going high over a corner for a spectacular catch on fourth down. He was not able to repeat the feat on what would have been an impressive third-down catch in the third quarter, but he again made up for it with a 55-yard catch-and-run which ended just short of the goal line. The Patriots scored two plays later. Gordon now has 16 targets over the last two games, and while Rob Gronkowski is expected to return next week, it looks like he will have a big role moving forward. That makes him an upside WR3 next week in Buffalo.
report: Josh Gordon hauled in 4-of-7 targets for 100 yards in the Patriots' Week 7 win over the Bears.

impact: "I’m excited to see where we’re going," Brady added. Gordon had a few hiccups against the Bears, but he responded with a great, leaping catch on fourth down and a 55-yard catch-and-run to help set up a touchdown. He also played 95 percent of the snaps, besting the season-high of 81 percent he set the week before. The arrow is squarely pointing up for Gordon.
report: Tom Brady said his "confidence" in Josh Gordon is "growing and growing and growing."

impact: This is Gordon's normal routine with the Patriots. Playing ever more snaps and gaining Tom Brady's trust, Gordon has locked himself in as an every-week WR2.
report: Josh Gordon (hamstring) was "limited" in Thursday's practice.

impact: Gordon has yet to get in a full practice since joining the Patriots. He's in no danger of missing Monday night's game in Buffalo. Coming off a season-high 100 yards in last week's victory over the Bears, Gordon can once again be trusted as an every-week starter in fantasy.
report: Josh Gordon (hamstring) remained limited at Friday's practice.

impact: Coach Steve Wilks is also on board with getting more work for Williams and Kirk, who combined to catch one-of-five targets in Sunday's season-opening loss to Washington. "We targeted Larry [Fitzgerald] a lot last week, but I think those other guys are more than capable of making plays," said Wilks. "We've got to spread it around." Bradford showed zero chemistry with Arizona's non-Fitzgerald receivers in Week 1 and could be in danger of being replaced with first-round rookie Josh Rosen waiting in the wings. Offensively, the Cardinals are a disaster right now.
report: Sam Bradford wants to get Chad Williams and Christian Kirk more involved in the Cardinals' passing game, especially early in games.

impact: The Cardinals aren't close enough in talks to extend Johnson before Week 1. It's possible something gets done later this year, but Johnson looks destined to play out 2018 without a new deal. Arizona has leverage on Johnson after drafting a potential replacement in fourth-rounder Chase Edmonds. The Cardinals can franchise Johnson for around $11 million next offseason.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports the Cardinals haven't ruled out an in-season extension for David Johnson.

impact: It's a last minute deal on the eve of Week 1. The Cardinals were reportedly far apart in talks with Johnson as recently as Friday, but the sides were able to bridge the gap with a shorter-term extension. Johnson gets $30 million guaranteed and $13 million AAV, making him the second-highest paid back behind Todd Gurley. It's a player-friendly deal for Johnson coming off a lost 2017. One of the league's top all-purpose playmakers, Johnson is now signed through his age-29 season.
report: Cardinals signed David Johnson to a three-year, $39 million extension.

impact: It was a pedestrian debut for Johnson, though he somewhat salvaged the day for fantasy owners by punching in a late goal-line touchdown. That score gave the Cardinals their first points of the afternoon with 5:47 remaining in the fourth quarter. With Arizona way behind, the Cardinals mostly abandoned their running game in the second half with Johnson receiving just three carries after halftime. Arizona wasn't competitive on Sunday and could be in for a rough season. Negative game-script could hinder Johnson throughout the year, including next week in a tough matchup against the Rams.
report: David Johnson accrued 37 yards and a touchdown on nine carries along with five catches for 30 yards on nine targets Sunday in the Cardinals’ Week 1 loss to Washington.

impact: The injury doesn't appear to be a concern for Johnson's Week 2 availability, but it's a situation to monitor after he received disappointing usage in Arizona's opener.  On a downright bad team, Johnson will have to overcome more odds than most running backs to realize his elite fantasy potential.
report: David Johnson was limited in Wednesday's practice with a back injury.

impact: Johnson figures to get slapped with another "limited" tag. Per in-house writer Darren Urban, Johnson was "hitting the blocking sled plenty hard." The issue could explain why Johnson barely saw the field in the second half of last week's blowout loss to the Redskins. There has been little indication it will be a concern for Week 2 against the Rams.
report: David Johnson (back) practiced again on Thursday.

impact: Johnson said he feels "100 percent" and his participation level on Friday would seem to support that claim. Negative game script limited Johnson to just 14 touches in Week 1 and while that concern does exist for Week 2, DJ's pass-catching role should keep him in the RB1 discussion against the Rams.
report: David Johnson (back) was upgraded to a full practice on Friday and was not listed on the Cardinals' final injury report for Week 2 against the Rams.

impact: He was shockingly not targeted in the first half, and he finished the game with just one catch, although he had another called back by a penalty. Benching Sam Bradford is the first order of business, but the Cardinals have to better utilize Johnson if they want to have any success on offense, especially with Larry Fitzgerald dealing with a hamstring issue. Johnson will be more of an RB2 in a tough matchup with the Bears next week.
report: David Johnson rushed 13 times for 48 yards and hauled in 1-of-2 targets for three yards in the Cardinals' Week 2 loss to the Rams.

impact: Johnson's Weeks 1-2 usage under first-year OC Mike McCoy has been one of the most disappointing developments of the 2018 fantasy season thus far.  He has been used more as a ground-and-pound grinder than space back, running between the tackles and seeing diminished passing-game usage until pass-heavy comeback mode.  Wilks promised Monday that will change, and gave McCoy a vote of confidence.   "I have total confidence," said Wilks.  (We don't.)
report: Cardinals coach Steve Wilks promised Monday that David Johnson will run more routes in the slot going forward.

impact: The bright spot was a 21-yard touchdown catch in the 1st quarter off a play action where Johnson dusted a linebacker in coverage for an easy pitch and catch. A week after promising to get Johnson more usage split out as a receiver, that was not the case on Sunday. Johnson has now found the end zone in two of the first three games, but has now rushed 34 times for 116 yards (3.4 YPC) with 10 catches for 63 yards. With the Cardinals potentially turning to Josh Rosen as their starting quarterback things may begin to shift for Johnson moving forward, but he will only be a RB2 option next week against the Seahawks due to his floor potential when he fails to find the end zone.
report: David Johnson rushed 12 times for 31 yards while catching 4-of-4 targets for 30 yards and a touchdown in Sunday's Week 3 loss to the Bears.

impact: Despite coming off the field for multiple passing situations, Johnson managed to have his best game of the early season Sunday. Johnson broke off a long run of 21 yards and a long catch of 30 yards as Arizona finally fed him the ball for the first time in a game this season. He scored a 1-yard touchdown in the 2nd quarter after a pass interference in the end zone. Despite his slow start, Johnson has still managed to find the end zone in three of the first four games. Johnson will be in the lower-RB1 mix Week 5 against the 49ers.
report: David Johnson rushed 21 times for 71 yards and a touchdown while catching 3-of-4 targets for 41 yards in Sunday's Week 4 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: Johnson averaged a thoroughly underwhelming 3.1 yards per carry against the Niners but for fantasy purposes, all that matters is that he scored two touchdowns. Both were of the goal-line variety. That gives Johnson four touchdowns in his last three games and five for the year. After seeing a bizarrely light workload early on, the Cardinals have shown a renewed commitment to Johnson, feeding him 45 touches over the last two weeks. D.J. has been alarmingly inefficient this year but now that his volume is on the rise, Johnson can safely be reinserted as a weekly RB1 in all fantasy formats. His next test will come against the Vikings in Week 6.
report: David Johnson collected 55 yards and two touchdowns on 18 carries while snagging two catches for 16 yards on three targets Sunday in the Cardinals’ Week 5 victory over San Francisco.

impact: Johnson's struggles continued, but he managed to salvage his game with a late one-yard TD. He dropped a red-zone target, lost a fumble, and was stuffed on fourth-and-goal from the one-yard line before his touchdown. Johnson's pass game role remained small, finishing with just two catches for 15 yards. Johnson has looked nothing like the back he was in 2016. Despite a lackluster season to this point, Johnson will be a must-start against a Broncos defense which has given up back-to-back 200-yard rushers.
report: David Johnson rushed 18 times for 55 yards and a touchdown in Week 6 against the Vikings.

impact: If you were watching, you know how infuriating this was. The Cardinals' clueless coaching staff continued to run Johnson right up the middle, only looking to get him into space deep into garbage time in the fourth quarter. It was play-calling so bad it had to be seen to be believed. That's been a theme all season, of course. It appears tonight's disaster could cost OC Mike McCoy his job. Even if it does, Johnson will have a hard time hitting RB1 value against the 49ers' middle-of-the-road run defense in Week 8. There is shockingly little talent around him.
report: David Johnson rushed 14 times for 39 yards in the Cardinals' Week 7 loss to the Broncos, adding three receptions for 31 additional yards.

impact: "Everything," was Leftwich's response when asked what he wanted to replicate from Arians' Johnson approach. "I sat shoulder to shoulder with B.A. every day I was here. There have been a lot of long nights sitting next to him, us nodding off together." That means no more slamming Johnson between the tackles every play and much more extensive usage as a receiver/space back. That's what made Johnson a superstar in 2016. The lack of talent around Johnson remains a major concern, but his 2018 fantasy arrow is pointed back upward.
report: New Cardinals OC Byron Leftwich wants to emulate ex-coach Bruce Arians' usage of David Johnson.

impact: The Pats were dialing up some exotic runs but predictably could not get Patterson going as a pass catcher. No one can. Patterson isn't going to make a realistic push for fantasy value the final three weeks of Julian Edelman's suspension.
report: Cordarrelle Patterson rushed three times for 13 yards in the Patriots' Week 1 win over the Texans, adding a six-yard reception.

impact: Patterson set up the Bears’ first touchdown with a fumble on a kickoff return, but he made up for it in the second quarter. With the Patriots down 17-7, Patterson took a kickoff 95 yards to the house to close the deficit and turn the game around. Despite the big special teams play, he has no value in standard fantasy leagues.
report: Cordarrelle Patterson recorded a 95-yard kick-return touchdown in the Patriots' Week 7 win over the Bears.

impact: This follows comments from coach Steve Wilks earlier this week. Kirk and Chad Williams combined for five targets in the season opener. Kirk's rookie status has him behind Williams in two-wide sets, but we like his chances of overtaking the starting role.
report: Christian Kirk is expected to "get more opportunities" in Week 2 against the Rams.

impact: As promised, Kirk was more involved this week, but it did not matter much in a game Sam Bradford failed to top 100 yards. Kirk did have some good plays including a run after catch which almost netted him a first down on third-and-long, but he will not be a fantasy factor as long as Bradford is under center.
report: Christian Kirk hauled in 4-of-5 targets for 27 yards in the Cardinals' Week 2 loss to the Rams.

impact: He was rear-ended on the highway by a woman who attempted to hit and run, though Kirk followed her and took down her license plate number. Kirk doesn't appear to be hurt and should be fine for Week 3 against the Bears. The rookie remains off the re-draft radar.
report: Christian Kirk (back) was held out of Thursday's practice as a precaution after getting in a car accident on Wednesday.

impact: Kirk sat out Thursday's practice after getting into a minor car accident on Wednesday, but there was never much concern about his status for Sunday's game. Until the Cardinals make a change at quarterback, the second-round rookie won't be of any use to fantasy owners.
report: Christian Kirk (back) returned to practice on Friday.

impact: Krik missed some practice time for precautionay reasons after getting into a traffic accident. He's fine for Sunday's matchup with Chicago. Kirk saw more targets than Chad Williams last week, but his early season role remains limited.
report: Christian Kirk (back) was removed from the Cardinals' injury report.

impact: After catching 5-of-7 targets for 31 yards over the first two games of the season, Kirk lead the Cardinals across the board in targets, catches and yards on Sunday. His highlight on the day was a 32-yard catch in the 4th quarter from Sam Bradford. Kirk was then Josh Rosen's favorite target, seeing three targets on the two possessions that Rosen helmed. For now, Kirk is still only a speculation add at best as the Arizona offense is not one to expect a lot of consistent production from for their best players, let alone an ancillary option.
report: Christian Kirk caught 7-of-8 targets for 90 yards in Sunday's Week 3 loss to the Bears.

impact: Kirk trailed on Larry Fitzgerald in targets, but failed to produce much in Josh Rosen's first career start. Kirk was wide open for a potential touchdown in the 1st quarter, but Rosen went elsewhere with the football. Kirk is only worth a stash in deep leagues with Arizona's offense struggling to prop up any fantasy options at all at the moment.
report: Christian Kirk caught 4-of-5 passes for 28 yards in Sunday's Week 4 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: Kirk broke loose for a 75-yard touchdown on the Cardinals' first play from scrimmage. That was Arizona's longest play from scrimmage this year. It also marked his first career touchdown. The rookie's involvement dwindled after that as the Cardinals got ahead and rode David Johnson to the finish line. The 21-year-old has easily been the Cardinals' most productive receiver this year, leading the team in yards two of the past three weeks. He's not a must-own by any means but Kirk has certainly showed promise in the early going. We'll see if he can keep it up next week when the Cardinals head to Minnesota.
report: Christian Kirk corralled three-of-four targets for 85 yards and a touchdown Sunday in the Cardinals’ Week 5 win over the Niners.

impact: It's the second straight week Kirk's led the Cardinals in receiving. Kirk has been Josh Rosen's go-to target, with his seven targets finishing behind only Larry Fitzgerald (8). Kirk had 44 yards on the first two series before the Cardinals offense stalled out. His ROS outlook is on the rise with Rosen. Kirk is a WR3/FLEX for Week 7 against the Broncos.
report: Christian Kirk caught 6-of-7 passes for 77 yards in Week 6 against the Vikings.

impact: Kirk will run most of his Thursday night routes against Broncos RCB Bradley Roby, who's allowed the fourth-most yards in the league. The Cardinals should feature Kirk with Larry Fitzgerald facing Chris Harris in the slot. Kirk has been Josh Rosen's top target since taking over for Sam Bradford. We like him as an upside FLEX this week.
report: Christian Kirk has run 59 percent of his routes on the outside this season.

impact: Both Josh Rosen and OC Mike McCoy seemed to lose track of Kirk for long stretches of time. He still ended up clearing 50 yards for the third-straight game, and fourth in five. Producing ahead of Larry Fitzgerald for most of the season, Kirk's WR4 appeal for Week 8 will be enhanced if the Cardinals fire McCoy, as is looking likely.
report: Christian Kirk caught 3-of-6 targets for 57 yards in the Cardinals' Week 7 loss to the Broncos.

impact: All of his work came in the second half. It was an encouraging debut for the fourth-rounder, though it’s doubtful he’ll see enough work to really register in the fantasy realm. It would probably take an injury to David Johnson for him to be relevant.
report: Chase Edmonds rushed four times for 24 yards while also pulling in four catches for 24 yards on four targets Sunday in the Cardinals’ Week 1 loss to the Redskins.

impact: Coach Steve Wilks expressed optimism Edmonds would suit up despite missing consecutive practices earlier in the week. He was notably limited on Friday. Edmonds has been the only back to handle any amount of touches behind David Johnson this season. If out, Wilks would (finally) be forced to play Johnson on every snap.
report: Chase Edmonds (back) is questionable for Week 6 against the Vikings.

impact: Edmonds missed some practice time early this week, but it wasn't enough to keep him out. He should see his nomal change-up role behind David Johnson.
report: Chase Edmonds (back) is active for Week 6 against the Vikings.

impact: Edmonds came into the game questionable with a back injury. He looked healthy, but it's possible the Cardinals scaled his snaps back at less than 100 percent. Edmonds didn't have any setbacks. He'll be fine for his change-up role in Week 7.
report: Chase Edmonds had one carry for four yards in Week 6 against the Vikings.

impact: He was sacked twice for a loss of eight yards. Bradford’s Cardinals career couldn’t have gotten off to a worse start. His first half was an utter disaster as the former first overall pick completed just three passes for 11 yards. Bradford averaged a pathetic 4.5 yards per attempt while showing little in the way of accuracy. His interception was the result of a miscommunication with tight end Ricky Seals-Jones. The only receiver he showed any measure of chemistry with was Larry Fitzgerald, which was probably to be expected. Cardinals fans could be calling for Josh Rosen to start if Bradford endures another poor outing next week against the Rams.
report: Sam Bradford completed 20-of-34 passes for 153 yards with an interception and a lost fumble while adding seven yards on two carries Sunday in the Cardinals’ Week 1 loss to the Redskins.

impact: This was a second dreadful showing from Sam Bradford in a row. He averaged 3.3 yards per attempt, and the Cardinals did not cross midfield until the second-to-last play of the game. At least able to put the ball on target in the past, Bradford has not even been accurate this season, and the offense is going absolutely nowhere with him at quarterback. He probably should not have started this game, and the Cardinals are simply wasting time if they put him under center next week against the Bears.
report: Sam Bradford completed 17-of-27 passes for 90 yards and an interception in the Cardinals' 34-0 loss to the Rams in Week 2.

impact: The idea is a simpler play sheet will help the struggling offense get on the same page. "I think the thought is just allow everyone to go out there and play faster," Bradford said, "simplify everything a little bit and hopefully it shows up in the speed in which we play." Bradford is averaging four yards per attempt so far this season and has struggled to get the offense past midfield let alone to the end zone. Perhaps this strategy will help, but Arizona should make the switch to Josh Rosen sooner than later.
report: Sam Bradford said the Cardinals are scaling back their offense this week.

impact: Bradford's had a rough first two weeks, but the Cardinals have stayed with him to this point. He'll start Sunday, but is at risk of an in-game benching. Josh Rosen got some first-team practice reps this week and could see the field if the offense continues to struggle. The Cardinals can save $4 million in roster bonuses if they move on from Bradford after this week.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports "there are some around the league" who believe the Cardinals are thinking of benching Sam Bradford.

impact: This conflicts with some previous speculation. The entire Cardinals offense has been a disaster, so there's no rush to put Josh Rosen in a bad situation. Arizona believes Bradford is still their best quarterback despite his early year struggles.  Bradford looks to have at least a couple weeks of leash before the Cardinals consider turning to Rosen.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports the Cardinals plan on sticking with Sam Bradford.

impact: Things started off well for Bradford as he completed 4-of-5 passes for 92 yards and two touchdowns in the 1st quarter, but then things quickly deteriorated. For the remainder of his time of the field, Bradford completed 9-of-14 passes for 65 yards with two interceptions and a lost fumble as the Cardinals have surrendered a 14-0 lead at home. It remains to be seen if this is truly the end for Bradford as the Cardinals starting quarterback or just a one-week relief appearance, but Bradford is on his last life as an starting NFL quarterback.
report: Arizona has pulled Sam Bradford in favor of Josh Rosen with 4:31 left in the Sunday's Week 3 game versus the Bears, trailing 16-14.

impact: Wilks plans to watch tape before determining the starter against Seattle. Bradford was benched in the fourth quarter after three turnovers, but Josh Rosen struggled in relief — throwing an interception and pick-six that was called back. The Cardinals should announce their decision early next week.
report: Cardinals coach Steve Wilks wouldn't commit to Sam Bradford starting in Week 4.

impact: He'll be a healthy scratch. It's a cost-saving move for the Cardinals as Bradford is due a $312,500 roster bonus for each week he's active. Mike Glennon will back up Josh Rosen on Sunday and likely for the foreseeable future.
report: Sam Bradford will be inactive for Week 4 against the Seahawks.

impact: Bradford looked like he was hoping to retire in the first 11-plus quarters of the season, and he is now Arizona's third-stringer behind Josh Rosen and new-backup Mike Glennon.  The Cards signed Bradford to a two-year, $40 million contract in the offseason.  He is making $20 million in salary and bonuses this year and will cost $5 million against Arizona's 2019 cap even after he gets cut.
report: Coach Steve Wilks confirmed Monday that Sam Bradford will remain the Cardinals' third-string quarterback going forward.

impact: White actually led the Patriots in targets, though he predictably got out-carried 18-5 by Rex Burkhead. He had a free release on his 12-yard touchdown catch in the second quarter, getting left completely unaccounted for. White is going to feature in games where the Patriots feel they need to get the ball out quickly. That should definitely be the case in Week 2 against the Jaguars' elite defense.
report: James White caught 4-of-9 targets for 38 yards and a touchdown in the Patriots' Week 1 win over the Texans, adding five rushes for 18 yards.

impact: Unsurprisingly, White led the Patriots in targets as they looked to counteract the Jaguars' pass rush. White now has 11 grabs through two games. Great for the Patriots but replacement-level in fantasy football. White does have a solid Week 3 matchup in the Lions, but he is ideally treated as a bye week fill-in.
report: James White caught 7-of-8 targets for 73 yards in the Patriots' Week 2 loss to the Jaguars, adding four rushes for 11 additional yards.

impact: White scored his touchdown on a perfect throw from Tom Brady in the third quarter. He split passing reps with Rex Burkhead and was limited to third downs behind feature back Sony Michel. White got most of his rushing yardage against prevent coverage on the final drive of the game. With Burkhead dealing with a neck injury, White could have passing downs to himself in Week 4.
report: James White rushed four times for 37 yards and caught three passes for 14 yards and a touchdown in Week 3 against the Lions.

impact: The carries, rushing yards and receptions were all new season highs. With Rex Burkhead (neck) on injured reserve, White's fantasy production will be more bankable. He is a legitimate FLEX option in every format of fantasy.
report: James White caught 8-of-10 targets for 68 yards and a touchdown in the Patriots' Week 4 win over the Dolphins, adding eight carries for 44 yards and an additional score.

impact: Now that's how you PPR. Even with Julian Edelman back in the lineup, White drew five more targets than any other Patriot. He's now 18-of-24 for 145 yards and two scores as a receiver since Tom Brady talked him up before Week 4. The Pats dressed only two running backs this evening. White will be an RB2 for Week 6's likely shootout with the Chiefs.
report: James White caught 10-of-14 targets for 77 yards and a touchdown in the Patriots' Week 5 win over the Colts, gaining zero yards on two carries.

impact: White's seven targets were behind only Josh Gordon (9). He benefitted from a run-heavy approach from the Patriots and had a larger role in the run game than normal. White was held out of the end-zone for the first time since Week 3, but he continues to have a bankable floor. He's and RB2/FLEX for Week 7 against Chicago.
report: James White rushed six times for 39 yards and caught 5-of-7 passes for 53 yards in Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: Already being heavily utilized, it did not seem like White had much room to grow in this offense, but that changed when Sony Michel exited with a knee injury in the second quarter. Kenjon Barner mixed in, but White was the primary back the rest of the way. He parlayed that role into yet another receiving touchdown in the second quarter, cooking an overmatched Leonard Floyd to get wide open near the goal line, and he found the end zone again in the fourth quarter on a jet flip in which he beat the defense to the corner. He now has six receiving scores on the season. Most impressively, he was able to grind out two first downs to help kill the clock in the fourth quarter. With Michel looking likely to miss some time, White could return RB1 value the next several weeks.
report: James White rushed 11 times for 40 yards and hauled in 8-of-10 targets for 57 yards and two touchdowns in the Patriots' Week 7 win over the Bears.

impact: Burkhead is not even listed on the injury report, but Reiss contends there is "an acclimation process that still needs to take place." Perhaps he cedes more work than usual to Jeremy Hill -- Sony Michel (knee) is questionable at best -- but it would be a surprise if Burkhead does not lead New England in carries Week 1. Even so, he is a riskier than normal FLEX play.
report: ESPN's Mike Reiss expects Rex Burkhead (knee) to be "eased into the mix."

impact: Burkhead is over his summer knee issue and isn't even on the Week 1 injury report.  However, some around the team expect Burkhead to be eased into the mix after battling recurring injuries throughout his time in New England.  With Sony Michel (knee) likely to sit, it'll likely be Burkhead and Jeremy Hill on early downs with James White handling much of the pass-game work.  Burkhead could flirt with 12-15 touches, putting him on the RB2/3 line as a FLEX play.
report: NESN's Doug Kyed expects Rex Burkhead to be the Patriots' "top ball-carrier" Week 1 against the Texans.

impact: Burkhead was targeted just three times in the passing game but was the Patriots' clear-cut lead rusher, especially after Jeremy Hill departed early in the third quarter with a knee injury. Whether that remains the case for Week 2 will depend on Sony Michel's (knee) health. Going up against the Jaguars next week, Burkhead could be featured more as a pass catcher against an elite defense where the Pats will need to counteract the rush.
report: Rex Burkhead rushed 18 times for 64 yards in the Patriots' Week 1 win over the Texans, adding a five-yard reception.

impact: Burkhead wasn't checked for a concussion in Week 1, so this comes as a surprise. This may be from the hit he took on his second-quarter fumble. Burkhead has four days to get cleared for Sunday's Jacksonville matchup. With Jeremy Hill on IR and Sony Michel (knee) questionable, the Patriots could be down to Kenjon Barner and James White at running back.
report: Rex Burkhead is in the concussion protocol.

impact: Burkhead was listed as a DNP because of a concussion on the official injury report. The fact he was already in pads and participating suggests he is close to being cleared. His participation on Thursday should tell the story.
report: NBC Sports Boston's Phil Perry reports Rex Burkhead (concussion) was in pads and participated in individual drills during Wednesday's practice.

impact: He was officially limited, though Jim McBride of the Boston Globe called him "limited at best." Already without Jeremy Hill (torn ACL), New England's ground game will be on life support if neither Burkhead nor Sony Michel (knee) can get cleared to face the Jaguars. James White is going to see a lot of targets either way.
report: Rex Burkhead (concussion) was seen practicing on Thursday.

impact: First-round rookie RB Sony Michel (knee) is also questionable for Week 2. Both Burkhead and Michel were limited in practice throughout the week but have been prepping as if they'll play. Without Jeremy Hill (torn ACL) in the mix, New England's ground game would come to a complete halt if neither Burkhead nor Michel could suit up Sunday. Either way, James White projects to finish among the Pats' leaders in targets against Jacksonville.
report: Rex Burkhead (concussion) is questionable for Week 2 against the Jaguars.

impact: Burkhead remains in the concussion protocol, but this puts him on track to be cleared. Most reports suggest he'll play after a limited week of practice. The Patriots could also get back Sony Michel (questionable, knee) for Sunday's game.
report: Rex Burkhead (questionable, concussion) traveled with the Patriots to Jacksonville.

impact: If Burkhead indeed gets cleared, he will be a low-end RB2/FLEX, even with Sony Michel (knee) expected to make his NFL debut. The Pats will need to have the short-passing game cranking against the Jaguars' elite front seven. We should get Burkhead's official status a little before 3PM ET.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Rex Burkhead (concussion) is expected to suit up against the Jaguars but "needs to clear pre-game warmups without any setbacks."

impact: As is Sony Michel (knee), though Burkhead is expected to lead the Patriots' ground attack in carries. Burkhead is an RB2/FLEX in one of the toughest matchups he will have all year. Inactive for the Patriots are G/C Brian Schwenke, CB J.C. Jackson, WR Corey Coleman, DE Derek Rivers, RB Kenjon Barner, RT Marcus Cannon and CB Keion Crossen.
report: Rex Burkhead (concussion) is active for Week 2 against the Jaguars.

impact: Burkhead wasn't targeted in the passing game. Bafflingly, Burkhead "started" but then touched the ball zero times in the second or third quarter. Sony Michel was the only show in town on early downs with James White taking the lead in passing situations. It's possible Burkhead's multiple recent injuries played a part. Through two games, Burkhead has touched the ball just 25 times, with 19 of those coming in Week 1. With Michel healthy, Burkhead's RB2 status is up in the air. The Pats play the Lions in Week 3. The Lions have gotten mauled by pass-catching running backs early on.
report: Rex Burkhead rushed six times for 22 yards in the Patriots' Week 2 loss to the Jaguars.

impact: Sony Michel only managed 13 while James White got in 34. That suggests Burkhead's usage was game-plan specific, but it is still concerning he disappeared for most of the second and third quarters, especially with Michel back in the fold. That said, this could be a buying opportunity. New England has averaged 17.7 rushing touchdowns over the last six seasons, but they have zero through two games. That should change in a hurry, and Burkhead is the most likely recipient of those scores.
report: Rex Burkhead played 15-of-61 (25 percent) snaps Week 2 against the Jaguars.

impact: Burkhead went down with the injury in the fourth quarter. He didn't have a carry behind Sony Michel, but led the Patriots' backs in receiving with two catches for 26 yards. Burkhead is going to be in a race to get cleared for Week 4.
report: Rex Burkhead suffered a neck injury in Week 3 against the Lions.

impact: The Patriots tipped this move after re-signing Kenjon Barner. Neck injuries can be serious, so it's possible Burkhead is shut down for the season. Sony Michel was playing ahead of Burkhead before he went down and is locked into the lead back role. James White will also have pass downs to himself with Burkhead out.
report: Patriots placed RB Rex Burkhead (neck) on injured reserve.

impact: Anyone who's seen Sam Bradford play the past two weeks would agree the time is right now, though Keim insists the Cardinals won't rush their first-year signal-caller. "Some guys have played too early and it has crippled their career," said Keim. "There are guys who have come in and had success right away. But usually it's a rocky road." Perhaps Keim can draw inspiration from the Browns, who won their first game in nearly two years after handing the reins to first overall pick Baker Mayfield on Thursday night. With Bradford circling the drain, we're not sure what the Cardinals are waiting for, though it shouldn't be long until Rosen gets his opportunity under center.
report: Cardinals GM Steve Keim said first-round QB Josh Rosen will start "when the time is right."

impact: Sam Bradford will start but is on a short leash. The entire Cardinals offense has been a disaster the first two weeks, but Arizona doesn't want to put Rosen in a bad spot. Coach Steve Wilks and GM Steve Keim have been noncommittal on making the move to Rosen. The Cardinals may be forced into playing Rosen if Bradford doesn't rebound this week.
report: ESPN's Josh Weinfuss "wouldn't be surprised" if the Cardinals turn to Josh Rosen if the offense continues to struggle this week.

impact: Rosen was thrown into the game 4:31 left in the game and the Cardinals trailing by two points. Things started off positively as the Cardinals moved the ball into Bears territory, but then Rosen threw an interception in which he was late and behind Christian Kirk on an out route down the right sideline. This was a tough spot to place Rosen in for his first game action, but with Sam Bradford turning the ball over three more times Sunday, Rosen should finally get a look to start next week at home versus the Seahawks.
report: Josh Rosen completed 4-of-7 passes for 36 yards with an interception in Sunday's Week 3 loss to the Bears.

impact: Sam Bradford looked ready for retirement in Weeks 1-3 and was benched with 4:34 left in the fourth quarter of Sunday's loss to Chicago.  Rosen flashed some ability to move the offense on quick throws before his game-ending pick.  Rosen will make his first NFL start in Week 4 versus Seattle.  He could become an option in two-quarterback leagues but won't be a QB1 streamer anytime soon.
report: Cardinals coach Steve Wilks announced Monday that Josh Rosen will start at quarterback going forward.

impact: Rosen played well enough to win and lost multiple touchdowns on the day as Larry Fitzgerald and J.J. Nelson each dropped touchdown passes on the day. Rosen's first touchdown pass of his career came on a 22-yard pass to Chad Williams which he managed the pocket and tied the game in the 4th quarter. Despite the positive start, Rosen will not be an option Week 5 against the 49ers outside of deeper 2-QB leagues.
report: Josh Rosen completed 15-of-27 passes for 180 yards and one touchdown in Sunday's Week 4 loss to the Seahawks.

impact: He was sacked once for a loss of six yards. Rosen got his first win as an NFL starter in this one, though he wasn't asked to do very much and even when he did, the rookie was rarely on the same page with his receivers. The 21-year-old got his highlight out of the way early, hitting the mark on a 75-yard deep bomb to Christian Kirk on the Cardinals' very first play from scrimmage. He essentially took the rest of afternoon off, though he was also done in by a number of bad drops. Rosen will have his work cut out for him next week in a tough road matchup against the Vikings.
report: Josh Rosen completed 10-of-25 passes for 170 yards and a touchdown while losing three yards on his three carries Sunday in the Cardinals’ Week 5 win over the 49ers.

impact: Rosen had some success early but flatlined in the second half. He was under constant pressures, taking four sacks. Rosen continued to lock on to Christian Kirk, who led the Cardinals with 77 yards. It was a tough spot for Rosen on the road against the Vikings. He'll get another tough matchup with the Broncos on Thursday night.
report: Josh Rosen completed 21-of-31 passes for 240 yards with an interception in the Cardinals' Week 6 loss to the Vikings.

impact: Two of Rosen's picks were housed for scores. Rosen also tweaked his toe on the final play of the game but said he was "fine." This was one of the worst starts you will ever see from an NFL quarterback. Although he was getting zero help from his play-calling, Rosen was inexcusably bad, delivering passes late and not feeling pressure. He was lucky to escape with "only" five turnovers. Rosen does not have the biggest arm for a first-round quarterback, and it showed this evening. Which brings us back to the play-calling. OC Mike McCoy seems to have zero awareness of Rosen's strengths and weaknesses, dialing up one sideline out after another while all but ignoring play action. There's a strong chance he's fired during the Cardinals' "mini bye" and replaced by QBs coach Byron Leftwich.
report: Josh Rosen completed 21-of-39 passes for 194 yards, one touchdown and three interceptions in the Cardinals' 45-10, Week 7 loss to the Broncos, also losing two fumbles.

impact: Rosen is also headed for an MRI.  The injury occurred on the Cardinals' final offensive play as Rosen was getting sacked.  His toe appeared to get stuck in the turf a bit.  Afterwards, Rosen said he was "fine" and admitted he was being "soft."  Once the doctor takes a look, we should know more.
report: Josh Rosen injured his toe late in Thursday night's loss to the Broncos and is in a walking boot.

impact: It's good news after what looked like a serious injury. There was some concern with Rosen in a walking boot on Friday. Rosen's practice reps may be scaled back next week, but with the Cardinals on a mini-bye, he shouldn't be in danger of sitting out Week 8.
report: Cardinals coach Steve Wilks doesn't expect Josh Rosen (toe) to miss any time.

impact: Coach Steve Wilks has said Rosen won't miss any time, but his Week 8 is off on the wrong foot. The Cardinals do not have to issue an injury report until Wednesday. A "limited" session would have Rosen on track to suit up against the 49ers.
report: Josh Rosen (toe) was held out of Monday's practice.

impact: As expected.  Rosen injured his toe on the final play of last Thursday night's blowout against the Broncos, but he's fine for this week against the Niners.
report: Josh Rosen (toe) returned to a limited practice Wednesday.

impact: Michel was limited in practice throughout the week, though he was seen riding a stationary bike during the media portion of practice Thursday. It's likely the club is just limiting his reps for precautionary reasons in lieu of their Sunday night matchup against the Chiefs. If active, consider the rookie a strong RB1 against a poor Kansas City front-seven expected to be lacking OLB Justin Houston.
report: Sony Michel (knee) is questionable for Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport hedged by calling him a "game-time decision," though the expectation is that Michel will play along with teammates Josh Gordon (hamstring), Rob Gronkowski (ankle) and Chris Hogan (thigh), who are also listed as questionable. The rookie has topped 100 yards from scrimmage in back-to-back games while settling in as a weekly starter in fantasy. Despite losing passing-down reps to James White, Michel remains a solid RB2 in all formats.
report: Sony Michel (questionable, knee) is expected to play Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: Josh Gordon (hamstring), Rob Gronkowski (ankle) and Chris Hogan (thigh) are also active. There wasn't much doubt over any of them. Michel has 100 total yards the last two weeks and is a locked-in RB2. The Patriots inactives are DT Malcom Brown, CB J.C. Jackson, DE Keionta Davis, DE Geneo Grissom, OT Cole Croston, OL Ted Karras, and OLB John Simon.
report: Sony Michel (knee) is active for Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: Michel looked fully healthy despite being a game-time decision. The Patriots continued to feature him in an early-down role, giving him his largest workload of the year. Both of Michel’s touchdowns came on goal-line conversions, and he’s now scored in three straight games. Michel will remain a locked-in RB2 for Week 7.
report: Sony Michel rushed 24 times for 106 yards and two touchdowns in Week 6 against the Chiefs.

impact: This looks like maintenance after Michel had 24 carries playing through his knee injury last week. Michel is an RB2 for Week 7 against Chicago.
report: Sony Michel (knee) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: Michel saw limited work at practice this week, just as he did a week ago when he blew up for 106 yards and two touchdowns in a win over Kansas City. Even against a strong Bears front, he'll be in play as a borderline RB1 in all fantasy formats.
report: Sony Michel (knee) is questionable for Week 7 against the Bears.

impact: Michel's status for Sunday's game at Soldier Field was never in doubt. The rookie out of Georgia has quickly asserted himself as an every-week starter in fantasy, contributing over 100 yards from scrimmage in each of his last three contests with four touchdowns during that span. This week he finds himself on the RB1/2 borderline.
report: Sony Michel (questionable, knee) is expected to play against the Bears in Week 7.

impact: As are Julian Edelman (heel) and Josh Gordon (hamstring). Michel's matchup is not ideal, but he has dominated carries the last several weeks and has as much touchdown upside as any back this side of Todd Gurley. He remains a back-end RB1.
report: Sony Michel (knee) is active Week 7 against the Bears.

impact: Sony Michel had his left leg twisted as he was being tackled at the end of a second-quarter run. He immediately dropped the ball and appeared to be in serious pain as he was helped off the field. He was eventually carted to the locker room. The injury is a big concern considering Michel had questions about his knees in the pre-draft process and was not ready for Week 1 because of a knee scope in August. With Michel out, James White should dominate the backfield work.
report: Sony Michel exited Week 7 against the Bears with a left knee injury.

impact: Michel's MRI brought back good news, but no one seems to know just how good. It still appears likely that Michel will miss next Monday's game against the Bills. We might not get our first formal update from the Patriots until Thursday, when they are required to issue their first Week 8 injury report. Fantasy owners should plan on being without Michel for at least game. Considering his history of knee woes, it could still be longer.
report: NFL.com's Ian Rapoport reports Sony Michel's knee injury is "not considered serious," though it's unclear how long he might be sidelined.

impact: It is the best possible news, though we would still consider Michel on the wrong side of questionable for Week 8 against the Bills. The Patriots are not going to take any chances in a game they could win with their second-team. James White will be in the RB1 mix while perhaps Kenjon Barner or a free agent addition will rotate in behind.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports Sony Michel (knee) has avoided structural damage and is week to week.

impact: The Patriots don't have to release an official practice report until Thursday with them playing on Monday night.  Either way, Michel is expected to sit.
report: Sony Michel (knee) is not practicing Wednesday.

impact: Michel also did not practice Wednesday and appears to be on the wrong side of questionable for Monday night. James White is shaping up as a high-end RB1 while Kenjon Barner could provide FLEX value if the Patriots do not add someone in the next couple days.
report: Sony Michel (knee) did not practice Thursday.

impact: Michel's knee injury wasn't as bad as initially feared, though it's likely to keep him out this week. Riding an unbelievable hot streak, James White will be an obvious RB1 in all formats going against a Bills defense that just yielded 159 yards to Marlon Mack in Week 7.
report: Sony Michel (knee) remained sidelined at Friday's practice.

impact: Michel didn't suffer a serious knee injury (as initially feared) against the Bears, but he was still considered week-to-week. He's quickly bucked that status and sat up like the Undertaker, returning to practice only a few short days post-injury. We don't expect him to play Monday night, but this development does leave the possibility open. Kenjon Barner would be the odd man out on early downs if Michel somehow suits up.
report: Sony Michel (knee) returned to practice Saturday.

impact: The Patriots limited Guerrero's access to the team last season, which caused a major rift between Brady and coach Bill Belichick. That issue seems to have been resolved, however, as Guerrero will still be allowed to work with Brady and Rob Gronkowski and will be allowed to travel with the team, though he's expected to go on fewer trips this year than he has in the past. The Patriots are doing all they can to accommodate Brady coming off yet another MVP season in 2017.
report: According to NFL Network's Ian Rapoport, the Patriots have reached a compromise with Tom Brady's personal trainer Alex Guerrero.

impact: Brady got off to a Foles-ian start, generating just 92 yards on his first 18 attempts. Of course, two of those completions were touchdowns, one a 21-yard strike to Rob Gronkowski who showed off some fancy footwork near the goal line. Brady and the Pats' offense woke up as the day progressed, with Brady sticking some important throws late. The Pats' weapons-limited offense could lack for elite rate stats while Julian Edelman is sidelined, but overwhelming volume will continue to take the day. That being said, Brady has as daunting of a matchup as possible for Week 2, as the Pats will be venturing to Jacksonville.
report: Tom Brady completed 26-of-39 passes for 277 yards, three touchdowns and an interception in the Patriots' 27-20, Week 1 win over the Texans.

impact: Brady added three rushes for 10 yards. Brady did about what was expected against the Jaguars' elite defense. It was the Patriots' D that let the team down on the road. The game was decided in the third quarter, where the Pats couldn't get the Jags off the field as they took up half the quarter on a field goal drive. Brady couldn't connect with Rob Gronkowski but did rekindle his connection with Chris Hogan, finding him for two scores. Brady is going to find much smoother sailing in Week 3 against the Lions, especially if No. 1 CB Darius Slay (concussion) can't play.
report: Tom Brady completed 24-of-35 passes for 234 yards and two touchdowns in the Patriots' 31-20, Week 2 loss to the Jaguars.

impact: Brady got off to a slow start with the Lions dominating time of possession. The Patriots couldn't get anything going in second-half comeback mode, but he still managed to throw a perfect 10-yard touchdown to James White. Brady made some mental errors, picking up a drive killing intentional grounding in the fourth quarter followed by a forced interception into double coverage. This will likely go down as one of Brady's worse games. New England has a matchup with the division-leading Dolphins in Week 4.
report: Tom Brady completed 14-of-26 passes for 133 yards with a touchdown and an interception in the Patriots' Week 3 loss to the Lions.

impact: Brady got off to a slow start, relying on the running game and Dolphins mistakes to get the Patriots some momentum. He heated up, finding Cordarrelle Patterson for a 55-yard screen score before delivering some real touchdown dimes to Phillip Dorsett and James White. It was Brady's best performance of the season, though he still appeared to be lacking arm drive at times, including both his interceptions. The first was a bad decision to a blanketed Dorsett. The second was a (late) blind heave into traffic. Brady needs Julian Edelman back, which he will receive in Week 5 against the Colts on Thursday Night Football. Of concern is that Rob Gronkowski checked out against the Dolphins with an ankle injury.
report: Tom Brady completed 23-of-35 passes for 274 yards, three touchdowns and two interceptions in the Patriots' 38-7, Week 4 demolition of the Dolphins.

impact: The scores were the 498th, 499th and 500th of Brady's incomparable career. Despite an egregious Julian Edelman drop on a potential long completion, Brady entered the break 23-of-27 for 203 yards and two of his scores. The Pats' offense was not nearly as crisp after halftime, though Brady tallied score 500 on what you could argue was an ill-advised end zone jump ball to Josh Gordon. Brady has yet to hit on all cylinders for an entire game this season, but he is getting closer. Edelman's return was an immediate hit. A Week 6 shootout against the Chiefs on Sunday Night Football awaits.
report: Tom Brady completed 34-of-44 passes for 341 yards, three touchdowns and two interceptions in the Patriots' 38-24, Week 5 win over the Colts.

impact: This was a gritty one for Brady, who had just 113 yards at half. The Patriots went with a run-heavy attack early, but were forced to throw in a second-half boat race with the Chiefs. Brady made up for his lack of touchdowns with a rushing score in the fourth quarter. His only real mistake was a late third-quarter fumble, but he engineered a game-winning field goal drive for the win. Brady has looked much better over the last three weeks with an improved supporting cast. He'll get a matchup with Chicago in Week 7.
report: Tom Brady completed 24-of-35 passes for 340 yards and a touchdown in the Patriots' Week 6 win over the Chiefs.

impact: Focusing on the short-passing game, Brady peppered his running backs and Julian Edelman with targets on his way to an opening touchdown drive. Edelman caught that touchdown, and he found James White for his other two scores -- a short pass into the flats in the second quarter and a shovel pass on a jet sweep in the fourth. He did push the ball down the field later in the game, finding Josh Gordon with a tight-window pass for 20 yards on the final play of the first quarter and then hitting the receiver again for a fourth-down conversion. He found Gordon again for a 55-yard gain in the second half to set up his third touchdown. Brady now has three touchdowns in three of his last four games, and he has topped 300 yards in two of those. He will be a high-end QB1 in Buffalo next Monday night.
report: Tom Brady completed 25-of-36 passes for 277 yards, three touchdowns, and an interception in the Patriots' Week 7 win over the Bears.

impact: Ballage has been a healthy inactive for each of his first two NFL games.
report: Dolphins declared RB Kalen Ballage, WR DeVante Parker, QB Luke Falk, QB David Fales, OT Zach Sterup, and CB Cordrea Tankersley inactive for Week 2 against the Jets.

impact: Kenny Stills was Miami's big-play weapon, while Amendola (six targets), Jakeem Grant (seven), and Albert Wilson (four) essentially shared time.  Beyond Stills, this will be a tough situation to invest in for fantasy purposes.
report: Danny Amendola caught 4-of-6 targets for 26 yards in the Dolphins' Week 1 win over Tennessee.

impact: He had three catches on three targets for 27 yards before briefly exiting, then returning.
report: Danny Amendola exited Sunday's Week 2 game to be checked for a concussion, but returned.

impact: He has drawn 6 and 4 targets through two games in Miami's low-volume passing offense, where Ryan Tannehill has yet to attempt 30 throws.  Amendola is capable of flirting with PPR value in games where Tannehill is forced to throw more, but the Dolphins' game plans are consistently balanced to run heavy.
report: Danny Amendola caught 4-of-4 targets for 32 yards in the Dolphins' Week 2 win over the Jets.

impact: That's about what Amendola has done all three games in a Dolphins uniform. He's the chain-mover in a receiver corps full of big-play threats. Even in PPR leagues, it is not going to translate to fantasy value.
report: Danny Amendola caught 3-of-3 targets for 42 yards in the Dolphins' Week 3 win over the Raiders.

impact: The two-catch afternoon came even with DeVante Parker (quad) sitting. Amendola has 13 grabs for 121 yards through his first four games as a Dolphin, putting him on pace for 52/484. If Amendola appears in all 16 games, it would be the first time he has done so since 2014.
report: Danny Amendola caught 2-of-3 targets for 21 yards in the Dolphins' Week 4 loss to the Patriots.

impact: Amendola led the Dolphins in targets with Ryan Tannehill checking down all game. His biggest play was a 16-yard contested catch on third down in second quarter, but he wasn't much of a factor. With DeVante Parker on track to return next week, Amendola's target share is going to take a hit.
report: Danny Amendola caught 3-of-4 passes for 30 yards in Week 5 against the Bengals.

impact: Amendola saw plenty of work in the win, though he averaged just 7.1 yards per reception with a long gain of 11 yards. Leonard Floyd pulled a wrestling move on Amendola in the first quarter but luckily the diminutive slot receiver was able to shake it off. Amendola's season-long touchdown drought continued against Chicago, though he saw more targets in this game than he had in his previous three combined. The veteran will go against Matt Patricia, another former Patriot, when the Dolphins host Detroit in Week 7.
report: Danny Amendola absorbed eight-of-11 targets for 59 yards Sunday in the Dolphins’ Week 6 win over Chicago.

impact: With DeVante Parker inactive and Albert Wilson (hip) banged up early, Amendola posted a new season-high for yardage. He now has 14 grabs on 18 targets over his past two games. With Kenny Stills joining Wilson on the shelf late against the Lions, Amendola could have some Week 8 relevance against the Texans.
report: Danny Amendola caught 6-of-7 targets for 84 yards and a touchdown in the Dolphins' Week 7 loss to the Lions.

impact: Amendola has been Brock Osweiler's favorite receiver through two starts, and he is on track to be an underrated WR3 play in PPR leagues on Thursday Night Football against the Texans.  His injury status is still worth monitoring, though.
report: Danny Amendola was listed as a limited participant in Monday's practice.

impact: There does not seem to be any concern about Amendola's Thursday night status. With Kenny Stills and Albert Wilson out, Amendola will be in the WR3 mix.
report: Danny Amendola (shoulder) remained "limited" on Tuesday.

impact: In Brock Osweiler's two starts, Amendola has 14 catches for 143 yards and a touchdown on 18 targets.  He's in the WR3 mix this week with Kenny Stills (groin) out and Albert Wilson (hip) sent to injured reserve.
report: Danny Amendola (shoulder) has been removed from the Week 8 injury report and will play Thursday night against the Texans.

impact: The highlight was Amendola's touchdown throw in the third quarter. He showed feathery ball placement on a cross-field pass to Kenyan Drake. The five receptions were a mild disappointment on a night where both Albert Wilson and Kenny Stills were sidelined, though Amendola now has 19 grabs over his past three games after entering Week 6 with just 16 on the year. Amendola should not have trouble finding space against the Jets' banged up secondary in Week 9.
report: Danny Amendola caught 5-of-6 targets for 43 yards in the Dolphins' Week 8 loss to the Texans, adding a 28-yard touchdown pass.

impact: Derby suffered the injury in Sunday's win against Oakland. He had been playing 56 percent of snaps, so this is good for Mike Gesicki's playing time. The Dolphins would likely promote Nick O'Leary from the practice squad if Derby's ruled out this week.
report: Dolphins TE AJ Derby (foot) isn't practicing Wednesday.

impact: Derby hurt his foot in the Dolphins' Week 3 win against the Raiders. The injury kept him out of practice Wednesday and Thursday, which doesn't bode well for his availability Sunday. Derby has played 56.6 percent of snaps this season, so if he misses the game, it could open up snaps for second-round pick Mike Gesicki.
report: Dolphins TE AJ Derby (foot) missed another practice Thursday.

impact: This was expected after Derby missed practice all week. The early rule out suggests this may be a multi-game absence. It's great news for Mike Gesicki, who's played just 49 percent of snaps. Gesicki should be have an every-down role against the Raiders.
report: Dolphins TE AJ Derby (foot) has been ruled out for Week 4.

impact: He's looking at a multi-game abesence after sitting out last week. Mike Gesicki played 84 percent of snaps against the Patriots with Derby out.
report: Dolphins TE AJ Derby (foot) remained sidelined at Wednesday's practice.

impact: He'll miss his second straight game. With Derby out, Mike Gesicki is locked into a near every-down role.
report: Dolphins TE AJ Derby (foot) is out for Week 5.

impact: Derby returned to limited practice after sitting out the last two games. This is only notable for Mike Gesicki's playing time. Gesicki has had a near every-down role with Derby out.
report: Dolphins TE AJ Derby (foot) is questionable for Week 6 against Chicago.

impact: It puts him on track to play after sitting the last three weeks. Derby returning could cut into Mike Gesicki's snaps.
report: Dolphins TE AJ Derby (foot) practiced fully on Wednesday.

impact: Derby was downgraded to limited after practicing fully the last two days. He's looking like a game-time decision. Derby sitting would lock Mike Gesicki into an every-down role.
report: Dolphins TE AJ Derby (foot) is questionable for Week 7 against Detroit.

impact: Derby looks on the wrong side of questionable after only getting in one limited practice. Mike Gesicki (shoulder) is also questionable but is expected to play.
report: Dolphins TE AJ Derby (foot) is questionable for Week 8 against the Texans.

impact: Gesicki played a ton, but he's not yet on the same page as Ryan Tannehill.  As Miami heads to face the Jets, look elsewhere for Week 2 tight end streamers.
report: Mike Gesicki caught 1-of-2 targets for 11 yards in the Dolphins' Week 1 win over the Titans.

impact: Gesicki has a world of talent, but he's simply not a big part of Miami's passing game yet.  He has played behind AJ Derby in each of the Dolphins' first two games and doesn't warrant a roster spot outside of Dynasty leagues.
report: Mike Gesicki was not targeted in the Dolphins' Week 2 win over the Jets.

impact: Even with starter AJ Derby sitting, Gesicki was invisible. The No. 42 overall pick has five grabs through four games. He's on pace for 204 yards.
report: Mike Gesicki caught 1-of-2 targets for nine yards in the Dolphins' Week 4 loss to the Patriots.

impact: It's one of his better games of the season. With AJ Derby out, Gesicki's role has been trending up, but the Dolphins need to get him more involved in an offense that lacks playmakers. Gesicki has a matchup with Chicago in Week 6.
report: Mike Gesicki caught 3-of-5 passes for 23 yards in Week 5 against the Bengals.

impact: The rookie took a backseat to Nick O’Leary, who outgained him by nearly 40 yards. Despite his immense athleticism, the Penn State alum has yet to become a factor in the fantasy realm. He’ll be off the streaming radar against Detroit in Week 7.
report: Mike Gesicki corralled one-of-two targets for 11 yards Sunday in the Dolphins’ Week 6 win over Chicago.

impact: Gesicki was also evaluated for a concussion but thankfully cleared. The 44 yards were a new career high. He could break that number again in Week 8 if neither Albert Wilson (hip) nor Kenny Stills (leg) can get cleared for Thursday Night Football against the Texans. That being said, Gesicki will remain a last-gasp TE2.
report: Mike Gesicki caught 3-of-3 targets for 44 yards in the Dolphins' Week 7 loss to the Lions.

impact: The rookie was upgraded to full practice on Wednesday after being a limited participant early in the week. Gesicki should be ready for Thursday night's game in Houston, though his fantasy prospects are minimal at best.
report: Mike Gesicki (shoulder) is questionable for Week 8 against the Texans.

impact: With Kenny Stills (groin) and Albert Wilson (hip) sidelined, Gesicki could be needed for a bigger role one week after setting a new yardage high. Also inactive for the Dolphins are QB Ryan Tannehill, CB Torry McTyer, DE Cameron Malveaux, OT Sam Young, TE A.J. Derby and DE Charles Harris.
report: Dolphins TE Mike Gesicki (shoulder) is active for Week 8 against the Texans.

impact: The catches and yards were both new season highs, though the story of Gesicki's night was the two huge hits he took. Gesicki has shown a tendency to let himself get blown up early in his career. It's resulted in a shoulder injury and Week 7 concussion evaluation. Even with the Dolphins majorly banged up at receiver, Gesicki barely has any TE2 value.
report: Mike Gesicki caught 4-of-5 targets for 14 yards in the Dolphins' Week 8 loss to the Texans.

impact: This is how Parker was trending after coach Adam Gase downplayed his odds of returning earlier this week. With Parker out, Jakeem Grant and Albert Wilson will continue to pick up his targets. The rest of Miami's inactives are  QB David Fales, DE Cameron Wake, CB Bobby McCain, TE A.J. Derby, and OT Zach Sterup.
report: DeVante Parker (quad) is inactive for Week 5 against the Bengals.

impact: Parker has missed the last two weeks despite practicing on a limited basis. The Dolphins have no reason to push Parker with Jakeem Grant and Albert Wilson playing well, but his quad injury was never overly serious. Unproductive in his only game this year, Parker won't be guaranteed a ton of snaps when he returns.
report: The Miami Herald reports the Dolphins expect DeVante Parker (quad) to return in Week 6.

impact: Parker has been an injury-riddled underachiever to this point in his career, so it makes perfect sense for the Dolphins to see what they can get. Unfortunately, not a whole lot is almost certainly the answer, especially considering Parker is owed $9.387 million next season after the Dolphins picked up his fifth-year option in April. Parker has played one game so far this season.
report: The Athletic's Michael Lombardi reports the Dolphins are shopping DeVante Parker.

impact: He had the same designation last week before not playing against the Bengals.  Parker should be good to return this week against the Bears, but he's miles away from fantasy relevance and has been subject to trade talk.
report: DeVante Parker (quad) was limited in Wednesday's practice.

impact: Parker hasn't played since injuring his quad at practice two weeks ago. He's been working on a limited basis this week but remains noncommittal on his Week 6 status. "I’m just going a day at a time and working my way back in there," he said. The injury-prone 25-year-old has been the subject of recent trade rumors, suggesting he could be on the outs in Miami.
report: When asked about his availability for Week 6 against the Bears, DeVante Parker (quad) said, "I'm not really sure."

impact: Parker got in limited practice this week but has been noncommittal on his status. He's looking like a game-time decision for Sunday. Parker's snaps may be limited even if he plays. He shouldn't be in Week 6 fantasy lineups.
report: DeVante Parker (quad) is listed as questionable for Week 6 against Chicago.

impact: Active for only the second time this year, the injury-prone Parker was targeted just once, which resulted in an interception by quarterback Brock Osweiler. The 26-year-old has never delivered on his first-round hype and could be a goner at the trade deadline later this month. He's not fantasy relevant.
report: DeVante Parker couldn’t haul in his lone target Sunday in Miami’s Week 6 win over the Bears.

impact: It confirms he didn't have any setbacks after returning last week. Parker is behind Kenny Stills, Albert Wilson and Danny Amendola for targets. He's not fantasy relevant.
report: DeVante Parker (quad) is practicing in full for Week 7.

impact: Parker practiced fully all week. He'll play in his second straight game since returning Sunday but is behind Kenny Stills, Albert Wilson and Danny Amendola for targets. Parker shouldn't be in Week 7 fantasy lineups.
report: DeVante Parker (quad) is questionable for Sunday's game with Detroit.

impact: Parker trade rumors have been out for awhile, but talks are starting to heat up with the deadline approaching. The Dolphins don't need Parker and are higher on Albert Wilson and Danny Amendola behind Kenny Stills. Miami is going to have to lower their third-round asking price if they want to move the perennially-injured Parker. Parker's fifth-year option was picked up before the season, so he's signed through 2019.
report: The Miami Herald confirms the Dolphins have "spoken to multiple teams" about trading DeVante Parker.

impact: Although technically on the injury report, Parker got in a full week of practice. He's a healthy scratch. The Dolphins have correctly determined they are better off moving forward with Kenny Stills, Albert Wilson, Danny Amendola and Jakeem Grant as their top-four wideouts. Parker is a strong candidate to be traded before next week's deadline. Also inactive for the Dolphins are QB Ryan Tannehill, S Maurice Smith, DE Jonathan Woodard, OT Sam Young, TE A.J. Derby and DE Charles Harris.
report: DeVante Parker (quad) is inactive for Week 7 against the Lions.

impact: The Dolphins have reportedly spoken with "multiple" teams, but the Eagles are the first identified by name. Parker is a de facto healthy scratch for Sunday's game with the Lions. The Dolphins appear desperate to move on before next week's trade deadline.
report: The Miami Herald reports the Dolphins have talked about a DeVante Parker trade with the Eagles.

impact: Parker was a surprise inactive despite practicing fully all week. With Albert Wilson (hip) going down, the Dolphins could have used Parker Sunday in a shootout loss to Detroit. This looks similar to the Jay Ajayi situation last year, with friction between Parker and Miami's coaching staff. Parker is a strong candidate to be traded at next week's deadline.
report: DeVante Parker's agent confirmed he's fully healthy.

impact: The Dolphins visit the Texans on Thursday Night Football, and Parker is on track to start on the outside opposite Jakeem Grant with Danny Amendola in the slot.  Parker's agent recently blasted Gase and the organization, but they need his client now with Kenny Stills ruled out and Albert Wilson likely headed to I.R.  Battling a quad injury, Parker has played fewer than 40 snaps on the year.
report: Coach Adam Gase confirmed Monday that DeVante Parker (quad) will play in Week 8.

impact: A de facto healthy scratch the past few weeks, Parker was only forced into the lineup because of injuries to Albert Wilson and Kenny Stills. He responded by dominating targets and posting the most yards of his four-year career. 46 of them came on a fluke ball that hit off of Jakeem Grant's hands and then a helmet, but Parker was feasting even before that. It's now looking extremely unlikely that Parker is dealt ahead of next week's trade deadline. The Dolphins will be facing the Jets' banged up secondary in Week 9.
report: DeVante Parker caught 6-of-9 targets for 134 yards in the Dolphins' Week 8 loss to the Texans.

impact: Suddenly a Dolphin a few weeks ago, O'Leary now has five catches over his past two games. He should stay involved for the Dolphins' Week 8 Thursday night game, as both Albert Wilson (hip) and Kenny Stills (leg) are banged up.
report: Nick O'Leary caught 2-of-3 targets for 23 yards in the Dolphins' Week 7 loss to the Lions.

impact: He beat Buster Skrine for a 29-yard score but was otherwise quiet.  Operating as Miami's No. 3/4 receiver in a rotation with Danny Amendola, Kenny Stills, and Jakeem Grant, Wilson has drawn 4 and 5 targets through two weeks.  The Dolphins' low-volume passing offense limits the upside of all its members.  Wilson led the team in receiving yards with just 37 on Sunday.
report: Albert Wilson caught 3-of-5 targets for 37 yards and a touchdown in the Dolphins' Week 2 win over the Jets.

impact: For the passing touchdown, Wilson got the ball on a double reverse then delivered a perfect strike down the right sideline to Jakeem Grant. For the receiving, Wilson took a shovel pass from Ryan Tannehill, found the edge, hit the hole and exploded through the Raiders' entire defense for a 74-yard score. Electrifying stuff. Of course, Wilson has just eight grabs through three games. He will make big plays in the Dolphins' creative offense, but the road to re-draft value is too long and winding.
report: Albert Wilson caught 2-of-2 targets for 74 yards and a touchdown in the Dolphins' Week 3 win over the Raiders, adding a 52-yard touchdown pass.

impact: Wilson how has five touches in 3-of-4 games, though he's on pace for a modest 712 yards from scrimmage. Wilson seems like a classic "better in real life than fantasy" player.
report: Albert Wilson caught 4-of-6 targets for 19 yards in the Dolphins' Week 4 loss to the Patriots, adding a two-yard rush.

impact: This was only the second 100-yard receiving game of Wilson's career. The first-year Dolphin did nearly all of his damage in the second half, blowing up for 150 yards after the break. Wilson showed game-breaking speed in the fourth quarter by turning a simple dump-off from Brock Osweiler into a 43-yard touchdown. He bettered that with a 75-yard touchdown later in the quarter, which tied the game at 28 with just over three minutes remaining. With so many mouths to feed in Miami, Wilson won't be someone fantasy owners can consistently rely on, though his touchdown prowess—he's now visited the end zone four times this season—puts him in play as a bye-week fill-in/DFS dart throw. We'll see what he does for an encore next week against the Lions.
report: Albert Wilson delivered six catches for 155 yards and two touchdowns on nine targets Sunday in Miami’s Week 6 victory over the Bears.

impact: Wilson had his knee looked at on the sideline before limping to the locker room. Wilson was injured after taking an awkward step evading a tackle at the end of a 24-yard reception. He was soaking up targets before departing. If Wilson is done for the day, the Dolphins will be down to three active receivers.
report: Albert Wilson was forced from Sunday's game against the Lions with a right leg injury and is questionable to return.

impact: The exact nature of Wilson's injury remains unclear. The Dolphins will finish the game with just three active receivers.
report: Albert Wilson (leg) has been ruled out for the second half of the Dolphins' Week 7 game against the Lions.

impact: Wilson was previously listed with a leg injury. He'll undergo an MRI to determine the severity, but with Miami playing on Thursday night, he's likely out this week. The Dolphins may be forced to hold on to DeVante Parker if Wilson misses extended time.
report: The Miami Herald confirms Albert Wilson is dealing with a hip injury.

impact: "The best-case scenario is that he would miss a few weeks," Rosenhaus added. NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports Wilson is dealing with a labral issue in his hip. With Kenny Stills also injured, the Dolphins are down to Danny Amendola, Jakeem Grant, and a disgruntled DeVante Parker at receiver.
report: Agent Drew Rosenhaus said Albert Wilson's hip injury could cost him the season.

impact: All we really know is that Wilson is going to miss multiple games. Even if it's not a season-ending issue, Wilson will probably be sent to injured reserve to heal. He's droppable in all formats of fantasy.
report: Albert Wilson (hip) is visiting a specialist to determine the severity of his injury.

impact: Kenny Stills (groin) has also been ruled out, leaving Danny Amendola and Jakeem Grant as the Dolphins' top-two wideouts. DeVante Parker should also be active after his recent de facto healthy scratches.
report: Albert Wilson (hip) has been ruled out for Week 8 against the Texans.

impact: Wilson doesn't need hip surgery, but the Dolphins want to give him time to recover correctly, so he will hit the injured reserve. Wilson, who can't return once he's placed on IR since the Fins already designated two players to return this season, is still only 26 years old and will be back with the Dolphins next season. With Kenny Stills ruled out for Week 8, the Dolphins will trot out Danny Amendola, Jakeem Grant, and DeVante Parker.
report: ESPN's Adam Schefter reports the Dolphins will "most likely" place Albert Wilson (hip) on injured reserve.

impact: This was fully expected. The Dolphins already designated two players to return this season, so Wilson won't be back this year. The good news is he doesn't need surgery. Wilson should be 100 percent for the start of OTAs.
report: Dolphins placed WR Albert Wilson (hip) on injured reserve.

impact: The good news is Drake handled 17 touches to Frank Gore's 9.  The bad news is Gore showed a ton of burst and was highly effective in his role, averaging 6.8 yards per carry to Drake's 3.4.  Drake is a more talented back, but Gore is a coaches' pet who doesn't make mistakes.  Expect a similar split in Week 2 at the Jets.
report: Kenyan Drake rushed 14 times for 48 yards and caught 3-of-4 targets for 18 yards in Miami's Week 1 win over Tennessee.

impact: Drake's touchdown came from six yards out on a perfectly-blocked inside-zone run in the first half.  Leading by one score late in the fourth quarter, it was notable that Frank Gore operated as Miami's clock killer over Drake.  Drake out-touched Gore 15 to 10, but this remains a committee and will stay one so long as Gore maintains effectiveness.  Drake will be an RB2 in Week 3 versus Oakland.
report: Kenyan Drake rushed 11 times for 53 yards and a touchdown and caught 4-of-4 targets for 17 yards in the Dolphins' Week 2 win over the Jets.

impact: His abdomen injury appears to be extremely minor. Drake found the end zone in last week's win over the Jets, but still ceded 10 touches to veteran Frank Gore. While Gore's involvement remains a concern, Drake should still be a worthwhile RB2 this week going against a Raiders defense that just yielded 168 rushing yards to Denver.
report: Kenyan Drake (abdomen) is practicing in full for Week 3 against the Raiders.

impact: It was a nightmare fantasy day in a golden matchup, but the Dolphins ran an absurdly low 39 plays. It was just bizarre game flow. Drake did watch as Frank Gore got the "start," though he out-touched his veteran teammate 7-6. We've been expecting — hoping? — Drake to banish Gore to the bench but through three games it is not looking imminent. Drake might be best downgraded to the RB2/3 borderline until he has a breakout game or officially renders Gore a non-factor. The Patriots will present another opportunity for a strong fantasy day in Week 4.
report: Kenyan Drake rushed five times for three yards in the Dolphins' Week 3 win over the Raiders, adding two catches for seven additional yards.

impact: It was Drake's second-straight usage disaster. Like last week, the Dolphins struggled to possess the ball, running only 45 total plays. Even that number was goosed by a marathon garbage time drive. The Dolphins have now run just 84 players over their past two weeks, which is almost inconceivable. Incredibly, it was Frank Gore, not Drake, who was in as the Dolphins killed the clock with Brock Osweiler down 38-0. It's getting difficult to call Drake an RB2 with a straight face. The Bengals' struggling defense is on tap for Week 5.
report: Kenyan Drake rushed three times for three yards in the Dolphins' Week 4 loss to the Patriots, adding a 13-yard reception.

impact: This is why bad teams stay bad.  Sure, the Dolphins are 3-1, but they're not nearly as good as their record and got straight up embarrassed by the Patriots in Week 4.  Drake had three carries that day, and Gore is out-carrying Drake 35-33 on the season.  In the offseason, Gase said he wanted Drake to average 15-20 carries and 6-8 targets and the offense to run 70-75 plays per game.  The Dolphins are averaging a laughably-bad 50.0 plays per game, 31st in the league ahead of only the Cardinals.  Gase is laying blame there.  "We're just not getting enough plays,"  he said.  Perhaps Miami would "get enough plays" if the coach started featuring his best player -- Drake.
report: Coach Adam Gase said Kenyan Drake and Frank Gore will "continue splitting that stuff" in the Dolphins' backfield.

impact: Drake was the only thing working in Miami's offense. He led the Dolphins in receiving in a game Ryan Tannehill threw for 185 yards. Drake didn't do much on the ground -- he was gifted a 25-yard run against prevent defense on the final play -- but it's a solid rebound after getting only four touches last week. Drake will be an RB3/FLEX in Week 6 against Chicago.
report: Kenyan Drake rushed six times for 46 yards and caught 7-of-11 targets for 69 yards and a touchdown in Miami's Week 5 loss to the Bengals.

impact: He out-touched Frank Gore (barely) but was significantly out-gained by the veteran. Drake was near tears after losing a goal-line fumble in overtime but he redeemed himself later by gaining 22 yards on the Dolphins' game-winning drive. This marked Drake's largest workload of the season both in terms of carries and total touches. He'll look to build off Sunday's performance next week against the Lions.
