report: Kenyan Drake totaled 57 yards on 13 carries while adding four catches for 21 yards on six targets Sunday in Miami’s Week 6 win over the Bears.

impact: 62 percent of Drake's yardage came on his 54-yard touchdown in the third quarter. Drake exploded through the hole and was not touched until he shed some tackles near the goal line. Although he got out-touched 11-10 by Frank Gore, Drake out-gained his backfield mate 87-33. Everyone knows Drake is the more explosive player, but Gore isn't going anywhere. Drake will remain a risk/reward FLEX for Week 8's Thursday night tilt with the Texans.
report: Kenyan Drake rushed six times for 72 yards and a touchdown in the Dolphins' Week 7 loss to the Lions, adding four receptions for 15 additional yards.

impact: The touchdowns were Drake's second and third in the past five days. His rushing score was a 12-yarder where he found the edge with lightning quickness. He did so despite RT Ja'Wuan James running the wrong play. Drake's receiving score was a trick play 28-yarder from Danny Amendola. Drake can't stop making plays, but he has exceeded 15 touches just once since Week 2. The wheels are coming off for Adam Gase's tenure in Miami. Drake will be a risk/reward RB2 for Week 9 against the Jets.
report: Kenyan Drake rushed 12 times for 58 yards and a touchdown in the Dolphins' Week 8 loss to the Texans, adding two receptions for 37 yards and an additional score.

impact: He should be good to go for Week 1. Grant could have a bigger role on offense this season, but it is unlikely he becomes a fantasy factor.
report: Dolphins WR Jakeem Grant has cleared the concussion protocol.

impact: The Dolphins appear to be using a three-way rotation behind Kenny Stills, with Grant, Albert Wilson, and Danny Amendola vying for targets.  It's a tough situation to bank on from a fantasy football standpoint.
report: Jakeem Grant caught 5-of-7 targets for 38 yards in the Dolphins' Week 1 win over the Titans.

impact: Grant led the Dolphins in Week 1 targets with 7, then took a backseat against the Jets.  He is the No. 4 receiver behind Kenny Stills, Danny Amendola, and Albert Wilson, and DeVante Parker could be activated at any time.
report: Jakeem Grant caught 2-of-4 targets for 37 yards in the Dolphins' Week 2 win over the Jets.

impact: That's maximizing your opportunities. The highlight was a 52-yard score Grant caught from
report: Jakeem Grant caught 2-of-3 targets for 70 yards and two touchdowns in the Dolphins' Week 3 win over the Raiders.

impact: Even with DeVante Parker (quad) sidelined, gadget player Grant was invisible. He has 12 touches through four games. Grant offers rare burst and explosion, but his production will be too scattershot to predict in the Dolphins' low-volume offense.
report: Jakeem Grant caught 2-of-2 targets for 17 yards in the Dolphins' Week 4 loss to the Patriots.

impact: Grant's targets have been in steady decline the last two weeks. He managed a 71-yard punt return touchdown, but he doesn't have much of a role on offense.
report: Jakeem Grant was held without a catch in Week 5 against the Bengals.

impact: Grant got in a full practice Friday, putting him on track to play. Even if DeVante Parker (quad) doesn't return this week, Grant has been a non-factor on offense.
report: Jakeem Grant (shoulder) is questionable for Week 6 against Chicago.

impact: Grant was questionable for this game after battling a shoulder injury throughout the week. The injury didn't seem to bother him, though obviously he wasn’t a big factor in this one. Grant won’t be a fantasy option against Detroit in Week 7.
report: Jakeem Grant brought in three-of-four targets for 32 yards Sunday in the Dolphins’ Week 6 win over the Bears.

impact: Grant has just 84 yards receiving over his past four games but will likely be needed for a bigger role in Week 8. Both Albert Wilson and Kenny Stills got banged up against the Lions, and the Dolphins are headed on a short week for Thursday Night Football. Grant is a waiver wire add to keep in mind.
report: Jakeem Grant caught 2-of-2 targets for 32 yards in the Dolphins' Week 7 loss to the Lions.

impact: The eight targets were a new season high in Albert Wilson and Kenny Stills' absence, though Grant had his thunder stolen by a resurgent DeVante Parker. That was quite literally true in the third quarter when Grant let a potential long grab get knocked out of his hands for a 46-yard Parker reception on a fluke play. Grant will be a risk/reward WR4 for Week 9 against the Jets.
report: Jakeem Grant caught 4-of-8 targets for 36 yards in the Dolphins' Week 8 loss to the Texans.

impact: He scored a ten-yard touchdown early.  After a lengthy weather delay, Stills came back to burn Titans CB Malcolm Butler for a 75-yard touchdown.  Long blocked from being Miami's top receiver by Jarvis Landry, Stills has now been freed.  He should be loaded into fantasy lineups as an upside WR3 in Week 2 at the Jets.
report: Kenny Stills logged four catches for 106 yards and two touchdowns on only five targets in the Dolphins' Week 1 win over the Titans.

impact: "We know he’s a vertical threat. He showed that again, that he’s still able to do that," Gase said.  "There’s [going to be] more underneath and there’s [going to be] more as far as receptions per game go, to where maybe instead of four catches for 100 yards, it might end up being like seven or eight catches, where there might be a couple of shorter throws in there."  Tannehill added, "He knows exactly what to do.  He’s able to kind of lead that room."  Stills was third on Miami with five Week 1 targets but obviously did the most damage with a 4-106-2 line.  He'll have a shot at his first 1,000-yard season if this steady progression continues.
report: Both coach Adam Gase and Ryan Tannehill praised Kenny Stills after Week 1, saying there is "a lot of trust there."

impact: Stills teased his upside with a monster Week 1, then returned to Earth in Week 2 as the Dolphins needed only 17 completions and 168 yards to beat the Jets.  In a low-volume passing offense, Stills will remain a dicey week-to-week proposition as a WR3/flex play.  He does get a plus draw next against Oakland.
report: Kenny Stills caught 2-of-3 targets for 17 yards in the Dolphins' Week 2 win over the Jets.

impact: Stills' score — his third in three games — was a 34-yarder where he got a step on Marcus Gilchrist and Ryan Tannehill threw it where only Stills could grab it in the end zone. Stills has now cleared 60 yards in 2-of-3 games but has just 13 total targets. That is going to make it difficult to provide weekly WR3 value. Stills is a WR4 you can plug in with genuine optimism he will reach his upside.
report: Kenny Stills caught 3-of-5 targets for 61 yards and a touchdown in the Dolphins' Week 3 win over the Raiders.

impact: DeVante Parker (quad) was sidelined, but Stills still posted his second-lowest yardage total of the season. Ryan Tannehill couldn't find any open receivers. With four games in the books, Stills is on pace for 48/896/12. The yards would be the second most of Stills' career. The touchdown pace should dissipate, though Stills does have a nine-TD season to his name.
report: Kenny Stills caught 3-of-6 targets for 40 yards in the Dolphins' Week 4 loss to the Patriots.

impact: Stills was invisible in a game Ryan Tannehill threw for 185 yards. He couldn't get anything going down the field and finished behind Albert Wilson in targets. After a fast start, Stills has been held 50 yards the last two weeks. He'll be a boom/bust WR3 for a Week 6 matchup with Chicago.
report: Kenny Stills caught 2-of-5 passes for 17 yards in the Dolphins' Week 5 loss to the Bengals.

impact: Stills had a goose egg through four quarters before coming down with a miraculous 35-yard grab off a deflection during overtime. Though he was held without a catch in regulation, Stills did contribute a two-point conversion during Miami’s fourth-quarter comeback. The 26-year-old hasn’t been much help to fantasy owners this year, clearing 40 yards receiving just once in his last five games. He’ll take a three-game touchdown drought into next week’s game against Detroit.
report: Kenny Stills managed just one catch for 35 yards on two targets Sunday in the Dolphins’ Week 6 win over Chicago.

impact: Stills pulled up injured on the Dolphins' desperation final drive. Stills also got banged up on his touchdown, where he crashed into a security guard. The Dolphins have moved the field far too close to the end zone. Stills displayed fancy footwork on his score. With Albert Wilson suffering a potentially serious injury today, the Dolphins could be forced to hold onto DeVante Parker.
report: Kenny Stills caught 1-of-3 targets for a five-yard touchdown in the Dolphins' Week 7 loss to the Lions.

impact: Stills suffered the injury on the final drive. Rapoport danced around a timetable, but he did suggest Stills has little chance to play Thursday against the Texans. With Albert Wilson (hip) also out, the Dolphins are down to Danny Amendola, Jakeem Grant, and disgruntled DeVante Parker at receiver.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports Kenny Stills suffered a groin strain Week 7 against the Lions.

impact: "And we'll see after that," coach Adam Gase said on Monday.  The Dolphins' three-receiver set on Thursday Night Football will have Jakeem Grant and DeVante Parker on the outside with Danny Amendola in the slot.  Stills has drawn five targets or fewer in all seven games.  He can be dropped in 14-team leagues.
report: Kenny Stills (groin) has been ruled out for Week 8 against the Texans.

impact: Stills was quickly ruled out for Thursday night's game, but Rapoport writes Stills has "a shot" to play next week and should at worst be ready in Week 10. This update is good news, but Stills has topped 40 yards just once since Week 1 and has a total of two catches in the last two games. He is not a must-hold fantasy option.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports Kenny Stills' groin injury is not a long-term concern.

impact: He averaged 6.8 yards per carry compared to Kenyan Drake's 3.4 YPC clip.  Gore dominated one first-half drive that resulted in Kenny Stills' ten-yard TD, parlaying three carries into 38 yards on that possession alone.  Gore lacks standalone value behind Drake, but he's going to remain a thorn on Drake's fantasy side.  Gore is worthy of an RB5/6 roster spot in 12-team leagues.
report: Frank Gore rushed nine times for 61 yards in the Dolphins' Week 1 win over the Titans.

impact: He remained the second portion of Miami's RBBC, logging 10 touches to Kenyan Drake's 15.  Gore did handle heavy work in crunchtime as the Fins worked to maintain a fourth-quarter one-score lead.  Gore is a low-upside flex option, but his role is secure.  He should get 8-12 touches in Week 3 versus Oakland.
report: Frank Gore rushed nine times for 25 yards and caught his lone target for a gain of 19 in the Dolphins' Week 2 win over the Jets.

impact: Gore got the "start." That's about all he did as the Dolphins needed just 39 total plays to rip the Raiders. Most of the action came through the air. Gore has been heavily involved through the Dolphins' first three games but has done little to suggest he's going to threaten Kenyan Drake's touch superiority.
report: Frank Gore rushed six times for 12 yards in the Dolphins' Week 3 win over the Raiders.

impact: Gore started and then bizarrely closed out the game with the Dolphins trailing 38-0. That was the score when Gore found the end zone for his first touchdown of the season. The 35-year-old back is on pace for 696 yards from scrimmage as he averages 4.81 yards per carry. With Kenyan Drake clearly not impressing the coaching staff, perhaps Gore might actually force his way into bye week FLEX consideration. We would still steer clear in Week 5 against the Bengals.
report: Frank Gore rushed 11 times for 41 yards in the Dolphins' Week 4 loss to the Patriots, adding two receptions for 16 yards and a touchdown.

impact: Gore started and continued to out-carry Kenyan Drake, who got most of his work in the fourth quarter. He was effective on the ground, but fell out of the gameplan with the Dolphins trailing late. Miami has been committed to using Gore in as the front man in a committee with Drake. He should remain the slight touch favorite for Week 6 against Chicago.
report: Frank Gore rushed 12 times for 63 yards in Week 5 against the Bengals.

impact: Gore, the NFL's oldest running back, is the first player to rush for 100 yards against Chicago this year. Go figure. The veteran brought the hammer in overtime, cruising to 47 yards during the extra period. He broke off a 32-yard run in overtime, which marked his longest rushing play in almost three years. Gore looked gassed after that run and was soon replaced by Kenyan Drake, who proceeded to lose a goal-line fumble. Miami's backfield remained a near even split on Sunday with Drake out-touching Gore 17-16. Those two will continue to work in tandem next week against the Lions.
report: Frank Gore registered 101 yards on 15 carries while turning his lone target into an 18-yard catch Sunday in the Dolphins’ Week 6 victory over the Bears.

impact: Gore out-touched Kenyan Drake 11-10 but got out-gained 87-33. It was Gore's least-productive game since Week 3. Coach Adam Gase has made it clear his backfield usage is not going to change. Gore will be a low-upside RB3 for Week 8's Thursday night game against the Texans.
report: Frank Gore rushed 10 times for 29 yards in the Dolphins' Week 7 loss to the Lions, adding a four-yard reception.

impact: It was another workmanlike effort for the ageless 35-year-old veteran. Gore is helping to move the sticks for the Dolphins, but it is not translating to meaningful fantasy value. He is averaging 56 yards from scrimmage and has one total touchdown. The Dolphins need to give Kenyan Drake a longer look in the second half of the season.
report: Frank Gore rushed 12 times for 53 yards in the Dolphins' Week 8 loss to the Texans, adding a five-yard reception.

impact: The Dolphins were losing 38-0 when Tannehill was sent to the showers midway through the fourth quarter. The Dolphins' offense got hit by a bus, but Tannehill had plenty of help in the meltdown. C Daniel Kilgore broke his arm, RT Ja'Wuan James got benched and an errant Travis Swanson snap led to a disastrous turnover. Tannehill routinely had no one to throw to thanks to excellent Patriots coverage. His pick was an inexcusable arm punt down the sideline. It was a "burn the tape" effort. Despite today's capsizing, Tannehill will remain a solid QB2 for next week's matchup with the Bengals' struggling defense.
report: Ryan Tannehill completed 11-of-20 passes for 100 yards, zero touchdowns and an interception in the Dolphins' Week 4 game against the Patriots.

impact: He also lost a fumbled that was returned for a touchdown. Tannehill had one of the worst pick-sixes of the year on short-armed throw directly into the Bengals defensive line. He's predictably regressed after exploiting weak matchups to open the season, throwing for under 200 yards in consecutive games. Tannehill won't be on the QB2 radar for Week 6 against Chicago.
report: Ryan Tannehill completed 20-of-35 passes for 185 yards with a touchdown and two interceptions in Miami's Week 5 loss to the Bengals.

impact: Tannehill practiced on Wednesday and Thursday but was downgraded to limited participation on Friday. Already slated for a tough matchup against the Bears, Chicago's defense would jolt to No. 1 at their position if Brock Osweiler is forced into a starting role. Note that the Fins' top pass rusher, Cameron Wake, is doubtful to suit up for the second consecutive week.
report: Ryan Tannehill (shoulder) is questionable for Week 6 against the Bears.

impact: Tannehill, who is reportedly dealing with a sprained AC joint, is looking like a true-game time decision. The Dolphins would pivot to Brock Osweiler at quarterback if Tannehill can't get the green light. Either way, Khalil Mack and the Bears' well-rested defense (they're coming off a bye in Week 5) should be licking its chops.
report: According to ESPN's Adam Schefter, Ryan Tannehill's (questionable, shoulder) availability for Week 6 against the Bears is "up in the air."

impact: Tannehill's shoulder hasn't been right all week and now he's looking like a long shot to suit up Sunday against Chicago. Brock Osweiler is expected to step in at quarterback, which will be a downgrade for all of Miami's pass-catchers. With Tannehill's status in doubt, Chicago's defense should be a high-owned DFS commodity.
report: According to ESPN's Jeff Darlington, Ryan Tannehill (questionable, shoulder) is now looking "doubtful" for Week 6 game against the Bears.

impact: Tannehill is out with a sprained AC joint in his throwing shoulder. Consider him week-to-week. With Tannehill down for the count, Brock Osweiler will make his first Dolphins start in Week 6. LB Chase Allen (foot), DE Andre Branch (knee), WR Jakeem Grant (shoulder), S T.J. McDonald (foot), WR DeVante Parker (quad) and OT Laremy Tunsil (concussion) are all active for the Dolphins.
report: Dolphins declared QB Ryan Tannehill, RB Kalen Ballage, TE A.J. Derby, DE Charles Harris, CB Bobby McCain, LB Martrell Spaight and DE Cameron Wake inactive for Week 6 against the Bears.

impact: Osweiler was not sacked. Making his first start for the Dolphins in place of an injured Ryan Tannehill, Osweiler was his usual head-scratching self in the first half but woke up by contributing 266 yards on 16-of-25 passing after the break. Brock had his most success throwing to Albert Wilson, who erupted for a pair of second-half touchdowns including a 75-yarder to tie the game with time winding down in the fourth quarter. Osweiler is now 3-0 against the Bears for his career. He's the first Dolphins signal-caller to reach the 300-yard mark in passing yards since Jay Cutler reached that threshold in Week 9 last season. If Tannehill's shoulder is still an issue, Osweiler could see the field again next week against the Lions.
report: Brock Osweiler completed 28-of-44 passes for a career-high 380 yards with three touchdowns and two interceptions while adding eight yards on two carries Sunday in the Dolphins’ Week 6 win over the Bears.

impact: Ryan Tannehill (shoulder) has been ruled out.  Osweiler surprisingly went 28-of-44 for a career-best 380 yards and three touchdowns in the overtime win against the Bears last week.  He tossed a couple picks, but that's the nature of the beast with him.  The Lions don't present as tough of a matchup on paper as the Bears, but Osweiler is by no means a recommended fantasy play.
report: Brock Osweiler will start Week 7 against the Lions.

impact: The two-score day was Osweiler's second straight in place of Ryan Tannehill. Frankly, Osweiler has looked better than Tannehill. Both his scores were dimes delivered into the end zone. With the Dolphins playing on Thursday Night Football in Week 8, Tannehill seems unlikely to get cleared. Despite his good play — relatively speaking — Osweiler will remain a last-gasp QB2, especially since the Dolphins will likely be without Albert Wilson (hip). Wilson went down in the first half Sunday.
report: Brock Osweiler completed 22-of-31 passes for 239 yards and two touchdowns in the Dolphins' 32-21, Week 7 loss to the Lions.

impact: Gase said he will not know about Tannehill's status until he sees him throw later this week. Worryingly, the coach added Tannehill actually got worse as last week went on, which is why they decided to sit him. Gase confirmed Tannehill will be the starter once he is healthy.
report: Dolphins coach Adam Gase said Ryan Tannehill (shoulder) is "day to day."

impact: Every other quarterback is throwing, and Brock Osweiler was the quarterback the Dolphins made available to the media.  We'd bet Osweiler starts this week, especially after he guided a win and Tannehill still being terrible.
report: Ryan Tannehill (shoulder) is present at Wednesday's practice but isn't throwing.

impact: Brock Osweiler will make another start after throwing for 380 yards and three touchdowns in an upset win over the Bears.  Osweiler may be just as good as Tannehill, which isn't saying much because the bar isn't high.
report: Ryan Tannehill (shoulder) is out for Week 7 against the Lions.

impact: Tannehill was a surprise inactive Sunday after practicing all week and being listed questionable. He's dealing with at least a two-game absence, suggesting Miami knew he wasn't playing. The Dolphins expect Tannehill back this season, but there's no timetable for his return.  Brock Osweiler will start against Detroit in Week 7.
report: ESPN's Cameron Wolfe reports the league has opened an investigation into how the Dolphins handled Ryan Tannehill's shoulder injury.

impact: Ryan Tannehill remains week to week with a shoulder injury.  Osweiler has held his own through two weeks and was not the reason for the Dolphins' Week 7 loss.  He'll get his shot at a "revenge" game Thursday night against the Texans.
report: Coach Adam Gase confirmed Monday that Brock Osweiler will start in Week 8 against Houston.

impact: Osweiler stepped into a few nice throws but was otherwise awful. Osweiler's pick was a high pass on the first play of the second quarter where the Texans arguably got away with a penalty, but he was extremely lucky to escape with only one turnover. The Texans flat dropped another pick a few minutes later and Osweiler tried to commit one of the worst fumbles you will ever see with time running out before the break. Cutting a throw off in the face of pressure, Osweiler brought the ball back into his body and had it knocked out for a 55-yard fumble six. Thankfully for him, replay revealed just enough of a "pass" attempt. If Ryan Tannehill cannot return for Week 9, Osweiler will be a last-gasp QB2 despite an attackable matchup in the Jets.
report: Brock Osweiler completed 21-of-37 passes for 241 yards, zero touchdowns and an interception in the Dolphins' 42-23, Week 8 loss to the Texans.

impact: Ruled out for this week early, it always seemed unlikely he would be ready for a Thursday night matchup with the Texans in Week 8. Brock Osweiler will start at least the next two games.
report: ESPN's Cameron Wolfe reports Ryan Tannehill (shoulder) faces an "uphill challenge" to return Week 8.

impact: He's sitting again this week and reportedly faces an "uphill challenge" to play in Week 8. Tannehill's shoulder injury is obviously more serious than initially thought, though the Dolphins are confident he won't require surgery. Brock Osweiler will continue to fill in at quarterback for Miami.
report: Dolphins coach Adam Gase said the team is not looking at "surgical options" for Ryan Tannehill (shoulder).

impact: Tannehill is out at least the next two weeks with his shoulder injury. He'll be back this year, but his status beyond 2018 is far from a lock. Tannehill is a rarely healthy bottom-tier starter that's going to have to take a pay cut from the $26 million he's owed next year to stay in Miami. The Dolphins can save $13.2 million if they move on from Tannehill this offseason.
report: The Miami Herald reports "there is doubt" over Ryan Tannehill's future with the Dolphins.

impact: Tannehill didn't throw in practice at all last week. He's not going to be ready in four days with Miami playing on Thursday night, leaving Brock Osweiler to make another start. The Dolphins don't have a timetable on when they expect Tannehill back, but he's expected to return this season.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports "it's hard to see" Ryan Tannehill (shoulder) returning in Week 8.

impact: Brock Osweiler will make his third straight start.  Tannehill was droppable weeks ago in 14-team leagues.  He remains without a known timetable to return.
report: Ryan Tannehill (shoulder) has been ruled out for Week 8.

impact: This is a coaches decision. UDFA Cam Phillips will pick up McCloud's snaps.
report: Bills WR Ray-Ray McCloud won't play in Week 7 against the Colts.

impact: He had just two targets. There's not a ton of conclusion to draw in a game Buffalo managed just 100 yards of offense. Even with Josh Allen likely to start, Clay should be avoided for a Week 2 matchup with the Chargers.
report: Charles Clay was held without a catch in Buffalo's season opener.

impact: It's an improvement after Clay was held without a catch in the season opener. Clay was more involved with Josh Allen starting, but he's not on the TE2 radar.
report: Charles Clay caught 2-of-3 passes for 29 yards in Week 2 against the Chargers.

impact: Clay is averaging merely 2.6 targets through three games for the Bills. He was valuable last season if only for his high floor and consistent targets from Tyrod Taylor. With Josh Allen's tendency to spread the ball around, Clay can't be depended on. He should be dropped immediately.
report: Charles Clay caught 2-of-3 passes for 18 yards in the Bills' Week 3 win over the Vikings.

impact: The limited practice suggests the injuries aren't a concern. Clay has been an afterthought in Buffalo's offense through three weeks. He's not a Week 4 streamer.
report: Charles Clay (shoulder, hip) was limited at Wednesday's practice.

impact: "He's still working through what he has," coach Sean McDermott said. "We're just taking it day by day and we're going to continue to do that." Clay is usually bothered by his knee. If Clay manages to play, he has yet to show enough to be a TE2.
report: Charles Clay (shoulder, hip) was downgraded to "DNP" on Thursday.

impact: He'll be limited, but coach Sean McDermott sounds like Clay is playing, admitting Thursday's DNP was more of a rest day.  Clay is a no-upside TE2.
report: Charles Clay (questionable, shoulder) returned to practice Friday.

impact: That doubled Clay's season production, which is all you need to know about his fantasy value.
report: Charles Clay caught 4-of-6 targets for 40 yards in the Bills' Week 4 loss to the Packers.

impact: The Bills did this last week, though Clay was listed with his shoulder and hip. We would guess it's just rep management. Although the Bills are as target starved as any team in the league, Clay has featured close to zero fantasy value this season.
report: Charles Clay (ankle) was downgraded to "DNP" on Thursday.

impact: Clay was limited to start the week, downgraded to DNP at Thursday's practice, then got in a full session on Friday. Regardless, it looks like he'll be out there Sunday against Tennessee. Clay hasn't done anything to warrant fantasy attention this year, though with the tight end position ravaged by injuries, almost any healthy player is worth streaming consideration.
report: Charles Clay (ankle) is questionable for Week 5 against the Titans.

impact: Battling injuries and his quarterback's ineffectiveness, Clay has been a total fantasy non-factor and will likely remain such in Week 6 at Houston.
report: Charles Clay caught his lone target for a 12-yard gain in Week 5.

impact: Clay came out of the gates "hot," catching all four of his passes in the first half. That was it for the low-upside tight end, who will remain just that next week against the Colts.
report: Charles Clay hauled in 4-of-5 targets for 20 yards in the Bills' Week 6 loss to the Texans.

impact: He also lost a fumble. Clay never had a chance in this one with Derek Anderson at QB. Even at a laughably thin fantasy position, Clay has made little noise this year, eclipsing 30 yards receiving in just one of seven games. He hasn't scored a touchdown since Week 3 of 2017. Needless to say, Clay belongs nowhere near a fantasy lineup right now.
report: Charles Clay corralled three-of-five targets for 14 yards Sunday in the Bills’ Week 7 loss to Indianapolis.

impact: He led Buffalo in receiving in a game they only managed 107 yards. Jones saw more targets than Jeremy Kerley, but he remains off the fantasy radar.
report: Zay Jones caught 3-of-6 passes for 36 yards in Buffalo's Week 1 game against Baltimore.

impact: It's the second straight week Jones has led Buffalo in receiving. Jones got most of his yards on a 57-yard bomb from Josh Allen, but his role is trending up. Jones is worth an end-of-roster stash in dynasty leagues.
report: Zay Jones caught 2-of-3 passes for 63 yards in Buffalo's Week 2 loss to the Chargers.

impact: The 38 yards were Jones' second most of the season. The sophomore is on pace for 40/576/0. With Kelvin Benjamin fading toward oblivion, Jones could take on a bigger role the final 12 games of the season.
report: Zay Jones caught 4-of-7 targets for 38 yards in the Bills' Week 4 loss to the Packers.

impact: Jones had Buffalo's biggest play of the game when he got open in the back of the end zone for a touchdown which gave the Bills the lead, but that was about it for the second-round sophomore. This game aside, Jones has been more efficient this season, but there is no fantasy value to find in this passing game.
report: Zay Jones hauled in 3-of-8 targets for 35 yards and a touchdown in the Bills' Week 6 loss to the Texans.

impact: It was another quiet week for Jones and the Bills' destitute offense. The 2017 second-rounder has cleared 40 yards receiving in just one of his seven outings this year. Even with a favorable matchup next week against a soft Patriots secondary, the 23-year-old won't be a fantasy consideration.
report: Zay Jones snagged three catches for 27 yards on four targets Sunday in Buffalo’s Week 7 loss to the Colts.

impact: Game flow worked perfectly for Ivory, who was able to rumble his way to 20 carries while the Bills milked a 27-0 first half lead. The three catches (and 70 receiving yards) were unexpected, but it was just another thing that happened to go right in a day chalked with them for Buffalo on Sunday. At worst, Ivory set himself apart from third-down RB Marcus Murphy (8-33) and made his case as a potential FLEX option if LeSean McCoy (ribs) misses an extended period. Ivory remains volume-driven, though.
report: Chris Ivory rushed 20 times for 56 yards and hauled in 3-of-4 targets for 70 yards in the Bills’ Week 3 win over the Vikings.

impact: It was a rough game for Benjamin, who dropped a touchdown in the end-zone. Benjamin was held back by Nathan Peterman in the first half, but saw more looks after Josh Allen took over. Benjamin has one of the worst quarterback situations in the league, but his target share keeps him in the WR3 discussion.
report: Kelvin Benjamin caught 1-of-7 targets for 10 yards in Week 1 against Baltimore.

impact: Benjamin's touchdown came deep into garbage time. He didn't make his first catch until deep in the third quarter and continued to be the victim of bad quarterback play. Benjamin should have better weeks as Josh Allen acclimates, but he can't be trusted in fantasy lineups.
report: Kelvin Benjamin caught two passes for 19 yards and a touchdown in Week 2 against the Chargers.

impact: It's a new ailment for the often-dinged-up wideout, but it isn't one that should affect Benjamin's Week 3 availability against the Vikings.  He's a WR4.
report: Kelvin Benjamin (hip) was limited in Wednesday's practice.

impact: With LeSean McCoy (ribs) back, Ivory retreated to a supporting role, though he actually out-carried McCoy 6-5. McCoy out-touched him 8-6. Occasionally, both backs were on the field at the same time. Ivory has zero standalone fantasy value.
report: Chris Ivory rushed six times for 15 yards in the Bills' Week 4 loss to the Packers.

impact: Virtually every Ivory touch is a wasted one, but he's a favorite of the coaching staff for whatever reason.  His longest run of the season is nine yards.  Ivory is LeSean McCoy's handcuff but nothing more.
report: Chris Ivory rushed 14 times for 43 yards in the Bills' Week 5 win over the Titans.

impact: With LeSean McCoy back and dominating work, Ivory took a backseat in this one. He has some stash value in deeper leagues in case the Bills trade LeSean McCoy, but that is looking unlikely at this point.
report: Chris Ivory rushed six times for five yards and caught his only target for four yards in the Bills' Week 6 loss to the Texans.

impact: He came on in relief of LeSean McCoy, who left with a head injury early in the first quarter. Ivory handled most of the Bills' backfield responsibilities after that, though he did leave briefly during the third quarter after Colts cornerback Pierre Desir came down awkwardly on his left foot. The nine-year vet broke off a couple big runs for Buffalo including a 21-yard burst in the second quarter, though he never came close to finding the end zone. Ivory would lead the backfield again if McCoy can’t go next week when the Bills host New England on Monday Night Football. That makes him a worthy roster add in all formats.
report: Chris Ivory delivered 81 yards on 16 carries while adding three catches for 25 yards on six targets Sunday in Buffalo’s Week 7 loss to the Colts.

impact: Ivory had a productive game with LeSean McCoy concussed in Week 7, though Shady practiced on Thursday and is trending toward playing Monday night against New England. In the off-chance that McCoy can't clear the protocol, Ivory would make for an acceptable, albeit volume-based RB2 in Week 8.
report: Chris Ivory (hamstring) was limited at Thursday's practice.

impact: Benjamin saw limited reps Wednesday due to a hip injury, though obviously the injury was nothing serious. He should see his usual workload on Sunday, though he'll be greeted by one of the league's better secondaries when the Bills travel to Minnesota.
report: Kelvin Benjamin (hip) was upgraded to full practice on Thursday.

impact: Josh Allen did most of his damage scrambling for his life outside of the pocket, and thus Benjamin wasn't looked to downfield much. He still leads the Bills' skill players in target share, but hasn't caught more than three passes or eclipsed the 30-yard mark in any game this season. He's droppable in all formats.
report: Kelvin Benjamin caught 3-of-5 targets for 29 yards in the Bills' Week 3 win over the Vikings.

impact: As inefficient as you've come to expect. Benjamin was also checked for a concussion but thankfully cleared the protocol. On pace for just 368 yards in the Bills' dysfunctional offense, Benjamin is miles from fantasy relevance.
report: Kelvin Benjamin caught 1-of-6 targets for 34 yards in the Bills' Week 4 loss to the Packers.

impact: Josh Allen hasn't helped him, but Benjamin has been atrocious this year.  He has shown no ability to separate from defensive backs or so much as win contested catches. Benjamin has finished below 40 yards in each of the Bills' first five games and is averaging under four yards per target.  Benjamin will not be a fantasy option in Week 6 at Houston.
report: Kelvin Benjamin caught 1-of-5 targets for 11 yards in the Bills' Week 5 win over the Titans.

impact: Benjamin was predictably quiet for most of this game, but he showed up with a couple big plays in the third quarter. The first was negated by an illegal formation penalty, but he came back on the next drive with a 39-yard catch. That catch went for more yards than he did in any of the first five games this season. He regressed right back to expectations after that, dropping a pass a couple plays later. He will not be an option next week against the Colts.
report: Kelvin Benjamin hauled in 2-of-6 targets for 43 yards in the Bills' Week 6 loss to the Texans.

impact: Ivory tweaked his hamstring at Thursday's practice, though it shouldn't keep him from playing Monday night against New England. He could be in the RB2/flex conversation, depending on the health of LeSean McCoy, who remains in the league's concussion protocol.
report: Chris Ivory (hamstring) remained limited at Friday's practice.

impact: Ivory's hamstring injury was worth monitoring since it cropped up mid-week, but he seems on track to play. LeSean McCoy (concussion), on the other hand, has yet to clear the league's protocol. We expect McCoy plays given the additional 24 hours he has to be cleared, but his status need be monitored up to the minute. Ivory's floor as an every-down back would be increased without McCoy in an otherwise terrible matchup.
report: Chris Ivory (hamstring) is expected to play in Week 8 against the Patriots.

impact: The Cowboys have also checked in on DeVante Parker and continue to do their "due diligence" on Amari Cooper. Dallas is in desperate need of receiving weapons and it's likely the Cowboys address that issue by adding a pass-catcher at the trade deadline. Hopefully the Cowboys can do a bit better than Benjamin, who has been a non-factor in Buffalo this year. Meanwhile Parker can't even get on the field in Miami.
report: According to ESPN's Dan Graziano, the Cowboys are "monitoring" Kelvin Benjamin ahead of next week's trade deadline.

impact: The 71 yards represented a new season-high for Benjamin, who made the most of his limited workload. He was the only receiver who showed anything resembling chemistry with Derek Anderson, who was making his first start in nearly two years. Despite a decent showing Sunday, it's still been a brutal year for the former first-round pick, who has converted just 37.8 percent of his targets this season. He'll take a five-game scoreless drought into next week's matchup against the Patriots.
report: Kelvin Benjamin secured four of his five targets for 71 yards Sunday in the Bills’ Week 7 loss to Indianapolis.

impact: Peterman was a disaster in his third career start, leading the Bills to no scoring drives and zero first downs in the first half. He threw for just 24 yards before getting pulled. Peterman looked completely lost, throwing both of his interceptions directly to the Ravens and taking three sacks. Josh Allen replaced Peterman in the third quarter and should remain the starter going forward.
report: Nathan Peterman was benched in the third quarter of Sunday's Week 1 game against Baltimore.

impact: Things started well for Peterman. Following a Texans fumble, Peterman led a touchdown drive he capped with a nice throw to Zay Jones in the back corner of the end zone to give the Bills the lead. It went downhill from there, however. After the Texans tied the game with under two minutes left, Peterman threw a horrific pick-six which gave Houston the lead. He followed that up with another bad interception on the next drive to end the game. If Allen is forced to miss time, Buffalo probably would be suited going with newly-signed Derek Anderson next week against the Colts.
report: Playing in relief of Josh Allen, Nathan Peterman completed 6-of-12 passes for 61 yards, one touchdown, and two interceptions in the Bills' Week 6 loss to the Texans.

impact: Allen replaced a faceplanting Nathan Peterman in the third quarter. It wasn't much of a debut, but he moved the offense better than Peterman. Allen should've had a touchdown that was dropped by Kelvin Benjamin in the end-zone. The Bills are likely to continue to go with Allen as their starter going forward. He'll get a tough test in the Chargers in Week 2.
report: Josh Allen completed 6-of-15 passes for 74 yards in Buffalo's Week 1 game against Baltimore.

impact: McDermott said he's still "going through it" at quarterback and will "continue to evaluate" where the team is. No. 7 overall pick Josh Allen replaced Nathan Peterman in the third quarter Sunday and instilled at least some life into the Bills' horrendous offense, having a would-be touchdown pass dropped by Kelvin Benjamin in the end zone. Buffalo is expected to move forward with Allen against a Chargers defense likely missing Joey Bosa.
report: Bills coach Sean McDermott has not named a starting quarterback for Week 2.

impact: Coach Sean McDermott really didn't have a choice.  Nathan Peterman has been an unmitigated disaster in two starts, throwing five interceptions in one half against the Chargers last year before completely face-planting Week 1 against the Ravens.  Peterman was seeing ghosts before he was yanked in the third quarter.  Allen led a field goal drive versus Baltimore while completing 6-of-15 passes for 74 yards.  The Chargers are on the D/ST streaming radar for Sunday.
report: First-round pick Josh Allen has been named the Bills' Week 2 starter against the Chargers.

impact: Allen moved the offense better than Nathan Peterman, but there were some rough stretches in his first start. He didn't get much help from an offense that allowed five sacks, but Allen held on to the ball too long at times and made some reckless throws, resulting in the two picks. Allen showed off his arm on a 57-yard bomb to Zay Jones, and his garbage-time touchdown to Kelvin Benjamin was threaded in a tight window. The Bills are committed to Allen as their starter for the rest of the year. He'll get another tough matchup with the Vikings in Week 3.
report: Josh Allen completed 18-of-33 passes for 245 yards with a touchdown and two interceptions in Sunday's Week 2 loss to the Chargers.

impact: Despite dealing with constant pressure throughout the afternoon, Allen made play after play with both his arm and legs in Buffalo's dominating win over Minnesota. The Bills' trenches did little to help Allen, but the No. 7 overall pick's ability to scramble and throw on the run allowed him to extend plays outside of the pocket and consistently find open receivers in the flats. Allen has quietly become Buffalo's red zone back, scoring two touchdowns inside the 10-yard line on Sunday. Allen and the Bills travel to Lambeau Field to face the Packers in Week 4.
report: Josh Allen completed 15-of-22 passes for 196 yards and one touchdown, adding 10 carries for 39 yards and two touchdowns on the ground in the Bills' Week 3 victory over the Vikings.

impact: Everything the Bills were in Week 3 against the Vikings, that's what they weren't today. Allen entered halftime just 5-of-19 for 58 yards and a pick. He was scarcely better after the break, where he specialized in taking thundering sacks as he spun backwards. His picks were amateur hour decisions. This kind of wild inconsistency is going to be Allen's hallmark as he gets his NFL sea legs amidst scarily-little surrounding talent in Buffalo. He will not be a recommended streamer against the Titans' upstart defense in Week 5.
report: Josh Allen completed 16-of-33 passes for 151 yards, zero touchdowns and two interceptions in the Bills' 22-0, Week 4 loss to the Packers, also losing a fumble and taking seven sacks.

impact: Buffalo pulled this upset without any hint of a passing game, instead relying on Allen's 14-yard rushing touchdown on their opening drive and two Steven Hauschka field goals, including the 46-yard game winner as time expired.  The Bills are now a surprising 2-3 after upset victories over Tennessee and Minnesota.  Allen will remain a high-variance QB2 when Buffalo visits Houston next.
report: Josh Allen completed 10-of-19 passes for 82 yards and an interception in the Bills' Week 5 win over the Titans, 13-12.

impact: Allen took a big hit to his elbow when was sandwiched between two defenders as he delivered a deep pass to Kelvin Benjamin in the third quarter. He stayed in for another play, but he grabbed his throwing arm after that throw and headed to the sideline. He is officially questionable to return, but he has a big wrap on his elbow which suggests his day is over. Nathan Peterman has taken over.
report: Josh Allen exited Week 6 against the Texans with a right elbow injury.

impact: The alternatives are Nathan "Pick" Peterman and Derek Anderson.  Allen's elbow injury doesn't seem serious, but it's to his throwing arm and kept him out of the end of Sunday's loss to Houston.  Allen was struggling mightily even before going down.  We'd be surprised to see him out there against Indianapolis.
report: Bills coach Sean McDermott was noncomittal Monday when asked if Josh Allen (elbow) will start in Week 7 against the Colts.

impact: Russini adds, "There is concern he will miss weeks." Russini also reports the Bills have yet to decide who will start in place of Allen, but "there is a feeling" coach Sean McDermott "is in danger of losing the locker room" if Nathan Peterman gets another start. Derek Anderson, who was just signed last week, is the only other option on the roster.
report: ESPN's Dianna Russini reports Josh Allen (elbow) will not start Week 7 against the Colts.

impact: A second opinion on his elbow from Dr. James Andrews confirmed that Allen has UCL damage to his throwing arm, but he will not need Tommy John surgery. Instead Allen will rest and rehab with the hope that he can return in about one month. With Allen out, the Bills can either start Nathan Peterman or Derek Anderson, who they signed just last week. Streaming defenses against this Bills offense is an attractive strategy.
report: Josh Allen (elbow) will miss at least the next two or three games and will be week to week after that.

impact: Allen is out with a UCL injury in his right (throwing) elbow. He's facing at least a 2-3 week absence. With Allen shelved, veteran Derek Anderson will draw the start Sunday at Indianapolis. It will be his first start since 2016. OG Vladimir Ducasse (knee) and DE Trent Murphy (ankle) are both active for Buffalo.
report: Bills declared QB Josh Allen, OG Ike Boettger, RB Taiwan Jones, CB Ryan Lewis, WR Ray-Ray McCloud, OT Conor McDermott and OG Wyatt Teller inactive for Week 7 against the Colts.

impact: Like last week, he was wearing a non-contact jersey during the portion of practice open to the media. He was officially limited. That suggests he is not a lock to play this weekend, but McCoy has said he plans to be out there against the Packers. He will be a FLEX consideration if he is active.
report: LeSean McCoy (ribs) is practicing Thursday.

impact: McCoy got in a limited week of practice. That was also the case last week when he sat out at Minnesota, but Shady has been adamant he'll be out there this week. McCoy has largely been a non-factor this year but still warrants back-end RB2/flex consideration in most fantasy leagues.
report: LeSean McCoy (ribs) is questionable for Week 4 against the Packers.

impact: McCoy was limited in practice throughout the week but remained insistent he would play. Although all signs point to him suiting up, his floor is no longer what it used to be, especially on the road in this matchup against the Packers that could lead to a negative game script for the Bills' rushing attack. Josh Allen is the only skill player worth starting for Buffalo, and even that's a stretch at Lambeau Field. It's best to avoid this offense altogether in Week 4.
report: LeSean McCoy (ribs) is expected to play in Week 4 against the Packers.

impact: McCoy will be a boom/bust RB2/3 against the Pack. Change-of-pace backup Marcus Murphy is sidelined, meaning Chris Ivory should see plenty of run behind McCoy. Also inactive for the Bills are CB Phillip Gaines, TE Logan Thomas, DT Robert Thomas, OL Wyatt Teller, OL Jeremiah Sirles and OL Ike Boettger.
report: LeSean McCoy (ribs) is active for Week 4 against the Packers.

impact: McCoy has now been held below 10 touches in 2-of-3 games and has handled the ball only 29 times all season. Speaking afterward, McCoy said "the plan was to get me the ball," and that he had no explanation for his light usage. The scoreboard was a major problem — the Bills were trailing all afternoon — but McCoy is more than capable of catching the ball, and change-of-pace Marcus Murphy was inactive. The Bills' Josh Allen-led offense is proving catastrophic for McCoy's fantasy value. He will be a high-risk FLEX option in Week 5 against the Titans' upstart defense.
report: LeSean McCoy rushed five times for 24 yards in the Bills' Week 4 loss to the Packers, adding three receptions for 13 additional yards.

impact: And it felt like a career game for McCoy after how poorly he started the season.  McCoy's 26 touches and 108 total yards were both easily year highs on a Bills offense that has struggled to function week to week.  Nevertheless, McCoy showed juice on several chunk-yardage gains and clearly has plenty left in his tank.  He will remain a risky RB2/flex option in Week 6 at Houston.
report: LeSean McCoy rushed 24 times for 85 yards and caught 2-of-3 targets for 23 yards in the Bills' Week 5 win over the Titans.

impact: This move would make a lot of sense. In the middle of a rebuild, the Bills do not need to pay a 30-year-old running back for the next two seasons, but it makes a lot of sense for an Eagles squad which is in the middle of their championship window and just lost Jay Ajayi to a torn ACL. McCoy did not leave Philly on the best terms way back in 2015, but Chip Kelly is long gone. Although it could take him some time to settle in, McCoy's fantasy value would get a big boost if he is traded to the Eagles...or really anywhere else.
report: WIVB Buffalo's Josh Reed reports the Eagles have "reached out" to the Bills about acquiring LeSean McCoy.

impact: "We’re just looking forward to the Houston Texans," McDermott said.  "We get calls all the time.  Incoming calls happen all the time.  [GM] Brandon [Beane] and I talk a lot.  I won’t get into any more detail than that.  LeSean is a valuable member of our football team and we'll leave it at that."  McDermott downplays the swirling rumors that popped up Tuesday, but did not shoot them down completely.  We'd bet the Bills would love to get a mid-rounder back.
report: Speaking Wednesday, coach Sean McDermott didn't totally dismiss the possibility of trading LeSean McCoy.

impact: The running-back-needy Eagles placed a call to Buffalo this week but those talks didn't get very far. McCoy has history with Philadelphia—it's where he started his career—but he's well-liked in the Bills' locker room and Buffalo values his veteran leadership. Per Rapoport, it would likely take a second-rounder and more to pry McCoy away from Western New York, which the Eagles rightly feel is an exorbitant asking price. The 10-year vet is under contract through 2019.
report: NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reports the Bills are unlikely to trade LeSean McCoy.

impact: Aside from Josh Allen scrambles and a random Nathan Peterman touchdown, McCoy was the Bills' offense in this one. He started his day with a 22-yard catch on an ill-advised throw from Allen, and he consistently made things happen in the running game. Unfortunately, it was not enough for the Bills to score more than 13 points. Volume will hopefully keep McCoy in the FLEX range all season, but touchdowns will be difficult to find, assuming he is not traded.
report: LeSean McCoy rushed 16 times for 73 yards and hauled in 3-of-5 targets for 21 yards in the Bills' Week 6 loss to the Texans.

impact: It's surprising that the Bills are checking him for a concussion as McCoy appeared to injure his right leg/ankle after being tackled out of bounds by Kenny Moore on Buffalo's opening drive. McCoy went to the locker room, where he'll presumably go through concussion testing. Chris Ivory will fill in at running back for Buffalo.
report: LeSean McCoy left Sunday's Week 7 game against the Colts and is being evaluated for a head injury.

impact: McCoy injured his head early in the first quarter after taking a hit from Colts CB Kenny Moore. It looked like he may have also injured his right leg/ankle on the play. He'll finish his day with just one yard on two carries. With Shady ruled out, ball-carrier responsibilities will now fall with Chris Ivory.
report: LeSean McCoy (head) will not return to Sunday's Week 7 game against the Colts.

impact: While he remains in the protocol, a practice this early in the week great sign for McCoy's availability on Monday night. Barring any setbacks, he should be cleared ahead of Monday night's game against the Patriots.
report: Bills coach Sean McDermott said LeSean McCoy will practice Thursday but remains in the concussion protocol.

impact: McCoy got in a second straight practice Friday but has yet to clear the league's concussion protocol. He's still on track to play (and get cleared) assuming another limited session on Saturday. Although he'll likely be thrown into a negative game script against the Patriots, McCoy's floor would be safer (making him a more confident option) if Chris Ivory (limited, hamstring) were unexpectedly ruled out. Stay tuned.
report: LeSean McCoy (concussion) has yet to clear the league's protocol.

impact: When asked about McCoy's status for Monday, coach Sean McDermott responded "we'll see" and "we'll just take it one day at a time right now." Players are ordinarily cleared on Saturday to play Sunday, so McCoy is at least allotted  the extra 24 hours before a decision has to be made. He's a true question mark at this time. Chris Ivory (hamstring) is on track to play.
report: LeSean McCoy (concussion) remains in the league's concussion protocol.
